Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer
פרקי דרבי אליעזר
Pirke de Rabbi Eliezer, trans. and annotated by Rabbi Gerald Friedlander, London, 1916
https://www.nli.org.il/he/books/NNL_ALEPH001020236

Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer



Chapter 1

CHAPTER I<br>THE CHAPTERS OF RABBI ELIEZER THE GREAT<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Also called “Baraitha of Rabbi Eliezer”; see <i>supra,</i> Introduction, and cf. Zunz, <i>G.V.,</i> p. 283, Weiss, <i>Dor Dor veDorshav,</i> iii. p. 290, and Hamburger, <i>Real-Ency.</i> s. 11. i. pp. 162 ff., on the <i>P.R.E.</i> The first two chapters are probably a later addition to the Midrash contained in the rest of the “Chapters.” They form a very good introduction to this pseudepigraphic book, which was attributed to the famous teacher, Rabbi Eliezer the Great. The third chapter opens with the name of Rabbi Eliezer. The MS. fragment of our book in the British Museum which Horowitz has edited in his <i>Sammlung Kleiner Midraschim,</i> i. 4 ff., begins with the third chapter. The same fact obtains in some of the fragments contained in the Bodleian Library. For the biography of Rabbi Eliezer ben Hyrḳanos see Bacher, T. i. pp. 96 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> v. 113 ff., where a bibliography is added. Our “Chapters” contain about twenty dicta attributed to R. Eliezer; see Bacher, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 122 f., who considers all these sayings as pseudepigraphic. The subject-matter of the first two chapters of our book is to be found in Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) 6 (<i>b</i>) xiii., Jalḳuṭ, Gen. §72, and Gen. Rab. 42 (in the new edition of Theodor, ch. xli., where further parallels are given in the notes on p. 397). Various recensions of the first two chapters have been published by Horowitz, <i>Beth ‘Eḳed Ha-Hagadoth,</i> pp. 7 ff.</i><br><small>RABBI ELIEZER AND THE TORAH</small><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The headings to the chapters have been added by the translator. The numbers in the square brackets after the headings indicate the pages and columns of the MS.</i> [1<small>B</small>. i.]<br>T<small>HE</small> following befell Rabbi Eliezer, son of Hyrḳanos. His father had many ploughmen<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Gen. Rab. 42:1 and Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> read: “his brethren were ploughing in the plain, whereas he was ploughing on the mountain.” The 1st and 2nd eds. omit the word “many.”</i> who were ploughing arable ground,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “were ploughing upon the surface of the <i>furrow</i>.” Cf. Ps. 129:3 for the word “furrows,”</i> whereas he was ploughing a stony plot; he sat down and wept. His father said to him: O my son! Why dost thou weep? Art thou perchance distressed because thou dost plough a stony plot? In the past thou hast ploughed a stony plot,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> These words are omitted in the 1st and 2nd eds.</i> now behold thou shalt plough with us arable soil.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This would be easier labour. At this point the MS. adds the second letter of the Hebrew alphabet to signify the beginning of the second paragraph. The 1st and 2nd eds. omit “with us.”</i> He sat down on the arable ground and wept. His father said to him: But why dost thou weep? Art thou perchance distressed because thou art ploughing the arable land? He replied to him: No. (Hyrḳanos) said to him: Why dost thou weep? He answered him: I weep only because I desire to learn Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Torah is not merely the written word of God, but also its oral interpretation. The term sums up all that is implied by Religion and Ethics.</i> (Hyrḳanos) said to him: Verily thou art twenty-eight years old<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) 6reads “22 years,” and cf. <i>ibid.</i> (<i>b</i>) xiii.</i>—yet dost thou desire to learn Torah? Nay, go, take thee a wife and beget sons and thou wilt take them to the school.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Thy merit will be accounted as though thou didst study the Torah; see T.B. Ḳiddushin, 30a, for this doctrine. The second paragraph in MS. ends here.</i> He fasted two weeks<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “He was distressed for three weeks” is the reading in Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) xiii. On “weeks” see Krauss, <i>T.A.</i> ii. pp. 422 f.; and note 784.</i> not tasting || anything, until Elijah<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> On Elijah in Rabbinical literature see <i>J.E.</i> v. 122 ff. In our work the Elijah story and legends are treated at considerable length. In Christian books Elijah also appears; see Mark ix. 4 ff. and Matt. xvii. 11. In the Gospel of Barnabas (124a) Elijah rebukes a man for weeping. See also Coptic Apocrypha, ed. Budge, p. 265, for a further parallel. Elijah is the “comforter” in Jewish and Christian literature, and in this capacity he is the forerunner of the Messiah.</i>— may he be remembered for good<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On this expression see Zunz, <i>Zur Gesch.</i> pp. 321 ff.</i>—appeared to him and said to him: Son of Hyrḳanos! Why dost thou weep? He replied to him: Because I desire to learn Torah. (Elijah) said to him: If thou desirest to learn Torah get thee up to Jerusalem to Rabban Jochanan ben Ẓakkai.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The greatest teacher of his day, who preserved Judaism in spite of the overthrow of the Jewish State by the Romans, in the year 70 <small>C.E.</small> For his biography see Bacher, T. i. pp. 22 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> vii. 214 ff. Graetz, <i>Geschichte der Juden,</i> iv. pp. 11 ff., Schürer, ii. 366 ff., and Schlatter’s biography should be consulted.</i> He arose and went up to Jerusalem to R. Jochanan ben Ẓakkai and sat down and wept. (R. Jochanan) said to him: Why dost thou weep? He answered him: Because I wish to learn Torah. (R. Jochanan) said to him: Whose son art thou? But he did not tell him.
(R. Jochanan) asked him: Hast thou never learnt<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) xiii. reads: “Didst thou never go to school?”</i> to read the Shema',<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The “Shema’” is the Jewish confession of faith. It is set forth in Deut. 6:4–9, etc.; see Singer, pp. 40 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> xi. 266.</i> or the Tephillah,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The “Tephillah” or “Shemoneh ‘ Esreh,” the Jewish prayer <i>par excellence,</i> is to be found in Singer, pp. 44 ff.; see <i>R.É.J.</i> xix. pp. 17 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> xi. 270 ff. Our “Chapters” deal with the subject-matter of the “Shemoneh ‘Esreh”; cf. Zunz, <i>G. V.,</i> p. 285, and S. Sachs in “Ha-Techiyah,” pp. 21 f. On the question as to the relation between Sirach and the “Shemoneh ‘Esreh” see Oesterley’s edition of <i>Ecclesiasticus,</i> pp. 232 and 349 f.</i> or the Grace after meals?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Geniẓah Fragment has: “the reading of the Grace after meals.” On Grace after meals see Singer, pp. 280 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> vi. 61 f.</i> He replied to him: No. He arose<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The student stood whilst learning; see T.B. Megillah, 21a. The 1st and 2nd eds. read: “He said, Stand, and I will teach thee the three (prayers).”</i> and (R. Jochanan) taught him the three (prayers).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the fourth paragraph begins here.</i> (Again) he sat down and wept. (R. Jochanan) said to him: My son, why dost thou weep? He replied: Because I desire to learn Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> And not merely prayers.</i> He (thereupon) taught him two rules (of the Law)<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> “Halakhoth,” <i>i.e.</i> laws to be observed by the Jews, based upon the Torah. Thus, according to Matt. xii. 1–8, Jesus discusses Halakhah. The final decisions become Halakhoth; cf. Mark vii. 5 and Luke xi. 40 f. See Bacher, <i>Terminologie,</i> i. <i>s.v.</i> <span>הלכה</span>, pp. 42 f.</i> every day of the week, and on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first two editions omit “on the Sabbath.”</i> (Eliezer) repeated them and assimilated them.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. this is the end of the fourth paragraph.</i> He kept a fast for eight days without tasting anything until the odour of his mouth attracted the attention of R. Jochanan ben Ẓakkai, who directed him to withdraw from his presence. He sat down and wept. (R. Jochanan) said to him: My son, why dost thou weep? He rejoined: Because thou didst make me withdraw from thy presence just as a man makes his fellow withdraw, when the latter is afflicted with leprosy. (R. Jochanan) said to him: My son, just as || the odour of thy mouth has ascended before me, so may the savour of the statutes of the Torah ascend from thy mouth to Heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> In Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) xiii. the reading is: “So may the teaching of thy mouth go forth from one end of the world to the other.”</i> He said to him: My son! Whose son art thou? He replied: I am the son of Hyrḳanos. Then said (R. Jochanan): Art thou not the son of one of the great men of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Hyrḳanos was a very wealthy man.</i> and thou didst not tell me? By thy life! he continued, This day shalt thou eat with me.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In MS. the sixth paragraph begins here.</i> (Eliezer) answered: I have eaten already with my host.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Akhsania</i> (<i>ξϵvia</i>), hospitality, lodging, host. According to Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) 6 Eliezer was silent when R. Jochanan asked him whether he had partaken of food.</i> (R. Jochanan) asked: Who is thy host? He replied: R. Joshua ben Chananjah<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Bacher, T. i. pp. 123 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> vii. 290 ff.</i> and R. José the Priest.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Bacher. T. i. pp. 67 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> vii. 243 ff.</i>
(R. Jochanan) sent to inquire of his hosts, saying to them: Did Eliezer eat with you this day? They answered: No; moreover has he not fasted eight days without tasting any food?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Here begins the seventh paragraph in the MS. The Geniẓah Fragment continues: “Moreover.”</i> R. Joshua ben Chananjah and R. José the Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) xiii. adds: “R. Simeon ben Nathaniel.”</i> went and said<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Some of the old printed editions read here: “Has he not been without food for the last eight days?” Luria, <i>in loc.,</i> thinks that the last clause was spoken by R. Jochanan to the Rabbis who visited him, telling them that Eliezer had not eaten at his table. Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>loc. cit.</i>) refers to R. Jochanan’s grief at this neglect, which might have cost Eliezer’s life.</i> to R. Jochanan ben ḳakkai: Verily during the last eight days (Eliezer) has not partaken of any food.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Geniẓah Fragment adds: “And he compelled him to eat and to drink, and on the morrow” (also).</i>

Chapter 2

CHAPTER II<br><small>R. ELIEZER AND HIS BRETHREN</small> [2<small>A</small>. i.]<br>T<small>HE</small> sons of Hyrḳanos said to their father: Get thee up to Jerusalem and vow that thy son Eliezer should not enjoy any of thy possessions.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “and ban thy son Eliezer from thy possessions.” The Geniẓah Fragment reads: “to put him in the ban.” The brothers claimed that Eliezer should be disinherited because he had left his old father without permission. For a parallel text see Gen. Rab. 42 (ed. Theodor, p. 398), Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) 6Was it the custom to resort to the Synhedrion in order to disinherit one’s son?</i> He went up to Jerusalem to disinherit him, and it happened that a festival was being celebrated there by R. Jochanan ben Ẓakkai. All the magnates of the district were dining with him; (such as) Ben Zizith Hakkeseth,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lam. Rab. 1:5 (31), Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 7:11, and T.B. Giṭṭin, 56a. According to the Talmud (<i>loc. cit</i>.) the name Ben Zizith Hakkeseth was due to his intercourse (<i>Kisê, i.e.</i> seat) with the great men of Rome.</i> Nicodemus ben Gorion,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> ix. 300, where the reference to T.B. Ta‘anith should be emended to 20a.</i> and Ben Kalba S'bu'a.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Ben Kalba S’bu‘a, this name is the result of a pun. According to T.B. Giṭṭin, <i>loc. cit.,</i> anyone who came to him even as hungry as a dog (<i>keleb</i>) was dismissed fully satisfied (<i>sab‘a</i>).</i> ||
Why was his name called Ben Zizith Hakkeseth? Because he reclined at table in a higher position than the other magnates of Jerusalem.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> T.B. Giṭṭin, <i>loc. cit.,</i> gives another explanation of this name, due to the tradition that the fringes (<i>Zizith</i>) of the man’s garments were hanging over the cushions of his seat. The Arukh (ed. Kohut, vii. 40a, <i>s.v.</i>) appears to have had a text of our passage in accordance with the Talmudic reading, but unlike our text.</i> Concerning Nicodemus ben Gorion, people said that he had (stored) provisions containing 3 S'ah<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> S’ah, a dry measure, the size of which is held to equal 12 148 litres or 10 696 qts. The Geniẓah Fragment reads “three years” instead of “three S’ah.”</i> of fine flour for every inhabitant of Jerusalem. When the zealots<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Zealots or Sicarii see Josephus, <i>Wars,</i> iv. 3. 9 ff.</i> arose and burnt all the storehouses, they measured and found that he had had provisions for three years for every inhabitant in Jerusalem.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This passage is missing in the printed editions, but it occurs in the Geniẓah Fragment.</i> Concerning Ben Kalba S'bua it was told that he had a house measuring 4 Kors<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Kor is assumed by Gesenius (Oxford ed. p. 499) to be the same as the Chomer, which was thirty times the S’ah. On these measures see <i>Enc. Bib.</i> iv. 5294 ff.</i> with roofs covered with gold.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first printed editions read: “gardens crushed with gold.” Luria reads: “he had a palace with an area covering 4 Kors, all the beams were overlaid with gold.” He thinks that the text should read: “he had a palace covering 4 Kors with treasuries containing gold.” The MS. seems to have preserved the true reading, which is also the reading in the Geniẓah Fragment.</i> The people said (to R. Jochanan): Behold, the father of R. Eliezer has arrived. He bade them saying: Prepare a place for him, and seat him next to us.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st and 2nd eds. read: “They prepared a place for him and seated him next to him” (<i>i.e</i>. R. Jochanan). The Geniẓah Fragment reads: “and seat him next to yourselves; they prepared a place for him and placed him next to him” (R. Jochanan). In the MS. the first paragraph ends here.</i> (R. Jochanan) fixed his gaze<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> For this expression see T.B. Synhedrin, 11a: “the sages fixed their gaze upon Hillel the Elder.”</i> on R. Eliezer, saying to him,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Geniẓah Fragment adds: “O my son!”</i> Tell us some words<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “One word.”</i> of the Torah. (R. Eliezer) answered him saying: Rabbi!<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps “Rabban” would be more correct. The MS. uses an abbreviation.</i> I will tell thee a parable. To what is the matter like? To this well which cannot yield more water than the amount which it has drawn (from the earth); likewise am I unable to speak words of the Torah in excess of what I have received from thee.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth 2:10, where Eliezer is described as a “plastered cistern which loses not a drop,” and cf. Taylor’s note on p. 34 of his (2nd) edition of Aboth. The second paragraph ends here in the MS.</i>
(R. Jochanan) said to him, I will (also) tell thee a parable. To what is the matter like? To this fountain which is bubbling and sending forth its water, and it is able to effect a discharge more powerful || than what it secretes; in like manner art thou able to speak words of the Torah in excess of what Moses<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st and 2nd eds. read, “they received.”</i> received at Sinai. (R. Jochanan) continued: Lest thou shouldst feel ashamed on my account, behold I will arise and go away from thee. Rabban Jochanan ben Ẓakkai arose and went outside. (Thereupon) R. Eliezer sat down and expounded.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Gen. Rab. <small>XLII.</small> i., the text of Eliezer’s exposition was Ps. 37:14, “The wicked have drawn out the sword, and have bent their bow; to cast down the poor and needy, to slay such as be upright in the way.” The brothers of Eliezer might possibly be described in the terms of this text.</i> His face shone like the light of the sun and his effulgence beamed forth like that of Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The reference is to Ex. 34:35, “And the skin of Moses’ face shone.” See also Eccles. 8:1.</i> so that no one knew whether it was day or night.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The third paragraph ends here.</i> They went and said to Rabban Jochanan ben Ẓakkai: Come and see R. Eliezer sitting and expounding, his face shining like the light of the sun and his effulgence beaming like that of Moses, so that no one knows whether it be day or night.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is wanting in the printed editions. There seems to be some confusion in the text. The MS. concludes here the fourth paragraph.</i> He came from (his place) behind him<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Aboth d. R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) xiii. R. Jochanan had gone forth from the assembly so as not to embarrass R. Eliezer. While Eliezer is expounding. R. Joshua and R. Simeon ben Nathaniel leave the assembly to find R. Jochanan, to whom they say, “Come and see! R. Eliezer is sitting and expounding things more profoundly than (the things) told to Moses at Sinai.” For another instance of kissing by the same teacher see T.B. Chagigah, 14b.</i> and kissed him on his head, saying to him: Happy are ye, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, because this one has come forth from your loins.
Hyrḳanos his father said: To whom does (R. Jochanan) speak thus? The people answered: To Eliezer thy son. He said to them: (R. Jochanan) should not have spoken in that manner, but (in this wise), "Happy am I because he has come forth from my loins." Whilst R. Eliezer was sitting and expounding, his father was standing upon his feet. When || (Eliezer) saw his father standing upon his feet, he became agitated and said to him: My father! be seated, for I cannot utter the words of the Torah when thou art standing on thy feet.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> It would be disrespectful for a son to sit in the presence of his parent, who would be standing; cf. T.B. Ẓiddushin, 33b, where this theme is discussed.</i> (Hyrḳanos) replied to him: My son, it was not for this reason that I came, but my intention was to disinherit thee. Now that I have come and I have witnessed all this praise; behold thy brothers are disinherited and their portion is given to thee as a gift.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The fifth paragraph ends here in the MS.</i>
(Eliezer) replied: Verily I am not equal to one of them.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This section to the end of the chapter is to be found in Jalḳuṭ Makhiri to Psalms (Ps. 119), § 77, with slight variations in the reading. The last sentence reads: “But I prayed to Him only that I might be found worthy, as it is said, ‘Therefore I esteem all precepts,’” etc.</i> If I had asked the Holy One, blessed be He, for land, it would be possible for Him to give this to me, as it is said, "The earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof" (Ps. 24:1). Had I asked the Holy One, blessed be He, for silver and gold, He could have given them to me, as it is said, "The silver is mine, and the gold is mine"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. and subsequent editions continue the rest of the verse, but a strange error has crept into their texts; they read “amar” instead of “n’um,” which is the actual reading in Haggai. This error is also in the Talmud (B.) Ḳiddushin, 82b.</i> (Hag. 2:8). But I asked the Holy One, blessed be He, that I might be worthy (to learn the) Torah only, as it is said, "Therefore I esteem all precepts concerning all things to be right; and I hate every false way" (Ps. 119:128).

Chapter 3

CHAPTER III<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is probably the beginning of the Baraitha or Pirḳê de R. Eliezer. The Chronicles of Jeraḥmeel begin with this section of our work. The following chapters up to Chapter XI. form a treatise dealing with Ma‘aseh Bereshith (The Work of the Creation) and Ma‘aseh Merkabah (The theme of God’s Chariot). Cosmological and theosophical themes were favourite ones in the school of R. Eliezer’s famous teacher, R. Jochanan ben Ẓakkai; see T.B. Chagigah, 14b, for the story of R. Jochanan ben Ẓakkai listening to R. Elaẓar ben ‘Arakh expounding the Ma’aseh Merkabah.</i><br><small>PREMUNDANE CREATION, AND THE WORK OF THE FIRST DAY</small> [2<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>R. E<small>LIEZER</small><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This gives the title to the book.</i> <small>BEN</small> H<small>YRḲANOS</small> opened<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. explained (the text).</i> (his discourse with the text), "Who can utter the mighty acts of the Lord, or<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition and several later editions are at variance with the actual text of the psalm by adding “and who,” which is not in the Biblical quotation. The quotation is correctly given in B.M. MS. and in the first printed text (Constantinople, 1514).</i> shew forth all his praise?" (Ps. 106:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc.</i></i> Is there any man<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions add: “in the world.”</i> who can utter the mighty acts of the Holy One, blessed be He, or who can shew forth all His praise?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 18a, for the view that the one who utters the praise of God to excess will be taken from the world, based on Job 37:20. Cf. Slav. Enoch xxiv. 3.</i> Not even the ministering angels<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The ministering angels are identified by Siphrê (Deut. § 306, end) with “the sons of Elohim” of Job 1:6, and they are probably to be identified with “the angels of sanctification” mentioned in the Book of Jubilees ii. 2, 18; cf. Eth. Enoch lxi. 10 ff. For “the heavenly host praising God” see Luke ii. 13, and for angelology see <i>J.E.</i> i. 583 ff.</i> are able to narrate (the Divine praise). But to investigate a part of His mighty deeds with reference to what He has done, and what He will do in the future (is permissible), so that His name should be exalted among His creatures, whom He has created, from one end of the world || to the other, as it is said, "One generation to another shall laud thy works" (<i>ibid.</i> cxlv. 4).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text has been used by Jalḳuṭ, Psalms, § 864. Here ends the first paragraph in MS.</i>
Before the world was created, the Holy One, blessed be He, with His Name<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Tetragrammaton see Nestle, <i>Z.D.M.G.</i> xxxii.; Fürst, <i>ibid.</i> xxxiii.; and Nager, <i>ibid.</i> xxxv. The printed editions read here: “The Holy One, blessed be He, and His great Name.” On “God and His Name” see D. H. Joël’s <i>die Religionsphilosophie des Sohar,</i> p. 235.</i> alone existed, and the thought arose in Him to create the world. He began to trace (the foundations of)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are based on B.M. MS., which reads: “He traced its foundations, its exits and entrances, on the earth, but it did not stand firm until He created repentance, because seven (things) were created before the world.”</i> the world before Himself, but it would not stand. They<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Rabbis.</i> told a parable, To what is the matter like? To a king who wishes to build a palace<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Palṭin = <i>παλáτιov, palatium</i>, palace.</i> for himself. If he had not traced in the earth its foundations, its exits and its entrances,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The phraseology is based on Ezek. 43:11. The printed editions reverse the order and read: “its entrances and its exits.”</i> he does not begin to build.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The architect’s plans must be prepared prior to the erection of the building. What holds good for our earthly experience is assumed to have its counterpart in the experience of the Creator. Philo (<i>de Mundi opific</i>. 4. i. M. 4, C.W. i. p. 4, § 19) offers a good parallel to the idea of preparing plans prior to the Creation; see also Gen. Rab. I. i. and my <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 4.</i> Likewise the Holy One, blessed be He, was tracing (the plans of) the world before Himself, but it did not remain standing until He created repentance.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Repentance is the sole condition whereby harmony, divine and human, can obtain, cf. Wisdom xii. 10, 19. On the subject of Repentance see <i>J.E.</i> x. 376 ff. Lazarus, <i>Ethik,</i> i. pp. 44 f., and Schechter, <i>Aspects,</i> see index, <i>s.v.</i> “Repentance” and “Penitence,” and cf. my <i>Grace of God,</i> pp. 30 ff. The second paragraph in the MS. ends here.</i>
Seven things<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This passage is borrowed from T.B. Pesachim, 54a, or T.B. Nedarim, 39b, the order being varied by Repentance coming after the Torah. See also Jalḳuṭ on Jeremiah, § 298, and cf. Gen. Rab. 1:4 (Theodor, p. 6 note, <i>in loc</i>.) and Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 31 p. 160, where only six subjects are enumerated. Friedmann (note 33, <i>in loc.</i>) points out that by comparing the various readings in Talmud and Midrash we find that there were nine premundane things, cf. Ẓohar, Lev. 34b. It is important to bear in mind, in reading Gen. Rab. 1:4. that of the six premundane things some were actually created and some were only ideally present in the mind of the Creator. The Torah and the Throne of Glory were created, but the patriarchs, Israel, the Temple, and the Name of the Messiah were only in the thought of God. In the Book of Enoch (Ethiopic) xlviii. 3, the Messiah is said to have had his name named <i>before</i> the sun and the signs were created; see my <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> pp. 15 ff., on the question of the pre-existence of the Messiah, and cf. Assumption of Moses i. 14.</i> were created before the world was created. They are: The Torah, Gehinnom, the Garden of Eden,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “The Garden of Eden” is usually rendered by the term Paradise. The fact that Gehenna is in juxtaposition to “Gan Eden” would lead one to infer that Paradise was referred to in this context. Our author is probably opposing the view that the Garden of Eden was created on the “third day”; see Jubilees ii. 7.</i> the Throne of Glory, the Temple, Repentance, and the Name of the Messiah.
Whence do we know that this applies to the Torah? Because it is said, "The Lord possessed me<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse might be rendered: “The Lord formed me as the beginning of his way.” The reference is to Wisdom, which is here personified; see <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> pp. 64 ff. Christianity under the influence of Alexandrian Jewish thought identified Wisdom with its Messiah, whilst Palestinian Judaism identified Wisdom with the Torah.</i> in the beginning of his way, before his works <i>of old</i>" (Prov. 8:22). "Of old"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. and later editions derive the inference from the word “<i>before</i>.”</i> means before the world was created.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “Whence do we know this with reference to Gehinnom? Because it is said, ‘For a Topheth is prepared <i>of old</i> ‘ (Isa. 30:33). ‘Of old’ means whilst yet the world had not been created.” This paragraph is omitted by the MS., but it occurs in the 1st ed. Topheth was a place in the Hinnom Valley (<i>i.e.</i> Ge-henna or Ge-Hinnom) where the hateful and cruel Moloch abominations had been perpetrated; see W. R. Smith, <i>Religion of the Semites,</i> p. 357. The Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab., <i>loc. cit.,</i> says: “Topheth is nought else but Gehinnom.” See also Schwally, <i>Z.A.T.W.,</i> 1890, pp. 212 ff.</i> Whence do we know this with regard to the Garden of Eden? Because it is said, "And the Lord God planted a garden <i>of old</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See R.V. <i>in loc.</i> Our Midrashic passage occurs as follows in the Pal. Targum of Gen. 2:8: “And a garden from the Eden of the just was planted by the Word of the Lord God before the creation of the world.” This Haggadah appears also in Jerome; see Diestel, <i>Geschichte des A.T. in der Christlichen Kirche,</i> p. 102, and Rahmer, <i>Die Hebräischen Traditionen in den Werken des Hieronymus,</i> p. 17. See also 4 Ezra 3:6, which states: “And thou leddest him (Adam) into Paradise, which thy right hand did plant <i>before ever</i> the earth came forward.” On Paradise see <i>J.E.</i> ix. pp. 516 f.</i> (Gen. 2:8). "<i>Of old</i>," whilst as yet the world had not been created. Whence do we know this with reference to the Throne of Glory?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Throne of Glory as premundane occurs in Slavonic Enoch xxv. 4, where God says, “And I made for myself a throne… and I said to the light,” etc.; see LXX Prov. 8:27.</i> Because it is said, "Thy throne is established <i>of old</i>" (Ps. 93:2). "Of old," whilst as yet the world had not been created. Whence do we know that Repentance (was premundane)? Because it is said, "<i>Before</i> the mountains were brought forth, or ever thou hadst formed the earth and the world" (<i>ibid.</i> xc. 2);<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The translation in the Revised Version might be consulted, in order to see how the Midrashic point of view, based on a literal translation, agrees with or differs from the ordinary interpretation. In the 1st ed. this section follows that dealing with the Temple.</i> and then in close proximity (we read), "Thou turnest man to contrition" (<i>ibid.</i> 3). "Before," <i>i.e.</i> before || the world was created. Whence do we know this with regard to the Temple? Because it is said, "A glorious throne, set on high <i>from the beginning</i>, is the place of our <i>sanctuary</i>" (Jer. 17:12). "From the beginning," whilst as yet the world had not been created.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The premundane or Heavenly Temple was known to the writer of the Epistle to the Hebrews, ix. 11, who speaks of the “greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is to say, <i>not of this creation.”</i> See Wisdom ix. 8, and Odes of Solomon iv. 3. Maimonides, <i>Guide</i> 1. ix., discusses our theme. See also Menorath Ha-Maor, Introduction to the fourth book, where we are cautioned not to take the words in this passage in their literal meaning.</i> Whence we do know that the name of the Messiah (was premundane)? Because it is said, "His name shall endure for ever; before the sun Yinnôn was his name" (Ps. 72:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The R.V. reads: “His name shall be continued as long as (or, “before”) the sun.” For Yinnôn as a Messianic name see T.B. Synhedrin, 98b, and <i>infra,</i> p. 233. The Midrashic interpretation in our text occurs already in LXX, <i>in loc</i>.: “His name endures <i>before</i> the sun.”</i> "Yinnôn," before the world had been created. Another verse says, "But thou, Bethlehem Ephrathah,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the quotation is missing in the MS.</i> which art to be least among the thousands of Judah, from thee shall he come forth unto me who is to be ruler over Israel; whose ancestry belongs to the <i>past</i>, even to the days of old<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation, a second one to justify the idea that the name of the Messiah was premundane, is omitted by the Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i> It is not given by the Talmud. On this verse in Micah see <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> pp. 5 f.</i>" (Mic. 5:2). "The past,"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “The past” is the same word which was rendered “of old” (Gen. 2:8) quoted above.</i> whilst as yet the world had not been created.
Forthwith<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the fourth paragraph begins here. On the theme see Wisdom ix. 9 f.</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, took counsel with the Torah whose name is Tushijah (Stability or Wisdom) with reference to the creation of the world. (The Torah) replied and said to Him: Sovereign of the worlds ! if there be no host for the king<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is quoted in Ginzberg’s <i>Geonica,</i> ii. p. 88.</i> and if there be no camp for the king, over whom does he rule? If there be no people to praise the king, where is the honour of the king? The Holy One, blessed be He, heard this and it pleased Him. The Torah spake: The Holy One, blessed be He, took counsel with me concerning the creation of the world, as it is said, "Counsel is mine, and sound knowledge;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The idea of Wisdom or the Torah being with God prior to the Creation is generally assumed to be expressed in the famous passage verses 22-31 of this eighth chapter of Proverbs. This is, however, a mistaken view; see <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> pp. 65 ff. The source is rather to be found in the LXX Prov. 8:30. Our Midrashic passage is based on Gen. Rab. 1. 1Prov. 8:14, § 941, and see Bacher, P. i. p. 107 (note), who refers to the parallel in Philo.</i> I am understanding; I have might" (Prov. 8:14). Hence they<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “The wise men.”</i> say, Every government which has no counsellors is not a proper government.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Might one infer from this passage that the writer of <i>P.R.E.</i> was living in a land where the régime was not conducted in accordance with the rule laid down? Perhaps the reference is to the rule of the Mohammedans in Palestine, Egypt, or Babylon.</i> Whence do we know this? From the government of the House of David which employed counsellors, as it is said, "And Jonathan David's uncle<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st and 2nd eds. have the reading “the son of David.” This is an error.</i> was a counsellor, a man of understanding, and a scribe" (1 Chron. 27:32). If the government of the House of David had counsellors, how much more so should other people act likewise. This is of benefit to them, as it is said, "But he that hearkeneth unto counsel is wise" (Prov. 12:15), || and (Scripture) says, "But in the multitude of counsellors there is safety" (<i>ibid.</i> xi. 14).
Eight<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The fifth paragraph in the MS. begins here. These eight things are almost identical with the seven things enumerated in Jubilees ii. 2, if “the abysses” of the latter correspond to the “Chaos and Void” of our text. See Jeraḥmeel i. 3, which is based on our text. This suggested identification seems to be warranted by the fact that Philo (<i>loc</i>. <i>cit.</i> 7) agrees with the enumeration in our text and Jubilees in the following six objects of creation: heaven, earth, darkness, water, spirit, and light. As the seventh object created on the first day he gives the abyss. This is also the reading in the Midrash Tadsheh vi., where Tehomoth = abyss. It seems that Philo knew a cosmology which was known to Jubilees, to Midrash Tadsheh, and to our author; see Charles, <i>Jubilees,</i> pp. 11 f. T.B. Chagigah, 12a, which gives appropriate quotations to support the view enunciated, enumerates ten things as being created on the first day. Neither the Talmud nor <i>P.R.E.</i> mention Tehomoth, which is the equivalent to abyss, but they both have Tohu and Bohu.</i> things were created on the first day, namely, Heaven, Earth, Light, Darkness, Tohu (Chaos), Bohu (Void), Wind (or Spirit), and Water, as it is said, "And the <i>wind</i> of God was moving upon the face of the <i>waters</i>" (Gen. 1:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>רוח</span> can mean <i>wind</i> or <i>spirit</i>; Gen. 1:2 might be rendered, “And a mighty wind.” Is there any ancient Rabbinic authority for the translation in the R.V., “the spirit of God”? See Bacher, T. i. p. 424, and cf. Philo, ed. Cohn, G.T. i. p. 36. n. 3. The following section first appeared in the 2nd ed. (Venice, 1544) of <i>P.R.E</i>.:<br>“Some (wise men) say that day and night also,<sup></sup> as it is said, ‘And there was evening and morning, one day’ (Gen. 1:5).<br>“Eight things were created on the second day, namely, the Well,<sup></sup> the Manna,<sup></sup> the Rod,<sup></sup> the Rainbow,<sup></sup> the art of writing, the written characters,<sup></sup> the Garments,<sup></sup> and the destroying spirits.<sup></sup><br>“Ten things arose in the thought (of the Creator),<sup></sup> namely, Jerusalem,<sup></sup> the spirits of the patriarchs.<sup></sup> the paths of the righteous,<sup></sup> Gehinnom,<sup></sup> the waters of the Flood,<sup></sup> the second tables of the Law,<sup></sup> the Sabbath,<sup></sup> the Temple,<sup></sup> the Ark,<sup></sup> and the light of the world to come.”<sup></sup><br>This reading occurs in Jeraḥmeel i. 3, 4, but not in the B.M. MS. of <i>P.R.E.</i> The latter continues: “Whence was the water created? From the light of the garment of the Holy One, blessed be He. Light signifies nought else but water, as it is said, ‘He spreadeth abroad the cloud of his light’” (Job 37:11).</i>
Whence were the heavens created? From the light of the garment with which He was robed.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. <small>L</small>. i. The idea of this Midrash is that God created the heavens without any help from any intermediary. God alone is the Creator. “The light of His robe” means His will or favour. The world has been created by Divine love and favour for the benefit of mankind, the children of the Heavenly Father.</i> He took (of this light) and stretched it like a garment and (the heavens) began to extend continually until He caused them to hear, "It is sufficient."<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, <i>loc. cit</i>., “This is what Resh Laḳish also said: What is the meaning of the words ‘I am God Almighty’ (<i>Shaddai</i>)? It means I am He who (<i>Sha</i>) said to the world, ‘ It is sufficient’ (<i>dai</i>).”</i> Therefore is He called God Almighty (<i>El Shaddai</i>), who said to the world:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions read: “to the heavens.”</i> "<i>It is sufficient</i>," and it stood (firm). Whence do we know that the heavens were created from the light of His garment? Because it is said, "Who coverest thyself with light as with a garment; who stretchest out the heavens like a curtain" (Ps. 104:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The second half of the verse is omitted in the MS. The fifth paragraph ends here. Cf. also Ps. 102:25, 26. The Church Fathers discussed the creation narrative in much the same way as our author: thus Athanasius in his exposition of the 103rd Psalm (corresponding to the Hebrew 104th Psalm) refers to the formation of the heavens in the terms of the Old Testament writers; see also Basil, <i>Hexœmeron,</i> iii.</i>
Whence was the earth created? He took of the snow<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See D. H. Joël, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 321 ff., where a full discussion of this passage is given and the views of Maimonides and the theories of the Cabbalists are examined.</i> (or ice) which was beneath His Throne of Glory and threw it upon the waters, and the waters became congealed so that the dust of the earth was formed, as it is said, "He saith to the snow, Be thou earth" (Job 37:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma (Buber) Miḳez, 16. Our text seems to be based upon T.J. Chagigah, 2:1. 77a, according to which the world was originally “Water in water.” Then God made the water into snow (or ice); see Ps. 147:16, 17. This psalm in verse 15 speaks of God sending out“his commandment upon (the) earth; his word runneth very swiftly”—pointing to the word of creation. See Bacher, P. iii. 218. The verse quoted from Job (37:6) is rendered by the R.V., “He saith to the snow, Fall thou on the earth.” See also Sepher Jezirah i. 11 for a parallel. See Isa. 40:12 for the reference to the “dust of the earth,” and cf. T.B. Joma, 54b; Maimonides, <i>Guide,</i> ii., xxvi., and Midrash Kônen, ed. Jellinek, <i>B.H.M.</i> ii. p. 24. This concludes the seventh paragraph. The sixth paragraph is not marked in the MS.</i>
The hooks<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Ḳurḳos (<i>κίρκοѕ</i>), ring or hook. The heavens being compared with a curtain are assumed to have hooks or rings wherewith they may be fastened; see Tosaphoth Chagigah, 12a, catchword “From the end.” The ‘Arukh (ed. Kohut, vii. 215b) quotes our text.</i> of the heavens are fixed in the waters of the ocean.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Oḳeanos (<i>ὠκ∊ανόѕ</i>). The Church Fathers dwell on the relation between the Ocean and the world; thus Chrysostomus, <i>Homilies on the Epistle to the Romans</i> (xxviii.), quotes Ps. 104:6 in this connection. Cf. Augustine, <i>de Civitate Dei,</i> xii. 12. John of Damascus, <i>On the Orthodox Faith,</i> ii. 9, tells us, “The Ocean flows around the entire earth like a river.” See Test. Levi ii. 7, “And I entered from the first heaven, and I saw there a great sea hanging.” Cf. also Jubilees ii. 4.</i> The waters of the ocean are situated between the ends of the heavens and the ends of the earth. The ends of the heavens are spread out over the waters of the ocean, as it is said, "Who layeth the beams of his chambers<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the heavens.</i> in the waters" (Ps. 104:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The eighth paragraph ends here.</i>
The dome (or inside shape) of the heavens ascends upwards like a tub,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, basket. The MS. uses the word <i>denda</i> (tent), which occurs again, <i>infra,</i> p. 323; this points to Spain as the home of the scribe who wrote our MS. On the “tent” see T.J. Berakhoth, 2c, d, and Baraitha d. Shemuel, i. The word which is translated by “tub” occurs only in our MS.</i> (that is to say) like a tent (<i>denda</i>) which is spread out<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds: “like a tent.”</i> with its extremities (fixed) || downwards<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads “upwards”; in this paragraph there are several variants in the MSS. and the printed texts.</i> and its dome stretching upwards so that people can sit beneath it and their feet stand on the earth, whilst all of them are inside the tent; in like wise are the heavens, their extremities are (fixed) downwards and their dome stretches upwards and all creatures dwell beneath them as in a tent, as it is said, "And he spreadeth them out as a tent to dwell in" (Isa. 40:22).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This verse is also applied by Basil, <i>op. cit.</i> i. 8, in his account of the form of the heavens.</i>
Four quarters<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>רוח</span> (as in Ezek. 42:16–20) = direction or quarter of the world; wind would not be appropriate here. Rab. 2:10, and Pesiḳta Rabbathi, § xlvi. p. 188a.</i> have been created in the world; the quarter facing the east, that facing the south, that facing the west and that facing the north. From the quarter facing the east the light goeth forth to the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, 25a, b.</i> From the quarter facing south the dews of blessing and the rains of blessing<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ezek. 34:26.</i> go forth to the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The rains which are not a blessing come from the north; see <i>infra,</i> note 9.</i> From the quarter facing west<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Eth. Enoch lxxvii. 2: “And the west quarter is named the diminished, because there all the luminaries of the heaven wane and go down.” In Num. Rab., <i>loc. cit.,</i> the reading is slightly different: “In the west are the treasuries of snow, and the treasuries of hail, cold, and heat go forth to the world… from the north cometh forth darkness to the world.”</i> where are the treasuries<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 12b, and cf. Eth. Enoch xli. 3 ff. The conception rests on Job 38:22. All the powers of nature were supposed to dwell in their respective chambers or to be stored up in treasuries.</i> of snow and the treasuries of hail, and thence come forth into the world cold and heat and rains. From the quarter facing north darkness goeth forth into the world. The quarter facing north He created, but He did not complete it, for He said, Anyone who says: I am a God, let him come and complete this quarter which I have left (incomplete) and all will know that he is a God.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This seems to point to polemics. Probably the Gnostic doctrine of the Demiurge is attacked here. For other polemics in our book, see <i>infra,</i> pp. 79, 85 f., and 252. See also Ascension of Isaiah 4:6.</i>
There (in the north) is the abode of the destroying spirits, earthquakes, winds, demons, lightnings and thunders; thence evil issues forth into the world, as it is said, "Out of the north evil shall break forth upon all the inhabitants of the earth" (Jer. 1:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the tenth paragraph ends here. Cf. Jubilees ii. 2. Origen, <i>de Principiis,</i> ii. viii. 3, quotes Jer. 1:14, and identifies the “north” with “the cold north wind,” which is the “Devil.” For Rabbinic references to the winds see T.B. Baba Bathra, <i>loc. cit.</i>; and cf. Num. Rab., <i>loc. cit.,</i> as a parallel to our text. Jeraḥmeel MS. omits the rest of this chapter.</i> Some say by ten Sayings was the world created<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text reappears in the Ẓohar. Lev. 11a. See Pirḳê Aboth 5:1, and Taylor’s note, p. 78 of his 2nd edition. Cf. T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 32a, where the first verse of Genesis is reckoned as one of the ten sayings owing to verse 6 of Ps. 33 The Venice edition adds the following, namely: (1) “And God said, Let there be light” (Gen. 1:3). (2) “And God said, Let there be a firmament” (<i>ibid.</i> 6). (3) “And God said, Let the waters be gathered together” (<i>ibid.</i> 9). (4) “And God said, Let the earth put forth grass” (<i>ibid.</i> 11). (5) “And God said, Let there be luminaries” (<i>ibid.</i> 14). (6) “And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly” (<i>ibid.</i> 20). (7) “And God said, Let the earth bring forth” (<i>ibid.</i> 24). (8) “And God said, Let us make man” (<i>ibid.</i> 26). (9) “And God said, Behold. I have given you” (<i>ibid.</i> 29). (10) “And God<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> said, It is not good that the man should be alone” (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 18).</i> || and in three (Divine attributes) are these (ten Sayings) comprised,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the translation should be: By three (Divine attributes) were (the works of creation) completed. The Venice edition adds: “And they are, Wisdom, Understanding, and Knowledge.” On these three attributes see T.B. Berakhoth, 55a, and Midrash Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 50:1, and Buber’s note (4), where the sources are given. This Midrash may help us to understand our text: “With three names did the Holy One, blessed be He, create His world, corresponding to the three good attributes through which the world was created.”</i> as it is said, "The Lord by wisdom founded the earth; by understanding he established the heavens, by his knowledge the depths were broken up" (Prov. 3:19, 20). By these three (attributes) was the Tabernacle made, as it is said, "And I have filled him with the spirit of God, with wisdom, with understanding, and with knowledge" (Ex. 31:3). Likewise with these three (attributes) was the Temple made, as it is said, "He<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Hiram, the builder of Solomon’s Temple.</i> was the son of a widow woman of the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a man of Tyre, a worker in brass; and he was filled with wisdom and understanding and knowledge" (1 Kings 7:14). By these three attributes it will be rebuilt in the future, as it is said, "Through wisdom is an house<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The <i>House</i> is a common designation of the Temple, see Jastrow, <i>Targum Dictionary,</i> p. 168a.</i> builded; and by understanding it is established; and by knowledge are the chambers filled" (Prov. 24:3, 4).
With these three attributes will the Holy One, blessed be He, give three good gifts to Israel in the future, as it is said, "For the Lord will give<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The next sentence should precede the rest of the quotation if we follow the order of the words in the MS. It is omitted in the printed editions.</i> wisdom, out of his mouth cometh knowledge and understanding" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 6).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Prov. § 935, where attention is drawn to the verb “will give” in the imperfect tense indicating the future. This point is lost sight of in the R.V.; see also Ex. Rab. xli. 3, and cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 5a.</i> It is not said, "The Lord has given wisdom." These three attributes will be given<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. adds “in double measure”; this has been adopted by later editions.</i> to King Messiah, as it is said, "And the spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the Lord" (Isa. 11:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This famous passage from Isaiah is quoted by Justin Martyr in his <i>Dialogue with Trypho,</i> lxxxvii., as referring to the Messiah.</i>

Chapter 4

CHAPTER IV<br><small>THE CREATION ON THE SECOND DAY</small> [4<small>A</small>. i.]<br>O<small>N</small> the second day<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. §5, and Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. § 338.</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, created the firmament,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Jubilees ii. 4, the firmament <i>only</i> was created on the second day; see Slav. Enoch xxvi.–xxvii.</i> the angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In Gen. Rab. 1:3 and iii. 8, the question is discussed as to which day of the week of creation were the angels called into being. According to R. Jochanan it was the second day, as in our text, whereas according to R. Chanina it was the fifth day. Theodor (<i>in loc.</i>) gives the various parallel sources in notes 7 and 8. See also Pal. Targum on Gen. 1:26, where the creation of the angels is also assigned to the second day, as in Slavonic Enoch xxix. 1 ff. In Jubilees ii. 2 this event is said to have been on the <i>first</i> day; see Charles’ note 2 on pp. 12 f. Our book opposes this view. The Church Fathers sometimes held this view; see Epiphanius, <i>adv. Hœr.</i> lxv. 4. The Rabbis were fully aware of the teaching that God was assisted at the creation by angels or the Messiah, and in order to oppose such doctrine the creation of the angels was fixed on the second or fifth day; cf. Ex. Rab. xv. 22.</i> fire for flesh and blood,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Pesachim, 54a, and Gen. Rab. 11:2 for the view that this fire was created at the termination of the first Sabbath. As the angels are often of fire (cf. Rev. xiv. 18), both angels and fire are held by our author to have been created on the second day. This view is held in spite of the statement that <i>light</i> was created on the first day.</i> and the fire of Gehinnom.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The fire of Gehenna is mentioned in the New Testament; see Matt, v. 22, and cf. Rev. xx. 10. See also Eth. Enoch xc. 24 and 26, the Apocalypse of Baruch lix. 10, 11, and the Apocalypse of Peter for an account of Gehenna. The 21st book of Augustine s <i>de Civitate Dei</i> is devoted to this theme. The Rabbis came to the conclusion that the fire of Gehenna must have been created on the second day, because the Scripture does not say with reference to this day “and it was good,” which, however, does occur in the story of the other five days of creation; see T.B. Pesachim, 54a, Ex. Rab. xv. 22, and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 15.</i> Were not heaven and earth created on the first day, as it is said, "In the beginning God created<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits the rest of the verse; it is given in the 1st ed. and subsequent editions.</i> the heaven and the earth" (Gen. 1:1)? Which firmament was created on the second day? Rabbi Eliezer said: || It was the firmament which is above the heads of the four Chajjôth (living creatures),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Chajjôth, see T.B. Chagigah, 13a, and Hastings’ <i>Dictionary of the Bible,</i> iii. 128 f. The Chajjôth are to be identified with the “creature” of Rev. iv. 7. Do they correspond with the angels of the presence of Jubilees ii. 2? The firmament implies the division between the upper and lower waters; see Midrash Kônen (Jellinek, <i>B.H.M.</i> ii. p. 25).</i> (as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” occurs in the printed texts.</i>), "And over the head of the Chajjôth there was the likeness of a firmament, like the colour of the terrible crystal"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “ice.”</i> (Ezek. 1:22). What is the meaning of (the expression), "like the colour of the terrible crystal"? It means like precious stones and pearls; it illuminates all the heavens like a lamp which is illuminating<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading in B.M. MS. See also Jalḳuṭ to Ezek. <i>loc. cit.,</i> and cf. Eth. Enoch xiv. 9 ff.</i> the whole house and like the sun which is shining with maximum intensity at noonday, as it is said, "The light dwelleth with him" (Dan. 2:22);<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The second paragraph in MS. begins here.</i> and like this in the future will the righteous shed light,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Matt. xiii. 43, Eth. Enoch xxxix. 7 f., and Ascension of Isaiah 8:22.</i> as it is said, "And they that be wise shall shine as the brightness of the firmament" (<i>ibid.</i> xii. 3).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This section is quoted by Tosapboth, T.B. Baba Bathra, 8b, catchword, “Umazdiḳê.”</i> Were it not for that firmament the world would be engulfed by the waters above it and below it;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the translation should be: “by the waters, for above it are waters and beneath it are waters.” This is practically the text in the printed editions. See Pal. Targum, Gen. 1:6.</i> but (the firmament) divides the waters (above) from the waters (below), as it is said, "And God said, Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, (and let it divide the waters from the waters)"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This part of the verse in brackets is wanting in the MS.</i> (Gen. 1:6), it illuminates<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “it divides.”</i> between the waters above and the waters below.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The second paragraph ends here.</i>
(As for) the angels created on the second<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> B.M. MS. reads: “first day.”</i> day, when they are sent (as messengers) by His word they are changed into winds, and when they minister before Him they are changed into fire, as it is said, "Who maketh his angels winds; his ministers a flaming fire" (Ps. 104:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This verse is quoted by many of the Church Fathers in order to describe the nature of the angels; see John of Damascus, <i>op. cit.</i> ii. 3. The MS. quotes only the first half of the verse. The entire verse is given by the first editions. The third paragraph ends here.</i>
Four<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The New Testament refers to the four living creatures before God’s throne; see Rev. iv. 6. The whole of this chapter is a parallel to our text.</i> classes of ministering angels minister and utter praise<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts omit “minister and.”</i> before the Holy One, blessed be He: the first camp (led by) Michael<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash here has given rise to a passage in the Hebrew prayer-book; see Singer, p. 297. See also Num. Rab. 2:10, Midrash Kônen, p. 27, and Pesiḳta Rabbathi, § xlvi. p. 188a. On Michael see the valuable monograph by Leuken, and <i>J.E.</i> viii. 535 ff. As parallels to our text see Targum to Job 25:2, and Eth. Enoch xl. 9 and lxxi. 8f., which mentions the four archangels in the following order: Michael, Raphael, Gabriel, and Phanuel; in this Book of Enoch (ix. 1) the angel Uriel appears to be the same as Phanuel. In the N.T. we find Michael and Gabriel mentioned. The B.M. MS. reads here Gabriel in place of Michael, and Michael instead of Gabriel.</i> on His right, the second camp (led by) Gabriel<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> v. 540 f.</i> on His left, the third camp || (led by) Uriel<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> xii. 383.</i> before Him, and the fourth camp (led by) Raphael<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> x. 317 f.</i> behind Him; and the Shekhinah of the Holy One, blessed be He, is in the centre. He<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> God.</i> is sitting on a throne high and exalted.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is omitted by the B.M. MS. The words are found in the Sabbath Morning Liturgy, Singer, p. 126, last two lines. See Eth. Enoch xiv. 18.</i> His throne is high and suspended above in the air. The appearance of His Glory is like the colour of amber.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The B.M. MS. adds: “One-half thereof is fire and the other half is hail.” In our MS. the fourth paragraph ends here. The 1st ed., followed by subsequent editions, adds: “As it is said: ‘And I saw as the colour of amber’” (Ezek. 1:27).</i> And the adornment of a crown is on His head, and the Ineffable Name<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “A crown is set on His head, and the diadem of the Ineffable Name is upon His forehead.” On the <i>Shem Hammephorash</i> or “Ineffable Name” see G. Klein, <i>Der älteste Christliche Katechismus,</i> pp. 44 ff., and <i>supra,</i> p. 10, note 2.</i> is upon His forehead.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> This passage is the source for the words: “Upon His forehead is impressed the glory of His holy name” in the Hymn of Glory; see Singer, p. 79. The Venice edition adds: “and His eyes run to and fro throughout the whole earth.”</i> One half (of His glory) is fire the other half is hail,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Fire and hail represent the two divine attributes of justice and love; see Ẓohar, Gen. 186a, and cf. Eth. Enoch xiv. 20. The B.M. MS. omits these words in this context.</i> at His right hand is life and at His left is death. He has a sceptre of fire in His hand and a veil<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Coptic Apocrypha, p. 90, and Eth. Enoch xiv. 21.</i> is spread before Him, and His eyes run to and fro throughout the whole earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 2 Chron. 16:9.</i> and the seven angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The seven angels or archangels are referred to in the Book of Enoch (Eth.), ch. xx.; see Charles’ notes, <i>in loc.,</i> for further references.</i> which were created first,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts read: “Since the beginning.” Does our book here agree with Jubilees ii. 2?</i> minister before Him within the veil, and this (veil) is called Pargod.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>פרגוד</span> <img src="data:image/jpg;base64,/9j/4AAQSkZJRgABAQEBLAEsAAD/2wBDAAUDBAQEAwUEBAQFBQUGBwwIBwcHBw8LCwkMEQ8SEhEP

T.B. Chagigah, 13a.</i> and the four holy Chajjôth are fixed to each leg, each one<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ezek. 10:14. On the Cherubim see Maimonides, <i>Guide,</i> iii. 1 ff. and cf. <i>ibid.</i> ch. xlv., and Hastings’ <i>Dictionary of the Bible,</i> i. 377 ff., where the N.T. and Patristic references are given. Speaking generally, the Patristic literature has much more to say concerning angels, good and bad, than Rabbinic literature. This can be easily seen by comparing the references in Eisenmenger’s <i>Entdecktes Judentum</i> or in Weber’s <i>Jüdische Theologie</i> on the one hand and the index to Thalhofer’s <i>Bibliothek der Kirchenväter,</i> i. pp. 226–229, on the other. The statement on the subject in Hastings’ Dictionary of Christ and the Gospels, i. 57, “The Jews believed all that the N.T. says of angels, but they also believed much more,” needs revision. The Church is more concerned with angels in its liturgy and ritual than the Synagogue.</i> has four faces and each one has four wings, as it is said, "And every one had four faces and four wings" (Ezek. 1:6), and these (Chajjôth) are the Cherubim.
