"></i> He || speaks towards the west He speaks between the two Cherubim with the face of the ox, when He speaks towards the north He speaks between the two Cherubim with the face of an eagle.
Over against them<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Cherubim.</i> are the Ophanim (Wheels) and the Whirling Wheels of the Chariot,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Merkabah (<span>מרכבה</span>) or Chariot is described in Ezek. 1 and x. See T.B. Chagigah, 14b, Maimonides, <i>Guide,</i> iii. 1–7, and cf. Ecclus. xlix. 8, and <i>J.E.</i> viii. 498 ff. The mystery of the Chariot is also referred to by Eth. Enoch xiv. 18, and Origen, <i>contra Celsum,</i> vi. 18. See also Hastings’ <i>Dictionary of the Bible,</i> i. 377 f. and v. 644. The Venice edition adds: “When He sits He is upon the throne high and exalted.”</i> and when He looketh upon the earth His chariots are upon the Ophanim, and owing to the noise caused by the whirling wheels of the Chariot—lightnings and thunder go forth into the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 77:18.</i> When He dwells<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is omitted in the Cambridge Geniẓah and in the first editions.</i> in heaven He rideth upon a swift cloud.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “as it is said, ‘And he rode upon a cherub, and did fly’” (Ps. 18:10). A more appropriate quotation would be: “Behold, the Lord rideth upon a swift cloud” (Isa. 19:1).</i> When He hastens He flies upon the wings of the wind, as it is said, "And he rode upon a cherub, and did fly; yea, he flew swiftly upon the wings of the wind" (Ps. 18:10).
The Chajjôth stand next to the throne of His glory and they do not know the place of His glory.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is wanting in the Oxford MS. (d. 35).</i> The Chajjôth stand in awe and dread,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> A parallel text with deviations occurs in Singer, pp. 38 and 130. See also Liturgy, Second Day of New Year, ed. Heidenheim, p. 36a.</i> in fear and trembling, and from the perspiration of their faces a river of fire arises and goes forth<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 13b; cf. Eth. Enoch lxxi. 6 and xiv. 18 f.: “And I looked and saw a lofty throne; its appearance was as <i>crystal,</i> and <i>the wheels</i> thereof as the shining sun, and there was the vision of <i>cherubim.</i> And from underneath the throne came <i>streams of flaming fire,</i> so that I could not look thereon.” The N.T. speaks of the heavenly throne; see Rev. i. 4, iii. 21, iv. 2; cf. Gen. Rab. 78:1.</i> before Him, as it is said, "A fiery stream issued and came forth from before him…"(Dan. 7:10). And the wings of Gallizur<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The whole of this sentence is missing in the printed texts. Gallizur, as the name of an angel, occurs in Pesiḳta Rabbathi, § xx. p. 97b; Jeraḥmeel, lii. 8; and Liturgy, Eighth Day of Solemn Assembly, ed. Heidenheim, p. 20b.</i> the angel, who stands next to the Chajjôth, (are spread forth) so that the fire which consumes the fire of the angels should not burn (them). Two Seraphim stand, one on His right and one on His left, each one has six wings,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The B.M. MS. adds here: “as it is said, ‘Above him stood the Seraphim; each one had six wings’” (Isa. 6:2).</i> with twain they cover their face<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text agrees with the B.M. MS., and this reading has been preserved in Jalḳuṭ on Isaiah, § 404; see also Lev. Rab. 27:3, and Tanchuma, Emor, § viii. The 1st and 2nd eds. read: “With twain does each one cover his face.”</i> so as not to behold the presence of the Shekhinah, with twain they cover their feet so that they should not be seen before the presence of the Shekhinah, || so that the standing of the foot of the calf<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The foot of the Cherub was like that of the calf (see Ezek. 1:7); this might recall the sin of the Golden Calf. See T.B. Chagigah, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> might be forgotten. With twain do they fly, praising and reverencing, and they sanctify.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> These words are similar to the first words of the Ḳedushah (Sanctification); see Singer, p. 160, and cf. Ps. 89:7. The Sephardic Liturgy is somewhat different, its phraseology for this part of the Prayer Book being probably based on Isa. 29:23. For the Ḳedushah see Ezek. 36:23; Isa. 6:3; Ex. Rab. xv. 6, and Lev. Rab. 2:8. The Venice edition adds: “His Great Name.” The B.M. MS. reads here: “And they stand near the throne of His glory and do not know the place of His glory, as it is said. ‘Blessed be the glory of the Lord from his place’ (Ezek. 3:12), and the Chajjôth stand in awe and dread,” etc., as above.</i> One answers and another calls,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on Isaiah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and T.B. Chullin, 91b, for the angelic sanctification. The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “One calls and they all reply and say.”</i> one calls and another answers, and they say, "Holy, Holy, Holy, is the Lord of Hosts; the whole earth is full of his glory" (Isa. 6:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the end of the 7th section in the MS. On the theme see Slav. Enoch xxi. 1.</i>
The Chajjôth stand at the side of the throne of His glory and they do not know the place of His glory;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading seems to be corrupt, and should run: “The Chajjôth respond and say,” etc. The first part of the sentence has already been given at the beginning of the preceding paragraph.</i> they respond and say in every place where His glory<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> On the “Glory” see Abelson, <i>The Immanence of God in Rabbinic Literature,</i> p. 380 ff. The <i>Place</i> of God’s glory is identified by <i>P.R.E.</i> with the Shekhinah; see <i>infra,</i> p. 225, note 9, and cf. Eth. Enoch xxxix. 12–14.</i> is, "Blessed be the glory of the Lord from his place" (Ezek. 3:12). Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The 9th section in the MS. begins here.</i> a nation unique on the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> These words occur in the Amidah for Sabbath afternoon; see Singer, p. 175.</i> declares daily<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) adds: “continually every day twice.”</i> the unity of His great Name, saying, "Hear, O Israel: the Lord is our God, the Lord is one" (Deut. 6:4). He answers His people Israel and says to them, I am the Lord your God who has delivered<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “who redeems.”</i> you from every trouble.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The many parallels in our text to Eth. Enoch xiv. 9–22, and Slav. Enoch xxi. 1 and xxii. 1–3 are noteworthy, and point to the influence which the pseudepigraphic books have had upon our author. The latter part of this chapter is of importance in connection with the liturgy of the Synagogue. We note how the threefold responses of the Ḳedushah are set forth here as the responses of (1) the angels, (2) Israel, and (3) God; compare Singer, pp. 160 f. The writer of the MS. did not end the chapter here, but continued with the next chapter. A later scribe has added in the margin, “Chapter V.,” thus agreeing with other MSS. and the printed editions. Our chapter should be compared with the Merkabah Midrashim in the first two volumes of Wertheimer’s <i>Bottê Midrashoth</i>.</i>

Chapter 5

CHAPTER V<br><small>THE GATHERING OF THE WATERS</small> [5<small>A.</small> i.]<br>O<small>N</small> the third day<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the week of creation. Our Book agrees here with the Book of Jubilees, which states: “And on the third day He commanded the waters to pass from off the face of the whole earth” (ii. 5). Cf. Ps. 104:6, according to which the mountains were beneath the water, the surface of which was like a plain.</i> all the earth was flat like a plain and the waters covered the surface of all the earth. When the word of the Almighty<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 8, reads: “The Holy One, blessed be He.”</i> was uttered, "Let the waters be gathered together" (Gen. 1:9), the mountains and hills arose from the ends of the earth and they were scattered<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The gathering of the waters revealed the hills and valleys which had hitherto been covered by the water.</i> over the surface of all the earth, and valleys were formed over the inner parts of the earth; and the waters were rolled together and gathered into the valleys, as it is said, "And the gathering together of the waters he called seas" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the tenth paragraph (of the fourth chapter) is marked here. For a parallel text see Wertheimer, <i>op. cit.,</i> i. p. 6.</i> Forthwith the waters became proud<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “The waters became insolent and attempted to ascend to Heaven as at first until He rebuked and subdued them and placed them beneath the soles of His feet, as it is said: ‘ Who maketh a way in the sea, and a path in the mighty waters’” (Isa. 43:16). The first editions agree with our MS.</i> and they arose to cover the earth as at first, when the Holy One, blessed be He, rebuked them || and subdued them,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 104:7, Job 38:8–10, and Prov. 8:29. Eth. Enoch offers a parallel: “the sea was created, and as its foundation He set for it <i>the sand against the time of anger,</i> and it dare not pass beyond it from the creation of the world unto eternity” (lxix. 18).</i> and placed them beneath the soles of His feet,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 9:8, Ps. 77:19, and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 93:5, where our text is preserved; cf. Midrash Kônen, p. 25. The 1st ed. (<i>P.R.E</i>.) reads: “and He subdued them beneath the ends of His feet.” The Midrash should be compared with Tanchuma, Chuḳḳath. § 1, and see T.B. Baba Bathra, 74b. The subject has been discussed by Jampel in the <i>Monatsschrift</i>, 1912, p. 148.</i> and measured them with the hollow of His hand<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 40:12.</i> that they should neither decrease nor increase. He made the sand as the boundary of the sea, just like a man who makes a fence for his vineyard. When they rise and see the sand before them they return to their former place,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 10.</i> as it is said, "Fear ye not me? saith the Lord<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The second half of the verse is not given in the MS., which reads “etc.”</i>: will ye not tremble at my presence, which have placed the sand for the bound of the sea?" (Jer. 5:22).
Before the waters were gathered together the depths<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds the words “the luminaries” before the words “the depths.” This is clearly a mistake.</i> were created. These are the depths which are beneath the earth; for the earth is spread<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ Makhiri to Psalms (Ps. 136:11) reads: “the earth floats upon the depths.” The text of this section in the Jalḳuṭ is more correct than the printed editions of <i>P.R.E.</i></i> upon the water like a ship which floats in the midst of the sea, so likewise is the earth spread out over the water, as it is said, "To him that spread forth the earth above the waters…" (Ps. 136:6). He opened an entrance to the Garden of Eden<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This agrees with the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. i.: “And to the north of the garden there is a sea of water.” See Jalḳuṭ Makhiri (<i>loc. cit.</i>) for a parallel to our text. The Venice edition differs slightly from the 1st ed. and reads: “The entrance to the Garden of Eden opened therein and He brought forth thence plants upon the face of all the earth.” This 5th chapter is devoted to the account of the creation on the third day. Thus far we find the following things enumerated: (1) the gathering of the waters, (2) the appearance of the mountains and hills, (3) the transference of the plants and trees from the Garden of Eden, and we shall have (4) an account of the mists and clouds which water the face of the earth. The Book of Jubilees seems to offer a parallel: (1) “And the dry land appeared, and on that day He created for them (2) all the seas according to their separate gathering-places, and all the rivers, and the gathering of the waters in the mountains and on all the earth and all the lakes, (3) and all the dew of the earth, (4) and the seed which is sown, and all sprouting things, and fruit-bearing trees, and trees of the wood, and the Garden of Eden in Eden, and all (plants after their kind). These four great works God created on the third day” (ii. 6, 7). It seems strange that both books in connection with the third day refer to the Garden of Eden, especially as our book has already dealt with this as one of the pre-mundane creations. According to Gen. Rab. 15:3 the Garden of Eden was created <i>before</i> the creation <i>of man,</i> who was created on the sixth day, whereas Eden was created on the third day. This tradition is preserved in Slavonic Enoch (A and B) xxx. 1 and in the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan), <i>loc. cit.</i></i> because thence were planted upon the face of all the earth all kinds of trees yielding fruit according to their kind, and all kinds of herbs and grass<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “He planted thereof, and in them was their seed upon the earth.”</i> thereof, and in them (was seed), as it is said, "Wherein is the seed thereof, upon the earth" (Gen. 1:11). He prepared a table for the creatures whilst as yet they were not created,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading in the first editions is: “whilst as yet the world was not created.” This “table” is not one of the premundane creations; see T.B. Synhedrin, 38a, based on Prov. 9:1–3, and <i>cf.</i> Lev. Rab. 11:1. Gregory, Bishop of Nyssa in the fourth century <small>C.E</small>., has a similar Midrash in his work <i>de Hominis opificio</i>, 2; see also Slav. Enoch (B) XXX. 1.</i> as it is said, "Thou preparest a table before me" (Ps. 23:5). All the fountains arise from the depths to give water to all creatures.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 104:10–13.</i> 
Rabbi Joshua said: The diameter<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> On this theme see T.B. Pesachim, 94a, and Gen. Rab. 4:5, and see Theodor’s notes on p. 29 of his edition for further parallels.</i> of the earth is equal to a journey of sixty years,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Oxford MS. (2835, c. 27) reads “five hundred years”; cf. T.J. Berakhoth, 2c; T.B. Chagigah, 12a, and Gen. Rab. 6:6.</i> and one of the depths which is near to Gehinnom bubbles with water and produces water<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “and produces delight for the sons of man.” On the subject referred to in the text see T.B. Sabbath, 39a.</i> for the delight of the sons of man.
Rabbi Jehudah || said: Once every month ducts<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text is preserved in Jalḳuṭ to Psalms (Ps. 42 § 744). On “Silonoth” (ducts) see Jastrow, T.D. 979b. Gaster, Jeraḥmeel ii. 5, renders here “rivulets ascend from the depths,” etc.</i> rise from the depths to irrigate the face of all the earth, as it is said, "And there went up a <i>mist</i> from the earth and watered<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse is not given by the MS., which reads “etc.”</i> the whole face of the ground" (Gen. 2:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The LXX renders this verse: “But a <i>fountain</i> ascended out of the earth”; see <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> p. 25 note.</i> The clouds cause the seas to hear the sound of their waterspouts,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Psalms (Ps. 42:16), where our text occurs with variant readings; thus, instead of “Zinôrôthiham,” which means “their splashing,” or “duct,” or “spout,” we find “Kinôrôthiham” (“their harps”).</i> and the seas cause the depths to hear the sound of their waterspouts, and the deep calls to the deep to bring up waters to give them to the clouds, as it is said, "Deep calleth unto deep at the sound of thy waterspouts" (Ps. 42:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ta‘anith, 25b, for the application of this verse in connection with the water ceremonies on the Feast of Tabernacles.</i>
The clouds draw water from the depths, as it is said, "He causeth the vapours to ascend from the ends<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Where originally the water was.</i> of the earth" (<i>ibid.</i> cxxxv. 7), and in every place where the King commands them,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 37:11–13. The rain illustrates the working of Divine Providence; cf. Jer. 14:22.</i> there they cause rain (to fall), and forthwith the earth becomes fruitful and yields produce like a widow who becomes pregnant through debauchery.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This rain would not be the rain of blessing, cf. T.B. Ta’anith, 6b.</i> But when the Holy One, blessed be He, desires to bless the produce of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 65:9, 10, and cf. T.B. Ta‘anith, 8b.</i> and to give provision to the creatures,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This phrase does not occur in the 1st ed. See Ps. 132:15.</i> He opens the good treasuries in heaven and sends rain upon the earth, namely, the fructifying rain,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The rain from heaven is full of vitalizing power; see <i>infra,</i> pp. 63 and 167. The actual expression in our context is “the masculine waters.” Eth. Enoch liv. 8 offers a parallel: “And all the waters shall be joined with the waters, that which is above the heavens is the <i>masculine,</i> and the water which is beneath the earth is <i>feminine.”</i> See Charles’ interesting note (8) on p. 107 of his edition, where he quotes T.J. Berakhoth, 9:2, “the upper water is male and the lower water is female.”</i> and forthwith the earth becomes fruitful like a bride who conceives from her first husband and produces offspring of blessing, as it is said, "The Lord shall open unto thee his good treasury the heaven"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse continues: “To give the rain of thy land in its season and to bless all the work of thy hand.” This is given in the B.M. MS. The 1st ed. and later editions add: “and it is written, ‘For as a young man marrieth a virgin, so shall thy sons marry thee ‘<sup></sup> (Isa. 62:5), and it is written, ‘ For as the rain cometh down, and the snow from heaven.<sup></sup>… and watereth the earth, and maketh it bring forth and bud, and giveth seed to the sower and bread to the eater’” (<i>ibid.</i> lv. 10).</i> (Deut. 28:12).

Chapter 6

CHAPTER VI<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the fifth chapter begins here.</i><br><small>THE PLANETS; THE COURSE OF THE SUN</small> [5<small>B</small>. i.]<br>O<small>N</small> the fourth day He connected together<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The B.M. MS. reads here “created.” The word in the printed texts means “associated” or “joined.” On the legend see Gen. Rab. 6:3 and T.B. Chullin, 60b, which is translated in <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 12 f.; and see Pal. Targum, Gen. 1:16.</i> the two luminaries,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the two great luminaries.”</i> of which one was not greater (in size) than the other.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This legend occurs in Eth. Enoch lxxii. 37, “but as regards size they are both equal,” and cf. Slavonic Enoch xvi. 7. Our text reads (if taken quite literally): “This one was not greater than that one, and that one was not greater than this one.”</i> They were equal<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The equality was implied in the words of the Scripture, “the two great lights.” The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “but the two of them were equal as though they were one.”</i> as regards their height,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Above the earth, or firmament.</i> || qualities,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>e.g.</i> they have the same shape.</i> and illuminating powers,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Pal. Targ. Gen. 1:16 offers a parallel here.</i> as it is said, "And God made <i>the two great</i> lights" (Gen. 1:16). Rivalry ensued between them, one said to the other, I am bigger than thou art. The other rejoined, I am bigger than thou art.
What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The B.M. MS. adds: “to restore peace between them. He made the one smaller because it had slandered its companion.” See Gen. Rab. 6:3.</i> so that there should be peace between them? He made the one larger and the other smaller,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and cf. 3 Baruch ix. 7. The Midrash is also preserved in the Machẓor Vitry, p. 154, reading of the Sabbath morning liturgy. Cf. Singer, p. 129. See also Baer’s ‘<i>Abodath Israel,</i> p. 212, note, for the reading in the Ṭur: “and He diminished (<span>והקטין</span>) the figure of the moon.”</i> as it is said, "The <i>greater</i> light to rule the day,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. does not give the second half of the verse, it merely reads “etc.”</i> and the <i>lesser</i> light to rule the night and the stars he also made" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 12 f.</i>
All the stars minister<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The word in the text may mean <i>serve</i>, or <i>minister to the needs of, or to be in attendance on others</i>, or <i>to be placed over</i>, hence to influence, or rule.</i> to the seven planets,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “Stars of the hours.” The 1st ed. reads, “the seven stars and all the hours,” but subsequent editions read, “the seven stars of the hours.” The first editions give the names in the following order: Mercury, the Moon, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, and Venus. These editions continue: “And they minister to the seven days of the week.” The idea implied is that each planet influences the world for one hour by day and by night. Thus—<br><img src="data:image/jpg;base64,/9j/4AAQSkZJRgABAQAAAQABAAD/2wBDAAgGBgcGBQgHBwcJCQgKDBQNDAsLDBkSEw8UHRofHh0a HBwgJC4nICIsIxwcKDcpLDAxNDQ0Hyc5PTgyPC4zNDL/2wBDAQkJCQwLDBgNDRgyIRwhMjIyMjIy For full explanation see Rashi on T.B. Berakhoth, 59b, and on T.B. ‘Erubin, 56a. The seven planets are mentioned in the Sepher Jezirah iv. 7 by the same names as in our text. See also Baraitha d. Shemuel, ch. iii.</i> and their names are: Sun, Venus, Mercury, the Moon, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The seven planets in the order of the text are represented by the following letters: Ch (Sun), N (Venus), K (Mercury), L (Moon), Sh (Saturn), Z (Jupiter), M (Mars). The letters represent the Hebrew names of the planets.</i> The mnemonic of their service is KZNSh ChLM, by night; ChLM KZNSh by day and KLSh ZMChN for the hours of the night; ChNKL ShZM for the hours of the day.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The whole of this sentence is missing in the printed editions.</i> On the first day Mercury and the Sun, on the second day Jupiter and the Moon, on the third day Venus and Mars, on the fourth day Saturn and Mercury, on the fifth day the Sun and Jupiter, on the sixth day the Moon and Venus, on the seventh day Mars and Saturn.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The seven planets were believed to move in seven different orbits; see Philo, <i>op. cit.</i> 38, i. M. 27, C.W. i. 112. Origen, <i>contra Celsum,</i> vi. 21, speaks of “the spheres of the planets.” In the next chapter of Origen we hear of the mysteries of Mithras, and in connection with the rites of this cult the seven planets are mentioned. The order is as follows: Saturn, Venus, Jupiter, Mercury, Mars, the Moon, the Sun. This is exactly the reverse order of the mnemonic in our text for the service of the planets by day. In chapter xxxi. Origen deals with the “ruling spirits” accepted by the teaching of the Gnostics; these “ruling spirits” are the seven planets. The system has fortunately been preserved in the <i>Pistis Sophia</i> (ed. Mead), pp. 360 ff. The Church Father John of Damascus, in his <i>Doctrine of Faith,</i> ii. 7, also mentions the seven planets. See also Hippolytus, <i>Philosophumena,</i> iv. 6 ff.</i> All of them minister to the twelve constellations<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Zodiac. On this subject see John of Damascus, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and cf. <i>J.E.</i> iv. 244 f. Slavonic Enoch xxx. reads: “The sun that he should go according to each sign of the Zodiac; and the course of the moon through the twelve signs of the Zodiac,” and see Eth. Enoch lxxiii.–lxxiv.</i> which correspond to the twelve months. The constellations are: Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricornus, Aquarius, and Pisces.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “These (<i>i.e.</i> the constellations) were created in the work of the Creation to rule the world, and thus are their ordinances. And these seven servants<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> were created, and He placed them in the firmament of the heavens.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> Our MS. agrees here with the Oxford MS. (d. 35).</i> All the constellations minister to<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the word should be rendered “serve”; see <i>supra,</i> p. 32, note 1. Gaster’s Jeraḥmeel iv. 2 has “rules” in reference to the sun, and “serves” in connection with the other planets.</i> the days of the sun.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Does this mean that the constellations influence the months, there being twelve constellations corresponding to the twelve months? Perhaps the reference is to the fact that the sun is in each constellation for 30 days, 10 hours, 30 minutes (<i>i.e.</i> a solar month). The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads, “the days of the solar year.” The Venice edition reads: “the days of the solar month.” According to John of Damascus (<i>loc. cit.</i>)—<br><img QaNa6J8TNS1bXNLvrzTb6FRDLabztYYyGC1D4v0xY/hLKuj6BPaQT3iSpAMvIy5B3EdcmvcWVWGG AP1oKKwAKggeooA8P8U6gfH2k6BoWkaffC6ikjMzz27IIdoGTkj27V0us3McXxN8OI9rdTJaW8kU sqW7FVdgAvOMdjXpSxIpJVQCeuBS7RnOBmgDyT42K0cfh+8FrI8Vvdh5JEQnYvvisJfFVhqHxqtd StIZ/s8lnsR3hYeYwHuOnavdZoYp4zHNEkiH+FhkVGun2aOrrawh0GFYRjKj2oA+fNd1XUfEXgjX C0UlLQAUUZooAKKKKACik70tABRRRQAlLRRQAGkoooAB0paKKAEooooAWiiigBDS0UUAJQKKKAFp KKKAFooooATvS0UUAFFFFABRRRQAGkoooAKKKKACloooASiiigAFLRRQAlLRRQAhooooAWkoooAK O1FFAC0UUUAJS0UUAIaXtRRQAnagUUUAFHaiigApaKKAEpRRRQAUUUUAFBoooASiiigAo7UUUAFL RRQAUUUUABooooA//9k= "><br>The 1st ed. adds “Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Venus, Saturn. Sun, Moon, Saturn, and Mercury minister to each constellation 30 (days) 4 hours like an attendant, and just as the Sun and Moon and Mercury enter simultaneously.” The text is evidently corrupt.</i> Now the days of the solar month are 30 days, 10 hours and a half,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. adds here: “and during the days of the lunar month two constellations serve for four days and eight hours.” The meaning is not evident. 4 days, 8 hours × 7 = 30 days, 8 hours.</i> and each constellation ministers to the || days of the solar month for two days and a half, so that two constellations (minister for) five days.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The sense to be conveyed seems to be that in a solar month every 2½ days is under the influence of a constellation, the last 10½ hours being reckoned as part of the service of the constellation which is next in order to that constellation which was placed over the last 2½ days of the month. We shall see that each constellation is served by the Moon for 2½ days, or, as John of Damascus says (<i>loc. cit.</i>), “The Moon passes through the twelve constellations in each month.”</i> The chief<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the constellation.</i> which begins at the beginning of the solar month is the same chief which completes<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This would then mean that the next constellation begins its influence at the beginning of the next solar month.</i> at the end of the solar month; the one which opens is the one which closes.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> It seems that the last 10½ hours of the solar month are under the influence of the constellation which ruled at the beginning of that month.</i>
The great cycle of the sun is 28 years,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, <i>loc. cit.</i>; T.B. Sabbath, 129b, with Rashi.</i> and therein are seven small cycles each of four years.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The order of the planets which begin the seven small cycles respectively is Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, the Sun, Venus, Mercury, and the Moon, a cycle of four years being supposed to elapse between the beginning of the rule of each of these planets.</i> The number of days of the solar year<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> 1st ed. reads “solar years,” the later texts read “the sun.”</i> is 365 and a quarter of a day. The seasons<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Teḳuphah; see Jewish Calendar, 1915–16, edited by the present writer, pp. 31, 35, etc., for the Teḳuphah. The word means “turn,” or “cycle”; cf. Ex. 34:22 and Ps. 19:6. It means in our book season, or (1) vernal equinox, or (2) the summer solstice, or (3) the autumnal equinox, or (4) the winter solstice. See Rashi on T.B. Berakhoth, <i>loc. cit.</i> where we learn that the first Teḳuphah of Nisan at the Creation was on the fourth day (Wednesday). Can Jubilees i. 14 and ii. 9 refer to Teḳuphah? See Pal. Targ. Gen. 1:14, which reads: “And God said: Let there be lights in the expanse of the heavens, to distinguish between the day and the night; and let them be for signs and seasons for festivals and for the numbering by them of the calculation of the days and for the sanctification by them of new moons and new years, (for) intercalations of months and intercalations of years and Teḳuphoth of the Sun and the Molad of the Moon and cycles.” Etheridge’s version (<i>The Targums,</i> i. p. 159) is inaccurate.</i> of the solar year are four, each season (consisting of) 91 days 7½ hours. The beginnings of the cycles of the seasons are the 4th, 2nd, 7th, 5th, 3rd, 1st, and 6th (days).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The seven days respectively of the seven small cycles. The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “The Teḳuphoth are at the beginning of the night of the fourth day, the beginning of the night of the second day”… concluding with “the beginning of the night of the sixth day.”</i> Between each cycle there are 5 days and 6 (hours).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Is the text faulty here? The interval of five days is apparent from the preceding sentence in the text.</i>
The Teḳuphoth (<i>i.e.</i> seasons) of the small cycle are four in each year, some of them (last) 91 days 7½ hours and some last 92 days.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This means that the year equals 4 × 91 days, 7½ hours=365½ days. The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “Some of them (last) 91 days and some of them 92 days.” This reading seems preferable to our text and seems to point to 366 days in the year, <i>i.e.</i> two seasons of 91 days each and two of 92 days each. Luria rejects the reading, “Some of them (last) 92 days.”</i> The first year of the cycle (of four years) has its Teḳuphah in Nisan at 6 p.m.; in the second year at 12 p.m.; in the third year at 6 a.m.; in the fourth year at 12 a.m.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria’s reading in the latter part of Note 22, <i>in loc.,</i> has been adopted, as the MS. text seems to be unintelligible. The MS. reads: The first year of the cycle is A–G (1st and 3rd letters of the Hebrew alphabet); the second year is B–B (2nd letter of Hebrew alphabet); the third year is GAD (3rd, 1st, and 4th letters); the fourth year is DD. The reading adopted for the translation gives the following abbreviations: A–A, B–V, G–A, D–V, where the first letters of each set refer to the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th years (of the small cycle) respectively; the 2nd letters indicate the hours when the Teḳuphoth of Nisan in the four years begin, namely: 6 p.m. (A), 12 p.m. (V), 6 a.m. (A), and 12 a.m. (V).</i>
The four beginnings of the Teḳuphah of the four months of Nisan<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In each cycle of four years.</i> commence at the beginning of the night,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Jewish day consists of night, lasting 12 hours, which begins at 6 p.m., and day, lasting 12 hours and commencing at 6 a.m.</i> at midnight, at the beginning of the day,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> 6 a.m.</i> and at noon (respectively). The rest of the other (days of the) || Teḳuphoth are as follows: ẒCh; GYCh; VACh; ṬDCh.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> ẒCh =7th and 8th letters of Hebrew alphabet.<br>GYCh=3rd, 10th, and 8th letters of Hebrew alphabet.<br>VACh =6th, 1st, and 8th letters of Hebrew alphabet.<br>ṬDCh =9th, 4th, and 8th letters of Hebrew alphabet.<br>Ch (8th letter) is an abbreviation for the word (<span>חצי</span>) meaning “half.” The abbreviations mean:—<br>When the Teḳuphah of Nisan is the 1st hour (A) of the night, <i>i.e.</i> at 6 p.m., the Teḳuphah of Tammuẓ is 7½ hours (ẒCh) later, <i>i.e.</i> 1.30 a.m. The Teḳuphah of Tishri is at 3 hours of the day (G), <i>i.e.</i> 9 a.m., and the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth is 10½ hours of the day (YCh), <i>i.e.</i> 4.30 p.m. Again, when the Teḳuphah of Nisan is the 6th hour, <i>i.e.</i> mid-night (V), the Teḳuphah of Tammuẓ is 1½ hour of the day (ACh), <i>i.e.</i> 7.30 a.m., and the Teḳuphah of Tishri is 9 hours of the day (Ṭ), <i>i. e</i> 3 p.m., and the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth is 4½ hours of the following night (DCh), <i>i.e.</i> at 10.30 p.m.<sup></sup></i>
The first Teḳuphah of Nisan<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> At the era of the Creation.</i> took place at the beginning (of the hours) of Saturn.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Saturn is the planet for the eve of the fourth day at 6 o’clock p.m. on Tuesday. See <i>supra,</i> p. 32, note 2.</i> The Teḳuphah of Tammuz (took place) at the middle (of the hours) of Saturn.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> 7½ hours later is still the hour of Saturn; this would be at 1.30 a.m. Wednesday.</i> The Teḳuphah of Tishri (occurred) at the beginning of the hours of Jupiter.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> 7½ hours later is the hour of Jupiter at 9 a.m. Wednesday.</i> The Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth (took place) at the middle (of the hours) of Jupiter.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> 7½ hours later is still in Jupiter at 4.30 p.m. Wednesday afternoon.</i> And thus with all the other Teḳuphoth, which occur at the beginning of the hours or at the middle of the hours.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to the service of the planets over the hours, as can be seen from the notes above; the two Teḳuphoth are either at the beginning or at the middle of the hours.</i>
The first cycle<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the seven Teḳuphoth cycles referred to above, the first begins on the fourth day, <i>i.e.</i> Wednesday (which commences on Tuesday at 6 p.m., which is the hour of Saturn).</i> took place at the beginning of the hour of Saturn, (and the names of the Planets of the hours are) Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, the Sun, Venus, Mercury, and the Moon. The second cycle occurred in the hour (of the Planet) which is in front of it,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In reference to the position of its orbit around the earth as centre. In this connection the position of the planets is as follows: nearest to the earth we have the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn.</i> (<i>i.e.</i>) at the beginning of the hour of Jupiter. The third cycle occurred at the beginning of the hour of Mars. The fourth cycle entered at the beginning of the hour of the Sun. The fifth cycle entered at the beginning of the hour of Venus. The sixth cycle entered at the beginning of the hour of Mercury. The seventh cycle entered at the beginning (of the hour) of the Moon. (At) the end of seven hours,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> It has been suggested by R. Elijah of Vilna that this reference to the seven hours should be omitted. Perhaps the reading should be “At the end of the seven planets of the hours,” <i>i.e.</i> the cycle recommences with Saturn. The Teḳuphoth of Nisan are as follows:—<br>The third cycle falls on Saturday, Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday at 6 and 12 p.m. and 6 and 12 a.m. respectively in the 9th, 10th, 11th, and 12th years respectively.<br>The fourth cycle falls on Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Sunday at 6 and 12 p.m. and 6 and 12 a.m. respectively in the 13th, 14th, 15th, and 16th years respectively.<br>The fifth cycle falls on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday at 6 and 12 p.m. and 6 and 12 a.m. respectively in the 17th, 18th, 19th, and 20th years respectively.<br>The sixth cycle falls on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday at 6 and 12 p.m. and 6 and 12 a.m. respectively in the 21st, 22nd, 23rd, and 24th years respectively.<br>The seventh cycle falls on Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday at 6 and 12 p.m. and 6 and 12 a.m. respectively in the 25th, 26th, 27th, and 28th years respectively.<br>It must be borne in mind that the first two Teḳuphoth of every cycle are p.m., and therefore the actual English day in these cases is nominally one day earlier than the Jewish day.</i> at the end of seven cycles, at the end of 35 days<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of the 1st ed. Later editions are faulty, and read “65 days.” The number 35 is due to 7 × 5 days, the latter being the interval between each small cycle of four years, during which there are 16 Teḳuphoth, and each Teḳuphah is 7½ hours’ interval later than its predecessor. 7 = the number of cycles.</i> of the great cycle of 28 years, the Teḳuphah cycle returns (<i>i.e.</i> begins again) at the beginning of the fourth day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Tuesday evening at six o’clock, when the fourth day (Wednesday) of the Hebrew week begins.</i> in the hour of Saturn in the hour when it was created.
In 366 (degrees)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> “Degrees” according to the reading in the first two editions. The 1st ed. reads “365 degrees.”</i> the sun rises and declines, it rises 183 (degrees) || in the east, and it declines 183 (degrees) in the west corresponding to the 365<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. a later writer has written “6” above the “5.” The first editions read, “according to the days of the solar year.”</i> days of the solar year. (The sun) goes forth through 366<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts read 366 apertures. According to T.J. Rosh Ha-Shanah ii. 5, 58a, l. 41 ff., “The Holy One, blessed be He, created 365 windows for the service of the world: 182 in the east and 182 in the west and one in the centre of the firmament, whence it came forth at the beginning at the Creation.” See also Ex. Rab. xv. 22: “The Holy One, blessed be He, created 365 windows in the firmament, 183 on the east and 182 on the west.” The Jalḳuṭ on 1 Kings, §185. compares the knops mentioned in 1 Kings vii. 24 to “the 365 windows which are in the east and in the west, for the sun rises in one in the east and sets in one in the west.” This section of the Jalḳuṭ is taken from the Midrash Tadsheh (cf. Epstein, Midrash Tadsheh, p. xvi). Further parallels are to be found in Buber’s Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 19:11, and Jalḳuṭ on Psalms (xix.), § 673, and on Eccles. § 967. The astronomical theories of our book are not in agreement with the Rabbinical system set forth in the Talmud and Midrashim. It seems that our author held the view that the solar year had 366 days. Each half-year the sun passes through 91, plus 91, plus 1 apertures, or in one year through 366 apertures. Now we find a parallel teaching in the Slavonic Enoch xiii. 2: “And I saw the six great gates open, each gate having sixty-one stadia.” Thus far Text B.; see Charles’ ed.. p. 15, and cf. Eth. Enoch lxxii. 2 ff. on the course of the sun. Here also “windows” are mentioned. The whole of this chapter should be read in comparison with our text. Eth. Enoch adopts the strange calculation that the solar year has 364 days, though he was acquainted with the year of 365½ days. Does our book attempt a new solution? or, as I venture to suggest, did our author borrow from Slavonic Enoch? This seems the most probable view.</i> apertures and enters by the east; 90 days<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read 91 days. This agrees with the Oxford MSS. (d. 35) and (O. 167) and also Gaster’s MS.</i> it is in the south (east) quarter, 91 days in the north (east) quarter and one aperture is in the middle<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This aperture separates the 91 N.E. windows from the 91 S.E. windows, and the sum total equals 183, which agrees with our text: “it rises 183 (degrees) in the east.”</i> and its name is Nogah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>נוגה</span>, or “Venus.” The word means light. The Venice edition reads “the aperture Nogah.”</i>
(At) the Teḳuphah of Tishri<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> About the time of the autumnal equinox; see <i>J.E.</i> xii. 76 f. The Teḳuphah Tishri falls now on October 7th, about 14 days after the equinox.</i> (the sun) begins from the aperture of Nogah and goes through its revolutions towards the south quarter, through one aperture after another until it reaches the aperture of Bilgah.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read (<span>שבתאי</span>) “Saturn.”</i> (At) the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth (the sun) begins from the aperture of Bilgah<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read (<span>שבתאי</span>) “Saturn.”</i> and continues its course, returning backward through one aperture after another until it reaches the aperture of Ta'alumah,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “darkness.” See Targum on Job 28:11.</i> through which the light goes forth,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation is not given by the Oxford MS. (d. 35).</i> as it is said, "<i>And the thing that is hid</i> bringeth he forth to light" (Job 28:11). (At) the Teḳuphah of Nisan (the sun) begins from the aperture of Ta'alumah,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “through which the light goeth forth.”</i> and it<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The sun.</i> goes to the north quarter through one aperture after another until it reaches the aperture No'aman.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “pleasantness.” Nature is at her best at this period of the year. The MS. reads “Nô’aman,” the first two editions read “Na’amôn.”</i> (At) the Teḳuphah of Ṭammuz (the sun) begins from the aperture No'aman and goes on its course, returning backwards through aperture after aperture until it reaches the aperture Cheder<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “secret chamber.”</i> whence the whirlwind goes forth, as it is said, "Out of <i>the chamber</i> cometh the storm<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits the second half of the verse, substituting “etc.”</i> and cold out of the scattering winds" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxvii. 9).
Through these apertures which are in the east (the sun) || goes forth and opposite to them<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The apertures on the east.</i> in the west (the sun) sets. The Shekhinah is always in the west.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, 25a, and T.B. Synhedrin, 91b.</i> (The sun) sets and worships<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “bows down.”</i> before the King of Kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Lord of all worlds! I have done according to all that Thou hast commanded me.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Deut. 26:14 for phraseology.</i>
The aperture which is in the midst of the firmament is named M'zarim<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “scattering winds.” See Job 37:9 and Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> and (the sun) does not go forth or set<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “does not go in or go out.”</i> therein except once in its great cycle;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> once in twenty-eight years.</i> (thereon) it goes through it as on the day when it was created.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “on the day when the world was created, on the day when it was created.”</i> At night the sun is in the west.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> when it sets. The Prague edition reads here: “on the day it was created at night and in the west.”</i> At the Teḳuphah of Tishri and at the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth the sun goes on its course in the south quarter and in the waters of the Ocean<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See John of Damascus, <i>op. cit.</i> ii. 9, with reference to the ocean which surrounds the earth.</i> (which are) between the ends of the heavens and the ends of the earth where it is submerged.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “where it sets.”</i> For the night is long and the way is long<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> To traverse half of the west, the north, and half of the east. The apparent risings of the sun are all in the east from the point of view of the spectator on the earth; half the year the rising is south of the earth’s equator, the other half of the year this is north of the equator; thus the setting in the west corresponds to the rising, and accounts for the “long way” after setting in the winter.</i> until (the sun) reaches the aperture which is in the east, (even) the aperture through which it desires to go forth,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> At its next rising. The following reading is given by the first two editions: “At the Teḳuphoth of Nisan and Tammuẓ the sun goes forth on its course to the north quarter to the waters of the Ocean which are between the ends of the heavens and the ends of the earth; for the night is short and the way is short (after sunset) until it reaches the apertures which are in the east through which it desires to go forth.”</i> as it is said, "It goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north" (Eccles. 1:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Ecclesiastes refers to the wind here, but our text applies this to the sun. See the Targum to this verse of Ecclesiastes.</i> It goes to the south at the Teḳuphah of Tishri and at the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth, and turns to the north at the Teḳuphah of Nisan and at the Teḳuphah of Tammuz. It goes on its course for six months in the south quarter, and for six months in the north quarter, and owing to its circuits the sun<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. wind or quarter. See previous note.</i> returns to the aperture which is in the east. The sun has three letters of (God's) Name written upon his heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jeraḥmeel iii. 4: “Three letters of the Ineffable Name of God are written upon the heart of the sun.” The sun has three different terms in Hebrew.</i> and the angels lead him;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Slav. Enoch xiv. 2–4 says: “When he (the sun) goes out by the Western gate four hundred <i>angels</i> take his <i>crown</i> and bring it to the Lord. And the sun revolves in his <i>chariot</i>… and when he comes near the east… the four hundred angels bring his crown and crown him.” There is probably some connection between this passage and <i>P.R.E.</i> Eth. Enoch refers to the sun’s chariot (lxxii. 5). See also 3 Baruch, ch. vi. 1 f. ed. Charles, <i>Apocrypha and Pseudepigrapha,</i> ii. p. 536. This Apocalypse of Baruch offers also other parallels to our Midrash, see Introduction, and cf. <i>J.E.</i> ii. 550.</i> such || as lead him by day do not lead him by night, and such as lead him by night do not lead him by day. The sun rides in a chariot and rises, crowned as a bridegroom,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and he goeth forth and rejoiceth like a strong man.”</i> as it is said, "Which is as a bridegroom coming out of his chamber, and rejoiceth as a strong man to run his course" (Ps. 19:5). The sun's rays and face, which are turned downwards (to the earth), are of hail;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “The sun’s rays and face which look downwards are of fire and his rays and face which look upwards are of hail.” The Venice edition adds “to the earth” after “downwards.” See Eth. Enoch iv.</i> and were it not for the hail which quenches the flames of fire<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “his face of fire.”</i> the world would be consumed by fire, as it is said, "And there is nothing hid from the heat thereof" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). In winter (the sun) turns the upper (half of) his face downwards,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the lower (half of) his face upwards, and were it not for the fire which warms the hail.”</i> and were it not for the fire which warms the face of hail the world could not endure because of the ice (cold), as it is said, "Who can stand before his cold?" (<i>ibid.</i> cxlvii. 17). These are the ends of the ways of the sun.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Compare with our text Eth. Enoch lxxxii. 15–20.</i>

Chapter 7

CHAPTER VII<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In MS. this is ch. vi.</i><br><small>THE COURSE OF THE MOON</small> [7<small>A</small>. i.]<br>R<small>ABBAN</small> J<small>OCHANAN BEN</small> Ẓ<small>AKKAI</small>, Rabban Gamaliel, R. Ishmael, R. Elazar ben 'Arakh, R. Eliezer ben Hyrḳanos, and R. 'Aḳiba<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> On Rabban Gamaliel ii. see <i>J.E.</i> v. 560 ff.; on R. Ishmael see Bacher, T. i. 232 ff., and <i>J.E.</i> vi. 648 ff.; on R. Elaẓar b. ‘Arakh see <i>J.E</i>. v. 96 f.; for life of R. ‘Aḳiba see Bacher, T. i. 263 ff. It is difficult to understand how R. ‘ Aḳiba or R. Ishmael could have discussed Torah with Rabban Jochanan b. Ẓakkai.</i> were expounding<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “were sitting and expounding.”</i> (the laws of) the Molad<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Molad is the conjunction of Moon and Sun; see Schwarz, <i>Der jüdische Kalender,</i> pp. 58 f.</i> of the moon. They said:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The margin of the MS. has, “and all of them” (said).</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, spake one word and the heavens were created<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 45:12. See Othijoth d. R. ‘Aḳiba, third paragraph of letter Resh, ed. Jellinek, <i>B.H.M.</i> iii. p. 46, and compare John i. 3, where the Logos or Word is the Creator.</i> as the residence of the Throne of His Glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “His Kingdom.”</i> as it is said, "By the <i>word</i> of the Lord were the heavens made" (Ps. 33:6). But in connection with the (creation of the) host of heaven He laboured with great labour.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “great labour is mentioned, as it is said, And all the host of them by the <i>breath</i> of his mouth’ (<i>ibid.</i>).”</i> || What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He blew with His mouth the wind of the breath<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Breath implies more than a mere word.</i> of life<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He blew with the wind of the breath of His mouth.”</i> and all the host of heaven were created,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> “Simultaneously” is added by the first editions.</i> as it is said, "And <i>all</i> the host of them by the <i>breath</i> of his mouth" (<i>ibid.</i>).
All the stars and constellations<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> “And the two luminaries” is added by the first editions.</i> were created at the beginning of<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> 6 p.m.</i> the night of the fourth<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Tuesday evening at 6 p.m., when the fourth day began.</i> day, one (luminary) did not precede the other except by the period of two-thirds of an hour. Therefore every motion<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “action.”</i> of the sun (is done) with deliberation, and every motion of the moon is (done) quickly.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Since the sun was created just before the moon the latter hastens to overtake the former.</i> The distance covered by the sun in thirteen days and a fifth<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “12 days.”</i> is covered by the moon in one day,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The text of the printed editions is hopelessly corrupt. They state: “The distance covered by the sun all the days of the year is traversed by the moon in one day.”</i> and (the distance) covered by the sun all the days of the year, the moon traverses (the same distance) in forty-one days.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “28 days.” The Venice text reads: “30 days,” which seems to be more correct than “41 days” of our MS. Our author seems to treat numbers without any regard to the exact amount. By treating fractions as though they were whole numbers, we may find an explanation of the difficulty which has already occurred in the previous chapter; perhaps the 365¼ days of the year were described as 366 so as to avoid the fraction. The text should probably read thus: “The distance covered by the sun in 12 days is covered by the moon in 1 day, and (the distance) covered by the sun all the days of the year, the moon traverses in 30 days.” See, however, T.J. Rosh Ha-Shanah ii. 5, p. 58a, which is possibly the source of our text here. The lunar month according to the Hebrew astronomers was said to be 29 days, 12 hours, and 793/1080 parts of an hour (1 minute=18 parts). Our book sometimes treats this as a whole number by saying, “the month has 30 days,” or we find the more exact reference to 29 days, 12 hours, and 40 minutes, neglecting the 4 minutes, 3⅓ seconds, which really belong to the sum total. On the entire subject of the Calendar see the valuable article by S. Poznaúski in Hastings’ <i>Encyclopœdia of Religion and Ethics,</i> iii. 17 ff.</i> All the days serve for the beginning of the Molad of the (new) moon; (for the following series<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The series of the small cycles of three years in which the Molad of the next cycle falls on the day which was anterior to that on which the previous Molad fell. The calculation is based on the length of the lunar month being reckoned as measuring 29 days, 12 hours, 40 minutes, so that in one year the surplus over the complete week equals 4 days, 8 hours (since each lunar month has 4 complete weeks and 1 day, 12 hours and 40 minutes; and this surplus multiplied by 12 equals 18 days, 8 hours, <i>i.e.</i> 4 days, 8 hours beyond the two weeks), and in three years we have a surplus of 13 days (two weeks less one day); therefore the day of the next series to the one in question will be one day earlier than the preceding series; see Schwarz, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 23, and Lewisohn, <i>Geschichte und System des jüdischen Kalenderwesens,</i> p. 25, note 84.</i>) the days are reckoned backward; at the beginning of the night of the fourth day<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Tuesday, at 6 p.m.</i> the beginning of the Molad (new moon) was in the hour of Saturn;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 32, note 2. Saturn is represented by Sh.</i> and the mnemonic is ShNZ KMLChSh. After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the third day, and the beginning of the Molad (new moon) is in the hour of Venus. After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the second day, the beginning of the Molad is in the hour of Jupiter. After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the first day, the beginning of the Molad || is in the hour of Mercury.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “Kôkhab Chamah,” which is not the usual appellation for Mercury; see Zunz, <i>Gesammelte Schriften,</i> iii. p. 243.</i> After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the Sabbath, the beginning of the Molad is in the hour of Mars. After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the sixth day, the beginning of the Molad is in the hour of the Moon. After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the fifth day, the beginning of the Molad is in the hour of the Sun. After three years of the small cycle the day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Molad at the beginning of the new cycle.</i> of the next cycle (reverts to) the beginning of the night of the fourth day, the beginning of the Molad reverts to the hour of Saturn as in the hour when it was created.
The great cycle of the moon is 21 years; it has 7 small cycles each containing 8 years.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Each constellation ministers to the days of the lunar month.”</i> The total of the days of the lunar month is 29½ days, 40 minutes, and 73 parts.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> As we have seen, 1 hour = 1080 parts, therefore 4 1/18 minutes. Luria holds that the expression “73 parts” is an interpolation. See T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 25a, on the question of the duration of a lunar month, which agrees with our text.</i> Each constellation serves the days of the lunar month for 2 days and 8 hours; three constellations serve for 7 days. The chief<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The constellation.</i> which begins on the new moon (of the lunar month) is the same which concludes at the end of the lunar month.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The twelve constellations serve or influence 28 days of the lunar month; the remaining 1½ days, etc., are under the influence of the constellation which presided at the beginning of the month.</i> The moon becomes new at every Molad, once at night and the next time<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “once.”</i> by day, || and this is their sign: "And it was evening and it was morning" (Gen. 1:5). Between one Molad and (the corresponding) Molad in the ensuing year (there elapse) 4 days, 8 hours, and 876 parts.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “4 days. 8 hours, and 873 parts.” This is incorrect. Luria reads: “4 days and 8 hours.” The basis of his assumption, which is unwarranted, is the theory that the lunar month =4 weeks and <i>1 day, 12 hours, and 40 minutes,</i> and this surplus multiplied by 12 =18 days, 8 hours, <i>i.e</i>. 2 weeks and 4 days, 8 hours. Again this surplus multiplied by 3 (the small cycle) =13 days exactly. Our MS. is quite correct; see Hastings’ <i>Encyclopœdia of Religion and Ethics,</i> iv. p. 120. The 1st and 2nd eds. add: “the difference between a great cycle and a small cycle is only 13 days.”<sup></sup></i>
From one small cycle to the next cycle (elapse) 13 days, 2619 parts.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This means 13 days, 2 hours, 25½ minutes.</i> When<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The text in the printed edition reads: “In the west at the time.” The reference is probably to the relation between the position of the sun and moon (1) in the winter and (2) at the beginning of the conjunction of the moon and sun. See T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 24a, with Rashi’s commentary at top of page.</i> the sun goes in the south quarter, the moon goes in the north quarter, and when the sun goes in the north quarter<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the summer the sun is more in the north than in the winter, and the moon is in conjunction in the south-west, and in the summer its position is south of the sun at its conjunction.</i> the moon goes in the south quarter. All the hours serve for the beginning of the Molad of the moon in a retrospective order, according to the order "ShLKNChM and Z."<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. omits this mnemonic.</i> In the first year at the beginning of the night of the fourth day the beginning of the Molad (conjunction of the moon) is in the hour of Saturn (Sh). In the second year<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> “In the hour following” is found in some of the late editions. The difference between one year and the next in this connection is taken to be 4 days, 8 hours; if the first Molad were at 6 p.m. Tuesday, in the next year it will be 4 days, 8 hours later, <i>i.e.</i> Sunday 2 a.m., which is the hour of the moon.
