"><br>Speaking of the sun and moon, Eth. Enoch says (lxxviii. 5): “And they set and enter the portals of the west, and make their revolutions to the north and come forth through the eastern portals on the face of the heaven.” The old Jewish belief as to the relation between the motion of the sun and moon was as follows: According to Rashi (T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, <i>loc. cit.</i>) the conjunction of every Molad (new moon) takes place when the moon is in the south-west corner of its orbit.<br>In winter since the sun does not traverse the west in the daytime save when it sets, therefore the moon is in the west before the sun gets there, because the moon during the first half of the lunar month goes to the north, whilst the sun revolves in the south.<br>In summer the sun goes over the greater part of the west in the daytime; and as it is then revolving in the north it is there before the moon, for then the moon is chiefly in the south. Where the sun sets there the moon rises.</i> the beginning of the conjunction of the moon is in the hour of the Moon (L). In the third year, in the following hour, the beginning of the conjunction of the moon is in the hour of Mercury (K).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 43, note 3.</i> In the fourth year the beginning of the conjunction of the moon is in the hour of Venus (N). In the fifth year, in the hour following, the beginning of the conjunction of the moon is in the hour of the Sun (Ch). In the sixth year the beginning of the conjunction of the moon is in the hour of Mars (M). In the seventh year, in the hour following, the beginning of the conjunction of the moon is || in the hour of Jupiter (Z) in the hour following.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “In the hour following” and the next sentence do not occur in the printed texts.</i> The third and fifth years are like the seventh. In like manner for three times these hours serve at the conjunction of the moon retrospectively until the (expiration of) the 21 years of the cycle.
All the constellations serve the moon by night from the four corners of the world:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 418, and Jalḳuṭ, 1 Kings, § 185, according to the latter passage, “The twelve constellations (<i>i.e.</i> the Zodiac) through which the world is ruled, three turn to the north… Aries, Leo, and Sagittarius; Taurus, Virgo, and Capricornus are turned to the west; Gemini, Libra, and Aquarius are turned to the south; Cancer, Scorpio, and Pisces are turned to the east.” An entirely different order is given in the Jalḳuṭ on Exodus, <i>loc. cit.</i> Cf. T.B. Pesachim, 94a, and see Eth. Enoch lxxii. 2 ff.</i> 3 in the north, 3 in the south, 3 in the east, and 3 in the west. All the hours<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the stars of the hours or the seven planets. This sentence is wanting in the 1st ed.</i> serve the moon by night from the four corners of the world: 2 in the south, 2 in the north, 2 in the east, and 2 in the west. In the hour in which it began to serve in the south, (therein) it finishes in the west;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The eight hours refer to the length of the shortest night according to our book; see <i>infra,</i> p. 322. The seven planets are placed thus: two in the south, two in the north, two in the east, and the seventh planet in the west; in addition, the first planet which served in the south serves at the end of the night (8th hour) in the west.</i> and so with all its circuits.
All the great<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads “small.”</i> luminaries of the stars<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The expression is borrowed from Ezek. 32:8. The seven planets are not referred to in this connection. The Pal. Targum, Ex. 40:4, “And thou shalt bring in the lamp-stand on the south side, because thence are the paths of the sun and moon, and the pathways of the luminaries.”</i> are situated in the south except Ursa Major,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>ענלה</span>, “waggon.” The constellation Taurus of the Zodiac or Ursa Major as a star is probably implied; see Rashi on T.B. Berakhoth, 58b.</i> which is placed in the north. All the Mazziḳin<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 14, note 8.</i> which move in the firmament and the angels<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The fall of the angels recalls Jude 6; Jubilees v. 6, 7; Slav. Enoch xviii.; Eth. Enoch vi.–xvi., xix., and lxxxvi.; Test. XII Pat. (Reuben, v. 6, 7), and Fragments of a Zadokite Work (ed. Schechter, iii. 18). See <i>infra,</i> pp. 99 and 160. The fall of the angels is a favourite subject with the Church Fathers, <i>e.g.</i> Athenagoras, <i>Embassy,</i> xxiv.; Justin Martyr, <i>Second Apology,</i> v.; and <i>Dialogue with Trypho,</i> lxxix.</i> who fell<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from their greatness.”</i> from their holy place (even) from heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in the days of the generation of Enosh.” This view opposes the doctrine of the Book of Jubilees v. 6–9, which holds that the fall of the angels took place in the days of Noah. Cf. Eth. Enoch vi. 4–6. On the “generation of Enosh” see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 37, 193, and 248; Jeraḥmeel xxiv. 9, xxvi. 20; Pal. Targum, Gen. 4:26. On the “fall of the angels” see Gen. Rab. 26:7; Pal. Targum, Gen. 6:4; Jeraḥmeel xxv., and Gaster’s Introduction, p. lxxiii, for further parallels. In Christian literature this legend also occurs; see <i>The Clementine Homilies,</i> xiii.</i> (when) they ascend to hear the (Divine) Word behind the veil<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 23, note 5.</i> they are pursued<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> 1st ed. reads: “they are separated.”</i> with a rod of fire, and they return<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “backwards.”</i> to their place.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> This is missing in the 1st ed.</i>
10 days, 21 hours, and 204 parts are the excess of the days of the solar year over the days of the lunar year;<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The 11⅓ minutes; Luria holds that this is a later addition to our text. On the astronomical question see Gen. Rab. 33:7. Our reading has been used by the Pal. Targum, Gen. 1:16 (see Ginsburger, <i>Pseudo-Jonathan,</i> p. 2, note 8). The Slavonic Enoch says, “And there remain 11 days over, which belong to the solar circle of the whole year” (xvi. 5). According to Eth. Enoch lxxviii. 15, 16, the lunar year has 354 days and the solar year has 364 days, thus the difference between them amounts to 10 days. Jubilees vi. 32–36 holds that the moon “comes in from year to year 10 days too soon.”</i> and the intercalation is introduced to equalize the days of the solar || year with the days of the lunar year.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> On the intercalation see <i>infra</i>, Chapter VIII. p. 57.</i> The sun and the moon begin (their courses) at the new moon of Nisan, the sun goes before the moon at its Teḳuphah;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Giḳaṭilla’s <i>Ginnath Egôẓ</i> (cd. Hanau), p. 50b, the text should read: “The sun goes before the moon according to her ordinance.”</i> and Aries begins to serve before it by day, and all the constellations serve thereafter<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “after it,” <i>i.e.</i> after Aries.</i> according to their order. The moon goes in the opposite direction<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “backwards.”</i> and Aries begins to serve before it<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “before him,” <i>i.e.</i> the sun. The first printed editions read: “before her,” <i>i.e.</i> the moon.</i> by night, and all the constellations serve thereafter according to their order, until the year of the small cycle, until the year of intercalation (comes round). (When) the intercalated month comes round it supersedes (or thrusts aside) the new moon (of Nisan) and remains at the new moon of Shebaṭ,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The intercalated month is always interposed between Adar and Nisan, so as to ensure the fall of the Passover in the early spring. The first printed editions read here, “Adar,” which appears to be the correct reading. The Venice edition adds: “and thus is it until the year of the small cycle<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> comes round; (when) the intercalated month comes it displaces the new moon and remains at the new moon of Ṭebeth.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> and so on until the twelve<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The text is questioned by Luria and others. If instead of “12” we read “7” then we have the cycle of 19 years with 7 intercalated months, which will be presently considered. Luria thinks that “the sun and moon are equal at the commencement of the eve of the fourth day in the hour of Saturn,” as “when they were created” only applies at the end of the cycle of 84 years. This number is obtained by multiplying 12 (the number of the constellations) by 7 (the number of the planets); or by multiplying the solar cycle of 28 years by 3; or by multiplying the lunar cycle of 21 years by 4; possibly this 84-year cycle was intended to be used for astrological purposes.</i> intercalated months (come round) when the sun and the moon are equal (again) at the commencement of the eve of the fourth day in the hour of Saturn in the hour when they were created. Between each Molad (conjunction of the moon and sun) there are only 36 hours, 40 minutes, and 73<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The “73 minims” must be considered as an interpolation; see <i>supra,</i> p. 43, note 5.</i> minims (parts).
The moon does not disappear from the firmament save for the twinkling of an eye; even though there were a full thread (of light) surrounding it in the east and in the west,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> That is, at the beginning and end of the Molad; see T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 20b, Rashi, <i>in loc.</i></i> the eye has not the power to see the moon until eight large<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The large hour equals two ordinary hours, as is explained in the next line of the text. This passage explaining the large hour is not in the printed editions. According to T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> the Palestinian Jews were unable to discern the moon at the Molad, for 6 hours after and 18 hours before the Molad; in Babylon the reverse rule obtained. The reading “6 hours” in this Talmudic passage seems to Luria to be the appropriate reading in our text. Assuming, however, that our text is correct, we might argue that Palestine could not be the place where our book arose.</i> hours (have elapsed). (The large hours) are two hours for each (large) hour, either at the beginning of the Molad (conjunction) of the moon or at the end of the Molad of the moon.
The number of the days of the lunar year is 354 days, a third of a day, and 876 minims.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> 876 minims equal 48⅔ minutes. There is evidently something amiss here, because the next sentence tells us that the lunar month has 708 hours and 40 minutes, which means that the lunar month equals 29 days, 12 hours, and 40 minutes. On this basis the lunar year has 354 days, 8 hours. Must we assume that the “876 minims” are an interpolation? This figure equals 48⅔ minutes, which in one lunar month equal 4 1/18 minutes or 73 minims.</i> || All the hours of a lunar month are 708 hours and 40 minutes; all the hours of a lunar year are 8504 hours.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> 8504 hours = 12 times 29 days, 12 hours, and 40 minutes.</i>
All the constellations serve the Molad of the moon and also the generations<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “history.”</i> of the children of men;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The knowledge of the influence of the stars and planets on terrestrial affairs or, in other words, astrology was believed to enable men to know the future. Our book bases this on the text, which is quoted in this paragraph; also Gen. 5:1, which was read as follows: “This is the calculation of the generations of man.” See also Job 38:19, “Where is the way to the dwelling of light… And that thou shouldst discern the paths to the house thereof? Thou knowest for thou wast then born.” The sun, moon, and the planets are referred to in this chapter, showing that they have some connection with the time and duration of life. Slav. Enoch xix. 2 says, “And these orders arrange and study the revolutions of the stars, and the changes of the moon, and revolutions of the sun, and superintend the good and evil condition of the world.” The N.T. also implies a belief in the doctrines of astrology, <i>e.g.</i> Matt. ii. 9; see Jeremias, <i>Babylonisches im N.T.,</i> p. 52. This book of Jeremias is the best book on N.T. astrology; for astrology among the Jews see Löw, <i>Gesammelte Schriften</i>, ii. 115 ff.</i> upon them the world stands, and everyone who is wise and understands, he understands the Molad of the moon and the generations of the children of men, and concerning them the text says, "And let them be for signs,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the next word in the verse, “and for seasons”; this is wanting in our MS.</i> and for seasons" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). The <i>signs</i> of the hours shall not depart from serving the sun by day and the moon by night.
In three cycles of the sun or in four cycles of the moon<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The lunar cycle referred to here consists of 21 years, as stated <i>supra,</i> p. 43. The solar cycle consists of 28 years, see <i>supra,</i> p. 34.</i> there are 84 years, which are one hour<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> God’s day equals 1000 years, therefore 1 hour (reckoning 12 hours to the day) equals 83⅓ years. The third part of the year is reckoned as a whole year. This is another instance of the use of fractions as whole numbers, which seems to be a characteristic of our author. The Church Fathers use this idea of God’s day lasting 1000 years; see Justin Martyr, <i>Dialogue with Trypho,</i> lxxxi., and Irenæus, <i>adv. Hær.</i> v. 28. 3; and cf. Slavonic Enoch xxxiii. 1 f.</i> of the day of the Holy One, blessed be He. When the sun and moon become equal<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> That is, they begin their courses as at the Creation.</i> at the beginning of the eve of the fourth day and at the hour of Saturn in the hour when they were created, and in the hour when the flames of the moon reach the sun by day at the degree (or ascent) of 60 (degrees), it passes therein and extinguishes its light; and in the hour when the flames of the sun reach the moon at night in the degree (or ascent) of 40 (degrees), it passes through it and extinguishes its light.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to the eclipses. It is not clear what the 60 or 40 degrees or ascents mean here.</i>
Rabbi Nehorai said: It is the decree of the King<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The decree of the King is made public by a word.” See Jalḳuṭ, Jer. § 285. Instead of the reading “by a word” Luria suggests the reading “in the world,” referring to the eclipses which are visible over a large portion of the world.</i> that when Israel sins || and fails to intercalate the year as is becoming, the Holy One, blessed be He, acts in His mercy at the time when the flame of the sun reaches the moon by night at 40 degrees (or ascents), then the Holy One, blessed be He, makes the moon dim and hides one of the Synhedrion.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 37a, and Cant. Rab. on Cant. 7:3. Here “to hide” means to conceal in the future life; this, in other words, is a warning not to neglect the intercalation. According to the Jesod ‘Olam iii. 17 the moon is the “chief” of the Synhedrion, which dies at the eclipse by being <i>hidden.</i> For eclipse in N.T. see Luke xxiii. 44, 45.</i> When Israel does the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, in His great mercy He makes the sun dim and He sends forth His anger upon the nations of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here also “the nations of the world.” Later editions read: “worshippers of idols.”</i> as it is said, "Thus saith the Lord, Learn not the way of the <i>nations</i>, and be not dismayed at the signs of heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions continue the verse.</i> for the <i>nations</i> are dismayed at them" (Jer. 10:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Some of the old editions read here: “the nations (or according to the Prague edition ‘the worshippers of idols’) are dismayed, but not Israel.” See Pseudo-Seder Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa (ed. Friedmann, p. 10 and note 40) on the eclipses, where the Talmudic and Midrashic sources are fully given. The astronomical question is treated at length in Israeli’s Jesod ‘Olam, <i>loc. cit.</i>; see also Maimonides, Hilkhoth Kiddush Ha-Chodesh.</i> Just as the moon's light does not rule over the sun's light<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Slavonic Enoch xvi. 7 the moon shines with her own light.</i> by day, nor does the sun's light rule over the moon's light<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, 60b. When the sun is invisible the moon shines.</i> by night, likewise the calculation of the moon does not rule by day nor does the calculation of the sun (obtain) by night,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “We do not count the calculation of the sun at night, nor the calculation of the moon by day.”</i> and the one does not trespass on the boundary of the other.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See, however, Gen. Rab. 6:3 for the opposite opinion. According to Lev. Rab. 26:4 the sun and moon borrow light from one another.</i>
The dwelling of the moon is between cloud and thick darkness<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Job 38:9. On the text see Buber’s introduction to Sepher Ha-Orah, p. 119.</i> made like two dishes turned one over the other,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first printed editions insert here: “and (the moon) goes forth from between them.”</i> and when it is the conjunction of the moon these two clouds turn in the east quarter<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first printed editions read: “turn their faces to the west quarter.”</i> and (the moon) goes forth from between them<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Singer, p. 128: “bringing forth the sun from his place, and the moon from her dwelling.”</i> like a ram's horn.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> At rising.</i> On the first night (is revealed) one measure (of light), on the second night the second measure, and so on until the half of the month when the moon is fully revealed, and from the middle of the month these two clouds turn their faces in the west quarter.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of the 1st ed. The Venice edition reads: “in the quarter of the east.”</i> The corner (<i>i.e.</i> crescent) of the moon with which it comes forth first,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jaḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 81:14, pp. 25a, b, and Jalḳuṭ, Job 38:9, § 923.</i> (the same) begins to enter and is covered therein by the two (clouds) on the first night<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> After full moon.</i> (by) one measure, on the second night (by) a second measure, and so on to the end of the month until || it is entirely covered. And whence do we know that it is placed between two clouds? Because it is said, "When I made the cloud the garment thereof, and thick darkness<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions give the next word of the text, whereas our MS. has “etc.”</i> a swaddlingband for it" (Job 38:9). And whence do we know that it becomes entirely covered? Because it is said, "Blow ye the trumpet in the new moon, <i>at the covering</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “Covering”; see ‘Arukh (ed. Kohut), iv. p. 266a, which has a different text of our passage. For further reference to the sun and moon see T.J. Berakhoth 1:1.; T.J. Rosh Ha-Shanah 11. 5 58a; Shocher Ṭob (Ps. 19), pp. 168f.; Pesiḳta de R. Kahana, P. Ha-Chodesh, 41b f.; and Ex. Rab. xv. 22.</i> on our solemn feast day" (Ps. 81:8). "At the covering," on the day when it is entirely covered, blow ye the trumpet in the new moon.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This verse of Ps. 81:3 is applied by the Liturgy (see Singer, p. 115) and by the Midrashim (<i>e.g</i>. Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 81 § 5) to the New Year. The fact that the Shophar (ram’s horn) was mentioned a few lines previously seems to point to this section as forming part of a Midrash for the New Year.</i>

Chapter 8

CHAPTER VIII<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is ch. vii. in the MS. The printed editions present a good deal of the material in this chapter in a different order to that of our MS.</i><br><small>THE PRINCIPLE OF INTERCALATION</small> [9<small>A</small>. i.]<br>O<small>N</small> the 28th of Ellul the sun and the moon were created.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 11a and 27a, for the view of R. Eliezer that the world was created in Tishri. The heavenly bodies were created on Ellul the 28th. The work of creation began on the 25th of Ellul, see also Lev. Rab. 29:1. In the preceding chapters the assumption was that the Creation took place in Nisan, cf. <i>supra,</i> pp. 35 f., 47. This opinion has also the support of the Talmud B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 12a. Part of this chapter is quoted in the “Megillah of Abiathar,” edited by Schechter in <i>J.Q.R.</i> xiv. pp. 463 ff.</i> The number of years, months, days, nights,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “hours.” Cf. Wisdom vii. 18 f.</i> terms, seasons, cycles, and intercalation were before the Holy One, blessed be He,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 3:7 as to the calculations prior to the Creation.</i> and He intercalated the years and afterwards He delivered the (calculations) to the first man in the garden of Eden,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In a holy place; for, according to our book, the Garden of Eden was near Mount Moriah in Palestine. See <i>infra,</i> p. 143.</i> as it is said, "This is the calculation<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 48, note 7, and cf. T.J. Rosh Ha-Shanah i. 3. 57b and Pesiḳta de R. Kahana P. Ha-Chodesh, p. 43b.</i> for the generations of Adam" (Gen. 5:1), the calculation of the world is therein for the generations of the children of Adam.
Adam handed on the tradition to Enoch,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The mention of Enoch in connection with the Calendar is significant, suggesting an acquaintance with the Calendar systems associated with Enoch in the pseudepigraphic literature. The fact that according to the O.T. Enoch lived 365 years is also noteworthy in this connection.</i> who was initiated in the principle of intercalation, and he intercalated the year, as it is said, "And Enoch walked with God" (<i>ibid.</i> 22). Enoch walked in the ways of the calculation concerning the world which God had delivered to Adam. And Enoch delivered the principle of intercalation to Noah,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This should probably read “Methuselah,” and the text should continue, “who handed it on to Noah.”</i> and he was initiated in the principle of intercalation, and he intercalated the year, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria’s text here needs correction.</i> "While the earth remaineth,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse is given by the first editions.</i> seed-time and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter" (<i>ibid.</i> viii. 22). "Seed-time" refers to the Teḳuphah of Tishri,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum of this verse reads: “During all the days of the earth, (there shall be) sowing at the Teḳuphah of Tishri, and harvest at the Teḳuphah of Nisan, cold at the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth and warmth at the Teḳuphah of Tammuẓ, and summer and winter, and days and night shall not fail.” Teḳuphah means not only season, but also the time of solstice and equinox according to the season.</i> "harvest" refers to the Teḳuphah of Nisan, "cold" refers to the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth, and "heat" refers to the Teḳuphah of Tammuz; "summer" is in its season and "winter" is in its season.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The “Megillah of Abiathar,” p. 463, adds: “summer in its season and winter in its season.”</i>
The counting of the sun is <i>by day</i> || and the counting of the moon is <i>by night</i>, "<i>they shall not cease</i>."<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This section is based on the text “day and night shall not cease” (Gen. 8:22).</i>
Noah handed on the tradition to Shem, and he was initiated in the principle of intercalation; he intercalated the years and he was called a priest, as it is said, "And Melchizedek<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Melchizedek is identified by our book with Shem. According to T.B. Nedarim, 32b, the priestly office held by Melchizedek’s successors passed to those of Abraham; see Beer, <i>Buch der Jubiläen,</i> p. 74. The question of the identification of Shem with Melchizedek occurs in the Talmud (<i>loc. cit.</i> in this note), and see Buber’s note 18 on p. 30 of the Midrash Agadah, cf. also Pal. Targum and Jer. Targum on Gen. 14:18, and Gen. Rab. 43:6 and lvi. 9. See also the note of Charles in his ed. of <i>Jubilees,</i> p. 101. A considerable part of this section of our text occurs in Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 110:16, but the quotation from Gen. 14:18 is omitted. There are other variations in the text.</i> king of Salem… was a priest of God Most High" (<i>ibid.</i> xiv. 18). Was Shem the son of Noah a priest? But because he was the first-born, and because he ministered to his God by day and by night, therefore was he called a priest.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse from Gen. 14:18 occurs here in the printed editions, and not above as in our MS.</i> Shem delivered the tradition to Abraham; he was initiated in the principle of intercalation and he intercalated the year, and he (also) was called priest, as it is said, "The Lord hath sworn, and will not repent,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse is not given by the MS., which merely adds “etc.”</i> Thou art a priest for ever after the order<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Heb. v. 6 ff., on this theme. The Hebrew <span>דברתי</span> might suggest the meaning of “ruling”; the Oxford <i>Gesenius,</i> p. 184, renders the word: “after the order,” or “manner of.” Is it merely a coincidence that the Test. XII Pat., Benj. x. 6, mentions the same names as in our text and in the same order?— “Then shall ye see Enoch, Noah, and Shem, and Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob.”</i> of Melchizedek" (Ps. 110:4). Whence do we know that Shem delivered the tradition to Abraham? Because it is said, "After the order of Melchizedek" (<i>ibid.</i>). Abraham delivered the tradition to Isaac, and he was initiated in the principle of intercalation, and he intercalated the year after the death of our father Abraham, as it is said, "And it came to pass after the death of Abraham, that God blessed Isaac his son" (Gen. 25:11), because he had been initiated in the principle of intercalation and had intercalated the year (therefore) He blessed him with the blessing of eternity.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “of the world.”</i> Isaac gave to Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Pss. <i>loc. cit.,</i> which reads: “And Isaac handed on to Jacob all the blessings, and handed to him the principle of intercalation,” confirming the accuracy of the text of our MS. The printed editions read: “Isaac delivered the tradition to Jacob, and he was initiated in the principle of intercalation, and he intercalated the year.”</i> all the blessings and delivered to him the principle of intercalation. When Jacob went out of the (Holy) Land, he attempted to intercalate the year outside the (Holy) Land. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob! Thou hast no authority to intercalate the year outside the land (of Israel); behold, Isaac thy father is in the (Holy) Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Although Isaac was blind, nevertheless the duty of intercalating the year devolved upon him and not upon Jacob when absent from the Holy Land. The Church offers a parallel to the subject-matter of our text in the famous controversy as to the right calculation for Easter; see the epistle sent to Pope Hilarus by Victorius in the fifth century. In this letter we have several references to the lunar cycle of 84 years which also occurs in our book. (For text see Thalhofer’s <i>Bibliothek der Kirchenväter,</i> Die Briefe der Päpste, vi. pp. 16–30; cf. also Ideler, <i>Handbuch der Chronologie,</i> 11, p. 276, and see also “The Paschal Canon of Anatolius of Alexandria,” in <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xiv. pp. 411 ff.)</i> he will intercalate the year, as it is said, "And God appeared unto Jacob again, || when he came from Paddan-Aram, and blessed him" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxv. 9). Why "again"? Because the first time He was revealed to him, He prevented him from intercalating the year outside the (Holy) Land; but when he came to the (Holy) Land the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob ! Arise, intercalate the year, as it is said, "And God appeared unto Jacob <i>again</i>,… and blessed him" (<i>ibid.</i>), because he was initiated in the principle of the intercalation, and He blessed him (with) the blessing of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the revelation of the Divine Name El Shaddai. “When I suspend judgment concerning man’s sins, I am called El Shaddai,” says the Midrash Tanchuma, Shemoth, § xx., and cf. <i>infra,</i> pp. 264 ff. In the first editions here follows the section beginning with the words: “Hence the (Sages) have said.”</i> Thus were the Israelites wont to intercalate the year in the (Holy) Land. When they were exiled to Babylon || they intercalated the year through those who were left in the (Holy) Land. When they were all exiled and there were not any (Jews) left in the (Holy) Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> After the murder of Gedaliah; see T.B. Sabbath, 145b, and Seder ‘Olam Rab. 27 p. 62a. The Land = Palestine.</i> they intercalated the year in Babylon. (When) Ezra and all the community with him<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Ezra 2:1; cf. T.B. ‘Arakhin, 13a and 32a.</i> went (to Palestine), Ezekiel<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On the question whether Ezekiel could have been a contemporary of Ezra, see Rashi on Ezek. 29 (end), and cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 249. The special privileges attached to the Holy Land are noteworthy in considering the provenance of our book.</i> wished to intercalate the year in Babylon; (then) the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Ezekiel ! Thou hast no authority to intercalate the year outside the Land; behold, Israel thy brethren,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> your brethren in the land of Israel, see 2 Kings 25:22 and Jer. 43:5.</i> they will intercalate the year,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The order of narrative in our MS.differs from that of the printed texts.</i> as it is said, "Son of man, when the house of Israel dwell in their <i>own</i> land" (Ezek. 36:17). Hence (the Sages) have said, Even when the righteous and the wise are outside the Land, and the keeper of sheep and herds are in the Land, they do not intercalate the year<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This passage if rendered literally reads: “Even the righteous and the wise outside the Land and the keeper of sheep and herds in the Land, then the year is intercalated only by the keeper of sheep and herds.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 18b and 26a, for instances of intercalation by shepherds. Cf. the narrative of the Magi and the Star in Matt. ii. 1 ff.</i> except through the keeper of sheep and herds in the Land. Even when prophets are outside the Land and the ignorant<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “commoners” (<span>הדיוט</span>=<i>ὶδιώτης</i>), see T.B. Nedarim, 78a. For an instance of intercalation outside Palestine see T.B. Berakhoth, 63a, and cf. Tosaphoth on Jebamoth, 115a.</i> are in the Land they do not intercalate the year except through the ignorant who are in the land (of Israel),<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions differ from our MS. here with reference to the arrangement of the material.</i> as it is said, "Son of man, when the house of Israel dwell in their <i>own</i> land"(<i>ibid.</i>) it is their duty to intercalate the year.
Jacob delivered to Joseph and his brethren the principle of intercalation, and they intercalated the year in the land of Egypt. (When) Joseph and his brethren died, the intercalations ceased from Israel in Egypt, as it is said, "And Joseph died, and all his brethren, and all that generation" (Ex. 1:6). Just as the intercalations were diminished from the Israelites in the land<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the Egyptian bondage.”</i> of Egypt, likewise in the future will the intercalations be diminished at the end of the fourth kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “bondage of the fourth kingdom.”</i> until Elijah, be he remembered for good, shall come.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “until King Messiah shall come.” This sign, due to the ignorance which will obtain in the period just before the advent of the Messiah, is to be compared with the “woes of the Messianic age” in Jubilees xxiii. 19: “For they have forgotten commandment, and covenant, and feasts, and months, and Sabbaths, and jubilees.”</i> Just as the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed to Moses and Aaron in Egypt, likewise in the future will He be revealed to them<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice ed. reads: “to us.”</i> at the end of the fourth kingdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Some editions read “exile,” or “bondage.”</i> as it is said, "And the Lord spake unto Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt <i>saying</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. does not continue the verse; the first editions add: “This month shall be unto you.”</i> This month shall be unto you the beginning of months" (<i>ibid.</i> xii. 1, 2). What is the significance of the word "saying"? Say to them,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “to Israel.”</i> Till now<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> From the death of Joseph during the period of bondage.</i> the principle of intercalation was with Me, henceforth it is your right to intercalate thereby the year.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pesiḳta de R. Kahana, <i>loc. cit.,</i> which reads: “it (the principle of intercalation) is delivered unto you.” See also T.J. Rosh Ha-Shanah i. 13. 57d and Ex. Rab. xv. 2. The order of the narrative here in the MS. differs from that of the printed texts. On the astronomical knowledge of Moses, see Clement of Alexandria, <i>Strom</i>. 1. xxiii., and cf. Acts vii. 22.</i> 
The intercalation takes place in the presence of three;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Men who know the principle of intercalation.</i> Rabbi Eliezer says that ten (men are required), as it is said, "God standeth in the congregation<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The “congregation” consists of ten, the Minyan; this is derived from the use of the word “congregation” in connection with the ten spies who brought a false report to Moses in the wilderness (Num. 14:27). The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads here: “‘In the congregation of God.’ ‘Congregation’ means only ten (men), as it is said: ‘How long shall I bear with this evil congregation,’” etc. (Num. 14:27). See “Megillah of Abiathar,” pp. 469 f.</i> of God"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “in the congregation of the mighty.” For the occasions when a Minyan is necessary, see Mishnah Megillah 4:3, tractate Sopherim 10:8, and <i>infra,</i> pp. 127f. The Talmud B. Synhedrin, 70b, also requires ten men at the intercalation, and cf. Ex. Rab. xv. 20.</i> (Ps. 82:1), and if they become less<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>e.g.</i> if one or more of the ten men go away, see T.B. Berakhoth, 47b. Luria thinks that the text is corrupt, reading “when they had deliberated” instead of “if they become less.” The MSS. do not support this suggested emendation.</i> than ten, since they are diminished they place a scroll of the Torah before them,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> To read therein the section dealing with the Calendar (Ex. 12:1 f.).</i> and they are seated in a circle in the court-room,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Such as was used by the Synhedrion at Jerusalem; see T.B. Synhedrin, 35b, 36b, and Sopherim 19:9.</i> and the greatest (among them) sits first,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, 120b, for order of procedure; for a Biblical parallel see Gen. 43:33. The text means literally: “And they sit, the greatest according to his greatness, and the least according to his littleness.”</i> and the least sits last; and they direct their gaze downwards<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. 9:24 for “falling on the face,” and see Ezek. li. 28.</i> to the earth and (then) they stand and spread out their hands<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lam. 3:41; Targ. Onḳelos on Gen. 14:22, and cf. T.B. Jebamoth, 105b.</i> before their Father who is in heaven, and the chief of the assembly<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The “Rosh Yeshibah” points to Palestine or to the schools of the Geonim in Babylon, or to the Academies in Egypt; see <i>J.Q.R.</i> xiv. p. 450, note 1.</i> proclaims<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the benediction on reading the Torah; see Singer, p. 68. It probably means that the Ineffable Name was pronounced. The “Megillah of Abiathar,” p. 469, recounts how the Ineffable Name was mentioned with “sanctification, greater than that of the Day of Atonement when the High Priest pronounced it seven times,”</i> the name (of God), and they hear a Bath Ḳol<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Heavenly Voice; see Mark i. 11, and cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 195, note 4.</i> (saying) the following words,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “according to this expression.” The Oxford MS. (d. 35) adds: “as it is said.”</i> "And the Lord spake unto Moses and Aaron… saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. does not continue the quotation.</i> This month shall be unto you" (Ex. 12:1, 2).
If, owing to the iniquity of the generation, they do not hear anything at all;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> R. Eliezer was permitted to hear the Bath Ḳol. See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 59b, and T.B. Soṭah. 48b. In later times this privilege was withdrawn because of the sins of the people.</i> then, if one may say so,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> On this term see Bacher, <i>Terminologie,</i> i. pp. 72 f.</i> He is unable to let His glory abide among them. Happy were they who stood in that place<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the court room of the Synhedrion. The reference is to the good days of old, long before our book was written.</i> in that hour,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> When the intercalation took place; this was at night. According to the “Megillah of Abiathar,” p. 471, the intercalation took place by day; see T.B. Synhedrin, 11b.</i> as it is said, "Happy is the people who know the joyful sound:<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Teru‘ah or trumpet blast. The various features of this ceremony have a parallel in the ceremonies of the Ban mentioned <i>infra,</i> p. 301. Are we dealing with a Geonic institution?</i> they walk, O Lord, in the light of thy countenance" (Ps. 89:15); in the light of the countenance of the Holy One, blessed be He, they walk.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria infers from our narrative that the Shophar was sounded at the intercalation ceremony; see T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Tosephta Synhedrin 2:7 ff., p. 417, on this ceremony.</i>
On account of three things<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “signs.” This is also the reading in the Oxford MS. (d. 35). See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 221, note 3.</i> is the year intercalated, on account of trees, grass, and the seasons (Teḳuphoth). If two of these (signs) be available and not the third, they do not intercalate the year, (that is to say) neither because of the trees nor because of the grass. If one (sign)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Teḳuphah. Luria thinks that the reading should be as follows: “If two signs be available and not the third we intercalate on account of the presence of the trees and the grass; if one sign be available and the other two be absent we do not intercalate on account of the Teḳuphah” (see T.B. Synhedrin, 12a, b, and cf. T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 21a).</i> be available and the other two be absent, they do not intercalate the year on account of the Tekuphoth.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “This is an error,” says Luria; “it should be the 16th”; see T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and T.B. Synhedrin, 13a: for if the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth fell on the 21st of Ṭebeth, then the Teḳuphah of Nisan would be on the 24th of Nisan (91 days’ interval), which is the day after Passover, accordingly Passover would not be in Abib (the Teḳuphah in Nisan), and therefore Adar Shêni should be intercalated. The reading in our text (the 20th) is approved by Schwarz (<i>Der jüdische Kalender,</i> p. 36, note 3). The “Megillah of Abiathar” (<i>op. cit.</i> p. 471) reads: “If the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth had occurred from half (of the month) and later they intercalate the year, but till half (of the month) and earlier they do not intercalate the year.” The printed editions read: “If the Teḳuphah had occurred by the 20th day of the month or earlier they intercalate the year; but from the 20th day of the month or later they do not intercalate the year.” This is clearly wrong. The correct reading is preserved by our MS., which is confirmed by the Oxford MS. (d. 35). On this subject see Maimonides, Ḳiddush Ha-Chodesh iv. 2, Schürer, i. (3rd ed.), pp. 752 ff.; F. K. Ginzel, <i>Handbuch der Mathematischen und Technischen Chronologie,</i> ii. p. 67; and L.Wreschner, <i>Samaritanische Traditionen,</i> p. 10. In the past year (5675) the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth fell on Wednesday, January 6, 1915, at 10.30 p.m., <i>i.e.</i> the fifth day of the Hebrew week, the 21st of Ṭebeth, and the Teḳuphah of Nisan fell on Thursday, April 8, 1915, at 6 a.m., <i>i.e.</i> the 24th of Nisan, <i>after</i> the termination of the Passover festival. The rule in our text does not apply now in actual practice. See Jozeroth, ed. Arnheim, p. 73.</i> If the Teḳuphah of Ṭebeth had occurred on the 20th<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “they intercalate the year on account of the Teḳuphoth.” This reading agrees with “Megillah of Abiathar,” p. 469.</i> day of || the month or later, they intercalate the year; but till the 20th day of the month Ṭebeth or earlier they do not intercalate the year.
The cycle of intercalation is 19 years, and there are 7 small cycles<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Of intercalated years.</i> therein; some of these are (separated by) 3 years, some (by) 2 years, others (are separated by) 3 or 2 years, or (by) 3, 3, and 3 years (the order of the cycles being): 3rd, 6th, 8th, 11th, 14th, 17th, and 19th years. There are two (sets) of three years' cycles.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text has the following order of years, 3rd, 6th (the 3rd after the preceding year of intercalation), the 8th (<i>i.e.</i> two years after the preceding year), 11th (again three years’ interval), 14th (again three years’ interval), 17th (three years’ interval), and the 19th year (two years’ interval). On this question see Ginzel, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 75 f.; and cf. Jesod ‘Olam iv. ii. p. 63b, and the works on the Calendar by Lewisohn, p. 40, and Schwarz, p. 78. According to the Oxford MS. (d. 35) the text should read thus: the 3rd, 5th, 8th, 11th, 14th, 16th, and 19th, agreeing with the cycle of Meton the Greek astronomer, with the exception that the latter has the 13th year instead of the 14th year.</i>
On the New Moon of Nisan || the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt, and it was the 15th<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria corrects this and reads “the 12th.” On the date of the Exodus see Seder ‘Olam Rab. 5 pp. 11b f.</i> year of the great cycle of the moon, the 16th year of the cycle of intercalation,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Of 19 years.</i> (and He said): "henceforward the counting devolves on you."<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See the “Megillah of Abiathar,” p. 464. On the important question as to the probable origin of <i>P.R.E.</i> in connection with the intercalation, see <i>J.Q.R.</i> (New Series) i. pp. 64 f.</i>

Chapter 9

CHAPTER IX<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. this is ch. viii.</i><br><small>THE CREATION AND WONDERS OF THE FIFTH DAY</small> [10<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>O<small>N</small> the fifth day<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> For the creation on the fifth day see Gen. 1:20–23; 4 Ezra 6:47 ff.; Jubilees ii. 11, 12; Slav. Enoch xxx. 7. Our book reckons three kinds of living things created on the fifth day: birds, fish, and locusts; in Jubilees, <i>loc. cit.,</i> three kinds: great sea monsters, fish, and birds are also enumerated.</i> He caused the waters to bring forth abundantly all kinds of winged fowls, male and female, unclean and clean. By two signs<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On the signs see T.B. Chullin, 59a, 61a and 62a; Tosephta Chullin 3:22, p. 505, and Pal. Targum on Lev. 11:13.</i> are they declared to be clean, by the crop, and by the craw peeling off. Rabbi Eliezer said: (Another sign was) also by the projecting toe of the claw. Two kinds of birds have been chosen for the offering of a burnt sacrifice,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This agrees with Luria’s reading; the printed texts read: “an offering and a burnt-offering.”</i> namely, the turtle-dove and the young pigeon.
He<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “On the fifth day.” The 1st ed. omits this and the following words up to “male.”</i> caused the waters to bring forth abundantly all kinds of fish, male and female, unclean and clean. By two signs are they declared to be clean, by the fins and by their scales;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> On fish see L v. xi. 9, 10, 12, and T.B. Chullin, 66b.</i> and if they do not have them (<i>i.e.</i> both signs) they are unclean.
On the fifth day He caused the waters to bring forth abundantly all kinds of locusts,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, 59a and 65 a, b.</i> male and female, clean and unclean. By two signs are they declared to be clean: by their long legs with which they jump,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “upon the earth.” See Lev. 11:20–23.</i> and by the wings which cover the entire body, such are clean. Such (living things) as were brought forth from the water, namely, fish and locusts,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Dr. Charles is mistaken in stating that in the “Pirke R. Eliezer ix. it is said that locusts are not created from water” (<i>Fragments of a Zadokite Work,</i> p. 31). Just the opposite theory is advocated by our work. The Zadokite Fragment taught that the elements of fire and water were to be found in the composition of the locusts, hence they are to be killed by fire or by water; see Schechter, <i>op. cit.,</i> p. 51, note 24. who points out that according to Rabbinic law, the locust requires no killing at all; see Maimonides, Mishneh Torah, Hilkhoth Shechitah, ch. i. 1, and Ṭur Joreh Di’ah, 13. The importance of this Halakhah will be appreciated if we are able to fix the date and home of our book. The question has been critically discussed by Dr. Büchler in the <i>J.Q.R.</i> (New Series) iii. (1913) pp. 442 f.; see <i>J.Q.R.</i> (New Series) iv. pp. 460 ff., where Jubilees v. 30 is cited as bearing on the question. Cf. also Wreschner, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 52.</i> are (eaten) without (being subject to the laws of) Shechiṭah<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “are eaten, for they are not (killed) by Shechiṭah.” For the ritual slaughter of animals by the knife see T.B. Chullin, 27a. This method probably obtained among the early Christians, see Acts xv. 20 and 29, xxi. 25; for further references see Preuschen, <i>N.T. Dict.</i> s.v. <i>πνικτóς</i>, c. 933.</i> (with the ritual slaughtering), but the bird cannot be eaten unless (it be killed) by (the method of) Shechiḳah. Such creatures which have been created from the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. actually reads “water,” but the text was here originally “earth.” The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “Such as were created from the earth have their blood poured out like water, and such as swarmed from the water have their blood covered by the dust.” As the parchment of our MS. has been damaged by the erasure, an attempt has also been made to change the word “water” (in the next line) into “earth.”</i> || have their blood covered with earth, and such as have been created from the water must have their blood poured out like water.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “Such as have been created from the water may have their blood consumed like water, and such as have been created from the earth, their blood is prohibited to be consumed: the exception is the fowl; for although it has been created from the water its blood is prohibited to be consumed, and, moreover, it requires that the blood which falls upon the earth when it is killed must be covered by dust.” The traditional text found in our MS. as well as in the first editions is probably correct in view of the unusual Halakhah (or Law) preserved in the <i>Fragments of a Zadokite Work</i> (ed. Charles), xiv. 13: “Nor shall fish be eaten unless they are split alive and their blood was shed.” Dr Schechter thinks that this rule was” “directed against the Rabbinic opinion permitting the eating of the blood of the fish. See Sifra, 39a, and Kerithoth, 20b.” See, further, T.B. Chullin, 27b, “where,” says Dr. Schechter, “we have a homily to the effect that cattle have to be killed in a certain way because they were created out of the dry land (earth); fish, again, require no killing, being created out of the water; whilst birds, which were created out of alluvial mud (a combination of water and earth), occupy also, with regard to their ritual killing, a middle place between cattle and fish. The notion was that the mode of killing is in some way connected with the element out of which the animal in question was created.” See Wreschner, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 54. The 1st ed. reads: “its blood is poured out on the earth.” The Venice edition agrees with our MS.</i>
Rabbi Eliezer said: Not only concerning the water does the Scripture say that "the waters should bring forth abundantly" (Gen. 1:20), but also concerning the birds<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) and the first editions read: “nations of the world.”</i> which are compared with water, as it is said, "And the uproar of many peoples, which roar like the roaring of the seas" (Isa. 17:12), and just as the waters brought forth abundantly on the fifth day, likewise in the future will the nations of the world swarm in the fifth world,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Is the fifth world the fifth kingdom, <i>i.e.</i> the kingdom of the Messiah? Or, is the “fifth world” another way of saying the “fifth era” or “day” of the world? This would be the period 5000 <small>A.M.</small> to 6000 <small>C.E.</small> (<i>i.e.</i> 1240–2240 <small>C.E.</small>). Our reading is also preserved in the 1st ed. In the Venice edition the word “fifth” is omitted.</i> and they will fight one another to destroy<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 4a, T.B. Synhedrin, 97b, and Ẓohar, Gen. 46b and 119a, for the wars of the Messianic Age, which were supposed to begin about the end of the fiftieth century <small>A.M.</small>; cf. <i>infra,</i> pp. 198–203; and see Rev. xvi. 14 for the internecine strife of the nations.</i> (one another), as it is said, "And they were broken in pieces, nation against nation, and city against city;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first two editions have erred here in a strange manner: they <i>both</i> quote as a Scripture text the words: “And I will set nation against nation, kingdom against kingdom, for God did vex them with all adversity.” The last clause is part of the quotation from 2 Chron. 15:6, the first part of this verse being accurately given by our MS. Where do we find the words: “And I will set nation against nation, kingdom against kingdom”? Might one suggest Matt. xxiv. 7, based on Isa. 19:2 and 2 Chron. 15:6, as a parallel? See also 4 Ezra xiii. 31.</i> for God did vex them with all adversity" (2 Chron. 15:6). What is written (immediately) afterwards? The Salvation of Israel (is mentioned), as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 62:11 and Ps. 14:7.</i> "But be ye strong; and your hands shall not be slack" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).
All rivers flowing on the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition omits “flowing on the earth”; the 1st ed. agrees with our text.</i> as soon as they flow on the earth, they are blessed and good and sweet. There is some benefit to the world through them;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Recognitions of Clement viii. 24 and John of Damascus, <i>op. cit.</i> ii. 9.</i> (when) they flow into the sea they are bad,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests the reading: “they are cursed, evil.”</i> cursed, and bitter, and they are of no benefit to the world. Why are they similar to Israel? For when the Israelites rely upon the protection of their Creator and do His will, they are blessed and good and sweet, and there is some benefit to the world through them, and for their sake<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jer. 10:2, 3, and Assumption of Moses i. 12. A parallel to our text is given by 4 Ezra 4:55, 59, vii. 11.</i> the world stands. (When) the men of Israel depart from their Creator and trust in the statutes of the nations,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Matt. v. 13, 14.</i> they are bad, accursed, and bitter, || and there is no benefit in them for the world. Just as the waters of the rivers (are) the food of the waters of the sea,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The river water is absorbed by the salt water and thereby the composition of the sea water is modified; see Gen. Rab. 5:3 on this problem.</i> so are (the sinners destined to be) fuel for Gehinnom. All the rains that descend into the sea are (as) seed for (all creatures) in them,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the sea. Cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 30, the rain is the male element in water; see Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 146 § 3, p. 268a.</i> and thereby the fish are fed.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “become fruitful.”</i>
On the fifth day the waters in Egypt<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 3, and cf. Mishnah ‘Edujoth ii. 10 for the duration of the Plagues. Our book (<i>infra,</i> p. 330) states that the day of departure was on the third day; on this point see T.B. Sabbath, 87b. Luria thinks that the text should be emended thus: “On the fifth day the sea was divided when our fathers went forth from Egypt.”</i> were changed into blood. On the fifth day our forefathers went forth from Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading of our text is preserved in Jalḳuṭ, Jonah, § 550, as follows: “It was taught in a Baraitha that R. Eliezer said, On the fifth day the waters of Egypt were turned into blood, on that day our fathers went forth from Egypt; on that day the waters of the Jordan stood still before the ark of the Lord, on that day Hezekiah stopped all the fountains; on the fifth day Jonah fled before God.” See first sentence in next chapter of our book.</i> On the same (<i>i.e</i>. fifth) day the waters of the Jordan stood still before the ark of the Covenant of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Josh. 3:15, 16; Tosaphoth in Menachoth, 30a, catchword: “From here onwards,” refers to the day when Jericho fell; cf. Seder ‘Olam Rab. 11; see Ratner’s ed. p. 24a, note 24, for the parallels, and see in our book, <i>infra,</i> pp. 423 f.</i> On the same (<i>i.e.</i> fifth) day Hezekiah stopped the fountains which were in Jerusalem, as it is said, "This same<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions are incorrect here.</i> Hezekiah also stopped the upper spring of the waters of Gihon" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 80).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> On Hezekiah see Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) ii. pp. 6a, b; and cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 5b, T.B. Pesachim, 56a, and in our book, <i>infra,</i> pp. 424 ff.</i>
On the fifth day He brought forth from the water the Leviathan,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The Leviathan is the “flying serpent.” See Isa. 27:1, and Gen. Rab. 7:4 with Theodor’s note, <i>in loc</i>.; 4 Ezra 6:49 ff. (ed. Box, p. 92); Eth. Enoch lxix. 7 f.; and cf. <i>Monatsschrift,</i> lxiii. p. 20. Our book holds the view that the Leviathan was created on the fifth day, and Behemoth on the sixth day; see <i>infra,</i> p. 75; and see also T.B. Baba Bathra, 74b, 75a; Pal. Targum on Gen. 1:21. Every day<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “And the Holy One, blessed be He, plays with it every day.” This part of the sentence is out of place, as it occurs again a few lines farther on in these editions. Jalḳuṭ on Job, § 927.</i> (Ps. 104:26).
Rabbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Meir.”</i> said: Such creatures which have been created from the earth increase and multiply on the earth, and such which have been brought forth from the water increase and multiply in the water, except all kinds of winged birds, for their creation was || from the water, yet they increase and multiply on the earth, as it is said, "And let the fowl multiply in the earth" (Gen. 1:22). Such as were brought forth from the water increase and multiply by the egg;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads here: “in the water” instead of “by the egg.”</i> and such as were created from the earth increase and multiply by fœtus (<i>i.e.</i> living offspring).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Basil, <i>op. cit.</i> vii. 2: and John of Damascus, <i>op. cit.</i> ii. 9, for the creation of and from the water; cf. T.B. Chullin, 27b, Bechoroth, 8a, Pal. Targum on Gen. 1:20, and Midrash Agadah, p. 3. Luria (note 43) suggests an emendation of the text as follows: “Such as <i>were created</i> from the water increase and multiply by living offspring” (<i>e.g.</i> whales); whereas such as were <i>brought forth</i> from the water are hatched from the egg” (<i>e.g</i>. the duck). The 1st ed. reads: “multiply on the earth.” Does the 1st ed. here preserve the true reading?</i>

Chapter 10

CHAPTER X<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. this is marked as ch. ix. Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Jonah, ed. Greenup, pp. 6 ff., contains selections from <i>P.R.E.</i> here.</i><br><small>THE HISTORY OF JONAH</small> [11 <small>A</small>. i.]<br>O<small>N</small> the fifth day Jonah<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The story of Jonah belongs to the series of events which happened on a Thursday; moreover, the Leviathan mentioned in connection with the story was created on the fifth day. See Jalḳuṭ, Jonah, § 550, and <i>supra,</i> pp. 63 f.</i> fled before his God. Why did he flee? Because on the first occasion when (God) sent him to restore the border of Israel, his words were fulfilled, as it is said, "And he restored the border of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here. The first two editions continue as in our translation.</i> from the entering in of Hamath" (2 Kings 14:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) continues this verse: “unto the sea of Arabah, according to the word of the Lord, the God of Israel, which he spake by the hand of his servant Jonah, the son of Amittai the prophet, who was of Gathhepher.” In spite of the sins of Israel, this prophecy of Jonah was fulfilled. Jonah is only once referred to in the apocryphal literature, 3 Macc. vi. 8; see LXX text of Tobit xiv. 4.</i> On the second occasion (God) sent him to Jerusalem to (prophesy that He would) destroy it. But<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “because they repented.”</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, did according to the abundance of His tender mercy and repented of the evil (decree), and He did not destroy it;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> It is assumed by our Midrash that this prophecy is referred to by Jonah (4:2), “Was not this my <i>saying</i> when I was yet in <i>my country</i>… for I knew that thou art a gracious God… and repentest thee of the evil.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 89b.</i> thereupon<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “Israel.”</i> they called him a lying prophet.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Kings 9:4, 11, 12. The prophet mentioned in these verses is Jonah, according to Rashi and Ḳimchi, <i>in loc.</i></i> On the third occasion<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Jebamoth, 98a.</i> (God) sent him against Nineveh<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to Nineveh.”</i> to destroy it. Jonah argued with himself, saying, I know that the nations are nigh to repentance,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> pp. 342 f., and Mekhilta Bô, 1, p. 2; T. J. Synhedrin 11:7, 30b; Tanchuma Vajiḳra, § vii. This is an excellent dictum. The non-Jews are easily turned to repentance. The first editions read: “this nation is nigh to repentance.”</i> now they will repent and the Holy One, blessed be He, will direct His anger against Israel. And is it not enough for me that Israel should call me a lying prophet; but shall also the nations of the world (do likewise)? Therefore, behold, I will escape from His presence to a place where His glory is not declared. (If) I ascend above the heavens, it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “it is said that His glory is there, as it is said.”</i> "Above the heavens is his glory" (Ps. 113:4). (If) above the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “Above the earth? It is said that His glory is there, as it is said.” For similar questions see Chrysostomus, <i>Homily on Repentance,</i> 3.</i> (it is said), "The whole earth is full of his glory" (Isa. 6:8); behold, I will escape to the sea,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the first editions the word (<span>לים</span>) “to the sea” is replaced by (<span>לי</span>) “for myself.”</i> to a place || where His glory is not proclaimed. Jonah went down to Joppa, but he did not find there a ship in which he could embark, for the ship in which Jonah might have embarked was two days' journey away from Joppa,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This addition to the Biblical narrative is preserved in the Midrash Jonah (in Jellinek’s <i>Beth Ha-Midrash,</i> i. pp. 96–105), and see the Ẓohar, Gen. 121a, b, for further embellishment. This Midrash, as well as our chapter, undoubtedly formed one of the Homilies for the service of the Day of Atonement, the Book of Jonah forming the lesson from the Prophets for the afternoon service of that day. This point is of importance in our estimate of the probable use which our book was intended to render. Was it a book for the Synagogue? Was it intended to supply Midrashic material for the preacher in his public discourses? As far as this 10th Chapter is concerned, the answer is in the affirmative. We shall find further evidence to support this view in the course of our study of this book.</i> in order to test<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the text should read: “In order to test Jonah what did the Holy One, blessed be He, do?”</i> Jonah. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He sent against it a mighty tempest on the sea and brought it back to Joppa. Then Jonah saw and rejoiced in his heart, saying, Now I know that my ways will prosper before me.
He said to the (sailors), We<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “<i>we</i> will embark.” The 1st and 2nd eds. read: “I will embark.”</i> will embark with you. They replied to him, Behold, we are going to the islands of the sea, to Tarshish.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Ibn Ezra on Jonah 1:3 tells us on the authority of Sa’adiah that Tarshish is Tarsus; he also gives another opinion that Tunis in Africa is the port referred to. For other views, see Gesenius (Oxford edition), pp. 1076 f.</i> He said to them, We<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads also here: “<i>we</i> will embark.” The 1st and 2nd eds. read: “I will embark.”</i> will go with you. Now (this) is the custom on all ships that when a man disembarks therefrom he pays his fare; but Jonah, in the joy of his heart, paid his fare in advance,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Nedarim, 38a, according to which Jonah pays the fares of all on board. See <i>J.E.</i> vii. 226 f. for the story of Jonah in Rabbinical literature.</i> as it is said, "But Jonah rose up to flee unto Tarshish from the presence of the Lord; and he went down to Joppa and found a ship going to Tarshish; so he paid the fare thereof, and went down into it,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. ends the quotation here, but adds “etc.” The first editions add “etc.” after “Joppa.”</i> to go with them" (Jonah 1:3).
They had travelled one day's journey, and a mighty tempest<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Midrash Kônen, p. 25, at the creation of the world God stipulated with the sea that it should not suffer Jonah to sail to Tarshish.</i> on the sea arose against them on their right hand and on their left hand; but the movement<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit “way.”</i> of all the ships passing<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The versions in Tanchuma Vajiḳra, § viii., and Jalḳuṭ Jonah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> differ somewhat. Our text is, however, the source whence the Midrashim have drawn their material. Ḳimchi on Jonah 1:7 remarks: “I have found in the Pirḳê R. Eliezer, A great tempest arose against them on the sea, and on their right hand and on their left hand all the ships were passing to and fro in peace in the tranquillity of the sea; and the ship into which Jonah had embarked was in great distress so that one thought that it would be broken in pieces.” See Gen. Rab. 24:4 with reference to the wind sent to hinder Jonah; cf. Lev. Rab. 15:1 on same point.</i> to and fro was peaceful in a quiet sea, but the ship into which Jonah had embarked was in great peril of shipwreck, as it is said, "But the Lord sent out a great wind into the sea, and there was a mighty tempest in the sea, so<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the preceding part of the quotation.</i> that the ship was like || to be broken" (<i>ibid.</i> 4).
Rabbi Chanina<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Chananjah.”</i> said: (Men) of the seventy languages<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The seventy nations of humanity have each one a representative on board. The ship is a type of the world, which only can find its salvation through the willing martyrdom of the Hebrew, who, although he be inoffensive in his conduct with his fellow-men of all nationalities, is nevertheless quite willing to allow himself to be doomed to destruction in order to relieve his fellow-men of their threatened ruin. This universalistic aspect of the mission of the Hebrew is familiar to the student of the Bible. Abraham, Moses, and the suffering servant of God, who is none other than Israel, represent this teaching, which our book enforces. The basis for the Midrashic idea of the seventy nations is afforded by comparing the text of Jonah 1:5, which says, “<i>And every man</i> cried unto his God,” with the text in Mic. 4:5, “For <i>all the people</i> will walk <i>every man</i> in the name of his God.”</i> were there on the ship, and each one had his god in his hand, (each one) saying:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first two editions read here: “as it is said, ‘ Then the mariners were afraid, and cried every man unto his God ‘” (Jonah 1:5). The Venice edition adds: “They bowed down saying, Let each man call on the name of his God.”</i> And the God who shall reply and deliver us from this trouble, He shall be God.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Elijah’s appeal on Mount Carmel, 1 Kings 18:24.</i> They arose and every one called upon the name of his god, but it availed nought.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum, Jonah 1:5.</i> Now Jonah, because of the anguish of his soul, was slumbering and asleep. The captain of the ship came to him, saying, Behold, we are standing betwixt death and life, and thou art slumbering and sleeping; of what people art thou? He answered them, "I am an Hebrew" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). (The captain) said to him, Have we not heard that the God of the Hebrews is great? Arise, call upon thy God, perhaps He will work (salvation) for us according to all His miracles which He did for you at the Reed Sea. He answered them,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “I will not hide from you that.”</i> It is on my account that this misfortune has befallen you; take me up and cast me into the sea and the sea will become calm unto you, as it is said, "And he said unto them, Take me up, and cast me forth into the sea; so shall the sea be calm unto you" (<i>ibid.</i> 12).
Rabbi Simeon said: The men would not consent to throw Jonah into the sea; but they cast lots among themselves and the lot fell upon Jonah.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said, ‘ So they cast lots, and the lot fell upon Jonah’” (Jonah 1:7).</i> What did they do? They took all their utensils which were in the ship, and cast them into the sea<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum, Jonah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Midrash Jonah (ed. They took Jonah and they stood on the side of the ship, saying, God of the world ! O Lord ! They took him (and cast him into the sea) up to his knee-joints, and the sea-storm abated. They took him up again to themselves and the sea became agitated again against them.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “they cast him (into the sea) up to his navel,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and the sea-storm abated. "And the Lord had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah" (<i>ibid.</i> 17).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation occurs here only in the MS. The two eyes of the fish were like windows<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads “<i>ampumeth</i>.” According to Jastrow, <i>T.D.</i> 78a, this stands for <i>ôphsejanioth,</i> “glass windows.” This represents <i>δψιανóς</i> (obsidian), a stone used as glass, see <i>infra,</i> p. 330. Rabbi Meir said: || One pearl was suspended inside the belly of the fish and it gave illumination to Jonah, like this sun which shines with its might at noon; and it showed to Jonah all that was in the sea and in the depths,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “and concerning him (<i>i.e.</i> Jonah) the Scripture says.” The Ẓohar, Exodus, 48a, offers a parallel to this sentence.</i> as it is said, "Light is sown for the righteous" (Ps. 97:11).
The fish said to Jonah, Dost thou not know that my day had arrived to be devoured in the midst of Leviathan's mouth? Jonah replied, Take me beside it, and I will deliver thee and myself from its mouth. It brought him next to the Leviathan. (Jonah) said to the Leviathan, On thy account have I descended to see thy abode in the sea, for, moreover, in the future will I descend and put a rope in thy tongue,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 40:25 (in Heb.= R.V. xli. 1).</i> and I will bring thee up and prepare<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to sacrifice.”</i> thee for the great feast of the righteous.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The feast of the righteous in the Messianic age is referred to by Jesus in Matt. xxvi. 29; see also T.B. (Jonah) said to it (<i>i.e</i>. the fish), Behold, I have saved thee from the mouth of Leviathan, show me what is in the sea and in the depths. It showed him the great river of the waters of the Ocean,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The river of the waters of the ocean means the water which was supposed to surround the earth; see 3 Baruch ii. 1, Apoc. Ps. 104:5 and T.B. Chagigah, 12b.</i> and it showed him the lowest Sheol,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads “Gehinnom.” See T.B. ‘Erubin, 19a. Enoch lxiii. 10, with Charles’ note, <i>in loc.</i></i> as it is said, "Out of the belly of Sheol I cried,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions give the last words of this quotation, which are missing in the MS.</i> and thou didst hear my voice" (<i>ibid.</i> 2); and it showed him (what was) beneath the Temple of God, as it is said,"(I went down) to the bottom of the mountains"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The roots of the seven mountains in Jerusalem whereon the Temple rested. The mountains are designated in the O.T. as follows: Mount Zion, Mount Moriah, The Holy Mount, The Mount of my Holy Beauty, The Mount of the House of the Lord, The Mount of the Lord of Hosts, and The Lofty Mount of the Mountains.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 6). Hence we may learn that Jerusalem stands upon seven (hills<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The word for “hills” is missing in the MS.; some other word was inserted and then erased. On the summit the Temple had been built in all its splendour.”</i>), and he saw there the Eben Shethiyah<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> According to T.J. Enoch, xviii. 2; and <i>infra,</i> p. 266.</i> (Foundation Stone) fixed in the depths.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “beneath the Temple of God.”</i> He saw there the sons of Korah<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria notes that according to Midrash Kônen (p. 31) the “company of Korah” are in the third department of Gehenna.
