They<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition and Midrash Jonah, p. 98, read: “The fish said.”</i> said to Jonah, Behold thou dost stand beneath the Temple of God, pray and thou wilt be answered. Forthwith Jonah said to the fish, Stand in the place where thou art standing, because I wish to pray. The fish stood (still), and Jonah began to pray before the Holy One, blessed be He, and he said: Sovereign of all the Universe !<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Thou art called ‘the One who brings up’ and ‘the One who brings down.’ I have gone down, now bring me up.”</i> Thou art called "the One who kills" and "the One who makes alive," behold, my soul has reached unto death, now restore me to life. He was not answered until this word came forth from his mouth, "What I have vowed I will perform" (<i>ibid.</i> 9), namely, I vowed to draw up Leviathan and to prepare<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to sacrifice.” See Midrash Jonah, p. 99.</i> it before Thee, I will perform (this) on the day of the Salvation<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the day of the Messianic judgment. The sailors saw all the signs, the miracles, and the great wonders which the Holy One, blessed be He, did unto Jonah, and they stood and they cast away<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “into the sea.”</i> every one his God, as it is said, "They that regard lying vanities forsake their own shame"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ḳimchi, <i>in loc.,</i> for the meaning of Chesed. Ḳimchi quotes in his commentary on Jonah 2:9 our passage with a variant reading.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 8). They returned to Joppa and went up to Jerusalem and circumcised the flesh of their foreskins, as it is said, "And the men<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The text of the Bible reads here “men,” as in our MS., but the first editions read “the sailors.” See Ẓohar, Ex. 231a.</i> feared the Lord exceedingly; and they offered a sacrifice unto the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> i. 16). Did they offer sacrifice?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Is it not (a fact) that they do not accept sacrifices from the nations?” See T.B. Menachoth, 73b, and cf. Paul’s attitude towards the table of the idolaters of his day (see 1 Cor. x. 21).</i> But this (sacrifice) refers to the blood of the covenant of circumcision, which is like the blood of a sacrifice.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ex. Rab. xvii. 3 and 5.</i> And they made vows every one to bring his children and all belonging to him to the God<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “They vowed and performed (it) that each one should bring his wife and all his household to the <i>fear</i> of the God of Jonah.” The “Phoboumenoi” and “Sebomenoi” correspond to these proselytes who fear God. On the subject see Schürer, 11. ii. 311–319 (E.T.).</i> of Jonah; and they made vows and performed them, and concerning them it says, "Upon the proselytes, the proselytes of righteousness."<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to the Shemoneh ‘Esreh, the xiiith benediction (Singer, p. 48, last paragraph). See also T.B. Megillah, 17b, and Midrash Jonah, <i>loc. cit.</i><br>This chapter should be compared with the Midrash Jonah (ed. Jellinek, and ed. Eisenstein, <i>Ozar Midrashim,</i> pp. 217b ff.). Our book was the source used by the author of the Midrash. The variant readings which a comparison of the two texts affords may be illustrated by one example: instead of “the day of the salvation of Israel,” the Midrash reads, “the day of my salvation.” Again, the prayer of Jonah in the Midrash is considerably longer than that of <i>P.R.E.</i><br>The story of Jonah is interpreted in a fine Midrashic spirit by Zeno in his 17th tractate. Ephraim (29th chap. on the prophet Jonah) refers to Jonah’s dread of being called a “lying prophet,” and mentions also the dread inspired by Jonah among the terrible monsters of the deep. A very interesting point is suggested by a passage in Origen, <i>contra Celsum,</i> vii. 57, according to which Jonah was considered to be the Messiah in place of Jesus. Our book ascribes certain Messianic functions to Jonah in connection with the Leviathan and the Day of Israel’s salvation. Perhaps he is a type of the “Messiah ben Joseph” who is to overcome the Anti-Christ or Satan (<i>i.e.</i> the Leviathan). The New Testament connects the story of Jonah with its Messiah; see Matt. xii. 39–41 and <i>ibid.</i> xvi. 4; cf. Luke xi. 29–32. The “Fish” as a Christian Messianic emblem may be associated with the Jonah legends.</i>

Chapter 11

CHAPTER XI<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the tenth chapter in our MS.</i><br><small>THE WORK OF CREATION ON THE SIXTH DAY</small> [12<small>B</small>. i.]<br>O<small>N</small> the sixth day (God) brought forth from the earth all kinds of animals, male and female, clean and unclean. By two signs<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, 59a, and <i>supra</i>, p. 60. The attention drawn to the ritual regulations of Shechiṭah and to the clean animals is what one would expect in a popular treatise for perusal in the home or Synagogue. This seems to be the tendency of much of the Pseudepigrapha, such as the Book of Jubilees or the Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs. The Jewish law as to clean animals is explained allegorically by the Epistle of Barnabas x.</i> are they declared to be clean: (the signs are) chewing the cud, and dividing the hoof.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. 11:4.</i> Three<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, Shemini, § vii.; there are only these three kinds of clean animals. Cf. T.B. Chullin. 63b.</i> kinds of animals were chosen for the sacrifice of a burnt-offering, namely, the ox, the lamb, and the goat. Every kind of clean animal which is neither <i>Nevelah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This word is usually rendered “carrion.”</i> (<i>i.e.</i> which has not been slaughtered according to the rules of Shechiṭah<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> On Shechiṭah see <i>J.E.</i> xi. 253 ff.</i>) nor Ṭerephah<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Ṭerephah is interpreted to mean not merely the flesh of an animal torn in the field, but all animal flesh which has not been killed according to the rules of Shechiṭah, and which has become unfit for consumption according to Jewish law and custom. See Acts x. 14, for “unclean” food.</i> (<i>i.e.</i> torn) in the field<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) and some editions read here “its flesh,” instead of “in the field.” The Prague edition reads: “it is kasher” (ritually in order and permitted). Cf. Ex. 22:31, on which our text is based, and see Baraitha of the 32 Middoth, ed. Reiffmann, p. 37.</i> is permitted to be eaten, except with regard to three parts, namely, the fat, || the blood, and the sinew of the thigh,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 32:32.</i> as it is said, "As the green herb have I given you all" (Gen. 9:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> According to T.B. Synhedrin, 59b (and cf. Siphra, Shemini, p. 48a), animal flesh was permitted to the “sons of Noah.” Had Adam not sinned, animal flesh would have been prohibited, says the Midrash Agadah, Genesis, p. 5.</i>
On the sixth day (God) brought forth from the earth seven clean beasts;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “namely, the hart, the gazelle, the roebuck, the wild-goat, the pygarg, the antelope, and the chamois.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> their slaughter and the method of consumption are similar<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The text is difficult to interpret; as regards fowl, only “one sign” is essential for the ritual slaughter, whereas “two signs” are requisite in the case of the animals mentioned; see T.B. Chullin, 71a, 89b, and 92b.</i> to the (rules observed) with a bird; and all the rest of the beasts in the field are entirely<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “all of them.”</i> unclean.
He<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “On the sixth day He brought forth.”</i> brought forth from the earth all kinds of abominations<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the original text was “Sherazim” (reptiles), instead of “Sheḳazim” (abominations); see, however, Deut. 14:3. The printed texts omit “kinds of.”</i> and creeping things, all of them are unclean.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> And therefore not to be eaten.</i> Such (creatures) which have been created from the earth, their life (or soul) and body are from the earth, and when they return they touch their dust<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “when they die they return to the place whence they were created.”</i> at the place whence they were created, as it is said, "Thou takest away their breath, they die, and return to their dust"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions do not give the last clause of the quotation.</i> (Ps. 104:29); and it is written, "And the spirit of the beast goes downward to the earth" (Eccles. 3:21).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The distinction implied here between man and beast is in the origin of the spirit, that of man is heavenly whilst that of the beast is of the earth.</i>
On the sixth day He brought forth from the earth a beast (Behemoth) which lies stretched out on a thousand hills<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 50:10 and Job 40:15, “Behold now Behemoth, which I made”; see T.B. Baba Bathra, 74b, and Targum on Ps. 50:10. Cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 63, note 11, and see 4 Ezra (ed. Box), pp. 90 ff. The Leviathan was created, according to our author, on the fifth day, whereas the Behemoth was created on the sixth day; see Jeraḥmeel v. and vi.; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 12, and <i>J.E.</i> viii. 37 ff.; and cf. Num. Rab. 21:18, and Lev. Rab. 22:10. On “Behemoth” see Midrash Kônen, pp. 26 and 37.</i> and every day has its pasture on a thousand hills, and overnight (the verdure) grows of its own account as though he had not touched it, as it is said, "Surely the mountains bring him forth food" (Job 40:20). The waters of the Jordan give him water to drink, for the waters of the Jordan surround all the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the land of Israel.” Cf. Eth. Enoch xxvi. 2 f.</i> half thereof (flow) above the earth and the other half below the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, <i>loc. cit.</i>, and cf. Gen. Rab. 5:8, and xxiii. 7.</i> as it is said, "He is confident, though Jordan swell even to his mouth" (<i>ibid.</i> 23). This (creature) is destined for the day of sacrifice, for the great banquet of the righteous,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 70. According to Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 3, the female companion of the Leviathan is reserved for the Messianic Banquet; cf. Pal. Targ. on Gen. 1:2, and cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, 75a, Gen. Rab. 7:4, Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 14.</i> as it is said, "He only that made him can make his sword<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> To slay him.</i> to approach unto him" (<i>ibid.</i> 19).
The<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Forthwith the Holy One,” etc.</i> Holy One, blessed be He, spake to the Torah:<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Torah is the instrument in God’s hand at the Creation; see <i>supra</i>, p. 12, and Gen. Rab. 1:1. Cf. Midrash Kônen, p. 23, based on Prov. 3:19. The idea was used by the author of the Epistle of Barnabas v. 5, vi. 12, where God is represented as consulting the Christ. According to other traditions of the Church and Synagogue, God consulted the ministering angels at the creation of man; cf. Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 4, and Irenæus, <i>adv. Hœr.</i> i. 24.</i> "Let us make || man in our image, after our likeness" (Gen. 1:26). (The Torah) spake before Him: Sovereign of all the worlds ! The man<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first edition reads: “This man.” The Venice edition has: “The world is Thine, this man,” etc.</i> whom Thou wouldst<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds here: “is Thine.” The idea expressed by the next few words, “that man would have but few days,” is to be compared with p. 125, <i>infra.</i> The sentence is based on Job 14 I.</i> create will be limited in days and full of anger; and he will come into the power of sin. Unless Thou wilt be long-suffering with him, it would be well for him not to have come into the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Matt. xviii. 6, and Eth. Enoch xxxviii. 2.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, rejoined: And is it for nought that I am called "slow to anger"<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 212, and Test. Abraham, <i>A.N.C.L.</i> (extra vol.) p. 192, and cf. Wisdom xi. 23 f.</i> and "abounding in love"? He began to collect the dust of the first man from the four corners of the world;<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “earth.” The Pal. Targum on Gen. 2:7 says: “And the Lord God created man with two inclinations; and He took dust from the place of the House of the Sanctuary and from the four quarters of the world, and mixed (the dust) with all the waters of the world, and created him red, dark red (or brown), and white.” It is evident that the Targum has used our book in this context. See also Tanchuma, Peḳudê, § iii. On the creation of Adam see T.B. Synhedrin, 38b, Ẓohar, Gen. 35b, <i>ibid.</i> 205b, and <i>infra</i>, Chapter XII. Cf. Grünbaum, <i>Beiträge</i>, pp. 54 ff.</i> red, black, white,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the following: “and yellow. ‘ Red,’ this is the blood; ‘black’ refers to the entrails;<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> ‘white’ refers to the bones and sinews.” Cf. T.B. Niddah, 31a.</i> and "pale green,"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 13, reads as our MS., “pale green.” The first editions read “yellow.” Might the four colours indicate the different colours of the skin of men?</i> (which) refers to the body.
Why (did He gather man's dust) from the four comers of the world?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) I. xxxiv., and Slavonic Enoch xxx. 13; and cf. Tertullian. <i>Against the Valentinians</i>, xxiv., and the Book of the Bee (ed. Budge), p. 16.</i> Thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He: If a man should come from the east to the west, or from the west to the east,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “or to any place where he may go.”</i> and his time comes to depart from the world, then the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “which is in that place.”</i> shall not say, The dust of thy body is not mine,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and I will not receive thee.”</i> return to the place whence thou wast created.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Gen. Rab. 20:10, and Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 31 (ed. Friedmann), p. 164, the “return” of man to the dust is held to signify the resurrection.</i> But (this circumstance) teaches thee that in every place where a man goes or comes,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and his end comes to depart from the world, whence the dust of his body comes thence it returns, and that dust will raise its voice, as it is said,” etc.</i> and his end approaches when he must depart from the world, thence is the dust of his body, and there it returns to the dust, as it is said, "For dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return" (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 19).
The day had twelve hours;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the order of the hours of the day whereon Adam was created is a gloss added by a copyist who knew the legends of the Talmud; cf. T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i> See Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 3a; Pesiḳta Rabbathi, § xlvi. p. 187b, note 7; Lev. Rab. 29 I; Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92:3; Tanchuma, Shemini, § viii. R. Bechai on Gen. 2:7 gives parallel readings to our text. The Church literature also has many legends of the Haggadic type concerning the creation of Adam; thus the Apostolic Constitutions, vii. 34, says: “Thou hast exhibited man (Adam) as the ornament of the world, and formed him a body out of the four elements.” Irenæus (<i>adv. Hœr.</i> v. 23) says: “Adam sinned on the sixth day of the Creation.” See also Aphraates, <i>Homilies</i>, ed. Wright, p. 168; other references are given by Ginzberg, <i>Die Haggada bei den Kirchenvätern</i>, p. 50; and cf. Kohut in <i>Z.D.M.G.</i> xxv. pp. 59–94, and <i>J.E.</i> i. 174 ff.</i> in the first hour He collected the dust for (the body of) Adam, in the second (hour) He formed it into a mass,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Hippolytus (in <i>A.N.C.L.</i> vi. p. 130) for Adam legends, and cf. <i>Clementine Homilies</i>, ii.</i> in the third (hour) He gave it its shape, in the fourth (hour) He endowed || it with breath,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “a soul was cast into him.” The first editions read: “He cast a soul into him.” See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 15, and Midrash Abkhir, and cf. W. R. Harper Memorial Vols. i. p. 258.</i> in the fifth (hour) he stood on his feet,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He made him stand on his feet.”</i> in the sixth (hour) he called the (animals by their) names, in the seventh (hour) Eve was joined to him (in wedlock), in the eighth (hour) they were commanded concerning the fruits of the tree, in the ninth (hour) they went up to (their) couch as two and descended as four,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees iii. 34, and cf. Gen. Rab. 22:2 and Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. lxxiii. Perhaps our book refers to the conception of Abel and his twin-sister. The Church Fathers deal with similar legends, see Cyril of Jerusalem, Catechism, xii. 6; cf. <i>Schatzhöhle</i>, p. 7, and the Book of the Bee, p. 24.</i> in the tenth (hour)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “They were brought into the Garden of Eden and.” This reading is contradicted by our book, see <i>infra</i>, p. 84. See also the Book of the Bee, p. 23.</i> they transgressed His commandment, in the eleventh (hour) they were judged, in the twelfth (hour) they were driven forth, as it is said, "So he drove out the man" (<i>ibid.</i> 24).
And He formed<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The story of man’s creation is recapitulated here and in the next chapter. We have a collection of three variant accounts of the same legend. See Introduction.</i> the lumps of the dust of the first man into a mass<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targ. Gen. 2:7 quoted <i>supra</i>, p. 76, note 11; Gen. Rab. 14:7 and 8 on the creation of Adam. See also T.J. Sabbath 2:4, p. 5b.</i> in a clean place,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Gen. Rab. 14:8 says: “He was created from the place of his atonement,” <i>i.e.</i> the Temple.</i> (it was) on the navel<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Palestine; see Ezek. 38:12 for the term “navel of the earth.” See Jubilees viii. 12, 19; Eth. Enoch xxvi. i.; the Book of the Bee, p. 17; and <i>infra</i>, p. 266.</i> of the earth. He shaped him and prepared<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> adorned him with the faculties which distinguish man from the beast.</i> him, but breath and soul were not in him. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He breathed with the breath of the soul of His mouth, and a soul was cast<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, note 2, on this phrase; and cf. Gen. Rab. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> into him, as it is said, "And he breathed into his nostrils the breath of life" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 7).
Adam stood and he began to gaze upwards and downwards.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “and his height was from one end of the world to the other,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> as it is said, ‘Thou hast beset me <i>behind</i> and <i>before</i>’ (Ps. 139:5). ‘Behind’ refers to the west, ‘before’ refers to the east.”</i> He saw all the creatures which the Holy One, blessed be He, had created; and he<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “he began to glorify the Name of his Creator.”</i> was wondering in his heart, and he began to praise and glorify his Creator, saying, "O Lord, how manifold are thy works !" (Ps. 104:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation from Ps. 104 is very appropriately placed in Adam’s mouth, inasmuch as this psalm is a song of the Creation.</i> He stood on his feet and was adorned with the Divine Image. His height was from east to west, as it is said, "Thou hast beset me behind and before" (<i>ibid.</i> cxxxix. 5). "Behind" refers to the west, "before" refers to the east.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This passage in this connection is not in the printed texts.</i> All the creatures saw him and became afraid<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 22, and Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 6:10. The word “creatures” of our text reads “ministering angels” in the Midrashim. Slav. Enoch xxxi. 3 refers to the envy of Satan “because things were subservient to Adam on earth.” See also Philo, <i>G.T.</i> i. p. 57, n. 3, and Wisdom ix. 2, x. 2.</i> of him, thinking that he was their Creator, and they came to prostrate || themselves before him.
Adam said to them: What (is this), ye creatures ! Why are ye come to prostrate yourselves before me?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Have we here a polemic against Gnostic doctrines? See Freudenthal, <i>Hellenistische Studien</i>, p. 69. The idea of the first Adam being a “lower” God is reflected in the doctrine of the “Second Adam.” See 1 Cor. xv. 45–49 for the “Second Adam,” and cf. <i>Hellenism and Christianity</i>, pp. 44 f.</i> Come, I and you, let us go and adorn in majesty and might, and acclaim as King over us the One<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “The Living One.” The Slavonic Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Jagíc, p. 9) speaks of Adam praising God in Paradise in company with the angels.</i> who created us. If there be no people to acclaim the king as king, the king acclaims himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads this sentence thus: “Because the people acclaim the king and no king acclaims himself, if there be no people to acclaim him.” The next sentence is omitted by the first editions; their text continues: “Adam went alone and acclaimed Him king first, and all the creatures (did likewise) after him, and he said, ‘The Lord reigneth,’” etc.</i> If there be no people to praise the king, the king praises himself. In that hour Adam opened his mouth and all the creatures answered after him, and they adorned in majesty and might and acclaimed their Creator as King over themselves, and they said, "The Lord reigneth, he is apparelled with majesty" (<i>ibid.</i> xciii. 1).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> According to T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 31a, this psalm was recited in the Temple on the sixth day of the week. This custom still obtains in the Synagogue; see Singer, p. 83.</i>
Ten kings ruled from one end of the world to the other. The first king was the Holy One, blessed be He, who rules in heaven and on earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targumim (Rishon and Shêni) on Esth. 1:1, T.B. ‘Erubin, 53a, T.B. Megillah, 11a, where Ahab, Nebuchadnezzar, and Ahasuerus only are mentioned. The text of Neh. 9:5, 6 was probably used by the writer of our Midrash. Our book has been used by the writer of the Midrash of the Ten Kings; see Horowitz, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 39 f.</i> and it was His intention to raise up kings on earth, as it is said, "And he changeth the times and the seasons;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits the rest of the quotation, which is given by the first editions.</i> he removeth kings, and setteth up kings" (Dan. 2:21).
The second king was Nimrod, who ruled from one end of the world to the other, for all the creatures were dwelling in one place and they were afraid of the waters of the flood,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> i. 4. 1.</i> and Nimrod was king over them,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, pp. 174 f., and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 62, and see Book of Jashar vii. 45, “And Nimrod reigned in the earth over all the sons of Noah”; and cf. Jeraḥmeel xxxi. 20, Pal. Targ. Gen. 10:10, and Jalḳuṭ ii. § 211. A different explanation is given by Josephus, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> as it is said, "And the <i>beginning</i> of his kingdom was Babel"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On Nimrod see <i>J.E.</i> ix. 309 ff. and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 44 f.</i> (Gen. 10:10).
The third king was Joseph, who ruled from one end of the world to the other, as it is said, "And <i>all</i> the earth came || into Egypt to Joseph" (<i>ibid.</i> xli. 57). It is not written here "Egypt came,"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “‘Earth’ is not written here, but ‘and <i>all</i> the earth.’” Earth or land would refer to Egypt alone, <i>all</i> the earth refers to all countries.</i> but "they came into Egypt,"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, pp. 306 f., and cf. Gen. Rab. 90:6. “The famine was restricted to Phoenicia, Arabia, and Palestine,” says the Midrash.</i> for they brought their tribute and their presents to Joseph to buy (corn); for forty years he was second to the king,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “of Egypt.”</i> and for forty years he was king<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 11a, Book of Jashar lviii. 6; and cf. <i>J.E.</i> vii. 248 ff. for “Joseph in Rabbinical literature.”</i> alone, as it is said, "Now there arose a <i>new</i> king over Egypt" (Ex. 1:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (d. 35) adds “etc.” The verse continues: “who knew not Joseph.” Hence the inference that the new king did not know his predecessor Joseph.</i>
The fourth king was Solomon, who reigned from one end of the world to the other, as it is said, "And Solomon ruled over <i>all</i> the kingdoms" (1 Kings 4:21); and it says, "And they brought every man his present,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse is omitted by our MS., but it is given by the first editions. On Solomon see <i>J.E.</i> xi. 439 f.</i> vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and raiment, and armour, and spices, horses, and mules, a rate year by year" (<i>ibid.</i> x. 25).
The fifth king was Ahab, king of Israel, who ruled from one end of the world to the other,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the words “who ruled… other.”</i> as it is said, "As the Lord thy God liveth, there is <i>no</i> nation or kingdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and our MS. do not continue the quotation, but add “etc.”</i> whither my lord hath not sent to seek thee" (<i>ibid.</i> xviii. 10). All the princes of the provinces<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>איפרכיא</span> or <span>אפרכיא</span> (<i>ὲπαρχία</i>), prefecture.</i> were controlled<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “were conquered.”</i> by him; they sent and brought their tribute and their presents to Ahab. Are not all the princes of the provinces of the world two hundred and thirty-two?<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “Ahasuerus ruled over half the world, 116 provinces, and by the merit of Esther 11 more provinces were added to him, as it is said, ‘Ahasuerus who reigned, from India unto Ethiopia, one hundred and seven and twenty provinces’”<sup></sup> (Esth. 1:1).</i> as it is said, "Then he mustered the young men of the princes of the provinces, and they were two hundred and thirty-two" (<i>ibid.</i> xx. 15).
The sixth king was Nebuchadnezzar, who<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 81, note 7.</i> ruled from one end of the world to the other.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits here the following passage, which occurs in this context in the first two editions: “as it is said, ‘And wheresoever the children of men dwell’” (Dan. 2:38). The preceding verse reads: “Thou, O king, art king of kings.”</i> Moreover, he ruled over the beasts of the field and the birds of heaven, and they could not open their mouth except by the permission of Nebuchadnezzar, || as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions vary the quotation by reading Isa. 10:14: “And there was none that moved the wing, or that opened the mouth, or chirped.” This verse is applied by Isaiah to Sennacherib; see <i>infra</i>, pp. 390 ff., for a reference to Nebuchadnezzar; and cf. Dan. 2:37, and T.B. Sabbath, 149b. The printed texts differ from the MS. here by omitting any reference to the beasts of the field.</i> "And <i>wheresoever</i> the children of men dwell, the beasts of the field and the fowls of the heaven hath he given into thine hand" (Dan. 2:88).
The seventh king was Cyrus,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> On Cyrus as king of the earth see Jeraḥmeel lxxviii. 1. See also T.B. Megillah, 12a. and T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 3b.</i> who ruled from one end of the world to the other, as it is said, "Thus saith Cyrus king of Persia,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends the quotation here; the first editions continue till “earth,” adding “etc.,” which also occurs in the MS.</i> <i>All</i> the kingdoms of the earth hath the Lord, the God of heaven, given me" (2 Chron. 36:23). Ahasuerus ruled over half the world. Is not half the world but 116 provinces, as it is said, "This is Ahasuerus, who reigned from India unto Ethiopia" (Esth. 1:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This paragraph in its context is peculiar to our MS.; see <i>supra</i>, p. 81, note 11.</i>
The eighth king was Alexander<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> On Alexander the Great in Rabbinic literature see <i>J.E.</i> i. 342 f., where a good bibliography is to be found at the end of the article. See also Jeraḥmeel, Index, p. 299, <i>s.v.</i> “Alexander.”</i> of Macedonia, who ruled from one end of the world to the other, as it is said, "And as I was considering, behold, an he-goat came from the west<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation in the MS. ends here; the first editions agree in this instance.</i> over the face of the <i>whole</i> earth" (Dan. 8:5). "Over the earth" is not written here, but "over the face of the <i>whole</i> earth."<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “that he might know what was at the ends of the earth.” The phrase occurs in a modified form a few lines lower down in our MS.</i> And not only that, but he wished to ascend to heaven in order to know what is in heaven, and to descend into the depths in order to know what is in the depths,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. ‘Abodah Ẓarah iii. 1, 42c.</i> and not only that, but he attempted to go to the ends of the earth in order to know what was at the ends of the earth. The Holy One, blessed be He, divided his kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. Rab. 13:14.</i> among the four corners (or winds) of the heavens, as it is said, "And when he shall stand up, his kingdom shall be broken, and shall be divided towards the four winds of the heaven" (<i>ibid.</i> xi. 4).
The ninth king is King || Messiah, who, in the future, will rule from one end of the world to the other,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Not merely over Palestine does the Messianic kingdom extend, but over the whole world. This universalism is noteworthy.</i> as it is said, "He shall have dominion also from sea to sea" (Ps. 72:8);<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This verse is not given in the first editions. The verse continues: “And from the river unto the ends of the earth.”</i> and another Scripture text says, "And the stone that smote the image became a great mountain, and filled <i>the whole earth</i>" (Dan. 2:35).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc.</i>, and Num. Rab. <i>loc. cit.</i> This verse was known to Josephus as a Messianic text; see <i>Ant.</i> x. 10. 4.</i>
The tenth king will restore the sovereignty to its owners.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to its owner”; see <i>infra</i>, p. 130, and Maimonides, Hilkhoth Melakhim xi. 4.</i> He who was the first king will be the last king, as it is said, "Thus saith the Lord, the King… I am the first, and I am the last;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends quotation here; the first editions continue the text.</i> and beside me there is no God" (Isa. 44:6); and it is written, "And the Lord shall be king over <i>all</i> the earth" (Zech. 14:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Messianic kingdom is universal in space, but not in time; the kingdom of God which follows the kingdom of the Messiah will be eternal and universal. The first editions continue: “and the sovereignty shall return to its (rightful) heirs and then, ‘ The idols shall utterly pass away. And the Lord alone shall be exalted in that day’ (Isa. 2:18, 17). And He will tend His flock and cause them to lie down, as it is written, ‘I myself will feed my sheep, and I will cause them to lie down’ (Ezek. 34:15); and we shall see Him eye to eye, as it is written, ‘For they shall see, eye to eye, when the Lord returneth to Zion’” (Isa. 52:8).</i>

Chapter 12

CHAPTER XII<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. this is ch. xi.</i><br><small>ADAM IN PARADISE</small> [14<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>W<small>ITH</small> love abounding did the Holy One, blessed be He, love the first man, inasmuch as He created him in<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “from a pure and holy place. From which place did He take him? From the site of the Temple.”</i> a pure locality, in the place of the Temple,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Man’s body is an emblem of God’s sanctuary. In the preceding chapter we are told that God gathered the <i>dust</i> to form the first man from the four corners of the earth, establishing thereby the right of every human being to live and to be buried in any part of the earth. A similar idea was known to Philo, <i>de Mundi opific</i>. Mi. 35, C.W. i. p. 42, § 51. As to the Temple being the site of Adam’s origin see T.J. Naẓir vii. 2, 52b, and Gen. Rab. 14:8, and cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 143. Eden was more than a mere garden. See T.B. Berakhoth, 34b.</i> and He brought him into His palace,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “Palace” recalls Dan. 11:45.</i> as it is said, "And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The words “to dress it and to keep it” are missing in the MS., but they are found in the 1st ed.</i> to dress it and to keep it" (Gen. 2:15). From which place did He take him? From the place of the Temple, and He brought him into His palace, which is Eden, as it is said, "And he put him into the garden of Eden to dress it" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This does not occur here in the printed texts, which continue: “What labour then was there in the midst of the garden, that (the text) should say: ‘to dress it and to keep it’?” According to Jubilees iii. 15, “Adam and his wife were in the garden of Eden for seven years tilling and keeping it, and we gave him work, and we instructed him to do everything that is suitable for tillage.” As we shall see, our book gives an allegorical interpretation of this “work in Eden.”</i> Perhaps thou wilt say:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “There was work (to be done) in the garden of Eden, namely, that he should prune the vines in the vineyards.”</i> To plough (the fields) and cast out<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 28:24 for phraseology.</i> the stones from the ground.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “or again, that he should pile up the sheaves or cut (the corn).”</i> But did not all the trees grow up of their own accord?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. Rab. 13:1.</i>
Perhaps thou wilt say: There was some other work (to be done) in the garden of Eden, (such as) to water the garden. But did not a river flow through and issue forth from Eden, and water the garden, as it is said, || "And a river went out of Eden to water the garden" (<i>ibid.</i> 10)?
What then is the meaning of this expression: "to dress it and to keep it"? (The text) does not say "to dress it and to keep it" except (in the sense) of being occupied with the words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Torah means not merely the written word of God, but also its interpretation and implication.</i> and keeping all its commandments,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts read differently here: “to keep the way of the tree of life.” See Siphrê, Deut. § 41.</i> as it is said, "to keep the way of the tree of life" (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 24). But the "tree of life" signifies only the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Palestinian Targum renders Gen. 2:15 as follows: “And the Lord God took the man from the mountains of worship, where he had been created, and made him dwell in the garden of Eden, to do service in the Law and to keep its commandments.” A similar interpretation occurs in the Church Father Theophilus (<i>To Autolycus</i>, ii. 24) and in the Slavonic Enoch xxxi. 1: “And I made a garden in Eden in the East, and (I ordained) that he should observe the Law and keep the instruction.”</i> as it is said, "It is a tree of life to them that lay hold upon it" (Prov. 3:18).
And (Adam) was at his leisure in the garden of Eden, like one of the ministering angels.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Man is become “like one of us,” was interpreted by the Midrash, Gen. Rab. 21:5, and Mekhilta, Beshallach, vi. p. 33a (n. 18 for parallels) as meaning: “like one of the ministering angels.” This idea of the Midrash was known to Justin Martyr, <i>Dial. c. Tryph</i>. lxii.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said: I am alone in My world and this one (Adam) also is alone in his<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Some texts read: “My.” See Pal. Targum, Gen. 2:18.</i> world. There is no propagation before Me and this one (Adam) has no propagation in his life;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “before him.”</i> hereafter all the creatures<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Supra</i>, p. 79, we read that the animals wished to worship Adam, thinking he was their Maker. The belief was prevalent in former days that all the animals in Paradise were endowed with speech and reasoning power. See Jubilees iii. 28 (n. 28), and Grünbaum, <i>op. cit</i>. pp. 56, 60.</i> will say: Since there was no propagation in his life,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “before him.”</i> it is he who has created us.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Our author may wish to refute the notion obtaining in some non-Jewish religions that God had physical offspring.</i> It is not good for man to be alone, as it is said, "And the Lord God said, It is not good for man to be alone; I will make him an help meet for him …" (Gen. 2:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Thereby divine attributes will not be given to him by the other creatures. They will perceive that man is not omnipotent. Our Midrash may also hint that Adam (first or Second Adam) was not the Creator. As we have pointed out, the view that the Second Adam was the Creator obtained in early Christian circles. See Gen. Rab. 12:7.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah said:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions insert here: “Do not read<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> (in Gen. 2:18) <i>k’negdo</i>, ‘meet for him,’ but (read) <i>l’negdo</i>, ‘against him.’”</i> If he be worthy she shall be an help meet for him; if not, she shall be against him to fight him.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 23, reads: “If he be fortunate she will correspond to him (and be in harmony with him); if not, she will oppose him.” According to Rashi she will be a “lash” (“Nigdo”) to him; see Midrash Agadah on Gen. 2:18.</i>
When the earth heard this expression<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. of man’s supremacy over it. Man was to increase and multiply, to fill the earth and to <i>subdue</i> it (Gen. 1:28). The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads: “When the earth heard the expression help-meet.”</i> thereupon it trembled and quaked, crying before its Creator: Sovereign of all worlds ! I have not the power to feed the multitude<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. sheep or herd.</i> of mankind. The Holy One, blessed be He, replied: I and thou will (together) feed the multitude<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. sheep or herd.</i> of mankind. They agreed to divide (the task) between themselves: the night was for the Holy One, blessed be He, || and the day (was apportioned) to the earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 42:8.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He created the sleep of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 3:5; T.B. Berakhoth, 58b; Gen. Rab. 14:9, and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 25:2; and cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 253. For further references to Adam legends see <i>Die Sagen der Juden</i>, ed. Micha Josef bin Gorion, 1913 (Anhang). Two volumes of this Midrashic collection have appeared, and in the appendix the sources are given for the legends dealing with the Creation, the Patriarchs, etc. Equally interesting and valuable are the <i>Legends of the Jews</i>, by L. Ginzberg; the sources of the legends have not yet appeared in the promised final volume. Parallels to the Midrashim in Christian literature are dealt with by L. Ginzberg in his <i>Haggada b. d. Kirchenvätern</i>, i., Amsterdam, 1899. Parallels in Mohammedan literature are given by Geiger, <i>Was hat Mohammed</i>, etc., and M. Grünbaum, <i>op. cit</i>. pp. 60 ff., and in <i>Z.D.M.G.</i> xxxi. pp. 183 ff.; the monographs by Rahmer (on Jerome), Funk (on Aphraates), Gerson, and Goldfahn (on Justin Martyr) should be consulted for “Christian” Midrashic parallels.</i> so that man lies down and sleeps whilst He sustains him and heals him and (gives) him life and repose, as it is said, "I should have slept: then had I been at rest" (Job 3:18). The Holy One, blessed be He, supports (man) with<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “supports the earth.”</i> the earth, giving it water; and it yields its fruit and food for all creatures—but the first<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “the first.”</i> man's food "in toil<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “sorrow,” see 4 Ezra 7:12, and <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount</i>, p. 191.</i> shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life" (Gen. 3:17).
The Holy One, blessed be He, had compassion upon the first man (Adam), and, in order that he should not feel any pain, He cast upon him the sleep of deep slumber,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The deep sleep made Adam insensible to pain; cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 39a. Tertullian, <i>De Anima</i>, xliii., discusses the “sleep” of Adam.</i> and He made him sleep whilst He took one of his bones from his side and flesh from his heart<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targ. Gen. 2:21. According to the Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. 2:21, Eve was made from the sixth rib. Theophilus, <i>op. cit</i>. xxviii., discusses why Eve was formed from Adam’s rib.</i> and made it into an help (meet for him) and placed her opposite to him. When he awoke from his sleep he saw her standing opposite to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> A similar expression is used by the Book of Jashar i. 4.</i> And he said, "Bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 28). As long as he was alone he was called Adam (man).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Talmud (T.B. Jebamoth, 63b) an adult male who lives without a wife is not called man (“Adam”). This designation was given when God blessed the first <i>pair</i>. This view is opposed by our author.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit till “R. Joshua ben Ḳorchah.”</i> said: Because of the name Adamah (ground) whence he was taken, his name was called Adam. Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: He was called Adam because of his flesh and blood (<i>dām</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, i. p. 34b: “The first man was called Adam because of the word for earth (Adamah), whence he was taken;” and see <i>ibid</i>. p. 307a for another version. The Church Fathers also find fanciful interpretations of the name of the first man. Augustine on the Gospel of John ix. 14 explains the four letters of Adam’s name (in Greek) as referring to the East, West, North, and South. Cf. Slavonic Enoch xxx. 13, and Sibylline Oracles iii. 24–26. Augustine (<i>op. cit</i>. x. 12) gives the numerical value of Adam as 46, pointing out that the Temple had stood 46 years at the time of the death of the Founder of Christianity. The Rabbis were not the only people who had recourse to “Gemaṭria.” The first editions add the following paragraph: “Immediately he embraced her and kissed her,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and he said: Blessed art thou of the Lord,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> thy bone is from my bones and it is becoming for thee to be called woman (<i>ishah</i>), as it is said.”</i>). He said to him: Adam ! Adam ! And when an help-mate had been built for him, his name was called <i>êsh</i> (fire), and she (was called) <i>êsh</i> (fire).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “When an help-mate, a woman (<i>ishah</i>), had been built for him, his name was called man (<i>ish</i>), and she was called woman (<i>ishah</i>).”</i>
What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He put His name (<span>יה</span>) between their (names), saying: If they go in My ways || and keep all My precepts, behold My name is given to them,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Ish</i> (<span>איש</span>) and <i>ishah</i> (<span>אשה</span>) have the letters Yod (<span>י</span>) and Hêh (<span>ה</span>) apart from the letters <span>אש</span> which they have in common. See Jeraḥmeel vi. 16, and cf. Pal. Targ. Ex. 28:30, on the Ineffable Name.</i> it will deliver them from all distress. If they do not (walk in My ways), behold I will take away My name from their (names), and they will become <i>êsh</i> (fire).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> By removing the letters Yod and Hêh from the Hebrew words <i>ish</i> and <i>ishah</i> each word spells <i>êsh</i>, fire; and see T.B. Soṭah, 17a.</i> And fire consumes fire, as it is said, "For it is a <i>fire</i> that consumeth unto destruction" (Job 31:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See ‘Arukh, <i>s.v.</i> “Adam” and <i>s.v</i>. “êsh,” and cf. T.B. Soṭah, 5a.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, made ten wedding canopies<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The canopy used at Jewish weddings is still called Chuppah. The word may also mean Wedding Chamber. For further details, see <i>Jewish Encyclopœdia, s.v</i>.; and cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, 75a; Gen. Rab. 18:1; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. §20; and Büchler in <i>Monatsschrift</i>, xlix., 1905, pp. 18 ff., and in <i>J.Q.R</i>. (New Series) iv. pp. 490 f.</i> for Adam in the garden of Eden. They were all (made) of precious stones, pearls, and gold. Is it not a fact that only one wedding canopy is made for every bridegroom,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 19:5.</i> whilst three wedding canopies are made for a king?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Cant. 3:9–11.</i> But in order to bestow special honour upon the first man, the Holy One, blessed be He, made ten (wedding canopies) in the garden of Eden, as it is said, "Wast thou in Eden the garden of God; was every precious stone<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse is omitted by the MS. and the first editions, which read: “etc.”</i> thy covering, the sardius, topaz, and the diamond, the beryl, the onyx, and the jasper, the sapphire, the emerald, and the carbuncle, and gold?" (Ezek. 28:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> On this verse see <i>Hellenism and Christianity</i>, pp. 99 f. The ten canopies are apparently indicated by the nine precious stones and gold as mentioned in the verse. Menorath Ha-Maor § 205, states that the Messiah will have ten canopies. See also <i>B.H.M</i>. iii. p. 60.</i> Behold these are the ten canopies. The angels were playing upon timbrels and dancing with pipes,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “like females.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> See Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 91 p. 46a.</i> as it is said, "The workmanship<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew here (<i>Melëkhëth</i>) suggests angels (<i>Mäläkhim</i>). The Midrashim which deal with the “Canopies” are numerous. The subject has not been considered in all its bearings. The Jewish Messiah will be married, hence the “Canopies,” for his wedding. This is probably a disguised attack on the Christian exaltation of the unmarried state, as exemplified by the Founder of the Christian Church. The discussion on the Canopies is to be found also in Lev. Rab. 20:2; Eccles. Rab. 8:1; Jalḳuṭ, Eccles. § 764. According to Dr. Büchler (<i>J.Q.R</i>., New Series, iv. pp. 490 f.) the word Chuppah might be rendered “bower.” One also thinks of cave or cavern in this connection. According to the <i>Schatzhöhle</i>, p. 7, Adam had one cave after his expulsion from Paradise; see also Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. v.</i> of thy tabrets and of thy pipes was with thee" (<i>ibid.</i>).
On the day when the first man was created, as it is said, "In the day when thou<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Adam.</i> wast created they were prepared" (<i>ibid.</i>), the Holy One, blessed be He, said to the ministering angels: Come, let us descend and render loving service to the first man and to his help-mate, for the world rests upon the attribute of the service of loving-kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> On Gemilluth Chasadim (Service of Loving-kindness) see Paul Goodman, <i>Die Liebestätigkeit im Judentum</i>, and Bergmann, in <i>Soziale Ethik im Judentum</i>, pp. 51 ff., and see <i>infra</i>, Chapter XVI.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said: More beloved is the service of loving-kindness than the sacrifices and burnt-offerings which Israel will bring in the future upon the altar before Me, as it is said, || "For I desire love, and not sacrifice" (Hos. 6:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 107.</i>
The ministering angels were going to and fro and walking before him like friends who guard the wedding canopies,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading in Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit</i>., is as follows: “And the ministering angels were going before him like friends who guard the wedding canopies, as it is said, ‘For he shall give his angels charge over thee, to guard thee on all thy ways’” (Ps. 91:11). The first editions read: “ministering angels were like groomsmen.”</i> as it is said, "For he shall give his angels charge over thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. quotes this verse up to “thee”; the entire verse is given by the first editions.</i> to keep thee in all thy <i>ways</i>" (Ps. 91:11). (The word) "<i>way</i>" here means only the way<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Prov. 30:19.</i> of bridegrooms. The Holy One, blessed be He, was like a precentor.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text is preserved in Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit</i>., and cf. Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 92 p. 46a. The precentor is the Chaẓan. The period when the Chaẓan became the Reader of the prayers is that of the Geonim. See Sopherim, 10:7, xi. 3, 5, and xiv. 14; Eppenstein’s article in <i>Monatsschrift</i>, lii., 1908, pp. 467 ff., and <i>infra</i>, p. 109.</i> What is the custom observed by the precentor? He stands and blesses the bride in the midst of her wedding chamber.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Or</i> canopy.</i> Likewise the Holy One, blessed be He, stood and blessed Adam and his help-mate, as it is said, "And God blessed them" (Gen. 1:28).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This indicates the sacred nature of matrimony, which is aptly termed <i>Ḳiddushin</i> (sanctification). See Gen. Rab. 18:2 for the marriage of Adam and Eve.</i>

Chapter 13

CHAPTER XIII<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. this is ch. xii.</i><br><small>THE SERPENT IN PARADISE</small> [15<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>"E<small>NVY</small>, cupidity, and ambition remove man (Adam) from the world."<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is taken from Aboth 4:28. The three sins enumerated brought about the sin and punishment of Adam and Eve. See Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. and (<i>b</i>) 1.; T.B. Synhedrin, 59b; and <i>infra</i>, p. 125.</i> The ministering angels<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The parallel text preserved in the Midrash Haggadol, Gen. (ed. Schechter), c. 86, reads: “the subordinate angels became jealous of him.”</i> spake before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all Worlds! "What is man, that thou shouldst take note of him?" (Ps. 144:3). "Man (Adam) is like unto vanity"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> According to our author, if Adam had not sinned he would have lived for ever. See <i>Z.D.M.G</i>. xxxi. p. 232.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 4), upon earth there is not his like.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 41:33 (Heb. xli. 24), and cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 265.</i> (God) answered them: Just as all of you praise Me in the heights of heaven so he professes My Unity on earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “in the lower regions.” See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 25. According to Slavonic Enoch xxx. 2, Adam in Paradise sees the heavens open “that he should perceive the angels singing the song of triumph.”</i> nay, moreover, are you able to stand up and call the names for all the creatures which I have created? They stood up, but were unable (to give the names). Forthwith Adam stood up and called the names for all His creatures, as it is said, "And the man gave names to all cattle" (Gen. 2:20). When the ministering angels saw this they retreated,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “they retraced their steps,” or “betook themselves backward.” This is missing in the first two editions. On the theme see Gen. Rab. 17:4.</i> and the ministering angels said: If we do not take || counsel against this man so that he sin before his Creator, we cannot prevail against him.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, pp. 367 f., 436, and cf. Jeraḥmeel xxii. 1. The spirit animating the angels in desiring the fall of man is that of jealousy; this explains the “envy” quoted from Aboth 4 at the beginning of the chapter.</i>
Sammael was the great prince in heaven;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> At first the “great prince” was Sammael, but after his fall Michael is “the great prince”; cf. T.B. Chagigah, 12b. On Sammael and Michael see <i>infra</i>, pp. 192 f., and <i>J.E</i>. x. 665 f. (<i>s.v</i>. Samael).</i> the Chajjôth<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>., reads: “The Chajjôth with four wings and the Seraphim with six wings.” Our text and Jalḳuṭ (<i>loc. cit</i>.) are parallel texts; the printed texts differ slightly. The first editions read: “The Chajjôth and the Seraphim with six wings.” The Midrash Haggadol (Genesis), <i>loc. cit</i>., differs in the arrangement, and omits the reference to the Chajjôth.</i> had four wings and the Seraphim had six wings, and Sammael had twelve wings. What did Sammael do? He took his band<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. troop of angels obeying him. See Geiger, <i>op. cit</i>. pp. 101 f.</i> and descended<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, pp. 99, 193 f. The word <span>וירד</span>, “descended,” recalls Eth. Enoch vi. 6, and Jubilees iv. 15; cf. Luke x. 18.</i> and saw all the creatures which the Holy One, blessed be He, had created in His world and he found among them none so skilled to do evil as the serpent, as it is said, "Now the serpent was more subtil<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. ends quotation here, adding “etc.”</i> than any beast of the field" (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 1). Its appearance was something like that of the camel,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Serpent had the appearance of the camel prior to the punishment meted out to it by God. On the theme see T.B. ‘Erubin, 18a; T.B. Synhedrin, 59b; Gen. Rab. 19:1; Ẓohar, Ex. 136a; and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 3a. In the Slavonic Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Jagíc, p. 26) Satan uses the Serpent to deceive Eve. See Archelaus, “Disputation with Manes,” in <i>A.N.C.L</i>. xx. p. 344, for a parallel.</i> and he<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Sammael, or Satan. See Ascension of Isaiah 1:8.</i> mounted and rode upon it.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash Haggadol, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>., adds: “and betook himself to mislead the man.”</i> The Torah began to cry aloud, saying, Why, O Sammael! now that the world is created, is it the time<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads ‘<i>äd</i>, the first editions read ‘<i>ês</i> (time); so also Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> to rebel against the Omnipresent? Is it like a time when thou shouldst lift up thyself on high?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This is quoted from Job 39:18. The R.V. renders, “What time she lifteth up herself on high.” The verse is intended to illustrate Sammael’s sin in approaching Eve and causing Adam to rebel. According to Tertullian, <i>de Patient</i>, v., the Evil One “impatiently bore that the Lord God subjected the universal works” to man. This led on to his “envy.” He deceived him because he envied him.</i> The Lord of the world "will laugh at the horse and its rider"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The R.V. reads: “She scorneth the horse and his rider.” The “horse” is applied in the Midrash to the Serpent and “the rider” to Sammael.</i> (Job 39:18).
A parable, to what is the matter like?<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The deed of Sammael is illustrated by the parable.</i> To a man in whom there was an evil spirit. All the deeds which he does,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “does he do them at his own suggestion?”</i> or all the words which he utters, does he speak by his own intention? Does he not act only according to the idea of the evil spirit, which (rules) over him? So (was it with) the serpent. All the deeds which it did, and all the words which it spake, it did not speak<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “it neither spake nor did.”</i> except by the intention of Sammael. Concerning him, the Scripture says, "The wicked is thrust down in his evil-doing" (Prov. 14:32).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the version in Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i>
A parable, to what is the matter like? To a king || who married a woman and made her supreme over all that he had.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “consisting of precious stones and pearls.”</i> He said to her: All that I have shall be in thy hands, except this house,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “cask” (<span>חבית</span>), and so throughout the parable; this is more correct than “house” (<span>הבית</span>) in our text.</i> which is full of scorpions. A certain old man visited her; he asks, for instance,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This expression is omitted in the Amsterdam edition of 1708 and in the Dyhrenfürth edition. The vinegar was used by the poor for dipping therein their bread; see Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xx. p. 36a.</i> for vinegar. He said to her: Wilt thou argue that he deals kindly with thee?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “How does the king treat thee? She said to him: All that he possesses has he given to me and left in my hands except this cask.”</i> He deals with me (thus): over all that he possesses has he made me supreme. Thus said he to her: Behold, all that I have is given into thy hands except this house,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “cask” (<span>חבית</span>), and so throughout the parable; this is more correct than “house” (<span>הבית</span>) in our text.</i> which is full of scorpions. (The old man) said to her: Is not all the jewellery<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Ḳosmin</i> (<i>κόσμος</i>), jewellery; see ‘Arukh, <i>s.v</i>. <span>קזמי</span>. The reading in the first editions is corrupt.</i> of the king indeed in this house<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “cask” (<span>חבית</span>), and so throughout the parable; this is more correct than “house” (<span>הבית</span>) in our text.</i>? But<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He spake not thus to thee save for the reason that he wishes to marry another woman.”</i> he wishes to marry another woman, and to give them to her. The king is the first man (Adam), the woman is Eve, and the one who asked for vinegar is the serpent;<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> For a variant parable to illustrate the theme taken from Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 3b, see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 29.</i> and concerning them (the text) says, "There are the workers of iniquity fallen, they are thrust down, and shall not be able to rise"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions omit the second half of the verse.</i> (Ps. 36:12).
The serpent argued with itself, saying: If I go and speak to Adam, I know that he will not listen to me, for a man is always hard<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 17:8 to illustrate the notion that a man is more easily appeased than a woman. The quotation from 1 Sam. is not in the printed editions. The Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 87, reads: “for Sammael has no authority over man because he is hard.”</i> (to be persuaded), as it is said, "For a man is churlish and evil in his doings" (1 Sam. 25:3); but behold I will speak to Eve,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “the woman whose mind is feeble.” Slavonic Enoch xxxi. 6 tells us how Satanail or Satan “conceived designs against Adam; in such a manner he entered and deceived Eve. But he did not touch Adam.” The “evil eye” mentioned in our text, <i>infra</i>, might be rendered “envy.”</i> for I know that she will listen to me; for women listen to all creatures, as it is said, "She is simple and knoweth nothing" (Prov. 9:18). The serpent went and spake to the woman:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> For a Christian Midrash on this theme see “Fragments from the lost writings of Irenæus” in <i>A.N.C.L</i>. ix. p. 166.</i> || Is it<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the words in brackets.</i> (true that) you also have been commanded concerning the fruit of the tree?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The text is probably corrupt here; Luria suggests that instead of the words “this tree” which occur in the printed texts we should read “this garden.” This agrees with the reading preserved in the Oxford MS. (d. 35), and in Jeraḥmeel xxii. 2. According to the reading “this tree,” the answer desired by the Serpent would not have been forthcoming. By asking about the “fruit of <i>the garden</i>” the Serpent was enabled to mislead Eve. The Talmud (T.B. Synhedrin, 29a) lays stress on the addition to the Divine command made by Eve when she said, “neither shall ye touch it” (Gen. 3:3). Our MS. intends the question to be quite general: “Is it a fact that you have been commanded (not to eat) the fruit of any tree?” This agrees with the Midrash Haggadol, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> She said (to him): Yes, as it is said, "Of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden" (Gen. 3:8). And when the serpent heard the words of Eve, he found a way<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “opening.” See Tertullian, <i>de Patient., loc. cit</i>.</i> through which he could enter (to approach her), so he said to her: This precept is nought else except the evil eye, for in the hour when ye eat thereof, ye will be like Him, a God. Just as<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “What does He do?”</i> He creates worlds and destroys worlds,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This idea of being able to create other worlds has a parallel in Slavonic Enoch xxxi. 3: “And the devil took thought, as if wishing <i>to make another world</i>.”</i> so will ye be able to create worlds and to destroy worlds. Just as He slays and brings to life, so also will ye be able to kill and to bring to life, as it is said, "For God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MSS. end the quotation here, but add “etc.”; the first editions continue the verse.</i> then your eyes shall be opened" (<i>ibid.</i> 5).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. ends here the 12th chapter.</i>
The serpent went and touched the tree, which commenced to cry out, saying:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 2b, the tree cried out when Eve stared at it and (desired its fruit). See also Jeraḥmeel xxii. 3.</i> Wicked One! do not touch me! as it is said, "Let not the foot of pride come against me, and let not the hand of the wicked drive me away. There are the workers of iniquity fallen"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MSS. give only the verse from Ps. 36:11; the first two editions omit the second half of this verse and add the first half of the next verse.</i> (Ps. 36:11, 12).
The serpent went and said to the woman: Behold, I touched it, but I did not die; thou also mayest touch it, and thou wilt not die.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 88, adds: “Forthwith the woman saw that the tree was good for food.” See Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Pal. Targum, Gen. 3:6.</i> The woman went and touched the tree, and she saw the angel of death<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Pal. Targum (<i>loc. cit</i>.), “and the woman beheld Sammael, the angel of death, and she was afraid.”</i> coming towards her; she said: Woe is me ! I shall now die, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will make another woman<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions add: “for him.”</i> and give her to Adam,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tertullian, <i>de Patient., loc. cit</i>., where Adam is described as “not <i>yet</i> Eve’s husband.”</i> but behold I will cause || him to eat with me; if we shall die, we shall both die,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See a similar Midrash in the Church Father Ephraim, Comm. in Gen. vol. i. p. 35.</i> and if we shall live, we shall both live. And she took of the fruits of the tree, and ate thereof, and also gave (of its fruits) to her husband, so that he should eat with her, as it is said, "And she took of the fruit thereof, and did eat; and she gave also unto her husband with her" (Gen. 3:6). When Adam had eaten of the fruit of the tree, he saw that he was naked,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 98.</i> and his eyes were opened, and his teeth were set on edge. He said to her: What is this that thou hast given me to eat, that my eyes should be opened and my teeth set on edge?<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “against my knowledge.” See Jer. 31:29, 30, and Ezek. 18:2. For the Rabbinic sources dealing with the Serpent, Eve, and Adam see Tosephta Soṭah iv. (end); T.B. Soṭah, 9b; Gen. Rab. 19:4; Pesiḳta Rabbathi, § xv. p. 68b; Tanchuma, Leḳach Ṭob and Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc</i>.; and see Midrash Agadah and Rashi on Gen. 3, and cf. Jeraḥmeel xxii.; see also <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 27 ff.; Ginzberg, <i>Legends of the Jews</i>, vol. i. pp. 71 ff.; and F. R. Tennant, <i>The Fall and Original Sin</i>, 1903, pp. 152 and 158.</i> Just as my teeth were set on edge, so shall the teeth of all generations be set on edge.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See the parallel version from Gen. Rab. 19:5, translated in <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 28, and cf. Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>., Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 90, “<i>their</i> teeth and the teeth of all generations.” According to Slavonic Enoch xxx. 16: “Therefore his <i>ignorance</i> is a woe to him that he should sin, and I appointed death on account of his sin.” The expression “to set the teeth on edge” in our text means “paying the penalty.” See also 4 Ezra 3:7.</i>

Chapter 14

CHAPTER XIV<br><small>THE SIN OF ADAM AND EVE</small> [16<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>T<small>EN</small> descents upon the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Numbers, § 93; Mekhilta Jethro, 3, p. 64a; Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxxiv. Other parallels are given by Schechter, p. 51b, note 32 of his edition of Aboth de R. Nathan. The other descents are mentioned in Chapters XXIV., XXV., XXXIX., XL., XLI., XLVI., and LIII.</i> were made by the Holy One, blessed be He; they were: (1) Once in the Garden of Eden; (2) once at (the time of) the generation of the Dispersion;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>infra</i>, pp. 176f., and Gen. Rab. 38:9.</i> (8) once at Sodom;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 179, and Gen. Rab. 48:7; and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 27, which reads: “Once in <i>Egypt</i>, once at the thorn-bush, once at Sinai, once at the cleft of the rock.” The reference to Egypt will be discussed <i>infra</i>, p. 303.</i> (4) once at the thorn-bush;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 29a. and cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 312.</i> (5) once in Egypt;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This is not in the first editions. See <i>supra</i>, note 3.</i> (6) once at Sinai;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta Jethro, 9, p. 72b; and cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 318.</i> (7) once at the cleft of the rock;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 365. The reading in the first two editions is: “<i>twice</i> at the cleft of the rock.” This is probably incorrect; see <i>supra</i>, note 3, and cf. Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> (8) and (9) twice in the tent of Assembly;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 433. Here also we should read, “Once in the tent of Assembly.” Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>., has this reading, and refers to Num. 11:25.</i> (10) once in the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>loc. cit</i>.) refers here to Zech. 14:4. The ninth and tenth descents are to be in the future also: see Siphrê, <i>loc. cit</i>.; T.B. Sukkah, 5a; and Othijoth de R. ‘Aḳiba, letter Hê (Jellinek, <i>B.H.M</i>. iii. p. 24).</i>
Once in the Garden of Eden; whence do we know? Because it is said, "And they heard the voice of the Lord God <i>walking</i> in the garden<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, the first editions continue the verse.</i> in the cool of the day" (Gen. 3:8). And it is written,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions have: “And another text says.”</i> "My beloved<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The “beloved” is God. This verse is quoted because it contains the verb (<span>ירד</span>) “<i>to descend</i>.”</i> <i>is gone down</i> to his garden, to the beds of spices" (Cant. 6:2). (God) sat in judgment,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 20:2 ff. for the judgment of the Serpent, Eve, and Adam. The first editions read here: “He sat in a judgment of truth, the Judge of righteousness and truth. He called to Adam and said to him.” Cf. <span>צרוק הרין</span> (Burial Service) in Singer, pp. 318 f.</i> and He judged with judgment. He said to him (Adam): Why didst thou flee<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> For similar phraseology see Ps. 139:7. This psalm is interpreted by the Midrashim as referring to Adam; see <i>infra</i>, p. 143.</i> before Me? He answered Him: I heard Thy voice<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “I heard the report of Thee.” Cf. Hab. 3:2 and Cant. Rab. 3:6.</i> and my bones trembled,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 4:14 for a similar expression.</i> as it is said, "I heard thy voice in the garden, and I was afraid, || because I was naked: and I hid myself" (Gen. 3:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “<i>And I hid myself</i> from my deed, <i>and I was afraid</i> of my deed, for I was <i>bare</i> of (the fulfilment of) my commandment,<sup></sup> as it is said, ‘For I was naked’” (Gen. 3:10).<sup></sup></i>
What was the dress of the first man? A skin of nail,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The dress of Adam and Eve was, according to the Pal. Targum, Gen. 3:7, “onyx-coloured”; cf. Gen. Rab. 20:12. The legend of an original skin of nail is preserved in the custom which still obtains among orthodox Jews, who gaze at their nails with the Habdalah light at the termination of the Sabbath. Dr. S. Daiches considers this custom as a relic of nail magic (see Jews’ College Publications, v. pp. 31 f. n. 1). According to the Church Father Ephraim, <i>op. cit</i>. p. 139, Adam and Eve lost their angelic endowments immediately after their sin, their sight and power of discerning became limited only to matters corporeal and sensible; see the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan), p. 215, for this reference. See also Odes of Solomon, pp. 66 ff. and 69, notes 1, 2.</i> and a cloud of glory covered him. When he ate of the fruits of the tree, the nail-skin was stripped off him,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here, “and he saw himself naked,” and not after the words, “and the cloud of glory departed from him.” See Pal. Targ. Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>. A similar tradition is preserved in the <i>Coptic Apocrypha</i>, ed. Budge, p. 250.</i> and the cloud of glory departed from him, and he saw himself naked, as it is said, "And he said, Who told thee that thou wast naked?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MSS. end the quotation here, the first editions continue the verse.</i> Hast thou eaten of the tree, whereof I commanded thee?" (<i>ibid.</i> 11).
Adam said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds! When I was alone, I did not sin against Thee.
