But the woman whom Thou hast brought to me enticed me away from Thy ways,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Thy words.” See <i>B.H.M</i>. iii. pp. 60 f.</i> as it is said, "The woman whom thou gavest to be with me,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MSS. end the quotation here.</i> she gave me of the tree, and I did eat" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). The Holy One, blessed be He, called<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “He said.”</i> unto Eve, and said to her: Was it not enough for thee that thou didst sin in thy own person? But (also) that thou shouldst make Adam sin? She spake before Him: Sovereign of the world! The serpent enticed my mind to sin before Thee, as it is said, "The serpent beguiled me, and I did eat" (<i>ibid.</i> 13). He brought the three<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targ. Gen. 3:16 and cf. Gen. Rab. 20:2, 3.</i> of them and passed sentence of judgment upon them, consisting of nine curses and death.
He cast down Sammael<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> On the identification of Sammael with the Devil see Wisdom ii. 24, Pal. Targum on Gen. 3:6; see also Rev. xii. 9 and xx. 2. Paul in 2 Cor. xi. 3 refers to the beguiling of Eve by the Serpent. On the speaking of the Serpent see Jubilees iii. 7 and Josephus, <i>Ant</i>. i. 1. 4. According to Slavonic Enoch xxxi. 3, “The devil took thought, as if wishing to make another world, because things were subservient to Adam on earth.… He became Satan <i>after</i> he left the heavens.” See T.B. Sabbath, 55a, for the Haggadic account of Adam and Eve and the Serpent.</i> and his troop from their holy place in heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “But the wicked Satan… <i>I hurled him down from heaven</i>, he it is who made the tree appear pleasant in your eyes,” says the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. i.; cf. <i>ibid</i>. xlv. The Fall of Satan is mentioned in Luke x. 18, John xii. 31, and cf. Eph. ii. 2.</i> and cut off the feet of the serpent,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This Midrash was known to Josephus; see <i>Ant. loc. cit</i>. The first editions add: “And He cursed it more than all living beasts and all cattle.” Two curses are set forth here; cf. T.B. Bechoroth, 8a, and see Gen. Rab. 20:5, Tosephta Soṭah 4:17, 18.</i> and decreed that it should cast its skin and suffer pain once in seven years in great pain, and cursed it || that it should drag itself with its belly (on the ground), and its food is turned in its belly into dust<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Job 20:14; T.B. Joma, 75a: “The serpent brought man back to dust, and therefore dust is its food.”</i> and the gall of asps,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum on Gen. 3:14. “A deadly venom shall be in thy mouth, and thou shalt eat dust all the days of thy life.”</i> and death is in its mouth,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 20:16.</i> and He put hatred between it and the children of the woman,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The New Testament refers to this incident in 1 John iii. 8, Col. ii. 15, Heb. ii. 14 ff., Rom. xvi. 20, and see Revelation of Moses (in “Ante-Nicene Christian Library,” xvi. p. 461). Ephraim, <i>op. cit</i>., refers to the cutting off of the Serpent’s feet; see <i>supra</i>, p. 99, note 7. The first editions read: “between it and the woman.”</i> so that they should bruise its head,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Kiddushin 4:11, p. 66c, and Sophrim xv. 10, for the rule, “Break the head of the best among serpents.”</i> and after all these (curses comes) death.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the words of Wisdom, <i>loc. cit</i>., “But through the devil’s envy came death into the world”; see also Slavonic Enoch xxxi. 3.</i> He gave the woman nine curses and death: the afflictions arising from menstruation and the tokens of virginity;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Erubin, 100b, and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 2b.</i> the affliction of conception in the womb; and the affliction of child-birth; and the affliction of bringing up children; and her head is covered like a mourner,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> For an example of this see Büchler, <i>The Economic Condition of Judea</i>, p. 53, and see T.B. Ḳiddushin, 72a. The New Testament also directs women to have their heads covered; see 1 Cor. xi. 5 and cf. the <i>Apostolic Constitutions</i>, i. 8. In our MS. and in the Oxford MSS. as well as in some of the old editions of our book (<i>e.g</i>. Venice, 1544) after “mourner” the words “she is not shaved except on account of immorality,” occur, but later editions have deleted the passage. This phrase is of great importance in view of Dr. Büchler’s interesting and learned monograph on this theme. A special note at the end of the book will recapitulate the results of Dr. Büchler’s investigations, as the date of <i>P.R.E</i>. may possibly be determined by the period when the custom of cutting the hair of the immoral woman as a punishment obtained.</i> and it is not shaved except on account of immorality, and her ear is pierced like (the ears of) perpetual slaves;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Schwally, <i>Das Leben nach dem Tode</i>, p. 39, refers to the inference suggested by the perforation of a woman’s ears; see also <i>Z.A.T.W</i>., 1891, p. 183.</i> and like a hand-maid she waits upon her husband; and she is not believed in (a matter of) testimony;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Because Adam listened to Eve, and was led astray by her; see ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, v. 394b.</i> and after all these (curses comes) death.
He extended pardon<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads <span>רימום</span> (pardon). The Oxford MS. (d. 35) reads <span>רומים</span> (retribution), and Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) has <span>רינו</span> (his sentence). The printed texts omit this and read: “He drew Adam aside and decreed against him nine curses and death.”</i> to Adam (as to a part of the) nine curses and death. He curtailed his strength, and He shortened his stature<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Coptic Apocrypha</i>, p. 250: “his body diminished in size.”</i> by reason of the impurity connected with issues and with pollution;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 38b.</i> as well as the impurity arising from sexual intercourse; he was to sow wheat and to reap thistles,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 20:10, and Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 31 p. 164.</i> and his food was to be the grass of the earth, like that of the beast; and (he was to earn) his bread in anxiety, and his food by the sweat (of his brow); and after all these (curses came) death.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> For a Christian interpretation of the judgment, see Revelation of Moses, <i>loc. cit</i>. p. 460 f.</i>
If Adam sinned, what was the sin of the earth, that it should be cursed? Because it did not speak against the (evil) deed,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> By protesting and warning Adam; see Pal. Targum, Gen. 3:17.</i> therefore it was cursed; for in the hour when the sons of man transgress the graver sins || God sends a plague<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth (v. end), T.B. Sabbath, 32a, and T.B. Joma, 83a. The Church Fathers have very elaborate expositions of the “Fall” and its consequences. Thus Irenæus (<i>adv</i>. <i>Hœr.</i> iii. 3) writes: “It was for this reason, too, that immediately after Adam, as the Scripture relates, He pronounced no curse against Adam personally, but against the ground, in reference to his works; as a certain person among the ancients has observed, ‘God did indeed transfer the curse to the earth, that it might not remain in man.’ But man receives as a punishment of his transgression the toilsome task of tilling the earth, and to eat bread in the sweat of his face, and to return to the dust whence he was taken. Similarly also did the woman (receive) toil, and labour, and groans, and the pangs of parturition, and a state of subjection, that is, that she should serve her husband; so that they should neither perish altogether when cursed by God, nor, by remaining unreprimanded, should be led to despise God. But the curse in all its fulness fell upon the serpent which had beguiled them.” For other references see Diestel, <i>op. cit</i>. (in Index), and Thalhofer, <i>Bibliothek der Kirchenväter</i> (in Index).</i> to the sons of man; and in the hour when the sons of man transgress sins less vital, He smites the fruits of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Coptic Apocrypha</i>, p. 243: “the fruit of the earth is little because of the sins of man.”</i> because of (the sins of) the sons of man, as it is said. "Cursed is the ground for thy sake" (<i>ibid.</i> 17).

Chapter 15

CHAPTER XV<br><small>THE TWO WAYS</small> [17<small>A</small>. i.]<br>R<small>ABBI</small> E<small>LIEZER</small> said: I heard with my ear<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 5:9, and note the Targum thereon. R. Eliezer ben Hyrḳanos was held to be worthy of being endowed with the Holy Spirit; see T.J. Soṭah (end) and T.B. Synhedrin, 11a; Jalḳuṭ, Job, § 919.</i> the Lord of hosts speaking. What did He speak? He said: "See, I have set before thee this day life and good, and death and evil" (Deut. 30:15). The Holy One, blessed be He, said: Behold, these two ways<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The theme of this chapter of our book is the Jewish doctrine of the Two Ways, the ways of good and evil, or of life and death. Adam did not keep the “way of life” (see <i>supra</i>, p. 85); he disobeyed God by taking of the fruit of the tree of “good and evil.” The “Way of Life” in Paradise was guarded by the Cherubim, and the earthly way of “good and evil” is likewise in the charge of angels, good and evil. Slavonic Enoch xxx. 15 connects the “two ways” with Adam before his disobedience. On the “Two Ways” see <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount</i>, pp. 239 ff. See also Gen. Rab. 21:5. The Christian literature has also its doctrine of the Two Ways; see the <i>Apostolic Constitutions</i>, vii. 1; Epistle of Barnabas xviii.–xx.; Hermas, Mand. vi. 2; Pseudo-Clementine Homilies, v. 7; and for “Heaven and Hell” see the <i>Revelation of Peter</i> (ed. Robinson and James, 1892, pp. 48 ff.). See also Test. XII Pat., Asher i. 3, with Charles’ note <i>in loc</i>. Some of the printed texts read “two words” instead of “two ways.” The latter is, of course, the correct reading; see Jalḳuṭ, Job, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> have I given to Israel, one is good, the other is evil. The one which is good, is of life; and the one which is evil, is of death.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 38b.</i> The good way has two byways, one of righteousness and the other of love, and Elijah,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> On Elijah in Jewish literature see <i>supra</i>, p. 2, note 7; <i>J.E</i>. v. 122 ff.; Schechter, <i>Aspects of Rabbinic Theology</i>, p. 288.</i> be he remembered for good, is placed exactly between these two ways.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. the ways leading to life and death.</i> When a man comes to enter (one of these ways), Elijah,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 95; T.B. Ḳiddushin, 70a; Ruth Rab. 5:6. On Elijah’s work see Seder ‘Olam Rab. 17</i> be he remembered for good, cries aloud concerning him, saying, "Open ye the gates, that the righteous nation which keepeth truth may enter in" (Isa. 26:2). And there cometh Samuel the prophet, and he places himself between these two byways.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Samuel, like Elijah, sought to reconcile God and man. On Samuel in Rabbinic literature see <i>J.E</i>. xi. 7. On the idea in our Midrash see 1 Sam. 2:26; according to this text, Samuel grew in favour with God and man. The favour of God is the result of “righteousness,” whilst the favour of man is due to “love” between man and his fellow.</i> He says: On which of these (two byways) shall I go? If I go on the way of righteousness, then (the path) of || love is better than the former; if I go on the way of love, (the way) of righteousness is better: but I call heaven and earth to be my witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This expression is very common in the Tanna de bê Elijahu.</i> that I will not give up either of them.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “but I will take them for myself.” See Eccles. 7:18.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Samuel ! Thou hast placed thyself between these two good byways. By thy life! I will give to thee three good gifts. This teaches thee that everyone who doeth<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “who desireth and doeth,” instead of “doeth.” Luria suggests “pursueth.”</i> righteousness and sheweth the service of love, shall inherit three good gifts, and they are: life, righteousness, and glory, as it is said, "He that followeth after righteousness and love, findeth life, righteousness, and glory" (Prov. 21:21). It is only written here (in the text): "He findeth life, righteousness, and glory."<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is missing in the printed editions.</i>
(Leading) to the way of evil, there are four<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the three sins of Israel mentioned by Amos 2:6 and the four calls of Wisdom in Prov. 1:20 ff.</i> doors, and at each door seven angels<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “seven watchers, angels, are sitting,” <i>i.e</i>. guardian angels.</i> are standing—four without, and three within. The (angels) without are merciful, and those within are cruel. When a man comes to enter,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the first door.”</i> the merciful angels go to meet him and say to him: What hast thou to do with the fire yonder? What hast thou to do with those glowing coals?<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Why wilt thou enter into the midst of this fire? Why wilt thou enter among the uncircumcised and the glowing coals?” Luria reads “flames” instead of “uncircumcised.” The picture of Gehenna in our context may be suggested by the “swords of flaming fire” in the hands of the Cherubim guarding Paradise. The “flaming fire” is outside Paradise. For the “everlasting fire” in the New Testament see Matt. xxv. 41; the old editions (<i>e.g</i>. Amsterdam) read <span>הרים</span>, “mountains,” instead of “wicked.”</i> Listen to us and repent.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “return”; possibly the word implies “<i>repent and return</i>.”</i> If he hearken to them and repent, behold it is well, and if not, he says to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “If he hearken to them it is well; and if not, verily they say to them: Amongst them (yonder) there is no life.” Our MS. has undoubtedly the better reading.</i> Amongst them (yonder) let my life (be). || They say to him: Thou hast entered the first door; do not enter the second door. When he comes to enter the second door, the merciful angels go to meet him and say to him: What benefit is it to thee to be erased<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to be removed.”</i> from the Torah of thy God?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the next sentence and read instead: “that they (<i>i.e</i>. the good angels) should call thee ‘Unclean,’ and that they should flee from thee.”</i> Would it not be better to be inscribed in the Torah of thy God? Hearken unto us and repent. If he listen to them and repent, it is well; and if not, he says to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See note 2 above.</i> With them yonder let my life (be). They say to him: Behold thou hast entered the second door, do not enter the third door. When he is about to enter the third door the merciful angels go to meet him and say to him:<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read, instead of our text, the following: “Why wilt thou be erased from the book of life?<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> Is it not better for thee to be inscribed (therein) rather than to be erased (therefrom)? Hearken unto us, and repent. If he listen to them, it is well; and if not, woe to him and to his head!” See Wisdom i. 13.</i> What benefit is to thee that they (<i>i.e</i>. the good angels) should flee from thee and call thee "Unclean"? Would it not be better that they should call thee "Pure One" and not "Unclean"? Hearken to us and repent. If he hearken unto them, behold, it is well; and if not, he says unto them: With them (yonder) let my life (be). They say to him: Behold thou hast entered the third door; do not enter the fourth door! When he is about to enter the fourth door the merciful angels go to meet him and say to him: Behold, thou hast entered these doors, and thou hast not hearkened nor returned.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The translation might also be, “repented.” See Jalḳuṭ, Job, <i>loc</i>. <i>cit</i>.</i> Thus far the Holy One, blessed be He, receives || the penitent; thus far the Holy One, blessed be He, pardons<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “sins.”</i> and forgives,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 86b, and T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 16a.</i> and every day He says: Return, ye children of man, as it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read, instead of our quotation, the following: “‘Return, ye backsliding children’ (Jer. 3:14). If man hearken unto them, it is well; and if not, woe to him and to his destiny!”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> "Thou turnest man to contrition"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “destruction.” See T.B. Chagigah, 16a, for an instance of repentance even after death; see also Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 91:18, and <i>infra</i>, p. 341.</i> (Ps. 90:8).
The cruel angels<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Prov. 17:11 and cf. Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 1:22, p. 11b, and cf. Justin Martyr, <i>Dialogue with Trypho</i>, cv., on the “evil angel taking our soul.” See also Hippolytus (<i>Against Plato</i>. ed Lagarde, p. 69).</i> say: Since he would not hearken to the first (angels), let us cause his spirit to depart, as it is said, "Let his spirit go forth, let him return to his earth" (<i>ibid.</i> cxlvi. 4). And concerning them<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The unrepentant.</i> (the Scripture) says:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts omit the quotation from Ex. 20:5 and conclude the quotation from Job 33:29 with the word “work,” adding “etc.”</i> "Upon the third and upon the fourth generation of them that hate me" (Ex. 20:5); and another verse says: "Lo, all these things doth God work, twice, yea thrice, with a man" (Job 33:29). And thus He calls to Eliezer.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that probably the text originally ended with a reference to Samuel. The first editions agree with our MS. and read “to Eliezer,” indicating Rabbi Eliezer ben Hyrḳanos, whose name also occurs at the beginning of the chapter.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, said: Eliezer ! Thou hast made thyself like a threefold cord,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts omit the quotation from Eccles. 4:12. Some of the texts read, “Hast thou made thyself?” etc. The threefold cord is Torah, Divine Worship, and Loving Service. R. Eliezer had acquired Torah, and devoted his life to the service of God; and by his action to his brothers he rendered loving service to them. The reference to Samuel would be just as likely.</i> as it is said, "And a threefold cord is not quickly broken" (Eccles. 4:12). I also will apply to thee this verse: "Thou shalt be perfect with the Lord thy God" (Deut. 18:13). Do not read thus, but: "Thou shalt be perfect <i>before</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the texts “with the Lord” are identical. This is clearly due to an error of a copyist. See Jalḳuṭ, Deut. § 919, and cf. Siphrê, Deut. § 173. I have followed the reading of the Pesiḳta Ẓuṭarta, p. 30b.</i> the Lord thy God."

Chapter 16

CHAPTER XVI<br><small>THE SERVICE OF LOVING-KINDNESS</small> [17<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>T<small>HE</small> world rests upon three things: upon the Torah, upon Divine Worship, and upon the service of loving-kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth 1:2; Pesiḳta Rabbathi, 5 p. 15b; and cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 89, and <i>infra,</i> p. 122.</i>
"Upon the Torah," whence do we know (this)? Because it is written, "If my covenant<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> God’s covenant is the Torah; see T.B. Sabbath, 33a; cf. T.B. Pesachim, 54a; and T.B. Nedarim, 32a. The argument by analogy afforded by comparing similar words in two different verses of Scripture is known as “Geẓerah Shavah,” and is employed here. For examples see Levy, <i>N.H.W.</i> i. 320 f.; and cf. Bacher’s <i>Terminologie,</i> i. <i>s.v.</i> pp. 13 ff.</i> of <i>day and night</i> stand not" (Jer. 33:25); and (another text) says, "This book of the Torah shall not depart out of thy mouth,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse is omitted by our MS.; it occurs in the first editions. The MS. adds the paragraph following dealing with the service of loving-kindness.</i> but thou shalt meditate therein <i>day and night</i>" (Josh. 1:8). Whence do we know (that the world rests) upon the service of loving-kindness? Because it is said, "For I desired love, || and not sacrifice" (Hos. 6:6). Whence do we know (that the world rests) upon Divine Worship? Because it is written, "And the prayer of the upright is his delight"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the text should read: “(The world rests) upon Divine Worship. What is this (Worship)? Prayer.” The preceding part of the verse quoted reads: “The <i>sacrifice</i> of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord, and the prayer of the upright is his <i>delight</i>” (Prov. 15:8). In Mal. 2:13 “delight” is used instead of “offering.” On this theme see Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) iv. p. 9b; T. J. Megillah 3:7. 74b; Num. Rab. 12:12. The ethical lesson here is noteworthy: knowledge of God’s Law must find expression, on the one hand, in Divine Worship, and, on the other, in the service of loving-kindness to humanity. Judaism claims to be the highest expression of religious truth, and stands or falls by the ethical teaching it enunciates.</i> (Prov. 15:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “What is the Divine Worship? Prayer, for thus we find in Daniel, to whom Darius said: ‘Thy God whom thou <i>servest</i> continually, he will deliver thee’ (Dan. 6:16). Was there any Divine Worship in Babylon?<sup></sup> But this (refers to) Prayer.”</i>
Whence do we learn of the service of loving-kindness for bridegrooms? We learn (this) from the Holy One, blessed be He; for He Himself bestowed loving-kindness upon Adam and his help-mate. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to the ministering angels: Come ye and let us show loving-kindness to Adam and his help-mate. The Holy One, blessed be He, descended with the ministering angels to show loving-kindness to Adam and his help-mate.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Garden of Eden; see <i>supra,</i> pp. 88 ff.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said: More beloved unto Me is the service of loving-kindness than sacrifices and burnt-offering which Israel, in the future, will bring on the altar before Me, as it is said, "For I <i>desired</i> love, and not sacrifice" (Hos. 6:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> pp. 76, 84, 89, for the idea that the world rests on love. Here the stress is on “<i>I desired</i>,” since God’s desire or will is the cause of the world’s existence. The bridegroom is especially mentioned, because the study of the Torah is to be set aside in order to render the service of loving-kindness to the bride and bridegroom. The Jewish teachers did not encourage celibacy; neither was the cult of virginity considered a desirable element in religion, as was the case in the Christian Church. It is possible that the emphasis laid on the Divine participation in Adam’s nuptials was intended to counteract the attitude of the Church towards marriage; see I Cor. vii. 8; Matt. xix. 10, 12. This section in our book should be compared with the latter part of Chapter XII.; see also Pesiḳta de R. Kahana, p. 172b (end).</i>
Rabbi José said: From whom do we learn of the seven days of banquet?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> At a wedding. The marriage feast is mentioned in the parables of the N.T.; see Matt. xxii. 2 ff.</i> From our father Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Nachmanides on Gen. 29:27; and cf. T.J. Kethuboth 1:1, p. 25a, and Jalḳuṭ, Judges, § 70.</i> For when our father Jacob married Leah, he made a banquet with rejoicing for seven days, as it is said, "Fulfil the <i>week</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> of this one" (Gen. 29:27).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And all the men of the place were gathered together to render loving service to Jacob, as it is said: ‘ And Laban gathered together all the men of the place, and made a feast’ (Gen. 29:22). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Ye have shown loving-kindness to Jacob, My servant. I will deal kindly and give you your reward in this world,<sup></sup> because there is no reward for evil-doers in the world to come, as it is said, ‘Because by him the Lord <i>had given</i> victory unto Syria’ (2 Kings 5:1), and he<sup></sup> received his reward.”<sup></sup></i>
Rabbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Shemajah.”</i> said: Our father Abraham wrote (in his will and bequeathed) all that he had as an inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 215; and cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, 130a. Isaac was destined to be Abraham’s heir according to God’s promise; see Gen. 15:4. The first editions omit the quotation, Gen. 25:5.</i> to Isaac, as it is said, "And Abraham gave all that he had unto Isaac" (<i>ibid.</i> xxv. 5). He took the document and gave it into the hands of Eliezer, his servant, (who) said, Since the document is in my hand all his money is in my hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words of Eliezer are not in the first editions.</i> so that he might go and be recommended<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> By the will of Abraham everything in his possession passed to Isaac. This circumstance would be appreciated by the family of Rebecca. See Gen. Rab. 59:10.</i> (thereby) in his<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Abraham’s.</i> father's house and with his family.
From Kirjath || Arba unto Haran was a journey of seventeen days; and in three hours<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The “shortening of the way” occurs also in the Gospel of Pseudo-Matthew xxii. (<i>A.N.C.L</i>. xvi. p. 38), and see <i>A.R.W.</i> xvi. p. 169.</i> the servant came to Haran. He was astonished in his mind<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “heart.”</i> and he said: This day I went forth, and this day I arrived, as it is said, "And I came <i>this day</i> unto the fountain" (<i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 42).
Rabbi Abbahu said: The Holy One, blessed be He, wished to show loving-kindness to Isaac, and he sent an angel<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 24:7, and cf. Gen. Rab. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> before Eliezer; and the way was shortened for him, so that the servant came to Haran in three hours.
And everything<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Luria’s reading based on Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 62:5.</i> is revealed before the Holy One, blessed be He. A daughter of kings,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 367. For Bethuel as king see Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 109, and Sopherim 21 (ed. Müller) p. 304, n. 46.</i> who in all her life had never gone forth to draw water, went out to draw water in that hour. And the girl, who did not know who the man<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading in the Jalḳuṭ <i>loc. cit</i>., is: “And the girl knew not man.” This reading is probably due to Gen. 24:16. Clement of Alexandria gives a parallel Haggadic interpretation in his <i>Strom</i>. iv. 25.</i> was, accepted (the proposal) to be married to Isaac. Why? Because she had been destined<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum Onḳelos to Gen. 24:14.</i> for him from his mother's womb,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> from his birth. The first editions read: “from her mother’s womb.”</i> as it is said, "In the balances they will go up, they are together lighter than vanity"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Lev. Rab. 29:8, Gen. Rab. 59:9, T.J. Bezah v. 2, 63a.</i> (Ps. 62:9).
Laban and Bethuel answered: Since (this) word has come forth from the mouth of the Almighty, we cannot prevent it, as it is said, "Then Laban and Bethuel answered and said, The thing proceedeth from the Lord:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS., the Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 368, and the first editions end the quotation here, and add: “etc.”</i> we cannot speak unto thee bad or good" (Gen. 24:50). "Behold, Rebecca is before thee; take her and go" (<i>ibid.</i> 51).
The servant arose early in the morning and saw the angel standing and waiting for him in the street. He said to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Eliezer is speaking to Laban and his friends.</i> "Do not hinder me,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends the quotation here; the first editions continue the verse, and then the printed texts read: “Behold he is in the street, waiting for me. They ate and drank at Rebecca’s banquet, as it is said.”</i> for the Lord hath prospered my way" (<i>ibid.</i> 56). For behold, the man who came with me yesterday, he has prospered my way; behold, he is standing || and waiting for me in the street,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 370, refers here to the “angel” who accompanied Eliezer.</i> as it is said, "And he said to them, Do not hinder me, for the Lord hath prospered my way." They ate and drank at Rebecca's (bridal) banquet.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add parts of verses 54 and 56 of Gen. 24</i> Like a precentor, who is standing and blessing the bride in her bridal canopy,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Haggadol, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i>; and cf. <i>supra,</i> pp. 89 f., and see Kallah 1, and Tosaphoth, Kethuboth, 7b, <i>s.v.</i> <span>שנאסר</span>.</i> so they stood and blessed Rebecca their sister (wedded) to Isaac, as it is said, "And they blessed Rebecca, and said unto her, Our sister…" (<i>ibid.</i> 60).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This was a marriage by proxy. The Rabbis differ as to whether the nuptial benedictions can be said only in the presence of the bride and bridegroom; see R. Nissim on T.B. Sukkah, 25b, and RIṬBA on Kethuboth, 8a.</i>
At six hours of the day<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> at noon, twelve o’clock. See Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 371, for a parallel text.</i> the servant went forth from Haran, and he took Rebecca and Deborah her nurse and made them ride upon the camels. So that the servant should not be alone with the maiden (Rebecca) by night, the earth was contracted<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Pal. Targum on Gen. 24:61 states: “And as the way was shortened for him in his journey to Paddan-Aram, so was it shortened for him on his return, so that in one day he went and in one day he returned.”</i> before him, and in three hours the servant came to Hebron at the time of the prayer of the afternoon-evening.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> at 3 p.m. The MS. reads: “the afternoon of the evening.” The first editions read “afternoon.” Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit</i>., has “evening.” The word “Minchah” is used to designate the “afternoon prayer” or the “afternoon offering”; see Jastrow, <i>T.D.</i> 779a.</i> And Isaac had gone forth to say the afternoon-evening prayer, as it is said, "And Isaac went forth to <i>meditate</i> in the field towards even" (<i>ibid.</i> 63).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “<i>Meditation</i> (Sichah) is nought else save prayer,<sup></sup> as it is said, ‘A <i>prayer</i> of the afflicted, when he is overwhelmed and poureth out his <i>complaint</i> (Siach) before the Lord’” (Ps. 102:1). See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 84. Gen. Rab. 68:9 quotes here Ps. 142:2, instead of Ps. 102:1 as above.</i>
Rabbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Ishmael.”</i> said: Abraham spake to Isaac his son (saying), This servant<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “O my son! this servant,” etc.</i> is suspected of all the transgressions of the Torah, and deceit is in this servant,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “This servant is suspected of transgressions, and deceit is in his hand.” <span>עבירה</span> (transgression) often means “immorality.”</i> as it is said, "He is a Canaanite,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Servants or slaves were called “Canaanites” in consequence of Noah’s curse upon his son Ham, whose son was Canaan; cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, 92b.</i> the balances of deceit are in his hand; he loveth to defraud" (Hos. 12:7). See, lest he has defiled her,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> “Zinôr,” euphem. for vagina; see 2 Sam. 5:8.</i> therefore bring the girl into the tent and examine her tactually;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> For a parallel see the legends of the Virgin Mary and Salome in “Ante-Nicene Christian Library,” xvi. p. 12 (The Protevangelium of James); and cf. same story in same volume, p. 32, The Gospel of Pseudo-Matthew, and see Hennecke, <i>A pokryphen d. N.T</i>., p. 61; see also Tertullian, “On the Veiling of Virgins,” xi. R. Simeon’s inference is based on the view that obtained in ancient times that slaves could be reasonably suspected of loose conduct; see T.B. Berakhoth, 45b; T.B. Pesachim, 91a and 113b. Clement of Alexandria, to quote but one of the Church Fathers, held a similar opinion of the slaves of his day; see <i>The Instructor,</i> iii. 4. The Midrash in our text also occurs in Jalḳuṭ on Gen., § 109, Midrash Abkhir, and in the Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 60. See also Roḳeach, pp. 54a, b (1st ed.). According to the Book of Jashar (xxiv. 40) Rebecca was ten years old when wedded to Isaac. Another opinion is to be found in Sopherim 21:9, and in Seder ‘Olam Rab. 1 p. 4a.</i> || and if she be undefiled, behold, she is destined for thee from her mother's womb.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “She is thine by the word of the Almighty.” See Midrash Haggadol, c. 373.</i> He brought her into the tent and examined her tactually, and he showed the result to Abraham his father, and afterwards he took her to be his wife, as it is said, "And Isaac brought her into the tent of Sarah his mother… And Isaac was comforted after his mother's death" (Gen. 24:67);<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The last clause of the quotation is not in the first editions.</i> for the deeds of Rebecca were like unto those of Sarah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “she was found to be as perfect as Sarah his mother.<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> ‘The king’s daughter <i>within</i> is all glorious’ (Ps. 45:13); ‘And Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death’” (Gen. 24:67).</i> Hence the Israelites have the custom of producing the tokens of the damsel's virginity,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “custom of tactual examination so that they should not be in doubt, as it is said, ‘Then shall the father of the damsel, and her mother, take’” (Deut. 22:15). On the custom see Müller’s <i>Chiluf Minhagim,</i> p. 37, where it is pointed out that it is a Palestinian custom. This might point to a Palestinian as the author of <i>P.R.E</i>., or to Palestine as its home.</i> as it is said, "Then shall the father of the damsel, and her mother, take and bring forth the tokens of the damsel's virginity" (Deut. 22:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See the rest of the verse.</i>
The steward of Abraham's household<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “The steward of his house (was) the servant of Abraham, for Eliezer was his servant.” Our translation agrees with the text of the first two editions.</i> was his servant Eliezer, and whence was his servant? When (Abraham) went forth from Ur of the Chaldees all the magnates of the kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “All the magnates of the generation arose and gave him gifts.”</i> came to give him gifts; and Nimrod<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On Nimrod see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 44 f. and 51; <i>J.E.</i> ix. 309; Ginzberg, <i>Legends of the Jews,</i> i. pp. 177; cf. Augustine, <i>de Civ. Dei,</i> xvi. 11, 3. See also Jeraḥmeel, <i>s.v.</i> in Index, for references. The first editions add: “arose and wrote a document transferring his servant Eliezer to Abraham.”</i> took his first-born (son)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the sentence is wanting in the first editions.</i> Eliezer and gave him to (Abraham) as a perpetual slave.
When (Eliezer had thus) dealt kindly with Isaac, he set him free, and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him his reward in this world, so that there should not be a reward for the wicked in the world to come;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Eliezer, however, inherited the future world according to the tradition of some Rabbis; see Derekh Erez Ẓuṭṭa, i. (end), and Midrash Agadah, Gen. 24 p. 60.</i> and He raised him to kingship, and he is Og, king of Bashan.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> v. 112, Pal. Targum on Gen. 14:13, <i>infra,</i> p. 167; and cf. Jalḳuṭ on Num. § 765, Gen. Rab. 60:2, Deut. Rab. i. 25, T.B. Baba Bathra, 58a, T.B. Joma, 28b, and Sopherim 24:9.</i>
Rabbi José<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Rabbi”; <i>i.e.</i> Jehudah 1 (<i>c.</i> 200 <small>C.E.</small>); see, however, <i>supra</i> in this chapter, p. 107, for a similar text. The whole of this section till “Syria (2 Kings 5:1)” is wanting in the first two editions. See <i>supra,</i> p. 107, note 6.</i> said: From whom do we learn (that there should be) seven days of (the wedding) banquet?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The custom is clearly indicated in the text Judg. 14:10 and 12; cf. Matt. ix. 15, and <i>supra,</i> p. 107.</i> From our father Jacob, who || made a banquet with rejoicing for seven days, and he took Leah (as his wife). Again he kept another seven days of banquet and rejoicing, and took Rachel (as his wife), as it is said, "And Laban gathered together all the men of the place, and made a feast" (Gen. 29:22). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Ye have shown loving-kindness to Jacob, My servant. I will give a reward to your children, so that there be no reward for the wicked in the world to come: "Because by him the Lord <i>had given</i> victory unto Syria" (2 Kings 5:1). From whom do we learn (that there should be) seven days of banquet? From Samson the Nazirite of God, for when he went down to the land of the Philistines, he took a wife and kept seven days of banquet and rejoicing, as it is said, "And it came to pass, when they saw him,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions end the quotation here.</i> that they brought thirty companions to be with him" (Judg. 14:11). What were they doing with him? They were eating and drinking and rejoicing,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read differently: “What is the meaning of (‘when they saw) <i>him</i>’? They were eating and drinking <i>with him,</i> as it is said,” etc.</i> as it is said, "And Samson said unto them, Let me now put forth a riddle unto you" (<i>ibid.</i> 12); and another text says, "They could not declare the riddle in three days" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc</i>., and Menorath Ha-Maor, § 173.</i>
The bridegroom is like a king. Just as a king is praised by everybody,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Kethuboth, 17a; and cf. Singer, p. 299: “The jubilant voice of bridegrooms from their canopies.” and Jer. 33:11.</i> so is the bridegroom praised by everybody (during) the seven days of the feast. Just as a king is dressed in garments of glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 61:10.</i> so the bridegroom is dressed in garments of glory.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “all the seven days of the banquet.”</i> Just as a king is rejoicing, with feasts in his presence, all his days, so || the bridegroom is rejoicing and has feasts before him all the seven days of the banquet. Just as the king does not go into the market-place alone, likewise the bridegroom does not go into the market-place alone.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashi on T.B. Menachoth, 98a, catchword <span>וירץ</span>. The mourners likewise are not permitted to go out alone. The order of the narrative here is different in the printed texts.</i> Just as the face of a king is shining like the light of a sun,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Prov. 16:15.</i> so the face of the bridegroom is shining like the light of a sun, as it is said, "And he<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the sun.</i> is as a bridegroom coming out of his chamber,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends the quotation here; the first editions add “etc.”</i> and rejoicing to run his course" (Ps. 19:5).

Chapter 17

CHAPTER XVII<br><small>LOVING SERVICE TO MOURNERS</small> [19<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>C<small>ONCERNING</small> the one who tenders the service of loving-kindness to mourners.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is missing in the printed editions.</i> Whence do we learn of the service of loving-kindness to mourners?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> On mourning customs see Bender’s article in <i>J.Q.R.</i> vi. pp. 317 ff. and 664 ff., also article in <i>J.E.</i> ix. 101 ff.</i> From the Omnipresent, who alone showed loving-kindness to Moses, His servant, and buried him<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On the death of Moses see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 270–272. The service of loving-kindness to mourners is not proved from the burial of Moses. See T.B. Soṭah, 14a, where the custom is inferred from the case of Abraham; cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 46a.</i> with His own hand. If this story had not been written (in the Torah) it would be impossible to say it, as it is said, "And he buried him in the valley in the land of Moab" (Deut. 34:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 13b, and Siphrê, Deut. § 357.</i>
Rabban Gamaliel,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> On R. Gamaliel see <i>J.E.</i> v. 560 ff. On the theme in our text see Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 787, and cf. Num. Rab. 19:20.</i> the son of R. Jehudah, said: Not to Moses alone did He show loving-kindness, but also to Aaron. For when they<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Moses, Aaron, and Eleazar. The Gaster MS. 9 begins with the words “were contending,” and continues to the end of the book as in the printed editions. The text, apart from the inserted and older MS. section, follows the Venice edition very closely.</i> went up Mount Hor all the tribes of Israel were contending and saying, Moses and Eleazar have left Aaron on Mount Hor and have gone down (by themselves).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> For their own advantage and glory; see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i> on the death of Aaron, pp. 235–238.</i> They did not believe that he was dead. To show loving-kindness to him, what did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He took Aaron's coffin and brought it above the camp of Israel, and all Israel saw Aaron's coffin flying and moving in the air.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 228; and for the loving-kindness see <i>ibid.</i> p. 240. A similar legend as to Mohammed’s coffin occurs in Arabian literature.</i> They then believed that he was dead, and they showed loving-kindness to him, as it is said: || "And <i>all</i> the congregation <i>saw</i> that Aaron was dead" (Num. 20:29). Only the men<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Not “all the congregation,” as at the death of Aaron.</i> showed loving-kindness to Moses, as it is said, "And the <i>sons</i> of Israel wept for Moses" (Deut. 34:8). The men and the women and the children<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit “and the children.”</i> showed loving-kindness to Aaron.
Why (was this)? Because he loved peace and pursued peace,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xii. pp. 24b ff.</i> and passed daily through the entire camp of Israel and promoted peace between a man and his wife, and between a man and his neighbour; therefore <i>all</i> Israel showed loving-kindness to him, as it is said, "And when <i>all</i> the congregation saw that Aaron was dead,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions insert the quotation, “they wept for Aaron,” etc., before the paragraph beginning, “Why (was this)?” The MS. as well as the first editions do not quote the first part of the verse (Num. 20:29).</i> they wept for Aaron thirty days, even <i>all</i> the house of Israel" (Num. 20:29).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the following: “This verse<sup></sup> is not in its right place, for at ‘Moserah there Aaron died, and there he was buried’ (Deut. 10:6). And the text points to this (place) as though he died there and was buried there.”<sup></sup></i>
Rabbi José said: From whom do we learn of the seven days of mourning?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 100:7, and T.B. Mo’ed Ḳaṭan, 20a; Tanchuma Vajechi, § xvii. Cf. T.J. Soṭah 1:10, 17c; Jalḳuṭ i. § 161.</i> From Jacob, our father, for thus did his son Joseph unto him,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “for Joseph kept for him seven days of mourning.”</i> as it is said, "And he made a mourning for his father seven days" (Gen. 50:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the following: “And all the magnates of the kingdom<sup></sup> went up with him, as it is said: ‘And there went up with him both chariots and horsemen’ (Gen. 1. 9).<sup></sup> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Ye have shown loving-kindness to Jacob, My servant,<sup></sup> and I will also give you and your children a good reward in this world. When the Egyptians died in the (Reed) Sea, they were not drowned<sup></sup> in the sea, but they were worthy to be buried,<sup></sup> as it is said: ‘Thou stretchedst out thy right hand, the earth <i>swallowed</i> them’” (Ex. 15:12).<sup></sup></i>
Whence do we learn (the duty of) showing loving-kindness to mourners? From Jezebel, the daughter of Ethbaal.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See 1 Kings 16:31.</i> The palace of Jezebel, daughter of Ethbaal, was near the market-place.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “street.” The basis of this Haggadah is to be sought in 2 Kings 9:35. The palace was near the city gate which is generally near the market-place or the “High Street.” The first editions add here: “When any bridegroom happened to pass (her palace) she would go forth from her palace, and she clapped her hands and praised with her mouth, and she would go ten steps.”</i> When any corpse was carried through the market-place, she would go forth from her palace, and she clapped<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And she made a noise by rubbing her hands, and she bewailed with her mouth.” The reading in our MS. seems to be drawn from the account describing Jezebel’s conduct when she saw bridegrooms.</i> with the palms of her hands and praised with her mouth, and she followed the corpse<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The usual distance was four cubits. See Ṭur, Joreh Di‘ah, § 361; Maimonides, Hilkhoth Abel, xiv.; and see also T.B. Soṭah, 35b and 46b.</i> ten steps. Concerning her, Elijah, be he remembered for good,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 2, note 8.</i> prophesied (and said): "In the portion of Jezreel shall the dogs eat the flesh of Jezebel" (2 Kings 9:36). But over the limbs which were (employed in) showing loving-kindness, the dogs had no power, as it is said, "And they went || to bury her: but they found no more of her than the skull, and the feet, and the palms of her hands" (<i>ibid.</i> 35).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation in the MS. is abbreviated thus: “And they went to bury her, but they found no more of her than the palms,” etc. See Rashi and Ḳimchi on 2 Kings 9:36. On the theme of our text see Jalḳuṭ, 2 Kings 9 (§ 232); Menorath Ha-Maor, § 216; Kad Ha-Ḳemach, <i>s.v</i>. <span>אבל</span>. Ṭur, Eben Ha-‘Eẓer, 65, quotes the Midrash, as though the text were “bridegroom and bride,” and not merely “bridegroom.”</i>
Whence do we learn (the duty of) showing loving-kindness to mourners? From the men of Jabesh-Gilead. For when Saul and his sons were slain, the men of Jabesh Gilead said: Are we not bound to show loving-kindness to the man who delivered us from the disgrace of the sons of Ammon?<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 1 Sam. 11 and see Pseudo-Rashi on 1 Chron. 10:12. Gilead was nigh to Benjamin, Saul’s tribe; see Num. Rab. 14 i.</i> All their mighty men arose and went all night to the walls of Beth-Shan,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> they came to Beth-Shan at night. Beth-Shan is three hours’ journey from Jabesh-Gilead. The first editions omit the next clause, and continue: “as it is said.”</i> and they took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the walls of Beth-Shan, as it is said, "All the valiant men arose, and took away the body of Saul" (1 Chron. 10:12).
The mourners are comforted with bread and wine,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Semachoth xii. The subject has been dealt with by Perles in his <i>Leichenfeierlichkeiten im Nachbiblischen Judentum.</i> See <i>J.E.</i> v. 529 f. and <i>ibid.</i> ix. 101 f.</i> as it is said, "Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, and wine unto the bitter in soul" (Prov. 31:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the first half of the verse. See T.B. ‘Erubin, 65a: “wine was only created in order to comfort the mourners.” “Bread” is mentioned in Jer. 16:7, Ezek. 24:17, 22, and Hos. 9:4, in connection with mourning.</i>
The men of Jabesh-Gilead showed (loving-kindness<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “loving-kindness.” It occurs in the first editions. Saul had rescued the men of Jabesh-Gilead from the attack of the children of Ammon (see also Josh. 2:12 for the term “<i>dealing kindly</i>”). The context refers to 2 Sam. 2:5. Loving-kindness is that extra service of love which is more than one is in duty bound to do to one’s fellow. The latter sums up one’s obligation to any and every human being, namely, to deal justly and truly with all men, and not to hurt anyone. Loving service goes beyond this. See <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount,</i> pp. 97, 104 f.</i>) to Saul and his sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Pss., p. 154b, add: “by fasting, weeping, and lamentation,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> as it is said: ‘And they <i>fasted</i><sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> seven days’ (1 Sam. 31:13). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: In the future.”</i> (God said,) I will also give you and your sons your reward in the future; for when the Holy One, blessed be He, in the future will gather Israel from the four corners of the world, the first whom He will gather, will be the half-tribe of Manasseh,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the land of Gilead; see Siphrê, Deut. § 355.</i> as it is said, "Gilead is mine, and Manasseh is mine" (Ps. 60:7). Afterwards (will He gather in) Ephraim,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 141. The children of Joseph will be the first to be redeemed in the future, says the Abḳath Rochel, ii. We are now in the field of Messianic Eschatology.</i> as it is said, "Ephraim is the defence of mine head" (<i>ibid.</i>). Afterwards Judah (will be gathered in), as it is said, "Judah is my sceptre" (<i>ibid.</i>).
"Gilead is mine," refers to Ahab, king of Israel, who died in Ramoth-Gilead;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See 1 Kings 22:29 ff.</i> "and Manasseh is mine," is to be taken literally; "Ephraim is the defence of mine head," refers to Jeroboam;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> He was an Ephraimite; see 1 Kings 11:26. The first editions add: “the son of Nebat.”</i> "Judah || is my sceptre," points to Ahithophel;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> He was of the tribe of Judah; see 2 Sam. 17:15 for the story of Ahithophel.</i> "Moab is my <i>washpot</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 8), means Gehazi;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Gehazi inherited the leprosy of Naaman; the “washpot” receives the dirt of the one who washes therein. On Gehazi see <i>J.E.</i> v. 580 and 582, and see Num. Rab. 14:1.</i> "upon Edom will I cast my shoe" (<i>ibid.</i>), refers to Doeg;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the Edomite.”</i> "Philistia, shout thou because of me" (<i>ibid.</i>). The Holy One, blessed be He, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “to them.”</i> It is for Me to search for merit on their behalf,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading of the Amsterdam edition is: “It is for Me to search for their merit.”</i> and to make them friendly towards one another.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Synhedrin 10:2, 29b and Num. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
Rabbi Phineas said: Thirty years<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ to 2 Sam. 21 § 154 reads like our MS., “After thirty years”; see Rashi on T.B. Jebamoth, 79a. The first editions read: “In the year after Saul and his sons had been killed.”</i> after Saul and his sons had been killed, a famine lasting three years arose in the days of David, year after year,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Ḳiddushin, 4:1, 65b, c, which is the source of our text; see also T.J. Ta‘anith, 3:3, 66c, and Num. Rab. 8:4, and Midrash Samuel xxviii. 5; cf. T.B. Jebamoth, 78b.</i> as it is said, "And there was a famine in the days of David three years, year after year" (2 Sam. 21:1). Why was it year after year? In the first year all Israel went up to (celebrate the great) festivals. David said to them: Go and look if perchance there be among you some who worship idols, for because of the sin of idolatry rain is withheld, as it is said, "Take heed to yourselves, lest your heart be deceived,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions end the quotation here.</i> and ye turn aside, and serve other gods, and worship them" (Deut. 11:16). What is written after this? "And the anger of the Lord will be kindled against you, and he will shut up the heaven, that there be no rain" (<i>ibid.</i> 17).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit from “What is written” to the end of the quotation.</i> They went forth and investigated, but did not find (any idolatry).
In the second year<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the famine.</i> all Israel went up (to celebrate) the festivals. David said to them: Go forth and see if there be among you people who lead immoral lives, because owing to the sin of immorality the heavens<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the rain is withheld.”</i> are closed, as it is said, "And thou hast polluted the land with thy whoredoms"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions continue: “and with thy wickedness.”</i> (Jer. 3:2). What is written after this in this context? "Therefore the showers have been withholden, and there hath been no latter rain" (<i>ibid.</i> 3). They investigated, but they did not find (any immoral people).
In the third || year all Israel went up (to celebrate) the festivals. David said to them: Go forth and see if there be among you people who shed blood, because on account of the sin of those who murder<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the shedding of blood.” Other reasons for the famine are suggested in T.B. Jebamoth, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 771; Midrash Samuel, <i>in loc.</i>; and cf. T. J. Ḳiddushin, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> the rain is withheld, as it is said, "So ye shall not pollute the land<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions end the quotation here; the MS. adds “etc.” Cf. Isa. 24:5.</i> wherein ye are; for blood, it polluteth the land" (Num. 35:33). They went forth and investigated, but they did not find (any murderer). David said to them: Henceforth the matter only depends upon me. David arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He. And He answered him: It is for Saul;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. Rab., <i>loc. cit</i>., and Jalḳuṭ, 2 Samuel (§ 154). The first editions read: “David said, Sovereign of the World ! I am not Saul, for in my days idolatry has not been done in Israel, and I am not Saul who was anointed with the oil of consecration, and I am not Saul who quarrelled with Samuel the prophet.” This agrees with MS. Gaster.</i> was not Saul one who was anointed with the oil of consecration? and was it not Saul in whose days there was no idolatry in Israel? and was it not Saul who secured his portion<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 246, and cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 12b, and Kaphtor Va-Pherach vii, (ed. Edelmann), p. 21a.</i> with Samuel the prophet? Yet ye are in the land (of Israel) and he is (buried) outside the land (of Israel).
David forthwith arose and gathered together all the elders of Israel and the nobles, and they crossed the Jordan. They came to Jabesh-Gilead and they found the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son. No worm<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Worms destroy bones as well as flesh. Luria prefers to read <span>רקבה</span>, “decay,” and not “worm.”</i> had been able to touch<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “to rule over them.”</i> them, as it is said, "He keepeth all his bones,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In spite of the prolonged transportation, the bones were not broken.</i> not one of them is broken" (Ps. 34:20). They took the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son, and placed them in a coffin, and they crossed the Jordan, as it is said, "And they buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son… and they performed<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed text and MS. Gaster add, “to them”; this is not in the Bible text.</i> all that the king commanded" (2 Sam. 21:14). The king commanded that they should bring the coffin of Saul in all the borders of each tribe. And it came to pass that the tribe || wherein they brought the coffin of Saul, the people (there) with their wives and their sons and their daughters came forth and displayed loving-kindness to Saul and to his sons, so that all Israel should discharge their obligation of showing loving-kindness. And thus (did they do) until it came to the border of his possession to the border of Jerusalem,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “the border of his inheritance, to the land of Benjamin”; see Num. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i> The first editions read: “until it came to the border of Israel and to the land of Benjamin, as it is said, ‘And they buried him in the border of his inheritance’” (Josh. 24:30).</i> in the land of Benjamin<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The text in the printed editions differs here from our reading.</i> in Jerusalem, as it is said, "And they buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the country of Benjamin" (<i>ibid.</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation continues: “In Zela, in the sepulchre of Kish his father” (2 Sam. 21:14).</i> in the vicinity of Jerusalem. When the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that all Israel had displayed loving-kindness (to him<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Saul.</i>), He was forthwith full of compassion, and He sent rain upon the land, as it is said, "And after that God was intreated for the land" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Nathaniel said: Three hundred years<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Between the accession of Jeroboam and Josiah there elapsed 320 years. Josiah was eight years old when he ascended the throne, so that 312 years elapsed from the accession of Jeroboam to the <i>birth</i> of Josiah. In round numbers this is 300 years, see <i>infra,</i> p. 233.</i> before the birth of Josiah, was his name mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 233.</i> as it is said, "Behold, a child shall be born unto the house of David, Josiah by name" (1 Kings 13:2); "And he was eight years old when he began to reign" (2 Kings 22:1). What is the disposition of a lad of eight years of age?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to 2 Chron. 34:3; see Targum on this text and also Pseudo-Rashi thereto.</i> He despised<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Isa. 7:16.</i> the idols and broke in pieces the pillars, and smashed the images<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Chron. 34:4, 7.</i> and cut down the groves.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Kings 23:14.</i> His merit was great<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. shining or illustrious. See T.B. Mo’ed Ḳaṭan, 25b, where Amos 8:8 is applied to Josiah.</i> before the<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “before the Holy One, blessed be He, and the Throne of Glory.”</i> Throne of Glory. Because of the evil which Israel did in secret<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Idolatry was again rife in the homes of the Hebrew people; see Lam. Rab. 1 (53) and T.B. Ta’anith, 22b.</i> the righteous one<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Josiah.</i> was gathered (to his fathers), as it is said, "For the righteous is taken away because of the evil" (Isa. 57:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is missing in the printed editions. The R.V. renders somewhat differently.</i> || All<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “All the men of Judah and Jerusalem.”</i> Judah gathered together also with Jeremiah the prophet to show loving-kindness to Josiah, as it is said, "And Jeremiah lamented for Josiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions end the quotation here, the printed texts add “etc.” The context justifies the insertion of the entire verse.</i> and all <i>the singing men</i> and <i>the singing women</i> spake of Josiah" (2 Chron. 35:25). Rabbi Meir said: "The singing men" refer to the Levites, who stood upon the platform<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “their platform.” On the meaning of “Dukhan” see Levy, <i>N.H.W.B.</i> i. 382a.</i> singing; "and the singing women" refer to their wives. Rabbi Simeon said: These terms do not refer merely to the Levites and their wives; but to the skilled women, as it is said, "Thus saith the Lord of hosts,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “the Lord.” The first editions read according to the Massoretic text.</i> Consider ye, and call for the mourning women,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends verse 17 here and continues verse 18. The first editions end the quotation at the words, “that they may come.”</i> that they may come; and send for the <i>cunning</i> women, that they may come: and let them make haste, and take up a wailing for us" (Jer. 9:17, 18). Hence the wise men instituted (the rule) that this should be done<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Thus all Israel took upon themselves to show loving-kindness.”</i> to all the <i>wise</i> men of Israel and to their great<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This agrees with Luria’s emendation.</i> men, as it is said, "And they made them an ordinance in Israel" (2 Chron. 35:25).
Solomon saw that the observance<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the attribute.”</i> of loving-kindness was great before the Holy One, blessed be He. When he built the Temple he erected two gates, one for the bridegrooms, and the other for the mourners and the excommunicated. On Sabbaths the Israelites went and sat between those two gates; and they knew that anyone who entered through the gate of the bridegrooms<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Sopherim 19:12 (ed. Müller, pp. 278 f.) for historical material. On the “gates” see Middoth 2:2, and Tamid, 27a, and Kaphtor Va-Pherach vi. p. 16b. Dr. Büchler has written on the subject of the gates of the Temple; see <i>J.Q.R.</i> x. 678 and xi. pp. 46 ff.</i> was a bridegroom, and they said to him, May He who dwells in this house cause thee to rejoice with sons and daughters. If one entered through the gate of the mourners with his upper lip covered, then they knew that he was a mourner, and they would say to him. May He who dwells || in this house comfort thee. If one entered through the gate of the mourners without<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. omits the negative.</i> having his upper lip covered, then they knew that he was excommunicated, and they would say to him, May He who dwells in this house<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “comfort thee.” Nachmanides, in his <i>Torath Ha-Adam</i> (ed. Venice), p. 7, omits these words.</i> put into thy heart (the desire) to listen to<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit “the words of.” Nachmanides, <i>op. cit</i>., agrees with our MS.</i> the words of thy associates, and may He put into the hearts of thy associates that they may draw thee near (to themselves), so that all Israel may discharge their duty by rendering the service of loving-kindness.
When the Temple was destroyed, the sages<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Nachmanides (<i>ibid</i>.) reads: “the sages”; see Semachoth vi. and Middoth (2:12). Sopherim, <i>loc. cit</i>., quotes this rule in the name of R. Eliezer ben Hyrḳanos, clearly showing that the compiler of Sopherim used our book and regarded it as the work of R. Eliezer b. Hyrḳanos. The rule is a Palestinian custom; see Brüll, <i>Jahrbücher,</i> i. p. 30.</i> instituted (the rule) that the bridegrooms and mourners should go to the synagogues and to the houses of study. The men of the place see the bridegroom and rejoice with him; and they see the mourner and sit with him upon the earth, so that<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Nachmanides (<i>ibid</i>.) omits “and they sit,” and reads: “all the Israelites.”</i> all the Israelites may discharge their duty in the service of loving-kindness. With reference to them he<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See for a similar expression, <i>supra,</i> p. 73. It might be that “he” refers to the one who receives the service of loving-kindness. Perhaps it merely refers to any Israelite who has to say the benediction. Or, we might render: “it says.”</i> says: Blessed art Thou,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “O Lord.”</i> who giveth a good reward to those who show loving-kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Kethuboth, 8b. The form of the benediction has its parallel in the Daily Morning Service; see Singer, p. 7.</i>

Chapter 18

CHAPTER XIX<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is ch. xviii. in the printed editions.</i><br><small>THE SABBATH</small> [22<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>T<small>HE</small> School of Shammai said: The heavens<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The history of the creation of man is associated by the Rabbis with the fundamental law of Jewish ethics, the rule of loving-kindness. To quote their dictum, “The Torah begins and ends with the service of loving-kindness” (T.B. Soṭah, 14a). The preceding chapters xvi. and xvii. dealt with the service of loving-kindness, and the story of the Creation is now resumed.</i> were created first, and the earth afterwards, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The controversy was evoked by the precedence given to heaven or earth in the texts of Scripture quoted by the different teachers; see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 6 f.</i> "In the beginning God created <i>the heavens</i> and the earth" (Gen. 1:1). The School of Hillel said: The earth was created first, and the heavens afterwards, as it is said, "Of old hast thou laid the foundation of the <i>earth</i>; and the heavens are the work of thy hands" (Ps. 102:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 12a; T.J. Chagigah 2:1, 77c, d; Gen. Rab. 1:15; Lev. Rab. 36:1; Midrash on Samuel v. (where the School of Shammai is represented as expressing the opinions which are elsewhere attributed to the School of Hillel); and cf. Sepher Ha-Bahir, § 17, and Bacher, T. i. 14.</i> The School of Shammai said: The heavens were created first, and the earth afterwards, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote here Isa. 48:13: “Yea, mine hand hath laid the foundation of the earth.” The earth is mentioned <i>first</i> in this verse, and therefore the opinion of the School of Hillel is thereby substantiated. The “School of Hillel” is the correct reading, as in our MS. The following passage until “Yea, mine hand” is omitted in the printed texts.</i> "These are the generations of the <i>heavens</i> and of the earth" (Gen. 2:4). The School of Hillel said: The earth was created first, and the heavens afterwards, as it is said, "In the day that the Lord God made <i>earth</i> and heaven" (<i>ibid.</i>). The School of Shammai said: The heavens were created first, because it is said, "And the <i>heavens</i> and the earth were finished" (<i>ibid.</i> 1). The School of Hillel said: The earth was created first, and the heavens afterwards, as it is said, "Yea, mine hand hath laid the foundation of the earth, and my right hand hath spread out the heavens" (Isa. 48:18). The School of Shammai said: The heavens were created first, and the earth afterwards, because it is said, "Thus saith the Lord, The <i>heaven</i> is my throne, and the earth is my footstool" (<i>ibid.</i> lxvi. 1). Contention arose between them (<i>i.e.</i> the Schools<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. them.</i>) on this question, until the Holy Spirit<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Shekhinah.”</i> rested between them, and they both agreed that both (heavens and earth) were created in one hour and at one moment.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Ẓohar, Gen. 17b, has this idea; cf. <i>ibid.</i> 29b. The basis for this third view is afforded by the text Isa. 48:13: “When I called unto them, they stood up together.” The Targum renders this text thus: “Yea, with my word I completed the earth, and with my power I expanded the heavens; I called to them, they stood together.”</i>
What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He put forth His right hand and stretched forth the heavens, and He put forth His left hand and founded the earth, as it is said, "Yea, mine <i>hand</i> || hath laid the foundation of the earth, and my <i>right hand</i> hath spread out the heavens:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the printed texts end the quotation here.</i> when I called unto them, they stood up <i>together</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> xlviii. 13). Both of them were created simultaneously, as it is said, "And the <i>heavens</i> and the <i>earth</i> were finished, and all their host" (Gen. 2:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, p. 1a.</i> And, indeed, were the heavens and the earth completed (so as not to require God's providence) for their continued existence and maintenance? Has it not been written concerning them, "Thus saith the Lord, The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool" (Isa. 66:1)?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions do not quote this verse, but “Do not I fill heaven and earth?” (Jer. 23:24) instead.</i> But they were finished with reference to the original deed (of creation) and with reference to the work (of being created) and being called into existence. Therefore it is said, "And the heavens and the earth <i>were finished</i>" (Gen. 2:1).
Israel spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of the worlds! Thou didst complete the heavens and the earth with reference to being made, created, and called into existence;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in the six days of Creation.”</i> let not Thy mercy and loving-kindness be withheld,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “From us” should probably be added to the text; cf. Ps. 40:11.</i> for if Thou withholdest Thy mercy and loving-kindness we are unable to exist,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Man sins, and therefore needs God’s grace and mercy. This idea is well expressed by the teaching of 4 Ezra 7:135–137. The Bible text, “Remember, O Lord, thy tender mercies and thy loving-kindnesses, for they have been <i>ever of old</i>” (Ps. 25:6), is a parallel to our passage; cf. Targum of this verse, which renders the last words, “for they have been from eternity.” Cf. Gen. Rab. 22:1, Jalḳuṭ, Ps. § 702, and Shocher Ṭob to Ps. 25:8, p. 107a, where the question is discussed. How would mankind have arisen if God had dealt with Adam with strict justice? The grace of God was granted to Adam so as to enable mankind to arise and flourish on earth before the doom of death over-took him. There may be an attempt here to counteract the un-Jewish doctrines of the Pauline school, which taught that, owing to Adam’s sin, God’s grace was withdrawn, and only through the advent of a Second Adam (or Christ) could this Divine grace be restored to the world. The theologians who suggest that Judaism has something to learn from the Pauline doctrine of grace must be unaware of the Jewish teaching on this theme.</i> because the world rests upon Thy mercy and loving-kindness,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This idea has already been mentioned in our book.
