See <i>supra,</i> pp. 76, 84, 106.</i> as it is said, "For the mountains shall depart,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the first editions, which add “etc.”; in the MS. the quotation ends with the words, “be removed.”</i> and the hills be removed; but my kindness shall not depart from thee… saith the Lord that hath mercy on thee" (Isa. 54:10);<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> God’s love and mercy <i>cannot</i> cease, they are eternal attributes.</i> and it says (elsewhere), "Remember, O Lord, thy tender mercies and thy loving-kindnesses; for they have been ever of old" (Ps. 25:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is wanting in the printed texts; it concludes in the MS. with the words, “loving-kindnesses.” The point in the quotation lies in the words “ever of old,” which might be rendered “eternal” or “from everlasting.”</i>
"And on the seventh day God finished<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> “His work” is not in the MS., but is covered by “etc.” of the printed editions. See Pesiḳta Rabbathi, p. 187b; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 16.</i> his work" (Gen. 2:2). The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven dedications,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The six days of Creation were complete, and each day’s work had its dedication. This did not apply to the seventh day; see T.B. Sabbath, 11b; T.B. Berakhoth, 58b. The Sabbath will only receive its completion in the future world; see T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 31a.</i> six of them He dedicated, and one is reserved for the (future) generations. He created the first day and finished all His work and dedicated it,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading has its parallel in Menorath Ha-Maor, § 159 (end).</i> as it is said, "And it was evening, and it was morning, one day" (<i>ibid.</i> i. 5). He created the second day and finished all His work and dedicated it, as it is said, || "And it was evening, and it was morning, a second day" (<i>ibid.</i> 8); and so through the six days of creation. He created the seventh day, (but) not for work, because it is not said in connection therewith, "And it was evening and it was morning." Why? For it is reserved for the generations (to come), as it is said, "And there shall be one day which is known unto the Lord; not <i>day</i>, and not <i>night</i>" (Zech. 14:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the Sabbath day, concerning which “day and night” are not mentioned in the Creation story. See <i>infra,</i> p. 143.</i>
A parable: To what is this matter to be compared? To a man who had precious utensils.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Aboth 3:23 with reference to the Torah.</i> And he did not desire to give them as an inheritance except to his son;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Mal. 3:17. The first editions add: “who serves him.” God and His children are referred to by the parable. Every nation is a child of God, Israel is the son who serves Him. See <i>infra,</i> p. 319, and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92 p. 201b, where this Haggadah is used, and as a parallel see Jubilees ii. 20.</i> likewise with the Holy One, blessed be He. The day of blessing and holiness<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit</i>., “blessing and holiness” occur instead of “rest and holiness,” of the first editions, based on the words of the Scripture, “He blessed and hallowed” (cf. Ex. 20:11).</i> which was before Him, He did not desire to give it as an inheritance except to Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jubilees ii. 18 f.</i> Know that it is so ! Come and see ! for when the Israelites went forth from Egypt,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Midrash (cf. Book of Jashar lxx. 47), the Sabbath had been given to Israel in Egypt, but not by God. See T.B. Ḳiddushin, 41b.</i> whilst yet the Torah had not been given to them, He gave them the Sabbath as an inheritance. Israel kept two Sabbaths<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tosaphoth in T.B. Sabbath, 87b, catchword “Just as.”</i> whilst as yet the Torah had not been given to them, as it is said, "And thou madest known unto them thy holy Sabbath"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, in the first editions it is continued without any interruption.</i> (Neh. 9:14). And afterwards He gave them the Torah, as it is said, "And commandedst them commandments, and statutes, and <i>Torah</i> by the hand of Moses, thy servant" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This text mentions the Sabbath before the “Commandments, statutes, and Torah.” The Sabbath law is mentioned in Exodus 16:23, in connection with the Manna prior to the revelation at Sinai.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, observed and sanctified the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees ii. 18.</i> and Israel is obliged<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92 p. 201b.</i> only to observe and sanctify the Sabbath. Know that it is so! Come and see! for when He gave them the Manna, He gave it to them in the wilderness during forty years on the six days of creation,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Sunday to Friday, the days of work.</i> but on the Sabbath He did not give (it) || to them. Wilt thou say that He did not have power enough to give it to them every day?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Menorath Ha-Maor. <i>loc. cit.</i>, which reads, “Lest thou shouldst say that He had no power to give, He continued to give it (<i>after</i> the Sabbath).” Another reading is given in Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> But (the fact was) the Sabbath was before Him; therefore He gave to them bread for two days on the Friday, as it is said, "See, for that the Lord hath given you the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, but “etc.” is added; in the first editions the verse is continued.</i> therefore he giveth you on the sixth day the bread of two days" (Ex. 16:29). When the people<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Israel.”</i> saw that Sabbath (was observed) before Him, they also rested, as it is said, "So the people rested on the seventh day" (<i>ibid.</i> 30).
"And God blessed the seventh day,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, but “etc.” is added; the first editions continue the quotation as in our version.</i> and hallowed it" (Gen. 2:3). The Holy One, blessed be He, blessed and hallowed the Sabbath day, and Israel is bound only to <i>keep</i> and to hallow the Sabbath day.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 11:2, and Mekhilta, p. 50b; and see <i>supra,</i> p. 137, and <i>infra,</i> p. 141.</i> Hence they<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Sages.</i> said: Whosoever says the benediction and sanctification over the wine on the eves of Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Friday evenings. See Jubilees ii. 21.</i> his days<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and years.”</i> will be increased in this world, and<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Variant readings are given in Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Roḳeach, 52. The first editions add here: “And years of life will be given to him.” As we shall see, the phraseology of this reading is borrowed from Prov. 9:11, according to the interpretation given in T.B. Synhedrin, 38a, and Lev. Rab. 11:1.</i> in the world to come, as it is said, "For by me thy days shall be multiplied" (Prov. 9:11) in this world; "and the years of thy life shall be increased" (<i>ibid.</i>) in the world to come.
"Ye shall keep the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, but the first editions continue the verse.</i> for it is holy unto you" (Ex. 31:14). What is the keeping of the Sabbath? Neither to do any work thereon,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions reverse the order of the clauses, “Not to kindle fire thereon, nor to do any work thereon.” The order in our MS. is based on the sequence of the texts dealing with the Sabbath commandments in Ex. 31:14. To kindle fire is prohibited in Ex. 35:3, and in the <i>previous</i> verse the prohibition to work is set forth; see Luria’s commentary, <i>in loc</i>., where the reading of our MS. had been anticipated.</i> nor to kindle fire thereon, neither to take forth nor to bring in beyond the Techum (limit)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The 2000 spaces or ells from the town, called a Sabbath-journey; see Acts i. 12, Jubilees 1. 8, and Zadokite Documents xiii. 7. See Tosephta Soṭah 5:13, p. 303, for a discussion as to whether the Techum principle is contained in the Torah, and cf. <i>J.E.</i> x. 592.</i> of the Sabbath even one foot,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Erubin, 52b.</i> nor to fetch in his hand something<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Anything not permitted to be used on the Sabbath is called “Muḳzeh.”</i> which is not his food nor the food for his cattle.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read after the word “something”: “and carry it four <i>spaces</i> in a public thoroughfare, and to bring it from one <i>allotment</i> to another.” See <i>J.E.</i> x. 582 on the “four ells” or <i>spaces</i>. “Reshuth,” territory, domain, <i>allotment,</i> one’s area or court. See Baba Ḳamma 3:1 for the different terms in connection with Reshuth; see also T.B. Sabbath, 6a, and cf. Jubilees ii. 29 and 1. 8, Zadokite Documents xiii. 16. The first editions omit the words: “which is not his food, nor the food for his cattle.”</i> This is the keeping of the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Trafficking on the Sabbath was a cause of reproach on the part of Jeremiah (xvii. 20 ff.) and Nehemiah (xiii. 17 ff.). The rest of this sentence is wanting in the first editions.</i> as it is said, "Wherefore the children of Israel shall keep the Sabbath" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).
"It<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Sabbath.</i> is a sign between me and the children of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation is concluded here in the MS.; the first editions continue as in our version.</i> for ever" (<i>ibid.</i> 17). The Holy One, blessed be He, said: This (Sabbath) have I given to Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “It is a sign” is added here by Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> as a sign between Me || and them; for in the six days of creation I fashioned all the world, and on the Sabbath I rested, therefore have I given to Israel the six days of work, and on the Sabbath, a day<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and the seventh day (for) blessing,” etc.</i> (for) blessing and sanctification,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and rest.” Scripture speaks of God blessing and sanctifying the seventh day (Gen. 2:3), and resting on the Sabbath (Ex. 20:11), “Wherefore the Lord blessed the Sabbath day and hallowed it” (<i>ibid</i>.). See <i>supra,</i> p. 137, note 4.</i> for Me and for them; therefore it is said, "Between me and the children of Israel it is a sign for ever" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “it is a sign for ever.”</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Sepher Jezirah iv. emphasizes the superior nature of the seventh kind of the various works of Creation; see also Lev. Rab. 29:11; Num. Rab. 3:8; Jalḳuṭ, Psalms (Ps. 139), § 888.</i> firmaments, and He selected from them all 'Araboth<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 12b. ‘Araboth is the seventh heaven. See also Hekhaloth iv. and also Maimonides, <i>Guide,</i> i. 70, who quotes our text. The New Testament speaks of the “third heaven” (2 Cor. xii. 2). See the <i>Apocalypse of Peter</i> on this theme. On the seven heavens see Slavonic Enoch, pp. xxx ff.</i> only for the place of the throne of glory of His kingdom, as it is said, "Cast up a highway for him that rideth on the 'Araboth,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. has “deserts.” The quotation ends here in our MS., the printed texts continue the same.</i> with Jah, his name" (Ps. 68:4). The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven lands,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> They are enumerated in Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit</i>., cf. Aboth de R. Nathan (a) xxxvii. p. 55b (n. 10); see also Midrash, Proverbs 8, where ten lands are mentioned. Israel passed through seven lands after leaving Egypt to enter the Holy Land. The lands are: Edom, Ammon, Moab, Midian, the land of the Amorites, Bashan, and the Holy Land, which is the seventh land. See also Siphrê, Deut. § 40, and <i>infra,</i> p. 167.</i> and He chose from all of them the land of Israel only, as it is said, "A land… the eyes of the Lord thy God are always upon it, from the beginning of the year even unto the end of the year" (Deut. 11:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See also Mal. 3:12, and for the reading of the text see Kaphtor Va-Pherach x. The latter part of the quotation is wanting in the first editions. The first editions add the following: “The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven mountains,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and he chose only Mount Sinai from all of them, as it is said, ‘Why look ye askance, ye high mountains, at <i>the mountain</i><sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> <i>which God hath desired for his abode</i>?’” (Ps. 68:16).</i> Another verse says, "I said, I shall not see the Lord, even the Lord in the land of the living" (Isa. 38:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is missing in the printed texts of our book.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven deserts, and of them all He chose the <i>desert</i> of Sinai<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Kadesh.” The order of the paragraphs here in the MS. does not agree with that of the printed editions. In Jalḳuṭ, Ps. 68 § 796, the wilderness of Sinai is the “chosen” one; this is another name of the wilderness of Kadesh. See T.B. Sabbath, 89a.</i> only to give therein the Torah, as it is said, "The <i>mountain</i> which God hath desired for his abode" (Ps. 68:16).
The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven seas,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, 74b, and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 24:6, p. 103a, notes 23 and 24, which refer to the seven seas in Palestine.</i> and of them all He chose the Sea of Kinnereth<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Lake or Sea of Gennesareth.</i> only, and gave it as an inheritance to the tribe of Naphtali,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The pre-eminence of Naphtali was due to the fact that the east side of his territory touched the Sea of Gennesareth and the west side was on the Mediterranean.</i> as it is said, "O Naphtali, <i>satisfied with favour</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> God’s favour; see Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 68 p. 160b.</i> and full with the blessing of the Lord:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS., in the first editions the verse is continued.</i> possess thou the <i>sea</i> and the south" (Deut. 33:23). What is the "blessing of the Lord"? (It means) that He blessed him and gave him as an inheritance the sea and the south, as it is said, "Possess thou the sea and the south" (<i>ibid</i>.).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is not in the printed editions.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven æons, ∥ and of them all He chose the seventh æon<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The æon was a period of 1000 years. On the Millennium see Slav. Enoch xxxii. 2–xxxiii. 2, where the <i>eighth</i> day is the day of rest.</i> only; the six æons are for the going in and coming out (of God's creatures) for war and peace. The seventh æon is entirely Sabbath and rest in the life everlasting.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 126, note 10, and cf. Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. ii, p. 6, and Jalḳuṭ, Ps. 139 § 888.</i> Seven lamps were made for the sanctuary, and the lamp of Sabbath was illuminating opposite the other six (lamps), as it is said, "In front of the lamp-stand the seven lamps shall give light" (Num. 8:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is not in the printed editions.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven days, and of them all He chose the seventh day only, as it is said, "And God <i>blessed</i> the seventh day, and hallowed it" (Gen. 2:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions add here: “The Holy One, blessed be He, created seven years, and of them all He chose the year of release only. The year of release is every seventh year.” See Jalḳuṭ, Ps. 139 § 888, and Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
Everyone<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> According to T.B. Sabbath, 118b, even idolaters will be forgiven; see <i>infra,</i> p. 146. The first editions read: “Everyone who keeps the Sabbath in this world, the Holy One, blessed be He, will forgive all his sins.”</i> who keeps the Sabbath, happy is he in this world and happy will he be in the world to come,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jubilees ii. 2. 8: “Everyone who observes it and keeps Sabbath thereon from all his work will be holy and blessed throughout all days.”</i> as it is said, "Happy is the <i>man</i> that doeth this, and the <i>son of man</i> that holdeth fast by it: who keepeth the Sabbath from profaning it" (Isa. 56:2). Do not read "(He who keepeth the Sabbath) <i>from profaning</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Mechallelô</i> (from profaning it).</i> <i>it</i>," but read "He who keepeth the Sabbath <i>is pardoned</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Machul lô</i> (it is forgiven him). This is a play on the word of the text of Isa. 56:2. See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 26 p. 134.</i> concerning all his transgression.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts read: “to teach (us) that all his transgressions are forgiven him.” The section on the Sabbath in Jubilees ii. 17 ff. and 1. 6 ff. should be compared with the regulations as to the Sabbath in our book. There are some striking resemblances as well as considerable points of dissimilarity. Jubilees (ii. 23, 24) connects the Sabbath with Jacob. Our book refers this institution to Adam; see previous chapter, and Introduction.</i>

Chapter 19

CHAPTER XVIII<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the printed text and MS. Gaster this is ch. xix.</i><br><small>THE CREATION ON THE EVE OF THE SABBATH</small> [21<small>A</small>. i.]<br>T<small>EN</small> things were created (on the eve of the Sabbath) in the twilight (namely):<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are missing in the MS. but they occur in the first editions and in MS. Gaster.</i> the mouth of the earth;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. 16:32. For the subject-matter of this paragraph see Aboth 5:9, with the excellent observations of Taylor in his 2nd edition of <i>Aboth,</i> pp. 83 ff. Our text agrees to a large extent with this Mishnah, but differs from the version in T.B. Pesachim, 54a; Siphrê, Deut. § 355, Pal. Targum, Num. 22:28, Mekhilta, p. 51a, and <i>supra,</i> p. 14. Eight things enumerated in our context were said (<i>supra,</i> p. 14, note 1) to have been created on the second day. This statement is wanting in our MS.; it was inserted for the first time in the second edition of <i>P.R.E.</i> For the ten things see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 24 f. See also Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. 2:3. p. 9a.</i> the mouth of the well;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In T.B. Pesachim and Siphrê, <i>loc. cit</i>., the “well” only is mentioned. The “<i>mouth</i> of the well” is mentioned in our text and in Aboth 5:9; this may refer to the well of Hagar or Jacob, or the reference might be to Num. 21:16. See <i>infra,</i> pp. 268, 323.</i> the mouth of the ass;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. 22:28.</i> the rainbow;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 9:13 and <i>J.E.</i> x. 312.</i> the Manna;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. 16:15, and Pal. Targ. to Ex. 16:4, 15; and cf. <i>J.E.</i> viii. 293. The Oxford MS. and MS. Gaster and the first editions add: “the Rod.” See <i>infra,</i> pp. 312 f., and cf. Ex. 4:17.</i> the Shamir;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See 1 Kings 6:7 for the information that no tool was used in the Temple. How then were the stones cut? The legend says, “By the worm called Shamir”; see T.B. Giṭṭin, 68a. On the Shamir see <i>J.E.</i> xi. 229 f. and T.J. Soṭah 9:13, 24b, and T.B. Soṭah 48b. For the references to the “Ten Marvels” created on the eve of the first Friday, see Siphrê, Deut., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> the shape of the alphabet;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 14, note 6.</i> the writing<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Interesting material on the Hebrew alphabet is contained in the Othijoth de R. ‘Aḳiba.</i> and the tables (of the law);<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> On the “tables of the Law” in Rabbinical literature see <i>J.E.</i> xi. 662 ff. The “tables” are not mentioned <i>supra,</i> p. 14, note 1; see, however, p. 15.</i> and the ram of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> pp. 228 ff. The Oxford MS. and MS. Gaster omit this. The next section in brackets is wanting in our MS.; it occurs in the Oxford MS. (O.A. 167), MS. Gaster, and in almost the same reading in the first editions.</i> (Some sages say: the destroying spirits<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 14, note 8; and see Gen. Rab. 7:4; and cf. <i>J.E.</i> iv. 514 ff.</i> also, and the sepulchre of Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Deut. 34:6.</i> and the ram of Isaac; and other sages say: the tongs also.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Taylor, <i>Aboth,</i> p. 86, note 22, and Hoffmann, <i>Mishnajoth,</i> p. 352, note 37.</i>)
At the seventh hour (of the day<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> 1 o’clock p.m.; see Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92:3, p. 202a. This contradicts the statement in Chapter XI.; see <i>supra,</i> p. 78.</i> on Friday<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “Of the day on Friday” is missing in our MS., but it occurs in the 2nd ed., and in the MS. Gaster. This was the day of his creation. The text is lit. “eve of the Sabbath.”</i>), the first man entered the garden of Eden, and the ministering || angels were praising before him,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 89; and cf. Slav. Enoch xxxi., where Adam perceives “the angels singing the song of triumph.” Cf. Koran, ed. Rodwell, 1911, p. 341.</i> and dancing before him, and escorting him<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> So also in Jubilees iii. 9.</i> into the garden of Eden; and at twilight at the eve of Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Friday afternoon between sunset and night; see also Slav. Enoch xxxii. 2, which implies that the expulsion of Adam was followed by the Sabbath. See <i>supra,</i> p. 78.</i> he was driven forth, and he went out. The ministering angels were crying aloud concerning him, saying to him: "Man<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew word is also “Adam.”</i> in glory tarrieth not overnight,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> For he did not tarry overnight in his glory in Paradise; see T.B. Synhedrin 38b.</i> when he is like the beasts that pass away"<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> when they were driven forth out of Paradise; see <i>infra,</i> p. 143. This Psalm (xlix.) is applied to Adam by our book and by many Midrashim, see Shocher Ṭob. Ps. 92:3, p. 202b.</i> (Ps.xlix. 12).
"Like a beast that passes away" is not written here, but "like the beasts that pass away," (so) were they both.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The point here is the change from the singular to the plural: “they were like”; see Gen. Rab. 21:7. They (<i>i.e.</i> Adam and Eve) became like the beasts when they were expelled from Eden; they had to die like the beasts. Perhaps the meaning of the Midrash would be better understood by translating verse 12 of Ps. 49 thus: “Adam did not tarry overnight in glory, he was to be likened to the beasts; yea, they (Adam and Eve) were to be (thus) compared.”</i> The Sabbath day arrived and became an advocate<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 74. Cf. <i>infra</i>, pp. 143 f.</i> for the first man, and it spake before Him: Sovereign of all worlds! No murderer<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the text should read: “No man has been slain.” In Shocher Ṭob, <i>loc. cit</i>., the reading is: “No man has been punished.”</i> has been slain in the world during the six days of creation, and wilt Thou commence (to do this) with me?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Sabbath.</i> Is this its sanctity, and is this its blessing? as it is said, "And God blessed the seventh day, and hallowed it" (Gen. 2:8). By the merit of the Sabbath day Adam was saved from the judgment of Gehinnom.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 118a. No mourning is permitted on the Sabbath, for the dead are not in the power of Gehenna on that day. For parallel Christian legends see Wisdom, ed. Deane, p. 163.</i> When Adam perceived the power of the Sabbath, he said: Not for nought did the Holy One, blessed be He, bless and hallow<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> By showing Divine love and mercy to Adam, the sanctity and the blessing of the Sabbath were realized by him.</i> the Sabbath day. He began to observe (the Sabbath)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to sing.”</i> and to utter a psalm for the Sabbath day, and he said: "A psalm, a song for the Sabbath day" (Ps. 92:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Shocher Ṭob, <i>loc. cit</i>., Adam wished to sing hymns to the Sabbath day: but the latter declined the honour, and told Adam to join in singing praises to God.</i> Rabbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Ishmael.”</i> said: The first man said this psalm, and it was forgotten throughout all the generations until Moses<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 22:13, and Ḳimchi, Preface to <i>Commentary on Psalms.</i></i> came and renewed it || according to his name,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “according to his name.” See T.B. Baba Bathra, 14b, for the Mosaic Psalms.</i> "A psalm, a song for the Sabbath day" (<i>ibid.</i>), for the day which is entirely Sabbath and rest in the life of eternity.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This is missing in Shocher Ṭob, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Jalḳuṭ, Ps. 92 § 843. It probably owes its place in our text to a marginal gloss by some scribe of our book, being based on the Mishnah Tamid (end). See Senior Sachs’ remarks on this passage in <i>Ha-Techiyah,</i> i. p. 20 (notes).</i>
"It is good to confess<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. “to give thanks.”</i> to the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>). The first man said: Let all the generations learn from me,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 147. The next clause occurs in our MS. and in the Oxford MS. only.</i> that whosoever sings and utters psalms to the name of the Most High, and confesses his transgressions in the court of justice<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. uses here an abbreviation, <span>בבר</span> (Bbd). It does not occur in any of the printed texts. The Oxford MS. reads: “at the judgment.”</i> and abandons (them), will be delivered from the judgment of Gehinnom,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Prov. 28:13. See also Wisdom, x. 1, 2.</i> as it is said, "It is good to confess to the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>).
"To declare thy loving-kindness in the <i>morning</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 2). Adam said: (This refers to) all who enter this world<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the world to come which is like unto the morning. ‘And thy faithfulness every <i>night</i>’ (Ps. 92:2) (refers) to all who come into this world, which is like unto the <i>night</i>.”</i> which is like unto the night;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 4a this is derived from Isa. 21:11: “Watchman, what of the night?”</i> and to all who come into the world to come, which is like unto the morning.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the term “Dayspring” applied to the Christian Messiah; see <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> p. 119. Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>., derives the lesson of our Haggadah from Lam. 3:23.</i> They shall declare the faithfulness and love of the Holy One, blessed be He, which He has shown to me,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In this world by prolonging my life.</i> (for He has) delivered me from the judgment of Gehinnom, as it is said, "To declare thy loving-kindness in the morning, and thy faithfulness every night" (<i>ibid.</i>).
"Upon a ten-stringed instrument and upon the psaltery" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). All testimonies reliable to Israel are (celebrated) with ten (males). The harp upon which David played had ten strings.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks the reading should be “Nimin” and not “Nebalim”; see Targum, <i>in loc</i>., and cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 229.</i> The testimony for the dead is through ten (males).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> To enable the benediction for the mourners to be recited, ten adult males are required to form a quorum, see T.B. Kethuboth, 8b, and Sopherim 10:8, xix. 12. See T.B. Megillah, 23b; Nachmanides, <i>Torath Ha-Adam,</i> pp. 49 ff., and Shocher Ṭob, <i>loc. cit</i>., p. 203b, note 61, and Joreh Di‘ah, 361. On the Minyan (or ten adult males) see <i>J.E.</i> viii. 603, and Elbogen, <i>Der Jüdische Gottesdienst in seiner geschichtlichen Entwicklung</i>, p. 493.</i> The testimony for the (public) benediction of (God's) Name is through ten (males).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to the “Bar‘khu”; see Singer, pp. 37, 96.</i> The testimony of the covenant of circumcision is through ten (males).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ṭur, Joreh Di‘ah, 265, quoting Zemach Gaon, who holds that if the rite can be performed in the presence of ten males it should be done, but it may be done even if ten be not present. See also Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92:7, p. 203b. note 62; and Jalḳuṭ to Ps. 92 § 843. Our text is referred to by Maharil in his Laws on the rite of Circumcision; see also Pisḳê Riḳanati, 593.</i> The testimony for Chalizah<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The ceremony of untying and taking off the shoe of a brother-in-law by the childless sister-in-law who has become a widow, see Deut. 25:5–11, and cf. T.B. Jebamoth, 101a, and Eben Ha-‘Eẓer, § 169, 13, and Shocher Ṭob, <i>loc. cit</i>., p. 204a, note 64.</i> is through ten (males),<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “The testimony for the benediction of marriage is through ten (males).” See T.B. Kethuboth, 8b, for the custom.</i> as it is said, "And he<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions read “Boaz,” which is not in accordance with the Hebrew text.</i> took ten men of the elders of the city" (Ruth 4:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Sec Shocher Ṭob, <i>loc. cit</i>., for the entire passage; and cf. T.B. Kethuboth, 7a.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, said: I desire of Israel the meditation of their mouths like<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed text reads “with,” Luria suggests “like”; see Jalḳuṭ. Ps., <i>loc. cit</i>., and Shocher Ṭob, <i>in loc</i>., p. 204a.</i> the psaltery and an instrument of ten strings,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “psaltery and harp.”</i> as it is said, "With<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “With” (<span>עלי</span>) is probably to be explained according to the Midrash as though it meant “it is for Me”; <i>i.e.</i> My lot is to hear their psalms.</i> the meditation of || the harp" (Ps. 92:3).
"For thou, O Lord, hast made me glad through thy work" (<i>ibid.</i> 4). Adam said: The Holy One, blessed be He, had made me glad and brought me into the garden of Eden, and showed me the place of the abode of the righteous in the garden of Eden,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Slav. Enoch viii. 1 ff.–ix. 1 describes the heavenly garden of Eden: “This place is prepared for the righteous.” See Introduction.</i> and He showed me the four kingdoms,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria adds in his text: “namely, Babylon, Media, Macedonia, and Syria.” The last name should probably be <i>Edom</i> (<i>i.e.</i> Rome).</i> their rule and their destruction;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “ruling and destroying.” The Shocher Ṭob (<i>in loc</i>.), p. 204b, agreeing with our MS., reads: “And He led me into the garden of Eden and showed me the place of the abode of the righteous, and He showed me the four kingdoms.” The printed editions omit the passage referring to the abode of the righteous.</i> and He showed me David,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Messiah.</i> the son of Jesse, and his dominion in the future that is to come.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The Messianic kingdom. This is to be followed by the “Future World.” The two periods, in contradistinction to the present age, are often spoken of as “the future that is to come.”</i> I took from my years seventy years<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> This Haggadic fancy, which occurs in Jubilees iv. 30, was known to Justin Martyr, <i>Dial. c. Tryph.</i> lxxxi.: “For according to the days of the tree of life… we believe a thousand years to be figuratively expressed. For as it was said to Adam, ‘In the day that he should eat of the tree, he should surely die’ (Gen. 2:17), so we know he did not live a thousand years. <i>We</i> believe also this expression, ‘The day of the Lord is a thousand years’ (Ps. 90:4; 2 Pet. iii. 8) relates to this.” See also Epistle of Barnabas xv. The origin of the legend is to be traced to the verse quoted (Ps. 61:6) and the psalmist’s interpretation of man’s life which is said to consist of seventy years; see Ps. 90:10; see also Gen. Rab. 19:8, and Num. Rab. 14:12.</i> and added them to his days,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> David’s life, which lasted seventy years.</i> as it is said, "Thou wilt add days to the days of the king;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; the first editions continue the verse.</i> his years shall be as many generations" (<i>ibid.</i> lxi. 6). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Thou wilt add days to the days of (the king Messiah); I also will add to his years in the future which is to come, as though they were many generations, as it is said, "His years shall be as many generations" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This entire sentence is missing in the printed texts.</i> I have given to God praise, and song (lauding) His works, as it is said, "I will sing of the works of thy hands" (<i>ibid.</i> xcii. 4).
"How great are thy works, O Lord!" (<i>ibid.</i> 5). Adam began to glorify and to praise the Name of the Most High, as it is said, "How great are thy works, O Lord!" (<i>ibid.</i>) but Thy thoughts are very deep,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to the depth of Thy thoughts (is similar to) the deep (which is) exceedingly deep.”</i> like the great deep<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The deep (Tehom) was held to be unsearchable. See Job 38:16: “Hast thou walked in the recesses of the deep?” Cf. T.B. Pesachim, 54b.</i> exceedingly (deep), as it is said, "Thy thoughts are very deep" (<i>ibid.</i>). "A brutish man knoweth not" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). Every man of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “A man who is brutish among Israel.”</i> who is brutish (in knowledge) and has not learnt understanding, let the wise men of Israel teach him the ways of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “teach him understanding.”</i> as it is said, "Consider, ye brutish among the people" (<i>ibid.</i> xciv. 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This is Israel; see Jalḳuṭ, Ps. § 843.</i> But a man who is an expert among the nations of the world<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first edition reads: “Expert in faith.” The Venice edition has the same reading as our MS. Paul held the wisdom of the world to be foolishness before God; see 1 Cor. iii. 19.</i> is still foolish. Why? For he knoweth not the words of the Torah, as it is said, "Neither doth a fool || understand <i>this</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “This” (<i>ẓôth</i>) is interpreted to mean the Torah; see T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 2b.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> xcii. 6).
"When the wicked spring up as the grass" (<i>ibid.</i> 7). True<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “At the time when Thou seest.”</i> (it is) that Thou, O Lord, beholdest the wicked, that they are as numerous<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “who are seen.”</i> as the grass to cover the face of all the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 27:6.</i> and all the worshippers of idols flourish,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. omits from this word till “And he did not say Hallelujah.”</i> (Thou knowest) that they and their works are an evil iniquity<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading of Shocher ᵬob (<i>in loc</i>.) is: “an iniquity hidden.”</i> for the days of the Messiah.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “And the wicked, who are as numerous as grass.”</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, has only multiplied them in order to destroy them from this world<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the days of the Messiah. According to the Christian doctrine of election, very many of the sons of men will be doomed to enter Hell and to remain there for all eternity. See Matt. vii. 13, xxiii. 33, and Mark ix. 48.</i> and from the world to come, as it is said, "To have them destroyed for ever and ever. And thou, O Lord, art on high for evermore" (<i>ibid.</i> 7, 8). David saw that the wicked increased like grass, (so as) to cover the face of all the earth, and that all the worshippers of idols flourished, and that they and their works were iniquity, and he did not say "Hallelujah" ("praise ye the Lord") until he perceived that in the future they would be destroyed from<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts omit from “from this world” to “Hallelujah.”</i> this world and from the world to come; and he said "Hallelujah," as it is said, "Sinners shall be consumed out of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts omit the rest of the verse.</i> and the wicked shall be no more. Bless the Lord, O my soul. <i>Praise ye the Lord</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> civ. 35).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 10a. Note the interpretation given by Beruria, the wife of Rabbi Meir: “Let <i>sins</i> be consumed out of the earth, and then there will be no more wicked people.” The first edition omits the next sentence in our text. The Venice edition reads: “Then the Holy One, blessed be He, (will be) King, exalted.”</i> (Then will He be) King exalted<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. reads “Marom,” exalted; the Venice edition reads “Masor,” which is an error. See Jalḳuṭ on Ps. 92:8, § 843.</i> in the heights and in the depths, as it is said, "And thou, O Lord, art on high for evermore" (<i>ibid.</i> xcii. 8).
"For, lo, thine enemies, O Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> 9); Israel said: Sovereign of all worlds! Thou hast placed all our enemies over us<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In Egypt and Babylon.</i> (to afflict us with) a heavy yoke on our backs, but we know that they are doomed to destruction, as it is said, "O Lord, for, lo, thine enemies shall perish"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 383.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). And all || idolaters, for they and their works are iniquity, shall be scattered like chaff<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Dan. 2:35.</i> before the wind.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “As it is said, ‘All the workers of iniquity shall be scattered’” (Ps. 92:9).</i>
"But my horn hast thou exalted like that of the reêm"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “wild-ox.” On the reêm see Delitzsch, <i>Babel and Bible</i> (E.T.), p. 164, where the reêm is shown in a beautiful illustration.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 10). Just as the horns of the reêm<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “this reêm.”</i> are taller than those of all beasts and animals,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob, p. 204a. The Venice edition reads: “of all animals.” This is wanting in the 1st ed.</i> and it gores to its right and to its left, likewise (is it with) Menachem, son of 'Ammiel, son of Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “Son of Joseph” probably means “of the tribe of Joseph.” The reference to the reêm is suggested by the Blessing of the tribe in Deut. 33:17. According to the Ẓohar (Num. p. 173b), Messiah ben David is Menachem; this is also the view of the Book of Zerubbabel (ed. Jellinek, <i>B.H.M.</i> i. 59). Cf. Abḳath Rochel ii.; T.B. Synhedrin, 98b; <i>J.E.</i> viii. 511 f.; and <i>R.É.J.</i> lxviii. pp. 135. 150. ‘Ammiel appears to be another form of “Emanuel.”</i> his horns are taller than those of all kings,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “all animals.” The 1st ed. omits the name of “Menachem, son of ‘Ammiel, son of Joseph,” and reads instead: “the son of David.”</i> and he will gore in the future towards the four corners of the heavens, and concerning him Moses said this verse, "His firstling bullock, majesty is his, and his horns are the horns of the reêm: with them he shall gore<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends quotation here, adding “etc.” The printed texts conclude the quotation with “reêm.”</i> the peoples all of them, even the ends of the earth" (Deut. 33:17). All<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This paragraph occurs in the first editions, but in the Venice edition it is inserted after the following passage, which is wanting in our MS. and in the 1st ed.: “With him are the ten thousands of Ephraim, and the thousands of Manasseh,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> as it is said, ‘And they are the ten thousands of Ephraim, and they are the thousands of Manasseh’” (Deut. 33:17).</i> the kings will rise up against him to slay him, as it is said, "The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers (take counsel together)" (Ps. 2:2). And Israel who (will be) in the Land (of Palestine) (will experience) great trouble,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pesiḳta Ẓuṭarta, Balaḳ, p. 129b.</i> but in their troubles they (will be) like a green olive,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds: “I am afflicted”; it is missing in the printed texts.</i> as it is said, "I am anointed with fresh oil" (<i>ibid.</i> xcii. 10).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob, <i>in loc.</i> The Midrash interprets “I am anointed” as though it were connected with the root “Balah,” “to afflict,” cf. 1 Chron. 17:9, and not from “Balal.” In the time of trouble Israel trusts in God and shall be like a green olive tree full of sap; cf. Ps. 52:8; T.B. Berakhoth, 35a, and Jalḳuṭ, Ps. § 845. Perhaps our text should be rendered: “But their trouble, being like a green olive tree, made one distressed”; or: “But (in) their trouble am I anointed as with (the oil of) a green olive tree.”</i>
"Mine eyes have looked on mine enemies" (<i>ibid.</i> 11). The Israelites in the Land (of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> After the great trouble and misfortunes endured by Israel the Messianic redemption will take place, and the enemies will be finally judged. See Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i>) behold the downfall of their enemies, as it is said, "Mine eyes have looked on mine enemies" (<i>ibid.</i>). And<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This paragraph does not occur in the printed editions.</i> such who in the future will come against them (Israel), their ears shall hear of their destruction, as it is said, "Mine ears have heard concerning the evil-doers that rise up against me" (<i>ibid.</i>).
"The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). Just as this palm tree is beautiful in all its appearance,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On the palm tree see Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 92:11, with notes 87 ff.</i> and all its fruits are sweet and good,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Kethuboth, 10b. The palm branch forms a striking element in the public entry into Jerusalem by the Founder of Christianity; see John xii. 13.</i> likewise the son of David<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the Messiah.</i> is beautiful in his appearance<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 21:5; and cf. Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 92:11.</i> and in his glory, and all his deeds || are good and sweet before the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree: he shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon" (<i>ibid.</i>). Just as this cedar has very many roots beneath the earth, and even if the four winds<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the winds from all four quarters of the world. Cf. Matt. vii. 24, 25, and Wisdom, iv. 4.</i> of the world came<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “to blow.”</i> against it, they could not move it from its place,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. agrees here with our MS. The Venice edition adds: “Likewise (will it be) with the son of David, whose might and deeds are manifold before the Holy One, blessed be He. Even if all the nations come against him they will not move him from his place.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> as it is said, "He shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon. They that are planted in the house of the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> 12, 13). In the future when the Holy One, blessed be He, will gather Israel from the four corners of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> So Isaiah (11:12) prophesies.</i> just like this gardener who transplants<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> To improve them.</i> his fir trees from one garden-bed to another garden-bed, likewise in the future will the Holy One, blessed be He, gather them<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “An unclean land” is expressed by “outside the Land” (of Palestine) in the Amsterdam ed. Any land outside the “Holy” Land is held to be unclean in the sense that the Biblical Laws of purity are not observed therein, such laws being only intended for Palestine; see Lev. 18:25.</i> from an impure land and (plant them) in a pure land,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 84. Just as Jews consider the soil of Palestine to be “terra sancta,” so the English Church has a preference for the water of the river Jordan in administering the rite of baptism; this, at least, was the case at the baptism of the late King Edward <small>VII</small>.</i> as it is said, "They that are planted in the house of the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>). Like this grass, they shall blossom and sprout forth in the Temple, as it is said, "In the courts of our God they shall flourish" (<i>ibid.</i>).
"They shall still bring forth fruit in old age" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). Just as this<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria omits the word “this.”</i> old age is glory and honour to old men,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Prov. 20:29.</i> so shall they be in glory and honour<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> before the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "They shall be full of sap and green"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The next words until “To declare” are missing in the first editions.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). These are the mighty heroes by reason of their good deeds, as it is said, "They shall be full of sap and green, to declare that the Lord is upright" (<i>ibid.</i> 14, 15). Why all these (statements)?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> As to the prosperity of the wicked. The Venice edition reads: “To declare, to praise,” etc.</i> To declare, and to proclaim clearly the works of the Holy One, blessed be He, for He is righteous and upright, and that there is no unrighteousness (in Him), as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “He is my rock.”</i> "And there is no unrighteousness in him" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> On God’s justice see Siphrê, Deut. § 307.</i>

Chapter 20

CHAPTER XX<br><small>ADAM'S PENITENCE</small> [24<small>A</small>. i.]<br>"So he <i>drove out</i> the man" (Gen. 3:24). <i>Driving out</i> (<i>i.e</i>.) and he went forth outside the garden of Eden (and he abode)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. does not read: “and he abode.” This is the reading of the first editions. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 34 (end), adds: “outside the garden of Eden.” The new abode of Adam was near the garden of Eden. The Midrash appears to understand, Gen. 3:24, thus: “So he drove out the man and he dwelt at the east of the garden of Eden.” This Haggadic interpretation already appears in the LXX.</i> on Mount Moriah, for the gate of the garden of Eden is nigh unto Mount Moriah.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Erubin, 19a. Beth-Shan is described as the door to Palestine; see <i>J.Q.R.</i> v. p. 148, where Origen’s Midrash about the garden of Eden being the centre of the world is quoted. As to where the garden of Eden was believed to be, see Delitzsch, <i>Wo lag das Paradies,</i> pp. 45 ff.</i> Thence He took him and thither He made him return to the place whence he was taken, as it is said, "To till the ground from whence he was taken" (<i>ibid.</i> 23).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Instead of this quotation the first editions cite Gen. 2:15: “And the Lord God took the man,” and then they add: “From what place did He take him? From the place of the Temple, as it is said: ‘To till the ground from whence he was taken’” (Gen. 3:23).<sup></sup></i>
Rabbi Jehudah said: The Holy One, blessed be He, kept the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “In the heavens” is also added by Shocher Ṭob, p. 203a, but it is wanting in the first editions of our book; see <i>supra,</i> pp. 125 f. The idea of Sabbath being observed in heaven occurs in Jubilees ii. 18; see previous chapter in our book, p. 138.</i> first in the heavenly regions, and Adam kept the || Sabbath first in the lower regions. The Sabbath day protected him from all evil, and comforted<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> pp. 125 f.</i> him on account of all the doubts of his heart, as it is said, "In the multitude of my doubts within me, thy comforts delight my soul" (Ps. 94:19).
Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: From the tree under which they hid themselves,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. xxxvi.</i> they took leaves and sewed (them), as it is said, "And they sewed fig leaves together,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MSS. and the first editions conclude the quotation here.</i> and made themselves aprons" (Gen. 3:7). Rabbi Eliezer said: From the skin<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> So also according to Pal. Targ. Gen. 3:21; and cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 99.</i> which the serpent sloughed off, the Holy One, blessed be He, took<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit “took.”</i> and made coats of glory<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Torah scroll of Rabbi Meir the reading was “coats of light”; see Gen. Rab. 20:12 and Epstein in <i>Monatsschrift,</i> 1884, pp. 343 ff. Cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 98, for the skin of nail, as the covering of glory of the first man.</i> for Adam and his wife, as it is said, "And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife coats of skin, and clothed them" (<i>ibid.</i> 21).
At twilight on Saturday<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria holds that this section is out of place. It should be inserted in the previous chapter at the point where the Blessing of the Sabbath occurs. See T.J. Berakhoth 8:6, 12b, on the day of 36 hours, during which the light of the first Sabbath lasted; and cf. Rabbi Mana said: How must<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “is he obliged.” Siddur Rab ‘Amram, 59b, reads: “How is a man obliged (to perform Habdalah) with the cup of wine? Both hands are to be stretched forth to the light according to our author and the authorities quoted (see Sha‘arê Teshubah, § 102, and Shibbolê Ha-Leḳeṭ (52b), § 130). See Siddur R. ‘Amram, 59a, for the expression to “look at the palms”; cf. Ha-Manhig, § 65, p. 34a. This was the custom of R. Naṭronai. The Mishnah Berakhoth 8:6 deals with the necessity of <i>enjoying</i> the light in order to say the blessing over same; see T.B. Berakhoth, 53b. According to our book the custom of looking at the nails is only to be observed when there is no wine. The Pirḳê de R. Eliezer seems to have the same custom here and in reference to rinsing the cup mentioned <i>infra,</i> p. 146, note 7, as obtained in Sura, and these customs were known to R. (He does this) over the cup of wine, with the light of fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The light will enable him to see the wine in the cup, and then he need not look at his nails, nor put forth his hands to the light; for he has already derived some benefit from the light. Sabbath, 150b, and <i>J.E.</i> vi. pp. 118 ff.</i> and he says: Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, who creates the various flames of fire; and when he removes his hand from the fire (flame) he says: Blessed art Thou, O Lord, who divides the holy from the profane.

Gaster and in the 2nd ed.: “Rabbi Eliezer said: After a man has drunk the (contents) of the cup of Habdalah, it is a religious privilege and duty to put a little water in the cup (of wine used at the Habdalah), and to drink in order to show that the precepts are beloved,<sup></sup> and what remains of the water in the cup should be put over his eyes. Why? Because the Wise Men have said: The (observance of the) ‘remnants’ left over in connection with a religious act keeps back punishments.”</i>

Chapter 21

CHAPTER XXI<br><small>CAIN AND ABEL</small> [25<small>A</small>. i.]<br>"B<small>UT</small><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions begin the chapter with the expression: “It is written.” Our MS. agrees with the Oxford MSS. here.</i> of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden" (Gen. 3:3). It was taught in a Baraitha,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “A tannaite tradition not incorporated in the Mishnah,” see <i>J.E.</i> ii. 513. The use of the term <span>חני</span> (it was taught in a Baraitha) in connection with a statement by Rabbi Ẓe‘era (4th cent, <small>C.E.</small>) is incongruous.</i> Rabbi Ẓe'era said: "Of the fruit of the tree"—here "tree" only means man, who is compared to the tree, as it is said, "For man is the <i>tree</i> of the field" (Deut. 20:19). "Which is in the midst of the garden"—"in the midst of the garden" is here merely an euphemism.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “Just as ‘ in the <i>middle</i> of the body’ (has its implication, likewise), ‘in the midst of the garden’ refers to that which is in the middle of the woman, because ‘ garden’ means woman,” etc.</i> "Which is in the midst of the garden"—for "garden" means here merely woman, who is compared to a garden, as it is said, "A garden shut up is my sister, a bride" (Cant. 4:12). Just as with this garden whatever is sown therein, it produces and brings forth, so (with) this woman, what seed she receives, she conceives and bears<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “from her husband.” This allegorical interpretation of the Paradise narrative is exceptionally bold. The Ẓohar, Gen. 35b, offers a parallel, having used our book as its original; see also Nachmanides, Torath Ha-Adam, 102b. The texts (Isa. 61:3, lx. 21, and xvii. 11) quoted by the Ẓohar <i>in loc. cit.</i> afford the scriptural basis for the interpretation in question.</i> through sexual intercourse.
(Sammael) riding on the serpent came to her, and she conceived;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “Cain.” See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 29 and § 35, and Ẓohar, <i>loc. cit</i>., for the reading: “Satan riding on the serpent.” See Pal. Targ. Gen. 4 I, which has used our author. This Haggadah occurs also in the Church Father Ephraim (in Gen. vol. i. p. 35); he says that the serpent was made to crawl on its belly “for having increased the pangs of child-bearing, through the seduction of Eve”; see also Slavonic Enoch xxxi. 6. The legend was most probably known to Paul, who refers to the “serpent” as having “beguiled Eve in his craftiness”; see 2 Cor. xi. 2, 3, and cf. 1 Tim. ii. 14, 15; and Protevangelium of James, 13 (<i>A.N.C.L</i>. xvi. p. 8), and cf. 4 Macc. xviii. 8.</i> afterwards Adam came to her, and she conceived Abel,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This agrees with Luria’s emendation, based on the Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 35, and Ẓohar, <i>loc. cit.</i>; see <i>supra</i>, p. 78.</i> as it is said, "And Adam knew Eve his wife" (Gen. 4:1). What is the meaning of "knew"? (He knew) that she had conceived.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Some of the Haggadic details of this chapter appear in Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> i. 1. 4. For the reading of the text here see Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> And she saw his<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cain’s. The Pal. (e. 76) and the first editions insert here the following: “Rabbi Ishmael said: From Seth<sup></sup> arose and were descended all the generations of the righteous, and from Cain arose and were descended all the generations of the wicked, who rebelled and sinned against Heaven, and said. We do not need the drops of Thy rains, as it is said, ‘Yet they said unto God, Depart from us’” (Job 21:14).<sup></sup></i>
Rabbi Miasha<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Oxford MS. (e. 76) reads “Meir” (2nd cent. <small>C.E.</small>). Miasha lived in the 4th cent. <small>C.E.</small></i> said: Cain was born, and his wife,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “His wife” does not occur in the first editions.</i> his twin-sister,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. From these words know that there were no other women whom they could marry, and these were permitted to them, as it is said, "For I have said, The world shall be built up by love"<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The R.V. renders the passage: “Mercy shall be built up for ever.”</i> (Ps. 89:2). With love was the world built up before the Torah had been given.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> R. Ishmael seems to imply that, prior to the giving of the Law (Torah), the world’s law was based on the impulses of nature and therefore immoral. See the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Epiphanius, <i>op. cit.</i> xxxix. 5, refers to this subject.</i> Rabbi Joseph<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. Rab. 22:2. According to the Book of Jashar, <i>loc. cit</i>., “Eve bore two sons and three daughters.” According to this book the union of Adam and Eve was consummated <i>after</i> the expulsion from Paradise; see also Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 15 and § 35, and T.B. Jebamoth, 62a. Josephus says: “Adam and Eve had two sons… they had also daughters” (<i>Ant.</i> i. 2. 1).</i> as it is said, "And she conceived, and bare (with) Cain" (Gen. 4:1). At that hour she had an additional capacity for child-bearing (as it is said), "And she <i>continued</i> to bear his brother Abel" (<i>ibid.</i> 2).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. agrees with Oxford MS. (e. 76), and partially with the Oxford MS. (OA. 167). The first editions read: “At that hour she was debarred from bearing,” as it is said, “And she <i>ceased</i> to bear.” Here “Asaph” = to cease. Our text agrees with Pal. Targ. Gen. 4:2. See Gen. Rab. 22:3, and cf. the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. lxxv.</i>
Now Cain was a man who loved the ground in order to sow seed; and Abel was a man who loved to tend the sheep; the one gave of his produce as food for the other, and the latter gave of his produce as food for his (brother). The evening of the festival of Passover<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Our book lays stress on the Passover in contradistinction to Jubilees, which exalts Pentecost and Tabernacles. Luria argues that as there was a tradition that the world was created on the 1st of Nisan, Adam was therefore created on the 6th, and “at the end of days” (Gen. 4:3) means one week, and these numbers equal thirteen, and after this day is the 14th, which is the eve of Passover. The offering was brought on the 14th, and eaten that day at even, which is the beginning of the 15th. On the other hand, according to our book, <i>supra,</i> p. 52, the creation began on the 25th of Ellul, and Adam was fashioned on the 1st of Tishri; “at the end of days” would be interpreted as the change in the seasons from autumn to spring, when the first-fruits would be brought. Cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 236. Our text is reproduced by Pal. Targ. Gen. 4:3, and Midrash Agadah (ed. Buber), Gen. p. 10, and see <i>ibid.</i> note 6.<br>According to Dr. Büchler (<i>J.Q.R</i>. v. 442), in the first year of the triennial cycle of reading the Torah, a Palestinian custom, on the first day of Passover, Gen. 3:22–iv. 26 was read. Now, the story of the offering of Cain and Abel occurs in Gen. 4:3 ff., and would fall in the Passover week. This explains our text, “the night of the festival of Passover arrived.” See <i>J.E.</i> xii. p. 256a, line 6; Gen. 3, which is quoted there, should probably be Gen. 4<br>Chrysostomus (about 175 <small>C.E.</small>) declared that it was customary to begin reading from Genesis during Lent, <i>i.e.</i> Nisan. This shows that the Early Church followed the old Jewish custom of commencing the reading of the Torah in Nisan, the beginning of the Jewish ecclesiastical new year; see <i>J.E. ibid.</i> p. 257b. For a parallel reading, with slight variants, see Midrash Haggadol, c. 106 f.</i> arrived. Adam called his sons and said to them: In this (night) in the future Israel will bring Paschal offerings, bring ye also (offerings) before your Creator.
(Cain) brought the remnants of his meal of roasted grain, (and) the seed of flax,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In Tanchuma, Bereshith, § ix., we read: “Some sages say, The remnants of his meal; other sages say, The seed of flax.” See ‘Arukh (ed. Kohut) iv. p. 229b; and cf. Ẓohar, Lev. 87a, where flax is mentioned as the offering of Cain.</i> and Abel brought of the firstlings of his sheep, and of their fat, he-lambs, which had not been shorn of their wool.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The offering was the first-fruit of the animal and the first shearing of the wool.</i> The offering of || Cain was precluded,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of Oxford MS. (e. 76). The Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) and the first editions read “was abhorred”; cf. Prov. 28:9.</i> and the offering of Abel was acceptable, as it is said, "And the Lord had respect unto Abel and to his offering" (<i>ibid.</i> 4).
Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: The Holy One, blessed be He, said: Heaven forbid ! Never let the offerings<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Wool from Abel’s sheep and flax from Cain’s offering. The two combined would come under the prohibition of Sha’aṭneẓ (cf. Deut. 22:11). Perhaps the prohibition of Kilayim (Lev. 19:19) is also intended. This reference to Adam in connection with Sha’atnez is probably intentional, and is our author’s imitation of Jubilees, which also connects various laws with the Patriarchs. See Tanchuma, Bereshith, <i>loc. cit</i>., for a variant reading, and cf. ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit., s.v. Kilayim,</i> and see Maimonides, <i>Guide,</i> iii. 37, and <i>J.E.</i> xi. 212 f.</i> of Cain and Abel be mixed up (with one another), even in the weaving of a garment, as it is said, "Thou shalt not wear a mingled stuff, <i>wool</i> and <i>linen</i> together" (Deut. 22:11). And even if it be combined<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads “embroidered.” This agrees with the Oxford MSS. The 2nd ed. reads “decomposed.”</i> let it not come upon thee, as it is said, "Neither shall there come upon thee a garment of two kinds of stuff mingled together" (Lev. 19:19).
Rabbi Zadok said: A great hatred<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Jashar i. 16 says: “And Cain was jealous of his brother on this account.” Josephus. <i>Ant., loc. cit.</i>, also agrees with this view. The first editions read: “<i>Envy</i> and a great <i>hatred</i>.” The Oxford MS. (e. 76) reads: “Envy and hatred.” Test. XII Pat., Benj. vii. 5: “Because forever those who are like unto Cain in <i>envy</i> and <i>hatred</i> of brethren, shall be punished with the same judgment.”</i> entered Cain's heart against his brother Abel, because his offering had been accepted.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This agrees with Jubilees iv. 2; see also Irenæus, <i>adv. Hær.</i> iv. 3 (<i>A.N.C.L.</i> v. p. 433).</i> Not only (on this account), but also because Abel's twin-sister was the most beautiful of women, and he desired her in his heart. Moreover he said: I will slay Abel my brother, and I will take his twin-sister<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In Jubilees iv. 1 the wife of Cain is ’Avan, who was born after Abel. See Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. lxxviii.</i> from him, as it is said, "And it came to pass when they were in the <i>field</i>" (Gen. 4:8). "In the field" means woman, who is compared to a field.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (e. 76) adds: “as it is said: ‘But if a man find the damsel that is betrothed in the <i>field</i>’” (Deut. 22:25). The first editions read: “as it is said: ‘For man is the tree of the field’” (Deut. 20:19). Man is the <i>tree,</i> woman is the <i>field.</i> This fine figure has a parallel in Euripides, Orestes, 552 ff. Compare our expression, “<i>Mother</i> Earth.”</i> 
He took the stone and embedded it in the forehead<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 1. lxxix. states: “And Cain… took a large stone and smote his brother with it upon his head.” See Pal. Targum, Gen. 4:8, which reproduces our text: “he embedded a stone in his forehead and slew him.” The Book of Jashar i. 25 speaks of “the iron part of the ploughing instrument with which he suddenly smote his brother.” See also Book of the Bee, p. 26.</i> of Abel, and slew him, as it is said, "And Cain rose up against Abel his brother, and slew him" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Jochanan said: Cain did not know that the secrets are revealed before the Holy One, blessed be He.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees (iv. 6) states, in connection with Cain’s crime, that “we announce when we come before the Lord our God, all the sin which is committed in heaven and on earth, and in light and in darkness, and everywhere. The 1st eds., Oxford MS. (e. 76) and Gaster MS. add: “What did he do?”</i> He took the corpse of his brother Abel and hid it in the field.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (e. 76) reads: “he dug in the earth and hid (or buried) it.” The first editions have almost the same reading. According to our book there was apparently no actual burial by Cain, this was done by Adam and Eve; see <i>infra</i> in this chapter. See Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 38. Our Midrash was known to Jerome, <i>Ep. ad Dam.</i> 125. See Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan), <i>loc. cit.</i> According to the Book of Jashar, <i>loc. cit</i>., “Cain rose up and dug a hole in the field, wherein he put the body of his brother, and he turned the dust over him.” Ginzberg, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 66, note 2, deals with this theme; see also Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 83 f.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: "Where is Abel thy brother?" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). He replied to Him: Sovereign of the world ! A keeper of vineyard and field hast Thou made me.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Abel’s flocks would not be in the fields or vineyards of Cain, and therefore, in the ordinary course of events, he would not have known the whereabouts of his brother.</i> A keeper of my brother Thou hast not made me; as it is said, "Am I my brother's keeper?" (<i>ibid.</i>). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: || "Hast thou killed, and also taken possession?"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “Hast thou taken possession” of thy brother? (<i>i.e.</i> his wife and his flock). The later editions read: “I have also heard.”</i> (1 Kings 21:19). "The voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto me from the ground" (Gen. 4:10). When Cain heard this word<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 37a, b.</i> he was confused. And He cursed him, that he became<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “that he should be.”</i> a wanderer on the earth because of the shedding of the blood,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Almost a literal quotation from Jubilees iv. 4, surely this must be something more than a mere coincidence.</i> and because of the evil death.
Cain spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the worlds ! "My sin is too great to be borne" (<i>ibid.</i> 13), for it has no atonement.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests that the last words might be read as a question: “Is there no atonement for it?”</i> This utterance was reckoned to him as repentance,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 101b, and Lev. Rab. 10:5.</i> as it is said, "And Cain said unto the Lord, My sin is too great to be borne" (<i>ibid.</i>); further, Cain said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Now will a certain righteous one<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit</i>., and Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 147 pp. 143a, b.</i> arise on the earth and mention Thy great Name against me and slay me.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> By mentioning God’s name, see <i>J.Q.R.</i> v. p. 409, and cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 379.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He took one letter from the twenty-two letters,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “which are in the Torah and wrote (it).” See Ẓohar, Gen. 36b. Most of this chapter has close parallels in the Ẓohar. See also Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> and put (it) upon Cain's arm<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In Pal. The dog<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 30:1. A raven<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit</i>., reads: “Two clean birds”; cf. Gen. Rab. 22:8. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 116.</i> (came), one of its fellow birds was dead (at its side). (The raven) said: I will teach this man what to do. The Holy One, blessed be He, gave a good reward to the ravens in this world. What reward did He give them? Moreover, that rain should be given<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “they cry that rain should be given.”</i> upon the earth (for their sakes), and the Holy One, blessed be He, answers them, as it is said, "He giveth to the beast his food, and to the young ravens which cry" (Ps. 147:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The previous verse of the Psalm speaks of rain.
