Chapter 22

CHAPTER XXII<br><small>THE FALL OF THE ANGELS</small> [26<small>A</small>. i.]<br>"A<small>ND</small><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “It is written: ‘And Adam,’” etc.</i> Adam lived an hundred and thirty years, and he begat in his own likeness after his image" (Gen. 5:3). Hence thou mayest learn that Cain was not of Adam's seed,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> pp. 150 f., for the statement that Cain was the offspring of Eve and Sammael. The Scripture text seems to have afforded ground for the distinction which the Rabbis and others drew between Cain and Seth: “And Adam knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and bare Cain, and <i>she</i> said, I have acquired a man (child) from the Lord” (Gen. 4:1). Concerning Abel the Bible states, “And she continued to bare his brother Abel” (<i>ibid.</i> 2), without adding any further qualification as in the case of Cain. With reference to Seth the text says, “And Adam lived an hundred and thirty years, and he begat in <i>his own likeness</i> after <i>his image,</i> and <i>he</i> called his name Seth” (<i>ibid.</i> v. 3). The fifth chapter of Genesis begins afresh the history of Adam’s offspring, but omits all reference to Cain, whose descendants are mentioned in ch. iv. The Pal. Targum to Gen. 5:3 adds: “but before Eve had borne Cain, who was not like to him” (<i>i.e.</i> Adam).</i> nor after his likeness, nor after his image.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words “likeness and image” are not mentioned in the story of Cain’s birth. The first editions add: “neither did his deeds resemble those of Abel his brother.” Cain inherited the nature of Sammael, the angel of Death, and became a murderer.</i> (Adam did not beget in his own image)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are not in the text.</i> until Seth was born, who was<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “of his seed.”</i> after his father Adam's likeness and image,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and his deeds were similar to those of Abel his brother.”</i> as it is said, "And he begat in his own likeness, after his image" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Ishmael.” Our MS. agrees with the Midrash Haggadol, c. 117, and the Oxford MS. (O.A. 167). Dr. Büchler observes: “Also in the text of the Talmud Ishmael and Simeon are very frequently interchanged.”</i> said: From Seth arose and were descended<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “all the creatures.”</i> all the generations of the righteous.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 151, note 5, for this paragraph. There is probably some confusion in the texts here. “The generations of the righteous” are the offspring of Seth mentioned in Gen. 5; and “the generations of the wicked” are the offspring of Cain enumerated in Gen. 4 See Ẓohar, Gen. 35b, and Gen. Rab. 23:1. Pal. Targum to Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i>, adds: “And Cain was cast out; neither is his seed enumerated in the ‘Book of the generations of Adam.’”</i> From Cain arose and were descended all the generations of the wicked, who rebel<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The expression is based on Ezek. 20:38.</i> and sin, who rebelled against their Rock,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 341. The expression is often used to denote God as Creator. The first editions read: “The Omnipresent.” The Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) and the Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i>, read: “their Creator.”</i> and they said: We do not need the drops of Thy rain,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Job 24:13. The Midrash applies this chapter of Job to the generation of the Flood. See Gen. Rab. 31:2.</i> neither to walk in Thy ways, as it is said, "Yet they said unto God, Depart from us" (Job 21:14).
Rabbi Meir said: || The generations of Cain went about stark naked,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum on Gen. 6:2 says: “And the sons of the great saw that the daughters of men were beautiful… walking with naked flesh”; cf. Job 24:10, and Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 75 ff.</i> men and women, just like the beasts,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees iii. 30, 31 and cf. <i>ibid.</i> vii. 16, for a strong protest against nudity. See also Jalḳuṭ, Deut. § 945; and cf. Brüll, <i>Trachten der Juden,</i> pp. 4 ff. The fact that our book protests so strongly against the immodest vogue which probably obtained at the period and in the place where the author lived might point to the “origin” of our book, if we could only locate the fact referred to. One is apt to think of the vagaries of certain classes of recluses who belonged to the Christian Church and led solitary lives in the deserts of Egypt. Thus, in the <i>Paradise of the Holy Fathers</i> (ed. Budge, vol. i. p. 242), we read of the Abba Bessarion, who “wandered hither and thither like one possessed; in the season of frost he went naked.” In the Jalḳuṭ quoted above, the passage states (on the text, Deut. 32:21, “They have moved me to jealousy with that which is <i>not God</i>”): “this refers to those who come from Barbary (or Mauretania) who walk naked in the street.” See also Siphrê, Deut. § 320. Have we an echo of the warnings against incest referred to in Jubilees xxxiii. 10 ff.? and cf. <i>ibid.</i> xli. 25–26. See also <i>Schatzhōhle,</i> pp. 14 f.</i> and they defiled themselves with all kinds of immorality, a man with his mother or his daughter, or the wife of his brother,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> For Rabbinic references to the subject see T.B. Synhedrin, 58a; and cf. T.B. Jebamoth, 63b. See also T.J. Jebamoth xi. 1. 11d, Gen. Rab. 18:5, and Siphra, Ḳedoshim x. 11.</i> or the wife of his neighbour, in public<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 60b. The first editions omit: “or the wife of his neighbour”; they read: “in secret and in public with evil inclination,” etc.</i> and in the streets, with evil inclination which is in the thought of their heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. 6:5.</i> as it is said, "And the Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here. The first editions continue as in our version. “Rabbi” mentioned in the next paragraph is R. Jehudah, the Prince.</i> in the earth" (Gen. 6:5).
Rabbi said: The angels who fell<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> These “fallen angels” were called Nephilim (the fallen ones). “Giants” is the usual rendering of this term. On the angels, cf. <i>supra,</i> pp. 46, 99; and <i>infra,</i> pp. 193 f. These angels who fell from heaven are not mentioned by name in our book, but they are named Shemchaẓai and Uẓẓiel in Pal. Targum to Gen. 6:4, and also in the Azazel Midrash in Jellinek’s <i>B.H.M.</i> iv. pp. 127 f.; see Jeraḥmeel, pp. 52 ff., also Deut. Rab. xi. 9, and Ẓohar, Gen. 46b, 47a. The source of the legend is the Book of Enoch; see Introduction. On the names of the angels, see Brüll, <i>Jahrbücher für Jüd. Gesch.</i> i. 147 f., where the reference to our text must be corrected.</i> from their holy place in heaven saw the daughters of the generations of Cain<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Nachmanides (in Gen. <i>in loc</i>.), who quotes our text.</i> walking about naked, with their eyes painted<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 6:2; and cf. Gen. Rab. 26:7, and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 44, quoting Midrash Abkhir.</i> like harlots, and they went astray after them,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum <i>in loc</i>.; and cf. Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 31 p. 158.</i> and took wives from amongst them, as it is said, "And the sons of Elohim<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The R.V. renders, “the sons of God.” The Targum gives “the sons of the nobles” (or the “mighty”) in the sense of “angels.” Our MS. quotes the second half of this verse only, the first editions quote the first half of the verse.</i> saw the daughters of men that they were fair; and they took them wives of all that they chose"<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Pal. Targum renders: “And they took to themselves wives of all who pleased them.”</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 2).
Rabbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “ben Ḳorchah.”</i> said: The angels are flaming fire, as it is said, "His servants are a flaming fire" (Ps. 104:4), and fire came with the coition of flesh and blood, but did not burn the body;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Paul’s expression, “burned in their lust one toward another” (Rom. i. 27). On the “sin of the angels,” see the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. iv., which gives a very interesting version, denying the possibility of “angels… committing sin with human beings”; and see <i>Recognitions of Clement,</i> iv. 26, and Methodius, <i>Discourse on the Resurrection,</i> vii.</i> but when they fell from heaven, from their holy place, their strength and stature (became) like that of the sons of men, and their frame was (made of) clods of dust, as it is said, "My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust" (Job 7:5).
Rabbi Zadok said: From them were born the giants (Anakim),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Anakim “giants” see T.B. Soṭah, 34b, and Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> who walked with pride in their heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “with high stature.” Cf. Wisdom xiv. 6.</i> and who stretched forth their hand to all (kinds of) robbery and violence, and shedding of blood,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Job 24:14.</i> as it is said, "And there we saw the Nephilim,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 160, note 2.</i> the sons of Anak" (Num. 13:33); and it says, "The Nephilim were on the earth in those days" (Gen. 6:4).
Rabbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> First editions add: “ben Ḳorchaḥ.”</i> said: || The Israelites are called "Sons of God,"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> On “Sons of God” in Gen. 6:2 see LXX, Aquila, and Pesh.; and Philo, <i>de Gigant.</i> 2, i. M. 1. 263, C.W. ii. 6 ff. p. 44, and other references given by Charles on Jubilees v. 1. See also Wisdom ii. 13, 15.</i> as it is said, "Ye are the sons of the Lord your God" (Deut. 14:1). The angels are called "Sons of God," as it is said, "When the morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy" (Job 38:7);<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees v. 1. The LXX version of Job 38:7 is interesting as a parallel to our author’s interpretation of the “sons of God.” “When the stars were made, all my <i>angels</i> praised me with a loud voice.” See also the Targum to Job <i>in loc.</i></i> and whilst they were still in their holy place in heaven, these were called "Sons of God," as it is said, "And also after that, when<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions give only part of the verse.</i> the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men, and they bare children to them; the same became the mighty men, which were of old, men of renown" (Gen. 6:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The angels whilst in heaven were the sons of “Elohim”; when they fell and sinned they lost their right to this designation. Men may rise by virtue and holiness and become worthy of being called “the sons of Elohim.”</i>
Rabbi Levi said: They bare their sons and increased and multiplied<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 36:1 and Lev. Rab. 5:1. Luria holds that this dictum of R. Levi has been interpolated here from Gen. Rab. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> like a great reptile, six children at each birth.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 174; and cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 6a.</i> In that very hour they<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The offspring.</i> stood on their feet, and spoke the holy language, and danced before them like sheep, as it is said, "They cast their young like sheep, and their children danced" (Job 21:11).
Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan), <i>loc. cit.</i>, offers a close parallel: “But Noah preached repeatedly to the children of Cain, saying, ‘The flood will come and destroy you, if we do not repent.’ But they would not hearken to him; they only laughed at him.” See also Gen. Rab. 30:7, Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 15 p. 74, the Book of Jashar v. 22 ff., Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 18, and T.B. Synhedrin, 108b. See also Ephraim, on the Repentance of Nineveh (E.T. p. 34), for the refusal of the people to repent at the bidding of Noah. The Church Fathers speak of Noah as a preacher. See Methodius, <i>Banquet of Ten Virgins,</i> x. 3. and cf. Hippolytus, <i>A.N.C.L.</i> vi. pp. 492 f.</i> said to them: Turn from your ways and evil deeds, so that He bring not upon you the waters of the Flood, and destroy all the seed of the children of men.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 39 f., and Wisdom x. 4.</i> They said to him: Behold, we will restrain ourselves from multiplying and increasing, so as not to produce the offspring of the children of men. What did they do? When they came to their wives they spilled the issue of their seed upon the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) reads: “And the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that they had corrupted their way.” See R.V. Gen. 6:12.</i> so as not to produce offspring of the children of men, as it is said, "And God saw the earth, and behold it was spilled" (Gen. 6:12). They said: If He bring from heaven the waters of the Flood upon us, behold, we are of high stature, and the waters will not reach || up to our necks;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> “Water up to the neck” is an expression of extreme peril; cf. Isa. 8:8, xxx. 28; Ps. 69:2.</i> and if He bring the waters of the depths against us, behold, the soles of our feet can close up all the depths. What did they do? They put forth the soles of their feet, and closed up all the depths.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum on Gen. 7:10, T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i>, and <i>infra,</i> p. 167.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He heated the waters of the deep, and they arose and burnt their flesh, and peeled off their skin from them, as it is said, "What time they wax warm, they vanish; when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place" (Job 6:17). Do not read thus ("When it is hot," <span>בחֻמו</span>), but (read) "in his hot waters" (<span>בחמימיו</span>).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew could be interpreted as meaning “anger.” The later editions add: “The Parashah (Portion) of Bereshith (Gen. 1:1–vi. 8) is completed.” These words are highly significant. They seem to indicate that our book was intended originally to be a Midrash on the Torah, and as it is now preserved it is but a fragment of what it might have been. The “Portion” of Genesis is not to be identified with the “Book” of Genesis. The question of the triennial cycle of reading the Torah must also be borne in mind in dealing with our book. The narrative dealing with the Adam legends recurs three times: (1) Chapters III.–V., (2) Chapters XI.–XIV., and (3) Chapters XVIII.–XXII. Thus far in the first twenty-two chapters of the book we have only covered the first six chapters of Genesis. The first two chapters were biographical, and apart from them, the actual Midrash of twenty chapters may be subdivided as follows:<br>Chapter XVI. and XVII. seem out of place in this scheme.<br>A considerable portion of this chapter and the one following occurs in the Midrash Haggadol. Several parallels are to be found in Leḳach Ṭob, Midrash Agadah, and Aggadath Bereshith.</i>

Chapter 23

CHAPTER XXIII<br><small>THE ARK AND THE FLOOD</small> [26<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>"<i>And this</i> is how thou shalt make the ark"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Scripture text reads “it,” referring to the ark. See <i>J.E. s.v.</i> Noah, Ark, Deluge; the Pal. Targum has undoubtedly used our Midrash in the paraphrase of the Noah narrative (Gen. 6–vii.). The subject has been dealt with by Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 79 ff., and by Ginzberg, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 39 ff., 79 ff., 87.</i> (Gen. 6:15). R. Shemiah taught: The Holy One, blessed be He, showed Noah with a finger<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> pp. 382 f., and T.B. Menachoth, 29a, Mekhilta, p. 2b, Tosaphoth to T.B Chullin, 42a, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 148.</i> and said to him, Like this and that shalt thou do to the ark. One hundred and fifty rooms<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “nests” or “cells”; see Pal. Targum, Gen. 6:15, and Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. ii., for a parallel tradition.</i> were along the length at the left<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “right side of the ark, and one hundred and fifty along the left side.” MS. Gaster reads: “One hundred rooms along the right side,” etc.</i> side of the ark, thirty-three<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.</i>, has: “thirty-six in the middle.” Ginsburger, <i>Pseudo-Jonathan, in loc.</i>, reads: “thirty-three.”</i> rooms across the width in the side within,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Where the entrance was, <i>i.e.</i> on the east of the ark.</i> and thirty-three rooms in the side across the width on the outside;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests that “within” may refer to the east, and “the outside” to the west.</i> and ten compartments in the centre, which were for the storerooms for the food.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan), <i>loc. cit.</i>, for a parallel, and cf. Hippolytus. <i>A.N.C.L.</i> vi. p. 491.</i> And there were five protected cisterns<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>אפטמיות = אַפֹוטֽנִיוֹת</span> (<i>puteana</i>), enclosures surrounding a well; see Book of Adam and Eve, <i>loc. cit.</i>: “line the well with lead.” This word occurs in the Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> on the right side of the ark, and fifty<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions read: “five.”</i> protected cisterns on the left side of the ark, and the openings for the water pipes opened and closed, and so was it in the lowest division;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the hold.</i> and so || on the second floor, and so on the third floor.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan), <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
The dwelling-place of all the cattle and animals<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 108b. A parallel to our Midrash is to be found in Hippolytus in <i>A.N.C.L.</i> vi., <i>loc. cit.</i>, and see German edition (Achelis), p. 88. Schatzhöhle, p. 17, has also a parallel.</i> was in the lowest compartment, the dwelling-place for all fowl was in the second compartment, and the dwelling-place for the reptiles<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and creeping things.”</i> and the human beings was in the third compartment.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Book of Adam and Eve, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Hence thou mayest learn<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Luria’s reading, which agrees with the tradition preserved in Midrash Kônen, <i>B.H.M.</i> ii. 36; cf. Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 39. According to Luria the text should be: “Hence thou mayest learn, that all the kinds of fowl on the earth equal 365; and likewise with the kinds of reptiles on the earth, and so with the kinds of cattle and animals on the earth.” The first editions read: “32 kinds of fowl on the earth, 365 kinds of reptiles on the earth.”</i> that there were 366 kinds of cattle on the earth, and 366 kinds of fowl on the earth, and 366 kinds of reptiles on the earth, for thus was (the number) in the lowest compartment,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> 366 rooms.<br>Docs this number refer to the 366 days of our author’s solar year? Noah was in the ark one solar year.</i> so in the second compartment, and so in the third floor, as it is said, "With lower, second, and third stories shalt thou make it" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).
Rabbi Tachanah<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Tanchuma.”</i> said: Noah made the ark during fifty-two years,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Book of Jashar v. 34 Noah took five years to build the ark; see <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xviii. p. 344.</i> so that they should repent of their ways.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and evil deeds,” but omit: “But they did not repent.” See the Book of Adam and Eve, <i>loc. cit.</i> The same tradition occurs in the writings of several of the Church Fathers: Theophilus of Antioch (<i>To Autolycus,</i> iii. 19), Ephraim of Syria (on Jonah, 13); Revelation of Paul, <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xvi. p. 491; and Book of the Bee, p. 31; see also <i>supra,</i> pp. 161 f.</i> But they did not repent. Whilst yet the Flood had not come, the unclean (animals) were more numerous than the clean (animals). But when the waters of the Flood came, and the Holy One, blessed be He, wished to increase the clean and to diminish the unclean (animals), He called to Noah and said to him: Take to thee into the ark of all clean beasts seven and seven,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions end the paragraph here.</i> the male and his female; and of the unclean beasts two and two, the male and his female, as it is said, "Of every || clean beast thou shalt take to thee<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS., which adds “etc.”</i> seven and seven, the male and his female; and of the beasts that are not clean two, the male and his female" (<i>ibid.</i> vii. 2).
Noah said to the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the world ! Have I then the strength to collect them unto me to the ark? The angels appointed over each kind went down and gathered them,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. viii. says: “My power shall go with it (the trumpet blast) to make it come into the ears of the beasts and the birds.… I will command my angel to blow the horn from heaven, and all these animals shall be gathered unto thee.” Cf. Pal. Targum on Gen. 6:20: “they shall enter to thee by the hand of the angel, who will take and cause them to enter to thee.”</i> and with them all their food unto him to the ark. They came to him of their own accord,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is not in the printed texts. For a similar legend see Gen. Rab. 32:4 and 5, and cf. Ephraim, Sermon on Repentance i. 3.</i> as it is said, "And <i>they</i> came unto Noah into the ark" (<i>ibid.</i> 9); they came by themselves. "And they brought (them) to Noah" is not written here, but, "And they <i>came</i> unto Noah into the ark."<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is not in the printed texts. In the previous sentence the first editions read: “‘And Noah brought’ is not written in the Scripture, but ‘And they came unto Noah.’”</i>
Rabbi Mana said: When all the creatures had entered (the ark), the Holy One, blessed be He, closed and sealed<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The same expression occurs in the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. ix.</i> with His hand the gate<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “door.”</i> of the ark, as it is said, "And the Lord shut him in" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).
Rabbi Meir said: One pearl was suspended in the ark, and shed light upon all the creatures in the ark, like a lamp which gives light<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc</i>.; T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc.cit</i>.; Jalḳuṭ,Gen., <i>in loc</i>.; Gen. Rab. 31:11, which has a different version as compared with the Talmudic version of the legend. According to the Midrash it is Rabbi Levi who gives the tradition. Cf. Leḳach Ṭob, <i>in loc.</i>, and <i>supra,</i> p. 21.</i> inside<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “by its power, as it is said: ‘A light shalt thou make.’” etc.</i> the house, and like the sun yonder which shines in his might, as it is said, "A light shalt thou make to the ark" (<i>ibid.</i> vi. 16).
Rabbi Zadok said: On the 10th of Marcheshvan all the creatures entered the ark; on the 17th of the same<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 7:11; and compare our text with the Scripture text. See also T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 11b; Seder ‘Olam Rab. 4 p. 10a, note 17. Rabbi Eliezer held the view that the world was created in Ellul and Adam in Tishri.</i> (month) the waters of the Flood descended from heaven upon the earth, for they were the waters (endowed with the) male (principle). And there came up the waters of the depths, for they are the waters (endowed) with the female (principle),<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 30; T.J. Berakhoth 9:3. 14a, and Eth. Enoch liv. 8. The rain from heaven is the male principle.</i> and they were joined with one another, and they prevailed so as to destroy || the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The living creatures in the world.</i> as it is said, "And the waters prevailed exceedingly upon the earth" (<i>ibid.</i> vii.	19).
And all living things which were upon the face of the earth decayed,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “were destroyed.”</i> as it is said, "And every living thing was destroyed which was upon the face of the ground" (<i>ibid.</i> 23), except Noah and those who were with him in the ark, as it is said, "And Noah only was left, and they that were with him in the ark" (<i>ibid.</i>), except Og,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Niddah, 61a, and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 267. The Midrashic interpretation of the word “Rephaim” (Deut. 3:11) gave rise to this legend. See Job 26:5, <i>supra,</i> p. 112, and <i>infra,</i> p. 253. The legend which connects Og with the “Paliṭ” is ignored by our book, which identifies Og with Eliezer, the servant of Abraham. The “Paliṭ” is identified with Michael, see <i>infra,</i> pp. 193 f.; and cf. <i>J.E.</i> ix. 388, and Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 80.</i> king of Bashan, who sat down on a piece of wood under the gutter<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “On a rung of (one of) the ladders.”</i> of the ark. He swore to Noah and to his sons that he would be their servant for ever.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 112.</i> What did Noah do? He bored an aperture in the ark, and he put (through it) his food daily for him, and he also was left, as it is said, "For only Og, king of Bashan, remained of the remnant of the giants" (Deut. 3:11). (The Flood was universal) except in the land of Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ẓebachim, 113a; Nachmanides in his commentary on Gen., <i>in loc</i>., and 3 Baruch iv. 10.</i> upon which the water of the Flood did not descend from heaven, but the waters were gathered together from all lands, and they entered therein, as it is said, "Son of man, say unto her, Thou art a land that is not cleansed, nor rained upon, in the day of indignation"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The land in the text is interpreted by the Midrash as referring to the Holy Land at the time of the Flood.</i> (Ezek. 22:24). 
He<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Noah. The first editions read: “Noah.”</i> sent forth the raven to ascertain what was (the state of) the world. It went and found a carcase of a man cast upon the summit of a mountain,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “upon the tops of the mountains.”</i> and it settled thereon for its food,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the interpretation of Job 24:20, in Gen. Rab. 33:5.</i> and it did not return with its message to its sender, as it is said, "And he sent forth the raven" (Gen. 8:7). He sent forth the dove to see what was (the state of) the world, and she brought back her message to her sender, as it is said, "And the dove came in to him at eventide,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends the quotation at “eventide.” The first editions continue the verse. Pal. Targum, Gen. 8:11, reads: “And the dove came to him at the evening time, and behold, a leaf of olive gathered, broken off, she brought in her mouth, and which she had taken from the mount of Olives.” Palestine had escaped the deluge. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 4 p. 10b, note 27, and Tosaphoth to ‘Erubin 18b.</i> and, lo, in her mouth an olive leaf pluckt off"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the R.V.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 11). And why in her mouth was an olive leaf pluckt off? || The dove spake before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all worlds ! Let my food be bitter like this olive, and let it be entrusted<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and given by Thy hand.”</i> to Thy hand, and let it not be sweet (even) as honey, and given by the hand of flesh and blood.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. Rab. 33:6; T.B. Synhedrin, 108b; and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 41. See also Revelation of Paul, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Hence they<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The sages of Israel.</i> said: He who sends a message by the hand of an unclean (messenger)<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Later editions read: “evil.” The raven was “unclean,” whilst the dove was a “clean” bird; see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 40 f.</i> is (like) sending by the hand of a fool, and he who sends a message by the hands of a clean (messenger) is like sending by the hand of a messenger faithful to his senders.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Prov. 25:13 for a similar expression; see Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 58; Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxxiv. p. 51b.</i>
Rabbi Zadok said: For twelve<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah ‘Edujoth ii.; and Seder ‘Olam Rab. 4 p. 9b. The Flood began on the 17th of Marcheshvan, and on the 27th of this month, a year later, Noah was released. This period lasted one year and eleven days, <i>i.e.</i> one lunar year plus eleven days, which is the duration of a solar year.</i> months all the creatures were in the ark; and Noah stood and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying before Him:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See the fine prayer in the Book of Jashar vi. 31, which has used our <i>P.R.E.</i> See Tanchuma, Noah § ix. The basis of the prayer here is probably Isa. 49:9.</i> Sovereign of all worlds ! Bring me forth from this prison, for my soul is faint, because of the stench<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests that the text should read: “the dread.”</i> of lions.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “bears and leopards.”</i> Through me will all the righteous crown Thee with a crown of sovereignty,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The story of Noah forms part of the “Ẓichronoth” in the Synagogue liturgy for the New Year. For another explanation see Tanchuma, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i> See Introduction.</i> because Thou hast brought me forth from this prison, as it is said, "Bring my soul out of prison,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; the first editions continue the verse.</i> that I may give thanks unto thy name: for the righteous shall crown me, when thou wilt have dealt bountifully with me" (Ps. 142:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar vi. 36.</i>
Rabbi Levitas, a man of Jamnia, said: He separated the males from the females of all which came to the ark<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “when they came into the ark.” See the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. vii. f.; T.J. Ta‘anith 1:6. 64d; T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Gen. Rab. 31:12. The Church has in some quarters to this day retained the custom of separating the sexes at Divine worship. For other references see Ginzberg, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 82, who quotes Origen and Ephraim.</i> when they came into the ark, as it is said, "And Noah went in, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives" (Gen. 7:7). Verily the males were on one side.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And the females were on the other side.” The legend occurs also in Hippolytus (ed. Achelis), G.T., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> When they went forth from the ark, He caused the males to be joined with the females, as it is said, "Go forth of the ark, thou, and thy wife,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MSS. end the quotation here: the first editions continue the verse.</i> and thy sons, and thy sons' wives with thee" (<i>ibid.</i> viii. 16). Verily a man with his wife (went forth), "Thy sons, and thy sons' wives with thee"<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Luria’s reading.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>) || He blessed them, that they might increase and multiply on the earth, as it is said, "And God blessed Noah and his sons,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends the quotation here; the first editions continue the verse till the word “multiply.”</i> and said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth" (<i>ibid.</i> ix. 1). The sons of Noah were fruitful and multiplied, and they begat sons with their twins with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence does not occur in the printed editions. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 165.</i>
Noah found a vine which was lying there,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “which had been cast forth.”</i> which had come out of the garden of Eden.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum, Gen. 9:20, reads: “And he found a vine which the river had brought away from the garden of Eden.” Apparently our Midrash wishes to connect the folly of Noah with the sin of Adam; see Siphrê, Deut. § 323. Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 70a, Gen. Rab. 36:3, and Ẓohar, Gen. 73a. See 3 Baruch iv. 10 ff.</i> It had its clusters with it, and he took of its fruit and ate, and rejoiced in his heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and he desired them in his heart.” The quotation which follows in our text is omitted by the printed editions.</i> as it is said, "My wine, which cheereth God and man" (Judg. 9:13). He planted a vineyard with it. On the selfsame day it produced and became ripe<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. and several later editions read: “its fruits ripened.”</i> with its fruits, as it is said, "In the day of thy planting thou dost make it grow,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and first editions.</i> and in the morning thou makest thy seed to blossom" (Isa. 17:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Note the preceding verse in Isaiah. See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 43.</i> He drank wine thereof, and he became exposed in the midst of the tent, as it is said, "And he drank of the wine, and was drunken; and he was uncovered within his tent" (Gen. 9:21).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation does not occur in the printed editions of our book.</i> Canaan entered and saw the nakedness of Noah, and he bound a thread (where the mark of) the Covenant<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Circumcision. The legend that Noah was an eunuch occurs also in Theophilus of Antioch (<i>To Autolycus,</i> iii. 19). See also Ẓohar, Gen. 73b, and Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 86.</i> was, and emasculated him. He went forth and told his brethren. Ham entered and saw his nakedness. He did not take to heart the duty of honouring (one's father<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads: “the duty (or precept) of ‘Honour’” (Ex. 20:12). Some editions (Amsterdam) add: “and mother.” See Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. xiii. According to Luria the text should continue: “therefore was he cursed by being called a slave”; see Tanchuma, ed. Buber, Gen. 24b.</i>). But he<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He went forth and told.”</i> told his two brothers in the market,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> So also the Targumim, <i>in loc.</i> Perhaps the translation should be “outside.”</i> making sport<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See Justin Martyr, <i>Dial. c. Tryph.</i> cxxxix.; “who <i>mocked</i> at his father’s nakedness.”</i> of his father. His two brothers rebuked him. What did they do? They took the curtain of the east<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “veil of the east,” the veil or curtain used to shield one from the heat and glare of the sun. The 2nd ed. reads: “the cover.”</i> with them, and they went backwards and covered<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 23, note 16.</i> the nakedness of their father, as it is said, "And Shem and Japheth took a garment,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and first editions.</i> and laid it upon both their shoulders, and went backward, and covered the nakedness of their father; and their faces were backward, and they saw not their father's nakedness" (<i>ibid.</i> 23).
Noah awoke from his wine, and he knew what the younger son of Ham had done unto him, and he cursed him,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>, and Justin Martyr, <i>Dial. c. Tryph., loc. cit.</i>; for other references to Church Fathers see Ginzberg, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 86.</i> as it is said, "And he said, Cursed be Canaan" (<i>ibid.</i> 25). Noah sat and mused in his heart, saying: The Holy One, blessed be He, delivered me || from the waters of the Flood, and brought me forth from that prison, and am I not obliged to bring before Thee a sacrifice and burnt offerings?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 70a. There is considerable agreement between the Ẓohar and <i>P.R.E.</i> in this and the next chapter.</i> What did Noah do? He took from the clean<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 111. xi.</i> animals an ox and a sheep,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and a goat.”</i> and from all the clean birds, a turtle-dove and pigeons; and he built up the first altar upon which Cain and Abel<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum, Gen. 8:20, reads: “And Noah built an altar before the Lord; that altar which Adam had built at the time when he was cast forth from the garden of Eden, and had offered an offering upon it; and upon it had Cain and Abel offered their offerings.” Cf. also T.B. Ẓebachim, 115b, and Gen. Rab. 34:9.</i> had brought offerings, and he brought four burnt offerings, as it is said, "And Noah builded an altar unto the Lord; and took of every<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> clean beast, and of every clean fowl, and he offered burnt offerings on the altar" (<i>ibid.</i> viii. 20). It is written here only, "and he offered burnt offerings on the altar," and the sweet savour ascended before the Holy One, blessed be He, and<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said, ‘and he offered burnt offerings on the altar’” (Gen. 8:20).</i> it was pleasing to Him, as it is said, "And the Lord smelled the sweet savour" (<i>ibid.</i> 21). What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He put forth His right hand, and swore to Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> pp. 335, 347; and cf. Tanchuma, Noah § xi.</i> that He would not<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “again.”</i> bring the waters of the Flood upon the earth, as it is said, "For this is as the waters of Noah unto me; for as I have sworn<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and the first editions, which add: “etc.”</i> that the waters of Noah should no more go over the earth" (Isa. 54:9). And He gave a sign in the rainbow as a sign of the covenant of the oath between Himself and the people, as it is said, "I do set my bow in the cloud,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and it shall be for a token of a covenant" (Gen. 9:13).
And thus our sages instituted<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 13a, for the daily recital of the story of the Exodus. The Scripture passage quoted occurs in the second section of the “Shema‘”; see Singer, p. 41. The ritual question involved here is interesting, because the actual narrative of the oath to Noah is not recited daily. The verse quoted as a reason for this institution continues, after the word “land,” thus: “which the Lord <i>sware</i> unto your fathers to give them.” This was not the oath to Noah. See Eth. Enoch lv. 2.</i> that they should (mention)<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “mention”; it occurs in the first editions.</i> the oath to Noah every day, as it is said, "That your days may be multiplied, and the days of your children, upon the land<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions end the quotation here; in the MS. the last word quoted is “children.” In the printed texts this quotation is the conclusion of the chapter. Our MS. continues with a section which forms part of chapter xxiv. in the printed editions.</i> which the Lord sware unto your fathers to give them, as the days of the heavens above the earth" (Deut. 11:21).


Chapter 24

CHAPTER XXIV<br><small>NIMROD AND THE TOWER OF BABEL</small> [28<small>B</small>. i.] Noah brought his sons and his grandsons, and he blessed them with their (several) settlements,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “gifts.”</i> and he gave them as an inheritance all the earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The division of the earth among the sons of Noah is also mentioned by Jubilees viii. 10, and was known to the Church Father, Epiphanius (G.T. pp. 217 ff.).</i> He especially blessed<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The verb is repeated.</i> Shem and his sons, (making them) dark but comely,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Cant. 1:5; but they were not “black”; the Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) reads: “white and comely.”</i> and he gave them the habitable earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Not the sea which was the lot of the sons of Ham, nor the deserts which fell to the sons of Japheth. Shem has his tents and fixed abode in the habitable lands of the earth.</i> He blessed Ham and his sons, (making them) dark || like the raven,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads, as an emendation, “black and uncomely”; cf. Gen. Rab. 36:7. If our MS. text be accepted, a parallel may be found in Cant. 5:11.</i> and he gave them as an inheritance the coast of the sea.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>e.g.</i> the Egyptians on the seacoast, or the Sidonians on the Phoenician coast; cf. Jer. 47:7.</i> He blessed Japheth and his sons, (making) them entirely white,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and beautiful.” Japheth as a word signifies “beauty.” The sons of Japheth were the migratory tribes from the north, <i>e.g.</i> the Goths who settled in Europe. See Eth. Enoch lxxxviii. 9.</i> and he gave them for an inheritance the desert and its fields;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “desert and fields.”</i> these (are the inheritances with) which he endowed them.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the children of Noah. The words in brackets occur in the first editions. See Introduction, pp. xxiv. f., and li.</i>
<br>R<small>ABBI</small> E<small>LIEZER</small><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Ilai.”</i> said: They begat their sons and increased and multiplied like a great reptile, six at each birth,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> We have had this expression <i>supra,</i> p. 161. It is an “Oriental” exaggeration, signifying the prolific nature of the people.</i> and they were all one people, and one heart, and one language, as it is said, "And the whole earth was of one language and of one speech" (Gen. 11:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> They despised the pleasant land,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Palestine; cf. Ps. 106:24, and Ẓohar, Gen. 75b.</i> as it is said, "And it came to pass, as they journeyed<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “In the east” might also be rendered “in the commencement,” or “at first”; see Ẓohar, Gen. 74b.</i> in the east" (<i>ibid.</i> 2). They went to the land of Shinar, and found there a large stone,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a large and extensive land, entirely a plain.”</i> very extensive, and the whole plain, and they dwelt there, as it is said, "And they found a plain in the land of Shinar, and they dwelt there" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi 'Aḳiba said: They cast off the Kingdom of Heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Erubin, 53a; cf. Pal. Targum to Gen. 10:8 on Nimrod; see also the Book of Jashar vii. 46 ff., and Jeraḥmeel lvii. 14. Augustine rendered Gen. 10:9, “Nimrod was a hunter against God” (<i>de Civ. Dei,</i> xvi. 4).</i> from themselves, and appointed Nimrod king over themselves; a slave son of a slave. Are not all the sons of Ham slaves?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “are slaves.”</i> And woe to the land when a slave rules,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The phraseology is based on Eccles. 10:16.</i> as it is said, "For a servant, when he is king"<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The previous verse says, “The earth trembles.” Nimrod caused the people to tremble, as a result of discarding the Kingdom of Heaven.</i> (Prov. 30:22).
Rabbi Chakhinai<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Chanina.”</i> said: Nimrod was a mighty hero, as it is said, "And Cush begat Nimrod, who began to be a mighty one in the earth" (Gen. 10:8). Rabbi Jehudah said:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 44 f. On the garments of Adam and Eve see the Book of Jashar, vii. 24 ff.; Gen. Rab. 20:12 and lxv. 16; Pal. Targ. Gen. 25:27, xxvii. 15.</i> The coats<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “coat.” See Book of the Bee, p. 35.</i> which the Holy One, blessed be He, made for Adam and his wife, were with Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “them.” See Hippolytus, <i>A.N.C.L.</i> vi. p. 492.</i> in the ark, and when they went forth from the ark, || Ham, the son of Noah, brought them forth with him, and gave them as an inheritance to Nimrod.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The <i>Recognitions of Clement,</i> iv. 27, speak of Ham as the first magician and refer to Nimrod as follows: “the magic art having been handed down to him as by a flash” (<i>ibid</i>. 29).</i> When he put them on, all beasts, animals, and birds, when they saw the coats,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “the writing” (<span>הכתב</span>).</i> came and prostrated themselves before him.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashi on T.B. Pesachim, 54b, and the Book of Jashar, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> The sons of men<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “they,” <i>i.e.</i> his fellow-countrymen; see Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 62. See <i>J.E.</i> ix. 309.</i> thought that this (was due) to the power of his might; therefore they made him king over themselves, as it is said, "Wherefore it is said, Like Nimrod, a mighty hunter before the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> 9).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The next verse says, “The beginning of his <i>kingdom</i>.” See Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> i. 4. 2; T.B. Pesachim, 94b; and cf. Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i>, and the Book of the Bee, p. 37.</i>
Nimrod said to his people:<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, 89a; Gen. Rab. 26:4; and cf. Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 27a.</i> Come, let us build a great city for ourselves, and let us dwell therein, lest we be scattered upon the face of all the earth, as the first people<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> At the Flood. According to Jubilees vii. 20, Noah enjoined upon his sons commandments “to cover the shame of their flesh, and to bless their Creator, and honour father and mother, and love their neighbour, and guard their souls from fornication and uncleanness and all iniquity. For owing to these three things came the flood upon the earth.”</i> (were). Let us build a great tower in its midst, ascending to heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 109a, and Othijoth de R. ‘Aḳiba, letter Resh. <i>B.H.M.</i> iii. pp. 46 f.</i> for the power of the Holy One, blessed be He, is only in the water,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the correct reading should be “in heaven,” and not “in the water.”</i> and let us make us a great name on the earth, as it is said, "And let us make us a name" (<i>ibid.</i> xi. 4).
Rabbi Phineas said: There were no stones there where-with to build the city and the tower. What did they do? They baked bricks and burnt them like a builder<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “stone mason.”</i> (would do), until they built it seven<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “seventy.” See Book of the Bee, p. 41.</i> mils<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> “Mil” (mille) =2000 cubits. According to the Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>in loc.</i>, the height was seven miles; see also Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 55 p. 145b. The MS. adds “of property.”</i> high, and it had ascents on its east and west. (The labourers) who took up the bricks went up on the eastern (ascent), and those who descended went down on the western (descent). If a man fell and died they paid no heed to him, but if a brick fell they || sat down and wept, and said: Woe is us ! when will another one come in its stead?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This indifference to the value of human life reappears in the story of the Egyptian bondage; see <i>infra,</i> p. 386. See also <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 46, and cf. 3 Baruch iii. 5.</i>
And Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the first editions the name is “Abram.” See Wisdom x. 5.</i> son of Terah,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Terah was one of those who assisted in the building of the Tower of Babel, according to the Ẓohar, Lev. 111b.</i> passed by, and saw them building the city and the tower, and he cursed them in the name of his God,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The expression is borrowed from 2 Kings 2:24. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 1 p. 3a.</i> as it is said, "Swallow up, O Lord, divide their language" (Ps. 55:9). But they rejected his words,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Abraham uttered his reproof in vain. See Jalḳuṭ, Pss. § 703.</i> like a stone cast upon the ground. Is it not a fact that every choice and good<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See 1 Sam. 9:2 for this phrase.</i> stone is only put at the corner of a building? and with reference to this, the text says, "The stone which the builders rejected is become the head of the corner" (<i>ibid.</i> cxviii. 22).
Rabbi Simeon said: The Holy One, blessed be He, called to the seventy<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The seventy nations with Israel form the human family. Israel has no guardian angel; God is the Guardian of Israel. See LXX, Deut. 32:8, for the earliest form of this Midrash. Augustine, <i>de Civ. Dei,</i> xvi. 5, offers a parallel to this Haggadah. See also Hippolytus (ed. Achelis), ii. p. 243; Clement of Alexandria, <i>Strom,</i> vi. 17; and <i>Recognitions of Clement,</i> ii. 42.</i> angels, who surround the throne of His glory, and He said to them: Come, let us descend and let us confuse the seventy nations and the seventy languages.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Come, let us confuse their speech.”</i>
Whence (do we know) that the Holy One, blessed be He, spake<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads, “He called.” The first editions read: “descended unto them.”</i> to them? Because it is said, "Go to, let <i>us</i> go down" (Gen. 11:7). "I will go down" is not written, but "Go to, let <i>us</i> go down."<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Pss., <i>loc. cit.</i>, and cf. Gen. Rab. 38:10.</i> And they cast lots among them. Because it is said, "When the Most High gave to the nations their inheritance" (Deut. 32:8). The lot of the Holy One, blessed be He, fell upon Abraham and upon his seed,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Some editions read: “and upon his house.”</i> as it is said, "For the Lord's portion is his people; Jacob is the <i>lot</i> of his inheritance" (<i>ibid.</i> 9).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said: The portion and lot which have fallen to Me,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Psalms, § 667.</i> My soul liveth thereby,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “My soul delighteth in him.”</i> as it is said, "The lots have fallen unto me in pleasures; yea, I have a goodly heritage" (Ps. 16:6). The Holy One, blessed be He, descended with the seventy angels, who surround || the throne of His glory, and they confused their speech into seventy<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Some editions read, “seventy languages.” The first editions add: “Each nation had its own writing and its own language, and He appointed an angel over each people. And Israel fell unto His lot and portion, and concerning this it is said, ‘For the Lord’s portion is his people’” (Deut. 32:9). Each nation had not only its own language but also its peculiar style of writing.</i> nations and seventy languages. Whence do we know that the Holy One, blessed be He, descended? Because it is said, "And the Lord God <i>came down</i> to see the city and the tower" (Gen. 11:5). This was the second descent.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 97.</i>
And they wished to speak one to another in the language<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read, “in the holy language.” See <i>supra,</i> p. 161. The original language was Hebrew. See for a parallel legend, <i>Recognitions of Clement,</i> i. 30, and the Book of the Bee, p. 42.</i> of his fellow-countryman, but one did not understand the language of his fellow. What did they do? Every one took his sword, and they fought one another to destroy (each other), and half the world fell there by the sword, and thence the Lord scattered them upon the face of all the earth, as it is said, "So the Lord scattered them abroad on that account, upon the face of all the earth" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).
Rabbi Meir said: Esau, the brother of Jacob, saw the coats<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “which the Holy One, blessed be He, made for Adam and Eve.”</i> of Nimrod, and in his heart he coveted them,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads, as in our text, “them”; but the Prague edition reads “it” (<i>i.e.</i> one garment).</i> and he slew him,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar vii. 24, and Pal. Targum, Gen. 25:27 f. The wonderful garments of Adam and Eve have a parallel in the seamless tunic of the Founder of Christianity, see <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xvi. pp. 235 f.</i> and took them from him.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Agadah, Gen. 27:13; Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 66b and 67a; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 115; cf. Rashi on T.B. Pesachim, 54b, and Tanchuma. Toledoth, § xii.</i> Whence (do we know) that they were desirable in his sight? Because it is said, "And Rebecca took the <i>precious</i> raiment of Esau, her elder son" (<i>ibid.</i> xxvii. 15). When he put them on he also became, by means of them, a mighty<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The sentence is wanting in the Oxford MS. (O.A. 167).</i> hero, as it is said, "And Esau was a cunning hunter" (<i>ibid.</i> xxv. 27). And when Jacob went forth<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> After receiving the blessing from Isaac.</i> from the presence of Isaac, his father, he said: Esau, the wicked one, is not worthy to wear these coats. What did he do? He dug in the earth and hid them there, as it is said, "A noose<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse says, “and a trap for him in the way.” The garments enabled the wearer to catch the animals. Sec Pal. Targum, Gen. 27:15; and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 115.</i> is hid for him in the earth" (Job 18:10).

Chapter 25

CHAPTER XXV<br><small>THE SIN OF SODOM</small> [29<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>T<small>HE</small> third descent<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See preceding chapter. On the ten descents see Ẓohar, Gen. 75a; Aboth de Rabbi Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxxiv.; Gen. Rab. 38:9 and xlix. 6; and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. §27 and §83, and <i>supra,</i> p. 97, note 1.</i> which He descended<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “which the Holy One, blessed be He, descended.”</i> || was at Sodom, as it is said, "I will go down now and see" (Gen. 18:21). The Holy One, blessed be He, said: Shall I not<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “I will tell.”</i> tell My friend Abraham an important matter which I will do in My world in the future, as it is said, "And the Lord said, Shall I hide from Abraham that which I do?" (<i>ibid.</i> 17). Rabbi Chanina, son of Dosa,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here “Chaninah.”</i> said: The Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed, and three angels<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> According to our book, God with three angels appeared to Abraham at Mamre; see Rashbam, Ibn Ezra, and Nachmanides, <i>in loc.</i> (Gen. 18). According to Midrash Agadah, Gen. (p. 39), the three angels were Michael, Gabriel, and Raphael. See also T.B. Joma, 37a, and Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 41b.</i> (appeared) unto our father Abraham, as it is said, "And he lifted up his eyes and looked, and, lo, three men" (<i>ibid.</i> 2). He<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “One” (angel).</i> began to inform him about the conception<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> On the angelic message to Abraham see T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 86b; Pal. Targum to Gen. 18:2; Gen. Rab. 48:16 and 1. 2; Ẓohar, Gen. 99a.</i> of the womb by Sarah his wife, as it is said, "I will certainly return unto thee when the season cometh round" (<i>ibid.</i> 10). Afterwards He<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Instead of “Afterwards,” the first editions read: “Another” (angel).</i> told (him) about the doom<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. the work, or affair, or business.</i> of Sodom,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and Gomorrah.”</i> as it is said, "And the Lord said, Because the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great" (<i>ibid.</i> 20).
Hence thou mayest learn:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “they said,” <i>i.e.</i> the sages.</i> Everyone, who wishes to tell his companion a matter which is a disgrace to him, begins with a good word<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This rule still obtains in connection with the public recital of the Torah; see Orach Chayyim, 138</i> and concludes with the evil matter which is unpleasant to him. Whence do we learn this? From the Holy One, blessed be He, for when He was revealed to our father Abraham, He began to announce to him (the good news) concerning the conception by Sarah his wife. Afterwards He told him about the fate of Sodom, as it is said, "And the Lord said, Because the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the repetition of the quotation here.</i> (Abraham) began to ask for compassion before Him on behalf of Lot, the son of his brother. He spake before Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! Like the death of the wicked shall the death of the || righteous be? (As it is said),<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is omitted in the MS.</i> "Wilt thou consume the righteous<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “The righteous” in the Hebrew is in the singular number; this fact might suggest the idea that Abraham was referring to Lot.</i> with the wicked?" (<i>ibid.</i> 23). The Holy One, blessed be He, answered him: Abraham !<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “By thy life!”</i> By the merit of the righteous<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “By the merit of fifty righteous (people).”</i> (one) will I forgive Sodom.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “as it is said.”</i> "If I find in Sodom fifty righteous" (<i>ibid.</i> 26), then will I forgive it all its<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “their.”</i> sins.
Hence they<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The sages.</i> said: If there be fifty righteous in the world, the world exists through their righteousness. (Abraham) arose and began to beseech (God), and made supplication before Him until he brought (the number down to) ten. Hence (the sages said):<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Hence the sages said: If there be ten righteous people in a place, by their merit the place is delivered.”</i> (When there are) ten people in a place, the place is delivered by their righteousness, as it is said, "And he said, I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten" (<i>ibid.</i> 32).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 49:13; Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 5 p. 26b; and Ẓohar, Gen. 105b. Jer. 5:1 is the Biblical authority for the doctrine that the merit of the individual procures Divine forgiveness; cf. Ezek. 14:19. The inference as to the salvation of the <i>world</i> by the merit of fifty righteous people is derived from God’s words in Gen. 18:26: “And I will spare for their sake <i>all</i> the place” (<i>i.e.</i> every place). Abraham had spoken merely of “the place.”</i>
Rabbi Ẓe'era said: The men of Sodom were the wealthy men of prosperity,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the wealthy men of the world.”</i> on account of the good and fruitful land<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Sodom was situated at the right of Jerusalem; see Ezek. 16:46. The phraseology in our text is borrowed from Num. 13:19, 20.</i> whereon they dwelt. For every need which the world requires, they obtained therefrom. They procured gold therefrom, as it is said, "And it had dust of gold" (Job 28:6). What<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit this sentence.</i> is the meaning (of the text), "And it had dust of gold"? "> of a silver Denar. On this point see Krauss, <i>T.A</i>. ii. p. 407. The first editions add: “(some) vegetables.”</i> He went and bought (it), and found beneath it heaps of gold;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “full of gold.” The first editions read: “gold.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 109a; Siphrê, Deut. § 43; and Tosephta Soṭah iii. p. 296.</i> thus it is written, "And it had dust of gold"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab. 5:2; and Jalḳuṭ, Job, § 915. The idea of the Haggadah seems to be as follows: When the vegetable was bought at the cost of an Assar, the dust of the earth which was clinging to the vegetable was so valuable (owing to the gold which it contained) that the purchaser received back more than he had paid.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). They obtained silver therefrom, as it is said, "Surely there is a mine for silver" (<i>ibid.</i> 1). They procured precious stones and pearls thence, as it is said, || "The stones thereof are the place of sapphires" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). They obtained bread therefrom, as it is said, "As for the earth, out of it cometh bread" (<i>ibid.</i> 5). But they did not trust in the shadow of their Creator, but (they trusted) in the multitude of their wealth,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 52:9; the Midrashim refer this passage to the story of Sodom.</i> for wealth thrusts aside its owners from the fear of Heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “thrusts aside from its owners the fear of Heaven.”</i> as it is said, "They that trust in their wealth" (Ps. 49:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Prov. 30:8.</i>
Rabbi Nathaniel<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Joshua, son of Ḳorchah.”</i> said: The men of Sodom had no consideration for the honour of their Owner by (not) distributing food to the wayfarer and the stranger,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the native and the stranger”; see Job 28:4. They caused human intercourse with the outside world to cease. To honour God is to be merciful; see Prov. 3:3 and xiv. 31; T.B. Sabbath, 127a. The men of Sodom did not suffer the birds to praise God by singing on the trees in their land. The Book of Jashar (xix. 7) says: “And when men heard all these things that the people of the cities of Sodom did, they refrained from coming there.” For further stories of cruelty see Pal. Targum on Gen. 18; and cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 60 ff.</i> but they (even) fenced in<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “they cut off.”</i> all the trees on top above their fruit so that they should not be seized;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “so that there should not be any benefit from them.”</i> (not) even by the bird of heaven, as it is said, "That path no bird of prey knoweth" (Job 28:7).
Rabbi Joshua, son of Ḳorchah,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Nathaniel.”</i> said: They appointed over themselves judges who were lying judges, and they oppressed every wayfarer<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the native and the stranger”; see Job 28:4. They caused human intercourse with the outside world to cease. To honour God is to be merciful; see Prov. 3:3 and xiv. 31; T.B. Sabbath, 127a. The men of Sodom did not suffer the birds to praise God by singing on the trees in their land. The Book of Jashar (xix. 7) says: “And when men heard all these things that the people of the cities of Sodom did, they refrained from coming there.” For further stories of cruelty see Pal. Targum on Gen. 18; and cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 60 ff.</i> and stranger who entered Sodom by their perverse judgment, and they sent them forth naked, as it is said, "They have oppressed the stranger without judgment" (Ezek. 22:29).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar xix. 3 ff.; T.B. Synhedrin, 109a.</i>
They were dwelling in security without care and at ease, without the fear of war from all their surroundings, as it is said, "Their houses are safe from fear" (Job 21:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit this quotation.</i> They were sated with all the produce of the earth, but they did not strengthen with the loaf of bread either the hand of the needy or of the poor,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Jashar (xix. 44) reads: “For they (the men of Sodom) had abundance of food and had tranquillity amongst them, still they would not sustain the poor and needy.”</i> as it is said, "Behold, this was the iniquity of thy sister Sodom; pride, fulness of bread,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, “etc.” being added.</i> and prosperous ease was in her and in her daughters; neither did she strengthen the hand of the poor and needy" (Ezek. 16:49).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Their prosperity led to their rebellion against God; cf. Hos. 13:6. In the Book of Jashar, chapter xix., we have two stories on the theme of this paragraph; they are probably variants of one tradition.</i> ||
Rabbi Jehudah said: They made a proclamation in Sodom (saying): Everyone who strengthens the hand of the poor or the needy with a loaf of bread shall be burnt by fire. Peleṭith,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 109b. The name Peleṭith is given by the Pal. Targum on Gen. 18:21, Book of Jashar xix. 24; cf. Gen. Rab. 49:6; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. §83; and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 63. In the Midrash Agadah (Genesis), p. 42. the name of Lot’s daughter is Kalah. The Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) reads “Palṭia.”</i> daughter of Lot, was wedded to one of the magnates of Sodom. She saw a certain very<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “broken,” “afflicted,” or “humiliated.” See <i>J.E.</i> xi. 424.</i> poor man in the street of the city, and her soul was grieved on his account, as it is said, "Was not my soul grieved for the needy?" (Job 30:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is not in the printed texts of <i>P.R.E.</i></i> What did she do? Every day when she went out to draw water she put in her bucket all sorts of provisions from her home, and she fed that poor man. The men of Sodom said: How does this poor man live? When they ascertained the facts, they brought her forth to be burnt with fire. She said: Sovereign of all worlds ! Maintain my right and my cause<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Ps. 9:4 may have suggested the phrase of our text. Luria observes that this Psalm might well apply to the story of Sodom.</i> (at the hands of) the men of Sodom. And her cry ascended before the Throne of Glory. In that hour the Holy One, blessed be He, said: "I will now descend, and I will see" (Gen. 18:21)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions continue the verse: “whether according to her cry which is come unto me.” The word in the Hebrew text which the R.V. renders “according to the cry of it” is rendered by the Midrash literally “according to her cry.”</i> whether the men of Sodom have done according to the cry<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum, Gen. 18:20 f., reads: “And the Lord said to the ministering angels, The cry of Sodom and Gomorrah, because they oppress the poor, and decree that whosoever giveth bread to the needy shall be burnt with fire, is therefore great; and their guilt is exceedingly heavy. I will now appear, and see whether, as the cry of the <i>damsel</i> Peleṭith, which ascendeth before Me, they have completed their sins.”</i> of this young woman, I will turn her foundations upwards,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 28:5. This chapter is applied by our author to the story of Sodom. See also Lev. Rab. 5:2; and Midrash Haggadol, c. 282, note 98.</i> and the surface thereof shall be turned downwards, as it is said, "I will now descend, and I will see whether they have done altogether according to her cry, which is come unto me" (<i>ibid.</i>). "According to <i>their</i> cry" is not written here (in the text), only "According to her cry."
And thus the text says,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “Behold (the text) says.” The reading, if rendered literally, is: “And thus it (or he) says.”</i> "He who walketh with wise men shall be wise: but the companion of fools shall be broken" (Prov. 13:20). || "He who walketh with wise men shall be wise." To what is this like? To one who enters a perfumer's shop, although he neither takes anything nor gives anything,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “he neither sells nor buys.”</i> nevertheless he absorbs a good scent, and goes away (therewith). Likewise everyone who walks with the righteous acquires some of their good ways and deeds. Therefore it is said, "He who walketh with wise men shall be wise." "But the companion of fools shall be broken" (<i>ibid.</i>). To what is this comparable? To a man who enters a tannery, although he neither takes or gives anything,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “he neither sells nor buys.”</i> nevertheless he has absorbed a foul odour.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and he brings it away with himself.”</i> Likewise he who walks with the wicked acquires some of their evil ways and deeds, that is according to what is written,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “as it is said.”</i> "But the companion of fools shall be broken" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Another explanation:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is missing in the first edition.</i> "He who walketh with wise men shall be wise" (<i>ibid.</i>). This refers to Lot,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳ’uṭ, Deut. § 824; Midrash, Prov. (ed. Buber), ch. xiii. p. 36b; and Jalḳuṭ, Prov. 13 § 950.</i> who walked with our father Abraham, and learned of his good deeds and ways. They<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The sages.</i> said: What did our father Abraham do? He made for himself a house opposite to Haran,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. 12:4 f. Luria suggests that the reading should be “Sodom.” See Agadath Bereshith, 25Gen. Rab. 52:1 and liv. 6; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 84, reads: “outside Haran.”</i> and he received everyone who entered into or went out from Haran, and he gave him to eat and to drink. He said to them: Say ye, The God of Abraham is the only one in the universe.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He said to him: There is one God in the Universe.”</i> || When Lot came to Sodom he did likewise. When they made proclamation in Sodom: All who strengthen the hand of the poor or needy with a loaf of bread shall be burnt by fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, quoted <i>supra,</i> p. 183, note 6.</i> he was afraid of the men of the city, (and did not venture) to do so by day, but he did it by night, as it is said, "And the two angels came to Sodom at even; and Lot sat in the gate of Sodom" (Gen. 19:1). Why did Lot sit in the gate of Sodom?<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “For on that day they had appointed him (judge) over themselves. (Lot) overtook them (the angels) and said to them,” etc. Cf. Esth. 5:13, for Mordecai who sits in the “king’s gate,” <i>i.e.</i> as a judge; cf. Sublime Porte for the use of “gate” as a court of government or law.<sup></sup> The MS. seems to have a mistake here; it merely repeats what was stated a few lines previously, without explaining why Lot sat in the gate of Sodom. See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> Because he was afraid of the men of the city, (and did not venture) to act (charitably) by day, but he did so by night. He saw the two angels walking in the street of the city, and he thought that they were wayfarers in the land, and he ran to meet them. He said to them: Come and lodge ye overnight in my house, eat and drink, and ye shall go your way in peace.
