But the men would not accept this for themselves, and he took them by the hand against their will, and brought them inside his house, as it is said, "And he urged them greatly" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).
A certain young man of the people of that city saw them, and he ran and told all the men of that city, and they all gathered together at the door of the house to do according to their wont, even deeds of sodomy,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit “deeds of sodomy.” A parallel occurs in Clement of Alexandria, <i>Pæd,</i> iii. 8.</i> as it is said, "And they called unto Lot, and said unto him, || Where<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. does not give this part of the verse.</i> are the men who came to thee to-night? bring them forth unto us that we may know<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “Know” in the sense of punishing offenders, cf. Judg. 8:16; see Parchon’s Heb. Lexicon, <i>s.v.</i> <span>ידע</span>; or perhaps it is used here in the sense of carnal knowledge.</i> them" (<i>ibid.</i> 5). What did Lot do? Just as Moses gave his life for the people,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Israel.” See Mekhilta, p. 34b.</i> so Lot<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “So Lot gave his life for them.” By going out to reason with the men of Sodom, who threatened to deal with him according to their wont.</i> gave up his two daughters instead of the two angels, as it is said, "Behold, now, I have two daughters" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). But the men<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Of Sodom.</i> would not agree (and did not accept them). What did the angels do to them? They smote them with blindness until the dawn of the (next) morning. All were treated with (measure for) measure.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 19:24: “And the word of the Lord had caused showers of favour to descend upon Sodom and Gomorrah that they might repent, but they did not.”</i> Just as he had taken them by the hand without their will and taken them into his house, so they took hold of his hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. 19:16 ff. Some of the later editions omit the words “the hand of his wife.” See Midrash Haggadol, c. 291 f.</i> and the hand of his wife, and the hand of his two daughters, and took them outside the city, as it is said, "But he lingered; and the men laid hold upon his hand" (<i>ibid.</i> 16). And they<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The angels.</i> said to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lot and his family. The text in Gen. (19:17) says, “Do not look behind <i>thee</i>”; note that the singular number is employed.</i> Do not look behind you, for verily the Shekhinah of the Holy One, blessed be He, has descended in order to rain upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum, Gen. 19:24, reads: “There are now sent down upon them sulphur and fire from before the word of the Lord from Heaven.” See Ẓohar, Gen. 107b f.</i> The pity of 'Edith<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads either “‘Erith” or “‘Edith.” Midrash Haggadol, c. 293, has “‘Edith.” In Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc.,</i> “‘Erith” is the reading. <i>’Edith</i> points to “‘Ed,” witness, for such was the pillar of salt. “Ado” is the reading in the Book of Jashar (xix. 52). Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.</i> 26, reads: “And his wife looked after the angel to know what would be the end of her father’s house, for she was of the daughters of the men of Sodom, and because she sinned by salt she was manifestly punished; behold, she was made a statue of salt.” The Second Version adds: “until the time of the resurrection shall come when the dead shall arise.”</i> the wife of Lot was stirred for her daughters, who were married in Sodom,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and she looked back behind her to see if they were coming after her or not. And she saw behind<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “behind her.”</i> the Shekhinah, and she became a pillar of salt, as it is said, "And his wife looked back from behind him, and she became a pillar of salt" (<i>ibid.</i> 26).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the following: “And she stands even now. All day the oxen lick it and it decreases up to her feet, and in the morning (the pillar of salt) grows afresh, as it is said: ‘And his wife looked back from behind him, and she became a pillar of salt’” (Gen. 19:26). In the days of Maimonides all trace of the pillar had been lost. The Book of Jashar (xix. 54) reads: “And the oxen which stood in that place daily licked up the salt to the extremities of their feet, and in the morning it would spring forth afresh and they again licked it up, unto this day.” For a parallel Christian Midrash, see “A Strain of Sodom” in <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xviii. p. 230. See Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1055; Jalḳuṭ, Exodus, § 256. See Koran (ed. Rodwell), lxxxvii. p. 301, and Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> i. 11. 4, for references to Sodom. On Lot’s wife, see Wisdom x. 7; Cyril of Jerusalem; Mystagogue’s Catechism viii.; Augustine, <i>de Civ. Dei,</i> x. 8. On the Flight from Sodom, see Ambrose, <i>Flight from the World,</i> 54; Gregory the Great, <i>Pastoral Rule,</i> iii. 27. On Lot’s hospitality, see Chrysostomus, Hom, xxxiii. 2; cf. Heb. xiii. 2. See also Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 132 ff., and Ginzberg, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 108 ff.</i>

Chapter 26

CHAPTER XXVI<br><small>THE TRIALS OF ABRAHAM</small> [31<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>O<small>UR</small> father Abraham was tried with ten trials,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees xvii. 17 and xix. 8. Parallels to our text are to be found in Aboth 5:3 (with a variant reading); Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxxiii. and (<i>b</i>) xxxvi.; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 68; Book of Jashar xii. ff.; Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 18 p. 77a; Midrash Agadah (Genesis), p. 26; and cf. Liturgy for the Second Day of the New Year, the Piyyuṭ: “Thy Word is pure”; and see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 75, and cf. Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 99 f.</i> || and he stood firm in them all.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions insert here the following: “and it was foreseen by him that in the future his children would tempt the Holy One, blessed be He, with ten trials, and He anticipated the cure for their wound,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and He tried him with ten trials.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> The first trial<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit.,</i> does not enumerate this nor the second trial. On the order of the trials, see Hoffmann, <i>Mishnajoth,</i> p. 352.</i> was when our father Abraham was born; all the magnates of the kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 49 f., and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.,</i> which reads as our MS.; and see the Book of Jashar (viii. 15 ff.), and Jeraḥmeel xxxiv. The first editions omit: “and the magicians.” Instead of “the kingdom” later editions read “Nimrod.” The magicians were led to persecute Abram by observing his star at his birth; see <i>infra,</i> pp. 377 f.; and cf. Beer, <i>Das Leben Abrahams,</i> pp. 98 f. The birth stories of Abraham, Moses (cf. Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> ii. 9. 2, and T.B. Soṭah, 12a), and Jesus have much in common except the “Virgin Birth,” which is peculiar to the narrative concerning the birth of the founder of Christianity.</i> and the magicians sought to kill him, and he was hidden under the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “in a house of the earth,” <i>i.e.</i> a cave. Cf. Isa. 41:2 and the Book of Jashar viii. 35.</i> for thirteen years without seeing sun or moon. After thirteen years<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrashim differ on this point; see Gen. Rab. 38:12, xcv. 3; Cant. Rab. on Cant. 2:5. See the Book of Jashar ix. 4; and R. Bechai on Gen., <i>in loc.</i> See also T.B. Nedarim, 32a; Est. Rab. 2:5; and generally for the legends of Abraham, see Ginzberg, <i>The Legends of the Jews,</i> i. pp. 185 ff., and Gorion’s <i>Die Sagen der Juden</i>, ii. pp. 26 ff. For further references see Beer, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 102 f. Our book relates that Abraham was in his fourteenth year when he abandoned idol worship. This agrees with Jubilees xi. 16, which also speaks of his learning writing. Our author varies this by referring to his knowledge of the Holy language. Jubilees xii. 25, 26, however, refers to Abraham’s ability to speak Hebrew.</i> he went forth from beneath the earth, speaking the holy language;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 42:8.</i> and he despised idols<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “groves.”</i> and held in abomination the graven images, and he trusted in the shadow of his Creator, and said:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “O Lord of Hosts.” This is part of the verse quoted. See the Gospel of Pseudo-Matthew vi. (<i>A.N.C.L.</i> xvi. p. 23) for a parallel Christian Midrash.</i> "Blessed is the man who trusts in thee" (Ps. 84:12).
The second trial was when he was put into prison for ten years—three years in Kuthi,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read Kutha, which is identified by the Talmud (B. Baba Bathra, 91a) with the Casdim; see also Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> i. 6. 5 and i. 7. 1.</i> seven years in Budri.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 77. The first editions read Ḳardi; for the variant spellings see Jastrow, <i>T.D.</i> 1412a. Probably our MS. should read Ḳudri. See also Hippolytus (ed. Achelis). p. 90.</i> After<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the first editions the reading is: “Some say three years in Ḳardi and seven years in Kutha.”</i> ten years they sent and brought him forth and cast him into the furnace of fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 52 ff., and cf. Pal. Targnm, Gen. 11:28. See also <i>infra,</i> p. 420.</i> and the King of Glory<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Pesachim, 118a, and Cant. Rab. on Cant. 1:1.</i> put forth His right hand<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 44:4.</i> and delivered him from the furnace of fire, as it is said, "And he said to him, I am the Lord who brought thee out of the furnace<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>אור</span> (Ur), “furnace.” Cf. Isa. 44:16 and Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 90 ff., and see Introduction, p. li.</i> of the Chaldees" (Gen. 15:7). Another verse (says), "Thou art the Lord the God, who didst choose Abram, and broughtest him forth out of the furnace of the Chaldees" (Neh. 9:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is omitted by the printed texts. It forms part of the morning liturgy; see Singer, p. 34.</i>
The third trial was his migration<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees xvii. 17. This trial is the first according to the Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 201.</i> from his father's house<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> From Ur of the Chaldees, his country. This agrees with Ibn Ezra’s interpretation of the text, Gen. 12:1.</i> and from the land of his birth; and He brought him to Haran,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the text should continue: “as it is said: ‘Get thee out of thy land and from thy birthplace’” (Gen. 12:1).</i> and there his father Terah died,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 1 p. 2b, note 22, and p. 3a, note 24.</i> and Athrai<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The 2nd ed. reads Amathlai; see T.B. Baba Bathra, 91a, and Beer, <i>op. cit.</i> pp. 96 f.</i> his mother.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Migration is harder for man than for any other creature.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Kethuboth, 28a, based on Isa. 22:17; see also T.B. Synhedrin, 26a, and Jalḳuṭ on Isa. § 280. Perhaps the last words of the sentence in our text should read: “than anything else.” The reading in the Midrash Haggadol, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> is: “which was the hardest of all” (the trials).</i> Whence do we know of his migration? Because it is said, "Now the Lord said || unto Abram, Get thee out" (Gen. 12:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions continue the quotation.</i>
The fourth trial (was the famine). From the day when the heavens and the earth were created, the Holy One, blessed be He, had not brought into the world a famine but only in the days of Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This does not agree with Gen. Rab. 25:3, according to which there were two famines prior to the days of Abraham.</i> and not in any of the lands but only in the land of Canaan,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashi, Gen. 12:10.</i> in order to try him and to bring him down into Egypt, as it is said, "And there was a famine in the land, and Abram went down into Egypt" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).
The fifth trial was when Sarah his wife was taken to Pharaoh to be (his) wife. And is there any man, who seeing his wife taken away to another man, would not rend his garments? But (he trusted in the Holy One, blessed be He,) that he would not approach her.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are missing in our MS.; they are based on Luria’s emendation. The first editions read: “But in accordance with her counsel he did not approach her.”</i> Whence do we know that Sarah was taken to Pharaoh to be his wife? Because it is said, "And the princes of Pharaoh saw her" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed texts omit the question and answer. The rest of the quotation reads: “And they praised her to Pharaoh: and the woman <i>was taken</i> into Pharaoh’s house.”</i>
Rabbi Joshua, son of Ḳorchah,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Rabbi Ṭarphon.” This agrees with the reading preserved in the Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 208 f.</i> said: In that night when our mother Sarah was taken, it was Passover night,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 153, for a similar expression in connection with the offering of Cain and Abel; cf. Ẓohar, Gen. 21b, 22a.</i> and the Holy One, blessed be He, brought upon Pharaoh and upon his house great plagues,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 68.</i> to make known<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “to make known to him.”</i> that thus in the future would He smite the people of his land,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the Egyptians with great plagues.”</i> as it is said, "And the Lord plagued Pharaoh and his house with great <i>plagues</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 17). Concerning the Egyptians it is written, "Yet one <i>plague</i> more will I bring upon Pharaoh, and upon Egypt" (Ex. 11:1). Was this a plague? Was it not (the slaying of) the first-born of the Egyptians? But the slaying is compared with the plagues, therefore it is said, "And the Lord <i>plagued</i> || Pharaoh" (Gen. 12:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This entire section from “Concerning” is omitted in the printed texts. On the subject-matter see Midrash Agadah (Gen.), p. 47.</i>
Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: Because of his love for her, (Pharaoh)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “Pharaoh” is missing in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i> wrote in her marriage document (giving her) all his wealth,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “his Mammon.” On this term see <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount,</i> p. 169.</i> whether in silver, or in gold, or in man-servants, or land,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.,</i> adds: “maid-servants.”</i> and he wrote (giving) her the land of Goshen for a possession. Therefore the children of Israel dwelt in the land of Goshen, in the land of their mother Sarah.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “which belonged to our mother Sarah.” Have we an apology on behalf of Jews, who in the days of our author were living in Egypt, claiming to be in their <i>own</i> land?</i> He (also) wrote (giving) her Hagar, his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 16:1, and Gen. Rab. 45:1., and the Book of the Bee, p. 42.</i> from a concubine, as her handmaid. And whence do we know that Hagar was the daughter of Pharaoh?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Hagar the Egyptian was an hand-maid?” See Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 208, and c. 241.</i> Because it is said, "Now Sarai Abram's wife bare him no children; and she had an handmaid, an Egyptian, whose name was Hagar" (<i>ibid.</i> xvi. 1). Pharaoh rose up early in the morning confused<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and agitated.”</i> because he had not approached her,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Sarah.” The various incidents are based on the story of Abimelech’s conduct in a similar instance.</i> and he sent and called Abraham, and said to him: Behold, Sarai thy wife is before thee, and all the deeds of her marriage contract are with her, take (her) and go, do not tarry in this land, as it is said, "Now therefore behold thy wife, take her, and go" (<i>ibid.</i> xii. 19).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And it is written after this (text).”</i> "And Pharaoh gave men charge concerning him,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here. See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i> The first editions add: “Whatever he gave to Sarah, Abimelech gave to Abram, as it is said, ‘And Abimelech took sheep and oxen, and menservants and womenservants’” (Gen. 20:14).</i> and they sent him forth" (<i>ibid.</i> 20). And he had Abraham led so as to come<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And he had Abram led (so as) to come in the land of Canaan as far as the land of the Philistines.”</i> to the land of Canaan. He sojourned in the land of the Philistines<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the reading of our text was originally thus: “Let us pass over the narrative of Abraham, from his entrance into Egypt till he came to the land of the Philistines; all this story will be narrated farther on in this book.” Our MS. preserves apparently a better reading.</i> in order to be refreshed there. And he went away. And everything is foreseen by the Holy One, blessed be He, and Abimelech<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria holds that the text should read: “As far as the land of the Philistines, and (here) Abimelech sent and took Sarah, thinking that he would be enabled to acquire children from her; but everything is revealed before the Holy One, blessed be He, Michael descended,” etc. Our MS. seems to have preserved the true text.</i> sent and took Sarah, thinking to raise up children from her, as it is said, "And Abimelech… sent, and took Sarah" (<i>ibid.</i> xx. 2).
And Abimelech became impotent, and all the women of his house became barren,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Ḳamma, 92a. The MS. adds: “and even Michael (came before) Abimelech.” The words are out of place, and are wanting in the Oxford MS.</i> even || to the smallest insect (which also became) barren, as it is said, "For the Lord had fast closed up all the wombs of the house of Abimelech" (<i>ibid.</i> 18). And the angel Michael descended and drew his sword against him.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “to slay him.” For the narrative see Pesiḳta Rabbathi, p. 176b; and cf. Liturgy for the Second Day of the New Year (ed. Heidenheim), p. 33a, where the ten trials are enumerated; and cf. T.B. Baba Ḳamma, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and <i>R.É.J.,</i> lxviii. p. 147.</i> Abimelech said to him:	Is this a true judgment and a true sentence to slay me as long as I had no knowledge?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to slay me for a matter which I did not know, as it is said.”</i> "Wilt thou slay even a righteous nation?" (<i>ibid.</i> 4).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Verily he said unto me: ‘She is my sister’” (Gen. 20:2).</i> He said unto him:<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Abimelech.</i> "Restore the man's wife, for he is a prophet" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “From thee one may learn, if a man come to a town, let people ask him concerning his requirements of food, but let them not inquire after his wife.” See T.B. Maccoth, 9b, and T.B. Baba Ḳamma, 92b.</i> "And he shall pray for thee, and thou shalt live" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Joshua, son of Ḳorchah, (rehearsed) before Rabbi Ṭarphon (saying): Whatever Pharaoh gave, he gave to Sarah; whatever Abimelech gave, he gave to Abraham; as it is said, "And Abimelech took sheep and oxen" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The text continues: “and gave them unto Abraham.” The entire sentence is wanting in the first editions. The section seems out of place here.</i> Abraham arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, and said before Him: Sovereign of all the worlds ! Thou hast created the whole world to increase and multiply, and let Abimelech and all the females of his household increase and multiply. The Holy One, blessed be He, was entreated of him, as it is said, "And Abraham prayed<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> unto God: and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maidservants;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “his household.” The legend of Abram in the furnace was known to Augustine, <i>de Civ. Dei,</i> xvi. 15. The incident with Sarah and Abimelech is discussed by Chrysostomus, <i>To Olympias,</i> iii. 3; Theodoret, <i>On Divine Providence,</i> x. Augustine, <i>de Civ. Dei,</i> xvi. 19, defends Abraham’s conduct and praises him in this connection.</i> and they bare children" (<i>ibid.</i> 17).

Chapter 27

CHAPTER XXVII<br><small>THE TRIALS OF ABRAHAM</small> (<i>continued</i>) [32<small>A</small>. i.]<br>T<small>HE</small> sixth trial<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 26, this incident is not enumerated among the ten trials of Abraham. A good deal of the material of this chapter is preserved in Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 214 ff.; especially cols. 217 and 218.</i> was (when) all the kings<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Amraphel and his allies mentioned in Gen. 14:1. Amraphel is identified with Nimrod in T.B. ‘Erubin, 53a. See Gen. Rab. 42:4.</i> came against him<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 68, which has used <i>P.R.E.</i></i> to slay him.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 95b.</i> They said: Let us first begin with the house<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “with the son of his brother.” The reference is to Lot.</i> of his brother, and afterwards let us begin with him.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Leḳach Ṭob and Agadath Bereshith on Gen. 14:11.</i> On account of Lot they took all (the wealth of)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. omits “the wealth of”; it occurs in the first editions; see also for similar text, Midrash Haggadol, Gen. c. 216.</i> Sodom and Gomorrah,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 42:7.</i> as it is said, "And they took all the goods of Sodom and Gomorrah" || (Gen. 14:11). Afterwards they took Lot captive, and all his wealth, as it is said, "And they took Lot… and<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “and all his goods”; the word “all” is not in the actual quotation.</i> his goods" (<i>ibid.</i> 12).
Michael came and told Abraham, as it is said, "And there came <i>one who had escaped</i>, and told Abram<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 182.</i> the Hebrew" (<i>ibid.</i> 13). He<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Michael. See Midrash Haggadol, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> which has a better text: “for he discloses all the secrets of the world.”</i> is the prince of the world, he was the one who told, as it is said, "Curse not the king, no, not in thy thought;… <i>he who hath wings</i> shall tell the matter" (Eccles. 10:20). Why was his name called "Paliṭ" ("One who had escaped")? Because in the hour when the Holy One, blessed be He, caused Sammael and his band to descend from heaven from their holy place,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> pp. 46, 92, 99.</i> he caught hold of <i>the wings</i> of Michael to make him fall<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “With him” is added by the ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, vi. p. 340b.</i> with himself, and the Holy One, blessed be He, saved<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>פלט</span>, hence <span>פליט</span> (Paliṭ).</i> him from his power;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “hand.” See Assumption of Moses x. 1, 2 for the final conflict between Michael and Satan. Cf. Jude 9.</i> therefore was his name called "The one who had escaped."<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Paliṭ. The title of Michael as P<small>ALIṬ</small> (<span>פליט</span>) may possibly be due to an abbreviated form of his other title of P<small>RAḲLIṬ</small> (<span>פרקליט</span>); see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 74.</i> Concerning him Ezekiel said, "One who had escaped<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 14:13.</i> out of Jerusalem came to me, saying, The city is smitten" (Ezek. 33:21).
Abraham rose up early in the morning, and he took his three disciples, Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre, with him, and Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “three disciples and Eliezer his servant.”</i> his servant with him (also), and he pursued after them as far as Dan, which is Pameas,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 6a, Bechoroth, 55a, and ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, vi. p. 369b; and cf. Targum to Cant. 5:4.</i> as it is said, "And he pursued as far as Dan" (Gen. 14:14). And there the righteous man<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Abraham.</i> was hindered, for there it was told him: Abraham, know thou that in the future<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 96a; and Pal. Targum, Gen. 14:14.</i> thy children's children will serve idols in this place; therefore was he hindered there. Whence do we know that Israel served idols there? Because it is said, "And he made two calves of gold… and he set the || one<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The calf of gold.</i> in Bethel, and the other put he in Dan" (1 Kings 12:28, 29). There he left his three disciples,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Nedarim, 32a; Gen. Rab. 43:2; Agadath Bereshith, 13; Agadath Bereshith, 13; and cf. Tanchuma, Lekh Lekha, § ix. The first editions add: “and their wives with them.”</i> and he took his servant Eliezer. The numerical value of the letters of his name equals 318.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> This Haggadah was known to Clement of Alexandria, whose book <i>The Miscellanies,</i> vi. 11, states: “As then in astronomy we have Abraham as an instance, so also in arithmetic we have the same Abraham. For, hearing that Lot was taken captive, and having numbered his own servants born in his house, 318, he defeats a very great number of the enemy.” See also the Epistle of Barnabas ix., where the “318” is interpreted as a Christian Midrash. See Siegfried, <i>Philo von Alexandria,</i> p. 330, and Güdemann, <i>Religionsgeschichtliche Studien,</i> pp. 119–121. Other Rabbinic parallels are Pal. Targum, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Pesiḳta Rabbathi, § xviii. p. 91b. The first editions add after 318: “He led forth his trained men, born in his house” (Gen. 14:14). There are also variations in the next quotation, according to our MS. and the first editions respectively.</i> He pursued them as far as the left of Damascus,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 14:15.</i> as it is said, "And he pursued them unto Hobah" (Gen. 14:15).
Samuel the Younger said: There the night was divided for him; (the night) when the children of Israel went forth out of Egypt,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “That is the night which was from of old, that is the night in which He smote the first-born of the Egyptians.” This night was destined from the beginning, prepared for the victories of Abraham and his seed, see Mekhilta, p. 13a; Gen. Rab. 43:3; and cf. <i>infra,</i> pp. 201, 402. The night itself was divided, one-half being spent in the days of Abraham in gaining victory, and the other half of the night was destined to be reserved for the victory of God over Egypt at the Exodus. See Wisdom xviii. 6.</i> that was the night in which Abraham smote the kings and their camps with them, as it is said, "And he divided himself against them by night, he and his servants" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And concerning this (night) it is said: ‘And it came to pass at midnight’” (Ex. 12:29). See Pal. Targum, Gen. 14:15.</i>
Hillel the Elder said: Abraham took all the wealth of Sodom and Gomorrah and all the wealth of Lot, the son of his brother, and he returned in peace,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on the Haggadic interpretation of Isa. 41:3. See Pal. Targum, Gen. 14:16, and cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 108b; Ẓohar, Gen. 26a, and Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and not even one of his men failed<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> For the word in the text see 2 Sam. 17:22. Luria interprets: “nothing of the wealth was missing.”</i> him, as it is said, "And he brought back <i>all</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. omits “all.”</i> the goods, and also his brother Lot" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “Abraham was afraid, and said: Perchance I have slain all these troops (or, multitude), and no righteous person can be found among them. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: ‘Fear not, Abram’ (Gen. 15:1). With reference to this it is said: ‘He pursueth them and passeth on safely, even by a way that he had not gone with his feet’ (Isa. 41:3). It has not come on thy foot to soil thee in this matter.” See Shocher Ṭob, p. 233 b.</i>
Rabbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “son of Ḳorchah.”</i> said: Abraham was the first to begin to give a tithe. He took all the tithe of the kings and all the tithe of the wealth of Lot, the son of his brother, and gave (it) to Shem,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> He was the chief priest then; see <i>supra,</i> pp. 53 f., and cf. <i>J.E.</i> xi. 261 f. As we have seen, <i>P.R.E.</i> identifies Shem with Melchizedek; see Jubilees xiii. 25, especially Charles’ note on pp. 100 f.</i> the son of Noah, as it is said, "And he gave him a tenth of all" (<i>ibid.</i> 20).
Shem, the son of Noah, came forth to meet him,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> With bread and wine; see Gen. 14:18.</i> and when he saw all the deeds which he had done and all the wealth which he had brought back, || he wondered in his heart. He began to praise, to glorify, and to laud the name of the Most High, saying: "And blessed be God the Most High, who hath delivered thine enemies into thy hand" (<i>ibid.</i>). Abraham arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all worlds ! Not by the power of my hand, nor by the power of my right hand have I done all these things, but by the power of Thy right hand with which Thou dost shield me in this world and in the world to come, as it is said, "But thou, O Lord, art a shield about me" (Ps. 3:3) in this world; "my glory, and the lifter up of mine head" (<i>ibid.</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “‘But thou, O Lord, art a shield about me; my glory, and the lifter up of mine head’ (Ps. 3:3) in the world to come.”</i> in the world to come.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See next chapter. According to the Midrash, Ps. 110 refers to Abraham; see Shocher Ṭob, pp. 233a, b.</i> The angels answered and said: Blessed art Thou, O Lord, the shield of Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Singer, p. 44. These angelic words form the end of the first benediction of the Shemoneh ‘Esreh. Other chapters of <i>P.R.E.</i> terminate with the last words of other benedictions of this Prayer. This fact is not mentioned in the annotated edition of Singer’s Prayer Book. From this aspect our book forms a Midrash on the Shemoneh ‘Esreh. See Roḳeach, 322, and Gen. Rab. 44:4. See also Sirach (li. x.*) in <i>A. and P.</i> i. p. 515. The last chapter of our book probably ended with the words printed in the “contents of the chapters” in the Venice edition (1544) and in later editions thus: “Blessed art Thou, O Lord, who healest the sick of Thy people Israel.” This is the eighth benediction of the Shemoneh ‘Esreh. See Singer, p. 47.</i>

Chapter 28

CHAPTER XXVIII<br><small>THE TRIALS OF ABRAHAM</small> (<i>continued</i>)<br>T<small>HE</small> seventh trial (was as follows): "After these things the word of the Lord came unto Abram in a vision, saying" (Gen. 15:1). To all the prophets He was revealed in a vision,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “he appeared in a vision of the night.” Instead of reading “of the night,” Luria holds that the reading should be, “or in a revelation.” This passage was possibly the authority used by Maimonides in dealing with the subject of prophecy; see his Hilkhoth Jesodê Ha-Torah vi. 2 and 6. For Luria’s suggested reading see Lev. Rab. 1:4. On “vision and revelation” see Gen. Rab. 44:6.</i> but to Abraham He was revealed<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “but to Abraham in a vision and in a revelation. Whence do we know of the vision? Because it is said: ‘In a vision saying, Fear not, Abram, I am thy shield’ (Gen. 15:1) in this world; ‘thy exceeding great reward’ (<i>ibid</i>.) in the world to come.” See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.,</i> and Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> in a revelation and in a vision. Whence do we know of the revelation? Because it is said, "And the Lord <i>appeared</i> unto him by the oaks of Mamre" (<i>ibid.</i> xviii. 1). Whence do we know of the vision? Because it is said, "After these things the word of the Lord came unto Abram in a <i>vision</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> xv. 1). He said to him: Abraham ! Do not fear, for My right hand is shielding thee in every place where thou goest;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 41:10, 13.</i> it is like a shield<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Aboth 4:15.</i> against misfortunes, and it gives thee a good reward, (even) to thee and to thy children, || in this world and in the world to come, as it is said, "Thy <i>exceeding great</i> reward" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrashim and Pal. Targum (Gen. 15:1) interpret the fear of Abraham as implying that his victory was his entire recompense for his life’s devotion to the cause of God. This would be covered by the word of the text, “Thy reward”; “exceeding great” would imply the reward in the future life.</i>
Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Jehudah the Prince. The first editions read: “Rabbi Jehudah.”</i> said: The Holy One, blessed be He, brought Abraham outside (his house) on the night of Passover,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The attack of Amraphel was also on the Passover night; see Pal. Targum, Gen. 14:13, and cf. Passover Haggadah <i>Oẓ Rob Nissim</i> and the poem <i>Omez Geburathekha.</i> The chief references for these traditions are: Mekhilta, Bo, p. 5a; Pal. Targum on Ex. 12:42, translated in <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 164 f. See also Seder ‘Olam Rab. 5:1. p. 11 b. Is there perhaps a reference here to the triennial reading of the Law, this section in Genesis being read on Passover?</i> and He said to him: Abraham ! Hast thou the ability to count all the host of heaven? He said before Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! Is there then a limit to Thy troops<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Job 25:3; see T.B. Chagigah, 13b, and Siphrê, Numb. § 42.</i> (of angels)? He said to him: Likewise thy seed shall not be counted owing to their great number, as it is said, "And he said unto him, So shall thy seed be" (<i>ibid.</i> 5).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of this chapter is missing in Luria’s edition. It is to be found in the old editions, <i>e.g.</i> Venice, Prague, Amsterdam. There is no reason to dispute its authenticity. The Censor is probably responsible for Luria’s omission. His book was printed in Warsaw.</i>
Rabbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Aḳiba.”</i> said: The Holy One, blessed be He, showed to our father Abraham (at the covenant) between the pieces<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 15:9 ff. For a Christian Midrash on this theme see Methodius, <i>Banquet of the Ten Virgins,</i> v. 2.</i> the four kingdoms, their dominion and their downfall, as it is said, "And he said unto him, Take me an heifer of three years old, and a she-goat of three years old" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). "An heifer of three years old" (<i>ibid.</i>) refers to the kingdom of Edom,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Roman Empire is referred to under this designation. Some of the old editions read, “Seir.” “Edom” is the usual term for the Roman Empire. MS. Gaster adds: “This is the fourth Kingdom.”</i> which is like the heifer of a sheep. "And a she-goat of three years old" (<i>ibid.</i>) refers to the kingdom of Greece,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On the kingdoms, Greece and Rome, see 4 Ezra 5:3; Rev. xvii.; Lactantius, <i>Divine Institutes,</i> vii. 15. “In the Johannine Apocalypse,” says Bousset, <i>Antichrist,</i> E.T., p. 126, “the Roman Empire is plainly enough indicated as the last anti-Christian power.”</i> as it is said, "And the he-goat magnified himself exceedingly" (Dan. 8:8). "And a ram of three years old" (Gen. 15:9); this is the kingdom of Media and Persia, as it is said, "And the ram which thou sawest that had the two horns, they are the kings of Media and Persia" (Dan. 8:20).	"And a turtle-dove" (Gen. 15:9); this refers to the sons of Ishmael.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Mohammedan Empire. Is this an indication of the date of our book? It fixes a limit, in the sense that it must have been written after the rise of the Mohammedan Empire. We shall have ground for asserting that the beginning of the ninth century is probably the earliest date of the final redaction of our book.</i> This expression is not to be understood in the literal meaning of Tôr (turtle-dove), but in the Aramaic language, in which Tôr means <i>Ox</i>, for when the male ox is harnessed to the female, they will open and break all the valleys,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 76:6. The first editions read: “they will open and break the (clods of) all the valleys. For phraseology cf. Isa. 28:24: “to open and break the clods” of the ground. The next words about the fourth beast are not in the printed editions.</i> even as it says (about) "the fourth beast" (Dan. 7:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The entire passage in the first editions reads thus: “This (expression) Tôr (turtle dove) is not said here in the language of the Torah (<i>i.e.</i> Hebrew), but in the Aramaic language. Tôr is the ox, and when the male ox is harnessed to the female they will open and break (the ground of) all the valleys.”</i> "And a young pigeon" (Gen. 15:9); this refers to the Israelites, who are compared || to a young pigeon, as it is said, "O my dove, thou art in the clefts of the rock" (Cant. 2:14). For thy voice is pleasant in prayer, and thy appearance is beautiful in good deeds. "And a young pigeon" (Gen. 15:9); this refers to the Israelites, who are compared to a young pigeon: "My dove, my perfect (one), is (but) one" (Cant. 6:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) reads: “Another explanation. ‘A young pigeon’ refers to Israel, as it is said, ‘My <i>dove,</i> my perfect (one), is (but) one’” (Cant. 6:9).</i>
Rabbi Acha ben Jacob said: This expression, "three years old" (Gen. 15:9), is said only with reference to the mighty in power, as it is said, "And a threefold cord is not quickly broken" (Eccles. 4:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. (O.A. 167) reads: “Rabbi Acha ben Jacob said: What is the meaning of this expression, ‘three years old’? It refers to the mighty in power, (who are) like a threefold cord, as it is said,” etc. On R. Acha ben Jacob, see <i>J.E.</i> i. p. 278.</i>
Rabbi Mesharshyah<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> There were several teachers so named; <i>J.E.</i> viii. 502b gives one only.</i> said: (Three years old) refers to a threefold (dominion) which they would exercise three times in the future in the land of Israel. At the first time each one would rule by himself; at the second time two together (would rule); on the third occasion (all) altogether to fight against the house of David,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Messianic wars are referred to here. The first editions read: “to fight against the Son of David.”</i> as it is said, "The kings of the earth set themselves,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and the rulers take counsel together, against the Lord, and against his <i>anointed</i>" (Ps. 2:2).
Rabbi Joshua said: Abraham took his sword and divided them, each one into two parts, as it is said, "And he took him all these, and he divided them in the midst" (Gen. 15:10). Were it not for the fact that he divided them, the world would not have been able to exist, but because he divided them, he weakened their strength, and he brought each part against its corresponding part, as it is said, "And he laid each half over against the other" (<i>ibid.</i>). And the young pigeon he left alive, as it is said, "But the bird he divided not" (<i>ibid.</i>). Hence thou mayest learn that there was not any other bird there except a young pigeon.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Hence thou mayest learn that the word Zippôr in the Torah means only a young pigeon.”</i> The bird of prey came down upon them || to scatter them and to destroy them.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targ. Gen. 15:11 reads: “And there came down people who were like unto an unclean bird, to steal away the sacrifices of Israel; but the merit of Abram was a shield over them.”</i> "The bird of prey" is nought else but David, the son of Jesse,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “is nought else but the Son of David.” See Hastings’ <i>D.B.</i> iv. p. 610a, on “the speckled bird.” This passage, in its Messianic interpretation, has escaped the notice of Schöttgen.</i> who is compared to a "speckled bird of prey," as it is said, "<i>Is mine heritage</i> unto me as a speckled <i>bird of prey</i>?" (Jer. 12:9).
When the sun was about to rise in the east, Abraham sat down and waved his scarf over them, so that the bird of prey should not prevail over them until the raven came.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “until evening set in.” This seems a better reading. Cf. Jubilees xi. 11.</i>
Rabbi Elazar ben 'Azariah said: From this incident thou mayest learn that the rule of these four kingdoms will only last one day<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The one day of God is 1000 years, see <i>supra,</i> p. 128. Do the four kingdoms referred to by Daniel begin with the Greek persecutions under Antiochus Epiphanes, 168 <small>B.C.E.,</small> so that the end of these hostile kingdoms was to be expected about 1000 years later, <i>i.e.</i> about 832 <small>C.E.</small>? If so, this is another indication as to the date of our book. It would not be later than this date (832 <small>C.E.</small>). Accordingly, we may fix the date of its final redaction in the early years of the ninth century.</i> according to the day of the Holy One, blessed be He. Rabbi Elazar ben 'Arakh said unto him: Verily it is so, according to thy word, as it is said, "He hath made me desolate and faint <i>all the day</i>" (Lam. 1:13), except for two-thirds of an hour (of God). Know that it is so. Come and see, for when the sun turns to set in the west, (during) two hours<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “two-thirds of an hour.”</i> its power is weakened,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “remain over.” The Venice edition omits this and reads instead: “it is dark and it has no light.” The words “it is dark” is an error, and should be “its strength fails.”</i> and it has no light, likewise whilst the evening has not yet come, the light of Israel shall arise,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the Son of David will cause the light of Israel to arise.” Cf. the use of “Zemach” (Dayspring) as a Messianic title in <i>Hellenism and Christianity,</i> pp. 119 f.</i> as it is said, "And it shall come to pass, that at <i>evening time</i> there shall be <i>light</i>" (Zech. 14:7).
Abraham arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, that his children should not be enslaved by these four kingdoms. A deep sleep fell upon him, and he slept, as it is said, "A deep sleep fell upon Abram" (Gen. 15:12). Does then a man lie down and sleep, and yet be able to pray? But this teaches thee that Abraham was lying down and sleeping because of the intensity of his prayer that his children might enslave || these four kingdoms,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “that his children might escape these four kingdoms.” In the preceding words the first editions read: “and sleeping and he prayed” that his children, etc.</i> as it is said, "And, lo, an horror of great darkness fell upon him" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Pal. Targ., <i>in loc.,</i> for a different reading; see also Gen. Rab. 44:18; Ex. Rab. li. 7; Pesiḳta de R. Kahana, 42b.</i> "Horror" refers to the kingdom of Edom, as it is written, "And behold a fourth beast, <i>terrible</i> and powerful, and strong exceedingly" (Dan. 7:7). "Darkness" is the kingdom<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the kingdom of Greece.” See also Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 52:8, pp. 143b f.; and Lev. Rab. 13:5. The idea in our context has a parallel in Wisdom xviii. 4.</i> of those who <i>darken</i> the eyes of Israel (by preventing the observance of) all the precepts which are in the Torah. "Great" (Gen. 15:12) refers to the kingdom of Media and Persia, which was <i>great</i> (enough to be able to afford) to sell Israel for nought.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Esth. 3:11: “And the king said to Haman: The silver is given to thee, the people also, to do with them as it seemeth good to thee.”</i> "Fell" (<i>ibid.</i>) refers to the kingdom of Babylon, because in their hand <i>fell</i> the crown<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Temple of God at Jerusalem. In the printed editions the quotation from Isa. 21:9 is missing.</i> of Israel, as it is said, "Babylon is fallen, is fallen" (Isa. 21:9). "<i>Upon him</i>" (Gen. 15:12) refers to the Ishmaelites, <i>upon whom</i> the Son of David will flourish,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or it might mean “arise”; cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 201, note 3.</i> as it is said, "His enemies will I clothe with shame:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, “etc.” being added; in the first editions the verse is continued.</i> but <i>upon him</i> shall his crown flourish" (Ps. 132:18).
Rabbi Ẓe'era<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions read “‘Aẓariah.”</i> said: These kingdoms were created only as fuel for Gehinnom, as it is said, "Behold, a smoking furnace,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targ., <i>in loc.,</i> renders: “And lo, Abram saw Gehinnom bringing up flaming coals and burning flakes of fire, wherein the wicked are to be judged.” See Jer. Targum, <i>in loc.,</i> and cf. also Gen. Rab. 44:21; Apoc. Baruch iv. 4; and 4 Ezra 3:14 (ed. Box), p. 12, note a.</i> and a flaming torch that passed" (Gen. 15:17). Here the word "furnace"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “‘Furnace’ and ‘torch’ refer only to Gehinnom, as it is said,” etc. The readings preserved in the Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 77, and the Midrash Haggadol, c. 234, should be compared with our text. Beer’s <i>Leben Abraham’s</i> should also be consulted for further references to the Midrashic sources.</i> signifies only Gehinnom, which is compared to a furnace, as it is said, "Saith the Lord, whose <i>fire</i> is in Zion, and his <i>furnace</i> in Jerusalem" (Isa. 31:9).

Chapter 29

CHAPTER XXIX<br><small>THE TRIALS OF ABRAHAM</small> (<i>continued</i>)<br>T<small>HE</small> eighth trial (was as follows): "And when Abram was ninety-nine years old" (Gen. 17:1),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, ‘Walk before me, and be thou perfect’” (Gen. 17:1).</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Until now thou hast not been perfect before Me; but circumcise the flesh of thy foreskin, and "walk before me, and be thou perfect"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Agadah, Gen. 17:21, p. 36.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). Moreover, the foreskin is a reproach, as it is said, "For that is a reproach unto us" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 14), because the foreskin is more unclean than all unclean things, as it is said, "For henceforth there shall no more || come into thee the uncircumcised and the unclean" (Isa. 52:1). For the foreskin is a blemish above all blemishes. Circumcise the flesh of thy foreskin and be perfect.
Rabban Gamaliel said: Abraham sent and called for Shem,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On Abraham’s circumcision see Gen. Rab. 46:4 and xlvii. 8. Shem was born circumcised; see Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 80; <i>J.E.</i> xi. 261; Hippolytus (ed. Achelis), p. 91; and Jerome, Ep. cxxvi. quoted by Rahmer, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 72.</i> the son of Noah, and he circumcised the flesh of the foreskin of our father Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Agadath Bereshith, p. 35, and Tanchuma Vayêra, § ii.</i> and the flesh of the foreskin of Ishmael his son, as it is said, "In the selfsame day was Abraham circumcised, and Ishmael his son"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the rest of the verse, “And also all those born in his house,” etc., is missing in our text.</i> (Gen. 17:26). "In the selfsame day" (means) in the might of the sun at midday.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> And then it is at its zenith. See Gen. Rab. 47:9; Rashi on Gen., <i>in loc.</i>; and Leḳach Ṭob, <i>in loc.</i></i> Not only that, but (it indicates) the tenth day of the month,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Tishri, the 7th month.</i> the Day of Atonement. It is written in connection with the Day of Atonement, "Ye shall do no manner of work on that <i>selfsame day</i>, for it is a day of atonement" (Lev. 23:28); and in the present instance the text says, "In the <i>selfsame day</i> was Abraham circumcised" (Gen. 17:26). Know then that on the Day of Atonement Abraham our father was circumcised.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is mentioned by Tosaphoth to T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 11a, catchword “But.” The story is given by R. Bechai, Comm. on Gen., <i>in loc.,</i> with a different reading; see also Midrash Agadah, Gen. 17:21. According to T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 86b, the circumcision of Abraham took place on Passover. Jubilees xxxiv. 18 speaks of the institution of the Day of Atonement in connection with Joseph. Our author, in his opposition to Jubilees, connects the Day of Atonement with the life of Abraham. Such variant traditions are common to all histories; cf. Usener, “Weihnachsfest,” for the different dates observed by the Church to celebrate the birthday of the Founder of the Christian faith.</i> Every year the Holy One, blessed be He, sees the blood of our father Abraham's circumcision, and He forgives all the sins of Israel, as it is said, "<i>For on this</i> day<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the event that marked this day, namely, the circumcision of the Founder of the Hebrew religion. The circumcision of the Founder of the Christian Church is now observed annually on 1st January.</i> shall atonement be made for you, to cleanse you" (Lev. 16:30). In that place where Abraham was circumcised and his blood remained, there the altar was built,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Mount Moriah. Cf. the legends of Golgotha and Akeldama, see Jerome, Com. in Eph. v. 14.</i> and therefore, "And all the blood thereof shall he pour out at the base of the altar" (<i>ibid.</i> iv. 30). (It says also),<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The last two sentences of this paragraph are wanting in the Oxford MS.</i> "I said unto thee, In thy blood, live;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits here the second half of the verse; it occurs in the first editions.</i> yea, I said unto thee, In thy blood, live" (Ezek. 16:6).
Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa said: All who are circumcised have (excessive) pain on the third day, as it is said, "And it came to pass on the third day, when they were sore" (Gen. 34:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Accordingly the sages have taught.”</i> They may wash || the child on the third day,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> After birth. This is a Mishnah in T.B. Sabbath 19:3. 134b, and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 135.</i> when it happens to fall on the Sabbath, and all things necessary for a circumcision<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 132a.</i> are permitted to be done on the Sabbath.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 128b and 133a.</i>
Every uncircumcised (man) shall not eat (of the Paschal offering), and shall not touch the sanctuary. He who separates himself from circumcision is like one separated from the Holy One, blessed be He.
Rabban Gamaliel,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is Gamaliel 11., to be distinguished from his grandfather Gamaliel 1. mentioned previously.</i> the son of Rabbi Jehudah the Prince, said: When our father Abraham was circumcised, on the third day he was very sore,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The pain on the third day was made exceptionally severe in order to test Abraham. This was the eighth trial according to our Book.</i> in order to test him.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Agadath Bereshith, pp. 37 ff., and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 82, which reads: “What did He do to try him? He pierced an aperture in Gehinnom.”</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He pierced one hole in the midst of Gehinnom, and He made the day hot, like the day of the wicked.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 86b, and see <i>infra,</i> p. 416, and cf. ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, v. 390, <i>s.v.</i> <span>נרתק</span>, and <i>ibid.</i> p. 20, <i>s.v.</i> <span>להט</span>. There is no eternal Gehenna in the future life, only a day of heat; see T.B. Nedarim, 8b.</i> He<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Abraham.</i> went forth, and sat down at the entrance of the tent in the cool of the day, as it is said, "And he sat at the tent door (in the heat of the day)" (<i>ibid.</i> xviii. 1). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to the ministering angels: Come ye, let us descend and visit the sick, for the virtue of visiting the sick is great before Me.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra,</i> pp. 89, 107.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, and the angels descended to visit our father Abraham, as it is said, "And the Lord appeared unto him" (<i>ibid.</i>). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to the ministering angels: Come ye and see ye<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This expression is a characteristic of our author.</i> the power of circumcision.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On Circumcision see <i>J.E.</i> iv. 92 ff., and on “’Orlah” see <i>ibid.</i> ix. 435.</i> Before Abraham was circumcised he fell<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Pal. Targum, Gen. 17:17, reads: “And because Abraham was not circumcised he was not able to stand, but he bowed himself upon his face.” Balaam also fell down when receiving the Divine oracles.</i> on his face (before Me), and afterwards I spake with him, as it is said, "And Abraham fell upon his face" (<i>ibid.</i> xvii. 17). Now that he is circumcised he sits and I stand. Whence do we know that the Holy One, blessed be He, was standing? Because it is said, "And he looked, and, lo, three men <i>stood</i> over against him" (<i>ibid.</i> xviii. 2).
Rabbi Ẓe'era || said: There are five<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 46:5. The tractate of ‘Orlah in the Mishnah, Tosephta, and Jerushalmi deals with the “uncircumcision” of trees based on Lev. 19:23–25.</i> kinds of 'Orlah (things uncircumcised) in the world: four with reference to man, and one concerning trees. Whence do we know this concerning the four (terms) applying to man? (Namely,) the uncircumcision of the ear, the uncircumcision of the lips, the uncircumcision of the heart, and the uncircumcision of the flesh. Whence do we know of the uncircumcision of the ear? Because it is said, "Behold, their ear is uncircumcised" (Jer. 6:10). Whence do we know of the uncircumcision of the lips? Because it is said, "For I am of uncircumcised lips" (Ex. 6:12). Whence do we know of the uncircumcision of the heart? Because it is said, "Circumcise the foreskin of your heart" (Deut. 10:16); and (the text) says, "For all the nations are uncircumcised, and all the house of Israel are uncircumcised in heart" (Jer. 9:26). Whence do we know of the uncircumcision of the flesh? Because it is said, "And the uncircumcised male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin" (Gen. 17:14). And "all the nations are uncircumcised" in all the four cases, and "all the house of Israel are uncircumcised in heart." The uncircumcision of the heart does not suffer Israel to do the will of their Creator. And in the future the Holy One, blessed be He, will take away from Israel the uncircumcision of the heart, and they will not harden their stubborn (heart) any more before their Creator, as it is said, "And I will take away the stony heart<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions it is continued as in our version. The MS. adds “etc.”</i> out of your flesh, and I will give you an heart of flesh" (Ezek. 36:26); and it is said, "And ye shall be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And ye shall circumcise the foreskin of your flesh,” which is not an actual quotation, but a combination of Gen. 17:11 and Deut. 10:16. The MS. originally read: “the foreskin of your heart,” which has been deleted.</i> (Gen. 17:11). Whence do we know concerning the one ('Orlah) for trees?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In addition to the Mishnah and Tosephta on “’Orlah” see Maimonides, Ma’akhaloth ’Asuroth, x. 9 ff. According to T.B. Ḳiddushin, 37a, the law of ‘Orlah is limited to Palestine.</i> Because it is said, "And when ye shall come into the land, and shall have planted all manner of trees for food, then ye shall count the fruit thereof as their uncircumcision:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> three years shall they be as uncircumcised unto you" (Lev. 19:23).
Rabbi Ẓe'era<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Ẓeriḳa.” On “Ẓe’era” see <i>J.E.</i> xii. 651 f., and on “Ẓeriḳa” see <i>ibid.</i> 662.</i> taught: The tree || which is mentioned here is none other than the vine tree.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Joreh Di’ah, 294. For a similar law see Jubilees vii. 1 and 35–38. <i>All</i> trees bearing fruit fit to be eaten were subject to this law; cf. Ezek. 17:5 ff. It is very remarkable that our author restricts the law of ‘Orlah to the vine, which the Rabbis included among the fruit-bearing trees; see Siphra, 90a.</i> If they do not cut off from the tree the fruit of the first three years, all the fruit which it yields will be gleanings fit to be pluckt off, and not good; and its wine will be disqualified for the altar; but if they cut off from the tree the fruit of the first three years, all the fruit which it yields will be good for the sight, and their wine will be selected to be brought upon the altar. So with our father Abraham; before he was circumcised, the fruit which he produced was not good [in its effects,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> With reference to Ishmael. See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 81.</i> and was disqualified from the altar; but when he had been circumcised, the fruit which he produced was good in its effects,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> With reference to Isaac.</i> and his wine]<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This portion in square brackets is missing in the MS., but undoubtedly it must be supplied; it occurs in the first editions.</i> was chosen to be put upon the altar like wine for a libation, as it is said, "And wine for the drink offering" (Num. 15:5).
Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Rabbi Ishmael.” This section occurs in a later part of the chapter in the printed texts.</i> said: Abraham did not delay aught<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Pesachim, 4a.</i> with reference to all (things) which He commanded him, as it is said, "And he that is eight days old shall be circumcised" (Gen. 17:12); and when Isaac was born, (and when) he was eight days old (Abraham) brought him to be circumcised, as it is said, "And Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old" (<i>ibid.</i> xxi. 4). Hence thou mayest learn that everyone who brings his son for circumcision is as though (he were) a high priest bringing his meal offering and his drink offering upon the top of the altar.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is not in the printed texts. The first editions read: “And he brought him (as) a meal offering upon the top of the altar, and he made festivities and a banquet.” See Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 112 p. 234b. This Midrash has used our book. Some of the printed texts read: “he presented him like an offering” (by circumcision). See Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Tania Rabbathi, 96 (ed. Warsaw), p. 101b.</i> Hence the sages said: A man is bound to make festivities and a banquet on that day when he has the merit of having his son<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tosaphoth on Sabbath, 130a; Joreh Di’ah, 265.</i> circumcised, like Abraham our father, who circumcised his son, as it is said, "And Abraham circumcised || his son Isaac"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions do not use this quotation, but “And Abraham made a great feast on the day that Isaac was weaned” (Gen. 21:8). This was not the day of circumcision. But just as Abraham made a feast at the weaning of his son, it was inferred that he had also made a feast at the circumcision.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Jochanan said: All heathens who come to Israel are circumcised by their own freewill and with their consent, and in the fear of Heaven are they circumcised. We do not believe a proselyte until seven generations (have passed), so that the waters should not return to their source.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> To test whether they might revert to their former idolatry. Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 94a, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 257.</i> But slaves are circumcised both by their freewill and with their consent as well as without their consent, and no confidence is placed in slaves. Likewise with all the slaves who were circumcised with our father Abraham, they did not remain true (converts) in Israel, neither they nor their seed, because it is said, "All the men of his house, those born in the house,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and those bought with money of the stranger, were circumcised with him" (<i>ibid.</i> xvii. 27). Why did he circumcise them? Because of purity, so that they should not defile their masters with their food and with their drink, for whosoever eateth with an uncircumcised person is as though he were eating flesh of abomination.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “as though he were eating with a dog. Just as the dog is not circumcised so the uncircumcised person is not circumcised.” For parallel N.T. teaching see Phil, iii. 2 and Eph. ii. 11.</i> All who bathe with the uncircumcised are as though they bathed with carrion,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a leper.” See Maimonides, <i>On Idolatry,</i> vii. 18.</i> and all who touch an uncircumcised person are as though they touched the dead, for in their lifetime they are like (the) dead;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Matt. viii. 22, where the Jews are referred to as “the dead.” The heathens or Gentiles were, according to the N.T., believed to be under the control of Satan (see 2 Cor. vi. 15–18; and cf. 1 Cor. x. 19 and xii. 2) and therefore children of death (see Heb. ii. 14 f.), whereas the believers or Christians are the only ones who really live (cf. Rom. v. 12–21, <i>ibid.</i> i. 16–32, <i>ibid.</i> vi. 13, and <i>ibid.</i> viii. 6–10). The Ephesians, formerly “Gentiles in the flesh who are called Uncircumcision” (Eph. ii. 11), are addressed thus: “You who were <i>dead</i> in trespass and sins” (<i>ibid.</i> 1).</i> and in their death they are like the carrion of the beast,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “of the field.” A parallel to the teaching of this section is to be found in the doctrine so strongly emphasized by Paul that the Christians should not partake of “the things which the Gentiles sacrifice” (1 Cor. x. 20). Jesus also said, “Give not that which is holy unto the <i>dogs,</i> neither cast your pearls before the swine, lest haply they trample them under their feet, and turn and rend you” (Matt. vii. 6). On “Dog” as applied to non-Christians in the New Testament and Christian literature, see <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount,</i> pp. 219 ff. See also Jubilees xv. 26. The Church Councils prohibited Christians eating with the Jews, see <i>Apostolic Constitutions,</i> ii. 62 and viii. 47.</i> and their prayer does not come before the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "The dead praise not the Lord" (Ps. 115:17). But Israel who are circumcised, their prayer comes before the Holy One, blessed be He, || like a sweet savour, as it is said, "But <i>we will bless</i> the Lord<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS., it is continued in the first editions.</i> from this time forth and for evermore. Praise ye the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> 18).
Rabbi said: Isaac circumcised Jacob, and Esau;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees xv. 30 says of Esau: “the Lord did not cause him to approach him.” See Jalḳuṭ. Gen. § 116.</i> and Esau despised the covenant of circumcision just as he despised the birthright, as it is said, "So Esau despised his birthright" (Gen. 25:34). Jacob clung to the covenant of circumcision, and circumcised his sons and his grandsons. Whence (do we know) that the sons of Jacob were circumcised? Because it is said, "Only on this condition will the men consent unto us to dwell<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS the quotation ends here.</i> with us… if every male among us be circumcised, as they are circumcised." (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 22). Another text says, "Only on this condition will we consent unto you: if ye will be as we be" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is not in the printed texts. The verse continues: “that every male of you be circumcised.”</i> Hence thou canst learn that the sons of Jacob were circumcised. The sons of Jacob circumcised their sons and their grandsons. They gave it to them as an inheritance for an everlasting statute, until Pharaoh the Wicked arose<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Eccles. Rab. on Eccles. 9:12; Ruth Rab. Proem. 6. According to Num. Rab. 15:12, only the tribe of Levi kept the rite of circumcision in Egypt; the other tribes refused to obey in this matter. See Ex. Rab. i. 20, and xix. 5; Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 23 p. 123; and Siphrê, Num. § 67.</i> and decreed harsh laws concerning them, and withheld from them the covenant of circumcision. And on the day when the children of Israel went forth from Egypt all the people were circumcised, both young and old, as it is said, "For all the people that came out were circumcised" (Josh. 5:5).
The Israelites took the blood of the covenant of circumcision,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and the blood of the Paschal lamb.” See Pal. Targum on Ex. 12:13, which reads, “And the blood of the Paschal offering and the rite of circumcision shall be a guarantee to you, to become a sign upon the houses where ye dwell”; see also Mekhilta (on Ex. 12:6) p. 5a, Ẓohar, Lev. 95a, and Num. Rab. 14:12.</i> and they put (it)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “them,” <i>i.e.</i> the blood of the circumcision as well as the blood of the Paschal lamb.</i> upon the lintel of their houses, and when the Holy One, blessed be He, passed over to plague the Egyptians, He saw the blood of the covenant of circumcision upon the lintel of their houses and the blood of the Paschal lamb, He was filled || with compassion<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The root “Pasach” (<span>פםח</span>) means to spare, hence to be compassionate.</i> on Israel, as it is said, "And when I passed by thee, and saw thee weltering in thy (twofold) blood,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> I said unto thee, In thy (twofold) blood, live; yea, I said unto thee, In thy (twofold) blood, live" (Ezek. 16:6). "In thy blood" is not written here, but in "thy (twofold) blood," with twofold blood, the blood of the covenant of circumcision and the blood of the Paschal lamb; therefore it is said, "I said unto thee, In thy (twofold) blood, live; yea, I said unto thee, In thy (twofold) blood, live" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Eliezer said: Why<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “For what purpose did the text see to say.”</i> did the text say twice, "I said unto thee, In thy blood, live; yea, I said unto thee, In thy blood, live"? But the Holy One, blessed be He, said: By the merit of the blood of the covenant of circumcision and the blood of the Paschal lamb ye shall be redeemed from Egypt, and by the merit of the covenant of circumcision and by the merit of the covenant of the Passover in the future ye shall be redeemed at the end of the fourth kingdom;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> At the Messianic redemption.</i> therefore it is said, "I said unto thee, In thy blood, live; yea, I said unto thee, In thy blood, live" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum on Ezek. 16:6; and cf. <i>infra,</i> pp. 383 ff.</i>
There are three afflictions,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Nedarim, 31b, 32a; T.B. Giṭṭin, 70a; Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 31 p. 121a; Lam. Rab. 1:50; T.B. Jebamoth, 71b, on the danger of circumcision when one travels.</i> (namely,) the affliction of the fast, the affliction of the prison, and the affliction of the road.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, journey.</i> Whence do we know of the affliction of the fast? (Because it is said,)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is omitted by the MS., but it occurs in the first editions.</i> "I <i>afflicted</i> my soul with <i>fasting</i>" (Ps. 35:13). Whence do we know of the affliction of the prison? (Because it is said,)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is omitted by the MS., but it occurs in the first editions.</i> "They <i>hurt</i> his feet with <i>fetters</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> cv. 18). Whence do we know of the affliction of the road? (Because it is said,)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is omitted by the MS., but it occurs in the first editions.</i> "He weakened my strength <i>in the way</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> cii. 23). On account of the affliction of the road, (the children of Israel)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is omitted by the MS., but it occurs in the first editions.</i> did not circumcise, and when they went forth from Egypt all the people were circumcised, both young and old, as it is said, "For all the people that came out were circumcised" || (Josh. 5:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions quote Josh. 5:7.</i>
Rabbi Ishmael said: Did the uncircumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Israelites.</i> hear the voice of the Holy One, blessed be He, on Mount Sinai, saying, "I am the Lord thy God" (Ex. 20:2)?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. Rab. 11:3, Cant. Rab. 1:12, and Shocher Ṭob, Pss. p. 39a; and cf. T.B. Jebamoth, 72a. The first editions add: “And did He give them the Torah? But, Heaven forbid! They were circumcised, but they did not have the corona uncovered.”</i> They were circumcised, but not according to its regulation.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to (<span>פריעה</span>) “P’ri’ah” (having the corona uncovered).</i> They had cut off the foreskin, but they had not uncovered the corona. Everyone who has been circumcised, but has not had the corona uncovered, is as though he had not been circumcised, therefore the text says, "Israel was not circumcised of old."<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This is not a Biblical quotation. Should Josh. 5:5 be quoted?</i>
When they came to the land (of Canaan),<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “When the Israelites came to the land of Israel.”</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Joshua: Joshua ! Dost thou not know that the Israelites are not circumcised according to the proper regulation? He again circumcised them a second time, as it is said, "The Lord said unto Joshua, Make thee knives of flint,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions the latter part of the verse only is given.</i> and circumcise again the children of Israel a second time" (Josh. 5:2). "And Joshua made him knives of flint" (<i>ibid.</i> 3), and he gathered all the foreskins until he made them (as high) as a hill, as it is said, "And he circumcised the children of Israel at the <i>hill</i> of the foreskins" (<i>ibid.</i>). The Israelites took the foreskin and the blood<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The law of the covering of the blood is ascribed by Jubilees vii. 30 to Noah, who tells his sons: “and work ye a good work to your souls by covering that which has been shed on the face of the earth”; see also <i>ibid.</i> 31, 33.
