In opposition to Jubilees, our author transfers the precept to Abraham.</i> and covered them with the dust<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Babylonian Jews appear to have used water to cover the blood at the circumcision, whereas the Palestinian Jews used earth to cover the blood and the foreskin after the circumcision. See Sha‘arê Zedeḳ v. 10; Ṭur Joreh Di‘ah, 265; Ẓohar, Gen. 95a. Cf. Menorath Ha-Maor § lxxx.</i> of the wilderness. When Balaam<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds here: “the magician.” See Jalḳuṭ. Gen. §71.</i> came, he saw all the wilderness filled with the foreskins of the Israelites, he said: Who will be able to arise by the merit of the blood of the covenant of this circumcision, which is covered by the dust? as it is said, "Who can count the dust of Jacob?" (Num. 23:10).
Hence || the sages instituted that they should cover the foreskin and the blood with the dust of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See previous note 3; and see Chiluf Minhagim, ed. Müller, pp. 18 f., and see also the Haggadic Commentary Sekhel Ṭob i. p. 19.</i> because they<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Israelites.</i> are compared to the dust of the earth, as it is said, "And thy seed shall be as the dust of the earth" (Gen. 28:14). Thus the Israelites were wont to circumcise until they were divided into two kingdoms. The kingdom of Ephraim cast off from themselves the covenant of circumcision.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees xv. 33 refers to the neglect of circumcision by the children of Israel.</i> Elijah, may he be remembered for good, arose and was zealous with a mighty passion, and he adjured the heavens to send down neither dew nor rain upon the earth. Jezebel heard (thereof), and sought to slay him. Elijah arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He.
The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: "Art thou better than thy fathers?"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 1 Kings 19:4.</i> Esau sought to slay Jacob, but he fled before him,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and he was saved.”</i> as it is said, "And Jacob fled into the field of Aram"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 168, and Menorath Ha-Maor § lxxx. Eventually Jacob escaped from Laban, as well as from Esau. The first editions read: “Esau attempted to slay Jacob, as it is said, ‘The days of mourning for my father are at hand; then will I slay my brother Jacob’” (Gen. 27:41).</i> (Hos. 12:12). Pharaoh sought to slay Moses, who fled before him and he was saved, as it is said, "Now when Pharaoh heard this thing,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; the first editions quote the latter part of the verse.</i> he sought to slay Moses. And Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh" (Ex. 2:15). Saul sought to slay David, who fled before him and was saved, as it is said, "If thou save not thy life to-night, to-morrow thou shalt be slain" (1 Sam. 19:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote (1 Sam. 19:11) only.</i> Another text says, "And David fled and escaped" (<i>ibid.</i> 18). Learn that everyone, who flees, is saved. Elijah, may he be remembered for good, arose and fled from the land of Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> To Horeb, which was outside Palestine.</i> || and he betook himself to Mount Horeb, as it is said, "And he arose, and did eat and drink" (1 Kings 19:8). There the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed unto him, and He said to him: "What doest thou here, Elijah?" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). He answered Him, saying: "I have been very zealous" (<i>ibid.</i> 10). (The Holy One, blessed be)<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This is missing in the MS., but it occurs in the first editions.</i> He, said to him: Thou art always zealous !<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Cant. Rab. 1:6; Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa (viii.), p. 187; Jalḳuṭ to 1 Kings § 217; Agadath Shir Ha-Shirim, p. 45, quoted by Schechter in his <i>Aspects of Rabbinic Theology,</i> p. 205; see also <i>ibid.,</i> p. 52, on Elijah’s zeal.</i> Thou wast zealous in Shittim<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 370, and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 71.</i> on account of the immorality. Because it is said, "Phineas,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Phineas is identified with Elijah. Just as we find in the New Testament that John the Baptist was held to be Elijah, see Matt. xi. 14. According to some Jewish authorities Elijah was a priest, see Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 18 pp. 97 f. This legend occurs also in the Book of the Bee (ed. Budge), p. 70.</i> the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> turned my wrath away from the children of Israel, in that he was zealous with my zeal among them" (Num. 25:11). Here also art thou zealous. By thy life ! They<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.,</i> read “Israel.”</i> shall not observe the covenant of circumcision until thou seest it (done) with thine eyes.
Hence the sages<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Sec Ṭur, Joreh Di’ah, 265; Tania Rabbathi, 96, p. 101a, and Halakhoth Gedoloth quoted by Schorr in <span>החלוץ</span>, v. 38.<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> instituted (the custom) that people should have a seat of honour for the Messenger of the Covenant; for Elijah, may he be remembered for good, is called the Messenger of the Covenant, as it is said, "And the messenger of the covenant, whom ye delight in, behold, he cometh" (Mal. 3:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The chair for Elijah is to this day a feature at every circumcision. The MS. Gaster and the first editions add: “O God of Israel! Hasten and bring the Messiah in our lifetime to comfort us, and may he restore<sup></sup> our hearts, as it is said: ‘And he shall restore<sup></sup> the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to the fathers’” (Mal. iv. 6).<sup></sup> According to this reading the chapter closes with a rhyme. Luria argues that as the verse quoted from Malachi speaks of Elijah, the reading might originally have been “Elijah” in place of the word “Messiah,” or perhaps both words were in the context. See <i>infra,</i> p. 344. The Oxford MS. reads the entire verse Mal. 3:1.</i>

Chapter 30

CHAPTER XXX<br><small>THE TRIALS OF ABRAHAM</small> (<i>continued</i>)<br>T<small>HE</small> ninth trial (was as follows): Ishmael was born with (the prophecy of the) bow,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the version should be, “Ishmael was born under (the constellation) Sagittarius.” The word “Ḳêshêth” sometimes means this constellation, or it might indicate “harshness.”</i> and he grew up with the bow,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 94 reads: “Ishmael was born and grew up with the bow.” Cf. Isa. 21:15.</i> as it is said, "And God was with the lad, and he grew …<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; the first editions quote the latter part of the verse only.</i> and he became an archer" (Gen. 21:20). He took bow and arrows and began to shoot at the birds.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tosephta Soṭah vi. p. 308; Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Gen. Rab. 53:15. The MS. reads “Pugoth.” This agrees with the Oxford MS. “Puga” is identified with “Suga,” the name of a bird. See T.B. Baba Bathra, 90b.</i> He saw Isaac sitting by himself, and he shot an arrow<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. O.A. 167 reads: “the arrows.” See Gen. Rab. 53:11.</i> at him to slay him.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 47, note 20, for other parallels.</i> Sarah saw (this), and told Abraham. She said to him: Thus and thus has Ishmael done to Isaac, but (now) arise and write (a will in favour) of Isaac, (giving him) all that the Holy One has sworn to give || to thee and to thy seed.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. 15:5 and xvii. 7. The first editions add: “By thy life.” Luria would read: “In thy life time” and connects it with the preceding sentence: “Write in thy life time.”</i> The son of this handmaid shall not inherit with my son, with Isaac, as it is said, "And she said unto Abraham, Cast out this bondwoman and her son" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).
Ben Tema<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This is missing in the printed editions and in Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc</i>. <i>cit.,</i> but it occurs in MS. O.A. 167. Ben Tema was an Amora.</i> said: Sarah said to Abraham, Write<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. O.A. 167 reads: “Arise and write,”</i> a bill of divorce,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 21:10.</i> and send away this handmaid and her son from me and from Isaac my son, in this world and from the world to come. More than all the misfortunes which overtook Abraham, this matter was exceedingly evil in his eyes, as it is said, "And the thing was very grievous in Abraham's sight on account of his son" (<i>ibid.</i> 11).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Pal. Targum, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> explains that this was due to the evil deeds of Ishmael in the future. The inference in our Midrash is derived from the quotation, and it was only in this instance that Scripture refers to the sorrow of Abraham. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 308.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. O.A. 167 adds: “the Prince.”</i> said: In that night the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed unto him. He said to him: Abraham ! Dost thou not know that Sarah was appointed to thee for a wife<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “from her birth.”</i> from her mother's womb? She is thy companion, and the wife of thy covenant;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the first wife. See Mal. 2:14; and Targum, <i>in loc.,</i> and cf. Rashi on Mal. 2:14.</i> Sarah is not called thy handmaid, but thy wife;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. O.A. 167 adds: “as it is said: ‘And God said, But Sarah thy wife’” (Gen. 17:19). This verse is also given by the first editions.</i> neither is Hagar called thy wife, but thy handmaid; and all that Sarah has spoken<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. O.A. 167 adds: “to thee.”</i> she has uttered truthfully. Let it not be grievous in thine eyes, as it is said, "And God said unto Abraham, Let it not be grievous in thy sight" (<i>ibid.</i> 12).
Abraham rose up early,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. O.A. 167 adds: “in the morning.” See Midrash Haggadol, c. 309.</i> and wrote a bill of divorce, and gave it to Hagar, and he sent her and her son away from himself, and from Isaac his son, from this world and from the world to come, as it is said, "And Abraham rose up early in the morning, and took<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, but “etc.” is added. The first editions and MS. O.A. 167 continue the verse. Luria adds: “And the child.”</i> bread and a bottle of water" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). He sent her away || with a bill of divorcement, and he took the veil,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 95, according to Jastrow, <i>T.D.</i> 1452b, for a variant reading. Cf. Gen. Rab. 53:13. The Venice edition reads “water-barrel”; cf. Siphrê, Num. § 115, and Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 750, which reads “water-barrel.” Our MS. agrees with the text in the 1st ed.</i> and he bound it around her waist, so that it should drag behind her to disclose (the fact) that she was a bondwoman.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 87a.</i> Not only this, but also because Abraham desired to see Ishmael, his son, and to see the way whereon they went.
By the merit of our father Abraham the water did not fail in the bottle, but when she reached the entrance to the wilderness, she began to go astray after the idolatry of her father's house;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the house of Pharaoh her father”; according to Rabbinic legend Hagar was the daughter of Pharaoh. See <i>supra,</i> p. 190, Gen. Rab. 45:2, and the Book of Jashar xv. 31.</i> and forthwith the water in the bottle was spent, as it is said, "And she departed and wandered" (<i>ibid.</i>), Ishmael was seventeen<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition gives twenty-seven years for Ishmael’s age.</i> years old (when) he went forth from the house of Abraham, and Isaac was forty<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “ten years.” The “forty years” may refer to Isaac’s age when he married Rebecca and left his father’s house to dwell in Sarah’s tent. It seems very probable that the MS. reading is based on a copy which read “four” years. This was altered by the writer of our MS. into “forty.” Ishmael was thirteen years older than Isaac, and as the former was seventeen years old when he left Abraham’s house Isaac must have been four years old. See <i>infra,</i> p. 225. See Gen. Rab. 53:13, according to which Ishmael was twenty-seven years old; see also the Book of Jashar xxi. 14, Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> years old. By the merit of our father Abraham the water did not fail in the bottle, but when she reached the entrance to the wilderness, she began to go astray after the idolatry of her father's house; the water in the bottle was spent,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The whole of this sentence thus far is an exact repetition of a few lines above. See also Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.,</i> for the same circumstance.</i> and the soul of Ishmael was faint with thirst.
"And she departed and wandered" (<i>ibid.</i>). The meaning of "and she wandered" is merely idolatry, because it is written, concerning (this root),<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 19:13.</i> "They are vanity, a work of delusion"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The root of this word (<span>וחתע</span>) is connected apparently with the Hebrew “to err” or “to wander” (<span>ךעה</span>); see Ẓohar, Gen. 118b.</i> (Jer. 10:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The previous verse refers to the images.</i> He went and cast himself beneath the thorns of the wilderness,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i> The phraseology is based on Job 30:7. This chapter is applied to Ishmael by the Midrash. The next few words (up to “upon him”) are wanting in the printed texts.</i> so that the moisture might be upon him, and he said: O God of my father Abraham !<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the version of the prayer in Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i> The printed editions of our book differ here from our MS. The first editions read thus: “Sovereign of the Worlds ! If it be Thy pleasure to give me water to drink, give me to drink and let not my soul depart because of thirst; for death by thirst is unnatural, and it is harder than all other (kinds of) death. The Holy One, blessed be He, heard his prayer.”</i> Thine are the issues of death; take away from me my soul, for I would not die of thirst. And He was entreated of him, as it is said, "For God hath heard the || voice of the lad where he is" (Gen. 21:17). The well<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> p. 263.</i> which was created at twilight<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the eve of the first Sabbath in the week of Creation. See <i>supra,</i> p. 124.</i> was opened for them there, and they went and drank and filled the bottle with water, as it is said, "And God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water" (<i>ibid.</i> 19). And there<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the wilderness of Beer-Sheba.</i> they left the well,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra,</i> pp. 268, 323.</i> and thence they started on their way,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “they lifted up their feet.”</i> and went through all the wilderness until they came to the wilderness of Paran, and they found there streams of water, and they dwelt there, as it is said, "And he dwelt in the wilderness of Paran" (<i>ibid.</i> 21). Ishmael sent for a wife from among the daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “fords.” The reading in our MS. is the correct text.</i> of Moab, and 'Ayeshah<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In later editions other readings of this name are found namely, “’Essah” and “’Ephah.” See Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 125.</i> was her name. After three years<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the narrative in the Book of Jashar xxi. 22 ff.; Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Midrash Haggadol, c. 310.</i> Abraham went to see Ishmael his son, having sworn to Sarah that he would not descend from the camel in the place where Ishmael dwelt. He arrived there at midday and found there the wife of Ishmael. He said<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The scribe has made a little mistake here by writing “She said.”</i> to her: Where is Ishmael? She said to him: He has gone with his mother to fetch the fruit of the palms<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria objects to the text, and prefers to read, “fruit of the broom-tree”; cf. Job 30:4. See Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.;</i> T.B. Baba Bathra, 75b; perhaps the text should read: “fruit and broom-trees.”</i> from the wilderness. He said to her: Give me a little bread and a little water,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a little bread and dainties.” The Prague edition reads: “a little water and bread and dainties.”</i> for my soul is faint after the journey in the desert. She said to him: I have neither bread nor water. He said to her: When Ishmael comes (home) tell him this || story, and say to him: A certain old man came from the land of Canaan to see thee, and he said, Exchange<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “That the door-sill of the house is not good.” See the Book of Jashar xxi. 31, and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> the threshold of thy house, for it is not good for thee. When Ishmael came (home) his wife told him the story. A son of a wise man is like half a wise man. Ishmael understood. His mother sent and took for him a wife from her father's house,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> From Pharaoh’s house. See <i>supra,</i> p. 190, and cf. the Book of Jashar xxi. 17.</i> and her name was Fatimah.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 21:21, and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i> These names Fatimah and ‘Ayeshah point to Arabian influence, and give us another <i>terminus a quo</i> to fix the date and locality of its redaction. ‘Ephah, mentioned above (p. 218, note 7), occurs as a woman’s name in 1 Chron. 2:46.</i>
Again after three years Abraham went to see his son Ishmael, having sworn to Sarah as on the first occasion that he would not descend from the camel in the place where Ishmael dwelt. He came there at midday, and found there Ishmael's wife. He said to her: Where is Ishmael? She replied to him: He has gone with his mother to feed the camels in the desert. He said to her: Give me a little bread and water, for my soul is faint after the journey<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> For this legend, see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 66 f. with notes.</i> of the desert. She fetched it and gave it to him. Abraham arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, for his son, and (thereupon) Ishmael's house was filled with all good things of the various blessings.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads “food and blessing.” See <i>infra,</i> p. 328, and cf. Midrash Haggadol, c. 311.</i> When Ishmael came (home) his wife told him what had happened, and Ishmael knew that his father's love was still extended to him, as it is said, || "Like as a father pitieth his sons" (Ps. 103:13). After the death of Sarah, Abraham again took (Hagar) his divorced (wife), as it is said, "And Abraham again<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions as in our version. See Pal. Targum, Gen. 25:1, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 375, note 8, where the parallel passages are given.</i> took a wife, and her name was Keturah" (Gen. 25:1). Why does it say "And he <i>again</i>"? Because on the first occasion she was his wife, and he <i>again</i> betook himself to her. Her name was Keturah, because she was perfumed with all kinds of scents.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Ishmaelites in the wilderness were the buyers and sellers of precious spices. Cf. Cant. 3:6, and Ezek. 27:21.</i>
Another explanation of Keturah (is): because her actions were beautiful like <i>incense</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew for “incense” (Ḳeṭoreth) suggests a connection with the name Ḳeṭurah.</i> and she bare him six sons,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here (instead of our context) the following: “Zimran, and Jokshan, and Medan and Midian, and Ishbak and Shuah.”</i> and they were all called according to the name of Ishmael,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The meaning is not quite evident; does it mean that the six names have some part of their spelling in common with the various letters of the name Ishmael? This is the case with the initial letter of five names, but Zimran is the exception.</i> as it is said, "And she bare him Zimran (<i>ibid.</i> 2).
Like a woman sent away from her husband, so likewise Abraham arose and sent them away from Isaac his son, from this world and from the world to come, as it is said, "But unto the sons of the concubines, which Abraham had,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Abraham gave gifts, and he sent them<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “‘and he sent them away’ by adeed of divorcement.”</i> away from Isaac his son" (<i>ibid.</i> 6), by a deed of divorcement.
Corresponding to the name of Ishmael's son<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “sons.” The descendants of Ishmael intermarried with the children of Keturah.</i> Kedar, the <i>sons of Kedar</i> were so called, as it is said, "Of Kedar, and of the kingdoms of Hazor" (Jer. 49:28). Corresponding to the name of Ishmael's son "Kedemah"<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the word has been partly erased, only the letters <span>קד</span> are legible.</i> (Gen. 25:15), the "sons of Ḳedem" were so called.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said: ‘The children of Ḳedem’” (Jer. 49:28).</i> Because they dwelt in the territory belonging to Cain, his children were called "sons of Cain," as it is said, "Now Heber the Kenite had separated himself from Cain" (Judg. 4:11). Were not all the sons of Cain cut off<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Rabbi Bechai’s commentary on Num. 24:22, which reads: “Were not all the sons of Cain cut off?” according to our text. The later editions read: “separated at the generation of the flood.”</i> by the waters of the Flood? But because they dwelt in the territory of the children of Cain, his children were called "sons of Cain," as it is said, "Nevertheless || Cain shall be wasted,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here. Our translation of the Scripture text differs from the usual version.</i> as long as Asshur shall dwell in thy place" (Num. 24:22). "Nevertheless Cain shall be wasted away" by fire, through the seed of Ishmael, the latter shall cause the kingdom of Assyria to cease.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The reference may be to the Moslem possession of Bagdad in Babylon. See <i>infra</i>, p. 350; and also Rashbam, <i>in loc.</i> (Num. 24:22).</i>
Balaam said: Of the seventy nations that the Holy One, blessed be He, created in His world, He did not put His name on any one of them except on Isra<i>el</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Some of the later editions add here: “And Ishma<i>el</i>, as it is said: ‘ And thou shalt call his name Ishmael’” (Gen. 16:11).</i> and since the Holy One, blessed be He, made the name of Ishma<i>el</i> similar to the name of Isra<i>el</i>, woe to him who shall live in his days, as it is said, "Alas, who shall live when God establisheth him?"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> By giving him the name of <i>El.</i> “Alas, who shall live when he is appointed (with the name) <i>El,”</i> may be the meaning read into the verse in question, or probably there is a play on the name Ishmael and the last two words Missumô el. The usual rendering is, “Alas, who shall live when God <i>doeth this.”</i> See Midrash Haggadol, c. 383.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 23).
Rabbi Ishmael said: In the future the children of Ishmael will do fifteen things in the land (of Israel) in the latter days, and they are: They will measure the land with ropes;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> To obtain exact dimension; cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, 103b.</i> they will change a cemetery into a resting-place for sheep (and) a dunghill; they will measure with them and from them upon the tops of the mountains; falsehood will multiply and truth will be hidden; the statutes will be removed far from Israel; sins will be multiplied in Israel; worm-crimson will be in the wool, and he will cover<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The root <span>קמל</span> means to be decayed. See Isa. 33:9: “Lebanon mouldereth”; or should we render “The paper will be decayed with the pen”? Literature will then perish. Krauss, <i>Studien zur Byzantisch-Jüdischen Geschichte</i>, p. 145, renders the preceding clause: “purple will be exceedingly dear.”</i> with insects paper and pen; he will hew down the rock of the kingdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The tombs of the Kings of Judah. Krauss, <i>op. cit.</i>, renders here: “the coinage will be withdrawn from circulation.”</i> and they will rebuild the desolated cities and sweep the ways; and they will plant gardens and parks, and fence in the broken walls of the Temple; and they will build a building in the Holy Place; and two brothers will arise over them,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “against them,” <i>i.e.</i> the two Caliphs, Mohammed Alemin and Abdallah Almamum (809–813 <small>C.E.</small>). See Graetz, <i>Geschichte</i>, v. pp. 197 f., and his article in Frankel’s <i>Monatsschrift</i>, 1859, p. 112. This gives us again a date for determining the period when our book was finally edited. Krauss, <i>op. cit.</i>, points out that the reference in the preceding clause is to the Mosque of Omar, the foundation of which was laid by the Caliph Omar after his conquest of Jerusalem in 636 <small>C.E.</small> In the next line we have the expression, “the Branch, the son of David,” cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 201, note 3, and see also the Shemoneh ‘Esreh, p. 49 (Singer).</i> princes at the end; and in their days the Branch, the Son of David, will arise, as it is said, || "And in the days of those kings shall the God of heaven set up a kingdom, which shall never be destroyed" (Dan. 2:44).
Rabbi Ishmael also said: Three wars of trouble<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “commotion.”</i> will the sons of Ishmael in the future wage on the earth in the latter days, as it is said, "For they fled away from the swords" (Isa. 21:15). "Swords" signify only wars, one in the forest of Arabia, as it is said, "From the drawn sword" (<i>ibid.</i>); another on the sea, as it is said, "From the bent bow" (<i>ibid.</i>); and one in the great city which is in Rome,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read here “Aram,” owing to the Censor.</i> which will be more grievous than the other two, as it is said, "And from the grievousness of the war" (<i>ibid.</i>). From there the Son of David shall flourish and see the destruction of<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “the idolaters.” See also Graetz, <i>Geschichte</i>, v. pp. 441 ff., especially p. 446, on the connection between our book and the <i>Secrets of R. Simeon ben Jochai.</i> The latter work, according to Graetz, was the source used by our author. The theory of Graetz was controverted by Steinschneider in <i>Z.D.M.G.</i> xxviii. pp. 645 f. The <i>Secrets</i> are printed in Jellinek’s <i>B.H.M.</i> iii. p. 78. A very interesting parallel to the latter part of this chapter of <i>P.R.E.</i> is to be found in the Book of the Bee, liii. (pp. 124 ff.).</i> <i>these and these</i>, and thence will He come to the land of Israel, as it is said, "Who is this that cometh from Edom,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> with crimsoned garments from Bozrah? this that is glorious in his apparel, marching in the greatness of his strength? I that speak in righteousness, mighty to save" (<i>ibid.</i> lxiii. 1).

Chapter 31

CHAPTER XXXI<br><small>THE BINDING OF ISAAC ON THE ALTAR</small> [38<small>A</small>. i.]<br>T<small>HE</small> tenth trial was (as follows): "And it came to pass after these things, that God did prove Abraham" (Gen. 22:1). He tried Abraham each time<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 55:1, and Cant. Rab. 1:9.</i> in order to know his heart, whether he would be able to persevere and keep all the commandments of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The next words, up to “as it is said,” are not in the printed editions.</i> or not, and whilst as yet the Torah had not been given, Abraham kept all the precepts<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Book of Jubilees, Abraham not only enacted the <i>laws of tithes</i> (xiii. 25–29), but he also celebrated the feast of first-fruits of the grain harvest on the 15th of Sivan (xv. 1, 2), and the feast of Tabernacles (xvi. 20–31); he ordained peace-offerings and the regulations as to the use of salt and wood for the offerings, washings before sacrifices, <i>and the duty of covering blood</i> (xxi. 7–17), and prohibited intermarrying with the Canaanites (xxii. 20, xxv. 5), and adultery (xxxix. 6). On this theme see Apoc. Baruch lvii. 2, and cf. Ecclus. xliv. 20.</i> of the Torah, as it is said, "Because that Abraham obeyed my voice,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, but it is continued in the first editions.</i> and kept my charge, my commandments, my statutes, and my Torah" (<i>ibid.</i> xxvi. 5).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 28a f.</i> And Ishmael went repeatedly from the wilderness to see || his father Abraham.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> As Abraham had visited Ishmael, the latter knew that his father would receive him. See Pal. Targum, Gen. 22:1, and Gen. Rab. 55:4, for the story of the dispute between Isaac and Ishmael, and for the account of the readiness of the former to offer up his life to the service of God.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah said: In that night was the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed unto him, and He said unto him: Abraham ! "Take now thy son,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the quotation ends here, but it is continued in the first editions.</i> thine only son, whom thou lovest, even Isaac" (<i>ibid.</i> xxii. 2). And Abraham, having pity upon Isaac,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that the reading should be: “The Holy One, blessed be He, had pity upon Isaac” (and ordered that Ishmael should be offered as an atonement for his past evil life). See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 96, Midrash Haggadol, c. 317, and cf. Wisdom x. 5.</i> said before Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! Concerning which son<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 69, and cf. the Liturgy for the second day of the New Year, ed. Heidenheim, pp. 34b ff.</i> dost Thou decree upon me? Is it concerning the son lacking circumcision,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Ishmael had been born thirteen years before God commanded the rite of circumcision, and when he was born his father was uncircumcised, but when Isaac was born Abraham was circumcised. On the theme of the “‘Aḳedah” see Gen. Rab. 55:1 f.</i> or the son born for circumcision? He answered him:	"Thine only son." He rejoined: This one is the only son of <i>his</i> mother, and the other son is the only son of <i>his</i> mother. He said to him: "The one, whom thou lovest." He said to Him: Both of them do I love.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 89b; Gen. Rab. 39:12.</i> He said to him: "Even Isaac."
"And offer him there for a burnt offering"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See the rest of this quotation.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). He spake to Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! On which mountain hast Thou told me (to offer him)? (God) answered him:	In every place where thou dost see My glory abiding and waiting for thee there, and saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “to thee”; see Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> This is Mount Moriah;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads here: “the altar.”</i> as it is said, "Upon one of the mountains which <i>I will tell thee</i> of" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “‘Which I have told thee of,’ is not written here, but, ‘ which I will tell thee of.’” God would indicate to Abraham the place in His own good time; cf. Gen. Rab. 55:8.</i>
Abraham rose up early in the morning, and he took with him Ishmael, and Eliezer, and Isaac his son, and he saddled the ass. Upon this ass did Abraham ride. This was the ass, the offspring of that ass which was created during the twilight,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Preceding the first Sabbath in the week of creation. See Aboth 5:9; Jalḳuṭ Gen. § 98; Jalḳuḳ on Zech. 9:9 (ed. King, p. 48); and cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 124.</i> as it is said, "And Abraham rose early in the morning, and saddled his ass" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation should probably belong to the previous sentence, and follow the word “ass.”</i> The same ass was also ridden upon by Moses when he came to Egypt, as it is said, "And Moses took his wife and his sons, and set them upon <i>the</i> ass" (Ex. 4:20). This || same ass will be ridden upon in the future by the Son of David,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Messiah; see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 71, note 2, and <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount</i>, p. 143, for the strange interpretation given to this Messianic function by Matthew (xxi. 7), and cf. Justin Martyr, <i>Dial. c. Tryph.</i> liii.</i> as it is said, "Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; shout, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy king cometh unto thee: he is just, and saved;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. this first part of the verse is not quoted.</i> lowly, and riding upon an <i>ass</i>, even upon a colt, the foal of an ass"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Later Rabbinic interpretation applied this verse sometimes to the Messiah ben Joseph. See Ibn Ezra, <i>in loc.</i></i> (Zech. 9:9).
Isaac was thirty-seven years old<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 25 p. 138, and cf. Seder ‘Olam Rab. 1; Tosaphoth to T.B. Jebamoth, 61b; Ex. Rab. i. 1, and the previous chapter in our book.</i> when he went to Mount Moriah, and Ishmael was fifty years old. Contention arose between Eliezer and Ishmael. Ishmael said to Eliezer: Now that Abraham will offer Isaac his son for a burnt offering, kindled upon the altar,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The wording here is based on Lev. 6:13.</i> and I am his first-born son, I will inherit (the possessions of) Abraham. Eliezer replied to him, saying: He has already driven thee out like a woman divorced from her husband, and he has sent thee<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> away to the wilderness, but I am his servant, serving him by day and by night, and I shall be the heir of Abraham. The Holy Spirit answered them, saying to them: Neither this one nor that one shall inherit.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 56:1; Midrash Haggadol, col. 320; Tanchuma, <i>in loc.</i> For the story see also the Book of Jashar xxiii. 22 ff., Pal. Targum, and the second version to Gen. 22 The Church Fathers deal with the theme in their usual style. See Ephraim of Syria on Jonah, 6; Ambrose <i>On Faith in Immortality</i>, G.T. i. pp. 404 f.; Zeno of Verona <i>On Patience</i>, 5.</i>
On the third day they reached Zophim,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Mount Moriah, on which the Temple was built; see 2 Chron. 3:1. See Rashi on T.B. Pesachim, 49a; ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, vii. 33a; and cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 61b. The word <span>צופים</span> means “watch-towers.” The Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads “Zuphith.” Jubilees (xviii. 13) agrees with our book in identifying the mount with Mount Zion. See also Book of the Bee, xxv. p. 43.</i> and when they reached Zophim they saw the glory of the Shekhinah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This passage is of considerable interest. We are in the domain of Philonic interpretation of the Bible. Thus Clement of Alexandria, under the influence of Philo’s allegorical interpretation, says on the text, Gen. 22:3, 4: “Abraham, when he came to the place which God told him of on the third day, looking up, saw the place afar off. For the first day is that which is constituted by the sight of good things; and the second is the soul’s best desire; on the third, the mind perceives spiritual things” (<i>Strom.</i> v. 11).<br>Our book identifies the place (<span>מקום</span>) with the Shekhinah, just as Philo does (<i>De Somniis</i>, i. M. i. 638, C.W. iii. p. 213); see Gen. Rab. 56:1 f.; and cf. the valuable note in Weinstein’s <i>Zur Genesis der Agada</i>, p. 88. The representation of the Shekhinah as a “Pillar of Fire” corresponds with Philo’s identification of the Logos with the “Pillar of Cloud,” which at night became the “Pillar of Fire” in the wilderness, leading God’s people to the Holy Land; see <i>Hellenism and Christianity</i>, p. 25, note. According to Jubilees xviii. 4: “And he came to a <i>well of water</i> and he said to his young men, ‘ Abide ye here with the ass.’” Does our author intentionally vary this by substituting the “cloud” for the well?</i> resting upon the top of the mountain, as it is said, "On the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes, and saw <i>the place</i> afar off" (Gen. 22:4). What did he see? (He saw) a pillar of fire standing from the earth to the heavens.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “He said to his son Isaac: My son! dost thou see anything upon one of these mountains? He said to him: Yes. (Abraham) said to him: What dost thou see? He replied: I see a pillar of fire standing from the earth up to the heavens.” See, for further references to the vision of Isaac and Abraham, Gen. Rab. 56:1, Pal. Targum, Gen. 22:4, and Tanchuma, Vayêra, §xxiii., which refers to “a cloud enwrapt on the mountain.” See also Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 99, and the Book of Jashar xxiii., which has used our book.</i> Abraham understood that the lad had been accepted for the perfect burnt offering. He said to Ishmael and Eliezer: Do ye see anything upon one of those mountains? || They said to him: No. He considered them (as dull) as an ass. He told them: Since ye do not see anything, "Abide ye here with the ass" (<i>ibid.</i> 5),<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Jebamoth, 62a; Gen. Rab. 56:2; Eccles. Rab. on Eccles. 9:7; T.B. Ḳiddushin, 68a; and Midrash Haggadol, c. 320.</i> with such who are similar to the ass.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Just as the ass does not see anything, likewise do ye not see anything, as it is said: ‘And Abraham said to his young men: Abide ye here with the ass’” (Gen. 22:5).</i>
He took the wood and placed it upon the back of his son Isaac, and he took the fire and the knife in his hand, and they went both of them together.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. 22:6.</i> Isaac said to his father: O my father ! Behold the fire and the wood, where is the lamb for the burnt offering? He replied to him: My son ! Thou art the lamb for the burnt offering, as it is said, "And Abraham said, God will provide<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The word might be rendered: “accept.” The verse might be translated thus: “God will accept for Himself the lamb, <i>i.e.</i> my son.”</i> for himself the lamb" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).
Rabbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Ishmael.”</i> said: The Holy One, blessed be He, pointed out<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “with the finger”; see <i>infra</i>, pp. 382 f.</i> the altar with a finger to Abraham our father, and said to him: This is the altar. That was the altar<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, pp. 153, 171; see also Aboth de Rabbi Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 4a; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 101, for a parallel text. The first editions add: “whereon the first man brought (his offering).”</i> whereon Cain and Abel sacrificed; it was the same altar whereon Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 171, note 8, and cf. Midrash Haggadol, c. 321.</i> and his sons sacrificed, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote Gen. 8:20 also.</i> "And Abraham built <i>the</i> altar there" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). "And Abraham built an altar there" is not written here, but "And Abraham built <i>the</i> altar there." That was the altar whereon the first ones (of old) had sacrificed.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests a variant reading, based on Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 36:5. “As it is said: ‘ And Noah built an altar to the Lord.’ ‘Abraham built there an altar’ is not written here, but ‘ and he built <i>the</i> altar.’” The reading in Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i>, is similar; see also Pal. Targum, Gen. 22:9.</i>
Isaac said to his father Abraham: O my father ! Bind for me my two hands, and my two feet, so that I do not curse<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “on account of reflex movement.” Read <span>פשימותא</span>, see Pesiḳta Rabbathi 40 (p. 170b), Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 27 p. 138; and Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa ii. p. 174; and cf. Agadath Bereshith 31 p. 62, and Grünbaum, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 112.</i> thee; for instance, a word may issue from the mouth because of the violence and dread of death, and I shall be found to have slighted || the precept, "Honour thy father" (Ex. 20:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 22:10, and Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> He bound his two hands and his two feet, and bound him upon the top of the altar, and he strengthened his two arms and his two knees<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 20:8, p. 176.</i> upon him, and put the fire and wood in order, and he stretched forth his hand and took the knife. Like a high priest<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab. 29:9 f., which implies that the ‘Aḳedah (Binding of Isaac) was on the Day of Atonement, so that the service of Abraham on that occasion might be considered as resembling that of the High Priest.</i> he brought near his meal offering, and his drink offering;<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The meal offering and the drink offering accompanied the “burnt offering” in the Tabernacle and Temple.</i> and the Holy One, blessed be He, was sitting and beholding the father binding with all (his) heart and the son bound with all (his) heart. And the ministering angels<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees xviii. 9 reads: “And I (the angel) stood before Him, and before the prince of the Mastêmâ, and the Lord said, Bid him not to lay his hand on the lad.”</i> cried aloud and wept, as it is said, "Behold, the Erelim<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> angels; see Ḳimchi’s <i>Book of Roots, s.v.</i> <span>ארה</span>. Cf. T.B. Chagigah, 5b; <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 73, note 1; and cf. Gen. Rab. 56:5, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 322.</i> cry<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i> without; the angels of peace weep bitterly" (Isa. 33:7). The ministering angels said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the worlds ! Thou art called merciful and compassionate, whose mercy is upon all His works;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 145:9.</i> have mercy upon Isaac, for he is a human being, and the son of a human being, and is bound before Thee like an animal. "O Lord, Thou preservest man and beast"; as it is said, "Thy righteousness is like the mighty mountains;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i> thy judgments are like a great deep: O Lord, thou preservest man and beast" (Ps. 36:6).
Rabbi Jehudah said: When the blade<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “sword.” See Midrash Haggadol, c. 323.</i> touched his neck, the soul of Isaac fled and departed, (but) when he heard His voice from between the two Cherubim,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 24. Cf. Heb. xi. 19.</i> saying (to Abraham), "Lay not thine hand upon the lad" (Gen. 22:12), his soul returned to his body, and (Abraham) set him free, and Isaac stood upon his feet. And Isaac knew<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “of the resurrection of the dead from the Torah.” The connection with the word Torah is not quite clear, and the word should be probably deleted. See Roḳeach, 322, and cf. Brode’s comment, <i>in loc.</i> The Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “He knew that in the future He would revive the dead.”</i> that in this manner the dead in the future will be quickened. He opened (his mouth), and said:	Blessed art thou, O Lord, who quickeneth the dead.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the second benediction of the Shemoneh ‘Esreh; see Singer, p. 45. The benediction is appropriately placed in Isaac’s mouth, for he had also been bound unto death and then set free. The benediction speaks of the loosening of the bound, as well as of the resurrection.</i> ||
Rabbi Zechariah said: That ram, which was created at the twilight,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the eve of the first Sabbath; see <i>supra</i>, p. 125.</i> ran and came to be offered up instead of Isaac, but Sammael<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees xviii. 12: “And the prince of the Mastêmâ was put to shame. And Abraham lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, a <i>single</i> ram caught and it came (?).” The word translated “and distracting it” is Masṭenô; it reminds one of Mastêmâ of Jubilees. See also Midrash Haggadol, c. 324.</i> was standing by, and distracting it, in order to annul the offering of our father Abraham. And it was caught by its two horns in the trees, as it is said, "And Abraham lifted up his eyes, and looked, and behold, behind him a ram caught in the thicket by its horns" (<i>ibid.</i> 13). What did that ram do? It put forth its leg and took hold of the coat of our father Abraham, and Abraham looked, saw the ram, and he went and set it free. He offered it up instead of Isaac his son, as it is said, "And Abraham went and took the ram,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MSS.</i> and offered it up for a burnt offering in the stead of his son" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Berachiah said: The sweet savour (of the ram) ascended before the Holy One, blessed be He, as though it were the sweet savour of Isaac,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 120b.</i> and He swore that He would bless him<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, and Apoc. Baruch, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> in this world and in the world to come, as it is said, "By myself have I sworn, saith the Lord, because thou hast done this thing"; and it says, "That in blessing I will bless thee, and in multiplying I will multiply thy seed, as the stars of the heaven" (<i>ibid.</i> 16, 17). "That in blessing" (refers) to this world; "I will bless thee," in the world to come; and "I will greatly multiply thy seed," in the future that is to come.
Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa said:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ Isa. § 436, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 325.</i> From that ram, which was created at the twilight, nothing came forth which was useless.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah, Ẓebachim ix. 5, as to the parts of a burnt offering which were not offered on the altar.</i> The ashes of the ram<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 204, and cf. T.B. Ẓebachim, 62a.</i> were || the base<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, foundation. Does the text here refer to the horns of the altar? or should the text read, “the foundation whereon (stood) the inner altar”? See Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> which was upon the top of the inner altar.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said: ‘And Aaron shall make atonement upon the horns of it once in the year’” (Ex. 30:10).</i> The sinews of the ram were the strings<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Read Nimin instead of Nebalim, and see <i>supra</i>, p. 127. The first editions read: “The sinews of the ram were ten, corresponding to the ten strings of the harp,” etc. According to one tradition the harp of David had only eight strings, and it is the harp of the Messiah which is to have ten strings. See Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> vii. 12. 3, and cf. Pesiḳta Rabbathi, pp. 98b f.</i> of the harp whereon David played. The ram's skin<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The inference here is drawn from the word “‘Ôr” (<span>עוד</span>), leather.</i> was the girdle (around) the loins of Elijah, may he be remembered for good, as it is said, "And they answered him, He was an hairy man, and girt with a girdle of leather about his loins" (2 Kings 1:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions have a corrupt quotation based on 2 Kings 1, verses 6 and 8. The MS. only quotes the few words: “He was an hairy man,” etc.</i> The horn<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Othijoth de Rabbi ‘Aḳiba, letter Ṭ; ed. Jellinek, <i>B.H.M.</i> iii. p. 31; and Roḳeach, 203. The first editions read: “the two horns.”</i> of the ram of the left side<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “Wherein the Holy One, blessed be He, blew upon Mount Sinai.” See Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> (was the one) wherein He blew upon Mount Sinai, as it is said, "And it shall come to pass, that when the ram's horn soundeth long"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. and the first editions quote Ex. 19:19.</i> (Josh. 6:5). (The horn) of the right side, which is larger than that of the left, is destined in the future to be sounded in the world that is to come,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “at the ingathering of the exiles.”</i> as it is said, "And it shall come to pass in that day, that a great trumpet shall be blown" (Isa. 27:13);<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The inference here is derived from the word “great,” implying the right side. On the subject of the Messianic trump, see Abḳath Rochel i., and cf. 1 Cor. xv. 52.</i> and it is said, "And the Lord shall be king over all the earth" (Zech. 14:9).
Rabbi Isaac said: Nothing has been created except by the merit of worship. Abraham returned from Mount Moriah only through the merit of worship, as it is said, "We will <i>worship</i>, and come again to you" (Gen. 22:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash Samuel (ed. Buber) iii. 7 contains a good parallel text, which is much fuller than our MS. It adds here: “The Israelites were redeemed from Egypt only in consequence of worship, as it is said: ‘And the people bowed the head and <i>worshipped’</i> (Ex. 12:27). The Torah was given only through the merit of worship, because it is said: ‘And <i>worship</i> ye afar off’” (<i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 1). See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 100.</i> The Temple was fashioned only through the merit of worship, as it is said, "Exalt ye the Lord our God, and <i>worship</i>" (Ps. 99:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash Samuel, <i>loc. cit.</i>, adds here: “The dead also will only be quickened through the merit of worship, as it is said: ‘O come, let us worship and bow down’ (Ps. 95:6). The exiles will only be gathered in again owing to the merit of worship, as it is said: ‘And it shall come to pass in that day, that a great trumpet shall be blown; and they shall come which were lost in the land of Assyria, and they that were outcasts in the land of Egypt; and they shall <i>worship</i> the Lord in the holy mountain at Jerusalem’” (Isa. 27:13). See also Gen. Rab. Ivi. 2, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 320 f. On the entire chapter see the Book of Jashar xxiii.; Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Gen. p. 57a, b; Tanchuma, Vayêra, § xxiii.; and Midrash Agadah, Gen. pp. 50 ff.</i>

Chapter 32

CHAPTER XXXII<br><small>THE DEATH OF SARAH AND THE STORY OF ISAAC AND REBECCA</small> [39<small>B</small>. i.]<br>S<small>IX</small> (people) were called by their names before they were created,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In Mekhilta, Bô, xvi. p. 19a; only Isaac, Solomon, and Josiah are mentioned. See Agadath Bereshith, 65, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 246. In T. J. Berakhoth 1:8 four names are mentioned, the three as in the Mekhilta and, in addition, Ishmael; cf. Gen. Rab. 45:8. In T.B. Chullin, 139b, the name of Moses is mentioned, as also the names of Mordecai, Esther, and Haman, all these names being hinted at in the Torah. Luria observes that Cyrus (Is. 44:28 and xlv. 1) should have been mentioned in the list of people named before their birth. This fact would not warrant the inference that all these people were pre-existent. This reasoning is, however, often applied to the name of the Messiah, as though it meant that the Messiah pre-existed because his name was named before his birth; see <i>Hellenism and Christianity</i>, p. 17.</i> and they are: Isaac, Ishmael, Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “our Rabbi,” or “our teacher.”</i> Solomon, Josiah, and King Messiah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the name of the Messiah.” The Amsterdam edition reads: “our Messiah.” The first editions add: “May the Holy One, blessed be He, cause him to come speedily in our days.”</i>
Whence do we know about Ishmael? Because it is said, "And the angel of the Lord said unto her, Behold, thou art with child,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit this part of the verse, and give the second half only.</i>… and thou shalt call his name Ishmael" (Gen. 16:11). Why was his name || called Ishmael?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Ishma-<i>el</i> is interpreted as meaning “<i>God</i> will hear”; cf. Gen. 16:11.</i> Because in the future the Holy One, blessed be He, will <i>hearken</i> to the cry<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the voice of the cry.”</i> of the people arising from (the oppression) which the children of Ishmael will bring about in the land in the last (days);<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “days.” It occurs in the first editions. The reference is to the time of woe preceding the coming of the Messiah. See <i>supra</i>, pp. 221 f., and cf. Matt. xxiv. 3 ff. for the Messianic woes.</i> therefore was his name called Ishmael.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said, ‘<i>God shall hear</i> and answer them’” (Ps. 55:19). The Hebrew for “God shall hear” contains the same letters as the Hebrew word <i>Ishmael.</i></i>
How do we know (this with reference to) Isaac? Because it is said, "And God said, Sarah thy wife shall bear thee a son indeed; and thou shalt call his name Isaac" (<i>ibid.</i> xvii. 19). Why was his name called Isaac?<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Haggadol, c. 256; Agadath Beresbith, 53; Gen. Rab. 53:7; and Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Gen. 54a. Jubilees xvi. 3 says: “And we told her (Sarah) the name of her son, as his name is ordained and written in the heavenly tables, (<i>i.e.</i>) Isaac.”</i> Because Yad (the first Hebrew letter of Isaac indicates) the <i>ten</i> trials<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Agadath Bereshith, <i>loc. cit.</i>, refers to the Ten Commandments. The context in our author agrees with Tanchuma, Ḳorah, § xii.</i> wherewith our father Abraham was tried; and he withstood them all. Zaddi (the second letter indicates) the <i>ninety</i> (years), for his mother was ninety years (at the birth of Isaac), as it is said, "And shall Sarah, that is ninety years old, bear?" (<i>ibid.</i> 17). Cheth (the third letter points to) the <i>eighth</i> (day), for he was circumcised on the eighth day, as it is said, "And Abraham circumcised his son Isaac, being eight days old" (<i>ibid.</i> xxi. 4). Ḳuf (the fourth letter of the name marks) the <i>hundred</i> (years), for his father was an hundred years old (at Isaac's birth), as it is said, "And Abraham was an hundred years old" (<i>ibid.</i> 5).
Whence do we know about Moses?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, 139b. The name of Moses is said to be hinted at in Ps. 18:16: “<i>He drew me out</i> (<span>ימשני</span>) of many waters.” The word Moses is connected with the root “to draw out” in Hebrew.</i> Because it is said, "And the Lord said, My spirit shall not abide in man for ever in their going astray" (<i>ibid.</i> vi. 3). What is the implication (of the expression), "In their going astray"?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The word ‘in their going astray’ has the same numerical value as (the name) Moses” (<span>משה</span> = MShH). See R.V. <i>in loc.</i></i> Retrospectively his name was called Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> B = 2, Sh = 300, G =3, M = 40 = 345.<br>M =40, Sh = 300, H = 5 =345.<br>This system is known as Gemaṭria, and was also known to and used by some of the Church Fathers; see Irenæus, <i>adv. Hœr.</i> v. xxx. 1 ff., where he speaks of the number of the name of the Antichrist; see also Clement of Alexandria, <i>Strom.</i> vi. ch. xi. According to Jastrow, <i>T.D.</i> 239a, this word is a transposition of the word <i>γραμμάτια</i>, “accounts”; see also ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, ii. p. 309b.</i> For the life of Moses was one hundred and twenty years, as it is said, "His days shall be an hundred and twenty years" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Whence do we know concerning Solomon? Because it is said, "Behold, a son shall be born to thee, who shall be a man of rest,… for his name shall be <i>Solomon</i>" (1 Chron. 22:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “and thou shalt call his name Solomon, because.” See Midrash Haggadol, c. 246.</i> Why was his name called Solomon? Because his name was called Solomon in the Aramaic language, as it is said, "I will give <i>peace</i> (Shalom) and quietness unto Israel in his days" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The name <span>שלמה</span> (Solomon) is connected with <span>שלום</span> (peace). See also 2 Sam. 12:24, with Ḳimchi’s commentary thereon. The Aramaic Sh’lama (peace) is somewhat similar to the Hebrew name Sh’lomoh (=Solomon). The printed texts omit the words “his name was called Solomon in the Aramaic language.”</i> ||
Whence do we know about Josiah? Because it is said, "Behold, a child shall be born unto the house of David, Josiah by name" (1 Kings 13:2). Why was his name called Josiah? (Because he was as acceptable)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets do not occur in the MS., but they are found in the first editions.</i> as an offering upon the altar; she<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The reference is probably to the mother. The first editions omit this.</i> said: A worthy offering let him be before Thee.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on 1 Kings 13 § 200. The name Josiah (<span>יאשיהו</span>) is interpreted as though it were <span>יאי שי הוא</span>, “he is worthy like a lamb.” The next sentence is found only in the MS.</i> Therefore was his name called Josiah, as it is said, "And he cried against the altar," etc. (<i>ibid.</i> 2).
Whence do we know concerning King Messiah? Because it is said, "His name shall endure for ever. Before the sun his name shall be continued (Yinnon)" (Ps. 72:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, iv. p. 141a, <i>s.v.</i> <span>נון</span>, in the sense of “offspring”; cf. Gen. 21:23. Gesenius (Oxford edition) renders Ps. 72:17: “Let his name have increase.” See Parchon’s <i>Heb. Dict. s.v.</i>, and note Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, which says: “He will stir up all the evil ones of the earth (in the future)”; cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 45, and Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Why was his name called Yinnon? For he will <i>awaken</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ibn Ezra on this verse of Ps. 72 See also T.B. Synhedrin, 95a, and <i>supra</i>, p. 230. ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “in the future he will bring to life those who sleep in the dust, therefore is his name called Yinnon.” See also <i>supra</i>, p. 12.</i> those who sleep at Hebron out of the dust of the earth, therefore is his name called Yinnon, as it is said, "Before the sun his name is Yinnon" (<i>ibid.</i>).
When Abraham returned from Mount Moriah in peace, the anger of Sammael<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Midrash Haggadol, c. 324, reads, “Satan.” On Sammael’s discomfiture see Jubilees xviii. 9 and 12. The name Sammael (<i>i.e.</i> the Devil) occurs in Christian books, <i>e.g.</i> in the Acts of Andrew and Matthew (in <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xvi. p. 362).</i> was kindled, for he saw that the desire of his heart to frustrate the offering of our father Abraham had not been realized. What did he do? He went and said to Sarah: Hast thou not heard what has happened in the world? She said to him: No. He said to her: Thy husband, Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Gen. 57b; Pesiḳta Rabbathi 40; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 98; T.B. Giṭṭin, 57b, and the Book of Jashar xxiii. 77. The first editions omit Abraham and read “the old man.”</i> has taken thy son Isaac and slain him and offered him up as a burnt offering upon the altar.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And the lad wept, and cried aloud because he could not be saved.”</i> She began to weep and to cry aloud three times,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “weepings.”</i> corresponding to the three sustained notes (of the Shophar),<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Teḳi‘oth.</i> and (she gave forth) three howlings corresponding to the three disconnected short notes<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the “Teru‘a”; cf. Mishnah, Rosh Ha-Shanah (iv. 9), p. 16a.</i> (of the Shophar), and her soul fled, and she died.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab. 20:2, and Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 9:1. According to these Midrashim it is Isaac who tells Sarah the story of the ‘Aḳedah. See Tanchuma, <i>in loc.</i> According to this version Satan, in the guise of Isaac, tells the tale. See also Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
Abraham came and found that she was dead. Whence did he come? From Mount Moriah,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. <i>in loc.</i> According to the Book of Jashar xxiii. 84, Sarah went to look for Abraham, but died at Hebron. Also according to Jubilees xix. 2, Sarah died at Hebron.</i> as it is said, "And Abraham came to mourn for Sarah" (Gen. 23:2).
Rabbi José said: Isaac observed mourning during three years<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> At the ‘Aḳedah, Isaac was 37 years old, and when he married Rebecca he was 40 years. For an instance of three years of mourning see 2 Sam. 13:38 f. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 388.</i> || for his mother. After three years he married Rebecca, and forgot the mourning for his mother.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “Sarah his mother” is the reading in the first editions.</i> Hence thou mayest learn that until a man marries a wife his love centres in his parents. When he marries a wife his love is bestowed upon his wife, as it is said, "Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and he shall cleave unto his wife" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 24). Does a man then <i>leave</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “forsake.”</i> his father and mother with reference to the precept, "Honour"?<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> “Honour thy father and thy mother” (Ex. 20:12).</i> But the love of his soul cleaves unto his wife, as it is said, "And his soul clave (unto Dinah)" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 3); and it says, "And he shall cleave unto his wife" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 24).
Rabbi Jehudah said: Rebecca<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Jashar xxvi. 5 says: “And Isaac and his wife rose up and went to the land of Moriah to pray there and to seek the Lord.” See also T.B. Jebamoth, 64a, and Pal. Targum, Gen. 25:21.</i> was barren for twenty years. After twenty years (Isaac) took Rebecca and went (with her) to Mount Moriah, to the place where he had been bound, and he prayed on her behalf concerning the conception of the womb; and the Holy One, blessed be He, was entreated of him,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Midrash Agadah, Toledoth, p. 21, God hearkened to his prayer because “he was righteous and the son of a righteous man.”</i> as it is said, "And Isaac intreated the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> xxv. 21). The children were contending with one another<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 63:6 for the cause of the struggle. Cf. Pal. Targum, Gen. 25:22.</i> within her womb like mighty warriors, as it is said, "And the children struggled together within her" (<i>ibid.</i> 22). The time of her confinement came round, and her soul was nigh unto death owing to her pains.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Book of Jashar xxvi. 9; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 110.</i> And she went to pray in the place<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Book of Jashar xxvi. 10 says: “And she went to the land of Moriah to seek the Lord on account of this.”</i> whither she and Isaac had gone, as it is said, "And she went to inquire of the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>). What did the Holy One, blessed be He,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the words: “the Holy One, blessed be He.”</i> do? Jacob took hold of the heels of Esau to make him fall, as it is said, "And after that came forth his brother, and his hand had hold on Esau's heel" (<i>ibid.</i> 26). Hence thou mayest learn that the descendants of Esau will not fall until a remnant || from Jacob will come and cut off the feet of the children of Esau from the mountain of Seir, as it is said, "Forasmuch as thou sawest that a stone was cut out of the mountain without hands" (Dan. 2:45).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote here Dan. 2:34. See Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> x. 10. 4.</i> Another Scripture text says, "Vengeance is mine, and a recompence,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. only quotes thus far, the first editions continue the verse.</i> at the time when their <i>foot</i> shall slide" (Deut. 32:35).
Rabbi Tanchuma<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “R. Acha.”</i> said: The two lads grew up; the one went by the way of life, and the other went by the way of death,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 102, for the “two ways.”</i> as it is said, "And the boys grew, and Esau was a cunning hunter" (Gen. 25:27). Jacob went on the way of life, for he was dwelling in tents,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Targumim, <i>in loc.</i>, the “tents” are the “academies.” See Jalḳuṭ Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and he studied the Torah all his days.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And Esau the wicked was going the way of death to slay our father Jacob, as it is said: ‘The days of mourning for my father are at hand; then will I slay my brother Jacob’” (Gen. 27:41).</i> Esau went on the way of death, because he slew Nimrod and his son Chavir, and he almost sought to kill Jacob his brother, as it is said, "The days of mourning for my father are at hand, and I will slay my brother Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i> xxvii. 41).
Rabbi Simeon said: In the hour when Isaac was bound, he lifted up his eyes heavenwards and saw the glory of the Shekhinah, as it is written, "For man shall not see me and live" (Ex. 33:20). Instead of death his eyes grew dim<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 78 f., and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 114.</i> in his old age, as it is said, "And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old, that his eyes were dim, so that he could not see" (Gen. 27:1). Hence thou mayest learn that the blind man is as though he were dead.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Nedarim, 64a, and Gen. Rab. 65:10.</i>
The night-fall of the festival day of Passover came,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 153. See also the Vilna Gaon on Orach Chayyim, 583 Cf. Heb. xi. 20 on the theme in our text.</i> and Isaac called unto Esau his elder son, and said: O my son ! To-night the heavenly ones<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen., <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “All the heavenly ones sing a song”; see Pal. Targum, Gen. 27:1.</i> utter songs,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Pss. cxiii.–cxviii.</i> on this night the treasuries<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Slavonic Enoch vi. and Eth. Enoch lx. 20, and <i>supra</i>, p. 17, for this expression; and see T.B. Chagigah, 12b; and T.B. Ta‘anith, 4b.</i> of dew<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The text is in the plural, “dews” here and throughout the chapter. The prayer for dew forms part of the liturgy for the first day of Passover.</i> are opened; on this day the blessing of the dews (is bestowed). Make me savoury meat whilst I am still alive, and I will bless thee. || The Holy Spirit rejoined, saying to him: "Eat thou not the bread of him that hath an evil eye,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> neither desire thou his dainties" (Prov. 23:6). He went to fetch it, and was delayed there.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 82.</i> Rebecca said to Jacob his (other) son:<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Rebecca said to Jacob, O my son!”</i> On this night the treasuries of dew will be opened, and on this night the angels utter a song.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “On this night in the future thy children will be redeemed from the power of bondage; on this night in the future they will sing a song.” See T.B. Soṭah, 12b, and Wisdom xviii. 6.</i> Make savoury meat for thy father, that he may eat and whilst he still lives he may bless thee.
Now (Jacob) was skilled in the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> He should have fulfilled the desire of his father; see T.B. Ḳiddushin, 31a, and Pal. Targum, Gen. 27:6, 11.</i> and his heart dreaded the curse of his father. His mother said to him: My son ! If it be a blessing, may it be upon thee and upon thy seed; if it be a curse, let it be upon me<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> So also Pal. Targum, Gen. 27:13.</i> and upon my soul, as it is said, "And his mother said to him, Upon me be thy curse, my son" (Gen. 27:13). He went and brought two kids of the goats. Were two kids of the goats the food for Isaac? But he brought one as a Paschal offering,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Would not one (goat) have been sufficient for him? As it is said: ‘The righteous eateth to the satisfying of his soul’ (Prov. 13:25). But one (goat) corresponded to the Paschal Lamb.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> and with the other he prepared the savoury meat to eat; and he brought it to his father,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “For we are taught in a Mishnah: the Paschal Lamb is brought only when one is satisfied with food. He entered,” etc.</i> and he said to him: "Arise, I pray thee, sit and eat of my venison" (<i>ibid.</i> 19).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashi, <i>in loc.</i>; Ẓohar, Gen. 154a; and cf. Derekh Erez Ẓuṭṭa v. on the rule as to eating in a sitting posture.</i> Isaac said: "The voice is the voice of Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i> 22). Jacob (declares) the unity of God. "The voice is the voice of Jacob"<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The unity of God proclaimed by the “voice of Jacob” is applied to the declaration of the children of Israel who exclaim: “Hear, O Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is one” (Deut. 6:4).</i> (<i>ibid.</i>) in the meditation of the Torah. "And the hands are the hands of Esau" (<i>ibid.</i>), in all shedding of blood and in every evil death. Not only this, but also when they proclaim in heaven, "The voice is the voice of Jacob," the heavens tremble.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 282; Gen. Rab. 66:4; Pesiḳta Rabbathi 21 p. 99b; Roḳeach, 362. The 1st ed. reads here: “And when they proclaim on earth, ‘The voice is the voice of Jacob’ (Gen. 27:22), every one who hears and does not obey, his portion is with ‘the hands which are the hands of Esau’” (<i>ibid.</i>).</i> And when they proclaim on earth, "The voice is the voice of Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i>), every one who hears will make his portion with "The voice which is the voice of Jacob." And every one || who does not hear and does not act (obediently), his portion is with "The hands, which are the hands of Esau."
Rabbi Jehudah said: Isaac blessed Jacob with ten blessings concerning the dews of heaven and the corn of the earth, corresponding to the ten words<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Ma’amaroth; see Lev. Rab. 34 (end); Deut. Rab. i. 14.</i> whereby the world was created, as it is said, "And God give thee of the dew of the heaven" (<i>ibid.</i> 28); "Let peoples serve thee, …" (<i>ibid.</i> 29). When Jacob went forth from the presence of his father Isaac, he went forth crowned like a bridegroom, and like a bride in her adornment,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, pp. 40, 112 f.; and cf. Isa. 49:18.</i> and the quickening dew from heaven descended upon him, and refreshed his bones,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words are based on Prov. 15:30.</i> and he also became a mighty hero; therefore it is said, "By the hands of the mighty Jacob, from thence is the shepherd, the stone<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 268. The R.V. should be noted.</i> of Israel" (<i>ibid.</i> xlix. 24).

Chapter 33

CHAPTER XXXIII<br><small>ELISHA AND THE SHUNAMMITE WOMAN</small><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This chapter seems to be the Midrash to the Haphṭarah of Vayêra (Gen. 17–xxii.), illustrating the resurrection experienced by Isaac at the ‘Aḳedah.
