The Book of Jonah, which formed the contents of Chapter X., is the Haphṭarah in the afternoon service on the Day of Atonement.</i> [41<small>A</small>. i.]<br>"A<small>ND</small><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “It is written: ‘And Isaac sowed,’” etc.</i> Isaac sowed in that land" (Gen. 26 <b>12</b>). Rabbi Eliezer said: Did Isaac sow the seed of corn?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The patriarchs were not to settle in Canaan; therefore they did not devote themselves to the agricultural life. Their wealth was in their flocks, which could be easily removed as occasion demanded. See Pal. Targum, Gen. 26:12; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 111; and <i>infra</i>, p. 289.</i> Heaven forbid ! But he took all his wealth,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “his mammon”; see <i>Jewish Sources of the Sermon on the Mount</i>, p. 169. The tithe had been observed by Abraham; see Gen. 14:20, and therefore Isaac also gave a tithe. See Num. Rab. 12:11. The first editions read: “But he took a tithe of all his wealth.”</i> and sowed it in charity to the needy, as it is said, "Sow to yourselves in righteousness, reap according to love" (Hos. 10:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu ḳuṭṭa (ed. Friedmann), i. p. 167.</i> Everything which he tithed, the Holy One, blessed be He, sent him (in return) one hundred times (the value) in different kinds of blessings, as it is said, "And he found in the same year an hundredfold: and the Lord blessed him" (Gen. 26:12).
Rabbi Simeon said: Owing to the power of || charity the dead will be quickened<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Prov. 11:4. Isaac’s charity and righteousness are assumed here to have been the cause of his resurrection; another cause was the “’Aḳedah”; see <i>supra</i>, p. 228. The first benediction of the Shemoneh ‘Esreh, as we have already seen, refers to Abraham; the second benediction refers to the resurrection, and therefore to Isaac, the <i>first</i> to experience this.</i> in the future. Whence do we learn this? From Elijah the Tishbite.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The dead son of Elijah’s hostess was quickened by God at the request of the prophet. The first editions add here: “For he was going from mountain to mountain, and from cave to cave.” This is based on 2 Kings 2:1 ff.</i> For he betook himself to Zarephath, and a woman (who was) a widow received him with great honour.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> By giving him the little she possessed and trusting in his word. See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 18 p. 97.</i> She was the mother of Jonah,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Sukkah 5:1. 55a; Gen. Rab. 98:11; and see also <i>J.E.</i> vii. 226.</i> and they were eating and drinking<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Jalḳuṭ, 1 Kings, § 209, omits the words “and drinking”; see T.B. Berakhoth, 35b. People did not drink oil, it was eaten with bread, etc.</i> his<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “her” here.</i> bread and oil; he, she, and her son, as it is said, "And she did eat, and he also" (1 Kings 17:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Rabbi Levi said: It is written, ‘He and she,’ but we read, ‘She and he.’” The Massorites afford numerous examples of this variation in the reading of the written text. See Berliner, Midrash Ḳeri and Kethib; see also Cant. Rab. 2:4; and Ḳimchi on 1 Kings 18:15; and cf. <i>J.E.</i> viii. 368.</i>
"He and she" (indicate that it was) by the merit of Elijah that they had to eat. After (a period of) days, the son of the woman fell sick and died,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The text does not state that the child died; see Maimonides, <i>Moreh Nebukhim</i>, i. 42; Ḳimchi, <i>in loc.</i>; cf. T.B. Niddah, 70b, and T.B. Chullin, 7b.</i> as it is said, "And it came to pass after these things that the son of the woman fell sick" (<i>ibid.</i> 17). The woman said to him (Elijah): Thou didst come unto me<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and first editions add: “for coition.” The text reads: “Thou art come unto me to bring my sin to remembrance and to slay my son” (1 Kings 17:18). The Midrash connects <span>ביאה</span> (“coition”) with <span>באת</span> (“thou art come”); see Gesenius (Oxford ed.) p. 98a.</i> for coition, and thou wilt bring my sin to remembrance against me, and my son is dead. Now take away all that which thou hast brought<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The blessing on the meal and oil.</i> to me, and give me my son. Elijah, may he be remembered for good, arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, and said before Him: Sovereign of all the worlds ! Is it not enough (to endure) all the evils which have befallen me,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “which have come over my head.”</i> but also this woman; for I know<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria holds that the text should read: “For Thou knowest”; cf. Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> that out of sorrow for her son has she spoken of a matter which has not occurred, which she has brought against me to vex me.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed editions read: “to provoke me”; cf. Job 9:20.</i> Now let all the generations learn<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> From the resurrection of her son.</i> that there is a resurrection of the dead, and restore the soul of this lad within him; and He was entreated of him, as it is said, "And the Lord hearkened unto the voice of Elijah" (<i>ibid.</i> 22). Another Scripture text says, "And Elijah || took the child… See, thy son liveth" (<i>ibid.</i> 23).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This concludes the exposition of R. Simeon on the Resurrection and Charity. The second quotation is not given in the printed texts.</i>
Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: Art thou astonished at this?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> That charity causes the dead to be quickened.</i> Do not be astonished, come and see, (learn) from Elisha, the son of Shaphat, for no woman was able to gaze at his face without dying; and he went from mount to mount, and from cave to cave, and he went to Shunem, and a great woman received him with great honour. She was a sister of Abishag,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Abishag lived at the close of David’s reign; see <i>J.E.</i> i. 66.</i> the Shunammite, the mother<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the wife of Iddo.” Iddo lived in the reign of Jeroboam. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 20; and cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 89b and 104a; Tanchuma, Toledoth, § xii. Jalḳuṭ, 2 Kings § 228, reads: “The mother of Iddo the prophet.” Luria, with fine judgment, suggested that Iddo of the printed texts should be corrected into “Oded,” the prophet who lived in the reign of Asa. See 2 Chron. 15:8; see also Rashi on 2 Kings 4:8, where our <i>P.R.E.</i> is mentioned.</i> of Oded, the prophet, as it is said, "And it fell on a day, that Elisha passed to Shunem" (2 Kings 4:8), and the woman said to her husband: This man of God is (holy),<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “Holy” is not in the MS., but it occurs in the first two editions.</i> no woman is able to gaze at his face without dying; but,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is added by the first editions; it does not occur in the parallel context in Jalḳuṭ, Kings, <i>loc. cit.</i>, which reads as our MS., “But ‘Let us make,’” etc.</i> "Let us make, I pray thee, a little chamber on the wall; and let us set for him there a bed, and a table, and a stool, and a lampstand" (<i>ibid.</i> 10). And every time that he passes he can turn thither into the chamber,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, add: “They built it, and prepared and arranged it. After some time<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> he passed by Shunem and turned in to the chamber.”</i> as it is said, "And it fell on a day, that he came thither, and he turned into the chamber" (<i>ibid.</i> 11). And he called for the Shunammite, as it is said, "And he said, Call her. And when he had called her, she stood at the door" (<i>ibid.</i> 15). Why did she stand at the door? Because she was unable to gaze at his face,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab. 24:6, and Sepher Chassidim (ed. Frankfort, 1724), 178.</i> so that she should not die. He said to her:
"At this season, when the time cometh round, thou shalt embrace a son" (<i>ibid.</i> 16), the fruit of thy womb. She said to him: My lord is very old, and the way of women has departed from me, || and it is impossible to do this thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria’s reads: “This thing cannot possibly be.”</i> "Nay, my lord, thou man of God, do not lie unto thine handmaid" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ḳimchi, <i>in loc.</i>, who uses the same words as our author, based on the quotation in our context in connection with Ps. 145:19.</i>
Rabbi Zechariah said: "He will fulfil the desire of them that fear him" (Ps. 145:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Megillah, 27a.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, fulfilled the desire of the prophet. She conceived and bare, and the child grew. He went forth to refresh<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut vi. p. 288b, <i>s.v.</i> <span>פנ</span>; cf. Lam. 2:18.</i> himself, and to look at the reapers. A mishap overtook him,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Jebamoth xv. 2, 14d.</i> and he died, as it is said, "It fell on a day, that he went out to his father to the reapers" (2 Kings 4:18); this restrained them (from work) until he came (among them),<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The phrase, “this restrained them until he came,” is in Aramaic and occurs only in our MS. Its meaning is doubtful. Is it an old Targum?</i> and he died, as it is said, "And he sat on her knees till noon, and then died" (<i>ibid.</i> 20).
The woman went to Mount Carmel, and fell on her face to the ground before Elisha, saying to him: Would that my vessel<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Kings 4:3; <span>כלי</span> (vessel) is used euphemistically here, meaning “womb.”</i> had remained empty ! But it was filled, and now its contents are spilt. The prophet answered: Everything which the Holy One, blessed be He, doeth, He telleth to me, but He has hidden this matter, as it is said, "And when she came to the man of God<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the quotation ends here.</i>… and Gehazi came near to thrust her away"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash here has a play on the word “lehadphah,” interpreting it as though it were “lehôd japhjah,” “the glory of her beauty,” <i>i.e.</i> the breasts; see T.B. Berakhoth, 10b, and T.J. Jebamoth ii. 4. 3d.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 27). What is the meaning of "to thrust her away"? To teach us that he put his hand upon (her) pride, which was upon her breasts,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> as it is said, "And the man of God said, Let her alone<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the verse given by our MS. is omitted in the printed editions.</i>… and the Lord hath hid it from me, and hath not told me" (<i>ibid.</i>). He took the staff which was in his hand, and gave it to Gehazi, saying to him: Do not speak with thy mouth any word at all; know that<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here “whilst” and omit “know that.”</i> thou goest and placest the staff upon the face of the lad, that he may live.
Now as for Gehazi, the matter was laughable in his eyes,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “before him.” On Gehazi see <i>J.E.</i> v. 580 f.</i> and to every man whom he met || he said: Dost thou believe that this staff will bring the dead to life? Therefore he did not succeed<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> His want of faith led to his failure to restore the child. Moreover, he did not believe that he was dead, because he told Elisha “the lad is not <i>awaked</i>” (2 Kings 4:31).</i> until (Elisha) went on foot and put his face<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “His mouth”; this agrees with the text in 2 Kings 4:34. Perhaps Luria’s suggestion that the reading should be: “his face… and his hands” is correct. John of Damascus, <i>op. cit.</i> iv. 34, refers to the virginity of Elisha; this idea occurs also in Ambrose and other Christian writers. See also Clement. “Two Epistles concerning Virginity,” xiv. (<i>A.N.C.L.</i> xiv. p. 393).</i> upon the face (of the child), and his eyes upon his eyes, and his hands upon his hands, and he began to pray before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the worlds ! Just as Thou didst perform miracles by the hand of Elijah, my master, and brought the dead to life, likewise let this child live; and He was entreated of him, as it is said, "Then he returned, and walked in the house once to and fro; and went up, and stretched himself upon him" (<i>ibid.</i> 35); "and the child sneezed seven times" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Azariah<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “Rabbi Zechariah”; this is also Brode’s reading.</i> said: Know thou the efficacy of charity.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> To cause the dead to be quickened.</i> Come and see from the instance of Shallum,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 78, and <i>J.E.</i> xi. 227.</i> son of Tikvah, who was one of the important men of his generation, giving charity every day. What did he do? He filled the bottle with water, and sat at the entrance of the city, and he would give water to every person who came on the way, restoring his soul to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> To feed the hungry is to restore his soul; cf. Lam. 1:11.</i> On account of the charity which he did, the Holy Spirit rested upon his wife,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> As to whether it also rested on him see <i>J.E., loc. cit.</i>, and cf. Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, which reads “upon him”; see T.B. Megillah, 14b, and Ḳimchi on 2 Kings 22:14, who quotes the entire passage from our <i>P.R.E.</i>; he does not, however, read “upon him.” The reason why the Holy Spirit rested upon Huldah is probably suggested by the special manner of her husband’s charity in pouring out water for the thirsty; cf. Isa. 44:3, and Joel 2:28.</i> as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Insert <span>שנאמר</span>.</i> "So Hilkiah the priest… went unto Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Shallum, the son of Tikvah" (<i>ibid.</i> xxii. 14). Originally his name was "the son of Sachrah";<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See 1 Chron. xxxiv. 22: “the son of Hasrah,” <i>i.e.</i> “<i>Ch</i>a<i>s</i>rah”—this becomes “<i>S</i>a<i>ch</i>rah” by interchanging the first two letters of the name, just as the Massorites have done with the name “Tikvah” in this verse. “Sachrah” means “merchandise.” See also 2 Kings 22:14.</i> just as thou dost say, "Merchandise is better<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the Venice edition.</i> than the circulation of money" (Prov. 3:14). One Scripture text || says, "The son of Sachrah."<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation is unknown to me; see, however, previous note (<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>).</i> When her husband died, the charitable deeds of her husband ceased,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew word for ceased is “Chasrah.” The Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc.</i>, reads: “The charity of her husband failed that righteous woman”; cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 47a, and T.B. Chullin, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and all Israel went forth to show loving-kindness to Shallum, son of Tikvah. But they spied the band,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “that was coming against them.”</i> and they cast the man into the sepulchre of Elisha,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ecclus. xlviii. 13.</i> and he came to life, as it is said, "And as soon as the man touched the bones of Elisha, he revived" (2 Kings 13:21); and afterwards he begat Chanameel,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> vi. p. 203, s.v. Hanameel, son of Shallum and Huldah.</i> as it is said, "Behold, Chanameel the son of Shallum thine uncle shall come unto thee" (Jer. 32:7).
Rabbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Chananiah ben Teradion.”</i> said: Know thou the power of charity.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The text here is probably corrupt. Instead of reading, “the power of charity,” we should perhaps read, “the power of righteous people.” Luria thinks that the whole phrase is out of place. The narrative fits in better at the end of Chapter XXXI.</i> Come and see from (the instance of) Saul, the son of Kish, who removed the witches and the necromancers from off the earth, and once again he loved that which he had hated.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum on 1 Sam. 28:7 ff.; Lev. Rab. 26:7; Midrash Samuel xxiv.</i> He went to En Dor, to the wife<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Ḳimchi, on 1 Sam. 28:7, reads: “to a woman who had a familiar spirit, Zephaniah.” See also Midrash Samuel, <i>loc. cit.</i>, and Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> of Zephaniah, the mother of Abner, and he inquired of her for himself by the familiar spirit, and she brought for him Samuel the prophet, and the dead saw Samuel ascending, and they ascended with him,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 4b, and cf. Ascension of Isaiah 9:17.</i> thinking that the resurrection of the dead had come,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, ii. § 140, adds that Samuel brought Moses with him. Thinking it was the great Day of the Last Judgment, Moses would testify on behalf of Samuel; see Midrash Samuel, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and the woman beheld, and she became very much confused, as it is said, "And the king said unto her, Be not afraid: for what seest thou?" (1 Sam. 28:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> “For what dost thou see?” is added by Luria.</i> Some say: Many righteous men like (Samuel) came up with him in that hour.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps this sentence is a gloss added by some copyist, taken from Midrash Samuel or Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
Rabbi Eliezer said: All the dead will arise at the resurrection of the dead, dressed in their shrouds.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and they will ascend in their garments. From what dost thou learn this?” Luria reads: “When all the dead arise,” etc. On the analogy employed by our author, see 1 Cor. xv. 36 ff., where the same thought occurs, and cf. T.B. Kethuboth, 111b; T.B. Synhedrin, 96b; and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, which reads: “clothed in their shrouds.”</i> Know thou that this is the case. Come and see from (the analogy of) the one who plants (seed) in the earth. He plants naked<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “From the seed in the earth, by an inference <i>a minori ad majus</i> with reference to wheat. What happens to the (seed of) wheat? It is buried in a naked condition and it comes forth.”</i> (seeds) || and they arise covered with many coverings; and the people who descend into the earth dressed (with their garments), will they not rise up dressed (with their garments)?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “how much more so will this apply to the righteous who were buried with their garments.” See 1 Cor. xv. 42 ff. for a similar discussion. See Gen. Rab. 96:6; T.B. Sabbath, 114a; Semachoth ix. on the question as to whether the garments used at the burial will be the garments of the resurrection.</i> Not only this, but come and see from Chananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who went down into the fiery furnace dressed in their garments,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and they came out in their garments, as it is said, ‘Nor was the hair of their head singed’” (Dan. 3:27).</i> as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 92b; and Sepher Chassidim, § 1129.</i> "And the satraps… being gathered together, saw these men, that the fire had no power upon their bodies… neither were their hosen changed" (Dan. 3:27). Learn<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And again, from whom canst thou learn this.”</i> from Samuel, the prophet, who came up clothed with his robe, as it is said, "And she said, An old man cometh up; and he is covered with a robe" (1 Sam. 28:14).
Rabbi Jochanan<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Nathan.”</i> said: All the prophets prophesied in their lifetime, and Samuel prophesied in his lifetime, and after his death, because Samuel said to Saul: If thou wilt hearken to my advice to fall by the sword, then shall thy death be an atonement for thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Death as an atonement is discussed by Schechter, <i>Aspects</i>, pp. 304, 307 f. See also T.B. Synhedrin, 44b, on this theme.</i> and thy lot<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Dan. 12:13 for a parallel expression.</i> shall be with me in the place where I abide.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Samuel, <i>loc. cit.</i>; and compare the words which are said to have been spoken by the Founder of Christianity to the penitent thief, Luke xxiii. 43.</i> Saul harkened to his advice, and fell by the sword, he and all his sons,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The text quoted in support of this continues: “and his armour-bearer, and all his men.” In 1 Chron. 10:6 the reading is: “So Saul died, and his three sons; and all <i>his house</i> died together.” The Targum to this passage renders “his house” by “the men of his house.” The first editions read: “he and all his house.”</i> as it is said, "So Saul died, and his three sons" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxi. 6). Why? So that his portion might be with Samuel the prophet in the future life, as it is said, "And to morrow shalt thou and thy sons be with me" (<i>ibid.</i> xxviii. 19). What is the meaning of "with me"? Rabbi Jochanan said: With me in my division in heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>, and T.B. Berakhoth, 12b, which is probably the source of the Midrash, and cf. Midrash Samuel, x.</i>
Hillel, the Elder, said: Samuel spake to Saul, saying, Was it not enough for thee that thou didst not hearken || unto His voice, neither didst thou execute His fierce anger upon Amalek,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 388.</i> but thou dost also inquire<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “to inquire through one possessed of a familiar spirit and to seek.” The first editions read: “Thou art come to inquire for thyself through one possessed of a familiar spirit.”</i> through one possessed of a familiar spirit,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gesenius (Oxford edition), <i>s.v.</i> <span>אוב</span>.</i> and thou seekest (to know the future). Woe is the shepherd, and woe is his flock! For on thy account has the Holy One, blessed be He, given Israel thy people into the hands of the Philistines, as it is said, "Moreover, the Lord will deliver Israel also with thee into the hand of the Philistines" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Tachanah<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Jochanan.” This is also the reading in the Jalḳuṭ Makhiri on Zech. 3:1, p. 35 (ed. Greenup).</i> said: Israel was exiled<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “went up.” This story is one of the versions of the Susanna narrative; see Brüll’s <i>Jahrbücher</i>, iii. pp. 8 ff., where Origen is quoted, who knew the story and refers to Zedekiah and Ahab.</i> to Babylon, and did not forsake their evil deeds. Ahab, son of Kolaiah, and Zedekiah, son of Maaseiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jer. 29:21, 23.</i> became lying healers,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 93a; Tanchuma, Vajiḳra, § vi. The incident may be based on Job 13:4. Cf. Ezek. 13:6, and xxii. 28.</i> and they healed the wives of the Chaldeans, and came unto them for coition.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See also Jalḳuṭ ii. § 309; Pesiḳta de R. Kahana xxv. pp. 164b.</i> The king heard thereof, and commanded that they should be burnt. They both said: Let us say that Joshua, the son of Jehozadak, was with us, and he will save<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chullin, 7a. The first editions read: “Let Joshua, the son of Jehozadak, a righteous man, come with us and we shall be saved through his merit.”</i> us from the burning with fire. They said to him: O our lord, O king, this man was with us in every matter. The king commanded that the three should be burnt by fire. And the angel Michael<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ẓohar, Gen. 104a.</i> descended and saved Joshua from the fiery flames, and brought him up before the throne of glory, as it is said, "And he shewed me Joshua,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “Jehozadak”; the verse is correctly quoted in the first editions.</i> the high priest" (Zech. 3:1); and the other two were burnt by fire, as it is said, "And of them shall be taken up a curse…. The Lord make thee like Zedekiah and like Ahab, whom the king of Babylon roasted in the fire" (Jer. 29:22). It is not written here "whom the king of Babylon burnt with fire," but "whom he roasted,"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Zech., <i>loc. cit.</i>, adds: “like these ears of corn he roasted them.” Is this part of the original text?</i> hence we learn || that his<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Joshua’s.</i> hairs were singed on account of their sins, as it is said, "In the pride of the wicked the poor is <i>hotly</i> pursued" (Ps. 10:2). Whence do we know that he was delivered? Because it is said, "And the Lord said unto Satan, The Lord rebuke thee, O Satan.… Is not this a brand plucked out of the fire?" (Zech. 3:2).
Rabbi Jehudah said: When Nebuchadnezzar brought a false accusation<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “wantonness of words”; baseless charges. Cf. Deut. 22:14, 17.</i> against Israel to slay them, he set up an idol in the plain of Dura, and caused a herald to proclaim: Any one who does not bow down to this idol shall be burnt by fire. Israel did not trust in the shadow<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 62, for this expression.</i> of their Creator, and came with their wives and sons and bowed down to the idolatrous image<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 12a; Cant. Rab. 7:6. The image is discussed in T.B. Berakhoth, 58b.</i>—except Daniel, whom they called by the name of their God,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Luria’s reading. Daniel was called Belteshazzar. “Bel” is, of course, a name of a Babylonian image or god.</i> and it would have been a disgrace to them to burn him<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Daniel.</i> in fire, as it is said, "But at the last Daniel came in before me"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse continues: “whose name was Belteshazzar, according to the name of my God.”</i> (Dan. 4:8). And they took Chananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, and put them into the fiery furnace, and the angel Gabriel<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In Jalḳuṭ, on Ezek. 37 § 375, the reading is Michael; see Gen. Rab. 44:13. Our reading agrees with T.B. Pesachim, 118a; Pesiḳta Rabbathi, p. 160b; Ex. Rab. xviii. 5; and see Jalḳuṭ on Dan., <i>in loc.</i>, and T.B. Synhedrin, 95b. It is noteworthy that Daniel is not mentioned here; he was therefore not cast into the furnace.</i> descended and saved them from the fiery furnace.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 55, note 1.</i> The king said to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrews who had worshipped his image.</i> Ye knew that ye had a God who saves and delivers; why have ye forsaken your God and worshipped idols which have no power to deliver? But just as ye did in your own land and destroyed it, so do ye attempt to do in this land, (namely) to destroy it. The king commanded, || and they slew all of them. Whence do we know that they were all slain by the sword? Because it is said, "Then said he unto me, Prophesy… O breath, and breathe upon these <i>slain</i>, that they may live" (Ezek. 37:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 5 p. 24, and <i>J.E.</i> ix. 202 f.</i>
Rabbi Phineas said: After twenty years, when all of them had been slain in Babylon,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 92b, and Tanchuma, Noah. § x.: “On the day when the three companions were delivered Ezekiel quickened the dead in the valley of Dura.” See Pal. Targum, Ex. 13:17, on the sons of Ephraim, who were slain for attempting to leave Egypt before the appointed time. See also Shibbolê Ha-Leḳeṭ, 219. According to one authority in T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc, cit.</i>, “the whole incident was indeed a parable.”</i> the Holy Spirit rested upon Ezekiel, and brought him forth into the plain of Dura, and called unto him very dry bones, and said to him: Son of Man ! What dost thou see? He answered: I see here dry bones. (The Spirit) said to him: Have I power to revive them? The prophet did not say:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the negative. The later editions (<i>e.g.</i> Amsterdam and Prague) read: “he should have said.”</i> Sovereign of all the worlds ! Thou hast power to do even more than (this) here; but he said: "O Lord God, thou knowest" (<i>ibid.</i> 3), as though he did not believe;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 19:11; Ẓohar, Num. 200a; Jalḳuṭ, Kings, § 244.</i> therefore his own bones were not <i>buried</i> in a pure land,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the land of Israel.</i> but in an unclean land, as it is said, "And thou shalt die in a land that is unclean" (Amos 7:17).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation from Amos is very strange, inasmuch as it is applied to Ezekiel as a prophecy concerning his <i>burial.</i> Moreover, the prophet refers to death, which might be quite distinct from the burial of the prophet. See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>, and cf. <i>J.E.</i> v. 315 f., for further parallels to this story.</i> "Prophesy over these bones" (Ezek. 37:4). He said before Him: Sovereign of all the worlds ! What ! will the prophecy bring upon them flesh and sinews and bones?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Read here “skin,” as in the text of Ezek. 37:8.</i> Or will the prophecy bring upon them all the flesh and bones which cattle, beast, and bird have eaten, and they (also) have died in the land?<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in another land.” This is probably the correct reading, as it occurs again in this section, and, therefore, what was missing would have to be miraculously restored by God. The prophet had his doubts as to whether this would or could be accomplished. Interesting parallels to this discussion are to be found in the writings of the Church Fathers; see Athenagoras, “Resurrection of the Dead,” ch. iv., and Tertullian, mentioned <i>infra</i>, p. 251, note.</i> Immediately the Holy One, blessed be He, caused His voice to be heard, and the earth shook, as it is said, "And as I prophesied there was a thundering, and behold an earthquake" (<i>ibid.</i> 7), || and every animal, beast, and bird which had eaten thereof and died in another land<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The words from “every animal” till “another land” occur only in our MS.</i> the earth brought together, "bone to his bone" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. § 375: “He caused His voice to be heard from between the two Cherubim”; see <i>supra</i>, p. 228, and cf. Ps. 99:1.</i>
Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: There came down upon them the quickening dew<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 260.</i> from heaven, which was like a fountain,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading in Jalḳuṭ, Ezekiel, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> which was bubbling and bringing forth water; so likewise (the bones) were moving and bringing forth upon themselves flesh, (other) bones<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Instead of “bones” we should probably read “skin”; see <i>supra</i>, p. 249, note 5.</i> and sinews, as it is said, "And I beheld, and lo, there were sinews upon them, and flesh came up, and <i>skin</i> covered them above" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). He said to him: Prophesy unto the wind, as it is said, "Then said he unto me, Prophesy unto<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads incorrectly “against.”</i> the wind.… Come from the four winds, O breath, and breathe upon these slain, that they may live" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). In that hour the four winds of the heaven went forth, and opened the treasure-house of the souls, and each spirit returned to the body of flesh of man, as it is said, "So I prophesied as he commanded me, and the breath came into them, and they lived,… an <i>exceeding</i> great army" (<i>ibid.</i> 10); and it is written about Egypt, "And the children of Israel were fruitful,… and waxed <i>exceeding</i> mighty" (Ex. 1:7). What is the meaning of "exceeding"? Just as in the latter case there were 600,000 (men), so in the former case there were 600,000 (men), and they all stood upon their feet except one man. The prophet said: Sovereign of all the worlds ! What is the nature of this man? He answered him: He gave out money for usury,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on Ezekiel, <i>loc. cit.</i>, which reads: “And he took usury and he shall not live (eternally).” This is based on Ezek. 18:8. See Ex. Rab. xxxi. 3, and see Tosaphoth T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 70b, catch-word, “Thou mayest lend”; cf. Pal. Targum, Ex. 13:17. See also Tosaphoth Soṭah, 5a.</i> and he took with interest. || As I live, he shall not live. In that hour the Israelites were sitting and weeping, and saying: We hoped for light, and darkness came. We hoped to stand up with <i>all</i> Israel at the resurrection of the dead, and now "our hope is lost" (Ezek. 37:11). We hoped to arise so as to be gathered with <i>all</i> Israel, and now "we are clean cut off" (<i>ibid.</i>). In that hour the Holy One, blessed be He, said to the prophet: Therefore, say to them, As I live, I will cause you to stand at the resurrection of the dead in the future that is to come, and I will gather you with all Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads here: “for the ingathering of the exiles to the land of Israel.” On the vision in Ezek. 37 see Cant. Rab. 7:9. Maimonides, <i>Moreh Nebukhim</i>, ii. 46, regarded the “resurrection” as a prophetic vision; see T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i>, for the Talmudic account. The doubt of Ezekiel is noted by Tertullian, <i>On the Resurrection of the Flesh</i>, xxx. In this passage the Church Father interprets the vision in a literal sense, rejecting the allegorical meaning which was given to the vision in his day. Justin Martyr (<i>First Apology</i>, lii.) refers to this prophecy as pointing to the resurrection to be brought about by the Christian Messiah at his second coming; his words are: “By Ezekiel the prophet it was said: ‘Joint shall be joined to joint, and bone to bone, and flesh shall grow again; and every knee shall bow to the Lord, and every tongue shall confess Him’” (Ezek. 37:7, 8, and Isa. 45:23). This may serve as a fair illustration of the method of quoting the Hebrew Scriptures by the Church Fathers.</i> to the land, as it is said, "Behold, I will open your graves, and cause you to come up out of your graves… and I will bring you into the land of Israel.… And I will put my spirit in you, and ye shall live" (<i>ibid.</i> 12, 14).

Chapter 34

CHAPTER XXXIV<br><small>THE RESURRECTION OF THE DEAD</small> [43<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>"S<small>EE</small> now that I, even I, am he,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, in the first editions the verse is continued and the first editions add: “What purpose has the text in saying twice ‘I, even I’?” See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i>, and Othijoth de R. ‘Aḳiba (<i>B.H.M.</i> iii. p. 17), letter <span>א</span>: “I was before the world, and I am after the world.” See also T.B. Berakhoth, 9b, Jalḳuṭ, Deut. § 946, and cf. Methodius, “On the Resurrection,” v. (<i>A.N.C.L.</i> xiv. p. 141).</i> and there is no God with me" (Deut. 32:89). Only the Holy One, blessed be He, said: "<i>I am</i>" in this world, and "<i>I am</i>" in the world to come; <i>I am</i> the one who redeemed Israel from Egypt, and <i>I am</i> the one who, in the future, will redeem them at the end of the fourth kingdom; therefore it is said, "I, even I, am he, and there is no God with me" (<i>ibid.</i>). Every nation who say that there is a second God, I will slay them as with a second death<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Dan. xiii. 2. Cf. Rev. xx. 6, 14, xxi. 8, and see Midrash Tannaïm, ed. Hoffmann, p. 202, and Siphrê, Deut. § 329.</i> || which has no resurrection; and every nation who say that there is no second God, I will quicken them for the eternal life. And in the future I will slay those (first mentioned) and quicken these, therefore it is said, "I kill, and I make alive" (<i>ibid.</i>). I have wounded<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> God destroyed Jerusalem, and He will rebuild it; cf. Lam. 1:17.</i> Jerusalem and her people on the day of My anger, and in great mercy<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 54:7, 11 f., and Jer. 33:6, 9.</i> I <i>will</i> heal them,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 30:26, and cf. Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 147 (end).</i> therefore it is said, "I have wounded, and I <i>will</i> heal" (<i>ibid.</i>). Neither any angel nor any seraph<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “‘I, even I,’ says God, ‘I will deliver them, I alone.’”</i> will deliver the wicked from the judgment of Gehinnom, as it is said, "And there is none that can deliver out of my hand" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Jochanan<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Jonathan.”</i> said: All the dead will arise at the resurrection of the dead, except the generation of the Flood,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 107b, and Aboth de Rabbi Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxxvi. pp. 53b ff.</i> as it is said, "The dead shall not live, the deceased (Rephaim)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Rephaim (giants) are the men of the generation of the Flood. See <i>supra</i>, pp. 160 f., 167, and Gen. Rab. 31:12.</i> shall not rise" (Isa. 26:14). "The dead (who) shall not live" refer to the heathens, who are like the carcase of cattle;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> doomed to destruction. Cf. the directions laid down for the conduct of Christians towards heathens, in Clement, “Two Epistles concerning Virginity,” vi. (<i>A.N.C.L.</i> xiv. pp. 387 f.). See <i>supra</i>, p. 208, n. 7.</i> they shall arise for the day of judgment,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Messianic age, or, rather, at the close of the reign of Messiah.</i> yet they shall not live; but the men of the generation of the Flood, even for the day of judgment they shall not arise, as it is said, "The Rephaim shall not rise" (<i>ibid.</i>). All their souls become winds,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “spirits who injure.”</i> accursed, injuring<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “Demons unto man”; see Jalḳuṭ Isa. <i>in loc.</i></i> the sons of men, and in the future world the Holy One, blessed be He, will destroy them out of the world, so that they should not do harm to a single Israelite, as it is said, "Therefore hast thou visited and destroyed them,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS., it is continued in the first editions.</i> and made all their memory to perish" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 25b.</i>
Rabbi Zechariah said: The sleep at night is like this world, and the awakening of the morning<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Isa. 26:19. Cf. Hippolytus (ed. Achelis), p. 107.</i> is like the world to come. And just as || in the sleep of the night a man lies down and sleeps, and his spirit wanders over all the earth, and tells him in a dream<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Eccles. 10:20, and see Midrash Rab. thereon; cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 18b, Gen. Rab. 14:9, and <i>supra</i>, p. 87.</i> whatever happens, as it is said, "In a dream, in a vision of the night… then he openeth the ears of men" (Job 33:15, 16), likewise (with) the dead, their spirit wanders over all the earth, and tells them all things<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of the Venice edition.</i> that happen in the world, but they are silent and (yet) they give song and praise to God, who will quicken them in the future, as it is said, "Let the saints exult in glory"<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Even in the grave the saints continue to glorify God. See Ps. 149:5; Jalḳuṭ, 1 Kings, § 169; and Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 30 p. 117b.</i> (Ps. 149:5). The awakening in the morning is like the future world. A parable<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The parable is only found in our MS. Cf. 1 Cor. xv. 20, 51; 1 Thess. iv. 14; and Eph. v. 14.</i>—unto what is the matter to be likened? To a man who awakens out of his sleep, in like manner will the dead awaken in the future world, as it is said, "O satisfy us in the <i>morning</i> with thy loving-kindness"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse continues: “and let us sing and rejoice <i>all</i> our days.” See Jalḳuṭ Makhiri on Ps. 90 p. 44a; T.B. Berakhoth, 18b. “The wicked sleep the eternal sleep, never to awaken in the future.” Cf. Jer. 51:39 and Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> (<i>ibid.</i> xc. 14).
The voices of five (objects of creation)<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Brode and Luria read “six.” In fact there are “six” cases enumerated according to the text of the first printed editions. The MS. has five instances only.</i> go from one end of the world to the other, and their voices are inaudible.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 20b, where four examples only are given. Jalḳuṭ, Psalms, § 743, has used our author. See Gen. Rab. 6:7. The first editions add: “and they are.”</i> When people cut down the wood of the tree<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This may be based on Deut. 20:19. See also Jer. 46:22 and Targum thereon.</i> which yields fruit, its cry goes from one end of the world to the other, and the voice is inaudible. When the serpent sloughs off its skin,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 99, Gen. Rab. 20:5. Cf. The Baraitha of the 32 Middoth, No. 14, ed. Reifmann, pp. 33f.</i> its cry goes from one end of the world to the other and its voice is not heard.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “The voice goeth forth from one end of the world to the other.” It occurs in the Amsterdam edition. Cf. Jer. 46:22.</i> When a woman is divorced from her husband,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mal. 2:14–16.</i> her voice goeth forth from one end of the world to the other, but the voice is inaudible.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “When a wife is with her husband at the first coition, her voice goeth forth from one end of the world to the other, but the voice is inaudible.”</i> When the infant || comes forth from its mother's<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 26:17, and xlii. 14; T.B. Joma, <i>loc. cit.</i>, and Lev. Rab. 27:7.</i> womb.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the cry goeth forth from one end of the world to the other, and the voice is not heard.”</i> When the soul departs from the body,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> the cry goes forth from one end of the world to the other, and the voice is not heard. The soul does not go out of the body until it beholds the Shekhinah, as it is said, "For man shall not see me and <i>live</i>" (Ex. 33:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 103; Siphra (beg.), and <i>infra</i>, p. 430.</i>
Rabbi Ẓe'era<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “‘Aẓariah.”</i> said: All the souls go forth and are gathered, each man's soul to the generation of his fathers and to his people.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Death reunites, whereas in life separation and dispersion are frequent experiences. See Ps. 49:19.</i> The righteous with the righteous,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 77, and Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 3:9.</i> and the wicked with the wicked, for thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, to Abraham: "But thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace" (Gen. 15:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “When the soul goes forth from the body, is this peace? But the angels come to meet (it) and say to it: Peace, as it is said: ‘He entereth into peace; they rest in their beds’ (Isa. 57:2). Another verse says: ‘Thou shalt be gathered to thy grave in peace’” (2 Kings 22:20).</i> And when the soul goes forth from the body,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests that the text should read: “What is the peace?” (Is there any peace for the body when the soul leaves it?) See also T.B. Sabbath, 152b. See the Book of the Bee lvi. pp. 131 ff. for a parallel to our text.</i> then the righteous come to meet them,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the souls. See Roḳeach, 313, which has used <i>P.R.E.</i>; the reading here is: “The righteous come before the souls.” See also T.B. Kethuboth, 104a, and Num. Rab. 11:7.</i> and say to them: Come unto peace ! One verse says, "Therefore, behold, I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt be gathered to thy grave in peace" (2 Kings 22:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 2 Chron. 34:28. Our MS. has omitted part of the verse, the first editions read the latter part only.</i>
Rab Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Rabbi Chanina.”</i> said: All Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read: “All the righteous.”</i> who die outside the land (of Israel), their souls<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Immediately after death.</i> are gathered into the land (of Israel), as it is said, "Yet the soul of my lord shall be bound in the bundle of the living"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The land of the living is the Holy Land; when David was an exile from the Holy Land he cries that he cannot worship God. See 1 Sam. 26:19.</i> (1 Sam. 25:29). All the heathens who die<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Some of the later editions read: “All the dead (bodies) of the wicked.” The Amsterdam and Prague editions read: “All the dead (bodies) of the idolaters.”</i> in the land of Israel have their souls cast outside the land (of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the reading of the Amsterdam and Prague editions.</i>), as it is said, "And the souls of thine enemies, them shall he sling out, as from the hollow of a sling" (<i>ibid.</i>), (even) beyond the land (of Israel).
In the future world the Holy One, blessed be He, will take hold of the corners of the land of Israel, and shake it (free) from all unclean (things),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “like a man shakes a garment and casts out all that is therein and throws this away.”</i> as it is said, "That it might take hold of the ends of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and the wicked be shaken out of it" (Job 38:13).
A man has three friends || in his lifetime, and they are: his sons and his household,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Aboth 6:9, Jalḳuṭ, Isa. § 494; Jalḳuṭ, Ps. § 834, reads “household.” Bachja in Kad Ha-Ḳemach, <i>s.v.</i> <span>אבל</span>, pp. 12a–b, quotes <i>P.R.E.</i> and reads: “his wife and his sons.” The latter reading is to be found in the first editions. Cf. also Menorath Ha-Maor, 278. See Israel Lévi’s article on this passage in <i>R.É.J.</i> xviii. pp. 83 ff., where he discusses the influence of “Barlaam and Josaphat” in this parable. “Barlaam and Josaphat” was written in the seventh century probably, and was known to the author of <i>P.R.E.</i> in its Greek or Arabic or Syrian version. See also Geiger, <i>Was hat Mohammed</i>, etc., p. 93, and <i>J.E.</i> ii. pp. 536 f.</i> his money, and his good deeds. At the hour of a man's departure from the world he gathers his sons and his household, and he says to them: I beg of you to come and save me from the judgment of this evil death.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is an explanation of Ps. 49:5, “Why should I fear in the days of evil?” (<i>i.e.</i> death).</i> They answer him, saying to him: Hast thou not heard that there is no one who can prevail over the day of death? and is it not written thus, "None of them can by any means redeem his brother" (Ps. 49:7)?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “The first editions read here: “Even his money which he loves cannot redeem him, as it is said: ‘Nor give to God a ransom for him’ (Ps. 49:7). Why?”</i> "For the redemption of their soul is costly"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Siphrê, Deut. § 329, says: “If they give to Him all the money in the world they would not be able to give Him his ransom.” The first editions add here the following: “And this thing must be let alone ‘for ever’ (Ps. 49:8), but go towards peace and rest on thy couch, and stand for thy lot at the end of days, and may thy lot be with the pious of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> When he sees (things) in this way.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> (<i>ibid.</i> 8). And he has his money fetched, and says to it:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “For thee have I toiled very much by night and by day.” See Eccles. 5:10–15 on the folly of heaping up wealth.</i> I beseech thee, save me from the judgment of this evil death. It answers him, saying: Hast thou not heard, "Riches profit not in the day of wrath"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the day of death. The text might be rendered “the day of passing away” (from this life). Cf. Eccles. 8:8.</i> (Prov. 11:4)? He (then) has his good deeds fetched, and he says to them: I beseech you, come and deliver me from the judgment of this evil death.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “and strengthen yourselves with me,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and do not leave me to depart from the world, for ye still have hope for me that I may be saved.”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> And they answer him and say to him:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Go towards peace.”</i> Before thou goest, verily, we will go in advance of thee, as it is said, "And charity delivereth from death" (<i>ibid.</i>). Does then charity deliver from death? (This refers) to an evil death only. Another Scripture says, "And thy righteousness shall go before thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS., it is continued in the first editions.</i> the glory of the Lord shall be thy rearward" (Isa. 58:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In Jalḳuṭ, Isa. <i>loc. cit.</i>, the verse: “And righteousness delivereth from death” (Prov. 10:2) is quoted. This is also to be found in the Kad Ha-Ḳemach, <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
All the seven days of mourning the soul goeth forth and returneth from its (former) home to its sepulchral abode, and from its sepulchral abode to its (former) home.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is omitted in the printed editions. See 4 Ezra 7:31.</i> After the seven days of mourning the body || begins to breed worms,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Roḳeach, 313, based upon our author; cf. T.B. Sabbath, 152a, and T.J. Mo’ed Ḳaṭan iii. 5. 82b.</i> and it decays and returns to the dust,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Niddah, 69b, and T.B. Sabbath, 152b. The return to dust is considerably later than the first seven days after death.</i> as it originally was, as it is said, "And the dust returns to the earth as it was"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The next sentence is not found in the printed editions.</i> (Eccles. 12:7). The soul goes forth and returns to the place whence it was given, from heaven, as it is said, "And the soul<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. text does not agree with the M.T. “Nephesh,” which we have rendered soul, should be “ruach,” spirit.</i> returns unto God who gave it" (<i>ibid.</i>). And whence do we learn that the soul has been given from heaven?<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> by God.</i> Come and see. When the Holy One, blessed be He, formed man, he did not have in him the spirit.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the spirit of the soul.” See <i>supra</i>, p. 78, n. 2. Cf. Tertullian, <i>On the Resurrection</i>, v.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He breathed with the spirit of the breath of His mouth, and cast a soul<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “breath.”</i> into him, as it is said, "And he breathed into his nostrils the breath of life" (Gen. 2:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The breath of life came from God and returns to Him.</i>
Rabbi Ishmael<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Simeon.”</i> said: All the bodies crumble<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Read <span>ננועין</span>, and cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 77.</i> into the dust of the earth, until nothing remains of the body except a spoonful of earthy matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “rottenness.” See T. J. Naẓir vii. 2, 56b, and Lev. Rab. 18:1. The Venice edition adds here: “And it becomes mixed with the dust of the earth like yeast, which is mixed with the dough.”</i> In the future life, when the Holy One, blessed be He, calls<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Voice of God will usher in the resurrection, see <i>supra</i>, p. 249; see also Othijoth de R. ‘Aḳiba; <i>B.H.M.</i> iii. p. 60. Cf. 4 Ezra 7:32; Apoc. Baruch xi. 4; 1 Thess. iv. 13, 15; and 2 Pet. iii. 4.</i> to the earth to return all the bodies deposited with it,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 335. The earth holds the bodies until the resurrection. The day of death is called the “day of Account” (Isa. 10:3); cf. Num. 16:29, “the visiting of every man.”</i> that which had become mixed with the dust of the earth, like the yeast which is mixed with the dough, improves and increases, and it raises up all the body.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first edition adds: “without water.” This became in the Venice edition: “without a blemish.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 91a, and Gen. Rab. 95:1.</i> When the Holy One, blessed be He, calls to the earth to return all the bodies deposited with it, that which has become mixed with the dust of the earth, improves and increases and raises up all the body without water.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is not in the printed texts. It is practically a repetition of the previous sentence. The first editions read instead: “like the leaven which improves and increases the dough.”</i> Forthwith the earth quakes and the mountains tremble,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 36b. See Arabic version of 4 Ezra 7:32 (ed. Box, p. 119).</i> and the graves are opened,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ezek. 37:13.</i> and the stones of the graves are scattered about one from the other, as it is said, "And the Lord God shall save them || in that day as the flock of his people:<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> for they shall be as the stones of a crown, lifted on high over his land" (Zech. 9:16).
Rabbi Azariah said: All the souls are in the hands of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "In whose hand is the soul of every living thing"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> After death. The parable illustrates this idea. This does not agree with the interpretation given in Siphrê, Num. § 139, quoted in Jalḳuṭ on Job, <i>in loc.</i></i> (Job 12:10). A parable—to what is the matter like? To a person who was going in the market with the key of his house in his hand. As long as the key is in his hand, all his money is in his hand. Likewise the Holy One, blessed be He, has the key of the graves,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ta’anith 2b, “For I am the Lord, when I open your graves.”</i> and the key of the treasure-houses of the souls;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “In the future life the Holy One, blessed be He, will open the graves, and He will open the treasure-houses of the souls.” See 4 Ezra 4:35, vii. 32; T. B. Chagigah, 12b; and Siphrê Deut. § 344.</i> and He will restore every spirit to the body of flesh of man, as it is said, "Thou sendest forth thy spirit,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Thereby reviving the spirit of man. Cf. Athenagoras, <i>Resurrection of the Dead</i>, xxv.</i> they are created;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> and thou renewest the face of the ground"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The earth will be renewed after the resurrection.</i> (Ps. 104:30).
The soul is like its Creator.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria adds: if one may so without irreverence.” On this expression, see Bacher, <i>Terminologie</i>, i. pp. 72 f.</i> Just as the Holy One, blessed be He, sees and is not visible, so the soul sees and is not visible.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 10a, and Deut. Rab. ii. 37, where six points of similarity are enumerated; cf. Lev. Rab. 4:8. On God’s seeing, cf. Jer. 23:24; on God’s invisibility, see Ex. 33:20 and Isa. 45:15. See similar theories in Tertullian, <i>de Anima</i>, xlv.; and Methodius, <i>Banquet</i>, vi. 1.</i> Just as the Holy One, blessed be He, has no sleep in His presence,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 121:4; and Gen. Rab. 14:9.</i> so the soul does not sleep.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 86.</i> Just as the Holy One, blessed be He, bears His world,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Isa. 46:4.</i> so the soul bears all the body.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Luria’s reading.</i> All souls are His, as it is said, "Behold, all souls are mine" (Ezek. 18:4).
Rabbi Jehudah said: From the day when the Temple was destroyed, the land (of Israel) is <i>broken down</i> on account of the wickedness of those who dwell therein; like a man who is sick and has no power to stand, so is the land broken down and is without power to yield her fruits, as it is said, "The earth also is polluted under the inhabitants thereof" (Isa. 24:5).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See the earlier part of the verse.</i>
In the future life the Holy One, blessed be He, will cause the reviving dew to descend, and He will quicken the dead and renew all things, as it is said, "<i>Thy</i> dead shall live" (<i>ibid.</i> xxvi. 19). They are the Israelites, who died trusting in His name. || "<i>My</i> dead bodies shall arise" (<i>ibid.</i>). They are the heathens, who are like the carcase of the beast;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> A similar statement occurs in Tertullian, <i>On the Resurrection, A.N.C.L.</i> xv. p. 311.</i> they shall arise for the day of judgment, but they shall not live. "Awake and sing, ye that dwell in the dust" (<i>ibid.</i>). They are the righteous, for they dwell<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The righteous dead are called “living.” See T.B. Soṭah, 5a, and T.B. Berakhoth, 18a. Cf. 4 Ezra 7:35, 36, 61 to illustrate the preceding part of the paragraph.</i> in the dust. "For thy dew is as the dew of light" (<i>ibid.</i>). The dew of the righteous is not the dew of darkness,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The dew of nature descends at night (see Job 29:19), and is called “the dew of darkness.” There is also “the dew of light,” which is the heavenly or spiritual dew.</i> but (it is) the dew of light, as it is said, "For thy dew is as the dew of light" (<i>ibid.</i>); and it gives healing to the earth, as it is said, "And the earth shall cast forth the dead"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Rephaim; the root of this word means “to heal.” See Cant. Rab. on Cant. 5:2.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). And what is the meaning of "And the earth shall cast forth the dead"?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “What is the meaning of ‘it giveth healing to the earth’?”</i>
Rabbi Tanchum said<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This is probably a gloss, copied from T.J. Berakhoth 5:2. 9b. It is only this sentence which belongs to Rabbi Tanchum. Perhaps the saying is merely that the earth will disgorge the dead entrusted to its keeping.</i>: On account of the seed of the earth, when it is commanded, (it) discharges the dew for the resurrection of the dead.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Luria’s reading, and Jalḳuṭ, 1 Kings, § 207.</i> From what place does it descend? From the head of the Holy One, blessed be He; for the head of the Holy One, blessed be He, is full of the reviving dew. In the future life the Holy One, blessed be He, will shake His head<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 130a, and Singer, p. 79, for the “dew of light,” based on Isa. 26:19.</i> and<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Luria’s reading.</i> cause the quickening dew to descend,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and He will revive the dead.”</i> as it is said, "I was asleep,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The righteous sleeps in death, but his heart is ever awake; his soul is fed by the Divine dew which will effect the resurrection.</i> but my heart waked<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i>… for my head is filled with dew, my locks with the drops of the night" (Cant. 5:2).

Chapter 35

CHAPTER XXXV<br><small>THE VISION OF JACOB AT BETHEL</small> [45<small>B</small> i.]<br>"B<small>ETTER</small> is the end of a thing than the beginning thereof" (Eccles. 7:8). The first blessings wherewith Isaac blessed Jacob were concerning the dews of heaven, and concerning the corn of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> material blessings of this earthly life.</i> as it is said, "And God give thee of the dew of heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> and of the fatness of the earth" (Gen. 27:28). The final blessings were the blessings of the foundation of the world, and in them there is no (interruption),<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> There is a lacuna in the MS.; the space is just sufficient for the word which occurs in the Oxford MS. or in the first editions, and which means “interruption.”</i> either in this world or in the world to come, as it is said, "And God Almighty bless thee" (<i>ibid.</i> xxviii. 3). And he further added unto him the blessing of Abraham, || as it is said, "And may he give thee the blessing of Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> to thee and to thy seed with thee"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse continues: “that thou mayest inherit the land of thy sojournings.”</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 4). Therefore (say)<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This occurs in the first editions, and is missing in the MS.</i>: "Better is the end of a thing<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The reference is to the final blessing of Jacob. The blessings which he received instead of Esau were but a cause of anguish and sorrow to him as far as material benefits were concerned; cf. Job 8:7.</i> than the beginning thereof" (Eccles. 7:8). "Better is the patient in spirit than the proud in spirit" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “‘Better is slowness to anger than the proud in spirit.’ ‘Better is slowness to anger,’ this (saying),” etc. The Oxford MS. agrees with our text.</i> "Better is the patient in spirit"—this (saying) is applicable<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Read <span>אמור כיעקכ</span>.</i> to our father Jacob, for every day he was patient in spirit, and he spake all kinds of words of entreaty.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “Pangeoth,” so also in first editions. Jastrow corrects this and reads Pagneoth (entreaty); see <i>T.D.</i> 1135a; his reference to our book on 1186a must be corrected so as to read Chapter XXXV. According to Luria the reading should be: “Every day he ate plain food.” The Oxford MS. has: “Every day he ate food which was disqualified” (for the altar).</i> (The words) "than the proud in spirit" (<i>ibid.</i>) refer to the wicked Esau, because every day he was eating the flesh of that which he had hunted. Owing to his pride he did not give any of his food to Jacob. Once he went out to hunt but he did not meet with any success. He saw Jacob eating lentil food, and he desired this in his heart, and he said to him: "Let me gulp down, I pray thee, some of that red pottage" (Gen. 25:30). Jacob said to him: Thou camest forth red at thy birth from thy mother; (now) thou dost desire to eat (this) <i>red</i> food; therefore he called his name "Edom" (red), as it is said, "And Esau said to Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Eliezer said: Lentils are the food of mourning<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, 16b; Pal. Targ. Gen. 25:29, and Gen. Rab. 63:14. Cf. Jerome, Epist. xxii. <i>ad Paulam</i>, quoted in <i>J.Q.R.</i> vi. 227, and Brüll in Kobak’s <i>Jeschurun</i>, viii. 31 ff.</i> and sorrow. Know thou that this is so, for when Abel had been killed, his parents were eating lentil food (as a sign) of their mourning for him in mourning and sorrow.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And when Haran was burned in the furnace of the Chaldees, his parents ate lentil food (as a sign) of their mourning for him in mourning and sorrow.”</i> And Jacob was eating lentil food in mourning and sorrow<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “because of the kingdom and the dominion and the birthright of Esau.”</i> because the kingdom, the dominion, and the birthright belonged to Esau. Moreover, on that day Abraham, his grandfather, died.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that since Jacob was wont to eat lentils, there was no special reason to connect this circumstance with the death of Abraham. See Pesiḳta Rabbathi 12 p. 48a.</i> The Israelites eat lentil food in mourning and sorrow on account of the mourning || and sorrow for the Temple,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The custom of eating lentils on the eve of the Fast of Ab obtained formerly; see Ṭur Orach Chayyim, 552 p. 48a.</i> The Israelites eat lentil food in mourning and sorrow on account of the mourning || and sorrow for the Temple,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The custom of eating lentils on the eve of the Fast of Ab obtained formerly; see Ṭur Orach Chayyim, 552, and cf. Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>, which says that lentils are a suitable repast for mourners because they have no mouth (<i>i.e.</i> slit), like the mourner who in his grief is struck dumb. Moreover, the lentils by their round form typify the going around of trouble and loss in this world. (See <i>J.E.</i> vii. 682.)</i> and on account of the exile of Israel. Hence thou mayest learn that the children of Esau will not fall until a remnant from Israel shall come and give to the children of Esau lentil food in mourning and sorrow, and will take away from them the dominion of the kingdom and the birthright, which Jacob acquired from (Esau) by oath, as it is said, "And Jacob said, Swear to me this day; and he sware unto him" (<i>ibid.</i> 33).
Rabbi ' Aḳiba said: Every place where our forefathers went, the well went in front of them, and they<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that “they” should be deleted, and that instead of this word we should read “Abraham.”</i> dug three times and found it before them.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Three times in connection with Abraham is the digging of a well mentioned. Isaac also had to dig for water. The Midrashim differ as to the number of wells; see Gen. Rab. 64:8. The next sentence in our text occurs only in our MS.</i> Abraham dug three times and found it before him, as it is said, "And Isaac digged again the wells of water, which they had digged in the days of Abraham" (<i>ibid.</i> xxvi. 18). And Isaac dug in the land (of Canaan) four times,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “three times.”</i> and found it before him, as it is said, "And Isaac's servants digged in the valley" (<i>ibid.</i> 19).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote the preceding verse and add the following: “He dug twice in the ground, and found it before him, as it is said, ‘And Isaac’s servants digged in the valley’” (Gen. 26:19).</i> And it is written about Jerusalem, "And it shall come to pass in that day, that living waters shall go out from Jerusalem" (Zech. 14:8). This refers to the well which will arise in Jerusalem in the future,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Messianic age.</i> and will water all its surroundings. Because they found (the well) seven<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Three times by Abraham and four times by Isaac.</i> times, he<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Isaac.</i> called it Shib'ah (seven).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said, ‘And he called it Shib‘ah’ (Gen. 26:33). By the name of the well (Beer) was a city called ‘Beer-Sheba unto this day’” (<i>ibid.</i>).</i>
Jacob was seventy-seven years old<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 17a, and Seder ‘Olam Rab. 2 p. 5a. Jacob was 63 years when he was blessed in place of Esau; he spent 14 years in the “tents” of Shem and Eber; and therefore he was 77 years old when he went to Beer-Sheba.</i> when he went forth from his father's house, and the well went before him.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> On the well in Jewish theology, cf. <i>Hellenism and Christianity</i>, p. 87; see also <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 81 and 263.</i> From Beer-Sheba as far as Mount Moriah is a journey of two days, || and he arrived there<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Mount Moriah; see ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, v. p. 227a, <i>s.v.</i> “Maḳom.”</i> at midday, and the Holy One, blessed be He, met him, as it is said, "And he met in the place,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Maḳom is used also as a title of God. The quotation from Gen. 28:11 might be rendered in the sense of our Midrash, thus: “And he met the Omnipresent” (<i>i.e.</i> God). In the MSS. the quotation ends here.</i> and tarried there all night, because the sun was set" (Gen. 28:11). Why is the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, called Maḳom?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> “Place.” The ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads as our MS. The first editions read: “Why was the place called Maḳom?”</i> Because in every <i>place</i> where the righteous are<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 119, reads: “where the righteous stand” (in prayer).</i> He is found with them<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Hos. 12:4: “He found him in the House of God” (Bethel).</i> there, as it is said, "In every <i>place</i> (Maḳom) where I record my name<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MSS. the quotation ends here.</i> I will come unto thee, and bless thee" (Ex. 20:24). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob ! The bread is in thy bag,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i>; the words are based on 2 Kings 4:42: “fresh ears of corn in his <i>sack</i>.” The Targum on this verse renders this last word “garments.” Perhaps the best word in our context would be “knapsack.”</i> and the well is before thee, so that thou mayest eat and drink<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “and sleep.” It occurs in Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and sleep in this place. He said before Him: Sovereign of all the worlds ! Till now the sun has still fifty degrees to set,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i>, and agrees with the text preserved by Nachmanides, Com. <i>in loc.</i> (Gen.); see T.B. Synhedrin, 95b, and Gen. Rab. 68:10.</i> and I am lying down in this place. And (thereupon) the sun set in the west, although not in its proper time. Jacob looked and saw the sun setting in the west, and he tarried there, as it is said, "And he tarried there all night, because the sun was set" (Gen. 28:11).
Jacob took twelve stones<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 91:6; Gen. Rab. 68:11; Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. 28:11.</i> of the stones of the altar, whereon his father Isaac had been bound, and he set them for his pillow in that place,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “The Omnipresent came to make known to him,” etc.</i> to indicate to himself that twelve tribes were destined to arise from him. And they all became one stone, to indicate to him that all (the tribes) were destined to become one people<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “nation” (<span>נוי</span>), which is used not only of the heathens but also of Israel. Luria reads <span>עם</span> (people); the Venice edition has <span>נוי</span>; this is also the reading of the Amsterdam and Prague editions.</i> on the earth, as it is said, "And who is like thy people Israel, <i>a nation that is alone</i> on the earth" (1 Chron. 17:21).
Rabbi Levi said: In that night the Holy One, blessed be He, showed him all the signs. He showed him a ladder standing from the earth to the heaven, as it is said, "And he dreamed, and behold || a ladder<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here. On the theme cf. Wisdom x. 10.</i> set up on the earth, and the top of it reached to heaven" (Gen. 28:12).
