And the ministering angels were ascending and descending thereon, and they beheld the face of Jacob, and they said: This is the face<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Pal. Targum, Gen. <i>in loc.</i>; and see T.B. Chullin, 91b; Gen. Rab. 68:12, lxxviii. 3; and liturgy for the second day of New Year, ed. Heidenheim, p. 36a.</i> like the face of the Chayyah,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the face of a man; cf. Ezek. 1:10, also T.J. Joma v. 3. 42c.</i> which is on the Throne of Glory.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The next sentence does not occur in the printed texts.</i> Such (angels) who were (on earth) below were ascending to see the face of Jacob among the faces of the Chayyah, (for it was) like the face of the Chayyah, which is on the Throne of Glory. Some (angels) ascended and some descended,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. <i>in loc.</i> Note that the text says that the ladder was set up towards the earth, <i>i.e.</i> from heaven to earth.</i> as it is said, "And behold the angels of God were ascending and descending on it" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 68:12.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, showed him the four kingdoms, their rule and their destruction, and He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Babylon ascending [seventy rungs, and descending; and He showed him the prince of the kingdom of]<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in square brackets are wanting in the MS., but they occur in the first editions.</i> Media ascending fifty-two rungs and descending; [and He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Greece ascending 180 ascents and descending;]<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in square brackets are wanting in the MS., but they occur in the first editions.</i> and He showed him the prince of the kingdom of Edom ascending, and he was not descending, but was saying, "I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the Most High" (Isa. 14:14). Jacob replied to him: "Yet thou shalt be brought down to Sheol,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> to the uttermost parts of the pit" (<i>ibid.</i> 15). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Even "though thou shouldest make thy nest as high as the eagle" (Jer. 49:16).
Jacob rose up early in the morning in great fear, and said:<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 91 p. 46b.</i> The house of the Holy One, blessed be He, is in this place, as it is said, "And he was afraid, and said, How dreadful is this place !<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 91:7, which has used our book.</i> this is none other but the house of God" (Gen. 28:17). Hence thou canst learn that every one who prays in Jerusalem<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 1 Kings 8:42.</i> is (reckoned) as though he had prayed before the Throne of Glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Menorath Ha-Maor, 100.</i> for the gate of heaven is there, and it is open to hear the prayers of Israel, as it is said, "And this is the gate of heaven" (<i>ibid.</i>).
And Jacob returned to gather the stones, and he found them all (turned into) one stone, and he set || it up for a pillar in the midst of the place, and oil descended for him from heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 88, and see Matt. iii. 16 for the Spirit of God descending like a dove from heaven in the narrative of the baptism of the Founder of Christianity. See Books of Adam and Eve in <i>A. and P.</i> ii. pp. 143 f.</i> and he poured it thereon, as it is said, "And he poured oil upon the top of it" (<i>ibid.</i> 18).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Joma v. 4. 42c; Lev. Rab. 20:4; and cf. T.B. Joma, 53b.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He placed (thereon)<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “planted.” Late eds. read, “stretched forth.”</i> His right foot,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the words of Isaiah the earth is God’s footstool, and our Midrash employs this bold imagery in speaking of the right foot of God. The stone became the centre stone of the earth, called “Eben Shethiyah.” See the Assumption of Moses i. 17, with Charles’ note, <i>in loc.</i>, and cf. Ẓohar, Gen. 131a, and T.J. Joma, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and sank the stone to the bottom of the depths, and He made it<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “them”; the first editions read “it.”</i> the keystone of the earth, just like a man who sets a keystone in an arch;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 122a.</i> therefore it is called the <i>foundation</i> stone,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> iv. 275b; Pal. Targum on Ex. 28:30, and Siphrê, Num. 76b. “Shethiyah” may mean “God has set (or fixed) it.”</i> for there is the navel of the earth, and therefrom was all the earth evolved, and upon it the Sanctuary of God<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 71.</i> stands, as it is said, "And this stone, which I have set up for a pillar, shall be God's house" (<i>ibid.</i> 22).
And Jacob fell upon his face to the ground before the foundation stone, and he prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all worlds ! If Thou wilt bring me back to this place in peace, I will sacrifice before Thee offerings of thanksgiving and burnt offerings,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 28:22, and Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 91:7, p. 200b.</i> as it is said, "And Jacob vowed a vow, saying" (<i>ibid.</i> 20). There he left the well,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 91, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and thence he lifted up his feet, and in the twinkle of the eye he came to Haran, as it is said, "And Jacob went on his journey,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and came to the land of the children of the east" (<i>ibid.</i> xxix. 1); and the (text) says, "And Jacob went<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> from Beer-Sheba, and went to Haran" (<i>ibid.</i> xxviii. 10). "And the Holy God is sanctified in righteousness"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The divine righteousness or charity experienced by Jacob caused him to sanctify God.</i> (Isa. 5:16). The angels answered and said: Blessed art Thou, O Lord, the Holy God.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the third benediction of the Shemoneh ‘Esreh; see Singer, p. 45. This benediction of the sanctification should remind us of Jacob, according to the teaching of our Midrash.</i>

Chapter 36

CHAPTER XXXVI<br><small>JACOB AND LABAN</small> [46<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>"W<small>HEN</small> thou goest, thy steps shall not be straitened; and if thou runnest, || thou shalt not stumble" (Prov. 4:12).
Jacob's steps were not straitened,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This refers to the extraordinary speed of his journey mentioned in the previous chapter of our book; cf. also <i>supra</i>, pp. 108, 110.</i> and his strength did not fail,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In spite of his excessive speed; cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 213.</i> and like a strong hero he rolled away the stone from the mouth of the well, and the well came up, and spread forth water outside itself,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Pal. Targum, Gen. 29:10; Gen. Rab. 70:8; and Ẓohar, Exodus, 13a.</i> and the shepherds saw and they all wondered, for all of them were unable to roll away the stone<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 91:1, which reads: “And they wondered, because all of them were unable to roll away the stone.”</i> from the mouth of the well; but Jacob alone rolled the stone from off the mouth of the well,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the sentence is wanting in the printed texts.</i> as it is said, "And Jacob went near, and rolled the stone from the well's mouth" (Gen. 29:10).
Rabbi 'Aḳiba said: Anyone who enters a city,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> For the purpose of finding a wife. This was the purpose of the journey of Eliezer, Jacob, and Moses. See Gen. Rab. 59:11, and <i>supra</i>, p. 108.</i> and finds maidens coming forth before him, his way will be prosperous (before him). Whence dost thou know this? Know that it is so. Come and see from Eliezer, the servant of our father Abraham, who, whilst he had not yet entered the city, found maidens coming out before him, as it is said, "Behold, I stand<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i> by the fountain of water," etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See the rest of the verse for the reference to the maiden.</i> (Gen. 24:43). And He prospered his way.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “As it is said, ‘The Lord hath prospered my way’” (Gen. 24:56).</i>
Whence again dost thou learn this? Know that it is so. Come and see from Moses, for, although he had not yet entered the city, he found maidens coming out before him, as it is said, "Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters; and they came" (Ex. 2:16). And He prospered his way, and he redeemed Israel from Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition and MS. Gaster read: “And he advanced to kingship.” On the kingship of Moses see the Book of Jashar lxxii. 34 ff.; T.B. Ẓebachim, 102a; cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 107.</i> Whence dost thou know this? Know that it<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> That one’s way will be prosperous if he meet maidens when he enters a city.</i> is so. Come and see from Saul, for whilst he had not yet entered the city, he found maidens coming forth before him, as it is said, "As they went up the ascent<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads: “in the gate.” This does not agree with M.T., which reads: “up the ascent.”</i> to the city, they found young maidens going out" (1 Sam. 9:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This section is wanting in the printed texts; cf. Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> And He prospered his way and he acquired the sovereignty. || And whence do we know this? Know thou that it is so. Come and learn from Jacob, for whilst he had not yet entered the city, he found maidens coming forth before him, as it is said, "And, behold, Rachel his daughter cometh" (Gen. 29:6).
Rab Huna said: Everything is revealed and foreseen before the Holy One, blessed be He. Before Jacob came to Haran, what did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He sent a plague among the sheep of Laban, and few were left out of many, and Rachel was tending<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> these, as it is said, "Rachel came with her father's sheep;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This part of the quotation is omitted by our MS.</i> for she kept them" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). Whence do we know that few remained of the many? Because it is said, "And Jacob fed the <i>rest</i> of Laban's flocks" (<i>ibid.</i> xxx. 86), "the rest" (which remained) after the plague, in order to increase and multiply Laban's flocks at the feet of Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “‘And the Lord hath blessed thee at my foot’<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> (Gen. 30:30). The feet of Jacob were worthy<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> to increase and multiply the sheep of Laban. Did the feet of Jacob increase and multiply?”</i> Hence (the sages) said: Sometimes the foot of man destroys the house, and sometimes the foot of man blesses the house,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And Jacob’s foot brought blessing, as it is said,” etc. See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 24 p. 125.</i> as it is said, "And the Lord hath blessed thee at my foot" (<i>ibid.</i> 80). Likewise Laban<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “Jacob said to Laban.” This does not agree with M.T. The Oxford MS., the first editions, and MS. Gaster read: “Laban said to Jacob.”</i> said to Jacob: "I have divined<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Laban relied on divination and the Teraphim; see T.J. ‘Abodah Ẓarah iii. 2. 42d.</i> that the Lord hath blessed me for thy sake" (<i>ibid.</i> 27).
When Laban heard the tidings of Jacob, the son of his sister, and the power of his might which he had displayed at the well, he ran to meet him, to kiss him, and to embrace him, as it is said, "And it came to pass, when Laban heard the tidings of Jacob, his sister's son" (<i>ibid.</i> xxix. 13). "And Laban said unto Jacob, Because thou art my brother" (<i>ibid.</i> 15). Was he then his brother? Was he not the son of his sister? This teaches thee that the son of a man's sister is like his son,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the reading of our MS., but the margin has: “it seems that one should read, ‘like his brother.’” The printed texts also read: “the son of a man’s sister is called his <i>son</i>.” The Oxford MS. reads: “like his brother.” Luria reads also “like his brother.” MS. Gaster reads, “is called his son.”</i> and the son of a man's brother || is like his brother. Whence do we learn (this)? From Abraham, our father, because it is said, "And Abram said to Lot, Let there not be strife<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i>… for we are brethren" (<i>ibid.</i> xiii. 8). Another verse (says), "And when Abram<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria’s text reads “Abraham”; this should be “Abram” in accordance with the Bible text.</i> heard that his brother was taken captive" (<i>ibid.</i> xiv. 14). Was he his brother?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Jebamoth, 17b.</i> Was he not the son of his brother? But it teaches thee that the sons of a man's brother are like his own brothers.
The sons of a man's sons are like his own sons. Whence do we learn (this)? From Jacob, because it is said, "Ephraim and Manasseh, even as Reuben and Simeon, shall be mine" (<i>ibid.</i> xlviii. 5). Were they his sons? Were they not the sons of his son? But it teaches thee that the sons of a man's sons are as his own sons. And the sons of one's daughters are as one's own sons. Whence do we learn (this)? From Laban, because it is said, "And Laban answered and said unto Jacob, The daughters are my daughters, and the sons are my sons" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxi. 43).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Jebamoth, 62b, and T.B. Baba Bathra, 143b. For an opposite view see Gen. Rab. 94:6; and cf. T.B. Soṭah, 49a.</i> Were they then his sons? Were they not the sons of his daughters? But it teaches thee that the sons of a man's daughters are like his own sons.
Jacob began to serve for a wife<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is based on Hos. 12:12; see Gen. Rab. 70:17.</i> for seven years. He<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Jacob. The Oxford MS. and the first editions read: “After seven years he made a banquet.” The Bible text says that “<i>Laban</i> gathered together all the men of the place, and made a feast” (Gen. 29:22).</i> made a banquet and rejoicing for seven days,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 112, and Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> and married Rachel,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. and the first editions read “Leah.”</i> as it is said, "Fulfil the week of this one" (<i>ibid.</i> xxix. 27). "And Jacob did so, and fulfilled the week of this one"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees xxviii. 8 says: “And Laban said to Jacob, ‘Let the <i>seven days</i> of the feast of this one pass by, and I will give thee Rachel, that thou mayst serve me another seven years’”; cf. Gen. 29:27–29 and cf. Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> i. 19. 7.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 28).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. and the first editions add here: “Again he kept another seven days of banquet and rejoicing, and he married Rachel,<sup></sup> as it is said: ‘And he gave him Rachel his daughter to wife’” (Gen. 29:28).</i> All the men of the place were gathered together to show loving-kindness to our father Jacob, as it is said, "And Laban gathered together all the men of the place, and made a feast" (<i>ibid.</i> 22).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said: Ye have shown loving-kindness to Jacob, My servant, I also will give || you and your sons your reward<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The whole of this paragraph is omitted in the Oxford MS.</i> in this world, so that there be no reward for the wicked in the future world, as it is said, "Now Naaman, captain of the host of the king of Aram<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here. <i>Aram</i> suggests to our author Laban, who was an Aramæan.</i>… because by him the Lord had given victory unto Aram" (2 Kings 5:1).
(Laban) took his two handmaids, and gave them to his two daughters. Were they his handmaids? Were they not his daughters?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The legend that Zilpah and Bilhah were sisters occurs in Jubilees xxviii. 9 and in Test. XII Pat., Naph. i. 9, 11; see also Pal. Targ. Gen. 29:24, 29, Gen. Rab. 74:13; and Singer, <i>Das Buck der Jubiläen</i>, i. p. 118.</i> But according to the law of the land the daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Read here <span>שבנוחיו</span>.</i> of a man by his concubines are called handmaids, as it is said, "And Laban gave to Rachel his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MSS. the quotation ends here.</i> Bilhah his handmaid to be her handmaid" (Gen. 29:29).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i> The Midrashic reading of Gen. 29:29 seems to be: “And Laban gave to Rachel his daughter Bilhah (by) his handmaid (to be) her handmaid.”</i>
Rabbi Levi said: The Holy One, blessed be He, saw the sorrow of Leah, and He gave her power to conceive, (bringing) consolation to her soul;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the joy of motherhood; see Gen. 29:31: “And the Lord saw that Leah was hated.”</i> and she bare a male child, goodly in appearance, and wise; and she said: <i>See ye a son</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>ראו בן</span> (Reuben). This is not the explanation of the Biblical text (Gen. 29:32); see T.B. Berakhoth, 6b, and Gen. Rab. 71:4; cf. <i>J.E.</i> x. 386.</i> which the Holy One, blessed be He, has given me, as it is said, "And Leah conceived, and bare a son, and she called his name Reuben; for she said, Because the Lord hath looked <i>upon my affliction</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 32). Therefore he<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “he called.” This reading agrees with Jubilees xxviii. 11. The first editions agree with the Oxford MS. and read: “she called.”</i> called his name Reuben.
Rabbi Eliezer said: Leah bare her sons after seven months,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Of gestation.</i> and in seven years there were born unto Jacob eleven sons<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here “tribes.”</i> and one daughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 2 p. 5a: “All the tribes and Dinah were born within 7 years, each one after 7 months.” See T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 12a. For a different view see Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 1, and cf. R. Bechai on Gen. 29, where the explanation is given as to the month in which each tribe was born, each one being born in a different year. See also the Book of Jashar xxxi. 15 ff., and Jubilees xxviii. 9 ff., according to which the eleven sons were born within ten years; see Charles’ note on p. 171 of <i>Jubilees</i>, and cf. Schürer, iii.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup> 349 (on Demetrius).</i> And all of them were born, each with his partner<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> future wife. They were twins, male and female; cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 304. According to Jubilees xxviii. 23, Leah bare two children, “a son and a daughter,” Zebulun and Dinah.</i> with him, except Joseph, whose partner was not born with him, for Asenath, the daughter of Dinah, was destined to be his wife,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> On Asenath see Hastings’ <i>D.B.</i> i. 162 f.; <i>J.E.</i> ii. 172 ff.; see also Pal. Targum on Gen. 41:45 and xlvi. 20; Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 97; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 146 (in name of Midrash Abkhir). See also <i>infra</i>, pp. 287 f.; and cf. the Book of Jashar xlix. 36 f.</i> and (also) except Dinah, whose partner was not born with her. She<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Leah.</i> said: This child is (according to) justice and judgment,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “Din” (“justice”). The idea here is probably the same as <i>supra</i>, p. 152, that the world was originally developed by the primitive instincts of nature. See Ẓohar, Lev. 77b. There may also be a reference to the coming events in Shechem.</i> therefore she called her name Dinah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 60a, and Pal. Targum, Gen. 30:21.</i>
Rabbi Eliezer also said: Jacob fled in order to come to Laban, and he fled to get away from Laban. Whence do we know that he fled in order to come to Laban? Because it is said, "And Jacob <i>fled</i> || into the field of Aram" (Hos. 12:12). (Whence do we know that)<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. and the first editions read: “Whence do we know?” The expression is wanting in our MS.</i> he fled in order to get away from Laban? Because it is said, "And it was told Laban on the third day that Jacob was fled" (Gen. 31:22). Why did he flee? Because the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob ! I cannot suffer My Shekhinah to dwell with thee outside the land,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The reference is to the land of Israel. The Oxford MS. reads: “I do not desire to let My Glory dwell with thee in this place”; the later editions read: “in the house of Laban.”</i> but "return unto the land of thy fathers, and to thy kindred; and I will be with thee" (<i>ibid.</i> 3).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> God promises to be with Jacob in his birthplace, and not in the house of Laban. See <i>supra</i>, pp. 54 f.</i> Therefore he fled. And Laban took all the men of his city, mighty men, and he pursued after him, seeking to slay him. The angel Michael descended, and drew his sword behind him,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Laban; see Pal. Targum, Gen. 31:24, and cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 191.</i> seeking to slay him. He said to him: Do not speak to Jacob, either good or bad, as it is said, "And God came to Laban the Aramæan in a dream of the night,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MSS. the quotation ends here.</i> and said unto him, Take heed to thyself that thou speak not to Jacob either good or bad" (<i>ibid.</i> 24). Laban rose up early in the morning, and saw all that Jacob had, and he said (to him):<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “To him” occurs in the first editions, but not in the MSS.</i> All these are mine, and since thou hast taken all these, yet wherefore hast thou stolen my Teraphim, which I worshipped?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Have we in the description of the Teraphim a protest against the worship of relics? See also Wisdom xiv. 15.</i>
What are the Teraphim? They slay a man, a firstborn, and he is red (in colour). All that a man requires (to know) is not written here. This is impossible, since the men who dispute about the knowledge of making (the Teraphim) have increased. Everyone who follows that knowledge will ultimately go down to Gehinnom.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The preceding words (from “he is red”) occur in our MS. only.</i> And they pinch off his head, and salt it with salt,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> For text see Buxtorf, <i>Lexic. Chald. Talm. Rabb.</i> (ed. 1640), <i>s.v.</i> <span>תרפים</span>; ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, viii. p. 285b, s.v. <span>חרף</span> adds: “and spices.” This addition agrees with the text of the first’ ditions. The Oxford MS. reads: “And they burn incense before him, and offer spices before him.”</i> and they write upon a golden plate<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On <span>קמיע</span>, (charm) written on golden plates, see Tosephta Kelim (Baba Mezi‘a) i. 12, p. 579. See also Origen, <i>c. Cels.</i> vi. 31; and M. Friedländer, <i>Antichrist</i>, p. 164, note 1, for other references and literature.</i> the name of an unclean (spirit),<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. adds “spirit.” This is also the reading of the first editions.</i> and place it under his tongue,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.</i>, has “head.”</i> and they put it in the wall, and they kindle lamps<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Schwally, <i>Das Leben nach dem Tode</i>, pp. 40 f., sees here a reference to the “lamp of the dead”; and cf. Perles in <i>Monatsschrift</i>, x. (1861), p. 382.</i> || before it, and bow down to it, and it<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.</i>, has: “and Laban was speaking with them (the Teraphim).”</i> speaks unto them. Whence do we know that the Teraphim speak? Because it is said, "For the Teraphim have spoken vanity" (Zech. 10:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This section occurs also in Midrash Tanchuma, Vayezê, § xii.; Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 130, Jalḳuṭ, Zechariah, § 578, the Book of Jashar xxxi. 41; Pal. Targum on Gen. 31:19, and see <i>J.E.</i> xii. 109; also Athanasius Kircher, <i>Œdipus Ægyptiacus</i>, i. p. 261, and cf. Selden, <i>de Dis Syriis Syntagma</i>, i. ii. pp. 96 ff. On the Teraphim see Blau, <i>Altjüd. Zauberwesen</i>, p. 120; Bacher, T. ii. pp. 164 f.; and cf. Mekhilta pp. 67a, b; Siphrê, Deut. § 43, p. 81b.</i> On that account had Rachel stolen them, so that they should not tell Laban that Jacob had fled, and not only that, but also to remove idolatrous worship from her father's house.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “not only that, but also to cut away the name of idolatry from the house of her father.” See also Gen. Rab. 74:5, and Pal. Targum, Gen. 31:32. ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, viii. p. 285b, reads: “and further to destroy idolatry from her father’s house.” Jubilees xxix. 5 fixes Nisan 21st as the day of Jacob’s departure from Laban. This date corresponds to the day when the Israelites crossed the Reed Sea. Jubilees does not mention the Teraphim, but has a good deal to say about the wickedness of the Rephaim. Are the “Rephaim” purposely substituted for the Teraphim?</i>
Now Jacob knew nothing of all this, and he said: Anyone who has stolen thy Teraphim shall die before his proper time;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The text says: “Let him not live” (Gen. 31:32); <i>P.R.E.</i> gives the paraphrase of this, so also the Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and the utterance<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “that which cometh out of the mouth.”</i> of a righteous person is like the speech from the mouth of an angel,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This may be an illustration of the verse: “Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin; neither say thou before the <i>angel</i>, that it was an error: wherefore should God be angry at thy voice, and destroy the work of thine hands?” (Eccles. 5:6).</i> and (Rachel) bare and died, as it is said, "And it came to pass, as her soul was in departing, for she died" (Gen. 35:18).
Rabbi Jehudah said: Three forefathers made covenants with the people of the land.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Of Canaan. The first editions add: “And they were: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”</i> (With reference to) Abraham (the circumstances were as follows).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets have been supplied to show the connection of thought. The first editions read: “Abraham made a covenant with the people of the land.”</i> When the angels were revealed unto him, he thought that they were travellers (from among) the people of the land,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Mezi‘a, 86b. “The angels looked like Arabs,” who travel from land to land, see Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 82.</i> and he ran to meet them, and he wished to prepare for them a great banquet,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xiii. p. 29a; Gen. Rab. 48:12; and Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and he told Sarah to prepare cakes for them. When Sarah was kneading, she perceived that the manner of women was upon her,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Mezi‘a, 87a.</i> therefore he did not hand them any of the cakes. He ran to fetch a calf. But the calf fled from before him, and went into the Cave of Machpelah, and he went in there after it, and he found Adam and his help-meet<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 127a, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 348.</i> lying there upon their beds,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 148, and cf. <i>J.E.</i> viii. 248. According to the Book of Adam and Eve (ed. Malan) 11. ix., Adam was “laid on the eastern side of the inside of the cave, the side of the incense, and (Seth) placed in front of him a lampstand kept burning.” This was the “Cave of Treasures.” The legend occurs in Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and they slept, and lights were kindled above them,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra</i>, previous page, note 6.</i> and a sweet scent was upon them like a sweet savour, therefore he desired to have the Cave of Machpelah as a burial possession. He spoke to the sons of Jebus, in order to purchase from them the Cave of || Machpelah by a purchase with gold,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i>; here and in Jalḳuṭ, Joshua, § 28, the expression is: “with a purchase by gold.” Luria thinks that our text should read: “with a perpetual purchase by gold.”</i> and by a perpetual deed for a possession of a burying-place. Were they Jebusites? Were they not Hittites? But they were called Jebusites according to the name of the city of Jebus.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See 1 Chron. 11:4: “Jerusalem, the same is Jebus, and the Jebusites the inhabitants of the land, were there.” These inhabitants were Hittites by descent; moreover, the text quoted (Gen. 23:16) speaks of them as the “children of Heth.”</i> The men did not accept (this request).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> At first they only consented to permit him to bury Sarah with their own dead.</i> He began to bow down and prostrate himself unto them, as it is said, "And Abraham bowed himself down before the people of the land" (<i>ibid.</i> xxiii. 12).
They said to him: We know that the Holy One, blessed be He, will give to thee and to thy seed in the future all these lands; make a covenant with us by an oath that thy seed shall not take possession of the cities<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Haggadol, c. 350. The first editions read: “The city of Jebus except by the consent of the children of Jebus.”</i> of Jebus, and we will sell unto thee the Cave of Machpelah by a purchase with gold and by a perpetual deed and for a perpetual possession. He made with them a covenant with an oath that the Israelites would not take possession of the city of Jebus<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The preceding words of this sentence up to “save by the consent” are omitted in the first editions. See Jalḳuṭ, Joshua, <i>loc. cit.</i> For a variant reading see ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, vi. p. 180a, s.v. <span>עוֵד</span>.</i> save by the consent of the sons of Jebus, and afterwards he bought the Cave of Machpelah by a purchase with gold, and a perpetual deed, for a perpetual possession,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jer. 32:7 ff. for the method of purchasing land. The MS. omits “as it is said”; this reading is found in the first editions.</i> (as it is said), "And Abraham hearkened unto Ephron;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and Abraham weighed to Ephron the silver, which he had named in the hearing of the children of Heth, four hundred shekels of silver, current money with the merchant" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).
What did the men of Jebus do? They made images of copper, and set them up in the street of the city, and wrote upon them the covenant of the oath of Abraham. When the Israelites came to the land (of Canaan), they wished to enter the city of the Jebusites,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Josh. 15:8, and Judg. 1:8: “And the children of Judah fought against Jerusalem, and took it, and smote it with the edge of the sword, and set the city on fire”; and cf. verse 19: “for he could not drive out the inhabitants of the valley.” What is the political significance of the legend?</i> but they were not able (to enter),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “to enter”; it is found in the first editions.</i> because of the sign of the covenant of Abraham's oath,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 56; and Rashi, <i>in loc.</i></i> as it is said, "And the children of Benjamin did not drive out<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions omit this first part of the verse.</i> the Jebusites that inhabited Jerusalem" (Judg. 1:21). || When David reigned<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 42; T.B. Ẓebachim. 114b; and cf. 1 Chron. 11:4 and Ps. 132:2–5. David desired to conquer Jerusalem and to build the Temple.</i> he desired to enter the city of the Jebusites, (but) they did not allow him, as it is said, "And the king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land; which<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads: “The men of Jebus said, Thou shalt not come in hither.” The last words occur also in 1 Chron. 11:5, which reads: “the <i>inhabitants</i> of Jebus said to <i>David</i>, Thou shalt not come in hither.” The first editions have followed the text of 2 Sam. 5:6.</i> spake unto David, saying, Thou shalt not come in hither" (2 Sam. 5:6).
(Although) the Israelites were like the sand of the sea,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In number; cf. 2 Sam. 17:11.</i> yet it was owing to the force of the sign of the covenant of Abraham's oath.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> That they were unable to capture the city of the Jebusites.</i> David saw (this) and turned backwards, as it is said, "And David dwelt in the stronghold" (<i>ibid.</i> 9).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> But not in the city.</i> They said to him: Thou wilt not be able to enter the city of the Jebusites until thou hast removed all those images upon which the sign of the covenant of Abraham's oath is written,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 1 Macc. viii. 22.</i> as it is said, "Except thou take away the blind and the lame" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). "The lame" refers to the images, as it is said, "Wherefore they say, The blind and the lame shall not come into the house" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). Lest thou shouldst say, The blind and the lame did not enter the Sanctuary, Heaven forbid (that we should say this), but these "blind and lame" refer to the images which have eyes and see not, feet and they walk not, (as it is said),<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is omitted by the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i> "That are hated of David's soul" (<i>ibid.</i>). Because David hated to hear of and to see idolatry, as it is said, "Wherefore they say, The blind and the lame shall <i>not</i> come into the house" (<i>ibid.</i>).
David said to his men: Whoever will go up first, and remove those images upon which the sign of the covenant of Abraham's oath<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Rashi and Ḳimchi, <i>in. loc.</i>, the sign was the effigy of Abraham.</i> is written, he shall be the chief.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “the head.”</i> And Joab, the son of Zeruiah, went up,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “first.”</i> and he became the chief, as it is said, "And Joab the son of Zeruiah went up first, || and was made chief" (1 Chron. 11:6). Afterwards he<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> David.</i> bought the city of the Jebusites for Israel by a purchase with gold and with a perpetual deed for a perpetual possession. What did David do? He took from each tribe fifty shekels; verily all of them amounted to six hundred shekels,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ẓebachim, 116b; Siphrê, Num. <i>loc. cit.</i>; Deut. § 62, and Baraitha of the 32 Middoth, 15. Our text is referred to by Tosaphoth on T.B. Kethuboth, 99a; catchword, “He gave.”</i> as it is said, "So David gave to Ornan<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> for the place six hundred shekels of gold by weight" (<i>ibid.</i> xxi. 25).
Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 68:7.</i> made a covenant with the people of the land, when he sojourned in the land of the Philistines. He noticed that they turned their faces away from him. He went away from them in peace, and Abimelech and all his magnates<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum on Gen. 26:26.</i> came after him. He said to them: Ye turned aside your faces from me, and now ye come unto me, as it is said, "And Isaac said unto them, Wherefore are ye come unto me,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.; the first editions read as far as “Wherefore.” As usual, “etc.” is added in all the texts.</i> seeing ye hate me?" (Gen. 26:27). "And they said, We saw plainly that the Lord was with thee" (<i>ibid.</i> 28). They said: We know that the Holy One, blessed be He, will give to thy seed in the future all these lands; make a covenant of an oath with us, that thy seed will not take possession of the land of the Philistines. He made a covenant of an oath with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence is not in the printed texts.</i> What did Isaac do? He cut off one cubit<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Gen. 26:28 ff., for this legend. According to the Midrash Agadah (Gen. <i>in loc.</i>), p. 66, Isaac was riding upon his ass when he made the covenant with the Philistines. He cut off the measure of a cubit from the bridle of the ass, so that it should be a proof to the Philistines that Isaac had sworn that his children should not take the land of the Philistines.</i> of the bridle of the ass upon which he was riding, and he gave it to them that it might be in their hands<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “And he gave it to him as a sign that there should be between them a covenant of an oath.”</i> for a sign of the covenant of the oath.
When David reigned, he desired to enter the land of the Philistines, but he was unable (to do so) because of the power of the sign of the covenant<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xx. 1; and Gen. Rab. 52:7.</i> oath of || Isaac, until he had taken from them the sign of the covenant of Isaac's oath, as it is said, "And David took the bridle of the cubit<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 60:1, p. 152b, and cf. T.B. Chullin, 60b, for the covenant of Abraham.</i> out of the hand of the Philistines" (2 Sam. 8:1),<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ḳimchi on this text, where the entire passage from <i>P.R.E.</i> is quoted. See also ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, v. p. 286b.</i> as it is written, "So the Philistines were subdued, and they came no more within the border of Israel" (1 Sam. 7:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “And he subdued them.” See Tosephta Soṭah, xi. 13, p. 316.</i>
Jacob made a covenant with the people of the land, because Laban said to him: I know that the Holy One, blessed be He, will give to thy seed in the future all these lands; make a covenant of an oath with me, that the Israelites will not take possession of the land of Edom.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Aram” (Syria). They add the following: “And he erected for himself a pillar and (a heap of) stones,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and brought his sons with him in the covenant of the oath.”</i> He<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Jacob.</i> made with him a covenant with an oath, as it is said, "And Jacob said unto his brethren, Gather ye stones" (Gen. 31:46). Were they his brethren? Were they not his sons? But this teaches thee that a man's sons are like his brethren.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 270, and see Rahmer, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 41.</i> Laban said to him: If the Israelites obtain possession of the land (of Canaan), then they must not come into the land of Edom<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See note 6, above.</i> for an evil purpose,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The next clause up to “as it is said” occurs only in the MS.</i> and if Edom obtain possession they must not come into the land of Israel for evil, as it is said, "That I will not pass over this heap to thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; the first editions read: “That I will not pass over this heap,” not quoting exactly as in M.T.</i> and that thou shalt not pass over this heap and this pillar unto me, for harm" (<i>ibid.</i> 52).
When David reigned, he wished to come into the land of Edom,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 279, note 6, first sentence.</i> but he was unable on account of the power of the covenant of Jacob's oath until he had broken that pillar. Concerning this, Solomon<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is an error. It should be “Moses.” The first editions read “Moses.”</i> said: "And break in pieces their pillars" (Ex. 23:24). Afterwards he conquered the land of Edom,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 279, note 6, first sentence.</i> as it is said, "David smote also Hadadezer the son of Rehob, king of Zobah,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. concludes the quotation here and omits “the son of Rehob.” The first editions read: “as it is written, ‘And David smote Hadadezer, king of Aram.’” This is not to be found in the Hebrew Bible. See 1 Chron. 18:3.</i> as he went to recover his dominion at the river"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The river Euphrates, which flows through the land of Syria. Zobah was an Aramæan kingdom; see Gesenius (Oxford ed.), p. 844a, b, and cf. 2 Sam. 10:6, 8, and Ps. 60:1.</i> (2 Sam. 8:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 60:1. p. 152b.</i>

Chapter 37

CHAPTER XXXVII<br><small>JACOB AND THE ANGEL</small> [49<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>"As if a man did flee from a lion || and a bear met him" (Amos 5:19). The "lion" means Laban, who pursued (Jacob) like a lion to destroy<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In Jalḳuṭ, Amos, <i>in loc.</i>, the reading is “to tear in pieces”; cf. Ps. 7:2, and see Midrash Haggadol, c. 524.</i> his life. The "bear" refers to Esau, who stood by the way like a bear bereaved by man,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “like a bereaved bear, he came.”</i> to slay the mother with the children. The lion is shamefaced, the bear is not shamefaced.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Laban not only did not molest Jacob, but admitted that he was unable to do so. Esau made no such admission.</i> Jacob arose and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all the Universe ! Hast Thou not spoken thus unto me, "Return unto the land of thy fathers, and to thy kindred, and I will be with thee"? (Gen. 31:3).
And behold, Esau, the evil one, has now come to slay me; but I fear him and he does not fear Thee. Hence (the sages) say: Do not fear an executive officer or a ruler, but (fear) a man who has no fear of Heaven. (Esau) stood by the way like a bear bereaved by man, to slay mother and child.
What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He sent an angel<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 78:1, as to whether the angel was Gabriel or Michael, see also <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, 95 f.; for a parallel see Pal. Targum, Gen. 32:25.</i> to him to deliver him, and to save him from the hand<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> For the wording see Jer. 42:11.</i> of Esau; and he appeared unto him like a man, as it is said, "And there wrestled <i>a man</i> with him<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Jacob. The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> until the breaking of the day" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 24). As soon as the dawn appeared, the angel said to him: Let me go, for the time has arrived when I must stand<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In Heaven; cf. Isa. 6:3 for the song of the angels. The same idea occurs in the New Testament; see Luke ii. 13. See also Midrash Haggadol, c. 511 f.</i> to sing<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to minister.”</i> and to chant praises before the Holy One, blessed be He. But Jacob did not wish to let him go. What did the angel do? He began to sing and to chant praises from the earth, || and when the angels (on high) heard the voice of the angel who was singing and praising from the earth, they said: Because of the honour of the righteous (one) do we hear<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “stand.” The first editions read: “hear.”</i> the voice of the angel who is singing and praising from the earth; and concerning him the verse says, "From the uttermost part of the earth have we heard songs,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> glory to the righteous" (Isa. 24:16).
Again the angel said to him: "Let me go" (Gen. 32:26). Jacob answered him: I will not let thee go until thou hast blessed me;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said: ‘I will not let thee go except thou bless me’” (Gen. 32:26).</i> and he blessed him, as it is said, "And he blessed him there" (<i>ibid.</i> 29). Again he said to him: "Let me go" (<i>ibid.</i> 26). He answered him: I will not let thee go until thou tellest me what thy name<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See also Hos. 12:4.</i> is. And (the angel) called his name Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The second half of this sentence is omitted by the Prague edition.</i> like his own name, for his own name was called Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 78:3, and Tosaphoth on T.B. Synhedrin, 37b, catchword “From the corner”; cf. Num. Rab. 10:6. The idea of this Haggadah seems to be: the angel is named according to the mission entrusted to him by God. Here it was to announce the ideal for Jacob to pursue, namely, that he was to live as Israel, the warrior of God, destined in his seed to do battle with everything which opposes the establishment on earth of the Kingdom of God. Therefore the angel is named Israel. Israel must fear neither man nor angel; he has prevailed over the powers above man, and need fear only God. See Judg. 13:3 ff. for the case of the angel and Manoah, where the same principle obtains. The angel is called <span>פלאי</span>, which suggests <span>הפלאה</span>, “the separation” involved in the Nazirate of Samson. It may also be that the angel was the guardian angel of Israel and therefore bore the name “Israel.”</i> Jacob wished to prevail over the angel, and to throw him down upon the earth. What did the angel do? He took hold of the sinew of the hip, which was upon the hollow of Jacob's thigh, and he lifted the sinew of his hip (out of its place), and it became like the fat<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The fat around the sinew of the thigh is prohibited to the Israelite; see T.B. Chullin, 89b, 92b, and 100b, and Maimonides, <i>Maakhaloth Asuroth</i>, viii. 1.</i> of the dead. Therefore the children of Israel are forbidden to eat of the sinew of the hip which is upon the hollow of the animal's thigh, as it is said, "Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sinew of the hip which is upon the hollow of the thigh" (<i>ibid.</i> 82).
Jacob wished to cross the ford of the Jabbok, and he was detained<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and to stay there.”</i> there. The angel said to him: Didst thou not speak thus<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “unto me.” The Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 132, omits “unto me.”</i>—"Of all that thou shalt give me<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions omit the first part of the verse.</i> I will surely give a tenth unto thee" (<i>ibid.</i> xxviii. 22)? What did our father Jacob do? He took || all the cattle in his possession which he had brought from Paddan-Aram, and he gave a tithe of them amounting to 550 (animals).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees xxxii. 4 refers to the separation of the tithe of Jacob’s cattle. 119 animals being offered: “This was his offering, in consequence of the vow which he had vowed that he would give a tenth.”</i> Hence thou mayest learn that all the cattle in the possession of our father Jacob, which he had brought from Paddan-Aram, amounted to 5500 (animals).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “He took all his cattle and gave a tithe amounting to 550 (animals); hence we learn that all his cattle amounted to 5500 animals.”</i> Again Jacob wished to cross the ford of the Jabbok, but he was hindered here. The angel said: Didst thou not speak thus—"<i>Of all</i> that thou shalt give me<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> I will surely give a tenth unto thee" (<i>ibid.</i>)? Behold, thou hast sons. Thou hast not given a tithe of them. What did Jacob do? He put apart the four firstborn<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first-born are excluded from the operation of the law of tithe; see T.B. Bekhoroth, 53b.</i> children of the four mothers, and eight children remained. He began (to count) from Simeon, and finished with Benjamin, who was still in his mother's womb.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> That means, eight children. Two more were required, and starting to count <i>ab initio</i> we find that Levi is the tenth. See Jubilees xxxii. 3, where Levi is chosen as the tithe: “Jacob counted his sons from (Benjamin), and Levi fell to the <i>portion of the Lord</i>.” Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.</i>, agrees with our author, but Gen. Rab. 70:7, and Tanchuma, Re’êh, § xiv., offer another calculation. Both Jubilees and our author fix the choice of Levi at the time when “Rachel became pregnant with her son Benjamin” (Jubilees xxxii. 3).</i> Again he began (to count) from Simeon, and he included Benjamin, and Levi was reckoned as the tithe, holy to God, as it is said, "The tenth shall be holy unto the Lord" (Lev. 27:82).
Rabbi Ishmael said: All firstborns are required to have a tithe taken (only) when they fall under the observation<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Luria we should read: “When they do <i>not</i> fall under the observation of the eye.”</i> of the eye.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> guarded so that the owner derives no benefit from them; see T.B. Bekhoroth, 9b, and T.B. Baba Mezi‘a, 6b.</i> Only Jacob observed the law of tithe in advance; he began with Benjamin, who was in his mother's womb, and Levi was reckoned as holy to the Lord,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is exactly the same method of reckoning which occurs in Jubilees xxxii. 3. Dr. Charles’ note on p. 192 of <i>Jubilees</i> must be modified accordingly. See also Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 133.</i> and concerning him the Scripture says, "The tenth shall be holy unto the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Michael, the angel, descended and took Levi, and brought him up before the Throne of Glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Test. Levi ii. 6: “And behold the heavens were opened, and an angel of God said to me, Levi, enter.”</i> and he spake before Him: Sovereign of all || the universe ! This is Thy lot,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 177.</i> and the portion<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> So also in Jubilees xxxii. 3.</i> of Thy works.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Instead of “Thy works” (<span>מעטיך</span>) read: “Thy tithe” (<span>מעטרך</span>); see R. Bechai on Num. 18:20, p. 200a, and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> And He put forth His right hand and blessed him, that the sons of Levi should minister on earth<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Deut. 10:8, and cf. Test. Levi ii. 10 ff., which forms a close parallel to our Midrash.</i> before Him, like the ministering angels in heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The priests are called “angels”; see Mal. 2:7, which the R.V. renders “messenger”; see also Ps. 103:21, and cf. Gen. Rab. 70:7.</i> Michael spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! Do not such who serve the king have provision of their food given to them? Therefore He gave to the sons of Levi all holy things which accrue to His Name,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees xxxii. 15 reads: “And all the tithes of the oxen and sheep shall be holy unto the Lord, and shall belong to His priests.” Our author and Jubilees agree in ascribing the law of the tithe and the choice of Levi to the priesthood to Jacob’s fulfilment of his vow to give a tithe “of all that came with him, both of men and cattle” (Jubilees xxxii. 2).</i> as it is said, "They shall eat the offerings of the Lord made by fire, and his inheritance" (Deut. 18:1).
When Jacob passed to come into the land of Canaan, Esau came to him from Mount Seir in violent anger, contriving to slay him, as it is said, "The wicked plotteth against the just, and gnasheth upon him with his teeth" (Ps. 37:12). Esau said: I will not slay Jacob with bow and arrows, but with my mouth and with my teeth will I slay him, and suck his blood, as it is said, "And Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him, and fell on his neck, and kissed him; and they wept" (Gen. 33:4). Do not read <i>vayishakêhu</i> (and he kissed him), but (read) <i>vayishkêhu</i> (and he bit him). But Jacob's neck became like ivory, and concerning him the Scripture says, "Thy neck is like the tower of ivory" (Cant. 7:4). The wicked (Esau's) teeth became blunt,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Cant. Rab. to Cant. 7:5, Gen. Rab. 54:9, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 517. The New Testament speaks of Esau as “a fornicator or profane person” (Heb. xii. 16): “For ye know that even when he afterward desired to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no place of repentance, though he sought it diligently with tears” (<i>ibid.</i> 17).</i> and when the wicked one saw that the desire of his heart was not realized he began to be angry, and to gnash with his teeth, as it is said, "The wicked shall see it, and be grieved; he shall gnash with his teeth, and melt away" (Ps. 112:10).
Jacob took all the tithe of his possessions and sent it by the hand of his servants, and gave it to Esau, saying to them: Say ye || to him, "Thus saith thy servant Jacob" (Gen. 32:4). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob ! That which was holy hast thou made profane? He replied to Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! I flatter the wicked, so that he should not slay me. Hence the (wise men) say, we may flatter the wicked in this world for the sake of the ways of peace.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 41b, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 508. On the “ways of Peace” see Lazarus, <i>Ethik</i>, i. pp. 179 ff. The Sermon on the Mount says: “Resist not him that is evil” (Matt. v. 39). The disciples of the Founder of Christianity are commanded to be “wise as serpents and harmless as doves” (<i>ibid.</i> x. 16), as they were being sent forth “as sheep in the midst of wolves” (<i>ibid.</i>).</i> Esau said to him: O my brother, I have enough; as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> "And Esau said, I have enough" (Gen. 33:9). And because he gave honour to Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Because Jacob gave honour to Esau.”</i> therefore the sons of Jacob paid honour to the sons of Esau with the same expression;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “Rab” (enough), also signifying “Rabbi” or “Master”; cf. the N.T. use of Rabbi, as a title of honour, Matt. xxiii. 7. See also Deut. Rab. xi. 10, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 517.</i> as it is said, "Ye have compassed this mountain long <i>enough</i>" (Deut. 2:8). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob ! Is it not enough for thee that thou hast made profane that which is holy? Nay, but I have said, "And the <i>elder</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This in Hebrew is “Rab.”</i> shall serve the younger" (Gen. 25:23); and yet thou hast said, "Thy servant Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 4). By thy life ! it shall be according to thy words; he shall rule over thee in this world, and thou shalt rule over him in the world to come. Therefore Jacob said to him (Esau): "Let my lord, I pray thee, pass over before his servant" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiii. 14). Hence thou mayest learn that the sons of Esau will not fall until a remnant from Jacob shall come, and cut off the feet of the children of Esau from Mount Seir,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Seir was the territory of Esau.</i> and the Holy One, blessed be He, will descend.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This phrase, “and the Holy One, blessed be He, will descend,” occurs only in the MS. The first editions quote Num. 24:19.</i> "And there shall not be any remaining to the house of Esau;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> for the Lord hath spoken it" (Obad. 18).

Chapter 38

CHAPTER XXXVIII<br><small>JOSEPH AND HIS BRETHREN</small> [50<small>B</small>. i.]<br>"O<small>R</small> went into the house and leaned his hand on the wall, and the serpent bit him"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The preceding chapter in our book began with the first half of this verse of Amos. Was the Haphṭarah for the portion of Vajishlach (Gen. 32:3–xxxvi. 43) Amos 5, instead of Obadiah, which is now read in the Synagogues of the Sephardim?</i> (Amos 5:19). When Jacob went into his house in the land of Canaan<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “land of his possession, which was in the land of Canaan.”</i> the serpent bit him. || And who was the serpent? This was Shechem, the son of Chamor.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Add “the Hivite”; this emendation is based on the reading in Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 10:8; cf. T.B. Sabbath, 85a, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 524 and c. 527. See Jubilees xxx. 2. The Targum of <span>נחש</span> (serpent) is <span>חר</span>, which suggests “Hivite.”</i> Because the daughter of Jacob was abiding in the tents, and she did not go into the street;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar xxxiii. 5 ff., and Pal. Targum, Gen. 34:1; see also Gen. Rab. 80:5, Leḳach Ṭob, <i>in loc.</i>, and Midrash Haggadol, c. 524.</i> what did Shechem, the son of Chamor, do? He brought dancing girls who were (also) playing on pipes<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Luria’s commentary <i>in loc.</i>, and Sopherim 21:8.</i> in the streets.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. text could be rendered: “outside his (house)”; the first editions read: “outside her (house).”</i> Dinah went forth to see those girls who were making merry; and he seized her,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 134; Leḳach Ṭob, <i>in loc.</i>; Rashi, <i>in loc.</i></i> and he slept with her, and she conceived and bare Asenath.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, pp. 272 f.</i> The sons of Israel said that she should be killed, for they said that now people would say in all the land<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “for now would all (the people of) the land say that there was a house of ill-fame in the tents of Jacob.”</i> that there was an immoral daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading in Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i>, is “daughter” (<span>כת</span>). The 1st ed. reads “house” (<span>כית</span>).</i> in the tents of Jacob.
What did (Jacob)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “Jacob”; the first editions insert this word.</i> do? He wrote the Holy Name upon a golden plate,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He brought a plate and wrote upon it,” see T.B. Ḳiddushin, 73b.</i> and suspended it about her<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Asenath’s.</i> neck and sent her away. She went her way. Everything is revealed before the Holy One, blessed be He, and Michael the angel descended<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Sopherim, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and took her, and brought her down to Egypt to the house of Potiphera; because Asenath was destined to become the wife of Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Midrash Agadah, Gen. p. 97, has copied our book in giving the legend of Asenath. The narrative is also given in the book Raẓiel, p. 7a; see also Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 146.</i> Now the wife of Potiphera was barren, and (Asenath) grew up with her as a daughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> As to the sterility of the wife of Potiphera see Koran, Joseph Sura, and cf. Gen. Rab. 86:3; Midrash Haggadol, c. 579; Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. p. 98b, note 9; Jalḳuṭ to Pss., § 732; and cf. T.B. Soṭah, 13b. The legend that Potiphera was impotent passed from the Jews to Jerome. See Schapiro, <i>Die Haggadischen Elemente im erzählenden Teil des Korans</i>, p. 34 f.; and A. Marmorstein, <i>Studien zum Pseudo-Jonathan Targum</i>, pt. i. pp. 31 ff.</i> When Joseph came down to Egypt he married her, as it is said, "And he<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Pharaoh.</i> gave him<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Joseph; see Sopherim (ed. Müller), p. 309 (49), and J. Perles, <i>R.É.J.</i> xxi. p. 254.</i> to wife Asenath<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> the daughter of Potiphera priest of On" (Gen. 41:45).
Simeon and Levi were moved by a great zeal on account of the immorality, as it is said, "And they said, Should he deal with our sister as with an harlot?" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 31). And each man<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Simeon and Levi.</i> took his sword and slew all the men of Shechem. When Jacob heard thereof, he became sorely afraid.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The phraseology is based on Neh. 2:2. Luria reads here: “as it is said: ‘Ye have troubled me, to make me of bad repute among the inhabitants of the land… and, I being few in number, they will gather themselves together against me and smite me’” (Gen. 34:30).</i> For he said: Now all the people of the land will hear, and they will gather together against me || and smite me. He began to curse the wrath of his sons, as it is said, "Cursed be their anger, for it is fierce" (<i>ibid.</i> xlix. 7); and he also cursed their sword<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> This agrees with the reading preserved in ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, v. p. 139; see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 119.</i> in the Greek language, for he said: "Weapons of violence are their <i>swords</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Amsterdam and Prague editions add: “For thus do the Greeks call the sword,” <span>מכיר</span> (<i>μάχαιρα</i>, “daggers”); cf. Tanchuma, Vayechi, § ix. This addition is also given by the ‘Arukh (ed. Kohut), v. p. 139b, <i>s.v.</i> <span>מכר</span>. Jerome uses this version. See Steinschneider’s <i>Festschrift</i>, p. 158, article by Krauss.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 5).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 99:6.</i> All the kings<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Later editions read: “All the inhabitants.”</i> of the earth heard (thereof) and feared very much, saying: If two sons of Jacob have done all these great things, if they all band themselves together, they will be able to destroy the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Later editions read: “us.”</i> And the dread of the Holy One, blessed be He, fell upon them, as it is said, "And the terror of God<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. renders here: “a great terror.”</i> was<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> upon the cities,… and they did not pursue after the sons of Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxv. 5).
Jacob took his sons and his grandsons,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> “Grandsons” is probably an error; see Seder ‘Olam Rab. 2 6a; Gen. Rab. <i>loc. cit.</i>; and the Book of Jashar xxxi. 38.</i> and his wives, and he went to Kirjath Arba (so as to be) near Isaac his father. And he found there Esau and his sons and his wives dwelling in the tents of Isaac.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> But Jacob’s home was at Migdal Eder; cf. Pal. Targum, Gen. 35:21, and Mic. 4:8.</i> And he spread his tent apart from him;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> apart from Esau; cf. the Book of Jashar xxxii. 72.</i> and Isaac saw Jacob, his wives,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “his sons.”</i> his daughters, and all that belonged to him, and he rejoiced in his heart exceedingly. Concerning him the Scripture saith, "Yea, thou shalt see thy children's children, <i>peace be upon Israel</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> “Israel” is interpreted here as pointing to Jacob.</i> (Ps. 128:6).
Rabbi Levi said: In the hour of the ingathering<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> at his death. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 541.</i> of Isaac, he left his cattle and his possessions, and all that he had, to his two sons; therefore they both rendered loving-kindness (to him), as it is said, "And Esau and Jacob his sons buried him" (Gen. 35:29).
Esau said to Jacob: Divide all that my father has left into two portions, and I will choose<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 13a.</i> (first), because I am the elder.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the first-born.”</i> || Jacob said: This wicked man has not satisfied his eye with wealth, as it is said, "Neither are his eyes satisfied with riches" (Eccles. 4:8). What did Jacob do? He divided all that his father had left as the one part, and the other part was to be the land of Israel and the Cave of Machpelah.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading in Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 138, and in Midrash Haggadol, <i>loc. cit.</i>; cf. Ex. Rab. xxxi. 17, and <i>infra</i>, pp. 291, 309. The first editions omit “and the Cave of Machpelah.” The rest of the paragraph is wanting in Midrash Haggadol.</i> What did Esau do? He went to Ishmael<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that we should read “the sons of Ishmael” instead of “Ishmael” both here and in the next sentence. The first editions agree with the text of our MS. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 2 p. 5a.</i> in the wilderness in order to consult him, as it is said, "And Esau went unto Ishmael" (Gen. 28:9). Ishmael said to Esau: The Amorite and the Canaanite<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 12:6. The Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads “The Canaanite,” without mentioning the Amorite.</i> are in the land, and Jacob trusts (in God) that he will inherit the land, therefore take all that thy father has left, and Jacob will have nothing.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Test. XII Pat., Gad vii. 4: “For though a man become rich by evil means, even as Esau, the brother of my father, be not jealous; but wait for the end of the Lord.”</i>
And Esau took all that his father had left, and he gave to Jacob the land of Israel, and the Cave of Machpelah, and they wrote a perpetual deed between them.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> On the written agreement between them see <i>infra</i>, p. 309.</i> Jacob said to Esau: Go from the land of my possession, from the land of Canaan. Esau took his wives, and his sons, and his daughters, and all that he had, [as it is said, "And Esau took his wives… and all his possessions which he had gathered in the land of Canaan],<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are not in the MS., but they occur in the first editions.</i> and went into a land<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds here “etc.,” clearly indicating that the words “and went into a land” belong to a quotation from Scripture. The quotation is continued in the first editions.</i> away from his brother Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxvi. 6). And as a reward<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 76 (quoting the Tanna de bê Elijahu), and see also Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 13 p. 65, note 49.</i> because he removed all his belongings on account of Jacob his brother, He gave him one hundred provinces from Seir unto Magdiel, and Magdiel is Rome, as it is said, "Duke Magdiel, Duke Iram" (<i>ibid.</i> 43).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 83:4.</i>
Then Jacob dwelt safely and in peace in the land of his possession,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in the land of Canaan.”</i> and in the land of his birth, and in the land of the sojournings of his father.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said: ‘And Jacob dwelt in the land of his father’s sojournings’” (Gen. 37:1).</i>
Rabbi Ishmael said: Every son of the old age || is beloved of his father, as it is said, "Now Israel loved Joseph<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> more than all his children, because he was the son of his old age" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxvii. 3). Was he then the son of his old age? Was not Benjamin the son of his old age?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Rashbam (comm., <i>in loc.</i>), Jacob called his youngest child “Son of days”—Ben-jamin; Judah also referred to him as “the child of old age.” Onḳelos renders: “Son of wisdom,” <i>i.e.</i> a wise child; see T.B. Megillah, 16b; Leḳach Ṭob, Gen. 35:18, p. 91a, notes 46 and 47. The interpretation given by <i>P.R.E.</i> agrees with the Arabian legend quoted by Schapiro, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 19. The same explanation is also given by Ephraim of Syria, <i>Hist. of Joseph</i>, p. 16 (quoted by Schapiro).</i> But owing to the fact that (Jacob) saw by his prophetic power that (Joseph) would rule<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In Egypt, and there he would sustain the entire family in Jacob’s old age. The reference to kingship may also refer to the ascendancy of the house of Joseph in Jewish history, and perhaps to the rule of the Messiah ben Joseph.</i> in the future, therefore he loved him more than all his sons. And they envied him with a great envy, as it is said, "And his brethren saw that<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> their father loved him more than all his brethren; and they hated him" (<i>ibid.</i> 4). Further, because he saw in his dream that in the future he would rule, and he told his father, and they envied him yet more and more, as it is said, "And they hated<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> him yet the more" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). Moreover, he saw the sons of his father's concubines<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Test. XII Pat., Gad i. 6, and cf. Gen. Rab. 84:7.</i> eating the flesh of the roes and the flesh of the sheep whilst they were alive,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This was one of the seven precepts of the “Sons of Noah”; see Pal. Targum, Gen. 9:4. On the mutilation of the flock see T.B. Bekhoroth, 39b; T.B. Kethuboth, 5b, and 37a; and cf. T.B. Chullin, 121 b. They are said to have taken of the flesh of the ear of the sheep, although the animals were alive. See Test. of the XII Pat., Gad, <i>loc. cit.</i>, where a “lamb” incident is mentioned; and cf. Pal. Targ. on Gen. 37:2.</i> and he brought a reproach<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>דפי</span>, “reproach”; cf. Ps. 50:20, where LXX renders the word by <i>σκάνδαλον</i> (offence).</i> against them before Jacob their father, so that they could not see his face any more (in peace), as it is said, "And they could not speak peaceably unto him" (<i>ibid.</i> 4). Jacob said to Joseph: Joseph, my son ! Verily I have (waited) many days without hearing of the welfare of thy brethren, and of the welfare of the flock, as it is said, "Go now, see whether it be well with thy brethren,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and well with the flock" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). And the lad<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. repeats the word “lad”; this is due to the scribe’s carelessness.</i> was wandering<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i>, and the Book of Jashar xli. 22. The first editions read: “was walking and wandering on the way.”</i> in the field, and the angel Gabriel<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 141, and Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i> This legend was known to Basil (i. p. 19). See Schapiro, <i>op. cit.</i>, p. 27, for the legend of the angel Gabriel and Joseph in Arabian literature. Gabriel appears in the New Testament account of the Annunciation of the birth of Jesus; see Luke i. 26.</i> met him, as it is said, "And a certain <i>man</i> found him, and, behold, he was wandering<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the 1st ed.</i> in the field" (<i>ibid.</i> 15). (The word) "man" (here in this context) is Gabriel only, as it is said, "The <i>man</i> Gabriel,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the 1st ed.</i> whom I had seen in the vision" (Dan. 9:21).
And (Gabriel) said to him: What seekest thou? He said to him: I seek my brethren, as it is said, "And he said, I seek my brethren" (Gen. 37:16). And he led him to || his brethren, and they saw him and sought to slay him, as it is said, "And they saw him afar off" (<i>ibid.</i> 18). Reuben said to them: Do not shed his blood, as it is said, "And Reuben said unto them, Shed no blood;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the 1st ed.</i> cast him into this pit that is in the wilderness" (<i>ibid.</i> 22). And<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “and he will die there.”</i> his brethren listened to him, and they took Joseph and cast him into the pit, as it is said, "And they took him, and cast him into the pit" (<i>ibid.</i> 24). What did Reuben do? He went and stayed on one of the mountains, so as to go down by night to bring up Joseph out of the pit.
