And his nine brethren were sitting down<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> To eat bread; cf. Gen. 37:25.</i> in one place, all of them like one man, with one heart and one plan.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Tanchuma, Vayesheb, § ii., reads: “As one man with one purpose.”</i> Ishmaelites passed by them, and (the brethren) said: Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites, and they will lead him to the end of the wilderness, and Jacob will not hear any further report concerning him.
(The brethren) sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Test. Gad ii. 3(b), with Charles’ note, <i>in loc.</i>, Pal. Targ., <i>in loc.</i>, and the Book of Jashar xlii. 19. Test. Zeb. 1:5 says: “Nor yet do I remember that I have done any iniquity, except the sin of ignorance which I committed against Joseph; <i>for I covenanted with my brethren not to tell my father</i> what had been done.” See the next verse also.</i> of silver, and each one of them took two pieces of silver (apiece) to purchase shoes for their feet, as it is said, "Thus saith the Lord,… Because they have sold<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> the righteous for <i>silver</i>, and the needy for a pair of <i>shoes</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Thereby reducing the needy to the condition of slavery. This legend has been borrowed from Test. Zeb. 3:2, or from its source; see Pal. Targ. Gen. 37:28, and Liturgy, Day of Atonement, ed. H. M. Adler, ii. pp. 178 f.</i> (Amos 2:6). They said: Let us swear<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “Let us put ourselves under the ban” (to prevent our divulging the matter).</i> among ourselves that no one of us shall declare the matter to our father Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “except it be by the consent of all of us.” See <i>supra</i>, note 1, quotation from Test. Zeb. 1:5.</i> Judah said to them: Reuben is not here, and the ban cannot be valid through nine (adults).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The ban cannot be valid save by ten (adults).” See Midrash Haggadol, c. 564.</i> What did they do? They associated the Omnipresent with them and proclaimed the ban.
And Reuben || went down by night to bring up Joseph out of the pit, but he did not find him there.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit.</i>, adds: “and he returned to his brethren and said to them.” See Test. Zeb. 4:5.</i> He said to them: Ye have slain Joseph; "and I, whither shall I go?" (Gen. 37:80). And they told him what they had done, and the ban which they had proclaimed; and Reuben heard of the ban, and was silent; the Holy One, blessed be He, because of the ban, did not tell the matter to Jacob, and (though) concerning Him it is written, "He sheweth his word unto Jacob" (Ps. 147:19); but this word He did not shew unto Jacob, therefore Jacob did not know what had been done to Joseph, and he said: "Joseph is without doubt torn in pieces" (Gen. 37:33).
Rabbi Jannai said: The sale of Joseph was not atoned by the tribes<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 84:17, and cf. Tosephta Berakhoth 4:18, p. 11.</i> until they<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Joseph’s brethren. The brethren are called “the tribes”; see <i>supra</i>, p. 264, and <i>infra</i>, p. 376.</i> died, as it is said, "And the Lord of hosts revealed Himself in mine ears, Surely this iniquity shall not be purged<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 565.</i> from you till ye die" (Isa. 22:14).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit</i>., in name of R. Mana.</i> Owing to the sale (of Joseph) a famine came into the land of Israel for seven years, and the brethren of Joseph "went down to buy corn" (Gen. 42:3) in Egypt. And they found Joseph (still) living, and they absolved themselves of the ban;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “they annulled” or “loosened the ban.” Cf. the use of “binding and loosing” in the N.T.: “I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be <i>bound in heaven</i>: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be <i>loosed in heaven</i>” (Matt. xvi. 19).</i> and Jacob heard about Joseph that he was living, and his soul and his spirit revived.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said, ‘The spirit of Jacob, their father, revived’” (Gen. 45:27).</i> Did their father Jacob's spirit die, so that it had to be revived? But, owing to the ban, the Holy Spirit had departed from him, and when they had removed the ban the Holy Spirit rested on him as at first; that || is what is written, "The spirit of Jacob their father revived" (<i>ibid.</i> xlv. 27).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Onḳelos translates this (passage): ‘And the spirit of prophecy rested on Jacob their father.’” Luria thinks that this is a gloss. On Onḳelos see <i>J.E</i>. ix. 405, and see Hastings’ <i>D.B</i>. iv. 679b.</i>
Rabbi 'Aḳiba said: The ban is as much as the oath, and an oath is as much as the ban; and everyone who violates the ban is as though he had violated the oath, and everyone who violates the oath is as though he had violated the ban. Everyone who knows the matter and does not declare<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> As in the case of Achan’s children; see <i>infra</i>, p. 296. Cf. Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit</i>., and see T.B. and T. J. Nedarim, Maimonides, Hilkhoth Nedarim, and Shulchan ‘Arukh, Joreh Di‘ah, § 203 ff., on the laws as to vows.</i> it, the ban falls upon him and destroys his timber and his stones, as it is said, "I will cause it to go forth, saith the Lord… and it shall enter into the house of him that sweareth falsely by my name… and shall consume it with the timber thereof and the stones thereof" (Zech. 5:4).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the first part only of the verse is given; in the first editions only the latter part is quoted. See Jalḳuṭ, Zech. (ed. King), p. 34.</i>
Know the power of the ban.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> Come and see from Joshua, the son of Nun, who put Jericho under the ban; it was to be burnt with all things therein by fire. Achan, son of Carmi,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The name “Carmi” means vineyard-man; see Josh. 7:1.</i> son of Zerach, saw the Teraphim,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is inferred from the reference in the Book of Joshua 7:21 to the “tongue of gold” stolen by Achan; see <i>supra</i>, p. 274.</i> and the silver which they brought (as offerings) before it, and the mantle which was spread before it, and one tongue of gold in its mouth. And in his heart he coveted them, and went and<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and he took them.”</i> buried them in the midst of his tent. On account of his trespass which he had committed, thirty-six righteous men died on his account,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 44a.</i> as it is said, "And the men of Ai smote of them<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> about thirty and six men" (Josh. 7:5).
Joshua went and rent his garments, and fell upon his face to the ground before the Ark of the Covenant of God, and he sought (to effect) repentance, and the Holy One, blessed be He, was appeased by him, and He said to him: Joshua ! Israel has trespassed the sin of trespass in the matter of the devoted things, as it is said, "Israel hath sinned" (<i>ibid.</i> 11). Joshua gazed at the twelve || stones which were upon the High Priest, which correspond to the twelve tribes.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions insert here: “The light of every tribe which had observed the commandments (lit. which had a precept in its hand) shone.”</i> Every tribe that had done some transgression, the light (of its stone) became dim,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “its light did not shine.”</i> and he saw the stone of the tribe of Judah,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashi, on Josh., <i>in loc</i>., who quotes <i>P.R.E</i>.</i> the light of which became dim. And he knew that the tribe of Judah had transgressed in the matter of the devoted thing. He cast lots, and Achan was taken, as it is said, "And he brought near<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits the words: “his household, man by man.”</i> his household man by man; and Achan, the son of Carmi, was taken" (<i>ibid.</i> 18). Joshua took Achan, the son of Zerach,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Josh. 7:18: “Achan, son of Carmi, the son of Zabdi, the son of Zerach.”</i> with the silver and the mantle and the tongue of gold, and his sons and his daughters, and all that he had, and he brought them up into the valley of Achor.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Josh. 7:24.</i> And it is written, "The fathers shall not be put to death for the children,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions. The latter add after the quotation: “If so, for what reason did these (children) die?”</i> neither shall the children be put to death for the fathers" (Deut. 24:16). But because they were cognizant of the matter, and did not report it,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 294. for the view of Rabbi ‘Aḳiba on this point.</i> he stoned them and burnt them.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum, Josh. 7:24 f. Rashi, Gersonides, and other Jewish commentators maintain that the stoning was inflicted only on the beasts, and that Achan’s children were there merely to see and to be warned.</i> If there was a burning, why (was there) a stoning, and if a stoning, why a burning? But the stoning was because they knew of the matter and did not report it; burning (was inflicted) because thirty-six righteous men died through him,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Achan.</i> as it is said, "And the men of Ai smote of them<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> about thirty and six men" (Josh. 7:5).
Because (Achan) confessed<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Josh. 7:20.</i> before the Name of the Holy One, blessed be He, he has a portion in the world to come, as it is said, "And Joshua said, Why hast thou troubled us?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far is the quotation in the MS.; this part of the verse is omitted in the first editions.</i> The Lord shall trouble thee <i>this day</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 25). "This day" thou art troubled, but thou shalt not be troubled in the future world.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit</i>., and <i>J.E</i>. i. 164 f.; cf. also Num. Rab. 23:6, and Semachoth, ii.</i>
Know thou the power of the ban. Come and see from the (story of) the tribes, who were zealous because of immorality against || the tribe of Benjamin.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 103b; Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 11 pp. 56 f.; and cf. T.B. Baba Bathra, 109b.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Ye are zealous because of the immorality,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “of the tribe of Benjamin.”</i> and ye are not zealous because of the image of Micah. Therefore the Benjamites slew some of them a first and a second<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> This reading agrees with Jalḳuṭ, Judg. § 76.</i> and a third time, until they went<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and fell upon their faces to the ground.” See Jalḳuṭ, Joshua, § 18. Cf. Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 18 p. 89.</i> before the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord seeking repentance, and they were forgiven. They decreed<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “They issued the ban” (against all who disobeyed).</i> that all Israel should (make peace) with them,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first edition has the same reading here as our MS. The Venice edition reads: “all Israel should go up after them.”</i> and they repented<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and they made an oath.”</i> both old and young, as it is said, "For they made a great oath<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> concerning him that came not up unto the Lord to Mizpah" (Judg. 21:5). Did all Israel take an oath? But the ban is the same as the oath.
The men of Jabesh-Gilead neither went up nor did they go with them in the assembly, and they incurred (the penalty of) death, as it is said, "Concerning him that came not up<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “unto the Lord to Mizpah” and reads instead “into the assembly.” The first editions omit the word “saying.” This omission in both texts is a probable indication of the dependence of the 2nd ed. on the 1st.</i> unto the Lord to Mizpah, saying, He shall surely be put to death" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Know thou the power of the ban. Come and see from (the story of) Saul, the son of Kish, who decreed that all people, both young and old, should fast, as it is said, "Cursed be the man that eateth any food<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> until it be evening" (1 Sam. 14:24). Jonathan did not hear (of this), and ate a little honey,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Samuel, <i>in loc</i>., and T.B. Berakhoth, 14a. Jalḳuṭ on Samuel, <i>in loc</i>., seems to be based on our Midrash.</i> and his eyes were enlightened,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Luria’s emendation we should read “both his eyes.”</i> as it is said, "And his eyes<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions read “both his eyes.” M.T. omits “both.” See T.B. Joma, 83a.</i> were enlightened" (<i>ibid.</i> 27). Saul saw the Philistines returning against Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, Vayesheb, <i>loc. cit</i>., which reads: “Saul saw that the Philistines were prevailing over the Israelites”; the Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc</i>., reads: “The Philistines were strengthening themselves against Israel.”</i> and he knew that Israel had trespassed in the matter of the ban. He looked at the twelve stones;<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He looked at the twelve tribes.” Perhaps we should read: “He looked at the twelve stones of the tribes.”</i> for each tribe which performed one of the precepts had its stone || (on the High Priest's breast-plate) shining with its light, and each tribe which transgressed, the light of its stone was dim.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 295, note 6.</i> He knew that the tribe of Benjamin had trespassed in the matter of the ban. He cast lots<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The method of procedure was as follows: The tribe concerned was indicated by the stone of that tribe on the breastplate. Then lots were cast to determine the family (see 1 Sam. 14:36–42), and finally the members of the family were placed before the Ark of the Covenant, which caused the transgressor to become paralysed. See Ḳimchi, on Josh. 7:18, and cf. <i>J.E</i>. xii. 385 ff.</i> concerning Benjamin, and Saul and Jonathan were taken, as it is said, "And Jonathan<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In this and the next two quotations our MS. reads “Jehonathan.” M.T. has “Jonathan.”</i> and Saul<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. and the first editions read: “Saul and Jonathan.” M.T. reads: “Jonathan and Saul.”</i> were taken" (<i>ibid.</i> 41). Saul took his sword to slay his son, as it is said, "God do so,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions add “to me.” This is not in M.T. The variant readings of Biblical texts preserved by our MS. are note-worthy.</i> and more also: for thou shalt surely die, Jonathan" (<i>ibid.</i> 44). The people said to him: Our lord king ! It is an error. They brought on his behalf a sacrifice of a burnt offering for his error, and He was entreated of him, and they saved him from an evil death, as it is said, "So the people rescued Jonathan, that he died not" (<i>ibid.</i> 45).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum and Nachmanides on Lev. 27:29. See also Targum on 1 Sam., <i>in loc</i>.</i>
The Cutheans<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or Samaritans. In Talmudic times were proselytes accepted from among the Samaritans?</i> are not considered as a nation<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. one of the seventy nations. For a parallel view see Ecclus. l. 26.</i> of the seventy languages, but they were the remnant of the five nations precious to the king,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, Vayesheb, <i>loc. cit</i>., which reads: “They were the remnant of the five nations whom the king of Assyria led captive, as it is said: etc.”</i> as it is said, "And the king of Assyria brought<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; the first editions add “from Cuthah,” and omit “from Babylon,” which is the reading of M.T.</i> men from Babylon, and from Cuthah, and from Avva, and from Hamath and Sepharvaim, and placed them in the cities of Samaria instead of the children of Israel" (2 Kings 17:24).
Rabbi José said: He added four more nations to them, and they were in all nine nations,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> On these nine nations see Seder ‘Olam Rab. 22 (end), p. 50a, note 40, and Bacher, T. ii. 189. 5.</i> as it is said, "The Dinaites, and the Apharsathchites,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> the Tarpelites, the Apharsites, the Archevites, the Babylonians, the Shushanchites, the Dehaites, the Elamites, and the rest of the nations… set in the city of Samaria" (Ezra 4:9, 10).
And when the Israelites were exiled<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from their place.”</i> from Samaria to Babylon, the king sent his servants, and he caused them to dwell in Samaria, to raise tribute for (his) kingdom. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He sent lions among them, || which killed some of them, as it is said, "And so it was, at the beginning of their dwelling there,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> that they feared not the Lord: therefore the Lord sent lions among them, which killed some of them" (2 Kings 17:25).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ta‘anith, 22b, and cf. Rashi, <i>in loc</i>.</i> They sent to the king,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “king of Babylon.” The Bible speaks here of the king of Assyria.</i> saying: Our lord, the king ! The land whither thou hast sent us will not receive us, for we are left but a few out of many.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, 2 Kings, § 234.</i> The king sent and called for all the elders of Israel, and said to them: All those years during which ye were in your land, the beasts of the field did not bereave you, and now it will not receive my servants. They gave him a word of advice, (thinking) perhaps he would restore them to their land. They said to him: Our lord, O king! That land does not receive a nation who do not study the Torah; behold, that land does not receive a nation who are not circumcised.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the words: “That land does not receive a nation who do not study the Torah.” Tanchuma, Vayesheb, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>., read: “Because they do not study the Torah.”</i> The king said to them: Give me two of you, who shall go and circumcise them and teach them the book of the Torah; and there is no refusal to the word of the king. They sent Rabbi Dosethai<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> On Dosethai see Krauss’ article in <i>J.E</i>. iv. 643 f. Bacher, T. ii. 385–7, considers that the name was probably suggested by its similarity to that of the Samaritan sect of the Dositheans.</i> of the Court-House,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “Bedaynê”; cf. Beth Din, and Jastrow, <i>T.D</i>. 140a.</i> and Rabbi Micaiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This name occurs only in our MS. The same name occurs in Neh. 12:35. The first editions read “Zechariah.” Krauss, <i>loc. cit</i>., seems to identify Zechariah with Sabbæus (<span>סבייא</span>, as in Tanchuma).</i> and they circumcised them, and they taught them the book of the Torah in the Noṭariḳon<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> On Noṭariḳon (shorthand) see <i>J.E</i>. xi. 339 f., where a reference to <i>P.R.E</i>. is made; see Krauss’ article in <i>R.É.J</i>. xlii. p. 29, note 1, and Bacher, <i>Terminologie</i>, i. 125.</i> script, and they<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The two Rabbis who foresaw the troubles destined to come from the Samaritans. Krauss, <i>loc. cit</i>., suggests that <span>ובוכים</span>, “and they wept,” should read <span>וכותים</span>, “and Samaritan” (writing); see Bacher, in <i>Monatsschrift</i>, xl. 19. The Karaites employed Noṭariḳon, which was known to the Samaritans (cf. At. BSh, <span>א״ת ב״ש</span>).</i> wept. Those nations followed the statutes of the Torah, and they served (also) their own gods.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “As it is said: ‘They feared the Lord, and served their own gods’” (2 Kings 17:33).</i>
When Ezra came up<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from Babylon.”</i> (with) Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua, || son of Jehozadak, they began to build<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “Bokhim” (weeping); this agrees with Tanchuma and the first editions. It seems probable that the original reading was “Bonim” (building); this reading is preserved in Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> the Temple of the Lord, as it is said, "Then rose up Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> and Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, <i>and began to build the house of God</i>" (Ezra 5:2). And the Samaritans came against them to fight (with) 180,000 (men).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This number as the unit for war is derived from 1 Kings 12:21; see also 2 Kings 19:35; and T.B. Synhedrin, 95b.</i> Were they Samaritans? Were they not Cutheans?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Dositheans flourished in Egypt, so much so that the Christian patriarch of Alexandria engaged in polemics against them. The Samaritans were divided into two sects: (1) that of the Kushan (Cuthim) and (2) that of the Dostan (Dositheans). See also Josephus, <i>Ant</i>. ix. 14. 3. The subject has been dealt with by Drusius in Trigland’s <i>Trium scriptorum illustrium de tribus Judœorum sectis syntagma</i>, i. 283. See also Montgomery, <i>The Samaritans</i>, pp. 254 ff.</i> But they were called Samaritans because of the city of Samaria. And further, they sought to kill Nehemiah, as it is said, "Come, let us<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. Sanballat and Geshem the Arabian; see Neh. 4:7 ff. and vi. 1 ff.</i> meet together<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions “in one of the villages” is added.</i> in one of the villages,… but they thought to do me mischief" (Neh. 6:2). Moreover, they made the work<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. the rebuilding of the Temple. The first editions read: “the heavenly work”; for the expression see T.B. Ta‘anith, 23a.</i> of the Lord to cease<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “annulled.”</i> for two years<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “as it is said: ‘And it shall be… until the year of Jubilee’” (cf. Lev. 25:50); so also in the first edition, which omits “as it is said.” In our MS. the portion in brackets is not given.</i> ["Then <i>ceased the work of the house of God</i>, which is at Jerusalem];<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on Kings, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Tanchuma, Vayesheb, <i>loc. cit</i>., for this reading; see also Gen. Rab. 94:9; Seder ‘Olam Rab. 29 p. 67b; T.B. Megillah, 11b.</i> and it ceased unto the second year of the reign of Darius, king of Persia" (Ezra 4:24).
What did Ezra, Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua son of Jehozadak, do?<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ezra 4:3.</i> They gathered all the congregation to the Temple of the Lord, and they brought 800 priests, 800 children,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “300 trumpets.” Shophar is the term here for “trumpet.”</i> and 800 scrolls of the Torah in their hands,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. the children’s hands; see Sopherim 3:18.</i> and they blew<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>., the trumpets were in the hands of the priests.</i> (the trumpets), and the Levites sang songs and praises, and they excommunicated the Cutheans with the mystery of the Ineffable Name, and with the script such as was written upon the tables (of the Law), and by the ban of the heavenly Court of Justice, and by the ban of the earthly Court of Justice (decreeing) that no one of Israel should eat the bread of the Cutheans.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 35b and 38a, and Jubilees xxii. 16. The first editions add “for ever.”</i> Hence (the sages) said: Everyone who eats the bread<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “the meat.”</i> of the Cutheans is as though he had eaten of the flesh of swine.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Shebi‘ith viii. 10; and cf. Tosaphoth Giṭṭin, 10a, and T.B. Chullin, 4a.</i> Let no man make a proselyte in Israel from among the Cutheans.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On proselytes see <i>J.E</i>. x. pp. 220 ff. and <i>R.É.J</i>. xii. p. 318. The form of the ban, and the prohibition of eating the bread of the Samaritans, have been exhaustively considered by Dr. Büchler in <i>R.É.J</i>. xliii. pp. 50 ff., where the following results are stated: (1) The form of the ban and its accompanying circumstances—(<i>a</i>) children as witnesses, (<i>b</i>) scrolls of law to sanctify the pronouncement, and (<i>c</i>) sounding of the Shofar—tally with the practice known to the Geonim of Babylon in the ninth century (<i>e.g</i>. Paltoi; see Chemdah Genuẓah, No. xxii., and cf. ‘Arukh, <i>s.v</i>. <span>הסת</span>, iii. 229a; see also Hekhaloth Rab., ed. Jellinek, <i>B.H.M</i>. iii. p. 84). The prohibition of eating the <i>bread</i> of the Samaritans mentioned by our author does not find any support in the Talmudic literature (see T.J. Shebi‘ith vii. 38b, line 69), but is “an institution of the Geonic age” (p. 64). The decree says that Samaritans could not be received as proselytes. Where the texts of the Talmud speak of <span>כותי</span>, “Samaritan,” we have probably to read <span>נכרי</span>. There was a sect who were put on this footing by the Gaon Naṭronai (Teshuboth Ha-Geonim, Sha‘arê Zedeḳ, p. 24a, Nos. 7 and 27). The Halakhoth Gedoloth (ed. Hildesheimer, 443) states that “Cutheans, Seboneans, and <i>Samaritans</i> are not to be received as proselytes.” This again appears in the Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa (p. 169). The Karaites in the ninth century mutilated the Bible text, and in their reading agreed with the Samaritans (p. 67). In other words the literature of the Samaritans of the ninth century exercised a baneful influence in creating sects opposed to orthodox Judaism. Hence the ban against them. Moreover, the word for ban (<span>חרם</span>) does not occur in the Talmud (B. Shebu‘oth, 35b–36a), but is common in the Geonic period. On the oath or ban see Eth. Enoch vi. 4 ff., where Mount Hermon is mentioned; Dr. Büchler sees here a reference to <span>חרם</span>. Is there any connection, he asks, between Enoch and our book here? That Jubilees was known to the Geonim has been shown by Epstein, <span>מקרמוניות היהורים</span>, page vii, and also the fact that many of the characteristics of the Enoch literature have their parallels in the Geonic literature (see <i>Z.D.M.G</i>. vii. (1853) p. 249) has been established.</i> They have no || portion in the resurrection of the dead,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Dositheans, like the Sadducees, denied the future life. The question as to a future life would not have arisen in the time of Ezra. See Mishnah Synhedrin 10:1 and the Baraitha in T.B. Synhedrin, 90a, where, however, heretics only are referred to, and not Samaritans.</i> as it is said, "Ye have nothing to do with us<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> to build an house unto our God" (<i>ibid.</i> 3), neither in this world, nor in the world to come. So that they should have neither portion nor inheritance in Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Jerusalem.”</i> as it is said, "But ye have no portion, nor right, nor memorial, in Jerusalem"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “Israel”; M.T. has “Jerusalem.” Is the M.T. purposely altered so as to justify the decree that no one in <i>Israel</i> is to receive a Cuthean as a proselyte?</i> (Neh. 2:20).
They sent the ban (letter) to the Israelites who were in Babylon. Moreover, they added an additional ban upon them, and King Cyrus ordained it as a perpetual ban upon them, (as it is said,)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is wanting in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i> "And the God that hath caused his name to dwell there<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here. Our MS. and the first editions read “tamman” (there), whereas M.T. has “tammah.” The meaning is, of course, identical.</i> overthrow all kings and peoples that shall put forth their hand to alter the same, to destroy this house of God which is at Jerusalem. I, Darius, have made a decree; let it be done with all diligence" (Ezra 6:12).

Chapter 39

CHAPTER XXXIX<br><small>JOSEPH IN EGYPT</small> [53<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>T<small>HE</small> fourth descent was (when) He descended into Egypt, (as it is said),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is omitted by the MS.; it occurs in the first editions and in the Oxford MS. and in MS. Gaster.</i> "I will go down with thee into Egypt" (Gen 46:4). Jacob heard concerning Joseph that he was living, and he was thinking in his heart, saying: Can I forsake the land of my fathers, the land of my birth, the land of the sojournings of my fathers,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This clause occurs in our MS. only.</i> the land where the Shekhinah of the Holy One, blessed be He, is in its midst, and shall I go to an unclean land in their midst,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Oxford MS. reads: “among slaves, in the midst of the children of Ham, where there is no fear of Heaven among them.” The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “among slaves, the children of Ham, in a land where there is no fear of Heaven in their midst.”</i> for there is no fear of Heaven therein?<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Gen. 20:11.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Jacob, do not fear; "I will go down with thee into Egypt,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MSS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and I will also surely bring thee up again" (<i>ibid.</i>).

Rabbi Tanchum<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> A Palestinian Amora of the third century. Rabbi Eliezer said: In the hour of the death of Jacob he called to his son Joseph, and said to him: O my son! Swear to me by the covenant of circumcision that thou wilt take me up to the burial-place of my fathers in the land of Canaan to the Cave of Machpelah. The<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Originally the ancients,” etc.</i> ancients used to swear by the covenant of circumcision prior to the giving of the Torah, as it is said, "Put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh" (<i>ibid.</i> 29), and "he sware unto him" (<i>ibid.</i> 31). He kept (the oath) and did (accordingly), as it is said, "And he said, Swear unto me" (<i>ibid.</i>). And all the mighty men of the kingdom went up with him to bury him, and to show loving-kindness to Jacob his father, as it is said, "And Joseph went up to bury his father" (<i>ibid.</i> l. 7). The camp of Israel numbered 5040 (people). All the (people of the) land were bringing food on account of the famine to the camp of Joseph.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “All the people, who were taking food home on account of the famine, were in the camp of Joseph.” This is the emended reading suggested by Luria. The people of Canaan were there to pay respect to Jacob; see Gen. 50:11; according to Gen. Rab., <i>in loc</i>., and Tanchuma, Vayechi, § xvii., even the kings of Canaan joined in this mark of respect.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Ye have shown loving-kindness<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, Chapter XVII.</i> to Jacob, My servant, I also will give you your reward, and also unto your children in this world. When the Egyptians died in the Reed Sea they did not die in the water,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 332. The first editions read: “they did not remain in the water.”</i> but they were deemed worthy to be buried in the earth. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Ye have submitted yourselves<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Pharaoh said: “The Lord is righteous, but I and my people are evil” (Ex. 9:27); see Mekhilta, Beshallach, Proem, 33b; and cf. T.B. Pesachim, 118a.</i> to the divine punishment; I also will give you a place of burial, as it is said, "Thou stretchedst forth thy right hand, the earth swallowed them" (Ex. 15:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 169 f., where the passage from the Mekhilta (referred to in the previous note) is translated.</i>
When they came to the Cave of Machpelah, Esau came against them || from Mount Horeb<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Esau came against them from Mount Seir.” See also Wisdom x. 12.</i> to stir up strife,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The expression is based on Prov. 26:17.</i> saying: The Cave of Machpelah is mine.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 13a; this passage is translated in <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 125 ff.</i> What did Joseph do? He sent Naphtali to subdue the constellations,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “To hasten like a hind.” This is Luria’s emendation. On Naphtali’s fleetness see Gen. 49:21, T.B. Soṭah, <i>loc. cit</i>.; and cf. Test. Naph. ii. 1.</i> and to go down to Egypt to bring up the perpetual deed which was between them,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Jacob and Esau; see <i>supra</i>, p. 290. The Prague and Brode’s editions read “in their hand” instead of “between them.”</i> therefore it is said, "Naphtali is a hind let loose" (Gen. 49:21). Chushim, the son of Dan, had defective hearing and speech,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar, ch. lvi., for a parallel account of the legend, which practically agrees with <i>P.R.E</i>. According to Charles the legend in the Book of Jashar “has borrowed its materials from the Midrash in Josippon”; see <i>Jubilees</i>, ed. Charles, p. 215, note. Charles refers to Bousset, <i>Z.f.N.T. Wissensch</i>., 1900, p. 205. In this connection the legend of the wars between the sons of Jacob and Esau with his sons in Jubilees xxxvii., xxxviii., the Testament of Judah (Test. XII Pat.) ix., and Jeraḥmeel, pp. 80–87, must be considered very briefly. According to Charles, “the oldest form of the legend is found in Jubilees and in the Test. Jud. 9; the next oldest is the Jalḳuṭ and Chronicles of Jeraḥmeel, and the latest is the Book of Jashar” (<i>Jubilees</i>, p. 215). The account in the Book of Jashar contains two parts: (1) the death of Esau by the hands of Chushim, son of Dan, at the burial of Jacob. This part of the legend is taken directly from our book, which was also the source used by Pal. Targum on Gen. 50:13. The source of our Midrash was T.B. Soṭah, <i>loc. cit</i>. Then (2) the account of the wars between the sons of Esau and the sons of Jacob which the Book of Jashar gives is undoubtedly connected with the account of Zepho, son of Eliphas, and Æneas of Africa, given in the history of Josippon. Now the Chronicles of Jeraḥmeel agree with the Book of Jubilees in making Jacob the slayer of his brother Esau, and they agree in fixing the occasion of the conflict at the mourning for Leah. According to Beer, <i>Das Buck der Jubiläen</i>, pp. 4 ff., the original form of the legend was that Judah slew Esau at the burial of Isaac. The death of Esau at the hands of Judah is mentioned in T. J. Kethuboth 1. 5 (p. 25c); T.J. Giṭṭin 5:6 (p. 47a); Siphrê, Deut. § 348; Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 18:40 (sect. 32); see also Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 162; and Jalḳuṭ, Samuel, § 163. The later form of the legend is preserved in T.B. Soṭah, <i>loc. cit</i>., which attributes the death of Esau to Chushim, who was deaf and dumb, at the burial of Jacob. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>., combines both forms of the legend. Jalḳuṭ, Pss. § 776, agrees with our book in the details of the death of Esau. Beer draws attention to the fact that the Jews of Palestine in the time of Hadrian (<i>c</i>. 135 <small>C.E.</small>) attributed the fierce hatred on the part of the Romans to the belief that Judah, the forefather of the Jews, had slain Esau, the forefather of the Romans, who were identified with the Edomites descended from Esau. In order to remove the “historical” foundation for this hostility, later forms of the legend transferred the deed to an irresponsible person, Chushim, whose descendants, the tribe of Dan, had long since disappeared from the land of Israel, having been carried away into exile, and, as some of the Rabbis taught, lost for all time. Jubilees holds to the original legend, owing to the opposition which it represents to the orthodox Rabbinic traditions of Palestine obtaining in the period prior to and following the rise of Christianity. Pirkê de R. Eliezer is aware of the teaching of Jubilees, and tries to correct and refute it on all fundamental points of controversy. This is sometimes done as strikingly by omission as by a variant doctrine, or story.</i> and he said to them: Why are we sitting here? He was pointing (to Esau) with his finger. They said to him: Because this man will not let us bury our father Jacob. What did he do? He drew his sword and cut off Esau's head with the sword, and took the head into the Cave of Machpelah. And they sent his body to the land of his possession, to Mount Seir.
What did Isaac do? He grasped the head of Esau and prayed before the Holy One, blessed be He, and said: Sovereign of all the universe ! Let mercy be shown<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The words are borrowed from Isa. 26:10.</i> to this wicked one, for he had not learnt all the precepts of the Torah, as it is said, "Let favour be shewed to the wicked,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions omit the first part of the verse.</i> yet will he not learn righteousness" (Isa. 26:10). He was speaking in iniquity concerning the land of Israel and the Cave of Machpelah, as it is said, "In<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads: “and in the land.” This is not the reading in M.T. which is given by MS. Gaster. The reading in the Venice edition is also faulty.</i> the land of uprightness will he deal wrongfully" (<i>ibid.</i>).
The Holy Spirit answered him, saying: As I live! he shall not see the majesty of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said, ‘And he will not behold the majesty of the Lord’” (Isa. 26:10).</i>

Chapter 40

CHAPTER XL<br><small>MOSES AT THE BURNING BUSH</small> [55<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>T<small>HE</small> fifth descent<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 97, for the fourth descent. These “descents” are connecting links in the narrative. This accounts for the apparent disorder in the chapters which now follow, for we have the “Revelation” in the thorn-bush and at Sinai before the narrative of the birth of Moses. On the “descent” see Pal. Targum, Ex. 3:8.</i> was when He came down to the thorn-bush, as it is said, "And I am come down || to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians" (Ex. 3:8). He abandoned the entire mountain,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. Sinai.</i> and descended into the thorn-bush, and He abode therein. And the thorn-bush was (an emblem of) grief and distress,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, Shemoth, § xiv.; Jalḳuṭ, Pss. § 843, and Ex. Rab. ii. 5.</i> and it was<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “The thorn bush was (full of) sorrow and distress because it was all thorns and thistles.”</i> full of thorns and thistles. Why did He abide in the midst of the thorn-bush which was (an emblem of) grief and distress? Because He saw Israel in great grief and He also dwelt with them,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “And He dwelt also with them in the midst of grief.”</i> thus fulfilling that which is said, "In all<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 144 f., note 1 on p. 145.</i> their affliction He was afflicted" (Isa. 63:9).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Ta‘anith, 16a.</i>
Rabbi Levi said: That rod<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 14, and cf. p. 124, and the Book of the Bee, pp. 24, 50.</i> which was created in the twilight<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> On the first Sabbath eve in the Creation week, see references given in the previous note.</i> was delivered to the first man<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar lxxvii. 39 ff. The Jalḳuṭ, Ex. §§ 168, 173, quotes this book as “the Book of the Chronicles of Moses,” according to which Adam took the rod from Eden when he was driven forth, at the time when the rod had been made; he tilled the ground therewith. See also <i>R.É.J</i>. lxxviii. p. 150.</i> out of the garden of Eden. Adam delivered it to Enoch, and Enoch delivered it to Noah,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Should this be: “Enoch handed it to Methuselah, and Methuselah handed it to Noah”? See <i>supra</i>, p. 53.</i> and Noah [handed it on]<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions have the words in brackets; the MS. omits same.</i> to Shem. Shem passed it on to Abraham, Abraham [transmitted it]<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions have the words in brackets; the MS. omits same.</i> to Isaac, and Isaac [gave it over]<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions have the words in brackets; the MS. omits same.</i> to Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 168, and the Book of Jashar lxxvii. 46 agree that Jacob received it when he fled to Paddan-Aram. He declares: “For with my <i>staff</i> I passed over this Jordan” (Gen. 32:10). See Gen. Rab. 76:5, and Agadath Bereshith on this verse. The rod divided the Jordan for Jacob and the Reed Sea for Moses and Israel; see Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 763. The rod passed on to David and his successors, and will belong to the Messiah.</i> and Jacob brought it down into Egypt and passed it on to his son Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar, <i>loc. cit</i>.; and cf. Ezek. 37:19: “the stick of Joseph.”</i> and when Joseph died and they pillaged his household goods, it was placed in the palace of Pharaoh. And Jethro<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “Reuel” is the reading in Jeraḥmeel xlvi. 4 and 12; Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 173, reads “Jethro.” “Pharaoh” of the printed texts is a mistake; for although he was a magician (cf. Ex. Rab. ix. 6 ff.) he would not take the rod which “he desired in his heart” and plant it in Jethro’s garden.</i> was one of the magicians of Egypt, and he saw the rod and the letters which were upon it, and he desired in his heart (to have it), and he took it and brought it, and planted it<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> For full details as to the various legends about the rod, see Grünbaum, <i>op. cit</i>. pp. 161 ff. Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>., omits the words “and he saw the rod” which occur in <i>P.R.E</i>.</i> in the midst of the garden of his house.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in the house of Jethro.”</i> No one was able to approach it<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Book of Jashar lxxvii. 49, 51, and the Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>., Jethro resolved to give his daughter to the man who was able to remove the rod.</i> any more.
When Moses came to his house he went into the garden of Jethro's house, and saw the rod and read the letters<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. viii. 3; see also <i>infra</i>, p. 329, n. 8, and Pal. Targum, Ex. 3:21. Cf. the Book of Jashar, <i>loc. cit</i>., which appears to have used <i>P.R.E</i>. in the account of the “rod” (ch. lxxvii. 39–51). The letters on the rod were the Ineffable Name of God or the initials of the ten plagues.</i> which were upon it, and he put forth his hand and took it. Jethro watched || Moses, and said: This one in the future will redeem Israel from Egypt. Therefore he gave him Zipporah his daughter to wife, as it is said, "And Moses was content to dwell with the man;<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> and he gave Moses Zipporah, his daughter" (Ex. 2:21).
Moses was keeping the sheep of Jethro for forty years,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Deut. § 357; and Midrash Tannaim, ed. Hoffmann, p. 226.</i> and the beasts of the field did not consume them, but they increased and multiplied exceedingly,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Cant. Rab. 3:5.</i> and concerning them the Scripture saith, "As the flock of holy things" (Ezek. 36:38).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Applied to Jethro’s flock because Moses led them to graze near the Mount of God. The first editions add the next two words of the quotation.</i>
And he led the flock until he came to Horeb, as it is said, "And he led the flock to the back of the wilderness,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> and came to the mountain of God, unto Horeb" (Ex. 3:1). There the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed unto him from the midst of the thorn-bush. Moses saw the bush burning with fire, and the fire did not consume the bush, and the bush did not extinguish the flames of fire.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Ex. 3:2.</i> Now the bush does not grow in the earth unless it has water beneath it. Moses saw and was wondering very much in his heart, and he said: What kind of glory<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “mystery” of God; see Lev. Rab. 11:5. The sentence is in Aramaic and is unusual in our book. The translation might be: “whose glory,” etc.</i> is there in its midst? He said: I will now turn aside and see this great sight, why the thorn-bush is not burnt. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Moses ! Stand where thou art standing, for there in the future will I give the Torah to Israel, as it is said, "And he said, Draw not nigh hither;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> put off thy shoes from off thy feet,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> for the place whereon thou standest is holy ground" (<i>ibid.</i> 5). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Go.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence occurs in our MS. only. The reference should probably be Ex. 3:16.</i> Hence (the sages) said: Anyone who enters the Temple<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Berakhoth 9:1; T.B. Berakhoth, 62b; T.B. Soḥah, 40a. The Book of Jashar, <i>loc. cit</i>., omits the reference to the removal of the shoes. See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc</i>. The first editions read: “Any one who stands in a holy place.”</i> must remove || his shoe, for thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, to Moses: "Put off thy shoes from off thy feet" (<i>ibid.</i>).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: "Come and I will send thee unto Pharaoh" (<i>ibid.</i> 10). He answered before Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! Have I not spoken thus to Thee three or four times, that I have no power, for I have a defective tongue, as it is said, "And Moses said unto the Lord, O Lord, I am not eloquent" (<i>ibid.</i> iv. 10). Not only this, but moreover Thou dost send me into the power of my enemy who seeks my hurt.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “enemies, and of them who seek my hurt. Was it not for this reason that I fled from them?”</i> For this reason I fled from him, as it is said, "But Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 15). He answered him: Do not fear him,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “them.”</i> for all the men who sought thy life are already dead.
Were they dead? Were they not alive? Only they had diminished<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “They had descended from their wealth”; see T.B. Nedarim, 64b and 65a.</i> their wealth. Hence thou mayest learn that all who lose their wealth are as though they were dead, therefore it is said, "For all the men are dead who sought thy life" (<i>ibid.</i> iv. 19). (God) said to him: "Come and I will send thee unto Pharaoh" (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 10). He replied to Him: Sovereign of all worlds! "Send by the hand of him whom thou wilt send" (<i>ibid.</i> iv. 13)—that is to say, by the hand of that man whom Thou wilt send in the future.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Elijah; or, perhaps, the reference is to Phineas the son of Aaron, who is identified by our author with Elijah; see <i>infra</i>, p. 371, and Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i>: “By the hand of Phineas.” On Elijah see T.B. ‘Erubin, 43b.</i> He said to him: I have not said, "Come and I will send thee to Israel," but "Come and I will send thee unto Pharaoh" (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 10). And as for that man of whom thou sayest that I should send him to Israel in the future that is to come, so it is said, || "Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here and then follows the next verse, of which the first three words in the Hebrew are quoted. The first editions do not have the second quotation, but continue the first verse.</i> before the great and terrible day of the Lord come" (Mal. iv. 5). "And he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers" (<i>ibid.</i> 6).
(Moses) spake before Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! Give me a wonder or a sign.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. iii. 12, and Siphrê, Deut. § 83. Moses wished to have a sign in heaven and a wonder on earth.</i> He said to him: Cast thy staff to the ground. He cast his staff to the ground, and it became a fiery serpent. Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, show unto Moses (a sign) with a fiery serpent,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “like a fiery serpent by (means of) the rod and (why) did He not show him something else?”</i> and why did He not show it to him with something else? But just as the serpent bites and kills the sons of man, likewise Pharaoh and his people bit and slew the Israelites. Afterwards it became again like a dry stick. Thus He spake: Likewise Pharaoh and his people shall become like this dry stick,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The preceding part of this sentence occurs in the MS. only.</i> as it is said, "And the Lord said unto Moses: Put forth thine hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, in the first editions it is continued.</i> and take it by the tail" (Ex. 4:4). He spake before Him: Sovereign of all worlds ! Give me a wonder. He said to him: "Put now thine hand into thy bosom" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). And he put his hand into his bosom, and he brought it out leprous like snow. Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, show unto Moses (a sign) by means of an unclean thing, and (why) did He not show it by means of a clean thing? But just as the leper is unclean and causes uncleanliness, likewise Pharaoh and his people were unclean, and they caused Israel to be unclean.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 382.</i> Afterwards (Moses) became clean again,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria adds: “as it is said: ‘And He said, Restore thy hand.’” Cf. Ex. Rab. iii. 13. The MS. repeats the quotation (Ex. 4:6).</i> and He spake to him: Likewise shall Israel become clean from the uncleanliness of the Egyptians, as it is said, "And he said, Put now thine hand into thy bosom" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Why did He show unto Moses the fire in the midst of the thorn-bush? || But the fire refers to Israel, who are compared to fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Because the Shekhinah abides among them, and because they possess the Torah, the “Law of fire.” Cf. Mekhilta de R. Simeon, p. 1 ff.</i> as it is said, "And the house of Jacob shall be a fire" (Obad. 18). The thorn-bush refers to the nations of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Amsterdam and Prague editions read: “the idolaters”; later editions read “the wicked.”</i> who are compared to thorns and thistles. He said to him: Likewise shall Israel be in the midst of the nations. The fire of Israel shall not consume the nations, who are compared to thorns and thistles; but the nations of the world shall extinguish the flames of Israel—(these flames) are the words of the Torah. But in the future that is to come the fire of Israel will consume all the nations, who are compared to thorns and thistles,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See the rest of the verse quoted from Isaiah.</i> as it is said, "And the peoples shall be as the burnings of lime" (Isa. 33:12).
Moses said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds! Make known to me Thy great and holy Name, that I may call on Thee by Thy Name,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra</i>, pp. 129, 264. See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 92:1, p. 198b. and 8. p. 200b; cf. Isa. 52:6. The first editions add: “And He made it known to him.”</i> and Thou wilt answer me, as it is said, "And God said unto Moses, I am that I am" (Ex. 3:14). "And God further said<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. ends the quotation here. The first editions continue the next two words in the Hebrew text. The verse continues: “Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, hath sent me unto you: this is my name for ever, and this is my memorial unto all generations.”</i> (to Moses)" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).
The angels saw that the Holy One, blessed be He, had transmitted the secret of the Ineffable Name<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Othijoth de R. ‘Aḳiba, letters <span>א ,ה ,ז</span>; <i>B.H.M</i>. iii. pp. 12 ff.; and cf. Grünbaum, <i>Z.D.M.G</i>. xl. p. 245. The rod with the Ineffable Name was transmitted by Moses to his successor Joshua, who conquered the Canaanites by its aid.</i> to Moses, and they rejoined: Blessed art thou, O Lord, who graciously bestoweth knowledge.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the fourth benediction of the Shemoneh ‘Esreh; see Singer, p. 46. Our Midrash attempts to associate Moses with its origin, see <i>supra</i>, p. 267.</i>

Chapter 41

CHAPTER XLI<br><small>THE REVELATION ON SINAI</small> [56<small>B</small>. i.]<br>T<small>HE</small> sixth descent<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, pp. 97, 312.</i> was when He came down on Sinai, as it is said, "And the Lord came down upon Mount Sinai" (Ex. 19:20). On the sixth of Sivan<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 359. Jubilees fixes the 15th of Sivan as the Festival of the Giving of the Law (see i. 1) and as the Feast of Weeks (vi. 17, 18); see Charles’ notes on pp. 52, 106. <i>P.R.E.</i> in following Rabbinic tradition opposes this here.</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed unto Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Mekhilta, p. 63b, Moses received the Divine Revelation on the 6th of Sivan.</i> on Sinai,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Mount Sinai.”</i> and from His place was He revealed (on) Mount Sinai,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and Mount Sinai was torn from its place.” See T.B. Sabbath, 88a; Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 284; Pal. Targum, Ex. 19:1; and Mekhilta, p. 65a.</i> and the heavens were opened, || and the summit of the mountain entered into the heavens. Thick darkness covered the mountain, and the Holy One, blessed be He, sat upon His throne, and His feet stood on the thick darkness, as it is said, "He bowed the heavens also, and came down;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> and thick darkness was under his feet" (2 Sam. 22:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sukkah, 5a, and T.B. Joma, 4a, on the Revelation on Mount Sinai.</i>
Rabbi Ṭarphon said: The Holy One, blessed be He, rose and came from Mount Sinai<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “rose from Mount Seir.”</i> and was revealed unto the sons of Esau, as it is said, "And he said, The Lord came from Sinai, and rose<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> from Seir unto them" (Deut. 33:2). And "Seir" means only the sons of Esau, as it is said, "And Esau dwelt in Mount Seir" (Gen. 36:8). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Will ye accept for yourselves the Torah? They said to Him: What is written therein? He answered them: It is written therein, "Thou shalt do no murder" (Ex. 20:13). They replied to Him: We are unable to abandon the blessing with which Isaac blessed Esau, for he said to him, "By thy sword shalt thou live" (Gen. 27:40). Thence He turned and was revealed unto the children of Ishmael, as it is said, "He shined forth from Mount Paran" (Deut. 33:2). "Paran"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Paran was the abode of Ishmael, Gen. 21:21.</i> means only the sons of Ishmael, as it is said, "And he dwelt in the wilderness of Paran" (Gen. 21:21). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them: Will ye accept for yourselves the Torah? They said to Him: What is written therein? He answered them: "Thou shalt not steal" (Ex. 20:15) is written therein. They said to Him: We are not able to abandon the usage which our fathers observed, for they<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “for they stole Joseph and brought him down,” etc.</i> brought Joseph down into Egypt, as it is said, "For indeed I was stolen away<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> out of the land of the Hebrews" (Gen. 40:15).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Joseph’s statement that he was stolen out of the land of the Hebrews refers to the transaction between his brethren and the Ishmaelites as recounted in Gen. 37:28. On this section see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 193 ff.</i> Thence<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “And Moses.” This is due to an error on the part of the copyist, “Umosheh” standing for “Umesham.”</i> He sent || messengers to all the nations of the world. He said unto them: Will ye receive for yourselves the Torah? They said to Him: What is written therein? He said to them: "Thou shalt have no other gods before me" (Ex. 20:3). They said to Him:<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “We are unable to abandon the law of our fathers who served idols.”</i> We have no delight in the Torah, therefore let Him give His Torah to His people, as it is said, "The Lord will give strength<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Strength (Ôẓ) is identified by the Midrash with the Torah.</i> unto his people; the Lord will bless<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> his people with peace" (Ps. 29:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ẓebachim, 116a.</i> Thence He returned and was revealed unto the children of Israel, as it is said, "And <i>he came from the ten thousands</i> of holy ones" (Deut. 33:2). The expression "ten thousands" means the children of Israel, as it is said, "And when it rested, he said,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> <i>Return</i>, O Lord, <i>unto the ten thousands</i> of the thousands of Israel" (Num. 10:36). With Him were thousands twice-told of chariots, even twenty thousand<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 68:17: “The chariots of God are twenty thousand, even thousands upon thousands: the Lord is among them, as in Sinai, in the sanctuary.”</i> of holy angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Jubilees i. 27 teaches that the “law was given through the ministry of angels.” According to Dr. Charles (<i>Jubilees</i>, p. 8, note 27) the text in Jubilees i. 27 “forms apparently the earliest testimony” to this idea. In the N.T. we have it also; see Gal. iii. 19, Acts vii. 53, and Heb. ii. 2. The idea is not Palestinian, but seems to be Alexandrian. This is perhaps an indication pointing to Alexandria as the home of Jubilees, just as Hebrews, Acts, and Paul’s teaching are all representative of Alexandrine teaching. Our Midrash combats the notion that the Torah was given to Israel by the angels: God Himself gives His law to His people.</i> and His right hand was holding the Torah, as it is said, "At his right hand was a fiery law unto them" (Deut. 33:2).
Hence thou mayest learn that the words of the Torah are like coals of fire.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Aboth 2:10: “for all the words of the Sages are like coals of fire.” The first editions add here: “And He gave it to them with an expression of love, as it is said: ‘His left hand is under my head’ (Cant. 2:6), and with an expression of an oath, as it is said: ‘The Lord hath sworn,’” etc. The quotation from Cant. 2:6 continues: “and his <i>right hand</i> doth embrace me.”</i> Why was it "at his right hand"? Whence do we know (that it was given to them) with expression of love? Because it is said, "The Lord hath sworn by his right hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i> and by the arm of his strength" (Isa. 62:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “‘His right hand’<sup></sup> is nought else save an oath, as it is said, ‘ The Lord hath sworn by his right hand’”<sup></sup> (Isa. 62:8).</i>
Rabbi Eliezer said: From the day when the Israelites went forth from Egypt, they were journeying and encamping in smoothness,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Of tongue. Luria thinks that the text should read “Machalôḳeth,” “strife.” This is also the reading in the Mekhilta, p. 62a, Lev. Rab. 9:9, and Lam. Rab. Proem. The next words, up to “as it is said,” occur in the MS. only.</i> they were journeying in smoothness and they were encamping in smoothness, as it is said, "And they journeyed (from Rephidim, and they came to the wilderness of Sinai),<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions read: “they journeyed and they encamped.”</i> and they encamped in the wilderness" (Ex. 19:2); until they all came to Mount Sinai, and they all encamped opposite the mountain, like one man with one heart, as it is said, "And there Israel encamped<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The verb here is in the singular number; the Israelites were united as though they were a single man, see Pal. Targum, Ex. 19:2.</i> before the mount" (<i>ibid.</i>). The Holy One, blessed be He, spake to them: Will ye receive for yourselves || the Torah? Whilst the Torah had not yet been heard they said to Him: We will keep and observe all the precepts which are in the Torah, as it is said, "And they said, All that the Lord hath spoken will we do, and be obedient"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote Ex. 24:3.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 7).
Rabbi Elazar of Modein said: From the day when the heavens and the earth were created, the name of the mountain was Horeb.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. 3:1 and xxxiii. 6; cf. 1 Kings 8:9.</i> When the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed unto Moses out of the thorn-bush, because of the word for the thorn-bush (<i>S'neh</i>) it was called Sinai (<i>Sinai</i>), and that is Horeb. And whence do we know that Israel accepted the Torah at Mount Horeb? Because it is said, "The day that thou stoodest before the Lord thy God in Horeb" (Deut. 4:10).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This is followed by the words: “And he drew near and stood at the foot of the mountain”; and there the Torah was given.</i>
Rabbi Phineas said: On the eve of Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 359.</i> the Israelites stood at Mount Sinai, arranged with the men apart and the women apart.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sukkah, 52a. The separation of the sexes was observed in the ark of Noah according to Jewish and Christian legend (see <i>supra</i>, p. 169), and it is observed to this day in some of the churches as well as in the synagogue.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: Go, speak to the daughters of Israel, (asking them) whether they wish to receive the Torah. Why were the women asked (first)? Because the way of men is to follow the opinion of women,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xxviii. 2; T.B. Sabbath, 87a, and Mekhilta, p. 62b.</i> as it is said, "Thus shalt thou say to the <i>house of Jacob</i>" (Ex. 19:3); these are the women. "And tell the children of Israel" (<i>ibid.</i>); these are the men. They all replied (as) with one mouth, and they said: "All that the Lord hath spoken we will do, and be obedient" (<i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 7). (The Scripture also says,) "They that sing<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the men.</i> as well as they that dance<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the women.</i> (shall say), All my fountains are in thee" (Ps. 87:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Shocher Ṭob. <i>in loc.</i>, p. 190b, and Cant. Rab. to Cant. 1:12.</i>
Rabbi Chanina<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “Chakhinai.”</i> said: || In the third month the day is double the night,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This is one of the most interesting expressions in the whole of our book. The longest day is twice as long as the shortest in latitude 49° in Northern Asia; see Eth. Enoch lxxii. 14, and see Charles’ note on p. 153 of the second edition of this book. Can we locate the place where this fact applies in connection with <i>P.R.E.</i>? Or is it merely a further instance of the dependence of <i>P.R.E.</i> upon the Pseudepigrapha?</i> and the Israelites slept until two hours of the day, for sleep on the day of the (feast of) 'Azereth<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Pentecost. Jubilees uses the term for the day following the seven days of Tabernacles; see Jubilees xxxii. 27, with Charles’ note <i>in loc.</i></i> is pleasant,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading “pleasant” agrees with the reading in Cant. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>: “sleep at ‘Azereth is pleasant and the night is long”; see T.B. Sabbath, 147a, and cf. Tosephta ‘Arakhin 1:9, p. 543. Luria reads: “for the period of the days at ‘Azereth is long and the night is short.”</i> the night being short. And Moses went forth and came to the camp of the Israelites, and he aroused the Israelites from their sleep, saying to them: Arise ye from your sleep,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the rest of the sentence.</i> for behold, your God desires to give the Torah to you. Already the bridegroom wishes to lead the bride and to enter the bridal chamber. The hour has come for giving you the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “The best man<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> came and led forth the bride just like a man who acts as best man to his companion.”</i> as it is said, "And Moses brought forth the people<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> out of the camp to meet God" (Ex. 19:17). And the Holy One, blessed be He, also went forth to meet them; like a bridegroom who goes forth to meet the bride, so the Holy One, blessed be He, went forth to meet them to give them<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The Amsterdam edition omits “them.”</i> the Torah, as it is said, "O God, when thou wentest forth before thy people" (Ps. 68:7).
Rabbi Joshua ben Ḳorchah said: The feet of Moses stood on the mount,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Sinai.</i> and all (his body) was in the midst of the heaven, like a tent<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads “Denda.” The first editions read “Ṭendos.” Jastrow, T.D. 541a, suggests that the reading should be “Ṭorus” (bolster or sofa). The word in our printed editions is taken by the ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, iv. p. 47b, to be the late Latin <i>tenta</i>; Greek <i>τέντα</i>. The word occurs in Pal. Targum, Lev. 25:31. See <i>supra</i>, p. 16, note 6.</i> which is spread out, and the children of men stand<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads “stand”; the first editions read “sit.”</i> inside it, but their feet stand on the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads “stand outside.”</i> and all of them are inside the tent; so was it with Moses, his feet stood on the mountain, and all his (body) was in the heavens, beholding and seeing everything that is in the heavens. The Holy One, blessed be He, was speaking with him like a man who || is conversing with his companion, as it is said, "And the Lord spake unto Moses face<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> to face" (Ex. 33:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “Face to face” means that the Divine word was as a man’s speech as far as Moses was concerned.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: Go and sanctify the Israelites for two days, as it is said, "And the Lord said unto Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This part of the verse is omitted by our MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i> Go unto the people, and sanctify them to-day and to-morrow" (<i>ibid.</i> xix. 10). What then was the sanctity of Israel in the wilderness? There were no uncircumcised people<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “people with uncircumcised hearts.”</i> in their midst; the manna descended from heaven for them; they drank water out of the Well;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Well see <i>supra</i>, pp. 124 and 218.</i> clouds of glory surrounded them. What then was the sanctity of Israel in the wilderness? It refers to their avoidance of sexual intercourse.
Moses argued with himself. Moses said: A man of Israel may have gone to his wife, and they will be found to be prevented from receiving the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>The Clementine Homilies</i>, xi. 30.</i> What did he do? He added one day (more) for them on his own account, so that if a man of Israel went to his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> On the eve preceding the day before the two days of prohibition; see T.B. Sabbath, <i>loc. cit.</i>; T.B. Jebamoth, 62a; and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) ii. p. 5a.</i> they would be found to be clean for two (complete) days; therefore he added one day for them on his own account.
The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Moses! How many souls of the children of men would have come forth from Israel in that night? What thou hast done has been (rightly) accomplished.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Thou hast done well.”</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, approved his action.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said, ‘And let them be ready against the third day’” (Ex. 19:11). See Mekhilta, p. 64a; Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 18 p. 101; and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 282. Luria reads in place of “as it is said,” etc., “Be ready for three days and do not touch any man his wife.”</i>
(The Holy One, blessed be He, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are found in the first editions and are needed. They are wanting in our MS.</i>) Let Moses descend to the camp, and afterwards will I cause My Torah to be proclaimed.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “to Israel, so that one should not say: Moses was speaking to us out of the midst of the cloud.”</i> He said to him: "Go down, charge the people" (<i>ibid.</i> 21). Moses was wishing to be || there,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 4b; Lev. Rab. 1:1; T.B. Berakhoth, 45a; and Mekhilta, p. 66a.</i> and he said to Him: I have already charged the people. He said to him: Go, and call thy Rabbi.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “teacher.” The first editions read: “Call Aaron.”</i> Moses descended to the camp to call Aaron, and the Holy One, blessed be He, proclaimed His Torah unto His people, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And the Lord said to him, Go, get thee down” (Ex. 19:24).</i> "So Moses went down unto the people,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions it is continued.</i> and told them" (<i>ibid.</i> 25). What is written after this? "And God spake all these words, saying, I, the Lord, am (to be) thy God,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions it is continued.</i> who brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage" (<i>ibid.</i> xx. 1, 2).
The voice of the first (commandment) went forth,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal.
