Targum on Ex. 20:2.</i> and the heavens and earth quaked thereat,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Judg. 5:4.</i> and the waters and rivers fled,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads “dried up” (cf. Nahum 1:4, and see Ex. Rab. xxix. 3) instead of “fled.”</i> and the mountains and hills were moved,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Hab. 3:6 and Nahum 1:5. These prophets recall the revelation at Sinai, believing firmly in this fundamental fact of the history of Israel. They would have smiled at some of the latest theories of the Higher Critics, who propose to date the Pentateuch as a production of the times of Hezekiah. They would have ridiculed the notion that some late writer had “invented” the Sinaitic theophany in order to account for the Decalogue, which he held to be divinely inspired. One is tempted to ask, Why is not Lev. 19 also set in a theophanic background?</i> and all the trees fell prostrate,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 29:5: “The voice of the Lord breaketh the cedars.” This Psalm is interpreted by the Midrash as referring to the Giving of the Law. Luria thinks that we should read “hinds” in <i>P.R.E.</i> instead of “trees”; cf. Job 39:1.</i> and the dead who were in Sheol revived, and stood on their feet till the end of all the generations,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The words “till the end of all generations” do not occur in all the texts.</i> as it is said, "But with him that standeth here with us this day" (Deut. 29:15),<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See the rest of the verse.</i> and those (also) who in the future will be created, until the end of all the generations, there they stood with them at Mount Sinai, as it is said, "And also with him that is <i>not</i> here<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> with us this day" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xxviii. 8, and cf. Tanchuma Nizabim, § ii.</i> The Israelites who were alive (then) fell upon their faces and died.
The voice of the second (commandment) went forth, and they were quickened,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xxix. 4, and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 196 ff.</i> and they stood upon their feet and said to Moses: Moses, our teacher! We are unable to hear any more the voice of the Holy One, blessed be He, for we shall die even as we died (just now), as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “‘My soul went forth when he spake’ (Cant. 5:6), and it is written:”.</i> "And they said unto Moses, Speak thou with us,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> and we will hear: but let not God speak with us, <i>lest we die</i>" (Ex. 20:19). And now, why should we die as we died (just now)? The Holy One, blessed be He, heard the voice of Israel, and it was pleasing to Him, and He sent for Michael || and Gabriel, and they took hold of the two hands of Moses against his will,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Joma, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and they brought him near unto the thick darkness, as it is said, "And Moses drew near unto the thick darkness where God was" (<i>ibid.</i> 21).
It is only written here (in the text concerning) Moses (that) "he drew near."<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Luria, the Midrashic text is to be explained thus: “He drew near” is not written here, but “He was drawn near.” The first editions seem to have the correct reading: “‘was approaching’ is not written, but ‘he approached.’”</i> The rest of the commandments He spake through the mouth of Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, p. 71b, as to whether the children of Israel heard the first two Commandments of the Decalogue, or more. Cf. Cant. Rab. on Cant. 1:2.</i> and concerning him the text says, "As the cold of snow in the time of harvest,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> so is a faithful messenger to them that send him" (Prov. 25:13).
And it came to pass, "When ye hear the sound of the trumpet"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And it came to pass, when ye heard the voice out of the midst of the darkness” (Deut. 5:23).</i> (2 Sam. 15:10). Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, cause His voice to be heard out of the midst of the<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “fire and darkness.”</i> darkness, and not out of the midst of the light? A parable: to what is the matter to be likened? To a king<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “who was an astrologer.” See Tosephta ‘Arakhin 1:10, p. 543. Cf. Ziegler’s <i>Die Königsgleichnisse des Midrasch</i>, p. 353. See also Jalḳuṭ, Deut. § 831. <span>אסמרלגוס</span>, <i>ἀστρóλoγoς</i>, astronomer or astrologer. The reading, as emended by Luria, is based on the Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.</i> Ziegler’s remarks on p. 352 (<i>op. cit.</i>) on astrology and marriage are interesting.</i> who was having his son married to a woman, and he suspended in the wedding chamber of his son black curtains,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, vii. p. 427a, <i>s.v.</i> <span>פרכיות</span>.</i> and not white curtains.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “The officials of the palace said to him: Our lord, O king! Nobody suspends in his son’s wedding chamber anything except white curtains.”</i> He said to them: I know that my son will not remain with his wife except for forty days; so that on the morrow they should not say the king was an astrologer, but he did not know what would happen to his son. So with the King, who is the Holy One, blessed be He, and His son is Israel, and the bride is the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Our book is noteworthy here in referring to God as the “Father” of Israel assisting at the wedding of <i>His Son</i> “Israel” and the bride “the Torah.” The usual poetry of the Midrashim is to unite God with Israel, His bride.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, knew that Israel would not remain (loyal) to the commandments except for forty days, therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, caused them to hear His voice out of the midst of<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “fire and darkness.”</i> darkness, and not out of the midst of light, therefore it is said, "And it came to pass, when ye heard the voice" (Deut. 5:28).
Rabbi Jehudah said: When a man speaks with his companion, he || hears the sound of his voice, but he does not see any light with it;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Our text agrees with Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 299. The first editions read: “When a man speaks with his companion he is visible, but his voice is invisible.”</i> the Israelites heard the voice of the Holy One, blessed be He, on Mount Sinai, and saw<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. 20:18.</i> the voice<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads Hakkol, “everything”; it should be Haḳḳol, “the voice.”</i> going forth from the mouth of the Almighty<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> On “Gebburah” see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 177.</i> in the lightning and the thunder,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> But otherwise they saw nothing.</i> as it is said, "And all the people saw the thunderings and the lightnings" (Ex. 20:18). All the precepts which are in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “Therefore is this code called Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> And whence do you know (this)? Because Torah has the value of 611 and the two (precepts) which the Lord spake.”</i> number 611, and two, which the Holy One, blessed be He, spake,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “number 613 precepts, and two, which the Holy One, blessed be He, spake.”</i> as it is said, "God has spoken once,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. The first editions read: “He has spoken once, <i>two</i> have we heard.” This is a mutilated form of the quotation Ps. 62:11, and clearly proves that the Venice edition copied the first edition (the Constantinople text). After the quotation the first editions add “behold 613.”</i> <i>two</i> have I heard thus" (Ps. 62:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. Rab. 11:7; Jalḳuṭ, <i>in loc.</i>, Pss. § 783. According to the Midrash the Decalogue was proclaimed in one utterance; see also Mekhilta, 41b, and cf. Ex. Rab. xxviii. 4.</i>
Rabbi Phineas said: All that generation who heard the voice of the Holy One, blessed be He, on Mount Sinai, were worthy to be like the ministering angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 82:6. According to the Book of Jubilees ii. 17–21, Israel is like the “angels of the presence and the angels of sanctification,” chosen to observe the Sabbath with God “in heaven and on earth.”</i> so that insects had no power over them.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Bathra, 15a; and cf. Ezek. 34:25 and Prov. 1:33; these two verses are applied by the Midrash to the generation of those who received the Torah in the wilderness.</i> They did not experience pollution in their lifetime, and at their death neither worm nor insect prevailed over them. Happy were they in this world and happy will they be in the world to come,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 90a ff., for discussion on the “future life.”</i> and concerning them the Scripture says, "Happy is the people, that is in such a case" (<i>ibid.</i> cxliv. 15).

Chapter 42

CHAPTER XLII<br><small>THE EXODUS</small> [58<small>B.</small> i.]<br>"A<small>ND</small> it came to pass, when Pharaoh had let the people go" (Ex. 13:17). This is what the Scripture says, "Thy shoots<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “Thy shoots” is to be interpreted as though it implied “thy coming forth.” In the Midrash here the word <span>שלחיך</span> is also taken to mean, “those of thee who went forth.”</i> are a garden of pomegranates" (Cant. 4:13). Just as this garden is full of (various) kinds of trees, each one bearing<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “fruit.”</i> according to its kind, so the Israelites, when they went forth from Egypt, were full of all good, (endowed with) the various kinds of blessings, as it is said, "Thy shoots are (like) a garden of pomegranates" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabban Gamaliel said: The Egyptians pursued after the children of Israel as far as the Reed Sea, and encamped behind them. The enemy was behind them<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Israel. The first editions read instead of this sentence: “The Israelites were between the Egyptians and the sea, which was in front of them, whilst the enemy was behind them.”</i> and the sea || was in front of them. And the Israelites saw the Egyptians, and feared very greatly, and there they cast away from themselves all the Egyptian abominations,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ezek. 20:7; Siphrê, Num. § 84; T.J. Sukkah 4:3. 54c; Ex. Rab. xxiv. 1; Mekhilta, Bô, 5a and 15a. The authority for the tradition is R. Eliezer ben Hakkapar (<i>c.</i> 200 <small>C.E.</small>). See also T.B. Synhedrin, 103b, as to whether the Israelites took any idols with them across the Reed Sea.</i> and they repented very sincerely, and called upon their God, as it is said, "And when Pharaoh drew nigh, the children of Israel lifted<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. Gaster reads: “cried unto the Lord.”</i> up their eyes" (Ex. 14:10). Moses beheld the anguish of Israel, and arose to pray on their behalf.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xxi. 1.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: "Speak unto the children of Israel, that they go forward" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).
Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all worlds ! The enemy is behind them, and the sea is in front of them, which way shall they go forward? What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He sent<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Ex. 14:19, and cf. Num. 20:16 for the sending of the angel to save God’s people. A parallel occurs in the Acts of Andrew and Matthias in <i>A.N.C.L.</i> xvi. p. 366.</i> Michael,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the great prince.” See Dan. 12:1 for reference to Michael, and cf. Gen. Rab. 50:2 (and see Reitzenstein, <i>Poimandres</i>, 294); Ex. Rab. ii. 5; and <i>supra</i>, p. 247. Our text is, perhaps, criticizing the Book of Jubilees, which says: “notwithstanding all signs and wonders the <i>prince of the Mastema</i> was <i>not</i> put to shame because he took courage and cried to the Egyptians to pursue after them with all the powers of the Egyptians” (xlviii. 12). On the opposition between Mastema (Sammael) on the one hand and Michael on the other, see <i>Archiv für Religionswissenschaft</i>, vol. xvi. p. 166, Marmorstein’s article, note 5. See Tanchuma (Buber), Gen. 48b; and Ex. Rab. xviii. 5, where Michael and Sammael are contrasted. See also T.B. Sotah, 10b.</i> and he became a wall of fire<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Zech. 2:5; Nachmanides on Ex., <i>in loc.</i>, and <i>supra</i>, p. 325.</i> between (Israel and<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are missing in our MS.; they occur in the first editions.</i>) the Egyptians. The Egyptians desired<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the text should be rendered “ran.”</i> to follow after Israel, but they are unable to come (near) because of the fire. The angels beheld the misfortune of Israel all the night, and they uttered neither praise nor sanctification<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Siphrê, Num. § 58, based on Isa. 62:6. The first editions read “thanksgiving.”</i> to their Creator,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See R. Bechai, <i>in loc.</i>; Ex. Rab. xxiii. 7; Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 105:1, p. 277b; and T.B. Megillah, 10b, which says that the angels did not sing to God because the work of His hands (<i>i.e.</i> the Egyptians) were perishing. The quotation is given by our MS. only.</i> as it is said, "And the one came not near the other all the night" (<i>ibid.</i> 20).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: Moses! "Stretch out thine hand over the sea, and divide it" (<i>ibid.</i> 16). "And Moses stretched out his hand over the sea" (<i>ibid.</i> 21), but the sea refused to be divided.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “He then showed it the covenant of circumcision and the coffin of Joseph, and the staff on which the Ineffable Name was engraved,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> but it did not consent. Moses returned before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all worlds! The sea will not listen to me. Forthwith was the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed before him in His glory at the sea. And the sea fled.” This is wanting in MS. Gaster.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He looked at the sea, and the waters saw the face of the Holy One, blessed be He, and they trembled and quaked,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 106:9, and Midrash thereon; and see also Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 114 p. 98a.</i> and descended into the depths, as it is said, "The waters saw thee, O God;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> the waters saw thee, they were afraid: the depths also trembled" (Ps. 77:16).
Rabbi Eliezer said: || On the day when He said, "Let the waters be gathered together"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> on the third day, see <i>supra</i>, p. 63. Cf. Gen. Rab. 5:5.</i> (Gen. 1:9), on that very day were the waters congealed, and they were made into twelve valleys,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “paths.” The word in our MS. might mean “streams.” On the subject, see Wisdom of Solomon xix. 7 ff., which contains the oldest extant Midrash on the Exodus. The twelve paths may be due to the idea of the twelve tribes; cf. Hab. 3:9. See also Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxxiii. p. 48b.</i> corresponding to the twelve tribes, and they were made into walls of water<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Ex. 14:21.</i> between each path,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Between each path were windows.” See ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, i. p. 124a, b. <i>s.v.</i> <span>אמפומיות</span>.</i> and (the people) could see one another,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Wisdom xix. 8; Pesiḳta, Beshallach, p. 86b; Jalḳuṭ on 2 Sam. 20 § 152.</i> and they saw the Holy One, blessed be He, walking before them, but the heels of His feet<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 27.</i> they did not see,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “were neither seen nor known.”</i> as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “‘They have seen thy goings, O God’ (Ps. 68:24); and it is written.”</i> "Thy way was in the sea,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions it is continued.</i> and thy paths in the great waters, and thy footsteps were not known" (Ps. 77:20).
Rabbi 'Aḳiba said: The Israelites advanced to enter the Reed Sea, but they turned backwards, fearing lest the waters would come over them.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Pesachim, 118b; T.B. Soṭah, 36b, 37a; and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 76:1, p. 170b. The first editions add here: “The tribe of Benjamin wished to enter therein, as it is said: ‘There is little Benjamin, their ruler’<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> (Ps. 68:27). They went down (into the sea),<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> and the tribe of Judah began to stone them, as it is said, ‘The princes of Judah cast stones<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> at them’ (<i>ibid.</i>); and Nachshon<sup></sup> sprang into the sea first, and he sanctified His great name in the eyes of all.” See also <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 176 ff.</i> The tribe of Judah sanctified His great Name, and entered the sea first, and under the dominion of the hand likewise of the sons of Judah<sup>1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first edition and MS. Gaster read: “Under the dominion of the hand of the son of Judah, Nachshon.” The words in brackets occur in the first editions but not in our MS., which reads: “under the dominion of the hand likewise the sons of Judah entered first.” The second edition reads: “under the dominion of the hand of the sons of Judah.”</i> (did all Israel enter the sea after them), as it is said, "Judah became his sanctuary,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> “His sanctuary,” in order to sanctify Him.</i> Israel his dominion"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add: “of Judah.” See Shocher Ṭob, <i>in loc.</i>, Gen. Rab. 84:17.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> cxiv. 2). The Egyptians desired<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See note 5 on p. 329.</i> to follow after Israel, but they turned backwards,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, p. 32a.</i> fearing lest the waters would return over them. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He appeared before them like a man riding on the back of a mare, as it is said, "To a steed in Pharaoh's chariots" (Cant. 1:9). The horse on which Pharaoh rode saw the mare (of God), and it neighed and ran and entered the sea after it.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Agadath Shir Ha-Shirim ix. (cd. Schechter, p. 17); Mekhilta, p. 33a; Tanchuma, Shopheṭim, § xiv.; and Jalḳuṭ Makhiri, Ps. 114, <i>loc. cit.</i></i>
The Egyptians saw that Pharaoh had entered the sea, and all of them entered the sea after him, as it is said, "And the Egyptians pursued<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. has in the margin “and they came.” Pharaoh is not mentioned here; cf. next chapter, p. 341.</i> after them" (Ex. 14:9). Forth-with the waters returned, and covered them, as it is said, "And the waters returned, and covered<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> || the chariots, and the horsemen" (<i>ibid.</i> 28).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 7 p. 43, and cf. <i>ibid.</i> xxiii. p. 123.</i>
Ben 'Azzai said: Everything is (judged according to the principle of) measure (for measure); just as the Egyptians were proud, and cast the male children into the river,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jubilees xlviii. 14: “And all the peoples whom he brought to pursue after Israel, the Lord our God cast them into the midst of the sea, into the depths of the abyss beneath the children of Israel, <i>even as the people of Egypt had cast their children into the river</i>.” See also Wisdom xi. 16. Charles refers also to the following parallels illustrating the <i>lex talionis</i>: Wisd. xi. 7, xii. 23, xvi. 1, xviii. 4, 5; Philo, <i>Adv. Flacc.</i> 20; Josephus, <i>Contra Ap.</i> ii. 13.</i> so the Holy One, blessed be He, cast them into the sea, as it is said, "I will sing unto the Lord, for he hath triumphed triumphantly<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Just as the Egyptians <i>triumphed</i> over the Israelites by casting their children into the <i>sea</i>, so God <i>triumphed</i> over the Egyptians by casting them into the <i>sea</i>. This seems to be the meaning read into the double expression of “triumphing” in Ex. 15:1. The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i>; the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea" (<i>ibid.</i> xv. 1).
Rabbi Shela said: All the children (of the Israelites) whom the Egyptians cast into the river did not die, for the river cast them up, and threw them into the desert of Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Deut. 32:10, and cf. Ezek. 16:5 with the Midrashic interpretation thereon.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, brought a rock to the mouth of each one, and a rock to the side of each one. The rock which was at his mouth was feeding him with honey and milk, and the rock which was at their side was anointing<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “feeding.”</i> them with oil, like a lying-in woman who anoints<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “feeds.” See Jastrow, <i>T.D.</i> 963b, l. 18.</i> her son,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 165, and Pal. Targum, Deut. 32:13; T.B. Soṭah, 11b; Ex. Rab. xxiii. 8, and Aboth de Rabbi Nathan, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> as it is said, "And he made him to suck honey out of the rock,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and oil out of the flinty rock" (Deut. 32:13). When Israel came to the sea, they saw the Holy One, blessed be He, and they recognized Him, and praised Him, and sanctified Him, as it is said, "This is my God, and I will praise him" (Ex. 15:2).
Rabbi Simon said: On the fourth day the Israelites encamped by the edge of the sea, and to the south<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that <span>מנגב</span> should be <span>מנגד</span>, “opposite,” because the Israelites were encamped towards the east of the sea. See Tosaphoth, ‘Arakhin, 15a; catchword: “Just as.”</i> of the sea. The Egyptians were floating like skin-bottles upon the surface of the waters,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 108a; Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 31 p. 158, based on Job 24:7, referring to the generation of the Flood. See also Wisdom x. 19 and Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> ii. 16. 6.</i> and a north wind went forth and cast them opposite the camp of Israel, and the Israelites went and saw them, and they recognized them, and they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and they recognized them, and they said, ‘These are the children of Israel.’” We should read: “and the children of Israel said.” This is another instance how the Venice edition (1544) has thoughtlessly copied the Constantinople edition (1514).</i> These (here) were the officials of the palace of Pharaoh, and those (there) were the taskmasters, and they recognized every one, as it is said, "And Israel saw the Egyptians<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. The next word in the verse, “dead,” is in the singular number, hence the Midrashic inference.</i> || dead upon the sea shore" (<i>ibid.</i> xiv. 30).
Rabbi Reuben said: The entire body follows the head,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Erubin, 41a.</i> and when<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria’s text reads: “When the shepherd is good, and goes on the right way, the sheep follow him.” This is practically the reading of the first editions in the next sentence.</i> the shepherd goes astray the sheep go astray after him, as it is said, "For the sins of Jeroboam which he sinned,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.</i> and wherewith he made Israel to sin" (1 Kings 15:30). When the shepherd is good, all follow after him.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add: “Our teacher Moses was a faithful shepherd.” Cf. Num. 27:17. The expression “faithful shepherd” in Aramaic is the title of part of the Ẓohar.</i> Moses began to sing, and to utter praises before the Holy One, blessed be He, and all Israel followed him,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 30b, and Midrash on Prov., ed. Buber, p. 38a.</i> as it is said, "Then sang Moses and the children of Israel" (Ex. 15:1). Miriam began to sing and to utter praises, before the Holy One, blessed be He, and all the women followed her, as it is said, "And Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> took a timbrel… and all the women went out after her" (<i>ibid.</i> 20). Whence did they have timbrels and chorus in the wilderness?<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> So also in Mekhilta, p. 44a; see also Rashi on Ex. <i>in loc.</i></i> But the righteous always know and conciliate (God), and are assured that the Omnipresent, blessed be He, performs for them miracles and mighty deeds. Before (the time of) their departure from Egypt they prepared for themselves timbrels and chorus.
Israel spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds! These (Egyptians) who have arisen to come against us to destroy us from Thy world,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read here: “And all who rise up against us are as though they rose up against Thee. (Destroy them) all in the majesty of Thy might, and in Thy fierce anger they shall be consumed like stubble.”</i> as well as all who rise up against us, are as though they had risen up against Thee. Let the majesty of Thy might and Thy fierce anger consume them like stubble, as it is said, "And in the greatness of thine excellency thou overthrowest <i>them that rise up</i> against thee:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions. See Ps. 68:34.</i> thou sendeth forth thy wrath, it consumeth them as stubble" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).
Israel spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! There is none like Thee among the ministering angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the explanation of the word <span>אלם</span> in the verse: “Who is like unto thee, O Lord, among the Elim (<span>באלם</span>)?” (Ex. 15:11).</i> and therefore all their descriptive names (contain part of the word) <i>Elo</i>him ("God"); <i>e.g.</i> Micha<i>el</i> || and Gabri<i>el</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 65, note 1; and Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 68 p. 160a, Ex. Rab. xxix. 2, and Pesiḳta, p. 108b; and cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 88.</i> "Who is like unto thee among the divine creatures,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “Elim.”</i> O Lord?" (<i>ibid.</i> 11). Pharaoh<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>infra</i>, p. 341.</i> replied after them<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Israelites.</i> with the tongue,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “with song and praise in the Egyptian language.”</i> saying: "Who is like thee, glorious in holiness,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> fearful in praises, doing wonders?" (<i>ibid.</i>). "Fearful in praise"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads, incorrectly, “praises”; the first editions have the right reading, “praise.”</i> is not written here, but "fearful in praises"; for the praises of the ministering angels are on high, and the praises of Israel are (uttered on earth) below. "Fearful in praises, doing wonders" (<i>ibid.</i>), and thus Scripture says, "But thou art holy, O thou that inhabitest the praises of Israel" (Ps. 22:3).
"Thou stretchedst out thy right hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> the earth swallowed them" (Ex. 15:12). The Holy One, blessed be He, told the earth to bury the slain.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Job 26:5. The first editions read: “The Holy One, blessed be He, said to the earth: Receive thy hosts,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> the slain.”</i> (The earth) said unto Him: Sovereign of all worlds! The waters have killed them, let the waters swallow<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> bury them. Cf. T.B. Pesachim, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> them. He answered (the earth) saying: On this occasion receive them; on another occasion such that be killed by thee in the future will I cast into the sea, namely, Sisera and all his host, these will I cast into the sea, as it is said, "The river Kishon swept them<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Sisera’s army.</i> away,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> that ancient river" (Judg. 5:21 ).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “The earth spake before Him: Sovereign of the world! Just as in the hour when only one person was slain<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> I was cursed for his sake, and if I receive all these hosts, how much more so will I be cursed!” MS. Gaster reads almost the same text.</i> (The earth) continued, saying to Him: Give me the oath by Thy right hand, that Thou wilt not claim them at my hand.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lam. Rab. on Lam. 1:9, and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 22 p. 90b.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, put forth His right hand, and swore to the earth that He would not claim them, as it is said, "Thou stretchedst out thy right hand, the earth swallowed them" (Ex. 15:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add here: “The ‘right hand’ is only an oath, as it is said: ‘The Lord hath sworn by his right hand, and by the arm of his strength’ (Isa. 62:8). Forthwith the earth opened her mouth and swallowed them.”</i> All the kings<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Amsterdam edition has misread the word “kings” and gives “angels.”</i> of the earth heard of the departure from Egypt, and the dividing of the Reed Sea; they trembled and feared,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 37b; and cf. Josh. 2:9 and ix. 24.</i> and fled from their place, as it is said, "The peoples have heard, they tremble" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).
Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! Put Thy dread || and Thy fear upon them, that their heart may be as stone, until Israel has passed through the Jordan,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “sea.” The reading in our MS., “the Jordan,” is in agreement with the version of Onḳelos on Ex. 15:16. See <i>Liturgy for New Year</i>, Singer, p. 239. MS. Gaster adds: “until Israel has crossed the fords of Arnon.”</i> as it is said, "Till thy people pass over<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i>
Thou shalt bring them in, and plant them in the mountain of thine inheritance" (<i>ibid.</i> 16, 17).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc.</i></i> Thou shalt bring them in to Thy holy mountain. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: Moses! Thou hast not said, "Bring <i>us</i> in<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and plant <i>us</i>," but (thou hast said), "Thou shalt bring <i>them</i> in<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In our MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and plant <i>them</i>." The One who brings in, He also brings out. By thy life ! According to thy words so shall it be.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Deut. Rab. ii. 9, and Num. Rab. 19:13.</i> In this world I shall<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “thou shalt.” MS. Gaster agrees with our MS. here.</i> bring them<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> This was promised to Moses, but by striking the rock at Massah this privilege was forfeited. Luria suggests a variant reading: “Thou hast not said, ‘I will bring them in and I will plant them,’ but, ‘Thou wilt bring them in and plant them.’ The one who brings them in is the one who brings them out; so shall it be in this world, and in the future world thou wilt bring them in and I will plant them.”</i> in, and in the world to come I will plant them as a true plant<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jer. 32:41.</i> which shall not be plucked up out of their land,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> From “as it is said” to the end of the quotation from Amos 9:15 is missing in the MS., which reads “etc.” The first editions read as far as “their land.”</i> as it is said, "And I will plant them upon their land, and they shall no more be plucked up out of their land which I have given them, saith the Lord thy God" (Amos 9:15); and it (also) says, "The Lord shall reign for ever and ever" (Ex. 15:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 182–184, for the parallel version from the Talmud.</i>

Chapter 43

CHAPTER XLIII<br><small>THE POWER OF REPENTANCE</small> [60<small>A</small>. i.]<br>R<small>EPENTANCE</small> and good deeds<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth 4:11 in the name of R. Eliezer ben Jacob. <span>תריס</span> = <i>θυρεός,</i> shield.</i> are a shield against punishment. Rabbi Ishmael<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Rabbi ‘Aḳiba said: ‘Repentance was created and the right hand,’” etc.</i> said: If repentance had not been created,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> Chapter III., p. 10.</i> the world would not stand. But since repentance has been created, the right hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, is stretched forth to receive the penitent<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Pesachim, 119a; Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa, xxii. p. 37, xxiii. p. 40; and cf. Ezek. 1:8, with the interpretation in Pesachim, <i>loc. cit.</i> See Jalḳuṭ and Targum on Ps. 90:3.</i> every day, and He says, Repent, ye children of men. "Repent, ye children of men" (Ps. 90:8).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> pp. 104f.</i> Know thou the power of repentance.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “charity and repentance”; see next note.</i> Come and see from Ahab, king of Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 102b; <i>J.E.</i> i. 281; and also Menorath Ha-Maor, § 284. The word Zedaḳah (Charity) should be omitted. The first editions add: “who repented sincerely.” See also Jalḳuṭ, 1 Kings 21 § 222; and T.B. Ta‘anith, 25b.</i> for he had robbed, coveted,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “oppressed.”</i> and murdered,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 113a, according to which he introduced idolatry; and cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 48b. Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “he coveted and murdered”; see Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 26 p. 130, and Num. Rab. 14:1.</i> as it is said, "Hast thou killed, and also taken possession?" (1 Kings 21:19). He sent and called for Jehoshaphat, king of Judah,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on 1 Kings 21 <i>loc. cit.</i>; Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i>; T.J. Soṭah, 3:4. 18d, which refers to three years of penitence.</i> who gave him thrice daily forty stripes, and in fasting and with prayer he rose up early and retired late, before the Holy One, blessed be He,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “and he studied the Torah all his days.”</i> and he did not return any more to his evil deeds. His repentance was accepted, as it is said, || "Seest thou how Ahab humbleth himself<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> before me? Because he humbleth himself before me, I will not bring the evil in his days" (<i>ibid.</i> 29).
Rabbi Abbahu said: Know thou the power of repentance. Come and see from David, king of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on 2 Samuel, § 165, and Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> For the Holy One, blessed be He, had sworn to the forefathers that He would multiply their seed like the stars of the heavens. And David came to count their number. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: David ! I have sworn to the forefathers that I would multiply their seed as the stars of the heavens. And thou comest to annul My word. For thy sake the flock is given over to destruction;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Sam. 24:17, and <i>infra,</i> p. 400. The Pesiḳta, pp. 160b ff., has used <i>P.R.E.</i></i> and in three hours there fell seventy thousand men,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 62b.</i> as it is said, "And there fell of Israel seventy thousand men" (1 Chron. 21:14). Rabbi Simeon said: Only Abishai, son of Zeruiah, fell amongst the Israelites, for he was equal in his good deeds and his knowledge of the Torah to the seventy thousand men,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash Samuel xxxi. (end); T.B. Berakhoth, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 17 p. 64a; and <i>J.E.</i> i. p. 66.</i> as it is said, "And there fell of Israel seventy thousand men" (<i>ibid.</i>). "Men" is not written here, only "man."<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. has “70,000 men,” and above this the letter <span>כ</span>, “as” or “like,” has been added by a later writer.</i> And David heard and rent his garments, and clothed himself in sackcloth and ashes, and he fell upon his face to the ground before the ark of the covenant of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions regard this sentence as a quotation and add: “as it is said.” The text is based on Josh. 7:6.</i>
He sought (to do) penitence, and spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! It is I who have sinned; forgive me, I beseech Thee, my sin. His repentance was accepted, and He said to the angel who had destroyed many (<i>Rab</i>) among the people: "Stay thine hand"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Now stay thine <i>hands</i>.”</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 15). What is the meaning of || "many" (<i>Rab</i>)? He said to him: <i>Rab</i> (the teacher) has fallen in Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Sam. 3:38: “for a prince and a great man has fallen this day in Israel.”</i> What did the angel do? He took his sword and cleaned it with the garment<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>טלית</span>, garment, also “Ṭallith.”</i> of David. David saw the sword of the angel,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “of death.”</i> and he trembled in all his limbs until<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add “the day of.”</i> his death<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 7 p. 39, and Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 17 p. 63b.</i> (as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “as it is said”; the first editions have the expression.</i>) "But David could not go before it<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> to inquire of God; for he was afraid because of the sword of the angel of the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> 30).
Rabbi Joshua said: Know thou the power of repentance. Come and see from Manasseh,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J. E.</i> viii. 281 on the Prayer of Manasseh. The legend dealing with his punishment and repentance occurs in the Apocalypse of Baruch lxiv. 8. Traces of this legend are to be found in the Apostolic Constitutions, ii. 22; also in Anastasius on Ps. 6, quoted by Charles in his Note on Apoc. Baruch, p. 107, where the Targum of 2 Chron. 33:12 f. is given. See also T.B. Synhedrin, 103a.</i> son of Hezekiah, who perpetrated all the evil abominations much more than all the nations.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “of the world, and wrought much evil, and sacrificed to idols,<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> as it is said: ‘He also made his children to pass through the fire in the valley of the son of Hinnom: (and he practised augury, and used enchantments, and practised sorcery, and dealt with them that had familiar spirits, and with wizards): he wrought much evil in the sight of the Lord, to provoke him to anger’ (2 Chron. 33:6).<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> He went to Jerusalem dedicating doves<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> to all the host of heaven.” MS. Gaster has almost the same reading.</i> He made his son to pass through the fire to Baal outside Jerusalem, causing (doves) to fly,<sup>9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Synhedrin, 3:3. The dove-flying was an occasion for betting.</i> and sacrificing to all the host of heaven. The princes of the troops of the king of Babylon came,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Chron. 33:11, and Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i> The first editions read: “The princes of the troops of Assyria came.”</i> and they caught him by the hair of his head, and brought him down to Babylon, and they put him in a pan (over) a fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “in copper fetters,” according to the Targum on 2 Chron. 32:11; see Ruth Rab. 5:6, and the Note in Lightfoot’s Hor. Heb. et Tal. in <i>Acta Apost.</i> xii. 7. See T.B. Synhedrin, 101b; Targum, 2 Chron., <i>loc. cit.</i>; Deut. Rab. ii. 13. The reading <span>במולווח</span>, the “hollow brazen horse,” occurs in the Targum as well as in Apoc. Baruch; see ‘Arukh, s.v. <span>מולחא</span>. Luria offers a variant reading: <span>דודא דנחשת</span>; see ‘Arukh, <i>s.v.</i> <span>מליאר</span>—an iron barrel with apertures around which a fire was kindled. See also Agadath Bereshith, 9 (end), and Bacher in <i>R.É.J.</i> xlv. 291 ff.</i> and there he called upon all the other gods<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “strange gods”; the later editions read “idols.”</i> to whom he had sacrificed, and not one of them either answered him or saved him. He said: I will call on the God of my fathers with all my heart; perhaps He will do unto me according to all His wonders which He did unto my father. And he called on the God of his fathers with all his heart, and He was entreated of him, and He heard his supplication, as it is said, "And he prayed unto him; and he was intreated of him,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and heard his supplication… then Manasseh knew that the Lord he was God" (2 Chron. 33:18). In that hour Manasseh said: There is both judgment as well as a judge.
Ben 'Azzai<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The chronology is hopelessly at fault here. Ben ‘Aẓẓai was dead long before the time of Simeon ben Laḳish.</i> said: Know thou the power of repentance. Come and see from (the story of) Rabbi Simeon, son of Laḳish. He with two || of his friends<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Giṭṭin, 47a, and cf. <i>J.E.</i> xi. 354 f.</i> in the mountains, were robbing<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and oppressing.”</i> all who passed them on the way. What did he do? He forsook his two companions who were plundering on the mountains, and he returned to the God of his fathers with all his heart. Fasting and praying he arose early and retired late,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> before the Holy One, blessed be He, and he was studying the Torah all (the rest of) his days, and (giving) gifts to the needy. He did not return any more to his evil deeds, and his repentance was accepted. On the day when he died, his two companions, who were plundering on the mountains, also died. And they gave a portion in the treasury of the living<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See the reading in the Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.,</i> which has used our book. Our text might be rendered: “They put Rabbi Simeon, son of Laḳish, in the treasury of the living.”</i> to Rabbi Simeon, son of Laḳish, but his two companions (were put) in the lowest Sheol.
The two companions spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the universe ! There is before Thee respect for certain persons. This one was plundering with us on the mountains, and he is in the treasury of the living, whilst the other men are<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “whilst we are.”</i> in the lowest Sheol. He said to them: This one repented in his lifetime, but ye have not repented. They said to Him: Give us the opportunity, and we will repent very sincerely. He said to them: Repentance is only possible until one's death.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Midrash on Prov. 6 (ed. Buber, p. 28a), and cf. Eccles. 9:10 with Midrash thereon.</i>
A parable—To what is the matter comparable? To a man who wished to take a voyage at sea. If he did not take with him bread and water from an inhabited land, he will not find anything to eat or to drink on the sea. Again, || if a man wish to go to the end of the wilderness, unless he take from some inhabited place bread and water, he will not find anything to eat or to drink in the wilderness. Likewise, if a man did not repent in his lifetime, after his death he cannot repent.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said, ‘He will not regard any ransom;<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> neither will he rest content, though thou givest many gifts’”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> (Prov. 6:35).</i> But (God) gives to a man according to his ways, as it is said, "I<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads: “For I the Lord.” This does not agree with M.T.</i> the Lord search the heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions as far as “reins.”</i> I try the reins, even to give every man according to his ways, according to the fruit of his doings" (Jer. 17:10).
Rabbi Nechunia, son of Haḳḳanah, said: Know thou the power of repentance. Come and see from Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who rebelled most grievously against the Rock, the Most High,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests another reading: “the Rock of Eternity.” The Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “Sovereign of Eternity.”</i> as it is said, "Who is the Lord, that I should hearken unto his voice?" (Ex. 5:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See the preceding chapter of our book, p. 331.</i> In the same terms of speech in which he sinned, he repented, as it is said "Who is like thee, O Lord, among the mighty?" (<i>ibid.</i> xv. 11). The Holy One, blessed be He, delivered him from amongst the dead. Whence (do we know) that he died?<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Reed Sea. The first editions read: “that he did not die.”</i> Because it is said, "For now I had put forth my hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> and smitten thee" (<i>ibid.</i> ix. 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. and Gaster MS. read here: “But in very deed, for this cause have I made thee to stand” (Ex. 9:16). The 2nd ed. adds: “And the Holy One, blessed be He, raised him up from amongst the dead<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> to declare the might of His power.<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> Whence (do we know) that He raised him up? Because it is said: ‘ But in very deed for this cause have I made thee to stand, for to shew thee my power, and that my name may be declared throughout all the earth’” (Ex. 9:16).<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> He went and ruled in Nineveh. The men of Nineveh were writing fraudulent deeds, and everyone robbed his neighbour, and they committed sodomy,<sup>4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Pesiḳta, p. 161a, and Jalḳuṭ, Jonah, § 550.</i> and such-like wicked actions. When the Holy One, blessed be He, sent for Jonah, to prophesy against (the city) its destruction, Pharaoh hearkened and arose from his throne, rent his garments and clothed himself in sackcloth and ashes, and had a proclamation made to all his people, that all the people should fast for two<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “three days.”</i> days, || and all who did these (wicked) things<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “All who did <i>not</i> do these things.”</i> should be burnt by fire. What did they<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “he.”</i> do? The men were<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He made the men stand on one side.”</i> on one side, and the women on the other, and their children were by themselves; all the clean animals were on one side,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and all the unclean animals were on the other side.” Luria thinks that “male animals” and “female animals” would be a more appropriate reading. See the reading in the Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i> Jalḳuṭ Jonah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> omits it.</i> and their offspring were by themselves. The infants saw the breasts of their mothers, (and they wished<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets, which are missing in our MS., occur in the first editions.</i>) to have suck,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “To have suck and they did not permit it, and they wept, and the mothers saw their offspring and they wished to give them suck, and they were unable and they wept.” See T.B. Ta‘anith, 16a, and T.J. Ta‘anith 2:1. 65b.</i> and they wept. The mothers saw their children, (and they wished<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets, which are missing in our MS., occur in the first editions.</i>) to give them suck. By the merit of 4123 children more than twelve hundred thousand men (were saved), as it is said, "And should not I have pity on Nineveh,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it concludes with the word “city.” The preceding part of the sentence reads in the first editions: “By (their) merit there were more than twelve hundred thousand men.”</i> that great city; wherein are more than six score thousand persons that cannot discern between their right hand and their left hand; and also much cattle?" (Jonah 4:11); "And the Lord<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions read “the Lord”; M.T. has “God.”</i> repented of the evil,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it concludes with the word “said.”</i> which he said he would do unto them"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See the reading in the Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 10). For forty years was the Holy One, blessed be He, slow to anger with them, corresponding to the forty days during which He had sent Jonah.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Menorath Ha-Maor, <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads: “when He spake to Jonah.”</i> After forty years they returned to their many evil deeds, more so than their former ones, and they were swallowed up like the dead, in the lowest Sheol, as it is said, "Out of the city of the dead<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. has “populous,” but in margin, “city of men.” Nineveh was destroyed by Nebuchadnezzar; see T.B. Megillah, 11b.</i> they groan" (Job 24:12).
The Holy One, blessed be He, sent by the hand of His servants, the prophets, to Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to prophesy against Israel and He said.”</i> (saying), "O Israel, return unto the Lord thy God" (Hos. 14:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The use of these verses from Hosea seems to suggest that this entire chapter on Repentance was originally a homily for the Sabbath of Repentance, <i>i.e.</i> the Sabbath before the Day of Atonement. This suggestion seems to be reasonable, because the reference to Jonah would be appropriate on the Sabbath before it was read. The Book of Jonah is the Haphṭarah at Minchah on the Day of Atonement; see <i>supra,</i> Chapter X.</i> (Even) unto Him whose voice ye heard at Mount Sinai, saying, "I, the Lord, am to be thy God" (Ex. 20:2).
"For thou hast fallen by thine iniquity" (Hos. 14:1). "And thy wealth"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “By thy glory and thy wealth.”</i> is not written here, but "For thou hast fallen by thine <i>iniquity</i>." It is not written here, "Take with you silver and gold," || but "Take with you words" (<i>ibid.</i> 2). It is not written here, "And we will render silver and gold," but "And we will render as bullocks (the offering of) our lips" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Menorath Ha-Maor, § 279; Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa ix. p. 189; T.B. Synhedrin, 96b; and cf. 4 Ezra 4:39.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah said: If Israel will not repent they will not be redeemed.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 93a, and T.J. Ta‘anith, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Israel only repents because of distress,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 21 p. 116; and Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa iv. p. 180, and xiv. p. 196. See also Assumption of Moses, i. 18.</i> and because of oppression, and owing to exile, and because they have no sustenance. Israel does not repent quite sincerely<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “Does not do a great repentance.”</i> until Elijah<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Of blessed memory,” or, “May his memory be a blessing”; see <i>supra,</i> p. 2. note 7. Cf. Luke i. 16f.</i> comes, as it is said, "Behold, I will send you<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the words from “Elijah” to “come” are omitted. In the first editions the entire verse is given.</i> Elijah, the prophet,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 17 p. 36a, b.</i> before the great and terrible day of the Lord come. And he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers" (Mal. iv. 5, 6).
Blessed art thou, O Lord, who delightest in repentance.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Singer, p. 46. This is the fifth benediction of the Shemoneh ’Esreh. Does our Midrash wish to associate Elijah with this benediction?</i>

Chapter 44

CHAPTER XLIV<br><small>AMALEK AND ISRAEL</small> [61<small>B</small>. i.]<br>R<small>ABBI</small> J<small>OCHANAN</small>, son of Nuri, said: (After)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “After” is wanting in our MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i> all the mighty deeds and wonders which the Holy One, blessed be He, did unto Israel in Egypt, and at the Reed Sea, they repeatedly tempted the Omnipresent<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The Holy One, blessed be He.”</i> ten times,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Read <span>ער</span>, instead of <span>עוד</span>. See Aboth, 5:4, and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) xxxiv. p. 49b.</i> as it is said, "Yet have they tempted me these ten times" (Num. 14:22). Moreover, they slandered the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: He<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The Lord.”</i> has forsaken us in this wilderness, and His Shekhinah is not in our midst, as it is said, "Is the Lord among us,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> or not?" (Ex. 17:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 78:22; and cf. <i>infra,</i> pp. 436f.</i>
Rabbi Joshua,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads incorrectly: “Ishmael, son of Ḳorcha.” MS. Gaster reads: “Simeon.”</i> son of Ḳorchah, said: After this section what is written? "Then came Amalek" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). Amalek came against them to punish them. He who comes from || a journey should be met on the way with food and drink. (Amalek) saw them faint and weary, owing to the Egyptian bondage and the affliction of the journey, and he did not take to heart<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> To have pity on them, or to fear God, so as not to afflict them. See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 24 p. 126: “Eliphaz the father of Amalek advised his son to go and dig wells for Israel, but he met them with the sword.”</i> the precept of "Honour,"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The fifth commandment is probably referred to here; see previous note, 8. The MS. alone reads: “the precept of ‘Honour’” The Book of Jubilees offers a parallel to this idea in the disobedience of the children of <i>Esau,</i> who forced him against his will to attack Jacob; see Jubilees xxxvii. 1 ff.</i> but he stood by the way like a she-bear, bereaved by man<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “By man” occurs in the MS only.</i> (and eager) to slay mother and children,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 281; cf. 1 Sam. 15:33.</i> as it is said, "How he met thee by the way" (Deut. 25:18).
Rabbi Azariah<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “Zechariah.”</i> said: Amalek was a descendant<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “grandson.”</i> of Esau, and because of his ancestor's<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “grandfather’s.” See Pal. Targ. Ex. 17:8, and Targum on Cant. 2:15.</i> enmity he came against them to punish them. The cloud<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The Pillar of Cloud.”</i> was surrounding<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Deut. 32:10 and Pal. Targum, Deut. 25:18. See also Mekhilta, p. 53a: “The clouds surrounded the Israelites on all four sides.”</i> the camp of Israel like a city surrounded by a wall.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Zech. 2:5.</i> The adversary and enemy<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Lam. 4:12 for phraseology.</i> were unable to touch them, but (when) anyone needed a ritual bath<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Pesachim, 68a; T.B. Giṭṭin, 60a; Num. Rab. 7:1; and see <i>J.E.</i> viii. 588 on the “Ritual Bath.”</i> the cloud excluded him from the camp of Israel, because the camp of Israel was holy, as it is said, "Therefore shall thy camp be holy" (<i>ibid.</i> xxiii. 14), and (then) Amalek was smiting and slaying<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “vehôlekh,” “and going”; the first editions read: “vehôreg,” “and slaying.” The latter seems to be the more correct reading.</i> the hindmost of those who were beyond the cloud,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> For another interpretation, see Tanchuma, Ki Têzê, § ix., and Pesiḳta, p. 27b. See <i>infra,</i> p. 389.</i> as it is said, "And he smote the hindmost of thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> all that were feeble behind thee" (<i>ibid.</i> xxv. 18).
Moses said to Joshua: Choose men for us, houses<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “sons.”</i> of the fathers,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ḳiddushin, 76b.</i> men who are mighty in strength and valour,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “who fear Heaven.” See Mekhilta, p. 53b: “Amalek did not fear Heaven.” Cf. Ex. Rab. xxvi. 3.</i> and go forth and do battle with Amalek. Moses, Aaron, and Hur stood on a high place,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> See Nachmanides on Ex. 17:9.</i> in the camp<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in the midst of the camp.”</i> of Israel, one on his right hand, and one on his left. Hence thou mayest learn that the precentor<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. has an abbreviation: “Sheshaz”; lit. “that the Messenger of the Congregation.” The 1st ed. agrees.</i> is prohibited to officiate unless there are two (men) standing with him,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, p. 54b, Pesiḳta, p. 22a, and Tanchuma Beshallach, § xxviii. Was the custom mentioned in our book applicable only to public prayer on Fast Days (for rain or when war arose)? See Ṭur, Orach Chayyim, 566.</i> in the camp<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in the midst of the camp.”</i> of Israel, one on his right hand, and one on his left. Hence thou mayest learn that the precentor<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. has an abbreviation: “Sheshaz”; lit. “that the Messenger of the Congregation.” The 1st ed. agrees.</i> is prohibited to officiate unless there are two (men) standing with him,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, p. 54b, Pesiḳta, p. 22a, and Tanchuma Beshallach, § xxviii. Was the custom mentioned in our book applicable only to public prayer on Fast Days (for rain or when war arose)? See Ṭur, Orach Chayyim, 566; and Beth Joseph, 566. 7.</i> || one on his right hand and one on his left.
All the Israelites (were standing<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “were standing.” The first editions have this reading.</i>) outside (their tents<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is missing in the MS., but occurs in the first editions; the next words up to “tents” are found in the MS. only.</i>); they had gone forth from their tents, and saw Moses kneeling on his knees, and they were kneeling on their knees.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 264.</i> He fell on his face to the ground, and they fell on their faces to the ground. He spread out the palms of his hands towards the heavens, and they spread out their hands to heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to their Father who is in Heaven.” See T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 29a.</i> Just as<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Hence thou mayest learn.”</i> the precentor officiates, in like manner all the people answer<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Amen.” See Jalḳuṭ (<i>loc. cit</i>.), which omits “Amen”; see also T.B. Berakhoth, 49b.</i> after him.
The Holy One, blessed be He, caused Amalek and his people to fall into the hand of Joshua,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to fall by the edge of the sword.”</i> as it is said, "And Joshua discomfited<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the 1st ed.</i> Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword" (Ex. 17:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum on Cant. 2:16, and cf. Pal. Targum on Num. 21:1.</i>
Rabbi Shela said: The Holy One, blessed be He, wished to destroy, to cut off all the seed of Amalek. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He put forth His right hand and took hold of the throne of His glory, and swore that He would destroy and cut off all the seed of Amalek,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from this world and from the world to come.”</i> as it is said, "And he said, Because there is a hand against the throne<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the 1st ed.</i> of the Lord, the Lord will wage war against Amalek" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).
Rabbi Phineas said: (After<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits: “after”; it occurs in the first editions.</i>) forty years Moses wished to say to Israel: Do ye remember that which ye said in the wilderness—"Is the Lord among us,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits: “or not”; it occurs in the first editions.</i> or not?" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 5b.</i> But Moses said: If I speak<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds: “not”; this is probably an error; it does not occur in the first editions.</i> thus to Israel, behold I will put them to shame, and whosoever puts (his fellow) to shame will have no portion in the world to come.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth 3:12; T.B. Megillah, 25b, and Pal. Targum on Deut. 6:16. The first editions add: “But I will tell them the story of Amalek, and they will understand<sup></sup> what is written (immediately) preceding this story.</i>
A parable—To what is the matter to be compared? To a king<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The legend is also given by Tanchuma, Ki Têzê, § ix., translated in <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 190 f.</i> who had || a garden and a dog chained at the entrance to the garden. The king was sitting in his upper room, watching and looking at all that (transpired) in the garden. The friend of the king entered to steal (fruit) from the garden, and he incited the dog against him, and it tore his garments. The king said: If I say to my friend, Why didst thou enter my garden? behold I will put him to shame; therefore, behold, I will say to him: Didst thou see that mad dog, how it tore thy clothes?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “not knowing that thou art my friend.”</i> And he will understand what he has done. Likewise spake Moses: Behold, I will tell Israel the story of Amalek, and they will understand what is written before it; therefore Moses said: "Remember what Amalek did unto thee<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> by the way, as ye came forth out of Egypt" (Deut. 25:17).
The Israelites said to our teacher Moses: Moses ! One Scripture text says, "Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy" (Ex. 20:8); and it is written, "Remember what Amalek did unto thee" (Deut. 25:17). How can these two texts be fulfilled?<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or: “established.” See Tanchuma, Ki Têzê, <i>loc. cit.</i> The first editions add: “this ‘Remember’ and that ‘Remember.’”</i> He said to them: The cup of spiced wine<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> “<span>קונדיטון</span>” (<i>conditum, κoνδîτoν</i>); cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 101.</i> is not to be compared to the cup of vinegar.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “sumin,” the first editions have “chomez,” and then add: “this is a ‘cup,’ and that is a ‘cup.’” The precept to “remember” the Sabbath is explained by the Rabbis to refer to the Ḳiddush, or sanctification of the Sabbath over the cup of wine; see Singer, p. 124.</i> This "Remember" is in order to observe and to sanctify the Sabbath day,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 138.</i> and the other "Remember" is in order to destroy and to cut off all the seed of Amalek, as it is said, "Therefore it shall be, when the Lord thy God hath given thee rest<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here. The first editions read: “‘Remember what Amalek did unto thee’ (Deut. 25:17), and when thou comest to the land ‘thou shalt not forget’” (<i>ibid.</i> 19).</i> from all thine enemies… thou shalt not forget" (<i>ibid.</i> 19).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 20b. Amalek was to be punished, and this Divine decree was not to be forgotten when Israel had their own land and king. This duty of executing Divine justice devolved upon Saul as the first king of the Israelites.</i> || Israel forgot to destroy and to cut off all the seed of Amalek, but the Holy One, blessed be He, did not forget.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, Ki Têzê, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Pesiḳta (Ẓachor), p. 26a, and Lam. Rab. 5:1.</i> When Saul reigned, Samuel said to him: "Thus saith the Lord of hosts, I have marked that which Amalek did to Israel…. Now go and smite Amalek, and utterly destroy all that they have" (1 Sam. 15:2, 3). What is the meaning of "all that they have"? Even all the living male creatures.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> On <span>משחין בקיר</span> see Lexica.</i> "Spare them not, but slay" (<i>ibid.</i>). Saul took the men of war, and he went out to meet Amalek. When Saul came to the crossing of the ways, he stood still, and thought in his heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 22b: Midrash Samuel (ed. Buber), xviii. p. 50a.</i> as it is said, "And Saul came to the city of Amalek,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions the verse is continued.</i> and argued<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>וירב</span> might be interpreted in the sense of meditating. See R. V.</i> in the valley" (<i>ibid.</i> 5). Saul said: If the men have sinned, what<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “Have the women done amiss? If the women have sinned, what have the children done amiss?<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> If the children have sinned.”</i> have the beasts done amiss? A Bath Ḳol<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The text in 1 Samuel 15:19 says: “Why hast thou not hearkened unto the <i>voice</i> of the Lord?” The Bath Ḳol was a Heavenly voice; see <i>supra,</i> p. 225.</i> came forth, saying to him: Saul ! Be not more righteous than thy Creator,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 4 Ezra 8:47; T.B. Joma, <i>loc. cit.</i>; and Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 7:16.</i> as it is said, "Be not righteous overmuch" (Eccles. 7:16).
Rabbi said: When Saul came to the camp of Amalek he saw the children of Israel tarrying<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Jethro mixed up in the midst”; this reading is probably the correct text.</i> in the midst of Amalek.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Kenites dwelt among the Amalekites.</i> He said to them: Separate yourselves from the midst of Amalek, as it is said, "And Saul said unto the Kenites, Go, depart, get you down<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions it is continued.</i> from among the Amalekites, lest I destroy you with them" (1 Sam. 15:6). Did Jethro show loving-kindness to all Israel? But did he not show loving-kindness to Moses our teacher alone? Hence thou mayest learn || that whosoever shows loving-kindness unto one of the great men of Israel is considered as though he had shown loving-kindness unto Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 63b; Midrash Samuel, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Cant. Rab. on Cant. 2:5.</i> Because of the loving-kindness which he showed, his children were saved from among the Amalekites.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “as it is said, ‘So the Kenites departed from among the Amalekites’” (1 Sam. 15:6).</i>
Rabbi José said: When Sennacherib came to the land (of Israel), all the nations who were in the regions round about the land of Israel saw the camp of Sennacherib, and feared greatly, and every man fled from his place, as it is said, "I have removed the bounds of the peoples,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions it is continued.</i> and have robbed their treasures" (Isa. 10:13). They went into the wilderness, and intermixed with the children of Ishmael,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Ishmaelites dwelt hard by the Amalekites; see <i>supra,</i> p. 220.</i> and all of them were (composed of) ten peoples, as it is said, "The tents of Edom, and the Ishmaelites;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the rest of the verses up to the word Assyria are omitted; as usual, “etc.” replaces the part left out.</i> Moab, and the Hagarenes; Gebal, and Ammon, and Amalek; Philistia, with the inhabitants of Tyre; Assyria also is joined with them" (Ps. 83:6, 7, 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sukkah, 52b.</i> All of them are destined to fall by the hand of the Son of David, as it is said, "O my God, make them like the whirling dust" (<i>ibid.</i> 13).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This Messianic passage is omitted in the modern editions owing to the fear of the censor. The ten nations mentioned in the Psalm are, of course, only memories of the past. The MS. adds “etc.” at the end of its quotation; the verse continues: “As stubble before the wind.”</i> "As the fire that burneth the forest,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the MS. quotes this verse.</i> and as the flame that setteth the mountains on fire" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). "So pursue them with thy tempest,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the MS. quotes this verse.</i> and terrify them with thy storm" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).

Chapter 45

CHAPTER XLV<br><small>THE GOLDEN CALF</small> [62<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>R<small>ABBI</small> S<small>IMEON BEN</small> J<small>OCHAI</small> said: When the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed to Moses out of the thorn-bush, in order to send him to Egypt, Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He (saying): Sovereign of all the worlds!<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of the Prague edition.
