The Venice edition omits “all.”</i> Swear to me that all things which I desire to do,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Just as God agreed to comply with the request of Moses in Ex. 8:13 and xxxiii. 17, and Num. 16:31.</i> Thou wilt do, so that I should not speak words before Pharaoh, and Thou wilt not fulfil them, for then will he slay me. And He swore unto him that "whatsoever thou || desirest to do, I will do, except with reference to two things," (namely,) to let him enter the land (of Canaan),<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Deut. 4:21.</i> and (to postpone) the day of (his) death. Whence do we know that He swore unto him? Because it is said, "By myself have I sworn, saith the Lord, the word is gone forth from my mouth in righteousness" (Isa. 45:23).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation from Genesis (22:16) given in the printed texts is hardly applicable to Moses. The quotation as in our text does not quite agree with M.T., which omits “saith the Lord.”</i> When Israel received the commandments they forgot their God<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 106:21.</i> after forty days, and they said to Aaron: The Egyptians were carrying their god, and they were singing and uttering hymns<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 333; Pal. Targum on Ex. 32:5; T.J. Soṭah 3:4. 19a; and see also Num. Rab. 9:49.</i> before it, and they saw it before them. Make unto us a god like the gods of the Egyptians, and let us see it before us, as it is said, "Up, make us a god" (Ex. 32:1).
They betook themselves to the one who carried out the words of Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice text reads: “to the companions of Moses.”</i> (to) Aaron his brother, and Hur, the son of his sister. Whence (do we know) that Hur was the son of (Moses') sister? Because it is said, "And Caleb took unto him Ephrath,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> which bare him Hur" (1 Chron. 2:19). Why was Miriam's name called Ephrath?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 11b; and Ex. Rab. i. 17.</i> Because she was a daughter of the palace,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>פלמיני</span> (<i>palatinus</i>; <span><i>παλατîνoς</i>, <i>παλατίνη</i></span>), a palatina, a daughter of a nobleman. See Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 122.</i> a daughter of kings, one of the magnates of the generation; for every prince and great man who arose in Israel had his name called an Ephrathite, as it is said, "And Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, an Ephrathite"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. has: “Ephraimite.” Jeroboam was of the tribe of Ephraim; he was not an inhabitant of the city of Ephrath, but of Zeredah. See 1 Kings 11:26.</i> (1 Kings 11:26); and it says, "And David was the son of that Ephrathite" (1 Sam. 17:12). Was he then an Ephrathite? Was he not of the tribe of Judah? But he was a nobleman,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>פלמיני</span> (<i>palatinus</i>; <span><i>παλατîνoς</i>, <i>παλατίνη</i></span>), a palatina, a daughter of a nobleman. See Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 122.</i> a son of kings, one of the magnates of the generation. But since Hur was of the tribe of Judah, and one of the magnates of the generation, he began to reprove Israel with harsh words,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. Rab. 15:7; Ex. Rab. xli. 7, xlviii. 4; and Lev. Rab. 10:3.</i> and the plunderers<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “despised ones.” See Tanchuma Tezavveh, § x. Whilst Moses ascended Mount Sinai, Aaron and Hur were left in charge of the Israelites; and when Moses descended the Mount he refers to Aaron only. Hence the inference that Hur was dead. See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 205 f.; parallels to Rabbinic literature are given there, p. 206, note 1.</i> who were in Israel arose against him, and slew him.
Aaron arose || and saw that Hur, the son of his sister, was slain; and he built for them an altar, as it is said, "And when Aaron saw this,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. omits this first part of the quotation. The first editions read: “And Aaron saw (what had happened) to Hur, for he was slain; and he built an altar, as it is said, ‘And Aaron saw’ (Ex. 32:5). What did he see? (He saw) that Hur, the son of his sister, had been slain, and he built an altar, as it is said, ‘ And he built an altar’” (<i>ibid.</i>). See Rashi, <i>in loc.</i>, and Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 181.</i> he built an altar before it" (Ex. 32:5).
Aaron argued with himself, saying: If I say to Israel, Give ye to me gold and silver, they will bring it immediately; but behold I will say to them, Give ye to me the earrings of your wives, and of your sons,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and of your daughters.”</i> and forthwith the matter will fail,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanchuma, Ki Thissa, § xix., and Ẓohar, Ex. 192a.</i> as it is said, "And Aaron said to them, Break off the golden rings" (<i>ibid.</i> 2). The women heard (this), but they were unwilling<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and they did not consent.”</i> to give their earrings to their husbands; but they said to them: Ye desire to<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The “addition” (Tosaphoth) to Rashi on T.B. Megillah, 22b, reads as in our MS., but the first editions read: “To make an idol, and an abomination without power in it to deliver—we will not listen to you.”</i> make a graven image and a molten image without any power in it to deliver. The Holy One, blessed be He, gave the women their reward in this world and in the world to come. What reward did He give them in this world? That they should observe the New Moons<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This custom is referred to in T.J. Pesachim 4:1. 30d; T. J. Ta‘anith 1:6. 64c; see “addition” (Tosaphoth) to Rashi on T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Jarchi’s Manhig, 43, and Roḳeach, 228, and cf. <i>infra</i>, p. 410.</i> more stringently than the men, and what reward will He give them in the world to come? They are destined to be renewed like the New Moons, as it is said, "Who satisfieth thy years with good things;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> so that thy youth is renewed like the eagle" (Ps. 103:5).
The men saw that the women would not consent to give their earrings to their husbands. What did they do? Until that hour the earrings were (also) in their own ears, after the fashion of the Egyptians, and after the fashion of the Arabs.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Judg. 8:24, which speaks of the earrings of the Ishmaelites.</i> They broke off their earrings which were in their own ears, and they gave (them) to Aaron, as it is said, "And all the people brake off || the golden rings which were in their ears" (Ex. 32:3). "Which were in the ears of their wives" is not written here, but "which were in <i>their</i> ears." Aaron found among the earrings one plate of gold upon which the Holy Name was written, and engraven thereon was the figure of a calf, and that (plate) alone did he cast into the fiery furnace,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum on Ex. 32:24.</i> as it is said, "So they gave <i>it</i> me:<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> This first part of the verse is given by the first editions, the MS. omits the quotation here, although “as it is said” is given.</i> and I cast it into the fire, and there came out this calf" (<i>ibid.</i> 24). It is not written here, "And I cast them in," but "And I cast <i>it</i> in the fire, and there came out this calf." The calf came out lowing, and the Israelites saw it,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “And they went astray after it” is omitted by the first editions, but it is preserved by R. Bechai in his comm. on Ex. <i>in loc.</i></i> and they went astray after it.
Rabbi Jehudah said: Sammael<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read: “Satan.” See Introduction, p. li.</i> entered into it, and he was lowing to mislead Israel, as it is said, "The ox knoweth his owner"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The owner is Satan according to the Midrash; see T.B. Berakhoth, 32a, and cf. Ps. 106:19, 20. The first editions add here: “All Israel saw it, and kissed it, and bowed down to it, and sacrificed to it.”</i> (Isa. 1:3).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: Israel has forgotten the might of My power, which I wrought for them in Egypt and at the Reed Sea,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 106:22.</i> and they have made an idol for themselves. He said to Moses:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “as it is said, ‘Go, get thee down: for thy people have corrupted themselves’ (Ex. 32:7). He spake to Moses: ‘Go, get thee down, for thy people have corrupted themselves.’”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup></i> Go, get thee down from thy greatness.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 207.</i> Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the worlds! Whilst Israel had not yet sinned before Thee, Thou didst call them "My people," as it is said, "And I will bring forth <i>my</i> hosts, <i>my</i> people" (Ex. 7:4). Now that they have sinned before Thee, Thou sayest unto me, "Go, get thee down, for <i>thy</i> people have corrupted themselves" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 7). They are Thy people, and Thine inheritance, as it is said, "Yet they are thy people and thine inheritance" (Deut. 9:29).
Moses took || the tables (of the law),<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.J. Ta‘anith 4:4. 68b, and Ex. Rab. xxviii. 1. Moses took them against the will of the heavenly host.</i> and he descended, and the tables carried their own weight<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 212; cf. T.B. Soṭah, 35a, with reference to the ark of the Covenant and its transportation. MS. Gaster reads: “When Moses came to the camp and saw the calf.”</i> and Moses with them; but when they beheld the calf and the dances,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the cymbals, the dances, and the calf.”</i> the writing fled from off the tables,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xli. p. 67a; T.B. Pesachim, 87b; Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 102a, and see Pal. Targum on Ex. 32:19. The first editions read: “fled and flew away from off the tables.”</i> and they became heavy in his hands,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Nedarim, 38a, and Deut. Rab. iii. 12.</i> and Moses was not able to carry himself and the tables, and he cast them from his hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 87b.</i> and they were broken beneath the mount, as it is said, "And Moses' anger waxed hot,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.; the printed texts give the latter part of the verse only.</i> and he cast the tables out of his hands, and brake them beneath the mount"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashbam’s comm. <i>in loc.</i></i> (Ex. 32:19).
Moses said to Aaron: What hast thou done to this people? Thou hast made them unruly, like a woman who is unchecked<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> For the phrase cf. Num. 5:18 with Pal. Targum thereon. See also <i>supra</i>, p. 100, and cf. Num. Rab. 9:49.</i> owing to immorality. He said to Moses: I saw what they did to Hur, and I feared very greatly.
Rabbi said: All the princes were not associated in the affair of the calf, as it is said, "And upon the nobles<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “Azilê.” See T.B. Megillah, 10b; Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 9 p. 52, and cf. Kallah 1 (end).</i> of the children of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> he laid not his hand" (<i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 11). The word ("Azilê") means the "princes," therefore they were accounted worthy to gaze upon the glory<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the presence.”</i> of the Shekhinah, as it is said, "And they saw the God of Israel" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>P.R.E.</i> identifies here the Shekhinah with the Deity.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah said: The tribe of Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 66b, and T.B. Chagigah, 6b.</i> also did not associate itself in the affair of the calf, as it is said, "Then Moses stood in the gate of the camp,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> and said, Whoso is on the Lord's side (let him come) unto me. And all the sons of Levi gathered themselves together unto him" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 26). Moses saw that the tribe of Levi was with him.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “had not associated itself with them.”</i> He became strengthened with his might, and he burnt the calf with fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “Forthwith was he strengthened and endowed with might, that he took the calf and burnt it with fire.”</i> and powdered it, like the dust<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Read <span>כעפר</span>, as in MS. Gaster and the Venice edition.</i> of the earth, and he cast its dust upon the face of the waters, as it is said, "And he took the || calf which they had made" (<i>ibid.</i> 20). He made Israel drink the water (with the dust of the calf). Everyone who had kissed the calf with all his heart, his upper lip and his bones<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “his lips became golden.”</i> became golden,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. the legend of Midas in Ovid’s <i>Metam.</i> xi. See also Pal. Targum, Ex. 32:20, and cf. Jalḳuṭ Makhiri on Ps. 78 p. 15a.</i> and the tribe of Levi slew him,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 4 p. 17, and cf. T.B. Joma, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> until there fell of Israel about three thousand men,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation does not appear in the printed editions.</i> as it is said, "And the sons of Levi did according to the word of Moses" (<i>ibid.</i> 28).
The Holy One, blessed be He, sent five angels to destroy Israel. (The angels were) Wrath, Anger, Temper, Destruction, and Glow of Anger.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xli. 5 (end); Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 7 p. 33b; Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Ex. pp. 57a, b; Deut. Rab. iii. 11; and cf. T.B. Sabbath, 55a; T.B. Nedarim, 32a; and T.B. Berakhoth, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Moses heard,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> God’s threat to destroy Israel; see Ex. 32:10.</i> and he went to invoke Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on Ps. 7 § 637: “He went to the cave of Machpelah,” as in our MS.; this phrase does not occur in the printed editions of our book. See also Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 182. For a parallel in Christian literature see the Acts of Andrew and Matthias (<i>A.N.C.L</i>. xvi. p. 356); cf. also 4 Ezra 7:106 f., and Assumption of Moses, xii. 6.</i> at the Cave of Machpelah, and he said: If ye be of the children of the world to come, stand ye before me in this hour, for behold your children are given over like sheep to the slaughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> For this phrase see Jer. 12:3. Cf. T.B. Sabbath, 129b.</i> Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob stood there before him. Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He (saying): Sovereign of all the worlds ! Didst Thou not swear to these (forefathers) thus to increase their seed like the stars of the heaven, as it is said, "Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and the first editions.</i> thy servants, to whom thou swarest by thine own self, and saidst unto them, I will multiply your seed as the stars of heaven" (<i>ibid.</i> 18).
By the merit of the three patriarchs, the three angels, Wrath, Anger, and Temper, were restrained from (doing harm to) Israel. But two (angels) remained. Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the universe ! For the sake of the oath which Thou didst swear unto them, keep back (the angel) Destruction || from Israel, as it is said, "To whom thou swarest by thine own self" (<i>ibid.</i>); and Destruction was kept back from Israel, as it is said, "But he, being full of compassion, forgave their iniquity,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here, it is continued in the first editions. See Wisdom xviii. 22, 25 for a parallel.</i> and <i>destroyed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> there was no “Destruction.” Cf. Deut. 10:10.</i> (them) not" (Ps. 78:88). Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds! For the sake of Thy great and holy Name, which Thou didst make known unto me,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “For the sake of the oath which thou didst swear unto me.”</i> hold back from Israel (the angel called) Glow of Anger, (as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is wanting in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i>) "Turn away from thy <i>fierce</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>חרון</span>, fierce; also used as the name of the angel here.</i> <i>anger</i>" (Ex. 32:12). What did Moses do? He dug in the earth in the possession of Gad,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tosaphoth to T.B. Soṭah, 14a. The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “the children of Gad.”</i> as (though for the foundation of) a large dwelling, and he buried "Fierce Anger" in the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Job 40:13 with Targum thereon, and Lev. Rab. 10 (end).</i> like a man who is bound in the prison.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Jubilees xlviii. 15: “the prince of the Mastema was bound and imprisoned.”</i> Every time Israel sins it arises and opens its mouth to bite<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Einhorn suggests the reading <span>לנשוף</span>, “to blow,” instead of <span>לנשוך</span>, “to bite.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 64a. MS. Gaster reads: “to blow.”</i> with its breath, and to destroy Israel. Moses pronounced against it the (divine) Name,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The New Testament speaks of the invocation of the name of Jesus in order to exorcise demons; see Mark ix. 38 and Acts iv. 10.</i> and brought it down beneath the earth. Therefore is its name called Peor (the one who opens). When Moses died, what did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He put his burial-place opposite to it. Every time Israel sins<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tosaphoth to T.B. Soṭah, <i>loc. cit.</i>: “Every year at that season when they sinned with the daughters of Moab, it arises to accuse them.”</i> it opens its mouth to bite with its breath, and to destroy Israel, but (when) it sees the burial-place of Moses opposite to it, it<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add: “it becomes afraid.”</i> returns backward, as it is said, "And he buried him in the valley,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> in the land of Moab, over against the house of Peor" (Deut. 34:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>in loc</i>., and Jalḳuṭ, Deut. § 965.</i>

Chapter 46

CHAPTER XLVI<br><small>MOSES ON THE MOUNT</small> [64<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>R<small>ABBI</small> E<small>LAzAR</small>, son of 'Azariah, said: On Friday, || on the 6th of the month,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 318; and cf. Mekhilta, Jethro iii. p. 63b; T.B. Sabbath, 86b and 88a; Book of Jashar lxxxii. 6; Pal. Targum to Ex. 19:16; and cf. Roḳeach, 296.</i> at the sixth hour of the day, Israel received the Commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> at 12 o’clock noon; the day begins at 6 a.m.; see Tosephta ‘Arakhin 1:9, p. 543.</i> At the ninth hour of the day they returned to their tents, and the Manna was prepared for them for two days,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> For Friday and Sabbath.</i> and Israel rested on that Sabbath full of joy as (with) the joy of the festival, because they were worthy to hear the voice of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "For who is there of all flesh,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued up to “living God.”</i> that hath heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the midst of the fire, as we have, and lived?" (Deut. 5:26). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses in a pure expression of speech:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> an elegant expression, euphemism. “Tent” signifies the wife who is to be found in the <i>tent.</i> This is wanting in MS. Gaster.</i> Go, tell the children of Israel, that for My sake they should return to their tents, (as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “As it is said” is wanting in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i>) "Go, say to them, Return ye to your tents" (<i>ibid.</i> 30). It is possible that even thou (Moses) shouldst return. Hence thou mayest learn that from the hour when Moses brought down the Torah to Israel, he did not approach his wife,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 270, where in note 2 it is pointed out that the Church Father Aphraates knew this legend.</i> as it is said, "But as for thee, stand thou <i>here by me</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 31).
Rabbi Joshua, son of Ḳorchah, said: Forty days was Moses on the mountain, reading the Written Law by day, and studying the Oral Law<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “Mishnah.” See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 19:7, p. 83b.</i> by night. After the forty days he took the tables (of the Law) and descended into the camp on the 17th of Tammuz,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Ta‘anith, 26b.</i> and he broke in pieces the tables, and slew the sinners<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Nachmanides, Commentary on Ex. 33:7. Asheri at end of T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah reads: “the Levites slew the Israelites.” The first editions read <span>לייטי</span>.</i> in Israel. He then spent forty days in the camp, until he had burnt the calf, and powdered it like<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 356, n. 12. The first editions read: “in the dust.” Luria’s text reads: “like the dust.”</i> the dust of the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add: “and he had slain everyone who had kissed the calf.”</i> and he had destroyed the idol worship from Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 44a.</i> and he instituted every tribe in its place. And on the New Moon of Ellul<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Asheri (<i>loc. cit</i>.) considers the reading in our text to be faulty. Moses was three times on Mount Sinai, each time forty days. On the 18th of Tammuẓ he ascended the second time and descended on the 29th of Ab. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 6 p. 15a; Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 185; Tanchuma, Ki Thissa, § xxxi.; Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 103b; and cf. Tosaphoth on T.B. Baba Ḳamma, 82a, catchword, “In order that.” Nachmanides, Comm. Ex. <i>loc. cit.</i>, also disputes our author. See also Roḳeach, 208; Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa, iv. p. 178; and Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 391.</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: "Come up || to me on the mount" (Ex. 24:12), and let them sound the Shophar (trumpet) throughout the camp, for, behold, Moses has ascended the mount, so that they do not go astray again after the worship of idols. The Holy One, blessed be He, was exalted<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “on that day and with that Shophar.”</i> with that Shophar, as it is said, "God is exalted<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. gives “gone up.”</i> with a shout,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it is continued.</i> the Lord with the sound of a trumpet" (Ps. 47:5). Therefore the sages instituted that the Shophar should be sounded on the New Moon of Ellul every year.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ṭur, Orach Chayyim, 581). Therefore the sages instituted that the Shophar should be sounded on the New Moon of Ellul every year.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ṭur, Orach Chayyim, 581, which reads: “every year and during all the month.” See Menorath Ha-Maor, § 290, and Jarchi’s Manhig, 24.</i></i>
Rabbi Tachanah<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 430.</i> said: The tables (of the Law) were not created out of the earth but out of the heavens, the handicraft<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 102:25, for phraseology. See Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 102a, and Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 392.</i> of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "And the tables, the work of God were <i>they</i>" (Ex. 32:16). <i>They</i> are the tables which were of old,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> “Miḳḳedem” probably refers in our book to premundane creation; see <i>supra,</i> p. 11. The text of the verse Ex. 32:16 continues: “And the writing was the writing of God, graven upon the tables.”</i> "<i>and the writing</i>" was divine writing; that was the writing which was of old, "<i>graven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This word only is given in the MS.; the first editions continue the quotation.</i> <i>upon the tables</i>." Do not read Charuth, "graven," but (read) Chêruth, "liberty."<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Erubin, 54a. The meaning of the Haggadah is: You are free if you observe the Torah. See Aboth 6:2; and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) ii. p. 5b.</i> When the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: "Hew thee two tables of stone<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> like unto the first" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 1), a quarry of sapphires<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Nedarim, 38a.</i> was created for Moses in the midst of his tent,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 101; Lev. Rab. 32:2; Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 9:11, and x. (end).</i> and he cut them out (thence), as it is said, "And he hewed two tables of stone like unto the first" (<i>ibid.</i> 4). Moses descended with the tables, and spent forty days on the mountain, sitting down before the Holy One, blessed be He, like a disciple who is sitting before his teacher,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 21a.</i> reading the Written Law, and repeating the Oral Law which he had learnt.
The ministering angels said to him: Moses ! This Torah has been given only for our sakes.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 88a, with reference to the first tables; here in our book the second tables are considered.</i> Moses replied to them: It is written in the Torah, "Honour thy father<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far our MS. text; the first editions read till “mother.” See Pesiḳta Rabbathi, p. 98a.</i> || and thy mother" (<i>ibid.</i> xx. 12). Have ye then father and mother? Again, it is written in the Torah, "When a man dieth in the tent" (Num. 19:14). Does death happen among you?<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “(The Torah) has been given for our sake only.” See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 198 ff., where the legend as told by the Talmud B. Sabbath, 88b and 89a, is translated. See also T.B. Chagigah, 16a.</i> They were silent, and did not answer anything further.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The phrase is borrowed from Job 32:15.</i>
Hence (the sages) say: Moses went up to the heavenly regions with his wisdom, and brought down the might of the trust<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the great trust.</i> of the ministering angels, as it is said, "A wise man<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Moses.</i> scaleth the city of the mighty,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> Heaven. The angels are called mighty heroes; see Ps. 103:20, and cf. Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xxiii. p. 38a; Lev. Rab. 31:5. The angels according to the Midrash are male creatures, “Gibborim.” They have no females in their company. In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and bringeth down the strength<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the Torah. See <i>supra,</i> p. 319, on “‘Ôẓ” (might) as a term used to denote the Torah.</i> of the confidence thereof" (Prov. 21:22). When the ministering angels saw that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the Torah to Moses, they also arose and gave unto him presents and letters<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “bound together” instead of “letters.” This is an error.</i> and tablets<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ḳiddushin, 73b; “Pittaḳin,” <i>πιττάκιον,</i> tablet. See <i>infra,</i> p. 399, and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 260.</i> for healing the sons of man, as it is said, "Thou hast ascended on high, thou hast led thy captivity captive;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> thou hast received gifts among men" (Ps. 68:18).
The Son of Bethera said: Moses spent forty days on the mount, expounding the meaning of the words of the Torah, and examining its letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Menachoth, 29b.</i> After forty days he took the Torah, and descended on the tenth of the month,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the seventh month.”</i> on the Day of Atonement, and gave it as an <i>everlasting</i> inheritance to the children of Israel, as it is said, "And <i>this</i> shall be unto you an <i>everlasting</i> statute" (Lev. 16:84).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 103b. “This” (Ẓôth) refers to the Torah in the Midrash. Here it also refers to the institution of the Day of Atonement. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 6 p. 15a, note 17; and Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa iv. p. 181.</i>
Rabbi Zechariah said: They read in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Giṭṭin, 60a, on the public reading of the Torah. The section referred to is Lev. 21–xxiv.</i> and found written therein, "And ye shall afflict your souls" (<i>ibid.</i> 29), and on the Day of Atonement<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “on that selfsame day.”</i> they caused a Shophar to be sounded throughout all the camp and proclaimed a fast for all Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “all the people, both men and women.”</i> old and young.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sukkah, 28a, b.</i> Were it not for the Day of Atonement the world could not stand,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See my sermon on “Judaism: the Religion of Life” (1913), p. 4.</i> because the Day of Atonement is<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “effects atonement.” MS. Gaster omits till “effects reconciliation” (p. 363).</i> in this world and in the world to come,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 86a, and T.B. Kethuboth, 103b.</i> || as it is said, "It is a sabbath of sabbaths unto you" (<i>ibid.</i> 31). "A sabbath" refers to this world, "sabbaths" refers to the world to come. Moreover, if all the festivals pass away,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> According to one opinion all the festivals except Purim will pass away in the future; cf. T.J. Megillah, 1:7. 70d.</i> the Day of Atonement will not pass away, for the Day of Atonement effects reconciliation for serious offences<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Shebu‘oth i. 1; Maimonides, Hilkhoth Teshubah 1:2. Cf. T.B. Kerithoth, 26a.</i> as well as for slight offences. Whence do we know that the Day of Atonement effects reconciliation? Because it is said, "For on this day shall atonement be made<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> for you, to cleanse you; <i>from all</i> your sins shall ye be clean" (<i>ibid.</i> 30). "From your sins" is not written here, but "from <i>all</i> your sins shall ye be clean before the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Sammael<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “On the day when the Torah was given, Sammael,” etc.</i> said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the universe ! Thou hast given me power<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 20a. The New Testament has a parallel idea. See the expression “son of the devil,” Acts xiii. 10, and cf. Matt. iii. 7, and John viii. 44.</i> over all the nations of the world, but over Israel Thou hast not given me power. He answered him, saying: Behold, thou hast power over them on the Day of Atonement if they have any sin, but if not, thou hast no power over them. Therefore they gave him a present<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “bribe.”</i> on the Day of Atonement, in order that they should not bring their offering,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> To Sammael. The first editions read: “in order not to annul the offering of Israel.” Luria suggests an alteration in the text: “that he should not come nigh to accuse them.” See ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, vi. p. 182a, <i>s.v.</i> <span>עוא</span>, and cf. R. Bechai, <i>in loc.</i>, and T.B. Joma, 67b, for the only reference in the Talmud to ‘Aẓẓa (or, ‘Uẓẓa) and <i>Azazel</i> as angels. See also Jastrow, T.D. 1049a, and cf. T.B. Nedarim, 32b, and Lev. Rab. 21 on “Satan,” and see Roḳeach, 216.</i> as it is said, "One lot for the Lord, and the other lot for <i>Azazel</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Azazel is to be identified with Satan or Sammael. See Zunz, <i>Gesammelte Schriften,</i> i. p. 236.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 8).
The lot for the Holy One, blessed be He, was the offering of a burnt offering, and the lot for Azazel was the goat as a sin offering, for all the iniquities of Israel were upon it, as it is said, "And the goat shall bear upon him<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.</i> all their iniquities" (<i>ibid.</i> 22). Sammael saw that sin was not to be found among them on the Day of Atonement. He said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the universe ! Thou hast one people like the ministering angels who are in heaven. Just as the ministering angels || have bare feet,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “have no joints,” <i>i.e.</i> in the feet and legs, and therefore they cannot sit down. See T.J. Berakhoth i. p. 2c; Gen. Rab. 65:21; Ruth Rab. 1 (beg.); and ‘Arukh, <i>s.v.</i> <span>קפץ</span>.</i> so have the Israelites bare feet on the Day of Atonement.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The custom still obtains. See Orach Chayyim, 124</i> Just as the ministering angels have neither food nor drink,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “on the Day of Atonement.”</i> so the Israelites have neither food nor drink on the Day of Atonement. Just as the ministering angels have no joints, in like wise the Israelites stand upon their feet. Just as the ministering angels have peace obtaining amongst them,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 15a; Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 1 p. 1b.</i> so the Israelites have peace obtaining amongst them on the Day of Atonement.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 58b. The Day of Atonement effects atonement only between God and man; in order for man to be fully pardoned he must be reconciled with his fellow-creature. Cf. T.B. Ta‘anith, 22a.</i> Just as the ministering angels are innocent of all sin on the Day of Atonement, so are the Israelites innocent of all sin on the Day of Atonement. The Holy One, blessed be He, hears the prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “their testimony.” MS. Gaster reads: “the misfortunes of Israel.”</i> of Israel rather than (the charges brought by) their accuser,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> “Ḳatêgôr,” <span><i>κατήγορὸς,</i></span> accuser. See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 74. Should the line read: “rather than the testimony of Israel from the accuser”?</i> and He makes atonement for the altar, and for the sanctuary, and for the priests,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Shebu‘oth i. 1, and T.B. Shebu‘oth, 14b.</i> and for all the people of the congregation both great and small, as it is said, "And he shall make atonement for the holy place" (<i>ibid.</i> 16).
Moses said: On the Day of Atonement I will behold the glory of the Holy One, blessed be He, and I will make atonement for the iniquities of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Moses stood in the cleft of the rock and beheld the Divine Vision on the Day of Atonement, when God pardoned Israel.</i> Moses spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the universe! "Shew me, I pray thee, thy glory" (Ex. 33:18). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Moses! Thou art not able to see My glory lest thou die, as it is said, "For men shall not see me and live" (<i>ibid.</i> 20); but for the sake of the oath which I have sworn unto thee<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 358. The first editions add: “and the Name which I have made known unto thee.”</i> I will do thy will. Stand at the entrance of || the cave,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, Ex. 33:22. Cf. 1 Kings 19:9; Elijah stood at the entrance of the cave. Cf. T.B. Megillah, 19b.</i> and I will make all the angels<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Where do we find this idea? See Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 185.</i> who move<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “who minister.”</i> before Me pass before thy face. Stand in thy might, and do not fear, as it is said, "And he said, I will make all my goodness pass before thee" (<i>ibid.</i> 19). When thou dost hear the Name which I have spoken to thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xxiii. 15.</i> there am I before thee, as it is said, "And he said, I will make all my goodness pass before thee" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Instead of this part of the verse, the first editions read here: “‘And I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious, and I will shew mercy on whom I will shew mercy’” (Ex. 33:19).</i>
The ministering angels said: Behold, we serve before Him by day and by night, and we are unable to see His glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 58, and Num. Rab. 14:21. Cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 25. The first editions have all the pronouns referring to God in the second person.</i> and this one born of woman<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Who sleeps by night. Cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, pp. 198 f., and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) ii. p. 5b, note 39.</i> desires to see His glory. And they arose<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Against “him” is added by the first editions and MS. Gaster.</i> in wrath and excitement<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The wording is borrowed from 2 Chron. 26:20. See T.B. Megillah, 29a.</i> to slay him, and his soul came nigh unto death.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Dan. 3:28.</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He revealed Himself unto him in a cloud,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> To protect him. See T.B. Chullin, 91b.</i> as it is said, "And the Lord descended in the cloud" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 5). This was the seventh descent.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 97.</i>
The Holy One, blessed be He, protected him<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 91:4: “He shall cover thee with his pinions, and under his wings shalt thou take refuge.” See Pesiḳta Rabbathi, p. 37b; and Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Ex. p. 57a.</i> with the hollow of His hand that he should not die, as it is said, "And it shall come to pass, while my glory passeth by,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> that I will put thee in a cleft of the rock, and I will cover thee with my hand" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiii. 22). When the Holy One, blessed be He, had passed by, He removed the hollow of His hand from him, and he saw the traces of the Shekhinah, as it is said, "And I will take away mine hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. and the first editions the quotation ends here.</i> and thou shalt see my back" (<i>ibid.</i> 28). Moses began to cry with a loud voice, and he said:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Moses is the one who declares the thirteen divine attributes. See T.B. Joma, 36b.</i> "O Lord, O Lord, a God full of compassion and gracious …" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxiv. 6).
Moses said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! Pardon now the iniquities of this people.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “the iniquities of Israel in connection with the affair of the (golden) calf. But if Moses had said: Pardon,” etc.</i> He said to him: Moses! If thou hadst said, Pardon now the iniquities of all Israel, even to the end of all generations (He would have done so).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The words: “He would have done so,” do not occur in our MS.; but the first editions and MS. Gaster have this reading, and they add: “because it was an acceptable time; and thus it says: ‘In an acceptable time have I answered thee’” (Isa. 49:8). See T.B. Berakhoth, 8a, and T.B. Jebamoth, 72a.</i> It was an acceptable time. || But thou hast said: Pardon, I beseech Thee, the iniquities of this people with reference to the affair of the calf. He said to him: Moses! Behold, let it be according to thy words, as it is said, "And the Lord said, I have pardoned according to thy word" (Num. 14:20).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. li. 4, and Deut. Rab. iii. 17.</i>

Chapter 47

CHAPTER XLVII<br><small>THE ZEAL OF PHINEAS</small> [66<small>A</small>. i.]<br><small>RABBI ELAzAR,</small> son of 'Arakh, said: When the Holy One, blessed be He, descended upon Mount Sinai to give the Torah to Israel, sixty myriads<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>רבוא</span>, “ten thousand.” See T.B. Sabbath, 88a; and cf. Cant. Rab. on Cant. 3:7.</i> of the ministering angels descended with Him, corresponding to the sixty myriads of the mighty men of Israel, and in their hands were swords and crowns,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Wisdom xviii. 16; Cant. Rab. on Cant. 8:4; Ex. Rab. xxix. 2; Ẓohar, Ex. 193b; Pesiḳta, pp. 107b, 124b; and the Targumim on Ex. 33:5. See ‘Arukh, <i>s.v.</i> <span>זיינותּ ,זוניאות ,זיינאותּ</span>, and Pesiḳta Rabbathi, pp. 98b, 154a.</i> and they crowned the Israelites with<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “with the diadem of.”</i> the Ineffable Name.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 22, and Bacher, T. ii. 118.</i> All those days, whilst they had not done that deed,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The making of the golden calf.</i> they were as good as<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “They were better than the ministering angels.”</i> the ministering angels before the Holy One, blessed be He. The Angel of Death did not hold sway over them, and they did not discharge any excretions<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Joma, 75b; and cf. Num. Rab. 7:4. The gnostics held similar views with reference to Jesus; see F. C. Conybeare, <i>Myth, Magic, and Morals,</i> p. 232.</i> like the children of man; but when they did that deed the Holy One, blessed be He, was angry with them, and He said to them: I thought that ye would be<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “before Me.”</i> like the ministering angels, as it is said, "I said, Ye are angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “Elohim”; cf. Judg. 13:22. The quotation in our MS. ends here, but it is continued in the first editions.</i> and all of you sons of the Most High" (Ps. 82:6). But now, "Nevertheless, ye shall die like men" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).
Rabbi Jehudah said: As long as a man is dressed in his garments of glory, he is beautiful in his appearance<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This reminds one of the English proverb: “Fine feathers make fine birds.”</i> and in his honour;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and in his glory.”</i> so were the Israelites when they apparelled themselves with that Name—they were good before the Holy One, blessed be He, like the ministering angels. But when they did that deed (of the golden calf), the Holy One, blessed be He, was angry with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and He said to them: ‘Put off thy ornaments from thee, that I may know what to do unto thee’” (Ex. 33:5).</i> || In that night the same<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “The same” is in the MS. only.</i> sixty myriads of ministering angels<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See the different account in T.B. Sabbath, <i>loc. cit.</i>; according to this version, “One hundred and twenty myriads of ministering angels” were present at the Revelation at Sinai.</i> descended,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “Corresponding to the sixty myriads of the strong men of Israel.”</i> and they severally took from each one of them what they had put upon them, and they became bare,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 98.</i> not according to their own wish, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation is wanting in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i> "And the children of Israel stripped themselves" (Ex. 33:6). It is not written here,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “‘They were stripped off,’ but ‘they stripped themselves’ with all their strength.” The later editions modify the last words and read: “against their will.”</i> "the children of Israel took away," but "the children of Israel stripped themselves." Some say by itself (their adornment) was stripped off.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “it peeled off.”</i>
Rabbi said: At every place where Israel <i>sat down</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The verb here means “to sit down” or “to abide.”</i> in the wilderness, they made idols<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. xli. 11: “wherever you find a reference to sitting down you find some stumbling block” (occurring to the Israelites). Cf. also T.B. Synhedrin, 107a.</i> for themselves, as it is said, "And the people <i>sat down</i> to eat and to drink" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 6). What is written here? "And they rose up to play" (<i>ibid.</i>); they commenced to worship idols. One verse says, "And Israel <i>abode</i> in Shittim" (Num. 25:1). What is written here? "And the people began to commit whoredom<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here: it is continued in the first editions.</i> with the daughters of Moab" (<i>ibid.</i>). They commenced to be immoral.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “This is idolatry.”</i>
Rabbi Jehudah said: "The counsel of the wicked is far from me" (Job 21:16). This (text) refers to the counsel of Balaam, the wicked, who advised Midian, and there fell of Israel twenty-four thousand men. He said to them: You will not be able to prevail against this people, unless they have sinned before their Creator. They made for themselves booths<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “shops”; cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 242; Num. Rab. 20:23; T.B. Synhedrin, 82b; and T.J. Synhedrin 10:2. 28d.</i> outside the camp of Israel, and they sold all kinds of merchandise of the market. The young men of Israel went beyond the camp of Israel and they saw the daughters of Midian, who had painted<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Book of Jashar (lxxxv. 54) we read: “The children of Moab took all their daughters and wives of beautiful appearance and comely form and dressed them in gold and silver and costly raiment.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 106a; Siphrê, Num. § 131; T.J. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i>; cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 82b; Num. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>; Tanchuma, Balaḳ, § xxvii., and Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 771; Pal. Targum to Num. 25:1; Midrash Agadah, Num., p. 147. Twelve miracles were connected with Phineas’ deed; see Ginzberg, <i>Legends of the Jews,</i> vol. iii. p. 387, and Pal. Targum, Num. 25:8.</i> their eyes like harlots, and they took wives of them, and went astray || after them, as it is said, "And the people began to commit whoredom with the daughters of Moab" (Num. 25:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In the 1st ed. the entire section is wanting; in the 2nd ed. the words “they sold… camp of Israel” are omitted.</i>
Simeon and Levi were exceedingly zealous because of the immorality, as it is said, "And they said, As with an harlot<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions. The next sentence occurs in our MS. only.</i> should he deal with our sister?" (Gen. 34:81). Each man took his sword and they slew the men of Shechem. The prince of the tribe of Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> did not remember that which his ancestor<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Simeon, son of Jacob, was zealous for the honour of his sister Dinah.</i> had done, and he did not rebuke the young men of Israel, but he himself came<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “with immorality.”</i> publicly<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>פדהסיא</span>, <i>παῤῥησία,</i> “openly.”</i> to the Midianitish woman for an immoral purpose, as it is said, "Now the name of the man of Israel that was slain,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions. The next sentence occurs in our MS. only.</i> who was slain with the Midianitish woman, was Zimri… a prince of a fathers' house among the Simeonites" (Num. 25:14).
All the princes with Moses, Eleazar, and Phineas saw the angel who was to destroy the people,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the angel of death.”</i> and they sat down and wept, and they did not know what to do. Phineas saw how Zimri went publicly to the Midianitish woman for an immoral purpose, and he was moved by a great zeal,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> To slay a prince, chief of one of the tribes.</i> and he snatched the spear out of the hand of Moses, and ran after (Zimri) and pierced him through the back, through the pudenda, and the spear went into the belly of the woman. Therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, gave a good reward to him and to his sons with the food of the shoulder.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “gave him the food of the maw. Moreover He strengthened his arms (so that) he fixed the spear in the earth, and they were found hanging from the top of the spear, the one above the other, the man above the woman.” See Pal. Targum, Num., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> And the jaws were separated, the jaws of the man (from) the jaws of the woman; therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him and his sons a good reward with the food of the cheeks,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Gave him for food the cheeks.” The gifts referred to were portions of certain sacrifices.</i> as it is said, "And they shall give unto the priest the shoulder,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions. For the Biblical account of the narrative see Num. 25:8. On this section see Gaster, <i>Jeraḥmeel,</i> p. xcvii and lv. 10–12, and Ginzberg, <i>op. cit.</i> p. 389.</i> and the two cheeks, and the maw" (Deut. 18:3).
He arose like a great spiritual leader<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>דיין</span>, “judge” or spiritual leader. See Ex. Rab. xxxiii. 5 and T.B. Synhedrin, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and he judged Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a judge for Israel.”</i> as it is said, "Then stood up Phineas, || and he executed <i>judgment</i>" (Ps. 106:30). What is the meaning of this expression, "And he executed judgment"? Like a great judge. Just as thou dost say,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This is an unusual form of introducing a quotation from the Bible in this book.</i> "And he shall pay as the judges determine" (Ex. 21:22). And he smote the young men of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “and they drew them throughout all the corners of the camp of Israel.”</i> so that all Israel should see and fear, as it is said, "And all Israel shall hear, and fear" (Deut. 21:21).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation is given by the MS. only.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, saw what Phineas had done, and forthwith was He filled with compassion; the plague was stayed, as it is said, "And so the plague was stayed" (Num. 16:50).
Rabbi Eliezer said: He called<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The Holy One, blessed be He, changed.” See Jalḳuṭ, Num., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> the name of Phineas by<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The text literally means “like.” Phineas flies in the heavens (see Pal. Targum to Num. 31:8) by invoking the Ineffable Name. This is also done by Elijah; cf. Basset, <i>Les Apocryphes éthiopiens,</i> vii. p. 26; a parallel story occurs in the conflict between Peter and Simon Magus (see Hastings’ <i>D.B.</i> iv. p. 523).</i> the name of Elijah<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Midrash Elijah was from Jerusalem of the tribe of Benjamin; see Ex. Rab. xl. 4; Gen. Rab. 71:9; Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 18 pp. 97 f. and note 57; and Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa xv. p. 199 (end). Cf. Tosaphoth on T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 113b.</i>—Elijah of blessed memory,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 2.</i> (who was) of those who repented in Gilead, for he brought about the repentance of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 106b, and Siphrê, Num., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> in the land of Gilead. The Holy One, blessed be He, gave him the life of this world and the life of the world to come,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Mo’ed Ḳaṭan, 26a, “Elijah lives on”; cf. Ps. 106:30, where Phineas is spoken of by the Psalmist.</i> as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> “‘Behold, I give my covenant of peace,’ and it is written: ‘My covenant was with him.’” This is the reading in the Jalḳuṭ, Num., <i>loc. cit.,</i> and is probably the most correct version preserved. “My covenant was with him” refers to Elijah, who is called the “angel.” Phineas is also called the “angel”; see Lev. Rab. 1:1.</i> "My covenant was with him<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> of <i>life</i> and <i>peace</i>" (Mal. 2:5). He gave to him and to his sons a good reward,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “between the righteous and the wicked.”</i> in order that (he might have) the everlasting priesthood, as it is said, "And it shall be unto him, and to his seed<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “sons” instead of “seed after him,” which is the MT. and the reading in the first editions.</i> after him, the covenant of an everlasting priesthood" (Num. 25:13).
Rabbi Elazar of Modein said: Phineas arose, and pronounced the ban<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> On the ban and the bread of the Cutheans see <i>supra,</i> p. 301.</i> upon Israel by the mystery of the Ineffable Name, and with the script which was written on the tables (of the Law), and by the ban of the celestial Court of Justice,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Liturgy of Evening of Day of Atonement, introduction to <span>כל נדרי</span>.</i> and by the ban of the terrestrial Court of Justice, that a man of Israel should not drink the wine of the nations<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> For the parallel in the New Testament see 1 Cor. viii. 1 ff. and <i>ibid.</i> x. 20 f., and the parallel passages.</i> unless it had been trodden by the feet, as it is said, "And as for my sheep, that which ye have trodden with your feet<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> they eat, and they drink that which ye have fouled with your feet"<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds here: “For all the wine of the heathens is poured out for idolatrous purposes and for immoral purposes.”</i> (Ezek. 34:19). Because all the wine of the nations was devoted to idolatry and immorality, for they took the first of their new wine for idolatry and immorality,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The orgies in connection with the Bacchic rites illustrate this statement.</i> as it is said, "Whoredom and wine<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS. The first editions continue thus: “Another verse says: ‘Be not among winebibbers; among gluttonous eaters of flesh’” (Prov. 23:20).</i> || and new wine take away the heart" (Hos. 4:11).
Rabbi Phineas said: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: Do ye remember what those Midianites did to you, for twenty-four thousand men fell in Israel? But before "thou art gathered in,"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> before thy death.</i> arise, execute vengeance,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “on them.”</i> (as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “as it is said,” and reads only the first two words of the verse; the first editions have: “as it is said.”</i>) "Avenge the children of Israel of the Midianites; afterwards shalt thou be gathered unto thy people" (Num. 31:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The command to punish the Midianites on account of the Peor idolatry was not put into execution immediately. Moreover, the punishment of the Amalekites was to be deferred until the Israelites had possession of the Holy Land.</i>
What did Moses do? He took a thousand men<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 157, and cf. Tanchuma (Buber), Maṭṭoth, p. 79b, for the meaning: “two thousand from each tribe.”</i> (and) a prince<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> “a prince” occurs in the MS. only; it is apparently an error.</i> from each tribe of the tribes of Israel. Behold, (there were) twelve thousand (men), and he who had been zealous because of the immorality, was the prince<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Phineas, see T.B. Soṭah, 43a; Siphrê, Num., <i>loc. cit.</i>; and cf. 1 Chron. 9:20.</i> over them. The<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “They took the holy vestments.”</i> holy vestments and the trumpets of alarm<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>תרועה</span>, “alarm.”</i> were in his hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in their hand.”</i> and they went, and they took captive the daughters of Midian, and they brought them (to the camp).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “And Moses heard, and he went forth to meet them, and he saw them.”</i> (Moses) said to (Phineas): Because of these did not twenty-four thousand men of Israel fall? as it is said, "Behold, these<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The preceding verse says: “And Moses said unto them: Have ye saved all the women alive?”</i> caused the children of Israel, through the counsel of Balaam,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> to commit trespass against the Lord in the matter of Peor" (<i>ibid.</i> 16); and he began to be angry with them, as it is said, "And Moses was wroth with the officers of the host" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 785, which quotes the Siphrê Ẓuṭṭa; see also Siphrê, Num., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> During his anger the Holy Spirit departed from him. Hence thou mayest learn that the impetuous<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>קפדן</span>, “hot-tempered,” “impatient.”</i> man destroys his wisdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Eccles. 7:7, and see Eccles. Rab. on Eccles. 7:7.</i> Eleazar saw<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He (<i>i.e</i>. God) called to Eleazar.”</i> and he heard (the voice) behind (Moses),<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> It passed by Moses, who failed to hear the Divine message.</i> as it is said, "And Eleazar the priest said<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> unto the men of war… This is the statute of the Law which the Lord hath commanded Moses" (<i>ibid.</i> 21). He<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Eleazar; see Siphrê, Num., <i>loc. cit.,</i> and cf. T.B. Pesachim, 66b, and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) i. p. 2a.</i> said to them: He<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> God.</i> commanded Moses and He did not command me.

Chapter 48

CHAPTER XLVIII<br><small>THE EGYPTIAN BONDAGE</small> [67<small>A</small>. i.]<br>R<small>ABBAN</small> J<small>OCHANAN</small>, son of Ẓakkai, opened (his exposition with the text): "In that day the Lord made a covenant with Abram,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> saying, Unto thy seed will I give this land, from the river of Egypt unto the great river, the river Euphrates" (Gen. 15:18). Abram said before the Holy One, blessed be He, Sovereign of all the universe ! Thou hast not given me seed, yet dost Thou say, "Unto thy seed will I give<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “I have given.” The first editions have: “will I give this land,” and the following is added: “as it is said. ‘Behold to me thou hast given no seed’” (Gen. 15:3).</i> || this land" (<i>ibid.</i>). He said: "Whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Abram! The entire world stands by My word,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “command” (<i>Dibbur</i>)<i> = λóγος.</i> See Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 119:89; cf. Jer. 31:3 ff. on the eternity of Israel.</i> and thou dost not believe in My word, but thou sayest, "Whereby <i>shall I know</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> that I shall inherit it?" (<i>ibid.</i>). By thy life! In two ways shalt thou surely know, as it is said, "And he said to Abram, Know of <i>a surety</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The double form of the verb in the Hebrew text suggests the Haggadic interpretation in our book. One form of the verb is taken to refer to the promise of seed; the other refers to the affliction of Abraham’s seed. In the MS. the quotation ends with the word “surety”; in the first editions it is continued.</i> that thy <i>seed</i> shall be a <i>stranger</i> in a land which is not theirs,… and <i>they shall afflict them</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 18).
Rabbi Elazar, son of 'Azariah, said: Is it not so that the Israelites did not dwell in Egypt except for 210<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>רד״ו</span> = 200 plus 4 plus 6; <i>i.e.</i> 210.</i> years? But in order to teach thee, know that this is so, come and see; for when Joseph went down to Egypt he was seventeen years old, and when he stood before Pharaoh he was thirty years old, as it is said, "And Joseph was thirty years old when he stood<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> before Pharaoh, king of Egypt" (<i>ibid.</i> xli. 46). And the seven years of plenty, and the two years of famine, behold, they are nine-and-thirty years (in all). And Levi, the son of Jacob, was six years older than Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 272. There was seven months’ interval between the birth of each child; Reuben, Simeon, and Levi. The last-named was born in the twenty-first month. Joseph was the last son born in the first seven years of Rachel’s married life.</i> and when he went down to Egypt he was forty-five years,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum to Ex. 6:16; Levi lived so long that he knew of Moses and Aaron standing before Pharaoh, and see T.B. Baba Bathra, 121b.</i> and the years of his life in Egypt were ninety-two years;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 3 p. 8a: “One hundred and sixteen years elapsed between the death of Levi and the Exodus.” See Ratner’s note (14), <i>in loc.</i> Cf. <i>Jubilees</i> (ed. Charles), p. 172.</i> behold, all of them (amount to) 137 years, (as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first edition omit “as it is said”; it occurs in the Venice edition.</i>) "And the years of the life of Levi were an hundred thirty and seven years" (Ex. 6:16). On his going down to Egypt, his wife bare unto him Jochebed, his daughter,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. 26:59: “who was born to Levi.” Jochebed was called “daughter of Levi” when Amram was married to her.</i> as it is said, "And the name of Amram's wife was Jochebed" (Num. 26.	59), and she was 130 years<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Book of Jashar lxvii. 2, Jochebed was one hundred and twenty-six years old at her marriage. See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 3 p. 7b; Pal. Targum, Ex. 2:1; T.B. Baba Bathra, 120a; T.B. Megillah, 8a, and Midrash Agadah, Ex. pp. 122 f.</i> when she bare Moses, (as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “as it is said”; it occurs in the first editions.</i>) "And Moses was fourscore years old when he stood before Pharaoh" (Ex. 7:7). || Behold, (the total is) 210 years in all.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and the mnemonic is ‘Rdu.’” “Descend” is the literal meaning of this word; the numerical value is 210, as above.</i> And thus it says, "And they shall serve them; and they shall afflict them<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> four hundred years" (Gen. 15:18).
Rabbi Elazar, son of 'Arakh, said to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “said to him,” <i>i.e.</i> R. Jochanan.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, said this to Abraham only at the hour when he had seed, as it is said, "Thy <i>seed</i> shall be a stranger<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions; the latter add: “and it is written, ‘For in Isaac shall thy <i>seed</i> be called’” (Gen. 21:12). And not through Ishmael; see <i>supra,</i> p. 215, and cf. T.B. Nedarim, 31a, and Seder ‘Olam Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> in a land that is not theirs" (<i>ibid.</i>). From the time when Isaac was born until Israel went forth from Egypt 400 years (elapsed).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Sixty years from the birth of Isaac to the birth of Jacob, plus 130 years when Jacob stood before Pharaoh and 210 years of bondage in Egypt, give a total of 400 years; cf. Seder ‘Olam Rab. 3 p. 7a.</i> (Rabban Jochanan, son of Ẓakkai<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words in brackets are wanting in the MS., but occur in the first editions.</i>) said to him: Verily it is written, "Now the sojourning of the children of Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> which they sojourned in Egypt, was four hundred and thirty years" (Ex. 12:40). He answered him, saying: 210<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads “220 years.” The first editions have “210 (Rdu) years.” The MS. text is corrupt. This can be proved by the fact that the next sentence speaks of 215 years as the total—210 years plus 5 years. In the previous pages our text mentions “210 years,” and this same figure reappears <i>infra,</i> p. 391.</i> years Israel abode in Egypt, and five years before Jacob came to Egypt there were born unto Joseph(the fathers of) two tribes, Manasseh and Ephraim,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar 1. 15; they were born when Joseph was thirty-four years old, <i>i.e.</i> in the fourth year of plenty, for he was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh and foretold the seven years of plenty which were to be followed by the years of famine.</i> and they belonged to the Israelites.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “they belonged to the tribes, as it is said. ‘Ephraim and Manasseh, even as Reuben and Simeon, shall be mine’” (Gen. 48:5).</i> Behold, (we have) 215 years of days and nights,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The bondage was by day and night. See Ex. Rab. xviii. 11. The Egyptians prevented the Israelites from living in peace and comfort when the day’s work was done. See Haggadah for the Passover (ed. Landshuth), p. 18.</i> (this equals) 430 years; for the Holy One, blessed be He, reduced<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “skipped.”</i> the time for the sake of the merit of the Patriarchs, for they are the mountains of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 248 f. The Jalḳuṭ, Cant. § 986, reads: “the fathers, who are the mountains of the world; and for the merit of the sons of Jacob, who are the hills of the world”; cf. T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 11a, and Pal. Targum, Gen. 49:26.</i> and for the sake of the merit of the Mothers,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Sarah, Rebecca, Rachel, and Leah.</i> for they are the hills of the world, and concerning them the Scripture says, "The voice of my beloved ! Behold, he cometh,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits the first part as well as the latter part of the quotation, reading: “leaping upon the mountains.” The first editions give the first part of the verse.</i> leaping upon the mountains, <i>skipping</i> over the hills" (Cant. 2:8).
Rabbi Eliezer said: During all those years, when the Israelites abode in Egypt, they dwelt securely and peacefully at ease<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> As long as they trusted in God and kept faith in His promises. The phrase is borrowed from Prov. 1:33. Cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 182.</i> until Ganoon,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The printed text of <i>P.R.E.</i> reads “Jagnoon.” MS. Gaster omits the name. See Introduction, p. 1. For the legend see the Book of Jashar, ch. lxxv. For further references in Rabbinical literature see <i>J.E.</i> v. 189, and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> pp. 256 f.</i> one of the grandchildren of Ephraim, came and said to them, The Holy One, blessed be He, has revealed Himself to me,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 78:8, 9. See also Mekhilta Beshallach, p. 24a; Cant. Rab. to verse of Cant. 2:7; and T.B. Kethuboth, 111a.</i> to lead you out of Egypt. The children of Ephraim, in the pride of their heart, for they were of the royal seed,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Of Joseph, according to Jacob’s blessing.</i> and mighty men in battle,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “arose and took their wives, their sons, and their daughters.”</i> took their wives and their sons, || and they went forth from Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This was thirty years before the Exodus. This vain attempt to hasten the Divine Deliverance was the cause of the harsh bondage which began then. See also Seder ‘Olam Rab. 3 7b, for another opinion.</i> The Egyptians pursued after them, and slew of them 200,000, all of them mighty men,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The text is not correct. See Pal. Targum on Ex. 13:17 and <i>ibid.</i> note 7. Luria reads: “The Egyptians pursued them and slew 200,000, all mighty men, as it is said,” etc. MS. Gaster reads: “The Egyptians arose and slew them, as it is said,” etc.</i> as it is said, "The children of Ephraim,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> being armed and carrying bows, turned back in the day of battle" (Ps. 78:9).
Rabbi Jannai said: The Egyptians did not enslave the Israelites but for one hour of the day<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> God’s day equals 1000 years, and reckoning 12 hours to the day the hour of God’s day equals 83⅓ years. On God’s day see <i>supra,</i> p. 128</i> of the Holy One, blessed be He, (that is to say, for) 83⅓ years. Whilst<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria reads: “Three years and a third before Moses was born.”</i> yet Moses was not born, the magicians said to Pharaoh: In the future a child will be born, and he will take Israel out of Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar lxvii. 19.</i> Pharaoh thought, and said:<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He thought and said in his heart.”</i> Cast ye all the male children into the river, and he<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Moses. See Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 3b; and Pal. Targum, Ex. 1:15.</i> will be thrown in with them,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said, ‘Every son that is born ye shall cast into the river’” (Ex. 1:22).</i> and thereby the word (of the magicians) will be frustrated; therefore they cast all the (male) children into the river.
