Three years (elapsed) until<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Exodus, § 165, which reads: “For three years and a third of a year they cast them in until Moses was born.” The first editions read: “Three years and a third of a year (elapsed) until Moses was born.” See also ‘Arukh, <i>s.v.</i> <span>אהרן</span>, and cf. the Book of Jashar lxviii. 3.</i> the birth of Moses. When Moses was born they said (to Pharaoh): Behold, he is born, and he is hidden from our vision. (Pharaoh) said to them: Since he is born, henceforth ye shall not cast the male children into the river, but put upon them a hard yoke<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Deut. 26:6.</i> to embitter the years of their lives with hard labour,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to embitter the lives of their fathers.”</i> as it is said, "And they made their lives bitter" (Ex. 1:14).
Rabbi Nathaniel said: The parents of Moses saw the child, (for) his form was like that of an angel of God.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 12a.</i> They circumcised him on the eighth day,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 16.</i> and they called his name Jekuthiel.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar lxviii. 24 ff. and Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 166, quoting the Book of Chronicles of Moses on the various names of Moses. See also 1 Chron. 4:18, where Jekuthiel is spoken of as the son of Bithyah, the daughter of Pharaoh. See the Targum to this verse and cf. T.B. Megillah, 13a. Clement of Alexandria, <i>Strom</i>. i. 23, gives Joachim and Melchi as names of Moses.</i>
Rabbi Simeon said: They called him Ṭob (good), as it is said, "And when she saw him that he was <i>good</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 2). They concealed him in a house || of<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “beneath the earth for three months, as it is said, ‘She hid him three months’” (Ex. 2:2).</i> the earth for three months. After three months<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “she could hide him no longer.”</i> she put him in an ark of bulrushes, and she cast him upon the bank of the river. All things are revealed before the Holy One, blessed be He. Now Bithyah,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>J.E.</i> iii. p. 231a.</i> the daughter of Pharaoh, was<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition reads: “Was smitten with sore leprosy.” According to the Book of Jashar lxviii. 15, the reason why Bithyah went down to bathe was because God had sent a consuming heat which oppressed the Egyptians.</i> smitten sorely with leprosy and she was not able to bathe in hot water,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 7 p. 42; Ex. Rab. xi. 5; Pal. Targum to Ex. 2:5, and Jalḳuṭ, Ex. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and she came to bathe in the river, and she saw the crying child. She put forth her hand and took hold of him, and she was healed.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 12a–b. This seems to be a Jewish-Hellenistic Midrash, as it occurs in Ezekiel’s drama, “The Exodus,” quoted by Clement of Alexandria, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> She said: This child is righteous, and I will preserve his life. Whosoever preserves a life<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a single life in Israel.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 37a, and T.B. Baba Bathra, 11b. The first editions add: “And whosoever destroys a single life in Israel is as though he had destroyed the whole world. Therefore was the daughter of Pharaoh worthy to take shelter beneath the wings of the Shekhinah, and she was called the daughter of Omnipresent.” Jalḳuṭ, Ex. <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “She was worthy to have the life of the future world”; cf. Derekh Erez Ẓuṭṭa i., where we read that “Bithyah entered Paradise in her lifetime,” <i>i.e.</i> without experiencing death. See also <i>J.E.</i> iii. 231 for further details as to the Rabbinical legends concerning Bithyah, “Daughter of God.”</i> is as though he had kept alive the whole world. Therefore was she worthy to (inherit) the life in this world and the life in the world to come.
All the household of Pharaoh's palace were (helping) to educate (Moses), as it is said, "And it came to pass in those days, when Moses was grown up, that he went out unto his brethren" (<i>ibid.</i> 11).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Rashi on Ex. 2:11; see also Jalḳuṭ, Ex. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> Moses went into the camp of Israel, and saw one of the taskmasters of Pharaoh smiting one of the sons of Kohath, the Levites, for they were his brethren, as it is said, "And he saw an Egyptian smiting an Hebrew, <i>one of his brethren</i>"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The <i>brethren</i> of Moses would be of the tribe of Levi.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). He began to rebuke him with the sword of his lips,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 59:7: “swords are in their lips,” and also Isa. 11:4. See <i>supra,</i> p. 156, and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Ex. <i>loc. cit.</i> As a parallel to our text see Pss. of Solomon xvii. 27: “He shall destroy the ungodly nations with the word of his mouth.” Probably the reference is to the invocation of the Ineffable Name. See Ex. Rab. i. 29, and Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 7a, notes 78 and 80. Cf. Fürst, <i>Z.D.M.G.</i> xxxiii. p. 299; Lev. Rab. 32:4, and Bacher, T. ii. p. 252. Clement of Alexandria, <i>loc. cit.,</i> says: “And the mystics say that he slew the Egyptian by a word only.” This is also probably a Jewish-Hellenistic Midrash.</i> and he slew him, and buried him in the midst of the camp, as it is said, "And he smote the Egyptian, and hid him in the sand" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). The word Chôl (sand) signifies (here) Israel only, as it is said, "Yet the number of children of Israel shall be as the <i>sand</i> of the sea" (Hos. 1:10).
He went forth on the second day, and saw two Hebrew men striving. Who were they? || Dathan and Abiram, as it is said, "And he said to him that did the wrong,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Wherefore smitest thou thy fellow?" (Ex. 2:18).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Ex.Rab.,<i>loc.cit</i>.,adds: “even though thy neighbour be an evil-doer.” Dathan and Abiram are cited because they vexed Moses in the wilderness. See Num. 16:1. Our Midrash has been used by the Pal. Targum on Ex. 2:13 f., which reads thus: “And he went out (on) the second day, and looked, and behold, Dathan and Abiram, men of the (tribe of) Judah, contended; and seeing Dathan put forth his hand against Abiram to smite him, he said to him: Wherefore dost thou smite thy companion? And Dathan said to him: Who is he who hath appointed thee a chief man and a judge over us? Speakest thou to kill me as thou didst kill the Egyptian?”</i> Dathan said to him: What! Dost thou wish to kill me with the sword of thy mouth as thou didst kill the Egyptian yesterday, as it is said, "Who made thee a prince and a judge over us?<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This part of the quotation is wanting in the MS. The entire verse is given in the first editions.</i> Speakest thou<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “sayest thou,” <i>i.e.</i> by the word of thy mouth wilt thou kill me? See Midrash Agadah, Ex. pp. 125 f., n. 43.</i> to kill me, as thou killedst the Egyptian?" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). "Seekest thou to kill me" is not written (in the Scripture) here, but "Speakest thou to kill me."
When Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh, they said to him: "Thus saith the Lord,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> the God of Israel, Let my people go" (<i>ibid.</i> v. 1), that they may serve Me.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This translation agrees with the Venice edition text. The modern editions read according to the Scripture: “That they may keep a festival (offering) unto me” (<span>ויחנו לי</span>). Our translation is a paraphrase of the Bible text. See T.B. Chagigah, 6b.</i> He said: I know not the Lord. "Who is the Lord,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> that I should hearken unto his voice to let Israel go? I know not the Lord, and moreover I will not let Israel go" (<i>ibid.</i> 2).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta Beshallach, 23b.</i> Aaron cast down his rod,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Forthwith Aaron cast down his rod before Pharaoh.”</i> and it became a fiery serpent. The<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Immediately Pharaoh called the magicians.”</i> magicians also cast down their rods, and they became fiery serpents. The rod of Aaron ran and swallowed them up with their rods, as it is said, "And Aaron's rod swallowed up their rods" (<i>ibid.</i> vii. 12).
(Moses) put his hand into his bosom, and brought it forth leprous like snow, and the magicians also put their hands in their bosoms, and brought them forth leprous like snow. But they were not healed till the day of their death.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence occurs in the MS. only. Cf. Pal. Targum, Ex. 8:14.</i> Every plague which the Holy One, blessed be He, brought upon them,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “brought upon the Egyptians in Egypt, they also performed.”</i> they also produced every plague until He brought upon them the boils, and they were not able to stand and to do likewise,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 67b; Ex. Rab. ix. 6; and Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 183.</i> as it is said, "And the magicians could not<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> stand before Moses because of the boils" (<i>ibid.</i> ix. 11).
Rabbi 'Aḳiba said: The executioners<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This word is the Latin <i>speculator,</i> executioner. See Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 169, and Deut. § 826, and cf. <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 144, note 1.</i> of Pharaoh used to strangle the Israelites in the walls of the houses,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “between the layers of bricks, therefore they cried out of the walls.” The Bible text says: “The Egyptians <i>oppressed</i> the Israelites.” “To oppress” (<span>לחץ</span>) suggests to the Haggadist writer the word which occurs in the story of Balaam, Num. 22:25: “And the ass saw the angel of the Lord and she <i>thrust</i> herself unto the <i>wall,</i> and <i>crushed</i> Balaam’s foot against the <i>wall.”</i> Hence the inference that the Egyptians oppressed Israel in connection with the walls. See T.B. Synhedrin, 111a.</i> || and the Holy One, blessed be He, heard their cry, as it is said, "And God heard their groaning,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 24). Further, they burnt their children in the furnace of fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.,</i> adds: “a sacrifice to their gods; therefore, when Israel left Egypt, God executed judgment on their gods.” Cf. Jer. 11:4, where we read of the “iron <i>furnace</i>.” See also Book of Jashar lxix. 7.</i> as it is said, "But the Lord hath taken you,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> and brought you forth out of the iron <i>furnace</i>, out of Egypt" (Deut. 4:20).
When<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions insert before this word: “And the Holy One, blessed be He, measured to them by that measure (which they had used), and slew their firstborn, as it is said, ‘To him that smote Egypt in their firstborn’” (Ps. 136:10). Israel was called God’s firstborn. When God bade Pharaoh to send forth His firstborn son Israel, he refused. In return God smote his firstborn. The Jewish teaching as to the Divine method of retribution is well expressed by the Book of Wisdom xi. 16, which refers to the plagues thus: “That they might know that by what things a man sinneth, thereby he is punished.” Cf. Revelation of Peter, 7 and 9, for a parallel view of retribution. As a parallel to our text, the following verse from Wisdom xviii. 5 seems appropriate: “But them who plotted to slay the infants of the holy ones (and when a single child had been exposed and saved) Thou to convict them didst deprive of the multitude of their children, and all together didst destroy them in a mighty flood.” Jubilees xlviii. 14 says: “A thousand strong and brave men perished for one infant whom they had cast into the river.” For further illustrations see Goodrick, <i>Wisdom,</i> p. 352.</i> Israel went forth,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from Egypt.”</i> what did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He cast down all the idols of their abominations, and they were broken,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, 7b.</i> as it is said, "Upon their gods also the Lord executed judgments" (Num. 33:4).
Rabbi Joseph<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “José.”</i> said: The Egyptians defiled the Israelites and their wives with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> For another opinion see Mekhilta, 5a, and Lev. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i> Israel was redeemed because of four virtues, which included the merit of not being suspected of immorality. See also Jalḳuṭ, Lev. § 657.</i> Bedijah, the grandson of Dan, married a wife from his tribe, Shelomith, daughter of Dibri,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. 24:11, Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 125, and Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 7a.</i> and in that night the taskmasters of Pharaoh came in unto her, for they slew him and came in unto her, and she conceived and bare a son. In every case the offspring follows the (nature of) the seed:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 150, and T.B. Niddah, 31a. The reference here is to the intellect which rules one’s life.</i> if it be sweet, it will be due to the sweet (seed); if it be bitter, it will be due to the bitter (seed). And when Israel went forth from Egypt, he<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The son of Shelomith.</i> began to blaspheme and revile the Name of the God of Israel, as it is said, "And the son of the Israelitish woman blasphemed the<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> Name, and cursed" (Lev. 24:11).
Rabbi Ishmael said: The five fingers of the right hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, all of them appertain to the mystery<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Read <span>לסוד</span>, which is the reading preserved by the ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, iv. p. 439a, <i>s.v.</i> <span>חמש</span>. Later editions read: “are the foundations.” On the “hand” of God see Passover Haggadah, p. 22. See also Jalḳuṭ, Ex. § 183, and Jalḳuṭ to Micah, § 653. Cf. Orach Chayyim, 473. 28.</i> of the Redemption.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Of Israel.</i> He showed the little finger of the hand to Noah,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “The little finger, therewith He shewed the ark to Noah.” See <i>supra,</i> p. 164, n. 2.</i> (pointing out) how to make the ark, as it is said, "And <i>this</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The word “this” in the text is the basis for the Haggadic inference that God’s finger pointed out to Noah what he was to do in making the ark. Cf. Ex. 30:13.</i> is how thou shalt make it" (Gen. 6:15). With the second finger, which is next to the little one, He smote the firstborn of the Egyptians,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 93b: “The Egyptians and Sennacherib were smitten by the entire hand.” Cf. Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 78 pp. 177b f.</i> as it is said, "The magicians said unto Pharaoh, || This is the finger of God" (Ex. 8:19). With how many (plagues) were they smitten with the finger? With ten plagues.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. alone has this sentence. Cf. Passover Haggadah, pp. 21 f.</i> With the third finger, which is the third (starting from) the little finger, He wrote the tables (of the Law), as it is said, "And he gave unto Moses, when he had made an end<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. gives the first part of the verse; the latter part only is given by the first editions.</i> of communing with him… tables of stone, written with the finger of God" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxi. 18). With the fourth finger, which is next to the thumb, the Holy One, blessed be He, showed<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The half-shekel.</i> to Moses what the children of Israel should give for the redemption of their souls,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Commentary “Tosaphoth” to the Torah, p. 43b (ed. Warsaw, 1876): “With the fourth finger He showed to Moses the moon, and with the thumb He showed to him the half-shekel.”</i> as it is said, "<i>This</i> they shall give<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions end the quotation here.</i>… half a shekel for an offering to the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> xxx. 18). With the thumb and all the hand the Holy One, blessed be He, will smite in the future all the children of Esau, for they are His foes,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the foes of the children of Israel.”</i> and likewise (will He smite) the children of Ishmael, for they are His enemies, as it is said, "Let thine <i>hand</i> be lifted up above thine adversaries, and let all thine enemies be cut off" (Mic. 5:9).
Rabbi Eliezer said: The five letters of the Torah, which alone of all the letters in the Torah are of double (shape),<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> M, N, Z, P, Kh,—the five letters which have a different shape when they are the final letters in words. The reading of our MS. is supported by the text preserved in the ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, iv. p. 439b. On these letters see T.B. Sabbath, 104a; T.B. Megillah, 2b; T.J. Megillah, 1:9. 71d; and Num. Rab. 18:21.</i> all appertain to the mystery of the Redemption.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 1:11; Tanchuma, Ḳorach, § xii. The term “mystery of the redemption” might also be rendered by “the secret of the redemption.” The idea in the Midrash here seems to be that the Israelites had a tradition or secret concerning the redemption. This is brought out in the legend of Serach and Moses. The Book of Wisdom says: “That night (of redemption) was known <i>beforehand</i> to our fathers, that knowing surely on what oaths they trusted they might be cheered” (xviii. 6).</i> With "Khaph" "Khaph" our father Abraham was redeemed from Ur of the Chaldees, as it is said, (Le<i>kh</i> Le<i>kha</i>) "Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and first editions end quotation here.</i>… unto the land that I will shew thee" (Gen. 12:1). With "Mem" "Mem" our father Isaac was redeemed from the land<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “from the land of the Philistines,” as in our MS. The first editions read: “from the <i>hand</i> of the Philistines.”</i> of the Philistines, as it is said, "Go from us:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> for thou art much mightier (<i>M</i>emennu <i>M</i>'ôd) than we" (<i>ibid.</i> xxvi. 16). With "Nun" "Nun" our father Jacob was redeemed from the hand of Esau,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is also the reading of the Venice edition, and agrees with the text in the ‘Arukh, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> as it is said, "Deliver me, I pray thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> (Hazilê<i>n</i>e <i>n</i>a) from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau" (<i>ibid.</i> xxxii. 11). With "Pê" "Pê" Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “our fathers.”</i> was redeemed from Egypt, as it is said, "I have surely visited you,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and first editions end the quotation here. See Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 10b, n. 3.</i> (<i>P</i>aḳôd <i>P</i>aḳadti) and (seen) that which is done to you in Egypt, and I have said, I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt" (Ex. 3:16, 17). With "Zaddi" "Zaddi" the Holy One, blessed be He, in the future will redeem Israel from the oppression of the kingdoms,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “at the end of the four kingdoms.”</i> and He will say to them, I have caused a branch to spring forth for you, as it is said, "Behold, the man whose name is (Zemach) the Branch;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse, Jer. 23:5: “I will raise unto David a righteous Branch,” is quoted by Tanchuma, <i>loc. cit.</i> See also Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Ex. p. 7, n. 107.</i> and he shall grow up (yizmach) || out of his place,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and he shall build the temple of the Lord" (Zech. 6:12).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> For the Messianic interpretation of this verse in Philo see my <i>Hellenism and Christianity</i>, pp. 119 f.</i> These letters were delivered only to our father Abraham. Our father Abraham delivered them to Isaac, and Isaac (delivered them) to Jacob, and Jacob delivered the mystery of the Redemption to Joseph, as it is said, "But God will surely visit (<i>P</i>aḳôd yi<i>p</i>hḳôd) you" (Gen. 1. 24). Joseph his son delivered the secret of the Redemption to his brethren. Asher, the son of Jacob, delivered the mystery of the Redemption to Serach<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> see T. B. Soṭah, 13a; Gen. Rab. 94:9; Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 9:18; Derekh Erez Rab. i. See also <i>J.E.</i> xi. 200 f.</i> his daughter. When Moses and Aaron came to the elders of Israel and performed the signs in their sight, the elders of Israel went to<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “our ancestress.”</i> Serach, the daughter of Asher, and they said to her: A certain man has come, and he has performed signs in our sight, thus and thus.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “She said to them: There is no reality in those signs<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> of Moses. They said to her: Did they not say to us ‘Paḳôd Paḳadti’—‘I have surely visited you?’”<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> (Ex. 3:16).</i> She said to them: There is no reality in the signs. They said to her: He said "<i>P</i>aḳôd yi<i>p</i>hḳôd"—"God will surely visit you" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The next two sentences are written on the margin of the MS.</i> She said to them: He is the man who will redeem Israel in the future from Egypt, for thus did I hear,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “from my father, ‘ Pê Pê,’ as it is said, ‘Paḳôd Paḳadti.’”</i> ("<i>P</i>aḳôd <i>P</i>aḳadti") "I have surely visited you" (Ex. 3:16). Forthwith the people believed<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in God and in Moses.”</i> in their God and in His messenger, as it is said, "And the people believed,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and when they heard that the Lord <i>had visited</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The people believed when they heard that God had <i>visited</i> them. This was the secret or mystery of the redemption.</i> the children of Israel" (<i>ibid.</i> iv. 31).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ex. Rab. v. 19, which has used <i>P.R.E.</i> See also Midrash on 2 Sam. 20:19.</i>
Rabbi 'Aḳiba said: The taskmasters of Pharaoh were beating the Israelites in order that they should make<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “for them.”</i> the tale of bricks, and it is said, "And the tale of the bricks,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> which they did make heretofore, ye shall lay upon them" (<i>ibid.</i> v. 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “The Egyptians did not give straw to the Israelites, as it is said: ‘There is no straw given unto thy servants, and they say to us, Make brick’” (Ex. 5:16).</i> The Israelites were gathering the straw of the wilderness, and they were carrying it on their asses and (also on) their wives,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> MS. Gaster and Jalḳuṭ, Ex. §176, read: “They were treading it in the mortar, they and their wives, their sons and their daughters.” The first editions read: “they were treading it down with their asses, their wives, and their sons and their daughters.”</i> and their sons. The straw of the wilderness pierced their heels,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Ex. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and the blood was mingled<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ezek. 16:6, and Zech. 10:5.</i> with the mortar. Rachel, the granddaughter || of Shuthelach,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. 26:36. Shuthelach was of the tribe of Ephraim.</i> was near childbirth, and with her husband she was treading the mortar, and the child was born (there) and became entangled in the brick mould.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum to Ex. 24:10.</i> Her cry ascended before the Throne of Glory.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Ex. <i>loc. cit.,</i> which has used <i>P.R.E.</i></i> The angel Michael<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> In Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.,</i> Gabriel is the angel.</i> descended and took the brick mould with its clay, and brought it up before the Throne of Glory.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pal. Targum, <i>loc. cit.,</i> which reads: “A memorial of the bondage wherein the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve in clay and bricks, (when) there were women treading the mortar with their husbands. The delicate young woman with child was also there and made abortive by being crushed with the mortar. And thereof did Gabriel, descending, make brick, and ascending to the heavens on high, set it (as) a footstool under the throne of the Lord of the world.” Cf. 3 Baruch iii. 5 for a parallel.</i> That night the Holy One, blessed be He, descended,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “was revealed, and smote all the firstborn.”</i> and smote the firstborn of the Egyptians, as it is said, "And it came to pass at midnight<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> that the Lord smote all the firstborn in the land of Egypt" (<i>ibid.</i> xii. 29).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here the paragraph beginning, “The Holy One.”</i>
Rabbi José<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Jehudah.”</i> said: All that night the Israelites were eating and drinking, rejoicing and taking wine and praising<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Sec Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 113 p. 235a, and cf. T.B. Pesachim, 95b.</i> their God with a loud voice,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 105:43.</i> whilst the Egyptians were crying with a bitter soul,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Isa. 65:14 for the expression; see also Ezek. 27:30.</i> because of the plague<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The slaying of the firstborn.</i> which came upon them suddenly,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Job 34:20.</i> as it is said, "And there was a great cry in Egypt;<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits the first part of the quotation.</i> for there was not a house where there was not one dead" (<i>ibid.</i> 80).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said: If I bring forth the Israelites by night, they<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The Egyptians will say: Now hath He done His deeds according to the way of thieves.” See Midrash Agadah, Ex. p. 142.</i> will say, He has done His deeds like a thief.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Book of Jashar lxxx. 60 and cf. T.B. Berakhoth, 9a.</i> Therefore, behold, I will bring them forth when the sun is in his zenith at midday.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> This day was also the middle of the month, at the time of full moon. The time of the deliverance was believed to be appointed at that time in order to show the Egyptians that their gods, including the heavenly host, were powerless and unable to save them. The first editions add here: “as it is said, ‘And it came to pass the <i>selfsame</i><sup></sup> day, that the Lord did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their hosts’” (Ex. 12:51).</i>
By the merit of three things<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, Bô, v. p. 5a; Lev. Rab. 32:5; Cant. Rab. on Cant. 4:12, Leḳach Ṭob, Ex. p. 16a, note 10.</i> Israel went forth from Egypt: (1) They did not change their language; (2) they did not change their names;<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mekhilta, Bô, <i>loc. cit.</i> The first editions omit this clause.</i> (3) and they did not slander one another. In the unity of (God's) Name Israel went forth from Egypt full of all good things, comprising (all) blessings,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 328.</i> because He remembered the word which He spake to our father Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 105:42: “For he remembered his holy word, and Abraham his servant.”</i> as it is said, "And also that nation, whom they shall serve,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> will I judge, and afterwards shall they come out with great substance" (Gen. 15:14).

Chapter 49

CHAPTER XLIX<br><small>THE SEED OF AMALEK</small> [69<small>B</small>. i.]<br>|| R<small>ABBI</small> S<small>IMEON</small>, son of Jochai, said: The Holy One, blessed be He, wished to destroy and to cut off all the seed of Amalek.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 346.</i> He sent to Saul, the son of Kish, to destroy and to cut off all the seed of Amalek. Saul and the people heard, and did not spare any vile man except Agag, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse reads: “But Saul and the people spared Agag, and the best of the sheep, and of the oxen, and of the fatlings, and the lambs, and all that was good, and would not utterly destroy them.”</i> "But Saul and the people spared<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Agag, and the best of the sheep, and of the oxen" (1 Sam. 15:9). Samuel heard (thereof), and he went to meet them, and he said to them: Ye have spared Amalek, and ye have left over a remnant of him.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. Rab. 25:8 and xxvi. 7.</i> They said to him: The sheep and the oxen are for sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 24b.</i> unto thy God. (Samuel) said to (Saul): The Omnipresent hath no delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, but only in obeying His voice and in doing His will, as it is said, "And Samuel said, Hath the Lord as great delight<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the Lord? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to hearken than the fat of rams" (<i>ibid.</i> 22).
Rabbi Phineas said: The Holy One, blessed be He, saw that in the future there would arise from Agag a man, a great enemy and adversary of the Jews.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 384; Ex. Rab. xxxviii. 4; T.B. Megillah, 12a and 19a; and cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 399.</i> Who was this? This was Haman, as it is said, "Because Haman, the son of Hammedatha,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> the <i>Agagite</i>, the enemy of all the Jews" (Esth. 9:24). From the seed of Saul (arose) an avenger and a redeemer for Israel, (who delivered them) out of the hand of Haman. Who was this? This was Mordecai, as it is said, "There was a certain Jew<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> in Shushan, the capital, whose name was Mordecai… the son of Kish, a Benjamite" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 5).
And there stood Samuel before the Holy One, blessed be He, and he said: Sovereign of all the Universe ! Do not forget the sin<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “The sorrow which the wicked Esau caused his father.”</i> which Esau did to his father, || for he took strange women (for his wives), who offered sacrifices and burnt incense to idols, to embitter the years of the life of his parents.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add: “as it is said, ‘and they were a bitterness of spirit unto Isaac and unto Rebecca’” (Gen. 26:35). The Book of Jubilees offers a parallel here; see ch. xxvii. 7 ff. and ch. xxv. 1, which reads: “My son, do not take thee a wife of the daughters of Canaan, as Esau, thy brother, who took him two wives of the daughters of Caanan, and they have embittered my soul with all their unclean deeds: for all their deeds are fornication and lust, and there is no righteousness with them, for (their deeds) are evil.”</i> Remember his sin unto his sons and unto his grandsons unto the end of all generations, as it is said, "Let the iniquity of his fathers be remembered<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> with the Lord" (Ps. 109:14). Samuel heard the voice of Agag muttering with his mouth, saying: Perhaps the bitterness of the evil death has passed from me, as it is said, "And Agag said, Surely the bitterness of death is past" (1 Sam. 15:32). Samuel said to him:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “Just as thy sword made women childless, so shall thy mother be childless among women.”</i> Just as the sword of Amalek thy ancestor consumed the young men of Israel who were outside the cloud,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 346.</i> so that their women dwelt (as) childless women and widows,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition adds: “so shall thy mother be childless.” MS. Gaster omits the rest of the paragraph, except the quotation.</i> so by the prayer of the women<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This idea is due to the Midrashic interpretation of the words in 1 Sam. 15:33, <i>i.e. “by women</i> (Esther and her maidens) shall thy mother be made childless.”</i> all the sons<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “every son.” The Prague edition has “every male.”</i> of Amalek shall be slain, and their women shall dwell (as) childless women and widows. And by the prayer of Esther and her maidens all the sons of Amalek were slain and their women remained childless and widowed, as it is said, "And Samuel said, As thy sword hath made women childless,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> so shall thy mother be childless among women" (<i>ibid.</i> 33).
The prayer of Samuel destroyed<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “diminished” (<span>חםר</span>).</i> the power of the children of Agag against Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in Gilgal.” MS. Gaster reads “Amalek” instead of “Agag.”</i> as it is said, "And Samuel broke<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> destroyed the power of Amalek. The Targum renders <span>וימסף</span> by <span>ופשח</span> (cf. Targum to Ps. 7:3): “and he flayed”; see also 2 Chron. 14:13: “for they were broken before the Lord.” In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Agag before the Lord in Gilgal" (<i>ibid.</i>).
The Holy One, blessed be He, said: He has made his attack against the heavenly beings,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Everyone who acts with the pride of the mighty.” See Gen. Rab. 10:7. The point here is that Haman’s pride was punished by the hand of a woman. On God’s ways with man, see Num. Rab. 18:19 (on Num. 16:35).</i> (and God) will send against them insignificant things, to teach them that the power of their might is nought. When Titus,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lam. 4:12 with Midrash Rab. thereon. See Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) vii. p. 11a; T.B. Giṭṭin, 56b; and cf. <i>J.E.</i> xii. p. 164a.</i> the wicked, entered the Holy of Holies, he said: No adversary || or enemy can prevail against me. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do to him? He sent a single gnat,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “against him.”</i> and it went into his nostril, and it ate its way into his brain. That gnat became like a young pigeon, weighing two pounds,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>לימרין</span> (<i>λίτρα</i>), <i>litra</i>; the Roman libra or pound weight.</i> to teach him that there was nothing at all in the might of his power. When Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Represented by the High Priest.</i> walked in the Holy of Holies with a proud heart, and said: No adversary or enemy<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lam., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> is able to stand before us. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do to them? He sent against them a man, proud and like one sifting the sea, Nebuchadnezzar, whose name was Kabbīr Mayim (like one sifting the sea),<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 31 p. 158; Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 137 p. 262b; and Pesiḳta Rabbathi, p. 144a. The first editions read: “He sent against them Nebuchadnezzar the wicked, who was a very proud enemy against them.” Kabbīr Mayim might mean “the mighty one of the waters.” According to Kebra Nagast (G.T.), p. 79, Nebuchadnezzar was the one who “escaped from the water” at his birth; cf. Ex. 2:10.</i> to teach; "For by strength shall no man prevail" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 9).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ezek. 7:20: “As for the beauty of his ornament, he turned it to pride”; see also <i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 21. On Nebuchadnezzar, see <i>J.E.</i> ix. pp. 201 ff.</i>
Rabbi Chakhinai<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition and Brode’s edition read: “Chaninah.”</i> said: The Holy One, blessed be He, set<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “and to the kingdom of Babylon. Whence do we know this about the Egyptian bondage?”</i> no limit to the kingdoms, except to the Egyptian bondage,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. T.B. Joma, 9a and 9b.</i> and to the kingdom of Babylon. Whence do we know this about the Egyptian bondage? Because it is said, "And they shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years" (Gen. 15:13). The Holy One, blessed be He, dealt according to the abundance of His tender mercy,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and according to His abounding love.” As Isa. 63:7 says: “I will make mention of the loving-kindnesses of the Lord, and the praises of the Lord, according to all that the Lord hath bestowed upon us; and the great goodness toward the house of Israel, which he hath bestowed on them according to his mercies, and according to the multitude of his loving-kindnesses.”</i> and He shortened (this time limit) by its half,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in the number of ‘Rdu’ 210 years.”</i> 210 years.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>supra,</i> p. 376.</i> Whence do we know about the Babylonian kingdom? Because it is said, "For thus saith the Lord,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. and the first editions omit this part of the verse; the MS. reads: “After seventy years be accomplished”; the first editions add “for Babylon.”</i> After seventy years be accomplished for Babylon, I will visit you, and perform my good word toward you, in causing you to return to this place" (Jer. 29:10).
Rabbi Abbahu said: Forty-five years did Nebuchadnezzar reign. Know that it is so. In the year<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria’s emendation reads: “In the second year.”</i> when he began to reign, he went up to Jerusalem, and conquered Jehoiakim, king of Judah, as it is said, "In the third year of the reign of || Jehoiakim, king of Judah,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> came Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, unto Jerusalem, and besieged it" (Dan. 1:1). For eight years he ruled over the kingdom of Jehoiakim, and eleven years Zedekiah ruled.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “he ruled over the kingdom of Zedekiah.”</i> (Behold,) nineteen years before he destroyed the Temple. (Thereafter he ruled) twenty-six years.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Behold nineteen years (elapsed) before the Temple was destroyed.” The Venice edition and MS. Gaster add: “After the Temple had been destroyed (he reigned) twenty-six years.” This is omitted in the 1st ed. See T.B. Megillah, 11b, and Rashi, who quotes Seder ‘Olam Rab.</i> Know that it is so. Come and see from the exile of Jehoiachin until his son Evil-Merodach<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Son of Nebuchadnezzar.</i> reigned thirty-seven<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Deduct from these thirty-seven years the eleven years of Zedekiah’s reign prior to the destruction of Jerusalem, and we have twenty-six years, mentioned in our book.</i> years elapsed, as it is said, "And it came to pass in the seven and thirtieth year of the captivity of Jehoiachin,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the seven and twentieth day of the month, that Evil-Merodach, king of Babylon, in the year that he began to reign, did lift up the head of Jehoiachin, king of Judah, out of prison" (2 Kings 25:27).
Rabbi Jonathan said: The last of the kings of Media<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and Persia.”</i> was Artaxerxes,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> He is apparently identified by R. Tachanah in the next paragraph of our book with the “fourth king” of Dan. 11:2.</i> king of Babylon, and he reigned thirty-two years, as it is said, "But in all this time I was not in Jerusalem;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> for in the two and thirtieth year of Artaxerxes, king of Babylon, I went unto the king" (Neh. 13:6).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Seder ‘Olam Rab. 28 p. 65a and xxx. p. 68b, note 10. According to some Jewish traditions (see T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 4a) Artaxerxes 11. is Darius 11., who sanctioned the rebuilding of the Temple. This king appears to have reigned thirty-six years; see Esth. Rab. 8:3, and Lev. Rab. 13:5. See also <i>J.E.</i> iv. p. 442, and cf. Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> xi. 6. 1.</i>
Rabbi Tachanah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “Tanchum.” See <i>supra,</i> p. 308.</i> said: Come and see how wealthy Ahasuerus was, for he was wealthier than all the kings of Media and Persia, and concerning him the Scripture saith, "And the fourth shall be far richer than they all" (Dan. 11:2). What was the wealth of Ahasuerus? He erected couches of gold and silver in the streets<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This is the paraphrase of Esth. 1:5: “in the court of the garden of the king’s palace.”</i> of the city, to show all the peoples<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to let all the world know.”</i> how rich he was, as it is said, "The couches were of gold and silver" (Esth. 1:6). All the vessels used by Ahasuerus were not vessels of silver, but vessels of gold.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 1 Kings 10:21, and Assumption of Moses iii. 2.</i> He brought the vessels of the Temple, and all the vessels of his palace were changed in appearance,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Because they became dim in splendour when brought together with the beautiful sacred vessels of the Temple. This constituted the diversity referred to in the text (Esth. 1:7); see Targum 1. thereon, which is probably the source of <i>P.R.E.’s</i> version.</i> so that they became like lead, as it is said, "The vessels being <i>diverse</i> one from another" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).
All the pavement of his palace consisted of precious stones and pearls, || as it is said, "Upon a pavement of porphyry, and white marble,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and alabaster, and <i>stone</i> of blue colour" (<i>ibid.</i> 6).
Rabbi Eliezer said: For half the year Ahasuerus made great banquets for all the peoples, as it is said, "Many days, even an hundred and eighty days" (<i>ibid.</i> 4). Every people<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Everyone.”</i> who ate its food in impurity,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> this food lacked the characteristics which marked the levitically pure food.</i> had its food provided in impurity, and every people who ate its food in purity<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Jewish Law determines the kind of food which may be eaten by its adherents. Such food is pure. The expression used here in our author, “Every people who ate its food in purity,” points to priestly regulations and conditions. The subject has been dealt with exhaustively by Dr. Büchler in his <i>Der Galiläische ‘Am-ha ‘Areṣ des Zweiten Jahrhunderts</i>.</i> had its food provided (according to the regulations of) purity,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions reverse the order of the clauses.</i> as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to fulfil that which is written.”</i> "That they should do according to every man's pleasure" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Esth. Rab., <i>in loc.</i>; Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1056; T.B. Megillah, 12a; and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1048.</i>
Rabbi José<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Simeon.”</i> said: It was the universal custom of the kings of Media<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Although Ahasuerus was the king of Persia he was apparently a Mede by race. On the morals of the Medes see T.B. Berakhoth, 8b.</i> when they were eating and drinking to cause their women to come before them stark naked, playing and dancing, in order to see the beauty of their figures. When the wine entered the heart of Ahasuerus, he wished to act in this manner<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> For other instances of the evil effect of too much wine see Gen. 9:21, and <i>supra,</i> p. 170; see also Hos. 4:11, and cf. T.B. Soṭah, 7a.</i> with Vashti the queen. She was the daughter of a king,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Belteshazzar; see T.B. Megillah, 9b, and Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1050.</i> and she was not willing to do this.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “that she should come naked before him,” and then add: “She sent to him saying: Foolish drunkard ! If I come they may see that I am ugly, (then) they will despise thee at thy table; and if they see that I am beautiful, one of thy princes will kill thee<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> in the hour of (his taking) wine. The king heard her words and commanded that she should be slain.”</i> He decreed concerning her, and she was slain. When the wine had passed from the heart of Ahasuerus, he sought after Vashti, but he did not find her. They told him of the deed which had been done,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “His princes told him of the decree which he had ordained against her.”</i> and (also) of the decree which had been ordained concerning her. Why was the decree passed against her? Because she used to make the daughters of Israel come<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “naked.”</i> and toil for her on Sabbaths, therefore was the decree ordained against her that she should be slain naked on the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the first editions the words “on the Sabbath” follow the words “ordained against her.”</i> as it is said, "He remembered Vashti,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions. On the theme see Esth. Rab., <i>in loc.,</i> and Targum 1. to Esth. 2:1.</i> and <i>what she had done</i>, and what was decreed against her" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 1).
Rabbi Zechariah said: || Merit is transmitted by the hand of the worthy. By the hand of Daniel<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster add: “who was Memucan.” See the Targum 11. to Esth. 1:16, and cf. Esth. Rab. 4:2 and 6. The latter does not, however, identify Memucan with Daniel. In Targum 1. to Esth. 1:16 he is compared with Haman; cf. T.B. Megillah, 12b. <i>P.R.E.</i> is the source used by Targum 11. in identifying Memucan with Daniel. Memucan means the “establisher.”</i> the sovereignty was transferred to Esther, because he said to the king, Let not the king weep, since all that thou hast done<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “to Vashti.”</i> thou hast done according to the Torah. And whosoever keeps the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the precepts of the Torah.” See Ezra 6:11, 12 for a parallel to the expression in our text.</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, preserves his kingdom; for thus the Torah says that the man shall rule his wife, as it is said, "And he shall rule over thee"<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> This was said to the first woman, and is one of the nine afflictions imposed upon womankind. See <i>supra,</i> p. 100.</i> (Gen. 3:16). The king sent in all the provinces to do according to his words,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the words of Memucan.”</i> as it is said, "That every man should<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> bear rule in his own house" (Esth. 1:22). He also said to the king: "Let there be sought for the king<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> fair young virgins" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 2). Not<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “Young virgins” and not “all young virgins.”</i> "all young virgins," but "fair young virgins."<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said.”</i> "And let the maiden which pleaseth<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> the king be queen instead of Vashti" (<i>ibid.</i> 4); and it is written elsewhere, "And the maiden pleased him" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). This refers to Esther. The Holy One, blessed be He, invested her with grace and love<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Targum 11. to Esth. 2:17: “and she was rewarded by (the king) with more grace and favour than all the virgins.”</i> in the eyes of all who saw her.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said.”</i> "And Esther obtained favour<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> in the sight of all them that looked upon her" (<i>ibid.</i> 15 ).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. adds: “for the sake of the merit that was to be (accomplished) at her hands.”</i>

Chapter 50

CHAPTER L<br><small>HAMAN</small> [70<small>B</small>. ii.]<br>"T<small>HERE</small> was a certain Jew in Shushan, the capital,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> whose name was Mordecai" (Esth. 2:5). Rabbi Shema'iah said: Was there then no other Jew in Shushan, the capital, except Mordecai alone? Lo! it is written, "And the Jews that were in Shushan" (<i>ibid.</i> ix. 15). But because he was a Jew,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a righteous Jew.”</i> and a direct descendant of the patriarchs and also of the royal seed, and he was engaged in (the study of) the Torah all his days, and he was not defiled by any forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “anything of unclean food did not pass into his mouth.” See <i>supra,</i> p. 393. note 6.</i> food in his mouth, therefore was his name called "a Jew."<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a certain Jew.” Cf. Ps. 60:7 and Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1052 (end). See also T.B. Megillah, 12b.</i>
"Whose name was Mordecai" (<i>ibid.</i> ii. 5), because his prayer || ascended before the Holy One, blessed be He, like the scent of <i>pure myrrh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> A play on the word Mordecai; see Targum 11. to Esth. 2:5. T.B. Chullin, 139b. translates the words <span>מר דדוד</span> of Ex. 30:23 by <span>מירא דכיא</span>, clear (liquid) myrrh; cf. T.B. Megillah, 10b. Prayer is compared with incense; see Ps. 141:2.</i> (טר לכי). "The son of Jair" (<i>ibid.</i>), because he enlightened (<i>Mair</i>) the faces (of the scholars) in Halakhah.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> As a member of the Synhedrion, he brought light to Israel in the hour of darkness; sec Esth. 8:16: “The Jews had light and joy.”</i> "The son of Shimei" (<i>ibid.</i>), who went forth to curse David.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Shimei was of the royal house of Saul, and therefore Mordecai as his descendant belonged also to the royal house. See Targum 11. to Esth.. <i>loc. cit.</i></i> "The son of Kish" (<i>ibid.</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Because he knocked (<i>shêhiḳḳish</i>) upon the doors of mercy and they were opened unto him.” See Sheḳalim v. 1: “Petachiah is Mordecai, because God opened to him the gates of prayer.”</i> of the seed of those who could use both the right hand and the left,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> For phraseology see 1 Chron. 12:2.</i> as it is said, "The children of Ephraim, being armed and carrying bows" (Ps. 78:9).
Rabbi Simeon said: Come and see the wisdom of Mordecai, for he knew seventy languages,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and his name was Mordecai Bilshan.”</i> as it is said, "Which came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i>… Mordecai, Bilshan"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Menachoth, 65a; T.B. Megillah, 13b. Bilshan (=“linguist”) is mentioned in this verse (Ezra 2:2) as a separate person.</i> (Ezra 2:2), and he sat in the gates of the king to see that Esther and her maidens should not become defiled by any kind of unclean<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> food. He heard the two eunuchs of the king speaking in the language of the Chaldees,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> According to T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> the language was that of Tarsus (<span>מורסיים</span>).</i> saying:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “one to the other.”</i> Now will the king take the afternoon sleep, and when he arises<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and when he gets up from his sleep he will say to us.”</i> he will say, Give me a little water; let a deadly poison<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Targum 11. to Esth. 2:21 speaks of “a poisonous snake in the golden cup” out of which Ahasuerus would drink.</i> be given to him in the golden vessel,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads “Ḳesibath.” The first editions read “Ḳitôn” (jug); see <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics,</i> p. 24. See also Targum 11. to Esth., <i>loc. cit.</i>: “Keepers of the <i>vessels</i>.” See also Zech. 12:2 for the word <span>סף</span>.</i> and he will drink thereof and die. Mordecai<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “heard their speech.”</i> went in and told Esther. Now Esther told the king in the name of Mordecai, as it is said, "And Esther told the king in Mordecai's name" (Esth. 2:22). Hence (the Wise Men) have said: Whosoever tells a matter in the name of its author brings redemption into the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth 6:6, T.B. Chullin, 104b, and T.B. Megillah, 15a.</i>
When the king arose from his sleep, he said to his servants, his eunuchs, who were wont to give him something to drink: Give me a little water. They brought him the golden jug, and a deadly poison || was therein. He said to them: Pour out the water before me. They said to him: O our lord, O king, this water is excellent, good, even choice. Why should we pour it out before thee? He said to them: Thus have I resolved to have it poured out before me. They poured it out before him, and he found therein the deadly poison,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 13b, according to which there was a serpent in the king’s cup. See also Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1053, quoting Abba Gorion.</i> and he commanded that they should be hanged, as it is said, "They were both hanged on a tree" (<i>ibid.</i> 23). They were both hanged on one tree, one after the other,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence occurs in our MS. only.</i> as it is said, "Upon a tree" (<i>ibid.</i>); it is not written, "Upon trees." All affairs which were enacted before the king they wrote before him, and they placed it in the king's box,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads “Achmetha” (pot or vessel); see Targum 1. to Esth. 1:4. The word in the first editions and in Luria’s edition should probably be “G’loosḳoma” (<i>γλωσσóκομον</i>), which occurs in the LXX to 2 Chron. 24:8, meaning case, chest, or coffin.</i> and when the king wished to discover what had happened to him they read the documents, and he knew what had happened to him. So they wrote in the book the word which Mordecai had told, as it is said, "And it was written in the book of the chronicles" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Phineas said: Two wealthy men arose in the world, one in Israel and one among the nations of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “And their wealth brought them only trouble,” says Esth. Rab. 7:4; see T.B. Pesachim, 119a; Ex. Rab. xxxi. 3; and Eccles. Rab. to Eccles. 5:12.</i> Korah in Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “for he found the treasures of gold belonging to Joseph.” Esth. Rab., <i>loc. cit.,</i> says: “treasures of silver and gold which Joseph hid”; see T.B. Pesachim, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> and Haman among the nations of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> “In Shushan” is inserted by the later editions instead of “among the nations of the world.” This is due to the censor.</i> who took the treasures of the kings of Judah.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and all the treasures of the Holy of Holies.” Haman was supposed by the Haggadist to have been in the army of Nebuchadnezzar at the capture of Jerusalem, and to have appropriated the treasures of the palace and Temple. Cf. Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 22 p. 99a and on Ps. 78 p. 173b.</i> (When) the king<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Ahasuerus.</i> saw his wealth and his ten sons<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the text should read “the wealth of his sons,” cf. <i>infra,</i> p. 408. See Esth. Rab., <i>loc. cit.,</i> which adds, after the word “sons”: “who were princes before him; he arose and exalted him and he aggrandized him.”</i> keeping guard before him, he exalted him, and aggrandized him, as it is said, "After || these things did king Ahasuerus promote<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Haman, the son of Hammedatha" (<i>ibid.</i> iii. 1). The king commanded concerning him that all the people should bow down and show reverence to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to Haman.”</i> What did Haman do? He made for himself an image of an idol, and had it embroidered upon his dress, above his heart, so that everyone who bowed down to Haman also bowed down to the idol which he had made. Mordecai<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria suggests another reading: “(Haman) saw that Mordecai did not consent to bow down and to prostrate himself before him, and he became full of wrath.”</i> saw this, and did not consent to bow down to the idol,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to his abomination.” See Jeraḥmeel, lxxix. 1.</i> as it is said, "But Mordecai bowed not down, nor did him reverence" (<i>ibid.</i> 2); and (Haman) was full of wrath against him, and said: These Jews hated my forefathers from of old, and now will I say to the king that he should destroy them from the world. Haman entered before Ahasuerus, and said to him: O my lord, O king, "There is a certain people scattered abroad and dispersed among the peoples<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> in all the provinces of thy kingdom" (<i>ibid.</i> 8), and they are of no benefit to thee and do not obey thee, and they do not perform thy will, and it is not for the king's profit to suffer them. If it please the king, accept half of my wealth and give me power<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “permission,” or “control.”</i> over them, as it is said, "If it please the king, let it be written that they be destroyed" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). (The king) said to him: Behold, they are given into thy hand for nought, as it is said, "And the king said to Haman, The silver is given to thee, the people also" (<i>ibid.</i> 11). The Holy Spirit cried out, saying: "Thus saith the Lord, Ye were sold for nought,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> || and ye shall be redeemed without money" (Isa. 52:3).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The two previous quotations are not given by the first editions.</i>
Rabbi José said: Haman was an astrologer,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a great astrologer.” The Targum 11. to Esth. 3:7 gives the reasons why the various days of the week and the months (except Adar) were unpropitious for Haman.</i> and he wrote letters on slips,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>פתקין</span>, slips; see above, p. 362, note 4.</i> and cast lots by the constellations to know the distinction between one day and another, and between one month and another, and between one constellation and another, as it is said, "They cast Pur, that is, the lot,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued up to “Haman” in the first editions.</i> before Haman from day to day, and from month to month" (Esth. 3:7). He wrote and sent throughout all the provinces to destroy and to slay and to exterminate all the Jews<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “both young and old, little children and women.”</i> on the thirteenth day of<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the twelfth month which is.”</i> the month Adar, on the third day in the constellation Leo.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The constellation of Adar is Pisces; see <i>supra,</i> p. 33. as to the constellations. It is Tuesday which is said to be connected with the constellation Leo. See T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Esth. Rab. 7:11. On the subject of the horoscope see Cassel’s <i>Esther,</i> pp. 104 f. This book contains an English version of the Second Targum.</i> Mordecai heard (thereof), and rent his garments,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> On the custom of rending the garments see T.B. Mo’ed Ḳaṭan, 26a. The MS. adds here “etc.”</i> and put on sackcloth with ashes, and he went forth into the midst of the city, as it is said, "And Mordecai knew all that was done" (<i>ibid.</i> iv. 1); and he cried before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all the worlds ! Thou didst swear to our fore-fathers to multiply their seed like the stars of the heaven, and now hast Thou given them like sheep to the slaughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra,</i> p. 357. On the Prayer of Mordecai cf. the prayer in the Apocrypha and in the Targum 11.; see T.B. Megillah, 11a; and cf. Siphra, p. 112b.</i> "Remember Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> Isaac, and Israel… to whom thou swarest… I will multiply your seed as the stars of heaven" (Ex. 32:13). Esther heard (thereof), and her strength failed, as it is said, "And the queen was exceedingly enfeebled"<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. renders: “grieved.” For the meaning of <span>חלחלה</span> as “weakness” see Isa. 21:3 and Nahum 2:11 (Heb.).</i> (Esth. 4:4). She sent and called for Hathach, the trusty (servant) of her household, to know what had been done<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> What sin had brought about this dire misfortune. See T.B. Megillah, 15a.</i> to Mordecai. Hathach went forth to Mordecai, who told him the words.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the decree against the Jews.</i> (Hathach) went in and told Esther. Haman saw Hathach coming and returning, and he slew him,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The text in Esther (4:12) says: “and <i>they</i> told Mordecai”; see Targum 1. thereon; Jalḳuṭ, Esther, §1056; and cf. T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> which identifies Hathach with Daniel. Targum 11. to Esth. 4:11 says: “And because Hathach was a messenger between Esther and Mordecai, Haman was very wroth against him and killed him. The words of Esther were then reported by writing to Mordecai.”</i> and Esther did not find another man faithful enough to send to Mordecai. She said that it was her || desire to return answer to Mordecai.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “She said that she would go to Mordecai, as it is said, ‘And Esther <i>spake</i> to return answer unto Mordecai’” (Esth. 4:15). This was her intention. See Jalḳuṭ, Esther, <i>loc. cit.</i>: “The Holy Spirit carried her message to Mordecai.”</i> <i>She</i> said to him, "Go, gather together all the Jews<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> that are present in Shushan, and fast ye for me, and neither eat nor drink three days" (<i>ibid.</i> 16). These (days) were the thirteenth, the fourteenth, and the fifteenth of Nisan.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Jebamoth, 121b; T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.</i>; Seder ‘Olam Rab. 29 p. 66b; Lev. Rab. 28:4; Pesiḳta, 71b. The first banquet was on the 16th of Nisan, and the second on the following day.</i> Mordecai said to her: Is not the third day<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the 15th of Nisan.</i> (of the fast) the day of Passover? She said to him: Thou art the elder in Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Thou art the head of the Synhedrion and thou sayest this word ! If there be no Israel, for whom is the Passover?” The “word” refers to Mordecai’s objection to fast on the Passover. The rule was not to fast on Sabbath or festival. The only exception was the Day of Atonement on a Sabbath, when the fast was duly kept thereon. See Shulchan ‘Arukh i. 288 (8).</i> If there be no Israel, wherefore is the Passover? Mordecai hearkened to her words, and he<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and he did all that she commanded, as it is said.”</i> agreed with her. "So Mordecai transgressed"<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>ויעבר</span> (Esth. 4:17). R.V. renders: “And he went his way.” The word <span>עבירה</span>, “transgression,” is from the same root as the verb <span>ויעבר</span>; see Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 1 p. 3.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 17). What is the meaning of the expression, "So he transgressed"? That he transgressed the festivals and Sabbaths.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Teaching that he transgressed the law of the first day of Passover, by not eating” the unleavened bread, as prescribed by the Torah (Ex. 13:6).</i> On the third day (of the fast) Esther put on the royal apparel, and sent and invited the king and Haman to the banquet which she had prepared on the fifteenth of Nisan.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Should we read “on the 16th of Nisan”? The printed texts as well as the MS. read “on the 15th.” This would mean that Esther had prepared the banquet on the first day of Passover, and that the king dined with her on the evening of that day, which was the 16th day of Nisan at night.</i> When they had eaten and drunk, Haman said:<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in his heart.”</i> The king exalts me, and his wife aggrandizes me, and there is none greater than I am in all the kingdoms; and Haman rejoiced very much in his heart, as it is said, "Then went Haman forth that day, joyful<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and glad of heart" (<i>ibid.</i> v. 9).
"On that night the king's sleep fled" (<i>ibid.</i> vi. 1). That night the throne<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the sleep.”</i> of the King who is King of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, became unsteady,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “fled.”</i> because He saw that Israel was in great distress. The sleep of the king<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, 15b, which reads: “the sleep of the king of the world.” There is no reference to the sleep of God in our MS.; this agrees with the Targum 11. on Esth. 6:1; cf. Esth. Rab. 10:1, and Jeraḥmeel lxxxiii. 1.</i> on earth fled, for he had seen in his dream Haman taking the sword to slay him;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Ahasuerus.</i> || and he became agitated and arose from his sleep,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Targum 11. on Esth., <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “(God) commanded the angel, who is in charge of confusion, to confound Ahasuerus and to deprive him of sleep.” See Eccles. Rab. 5 on Eccles. 5:3, and Jalḳuṭ, Esther, § 1057.</i> and he told the sons of Haman, the scribes,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The ‘Arukh, ed. Kohut, v. p. 385a, <i>s.v.</i> <span>נקראין</span>, quotes <i>P.R.E.</i>: “They were the readers of the books of the king.” See also Esth. Rab., <i>loc. cit.,</i> which has used our book.</i> to read in the books so as to see what had happened to him. They opened the books, and found the incident which Mordecai had told,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “concerning Bigthan and Teresh.” See Esth. 2:21–23; cf. T.B. Megillah, 15a.</i> but they did not wish to read this, and they rolled up the scrolls. The king said to them: Read ye what is written before you. But they were unwilling to read, and the writing was read (of its own account)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> By a miracle. The Targum 11., <i>loc. cit.,</i> says: “When Shimshê the scribe saw what was told concerning Mordecai in the affair of Bigthan and Teresh, he turned over the leaves and did not want to read them. But it was the will of the Lord of the world that the leaves should open and <i>read of themselves</i> the record written on them.” This passage illustrates how this Targum has used <i>P.R.E.</i></i> by itself, as it is said, "And they were read before the king" (<i>ibid.</i>). It is not written here, "They were reading," but "They were read."<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Esth., <i>loc. cit.,</i> adds: “Do not be surprised, because the reading was due to the (power of) the lot (<span>נורל</span>); for the script had flown away from the various narratives and came to the lap of the king.”</i> The king spake to his servants: Call ye Haman to me. They said to him: Behold, he is standing outside. The king said: The thing is true which I saw in my dream;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Eccles. Rab., <i>loc. cit.</i>; the Targumim on Esther, <i>in loc.</i>; I.C.C. Esther, p. 244, and Gelbhaus, <i>Das Targum Scheni zum Buche Esther</i>, for Midrashic parallels.</i> he has come only in this hour to slay me. He said: Let him come in. He entered before the king. The king said to him: I wish to exalt and aggrandize a certain man; what shall be done to him? Haman said in his heart, for the seed of Esau<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “All the seed of Amalek.” See T.B. Megillah, 7a, which infers that the Book of Esther was inspired, as otherwise we could not know what Haman thought in his heart.</i> speak in their hearts, but never reveal their secret with their mouths, as it is said, "And Haman said in his heart" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). Haman said in his heart: He does not desire to exalt any other man except me.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “To whom should the king desire to do honour more than to me.”</i> I will speak words so that I shall be a king just as he is. He said to him: Let<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the previous sentence and read here: “My lord, O king! if thou desirest to do honour to the man in whom thou takest delight.”</i> them bring the apparel || which the king wore on the day of the coronation,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum 11. on Esth. 6:7 for the dream and its fulfilment by Haman’s words. Targum 1. on Esth. 6:8 adds: “on the day of his accession to the throne.”</i> and (let them bring) the horse upon which the king rode on the coronation day, and the crown which was put upon the head of the king on the day of coronation.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This is probably due to the text: “And the royal crown which is set upon his head” (Esth. 6:8).</i> The king was exceedingly angry because of the crown.
