The king said: It does not suffice this villain, but he must even desire the crown which is upon my head.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “if so, what hast thou left me?”</i> Haman saw that the king was angry because of the crown; he said: "And let the apparel and the horse be delivered<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> to the hand of one of the king's most noble princes" (<i>ibid.</i> 9).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> No reference is now made to the crown.</i> (The king) said to him: Go, and do thus to Mordecai.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “the Jew, who sitteth at the king’s gate.”</i> As soon as Haman heard this he became greatly agitated,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “he became confused and agitated.” See Targum 11. on Esth. 6:10: “When Haman heard these words he was in great trouble, his countenance was changed, his sight became dim, his mouth became distorted, his thoughts confused, his loins languid, and his knees beat one against the other.”</i> and he said to him: My lord, O king! There are very many named Mordecai. The king answered: "The Jew." (Haman) said to him: There are very many Jews.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “who are named Mordecai.”</i> The king said to him: "He who sits at the king's gate" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here the following: “He said to him: My lord, O king! I did not think when thou didst speak but that it was for one greater than this man. As for this man, give him fields and vineyards and it will suffice for him; as for these other (honours), how will they benefit him? The king said to him: Go, do as thou hast spoken. I also am able to give him all that which thou hast decreed with thy mouth.<sup></sup> The king said to him: By the life of my head and my kingdom! It is becoming for thee to do thus.”<sup></sup></i>
Haman took the apparel and the horse and went to Mordecai.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds here: “And he inquired after his welfare (lit. peace). Mordecai replied: ‘There is no <i>peace,</i> saith the Lord, unto the wicked’” (Isa. 48:22). This passage is wanting in the Oxford MS.</i> (Haman) said to him: Arise, and put on the purple of the king. (Mordecai) said to him:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition adds: “Fool of the world!”</i> Villain! Dost thou not know that for three days I have put on sack-cloth with ashes,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Esth. 4:1. Targum 11. on Esth. 6:11 reads: (Haman says): “Now arise from your sackcloth and ashes, and put on the royal garment.”</i> sitting on the ashes,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Esth. 4:3.</i> because of that which thou hast done to me? Now take me to the bath-house,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “What did Esther do? She ordained that any person who should stand (about) in the baths (the same) should not live. And if (Haman) should tell anyone to kindle lights, they should not hearken unto him. Haman went and (by) himself kindled the lights against his will. He sent his eldest son to call Mordecai into the baths. Mordecai received (him) and struck him with his foot, saying to him: Why did not thy father come himself? Is he not my servant? He returned to his father and told him, and he went against his will to take (Mordecai) to the baths, and he shaved his head and divested him (of his garments) and dressed him.”</i> and afterwards will I put on the purple of the king. And he washed him and dressed him. (Haman) said to him: Mount and ride upon the horse. He said to (Haman): On account of the affliction of the fast I have no strength to mount and ride upon the horse. What did Haman do? He lowered himself, || and Mordecai put his foot upon his neck, and he mounted and rode upon the horse.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “And as he lifted up one leg, he struck him with the other foot. (Haman) said to him: Is it not written in the Torah (<i>i.e.</i> Bible): ‘Rejoice not when thine enemy falleth’ (Prov. 24:17)? (Mordecai) said to him: These words apply to Israel, but concerning the nations of the world (the text says): ‘But thou shalt tread upon their high places’” (Deut. 33:29). The Amsterdam and Prague editions read “idolaters” instead of “nations of the world” just before the quotation from Deuteronomy. This long section is undoubtedly a later expansion of the simple original narrative which we have probably preserved in our MS. and in the Targum 11. The Venice text contains several Aramaic words which are quite alien to the language of the <i>P.R.E.</i></i> Mordecai<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum 11. to Esth., <i>loc. cit.</i></i> said: Blessed be the Omnipresent, who hath not let aught of His words fall to the earth, to fulfil that which is said, "But thou shalt tread upon their high places" (Deut. 33:29). Mordecai<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Mordecai came before the king, and Haman was proclaiming before him: ‘Thus shall it be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour’ (Esth. 6:11). ‘ But Haman hasted to his house’” (<i>ibid.</i> 12), etc.</i> betook himself to his seat of honour at the king's gate, whilst Haman was hurried along, and he went<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.</i></i> "to his house mourning and having his head covered" (Esth. 6:12),<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The covered head was a sign of disgrace and mourning among the Jews (see <i>supra,</i> p. 100); also among the Persians (see Q. Curtius, v. 10 and x. 5).</i> because of that which had happened to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> for the legend of Haman’s daughter, who killed herself when she discovered her father’s disgrace.</i>
Zeresh his wife and all his astrologers<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “friends.”</i> said to him: Hast thou not heard what was done unto Pharaoh?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in Egypt.” See Targum 1. to Esth. 6:13, which seems to have preserved the original text of <i>P.R.E.</i>; <i>or</i> is the real fact <i>vice-versa</i>? See Posner’s dissertation on Targum 1. p. 47. The version in the Targum 1., <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “Before whom thou hast begun to fall, as the kings fell before Abraham in the Plain of the Field, as Abimelech fell before Isaac, as the angel was vanquished by Jacob, and as by the hands of Moses and Aaron Pharaoh and all his host sank in the Reed Sea, and as all kings and princes, who did them harm, were delivered by God into their hand, so also wilt thou accomplish nothing harmful against him.” See also Targum 11. to Esth. 6:13.</i> as it is said, "And Zeresh his wife said unto him, If Mordecai, before whom thou hast begun to fall, be of the seed of the Jews,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> thou shalt not prevail against him" (<i>ibid.</i> 13).
In that hour the pages of Esther came and took Haman to the banquet which she had prepared on the sixteenth<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and MS. Gaster read: “the 17th of Nisan.”</i> of Nisan. When they had eaten and taken (wine) the king said to Esther: "What is thy petition,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> queen Esther? and it shall be granted thee; and what is thy request?" (<i>ibid.</i> vii. 2). She said to him: My lord, O king!<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “‘If it please the king, let my life be given me at my petition, and my people at my request’” (Esth. 7:3). See Targum 1., <i>in loc.,</i> which paraphrases this verse thus: “If I have found grace in thy sight, O king”: “If I have found mercy before Thee, O High King,” referring to God. Our author also only quotes the second half of the verse as referring to Ahasuerus.</i> I ask nought of thee, except my life, and my people. Because one man has come and has bought us to destroy, to slay, and to cause to perish.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Esth. Rab. Proem.</i> "But if we had been sold for bondmen and bondwomen, I had held my peace" (<i>ibid.</i> 4). The king said to her:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Who is he and where is he?” (Esth. 7:5).</i> Who is this man? She answered him: This one is the wicked Haman,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “This wicked Haman” (Esth. 7:6). See Targum 1., <i>in loc.</i> In the MS. the quotation which follows ends with the word “enemy.” Then the first editions add: “Forthwith they covered his face.”</i> as it is said, "And Esther said, An adversary and an enemy, even this wicked Haman" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). "The king arose in his wrath" (<i>ibid.</i> 7).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from the banquet of wine, and he went into the palace garden.”</i> What did the angel Michael<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum 11. to Esth. 7:7, and cf. Targum 1. to Esth. 7:7, which speaks of the “ten angels in the guise of the ten sons of Haman cutting down the king’s plants.” Josephus should be compared with our Midrash in connection with his account of the story of Esther.</i> do? He began to cut down the plants in his presence.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “The king saw and asked him: Who is this? He answered him: I am the son of Haman, for thus did my father command me.<sup class="footnote-marker"></sup> Immediately was his wrath kindled.” See T.B. Megillah, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and Esth. Rab. 10:9.</i> || Intense wrath was kindled within him, and the king returned from the palace garden to the place of the banquet of wine. What did the angel Michael do? He lifted up Haman<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Against Esther, see Esth. 7:8; and cf. Targum 11. to Esth. 7:8. The Venice edition reads: “He lifted Haman up from Esther, as though he had wished to come to her.”</i> from Esther. The king exclaimed:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of this sentence occurs in the MS. only.</i> As for this villain, he is not satisfied with having purchased the people of Esther to destroy, to slay, and to cause to perish, but he must needs come upon her! "Will he even force the queen before me in the house?" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Josephus, <i>Ant.</i> xi. 6. 11, adds: “as he had fallen upon the queen’s bed.”</i> Haman heard this word and his countenance fell, as it is said, "They covered Haman's face" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence occurs in the MS. only.</i> And the king commanded that he should be hanged on the gallows.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said, ‘And the king said, Hang him thereon’” (Esth. 7:9).</i> What<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “In that hour what did Elijah,” etc.</i> did Elijah, his memory be a blessing, do? He assumed the guise of Harbonah,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Hagahoth of Maimonides, Hilkhoth Megillah, 1:7; <i>J.E.</i> vi. 231, also Esth. Rab. 10:9.</i> one of the chamberlains of the king. He said to him: My lord, O king! There is a tree<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> “‘<i>Êz</i>,” tree, wood, or gallows. See also Targum 11. to Esth. 7:9; Josephus, <i>loc. cit.,</i> and cf. Jeraḥmeel lxxxii. 6.</i> in Haman's house (taken) from the Holy of Holies,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Luria thinks that we should read here: “from the house of the forest of Lebanon.” This is very likely correct.</i> fifty cubits high. Whence do we know that it was from the Holy of Holies? Because it is said, "And he built the house of the forest of Lebanon" (1 Kings 7:2).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions vary the quotation and read: “‘And he made the porch of pillars; the length thereof was fifty cubits’” (1 Kings 7:6).</i> Forthwith the king commanded that he should be hanged thereon, as it is said, "And (the king<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits “the king.”</i>) said, Hang him thereon" (Esth. 7:9), so as to fulfil that which is said, "Let a beam be pulled out from his house,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> and let him be lifted up and fastened thereon; and let his house be made a dunghill for this" (Ezra 6:11). And it says, "So they hanged Haman<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> on the gallows that he had prepared for Mordecai" (Esth. 7:10). The king took all that belonged to Haman<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> “and his house” is added by Luria.</i> and gave it to Mordecai and to Esther.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add the following: “to fulfil that which is said: ‘And let his house be made a dunghill for this’” (Ezra 6:11).</i> He<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The king commanded the Jews to do as seemed good in their eyes.”</i> said to them: Write concerning the Jews as seems good in your eyes<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The king had told Haman to do with the Jews as seemed good in his eyes; this was the sequel. “Measure for measure.”</i> in the name of the king. They wrote official letters, and they sent throughout all the provinces<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “of the king.”</i> to destroy, to slay, || and to cause all the enemies of the Jews to perish on the thirteenth of the month of Adar, on the third day in the constellation of Leo.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Esth. § 1059, and the note at the end of the Warsaw (1877) edition of the Jalḳuṭ.</i> Just as the lion<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e.</i> the constellation Leo.</i> is the king<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit.,</i> reads: “And the lion is the king.”</i> over all the beasts, and he turns his gaze towards any place as he wishes; likewise did he<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The constellation Leo.</i> think fit, and he turned his face to destroy and to slay all the enemies of Israel, as it is said, "In the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to have rule over them" (<i>ibid.</i> ix. 1).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Just as he thought and he turned his face to destroy and to slay and to exterminate all the Jews, so was it reversed to their enemies, as it is said, ‘Whereas it was turned to the contrary, that the Jews had rule’” (Esth. 9:1).</i>
Rabbi Eliezer said: Haman had forty sons;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Book of Esther the ten sons of Haman are referred to four times.</i> ten of them were the scribes of the books of the king, and thirty were ruling in all the provinces, as it is said, "And the ten sons of Haman, in the rest of the king's provinces" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). They were all hanged upon the gallows of their father, as it is said, "And they hanged Haman's ten sons" (<i>ibid.</i> 14) upon the gallows. Another Scripture text says, "And they hanged Haman's ten sons" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The previous quotation does not contain the words “upon the gallows”; probably Esth. 9:25 was intended to be the quotation.</i>
Rabbi Phineas said: Mordecai ruled<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “reigned over all the Jews.”</i> over the Jews. Just as the king is dressed in purple, so was Mordecai dressed in purple, as it is said, "And Mordecai went forth from the presence of the king<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> in royal apparel" (<i>ibid.</i> viii. 15).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions omit part of this section.</i> Just as the king has a crown upon his head, so Mordecai had a crown upon his head, as it is said, "And Mordecai went forth<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> This part of the quotation is not given by the MS.</i>… with a great crown of gold" (<i>ibid.</i>). Just as the king's fear obtains in all the land, so was the fear of Mordecai upon them, as it is said, "Because the fear of Mordecai was fallen upon them…" (<i>ibid.</i> ix. 3).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “And his fame went forth throughout all the provinces” (Esth. 9:4).</i> Just as the king's money is current throughout the land, || so was Mordecai's money current in all the land, as it is said, "For Mordecai was great" (<i>ibid.</i> 4).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions quote the next phrase in the verse: “And his fame went forth.”</i> What was the money of Mordecai? On the one side was (the face of) Mordecai and on the other (the face of) Esther. Wherefore? Because he was a good man, and a man of peace and seeking the peace of his people, as it is said, "For Mordecai the Jew was next unto king Ahasuerus, and great among the Jews" (<i>ibid.</i> x. 3); concerning him the Scripture saith, "Mark the perfect man, and behold the upright:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> for the latter end of (that) man is peace"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The R.V. has in the margin: “For there is a reward for the man of peace.”</i> (Ps. 37:37).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See the Midrashim to this Psalm, which could be applied to the fall of Haman; see also Esth. Rab. 10:12. The Midrash Abba Gorion, as well as the other Midrashim to Esther edited by Buber in Siphrê d’Agadatha, should be compared with this chapter. Munk’s edition of Targum 11. should also be consulted.</i>

Chapter 51

CHAPTER LI<br><small>THE NEW HEAVENS AND EARTH</small> [73<small>B</small>. i.]<br>R<small>ABBAN</small> G<small>AMALIEL</small> said: Just as the New Moons are renewed<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “are sanctified and renewed.” The reference is to the “Benediction pronounced at the beginning of every lunar month.” See T.B. Synhedrin, 42a; Sopherim 25:1, p. 280; Ex. Rab. xv. 24; and cf. T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 24a, and <i>supra</i>, p. 354.</i> and sanctified in this world, so will Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> It is only natural that the authors of the Midrashim should think of Israel in the same way as the Christian writers in all ages think of Christians. Thus Justin Martyr, in his <i>Second Apology</i>, vii., declares that the whole world is preserved only for the sake of Christians.</i> be sanctified<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ezek. 36:23, and T.B. Synhedrin, 90b, on the future life. The Church Fathers also discuss the passing away of the heavens and their renewal, see Methodius, <i>On the Resurrection</i>, viii. f.</i> and renewed in the future world just like the New Moons, as it is said, "Speak unto all the congregation of the children of Israel, and say unto them, Ye shall be holy:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> for I the Lord your God am holy" (Lev. 19:2). The sages say: The heavens and the earth are destined to pass away and to be renewed. What is written concerning them?	"And all the host of the heaven shall be dissolved,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This part of the verse is omitted by the MS. and the first editions.</i> and the heavens shall be rolled together as a scroll" (Isa. 34:4). Just as when a man reads in a scroll of the Torah and he rolls it,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> R.S. b. Adereth in his Responsa, i. ix, and R. Bechai on Gen. 1:22, add here: “again he opens it and reads therein and rolls it together.” This agrees with the reading of our MS. The first editions omit this. The opening of the scroll the first time might be for the purpose of airing the parchment, the second time to find the place which was to be read.</i> and again he opens it to read therein and he rolls it (together), likewise in the future will the Holy One, blessed be He, roll together the heavens like a scroll, as it is said, "And the heavens shall be rolled together as a scroll"<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> R.S. b. Adereth, <i>loc. cit</i>., and R. Bechai, <i>loc. cit</i>., agree here also with the reading in our MS. The text is corrupt in the first editions.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>); "And the earth shall wax old like a garment" (<i>ibid.</i> li. 6); just as a man spreads out his garment and folds it<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Unless we adopt this reading, which is probably the correct text, we should read: “and shakes it.” The first editions have an abbreviated text.</i> up, and again he unfolds it || and puts it on and renews it (thereby), likewise the Holy One, blessed be He, in the future will fold up the earth and again will He spread it out and put it in its place like a garment, as it is said. "And the earth shall wax old like a garment" (<i>ibid.</i>).
All its inhabitants shall taste the taste of death<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> But they will not really die. Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 91b.</i> for two days, when there will be no soul of man or beast upon the earth, as it is said, "And they that dwell therein shall die in like manner" (<i>ibid.</i>). On the third day He will renew them all and revive the dead, and He will establish it<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions and R.S. b. Adereth read: “them.”</i> before Him, as it is said, "On the third day he will raise us up, and we shall live before him" (Hos. 6:2).
Rabbi Eliezer said: All the host of heaven in the future will pass away and will be renewed. What is written concerning them? "And all the host of heaven shall be dissolved"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “yibbôlu” (shall fade away); this does not agree with M.T. The first editions quote from the same verse: “And all their host shall fade away, as the leaf fadeth from off the vine.”</i> (Isa. 34:4). Just as the leaves fade<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> R.S. b. Adereth and R. Bechai agree herewith. The first editions read somewhat differently.</i> from off the vine and the fig tree, and the latter remain standing as a dry tree, and again they blossom afresh and bear buds and produce new leaves and fresh leaves. Likewise<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The 1st ed. reads: “Likewise all the hosts of heaven in the future will pass away and blossom again, bearing buds and sprouting afresh, and they shall become renewed in their place; to make known that He maketh everything to pass away. Never again will there be famine or plague, as it is said, ‘For, behold, I create new heavens and a new earth’” (Isa. 65:17). The Venice edition agrees on the whole with this text, but adds: “there will not be any more new misfortunes.” R.S. b. Adereth reads “evil” instead of “plague.” In the Messianic Kingdom there will be neither sin nor misfortune.</i> in the future will all the host of heaven fade away like a vine and a fig tree, and they will again be renewed before Him to make known that there is passing away (which) does not (really) pass away. No more shall there be evil, and no more shall there be plague,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> And then all misfortunes, even death, will cease. See Gen. Rab. 26:6, cf. Assumption of Moses, x. 2, and Methodius, <i>op. cit</i>. ix.</i> and (there shall) not be the former misfortunes, as it is said, "For, behold, I create new heavens" (<i>ibid.</i> lxv. 17).
Rabbi Jannai said: || All the hosts of heaven pass away and are renewed every day.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Singer, p. 128: “Who reneweth in His goodness every day continually the work of the Creation.”</i> What are the hosts of heaven? The sun, the moon, the stars, and the constellations.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This line occurs in the MS. only.</i> Know that it is so. Come and see, for when the sun turns in order to set in the west, it bathes in the waters of the Ocean<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 39; Jalḳuṭ, Isa. § 513; T.B. Pesachim, 94b, and the Pal. Targum to the verse Gen. 19:23. The first editions add here: “like a man who extinguishes his lamp in the midst of the waters, so by the waters of the Ocean the flames of the sun are extinguished.”</i> and extinguishes the flames of the sun, and no light is left, and it has no flame all night long until it comes to the east. When it arrives at the east it washes itself in the river of fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Chagigah, 13b; Ex. Rab. xv. 6, and cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 25.</i> like a man who kindles his lamp in the midst of the fire. Likewise the sun kindles its lamps and puts on its flames and ascends to give light upon the earth, and it renews every day the work of the Creation.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See note 2 above.</i> And thus (it is) until even comes.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “until it comes to the west.”</i> At evening-time the moon and the stars and the constellations wash themselves in the river of hail,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>e.g</i>. the light of the moon and stars, which lacks heating power. See Jalḳuṭ on Isa., <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> and they ascend to give light upon the earth. In the future that is to come, the Holy One, blessed be He, will renew them and add to their light a sevenfold light,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “like the light of seven days.”</i> as it is said, "Moreover, the light of the moon shall be as the light of the sun, and the light of the sun<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions it ends with the words, “as the light of the sun,” mentioned previously.</i> shall be sevenfold, as the light of seven days" (<i>ibid.</i> xxx. 26). "In the day" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse continues: “<i>in</i> the day that the Lord bindeth up the hurt of his people, and healeth the stroke of their wound.” The MS. reads: “<i>as</i> the day.”</i> Like which day? In the day of the redemption of Israel, as it is said, "In the day that the Lord bindeth up the hurt of his people" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabban Gamaliel said: The Sabbath burnt offering which they brought || every Sabbath (consisted of) two he-lambs, and the burnt offering for the New Moon which they brought every New Moon consisted of two young bullocks. Two for each occasion,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “These two and those two,” <i>i.e</i>. Sabbath and New Moon.</i> corresponding to what? Corresponding to the two worlds, this world and the world to come. "One ram and one he-goat":<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. 28:11, 15.</i> just as they<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The Israelites. Our MS. text agrees with that of the Amsterdam and Prague editions. The first editions read: “Just as He is one, so are they one and their God is one.” This seems to be a conflate text.</i> are a single nation, their God is (likewise) <i>one.</i> "<i>Seven</i> he-lambs of the first year without blemish" (Num. 28:11), corresponding to those who bring their offerings,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The seven occasions when additional offerings (the Mussaphim) were brought, namely, Passover, Pentecost, Tabernacles, New Year, Atonement, Sabbath, and New Moon. Perhaps the reference is to the seven planets.</i> to Him who renews them<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> “In the future” is added by Luria.</i> like the New Moons, as it is said, "This is the burnt offering of every month<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> throughout the months of the year" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).
Rabbi Zechariah said: After<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Our MS. reads “one”; it should be “after (the words) the burnt offering of every month.” The Venice edition reads: “After ‘the New Moon’ what is written?”</i> (the words) "the burnt offering of every month<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> throughout the months of the year" (<i>ibid.</i>), what is written? "And one<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits in this quotation, which is repeated a little lower down, the word “one.”</i> he-goat for a sin offering unto the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i> 15). For what purpose was the sin offering? When the Holy One, blessed be He, created His world, He created two great luminaries,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 31.</i> as it is said, "And God made the two great lights"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> In Luria’s text the word for “lights” is inaccurate as a quotation from the Bible. In the MS. the quotation ends with the word “made.” In the first editions the quotation is continued.</i> (Gen. 1:16). The one He made larger and the other smaller, and the moon obstinately refused<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> On the Midrash see T.B. Chullin, 60b; Midrash Kônen, p. 26; and <i>Rabbinic Philosophy and Ethics</i>, p. 13, and note 1; and cf. Midrash Agadah on Gen. 1:16.</i> to do the will of its Creator so as to be made smaller; therefore Israel offered on its behalf the he-goat for a sin offering heavenwards as one of the burnt offerings of the New Moon, as it is said, "And one<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. omits again the word “one” in this quotation.</i> he-goat for a sin offering unto the Lord" (Num. 28:15). What is the meaning of "unto the Lord"? The Holy One, blessed be He, said: This he-goat shall be an atonement for Me,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The interpretation is due to the fact that only in connection with the sin offering for the New Moon does the Torah say: “A sin offering to the Lord.” See T.B. Shebu’oth, 9a; T.B. Chullin, <i>loc. cit</i>.; and Gen. Rab. 6:3; and cf. Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 44, quoting Midrash Abkhir.</i> because I have diminished the (size of the) moon.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the idea underlying this Haggadah is not only the fact that the moon is much smaller than the sun, but also the fact that, unlike the sun, the moon is never constant in its phases as seen from the earth. Perhaps the waxing and waning are referred to in our Midrash. See Singer, p. 129, and <i>supra</i>, p. 31.</i>
Rabbi Eliezer said: In the future the Temple will be raised up and renewed, as it is said, "Behold, I will do a new thing; now shall it spring forth;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> shall ye not know it?" (Isa. 43:19). || And its gates<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Of the Temple; cf. Isa. 61:4 and Zech. 6:12, 13; Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. § 383.</i> which are buried in the earth will be renewed in the future and arise every one in its place, and the gate of the inner court which turned to the east.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds: “shall be, etc.”</i> On the six days of work its doors shall be closed, and on the Sabbath day they are opened by themselves, as it is said, "Thus saith the Lord God: The gate of the inner court<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> that looketh toward the east shall be shut the six working days; but on the Sabbath day it shall be opened, and in the day of the new moon it shall be opened" (Ezek. 46:1).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ẓohar, Gen. 75b.</i>
Rabbi Jehudah said: On Sabbath and New Moons Israel stood there,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> In the inner court of the Temple. The first editions add: “and they saw the doors open by themselves and they knew.”</i> (and they perceived) that the Sabbath day had come, and they sanctified the Sabbath day;<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “and afterwards the heavenly (ones, <i>i.e</i>. angels) do likewise.” This reading is exceedingly interesting, as it seems to be a parallel to the Book of Jubilees ii. 18: “And all the angels of the presence, and all the angels of <i>sanctification</i>, these two great classes—He hath bidden us to keep the Sabbath with Him <i>in heaven</i> and on earth.” The sanctification of the Sabbath is not the same as the sanctification of the New Moon. See T.B. Bezah, 17a; and T.B. Ḳiddushin, 37a.</i> and so also on the New Moons the Israelites were standing there and saw the doors opening by themselves,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>.: “Israel <i>will stand</i>.” There is no tradition to support the saying of R. Jehudah as to the part attributed to the people in proclaiming the New Moon. This function was in the hands of the Synhedrion or the Nasi. See <i>supra</i>, Chapter VIII., on the intercalation of the month.</i> and they knew that in that hour it was New Moon, and they sanctified the New Moon,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here: “They sanctified the New Moon, and afterwards in the heavenly regions, because the sign of the beginning of a New Moon (was known) to the children of Israel.” The Venice text continues: “Since they stood there and saw the doors open by themselves they knew that the Shekhinah of the Holy One, blessed be He, was therein, as it is said, ‘O Lord God of hosts, who is a mighty one like unto thee, O Lord?’ (Ps. 89:8); (and it is said: ‘And the Lord) said unto me, This gate shall be shut’… ‘for the Lord, the God of Israel, hath entered in <i>by it</i>; therefore it shall be shut’” (Ezek. 44:2). The first editions have a corrupt text here, the portions in brackets are wanting.</i> and afterwards (this was done) among the heavenly ones. Therefore Israel sanctifies the New Moons first in the lower regions (on earth) and afterwards (it is sanctified) in the heavenly regions, because they<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The doors moved by the presence of the Shekhinah.</i> have defined the beginning of the Molad of the Moon in the presence of Israel, who saw the doors open by themselves, and they knew that the Shekhinah of the Holy One, blessed be He (was therein<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. there is a lacuna; the first editions read: “was therein.”</i>), as it is said, "For the Lord, the God of Israel, hath entered in by it"<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew for “by it” might be rendered “therein.”</i> (<i>ibid.</i> xliv. 2). Forthwith they<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The people of Israel.</i> fall down and prostrate themselves before their God. So it was in the past and so will it be in the future that is to come, as it is said, "And the people of the || land shall worship<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> at the door of that gate before the Lord in the Sabbaths and in the New Moons" (<i>ibid.</i> xlvi. 3).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> There were thirteen gates in the Temple, and the people prostrated themselves thirteen times. See Sheḳalim vi. 1.</i>
Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Rabbi Jonathan.”</i> said: Is it not written, "There is no <i>new</i> thing under the sun" (Eccles. 1:9)? The (sages) said to him:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition and Luria’s text read: “He said to him.” It should be: “the sages said to him,” that there was an exception to the saying of Solomon that “there was nothing new under the sun,” namely, the righteous, who were destined to be <i>renewed</i>.</i> The righteous and all their works will be <i>renewed</i>, but the wicked will not be renewed and "no new thing" shall be given to them, (even) to all who worship and trust <i>under</i> the sun, therefore it is said, "There is no new thing under the sun" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Phineas said: In the future the waters of the well will ascend from under the threshold of the Temple, and they will overflow and bubble<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and will fructify.” Jalḳuṭ, Ezek., <i>loc. cit.</i>, reads “umephakin”: “The waters of the well in the future shall rise up from under the threshold of the Temple, and shall ooze and bubble and go forth in twelve streams.” See also Jalḳuṭ, Josh. § 15, and Jalḳuṭ, Zech. § 579. Jalḳuṭ, Ezek., <i>loc. cit</i>., says that this water of the well “will go forth in <i>three</i> parts.” See Wisdom xix. 7 on the narrative of the Exodus. Cf. <i>supra</i>, pp. 70, 330, on the twelve paths in the Reed Sea.</i> over and issue forth and become twelve streams corresponding to the twelve tribes, as it is said, "And he brought me back unto the door of the house; and<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation commences here in the MS.; in the first editions the preceding clause is given.</i> behold, waters issued out<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions the quotation ends with the word “house,” and they add the concluding part beginning with the words: “from the right side.”</i> from under the threshold of the house eastward, for the forefront of the house was toward the east: and the waters came down from under, from the right side of the house, on the south of the altar" (Ezek. 47:1). Three (streams) towards the south to pass through them up to the ankles, and three (streams) towards the west to pass through them up to the knees, as it is said, "When the man<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read here “the sun”; the M.T. has “the man”; both editions omit “and he caused me to pass,” which occurs in the M.T. and in the MS. This variation of the texts proves the dependence of the Venice text upon that of the first edition.</i> went forth eastward with the line in his hand, he measured a thousand cubits, and he caused me to pass through the waters, waters that were to the ankles. Again he measured a thousand, and<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation begins here.</i> he caused me to pass through the waters, waters that were to the knees" (<i>ibid.</i> 3, 4).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add here: “There were three (streams) towards the north to pass through them up to the loins, as it is said, ‘And he measured a thousand <i>cubits</i> and caused me to pass through <i>the waters</i>, waters that were to the loins’” (Ezek. 47:4). In this verse also there are two variations of the M.T., and both occur alike in the first edition. The variations are printed in <i>italics</i>.</i> And three (streams) towards the east to pass through them up to the neck, for the neck is the extremity of the body, as it is said, "And he measured a thousand cubits, and<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation begins here.</i> he caused me to pass through the waters that were to the extremity"<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <span>אפסים</span>, R.V. renders “ankles.” See Tosephta Sukkah 3:3, pp. 195 f.; cf. T.B. Joma, 77b; and Targum on Ezek. 47:3, which also renders this word by <span>קרסולים</span>.</i> (<i>ibid.</i> 3). And (the waters) descended to the brook of Kidron, and they rose higher than in "the stream,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on Ezek. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> that I could not pass through" (<i>ibid.</i> 5), as it is said, "For the waters were risen, waters to swim in, a stream that could not be passed through"<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The last word in the quotation in our MS. differs from the M.T.</i> (<i>ibid.</i>). And the waters are drawn (thence), and they flow down to the fords of the Jordan,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. <i>loc. cit</i>., reads: “to the fords of Jericho.”</i> as it is said, "And they shall go down into || the Arabah" (<i>ibid.</i> 8).
Every field and vineyard which did not yield fruit, people water<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The entire chapter seems to refer to the future, therefore the verb should be rendered as though it were the future tense: “will water.”</i> them with those waters and they yield fruit, as it is said, "And it shall come to pass, that every living creature which swarmeth, in every place whither the rivers come, shall live<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation in the MS. begins with the words “for these waters,” and ends with the word “thither”; the first editions begin the verse and end with the word “swarmeth.”</i>… for these waters are come thither, that all things may be healed and live" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). Then (the waters) enter the Salt Sea and they heal it.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> See Sheḳalim vi. 3. Another reading is given by Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. <i>loc. cit</i>., “and they extract from them” (the salt thereof); the first editions read: “and they cover it.”</i> And<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “as it is said: ‘Then said he unto me, These waters issue forth from the eastern regions.’” The whole verse might be read with advantage in order to follow the trend of the Midrash.</i> the waters "shall go towards the sea,… and the waters shall be <i>healed</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> 8). And there they generate all kinds (of fish). The Scripture text (here) gives a general rule concerning the fish, that they will be as sweet as Manna.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Perhaps the MS. reads: “like Manna.” The first editions read for this sentence: “And they produce all kinds of fish in the great sea (ocean), as it is said: ‘Their fish shall be after their kinds, as the fish of the great sea, exceeding many’ (Ezek. 47:10). And they are sweetened.” For the last word Luria suggested: “they are moved.” In view of the text preserved in our MS. the reading in the first editions is not to be rejected.</i> They ascend in the stream as far as Jerusalem, and there they are caught in its nets,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in their nets.”</i> as it is said, "And it shall come to pass that<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds here “Ki,” which does not occur in M.T.</i> fishers shall stand by it" (<i>ibid.</i> 10). It is written, "They shall stand by it."<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> “And be caught there.” The first editions add: “‘From En-gedi<sup></sup> even unto Eneglaim<sup></sup> shall be a place for the spreading of nets’” (Ezek. 47:10).<sup></sup></i>
There upon the bank of the stream grow all kinds of trees bearing according to their kind.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “were growing all kinds of trees bearing fruit according to their kind, as it is said. ‘By the river upon the banks thereof shall grow’” (Ezek. 47:12).</i> By the river they shall stand, "upon the banks thereof on this side and on that side" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). Every month they bring forth new fruit, as it is said, "It shall bring forth new fruit every month" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. Rab. 21:22, and Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> Some of them are for food and others are growing, as it is said, "Because<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation in the MS. begins here and ends with the word “sanctuary.” The first editions continue to the end of the verse. The idea seems to be: The waters will be drawn from the Dead Sea and flow through the brook Kidron to Jerusalem. The reading in our MS. is considerably shorter than in our printed texts.</i> the waters thereof issue out of the sanctuary: and the fruit thereof shall be for meat, and the leaf thereof for healing" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Every man who is ill and bathes in those waters, will be healed, as it is said, "In every place whither the rivers come, he shall live<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i>… and every thing shall live whithersoever the river cometh" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). Every man who has a wound will be healed by taking of their leaves<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> And by using them as a plaster. See T.J. Sabbath 7:2. 10c, and Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> and applying them to his wound, as it is said, "And the fruit thereof shall be for meat, and the leaf thereof for healing" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). What is the meaning of "for healing"? Rabbi Jochanan said: For a laxative; || suck its leaves and one's food is digested.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Sheḳalim vi. 5; Cant. Rab. to Cant. 4:12; and Jalḳuṭ, Ezek. <i>loc. cit</i>.</i>

Chapter 52

CHAPTER LII<br><small>THE SEVEN WONDERS OF OLD</small> [75<small>A</small>. ii.]<br>S<small>EVEN</small> wonderful things have been done<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Gen. § 77, which also reads: “have been done.” The first editions read: “have been created.”</i> in the world, the like of which have not been created.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “which have no equal. The first wonder (was).”</i> From the day when the heavens and the earth were created no man was ever saved from the fire<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “fiery furnace.”</i> until our father Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 188.</i> came and was delivered from the fiery furnace. All the kings of the earth heard (thereof) and they were astonished, for they had not seen anyone like him from the day when the world was created. And whence do we know that he was delivered from the fiery furnace? Because it is said, "And he said unto him, I am the Lord that brought thee out of the <i>furnace</i> of the Chaldees" (Gen. 15:7).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The next quotation is omitted by the first editions.</i> Another text says, "Thou art the Lord the God, who didst choose<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> Abram, and broughtest him forth out of the furnace of the Chaldees" (Neh. 9:7).
The second wonder (was) about the wives of the sons of Noah.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The words: “About the wives of the sons of Noah” occur in the MS. only.</i> From the day when the heavens and the earth were created there never was a woman who at ninety years of age had a child, until<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> “Our mother” is added by the first editions. See Midrash Haggadol, c. 303.</i> Sarah came and bare (a son) when (she was) ninety years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “as it is said. ‘And shall Sarah, that is ninety years old, bear?’” (Gen. 17:17).</i> All the kings of the earth heard (thereof), and they did not believe.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 53:9. For phraseology see Ps. 48:5. The first editions read: “All the kings of the earth saw and were astonished, and they did not believe.”</i> What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do to them? He dried up<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “He caused the ducts of the breasts of their wives to become dried up”; cf. Gen. Rab., <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> the breasts of their wives,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and they brought their children to Sarah that she might give them suck”; cf. T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 87a.</i> as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse is not given as a complete quotation in the MS. or in the first editions.</i> "And all the trees<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The identification of human beings with trees has occurred in our book; see <i>supra</i>, p. 150; cf. Gen. Rab. 53:1.</i> of the field shall know<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here.</i> that I the Lord have brought down the high tree, have exalted the low tree, have dried up the green tree, and have made the dry tree to flourish" (Ezek. 17:24).
"All<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The verse (Ezek. 17:24) is now expounded allegorically.</i> the trees of the field shall know" (<i>ibid.</i>); this (expression) refers to the nations of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read: “the worshippers of fire.”</i> "That I the Lord have brought down the high tree" (<i>ibid.</i>) (this refers to Nimrod<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> “This refers to Nimrod” is omitted by our MS., but it occurs in the first editions. The reference is to Nimrod’s attempt to destroy Abraham by casting him in the fiery furnace.</i>). "I have exalted the low tree" (<i>ibid.</i>); this is Abraham our father. "I have dried up the green tree," refers to the breasts of the wives of the nations of the world.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read: “the worshippers of fire.”</i> || "I have made the dry tree to flourish"; this refers to the breasts of Sarah, for they brought their children to be suckled by Sarah's breasts, for Sarah gave suck to all their children in peace, as it is said, "And she said, Who would have said<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. The first editions read: “‘I have made the dry tree to flourish.’ This refers to our mother Sarah, for all of them brought their children to Sarah and she gave them suck, as it is said, ‘Should Sarah give children suck?’” (Gen. 21:7).</i> unto Abraham, that Sarah should give children suck?" (Gen. 21:7).
The third wonder (was): From the day when the heavens and the earth were created there never was a man upon whom grey hairs were sprinkled<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See Hos. 7:9 for a similar expression; cf. T.B. Baba Mezi’a, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Gen. Rab. 65:9.</i> until Abraham came.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “From the day when the heavens and the earth were created, grey hairs were not sprinkled upon the children of men until our father Abraham came, and upon him were grey hairs sprinkled.”</i> The people were astonished because they had not seen any one like him from the day when the world was created. Whence do we know that grey hairs were sprinkled upon him? Because it is said, "And Abraham was old, well <i>stricken in age</i>" (<i>ibid.</i> xxiv. 1).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. 15:15.</i>
Rabbi Levitas, a man of Jamnia, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Like a crown which is the glory on the king’s head, so are grey hairs,” etc.</i> Like a diadem which belongs to the head of the king, so are grey hairs beauty and glory to old men, as it is said, "The glory of young men is their strength,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation begins here; the first editions read the entire verse.</i> and the beauty of old men is the hoary head" (Prov. 20:29).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. also Prov. 16:31: “The hoary head is a crown of glory; it shall be found in the way of righteousness”; cf. Gen. Rab. 59:1.</i>
The fourth wonder (was): From the day when the heavens and the earth were created no man was ill, (who) sneezed and lived, but in every place where he happened to be, whether on the way or in the market,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions differ from our text; they read: “no man was ill unless he happened to be on the way or in the market-place.” Jalḳuṭ on Job, § 927, reads: “Till Jacob’s day it had never happened that a man sneezed and recovered from his sickness.”</i> and (when he) sneezed, his soul went out through his nostrils; until our father Jacob came and prayed<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “And he sought for mercy.” See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, <i>loc. cit</i>. On “sneezing” see <i>J.E</i>. ii. 255 f.; a bibliography is appended.</i> for mercy concerning this, and he said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all the worlds! Do not take my soul from me until I have charged<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> To keep the way of God.</i> my sons and my household;<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, <i>loc. cit</i>.; Gen. Rab. 65:9; and cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 107b.</i> and He was entreated of him, as it is said, "And it came to pass after these things, that one said to Joseph,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Behold, thy father is sick" (Gen. 48:1). || All the kings of the earth heard (thereof), and they wondered because there had been no one like him from the days when the heavens and earth had been created. Therefore a man is in duty bound to say to his fellow: Life!<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Therefore is a man bound to say when he sneezes, Life ! for this death has been changed into light.” See the parallels quoted by the ‘Arukh (ed. Kohut) vi. 191a. Cf. T.J. Berakhoth 3:5. 6d; Tosephta Sabbath viii. p. 118, and T.B. Berakhoth, 53b.</i> when the latter sneezes,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>., reads: “A man is bound to thank God when he sneezes.” To sneeze in times of illness was regarded as a good omen; cf. 2 Kings 4:35, for the story of the child restored to life. See T.B. Berakhoth, 57b.</i> for the death of the world was changed into light, as it is said, "His neesings flash forth light" (Job 41:18).
The fifth wonder (was): From the day when the heavens and the earth were created, the waters of the sea had not been changed into dry land until Israel went forth from Egypt and passed over on dry land in the midst of the sea, as it is said, "But the children of Israel walked on dry land in the midst of the sea" (Ex. 15:19).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit the quotation.</i> All the kings of the earth heard (thereof) and trembled, because there had been nothing like it from the day when the world had been created, as it is said, "The people heard, they trembled" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 330.</i>
The sixth wonder (was): From the day when the heavens and earth were created, the sun,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions omit: “the sun.”</i> the moon, and the stars and the constellations were ascending to give light upon the earth, and they did not come into contact<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Josh. § 22, and Shocher Ṭob on Ps. 19:9, p. 84a.</i> with one another until Joshua came and fought the battles of Israel. It was the eve of the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> According to Seder ‘Olam Rab. 11 it was the 3rd of Tammuẓ, the day of the “Teḳuphah.”</i> and he<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Joshua.”</i> saw the plight of Israel lest they might desecrate the Sabbath, and further, he saw the magicians of Egypt<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “the magicians of the nations.”</i> compelling<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The Venice edition agrees with our MS. and reads: “compelling.” Perhaps the reading should be “Chôshebim” (calculating). Jalḳuṭ, Gen. <i>loc. cit</i>., reads: “exciting.” See Gen. Rab. 44:10, 12. Perhaps the idea is that of casting spells to force the constellations to oppose the enemy; cf. for this notion Judg. 5:20: “They fought from heaven; the stars in their courses fought <i>against</i> Sisera.” See also Jalḳuṭ, Josh., <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> the constellations to come<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “coming,” present participle, and not the infinitive as in the MS.</i> against Israel. What did he<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Joshua.”</i> do? He stretched forth his hand to the light of the sun and to the light of the moon,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “and to the light of the stars.”</i> and he invoked upon them the || (Divine) Name, and each one stood for thirty-six hours in its place until the termination of the Sabbath day,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. ‘Abodah Ẓarah, 25a.</i> as it is said, "And the sun stood still, and the moon stayed" (Josh. 10:13).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “‘until the nation had avenged themselves of their enemies’ (Josh. 10:13). And it is written, ‘And there was no day like that before it or after it, that the Lord hearkened unto the voice of a man’” (<i>ibid.</i> 14).</i> All the kings of the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The kings of the earth heard.” The later editions have: “many people heard.”</i> heard thereof and they wondered, because there had been none like him from the day when the world had been created, as it is said, "And there was no day like that<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> before it or after it, that the Lord hearkened unto the voice of a man" (<i>ibid.</i> 14).
The seventh wonder (was): From the day when the heavens and earth had been created there had never been a sick man who had recovered from his sickness,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Gen. Rab. 65:9. Because of the unprecedented experience of Hezekiah, a sign was given. See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, <i>loc. cit</i>., where Elisha’s cure is quoted as the first. Cf. T.B. Synhedrin, 104a, and <i>ibid.</i> 107b.</i> until Hezekiah, king of Judah, came and fell sick and (yet) he recovered, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation in the first editions is: “‘In those days was Hezekiah sick unto death’” (2 Kings 20:1).</i> "The writing of Hezekiah, king of Judah, when he had been sick, and was recovered of his sickness" (Isa. 38:9). He began to pray before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: Sovereign of all worlds!	"Now, O Lord, remember, I beseech thee, how I walked before thee in truth<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the MS. the quotation ends here; in the first editions the last word quoted is “thee.”</i> and with a perfect heart, and have done that which is good in thy sight" (2 Kings 20:3); and He was entreated of him, as it is said, "Behold, I will add unto thy days fifteen years" (Isa. 38 <i>5)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The text of the quotation in our MS. differs from that printed in the first editions. The M.T. should also be compared.</i> Hezekiah said before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! Give me a sign, as it is said, "And Hezekiah said unto Isaiah, What shall be the sign<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions. The MS. as well as the first editions differ from the M.T. by omitting “unto Isaiah.”</i> that the Lord will heal me, and that I shall go up unto the house of the Lord?" (2 Kings 20:8). He answered him: Ahaz thy father compelled<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Should we read “Chôsheb,” “was calculating”? Cf. <i>supra</i>, p. 423, note 10. The reading in our MS. agrees with the previous reading in this chapter in connection with Joshua. Brode suggests: “paid respect to” or “honoured”; if “compelled” be correct, “through spells” might be added for the purpose of interpretation.</i> the constellations, and he bowed down<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ on 2 Kings, § 245.</i> to the sun,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “moon, stars, and constellations.”</i> and the sun fled before him<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>., agrees practically with this reading. The first editions read: “He fled before the sun.”</i> and went down in the west ten steps.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Should we render the word “steps” or “degrees”?</i> If thou desirest, it shall go down ten steps, or it shall ascend ten steps.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “If thou desirest, it shall again descend ten steps.” See 2 Kings 20:9. Our MS. reads: “or shall it ascend ten constellations?” (<span>מזלוח</span>). This last word should be <span>מעלות</span>, “steps.”</i> Hezekiah spake before the Holy One, blessed be He: Sovereign of all worlds ! Nay, || but those ten steps which it has (already) gone down let it retrace and stand,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in its place.”</i> as it is said, "Nay, but let the shadow return<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; the first editions read also the next word. The Venice edition and the MS. read as a quotation <span>כי לא ישוב</span> instead of <span>לא כי ישוב</span>. The first editions add after the quotation from 2 Kings 20:10 the words: “on the steps which it had gone down.”</i> backward ten steps" (<i>ibid.</i> 10). And He was entreated of him, as it is said, "Behold, I will cause the shadow on the steps,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is omitted in the first editions.</i> which is gone down on the dial of Ahaz with the sun, to return backward ten steps" (Isa. 38:8). All the kings<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read: “All the nations of the earth.”</i> of the earth saw, and they were astonished, for there had been nothing like it from the day when the world was created, and they<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. the Babylonians.</i> sent to behold the wonder,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read “as it is said,” as though it were a Biblical quotation. This is an error.</i> as it is said, "Howbeit<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “uba,” “and he came,” instead of “vekhên,” “howbeit,” which occurs in the M.T. and in the first editions.</i> in (the business of) the ambassadors of the princes of Babylon<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the first editions; it is continued in the MS. as in our version.</i> who sent unto him to inquire of the wonder that was done in the land" (2 Chron. 32:31).
And Hezekiah saw the messengers,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first edition reads: “And Hezekiah saw the kings of Babylon.” The Venice edition corrects this and reads: “And Hezekiah saw the kings (?) of the king of Babylon”; it should be: “the messengers of the king of Babylon.”</i> and his heart was puffed with pride,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See 2 Chron. 32:31. See also Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 8 p. 46: “He became proud when he saw that God had worked a miracle on his behalf.”</i> and he showed them all the treasures of the kings of Judah, and all the treasures of the Holy of Holies in the Temple,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This is inferred from the words of the text: “There was nothing in his house, nor in all his dominion, that Hezekiah shewed them not” (2 Kings 20:13). The king controlled the treasures of the Temple; see Sheḳalim v. 2.</i> and further, he opened the Ark of the Covenant, and he showed them the tables of the Law,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Targum to 2 Chron. 32:31; and cf. Num. Rab. 5:9. There may have been in the Temple a second ark containing the broken Tables of the Law; see Tosaphoth to ‘Erubin, 63b, which quotes T.J. Soṭah on this point.</i> and he said to them: With this do we wage war<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Cant. Rab. to Cant. 3:4.</i> and conquer, as it is said, "And Hezekiah was glad of them, and shewed them<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> the house of his precious things" (Isa. 39:2). The Holy One, blessed be He, was angry with him, and He said to him: Was it not enough for thee to have shown them all the treasures of the kings of Judah and all the treasures of the Holy of Holies? Moreover, thou hast opened for them the Ark, and hast shown them the tables, the work of My hand. By thy life! They shall come up and take away all the treasures of the kings of Judah, and all the treasures of the Holy of || Holies, as it is said, "Behold, the days come,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds: “saith the Lord.” This does not occur in the M.T. or in the printed editions. The quotation ends in the MS. with the word after “come” in the Hebrew text; in the first editions the quotation is continued up to “house.”</i> that all that is in thine house, and that which thy fathers have laid up in store until this day, shall be carried to Babylon" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). Instead of the tables of the Law, they shall take of thy sons to be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon, as it is said, "And of thy sons that shall issue from thee,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> which thou shalt beget, shall they take away; and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon" (<i>ibid.</i> 7). These were<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions insert “Daniel.”</i> Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who were made eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon, and they did not beget children. Concerning them the Scripture says, "For thus saith the Lord to the eunuchs that keep my sabbaths,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 26 p. 134. The MS. omits “my sabbaths”; the first editions give this.</i>… Unto them will I give in mine house and within my walls a memorial<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Synhedrin, 104a.</i> and a name<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; in the first editions one word more of the text is added.</i> better than of sons and of daughters; I will give them an everlasting name, that shall not be cut off" (<i>ibid.</i> lvi. 4, 5).

Chapter 53

CHAPTER LIII<br><small>THE SIN OF SLANDER</small> [76<small>B</small>. i.]<br>E<small>VERYONE</small><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “All who slander a man in secret.” This chapter is numbered lii. in the MS. referred to by Wertheimer; see <i>infra</i>, p. 436, note 5.</i> who secretly slanders<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This leads on to the narrative of Miriam and Aaron, who slandered Moses; see Num. 12:1 ff.</i> his fellows has no remedy,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “has no portion in the world to come.” See T.B. ‘Arakhin, 15b. The Menorath Ha-Maor, § 52, reads: “He has no remedy,” as in our MS. text. See also Derekh Erez Rab. xi.; and cf. Maimonides, Hilkhoth Teshubah, 3:6, vii. 4; Tosephta Peah 1:1; and Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) xl. p. 60b.</i> as it is said, "Whoso privily slandereth his neighbour,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> him will I destroy: him that hath an high look and a proud heart will I not suffer" (Ps. 101:5). Another Scripture text says, "Cursed be he that smiteth his neighbour in secret" (Deut. 27:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 37a. The quotation from Deuteronomy is interpreted as though it meant that one must not slander.</i> Know that it is so. Come and see from the (narrative of) the serpent which uttered slander concerning the Holy One, blessed be He, to Adam and his helpmate.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 94; and cf. Gen. Rab. 19:4.</i> The Holy One, blessed be He, cursed it, so that its food became the dust, as it is said, "And dust shalt thou eat all the days of thy life" (Gen. 3:14).
Rabban Gamaliel said: Israel also slandered<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jalḳuṭ, Lev. § 524.</i> the Holy One, blessed be He, (by) saying: Wilt thou say that He has power<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Has the Lord power.”</i> to feed us in the wilderness? as it is said, "Yea, they spake against God; they said, Can God prepare a table in the wilderness? Behold, he smote the rock,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> that waters gushed out, and streams overflowed" (Ps. 78:19, 20). The Holy One, blessed be He, heard<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “saw.”</i> that they slandered His Glory, || and from His Glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Jalḳuṭ, <i>loc. cit</i>., reads: “And He sent against them from His Glory, which is a fire that consumes fire, a fire to devour them.” This is the correct text according to Luria. See also T.B. Joma, 21b.</i> which is a consuming fire, He sent against them a fire which consumed them round about, as it is said, "And the people were as murmurers<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Thus far the quotation in the MS.; in the first editions the latter part only of the quotation beginning with “and the fire” is given.</i>… and the fire of the Lord burnt among them, and devoured in the uttermost part of the camp" (Num. 11:1). The Israelites betook themselves to our teacher Moses, and they said to him: Moses, our lord!<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Moses, our Rabbi! Give us like sheep.”</i> Let these be given like sheep to the slaughter,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 357.</i> but not to the fire which is consuming fire. Moses saw the plight of Israel, and he arose to pray on their behalf,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 85.</i> and He was entreated of him, as it is said, "And the people cried unto Moses" (<i>ibid.</i> 2).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions cite the next verse: “And Moses prayed unto the Lord, and the fire abated.”</i>
Rabbi Judah<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Jehudah.”</i> said: That fire which descended from heaven settled on the earth, and did not again return to its (former) place in heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> See Siphrê, Num. § 86, and Tanna de bê Elijahu Rab. 1 p. 6.</i> but it entered the Tabernacle. That fire came forth and devoured all the offerings which they<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “Israel.”</i> brought in the wilderness,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Ẓebachim, 61b; Siphra, pp. 44b f.; Lev. Rab. 7:5. The fire was kindled for 116 years—39 years in the wilderness, 24 years in Gilgal, and 53 years in Nob and Gibeon; see, however, Luria’s note, <i>in loc</i>.</i> as it is said.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “‘And there came forth fire from before the Lord’” (Lev. 9:24).</i> "And there descended fire from heaven" is not written here, but "And there came forth fire from before the Lord" (Lev. 9:24).<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 87b. It was on the 1st of Nisan that the fire descended upon the altar. The people revolted at the end of Iyar; see T.B. Ta‘anith, 29a; Jalḳuṭ, Num. § 732 and § 752, and Deut. § 813: “That fire came down and devoured the (two) sons of Aaron, as it is said, ‘And fire came forth from the Lord’ (Num. 16:35); and that fire also consumed the company of Korah.”</i> This was the fire which came forth and consumed the sons of Aaron,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “That was the fire which consumed the company of Korah,” and omit the reference to Nadab and Abihu, the sons of Aaron.</i> as it is said, "And there came forth fire from before the Lord" (<i>ibid.</i>). That fire came forth and consumed the company of Korah, as it is said, "And fire came forth from the Lord" (Num. 16:85).
No man departs from this world until some of that fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The inference is probably based on Deut. 18:16: “Neither let me see this great fire any more, that I die not.” At the hour of death the fire, which symbolizes the Shekhinah, is seen. For man cannot see God and live, but he beholds the Vision Divine when he ceases to live. See <i>supra</i>, p. 254, and cf. Siphra, p. 4a.</i> which rested among the sons of man,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “which rested upon the earth.”</i> passes over him, as it is said, "And the fire rested" (<i>ibid.</i> xi. 2). ||
"And Miriam and Aaron spake against Moses<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> because of the Cushite woman whom he had married" (<i>ibid.</i> xii. 1). Was she then a Cushite woman?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Mo’ed Ḳaṭan, 16b; Siphrê, Num. § 99; Shocher Ṭob, Ps. 7 p. 35b; and see Siphrê, Ẓuṭṭa, p. 33, in the last instalment in <i>Monatsschrift</i>, vol. 54.</i> Was she not Zipporah? But just as this Cushite<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Or “Ethiopian.”</i> is different as regards his body from all other people,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “is different in his skin.”</i> so was Zipporah different from all other women by her words<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “by her good deeds.”</i> and by her good deeds; therefore was she called a Cushite, as it is said, "For he had married a Cushite woman" (<i>ibid.</i>).
Rabbi Tachanah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The later editions read: “Tanchum.”</i> said: The Israelites also are called Cushites, as it is said, "Are ye not as the children of the Cushites unto me,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> O children of Israel?"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> For a Christian Midrashic parallel see “The Arabic Gospel of the Saviour’s Infancy,” 40 (in <i>A.N.C.L</i>. xvi. p. 119).</i> (Amos 9:7). Just as the body of this Cushite is different from all creatures, so do the Israelites differ from all the nations of the world in their ways and by their good deeds; therefore are they called Cushites. One Scripture saith, "And Ebedmelech, the Cushite, said" (Jer. 38:12). Was it Ebed?<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See Pesiḳta Rab. p. 130b; Jalḳuṭ, Jeremiah, § 326, where the title of Cushite is given to Ebed; see also T.B. Mo‘ed Ḳaṭan, <i>loc. cit</i>., and Targum on Jer. 38:7, where the title is referred to the king Zedekiah.
