The first editions read: “Was Ebed a Cushite?”</i> Was he not Baruch, son of Neriah?<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See Jer. 39:15 and xlv. 1.</i> But just as this Cushite is different in his body from all other people, so was Baruch, son of Neriah, different in his deeds and good ways from the rest of the sons of men.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The words following till “Then” do not occur in the first editions.</i> Therefore was he called a Cushite.
One Scripture text says, "Then said Joab to the Cushite, Go, tell the king<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS. and in the first editions.</i> what thou hast seen" (2 Sam. 18:21). Was he a Cushite? Was he not a Benjamite?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See Ps. 7:1: “Cush a Benjamite.”</i> But just as this Cushite is different from all creatures, so was the Benjamite || different by his ways and his good deeds;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “from all Israel.”</i> therefore was his name called "Cushite."
Rabbi Eliezer said: Come and see the integrity and perfection of that man, for he said to Joab, Even if thou wouldst give me gold and silver<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “a thousand pieces of silver.”</i> I would not transgress the king's commands which he commanded thee, as it is said, "And the man said unto Joab,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; the first editions begin with the next word. The text of the quotation in the M.T. differs from that cited in the first editions.</i> Though I should receive a thousand (pieces of) silver in mine hand" (<i>ibid.</i> 12). Joab said to him: I beseech thee, show me the place where Absalom is hanging. But he did not consent. Joab began to bend the knee, and to prostrate himself before him, as it is said, "Then said Joab, Shall I not entreat<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> R.V. renders: “I may not tarry thus with thee.”</i> thee in this wise?" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). Then he took (Joab) by his arm, and showed him the place where Absalom was hanging.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> See Mishnah Soṭah, 9b.</i> Everyone who transgresses the commandment "Honour thy father"<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “Honour”; this is the Fifth Commandment. The first editions omit this sentence.</i> is accounted as though he had transgressed the Decalogue. Therefore was (Absalom) pierced by ten spears, as it is said, "And ten young men that bare Joab's armour compassed about<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; the text of the verse in the first editions differs from the M.T.</i> and smote Absalom; and slew him" (<i>ibid.</i> 15).
Six people were similar to the first man,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Soṭah, 10a; five people were created with some likeness to the nature of the heavenly bodies. Because before his sin Adam was a perfect image of the heavenly bodies. In the legend of the Talmud, the third and fourth instances enumerated by our Midrash are omitted, and instead Asa of fleet foot is mentioned.</i> and they were all slain. They were: Samson with his<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. the might of Adam at his creation.</i> might, and he was slain;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in his might.”</i> Saul with his stature, and he was slain;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in his stature.”</i> Asahel with his swiftness, and he was slain;<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “in his swiftness.”</i> Josiah with his nostrils,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The inference is probably based on Lam. 4:20: “The breath of our <i>nostrils</i>, the anointed of the Lord”; cf. T.B. Ta’anith, 22b, and T.B. Synhedrin, 93b.</i> and he was slain through his nostrils; Zedekiah with his eyes, and he was slain through his eyes;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> The Babylonians put out his eyes; see 2 Kings 25:7.</i> Absalom with his hair, and he was killed through his hair. Absalom was a mighty hero in battle, and his sword was bound upon his loins.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. 2 Sam. 20:8, and T.B. Soṭah, 9b.</i> Why || did he not draw his sword and cut the hair of his head, and get down? But he saw that Gehinnom was open beneath him, and he said: It is better for me to hang by my hair<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “by the hair of my head.”</i> and not to descend into the fire; therefore he was hanging,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “in an oak,” and omit the quotation.</i> as it is said, "Behold, I saw Absalom<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our text.</i> hanging in an oak" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).
Rabbi José said: There are seven doors to Gehinnom. Absalom entered as far as the fifth door,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “of Gehinnom.” Cf. 4 Ezra 7:80–87.</i> and David heard (thereof), and began to weep, to lament, and to mourn, and he called<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “for Absalom five times, ‘My son,’ ‘My son,’ as it is said.”</i> Absalom! My son! five times,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> At five doors of Gehenna; cf. T.B. Soṭah, <i>loc. cit.</i>, and T.B. Synhedrin, 102b.</i> My son, my son, my son! "And the king was much moved, and he went up to the chamber over the gate,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. adds “etc.,” indicating that this is a quotation; the first word differs from the M.T. and the text in the first editions, which continue the quotation from the words, “O my son.”</i> and wept: and as he went, thus he said, O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! would God I had died for thee, O Absalom, my son, my son!" (<i>ibid.</i> xviii. 33). And they<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The words of David; by his intercession and merit Absalom was saved from Gehenna. The first editions read: “And <i>he</i> brought him back.”</i> brought him back from the five doors of Gehinnom, and he began to praise and laud and to glorify his Creator, saying: "Shew me a token for good;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here; it is continued in the first editions.</i> that they which hate me may see it, and be ashamed: because thou, Lord, hast helped me, and comforted me" (Ps. 86:17). "Thou hast helped me" out of the war of Absalom, and "thou hast comforted me" in my mourning for him.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. continues the chapter with the material of the fifty-fourth chapter in the printed editions.</i>

Chapter 54

The eighth descent<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 97, and Introduction, p. xv.</i> was when He<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “The Holy One, blessed be He.”</i> descended into the Tabernacle, as it is said, "And the Lord came down in a pillar of cloud,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> and stood at the door of the Tent, and called Aaron and Miriam;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> According to the Biblical record the eighth descent was at the appointment of the seventy elders; so that the descent in our chapter is really the ninth.</i> and they both came forth" (Num. 12:5). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them:<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “to him,” <i>i.e</i>. Aaron.</i> Whosoever speaketh slander against his fellow in secret, hath no cure; if he slander his brother, the son of his father or the son of his mother,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Ps. 1. 20: “Thou sittest and speakest against thy brother; thou slanderest thine own mother’s son.” See also Siphrê, Num. §§25 and 99; Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) ix. pp. 20b f., note 35; and cf. Deut. Rab. vi. 8 ff. The first editions read: “the son of his father and mother.”</i> how much more so<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>i.e</i>. is the punishment an incurable disease?</i> is this the case? The Holy One, blessed be He, was angry with them, and He departed from the Tent, as it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “as it is written”; this is unusual in our book.</i> "And the anger of the Lord was kindled against them; and he departed" (<i>ibid.</i> 9). || "And the cloud removed from over the Tent" (<i>ibid.</i> 10).<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> This quotation occurs only in the MS.</i> Forthwith Miriam became leprous. The Holy One, blessed be He, said: If Aaron also be leprous,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Sabbath, 97a.</i> the High Priest, who is afflicted with a blemish, will not be able to bring an offering upon My altar;<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Tosaphoth to Ẓebachim, 102a; Mo’ed Ḳaṭan, 8a; and Bechoroth, 45b.</i> but he shall look upon his sister and become astonished,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions read: “and become distressed.” See Siphrê, Num. § 105: “As long as he beheld her (the leprosy) was spreading over her”; see also Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>a</i>) ix. p. 21a.</i> as it is said, "And Aaron looked upon Miriam, and, behold, she was leprous" (<i>ibid.</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> In the Fragments from the lost writings of Irenæus (xxxii.) we find a parallel Midrash to our author; see “Ante-Nicene Christian Library,” vol. ix. p. 173.</i> Aaron went to Moses, and said to him: O our lord, Moses! Brethren do not suffer themselves to be separated one from the other except through death, as it is said, "Though he be fruitful among his brethren"<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The text in Hosea reads: “he be fruitful,” but the first editions read: “he be separated”; this is probably to be interpreted as an instance of “Do not read”… “but read …”</i> (Hos. 13:15). Our sister, while still among the living, is separated from us,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The first editions add: “by death,” and omit the quotation.</i> as it is said, "Let her not, I pray, be as one dead" (Num. 12:12). Not only this, but now all Israel will hear and say that the sister of Moses and Aaron is leprous. Half of this infamous report concerns thee.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> This sentence occurs in our MS. only.</i> Moses was appeased by the words, and he arose and prayed for her,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Prague edition reads: “he prayed for them.”</i> and He was entreated of him, as it is said, "And Moses cried unto the Lord, saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in our MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> Heal her, O God, I beseech thee" (<i>ibid.</i> 13).
Rabbi Levitas, a man of Jamnia, said: Unless the father<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads: “mother,” but as the verb belonging to this word is masculine, it is an error due to the scribe’s carelessness, and we should read “father,” as in the first editions.</i> of a leprous person spit<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> The reading agrees with the Venice edition. Cf. Lev. 15:8; and Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>.</i> in his face, he will not be healed,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> See Aboth de R. Nathan, <i>loc. cit</i>.: “Moses drew a small circle about him, and said: I will not move until Thou hast healed Miriam my sister.” The New Testament affords a parallel to the practice of healing by spitting; see Mark vii. 33, where it is said that Jesus cured a man who was deaf and who had an impediment in his speech: “And he took him aside from the multitude privately, and put his fingers into his ears, and he spat, and touched his tongue.” See also Mark viii. 23: “When he had spit on his eyes.” See Preuss, <i>Medizin des Talmuds: Speichel als Heil-Mittel</i>, pp. 321 f.</i> as it is said, "And the Lord said unto Moses, If her father had but spit in her face,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> would she not be ashamed seven days?" (<i>ibid.</i> 14). Hence (the sages) say: A male afflicted with unclean issue (needs) seven (days for his purification<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Or, “cleansing.”</i>); a woman with an issue (requires) seven (days' separation); a menstruant (needs) seven (days of purification);<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> This and the next instance are omitted in the first editions. On the subject see Aboth de R. Nathan (<i>b</i>) i. p. 1b.</i> one made unclean through a corpse<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Num. 19:11. On mourning customs see <i>supra</i>, p. 115.</i> (needs) seven (days of purification); a mourner (mourns for) seven (days); the wedding feast (lasts) seven (days);<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> This clause occurs in the MS. only; the reference is to the marriage banquet, see <i>supra</i>, p. 112.</i> and a leprous person (requires) seven (days' separation). (Whence do we know that<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This is wanting in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i>) a male with an unclean issue (requires) seven days (for his purification)? || (Because it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> This is wanting in the MS.; it occurs in the first editions.</i>) "And when he that hath an issue is cleansed<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> of his issue, then he shall number to himself seven days for his cleansing" (Lev. 15:13). Whence do we know that a woman with an issue (requires) seven (days of purification)? Because it is said, "But if she be cleansed of her issue,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.; it is continued in the first editions.</i> then she shall number to herself seven days, and after that she shall be clean" (<i>ibid.</i> 28).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In the printed editions there is a lacuna here. The MS. has probably some of the missing text. The Tanna de bê Elijahu Ẓuṭṭa has also part of the lost chapters of the <i>P.R.E.</i>, according to Friedmann.</i> Whence do we know that a menstruant (requires) seven (days of separation)? Because it is said, "She shall be in her separation seven days" (<i>ibid.</i> 19). "Her separation"<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The MS. reads the exact letters of the word in Lev. 15:19 (“B’niddathah”), which is translated by the R.V. “in her separation,” or “impurity.” The fact that the same letters are repeated as the word which has to be read suggests either that this word with the same letters was read differently to the M.T., or that some other form of the word, such as the same word less the first letter (“Niddathah”), <i>i.e</i>. “Her separation,” as we have assumed in our version, was before the copyist. The Midrashim on this theme are to be found in Horowitz’ edition of the Baraitha dealing with Niddah, of which there are several recensions.</i> (or impurity) thou dost not read, but "<i>in</i> her impurity"; because Rabbi Ẓe'era said: The daughters of Israel have made the Law exceptionally stringent for themselves, so that if they see a blood stain of the size of a mustard seed<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Berakhoth, 31a; and cf. T.J. Berakhoth, 5:1. 8d.</i> they observe on its account seven days, after that they are cleansed<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Lit. “clean.”</i> (of their issue of blood<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> See Lev. 15:19.</i>). Whence do we know that one made unclean through a corpse (needs) seven (days of purification)? Because it is said, "And whosoever in the open field toucheth one<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> that is slain with a sword, or a dead body… shall be unclean seven days" (Num. 19:16). Whence do we know that the mourner (mourns for) seven (days)? Because it is said, "And he made a mourning for his father seven days" (Gen. 50.10). Whence<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The rest of the paragraph is wanting in the text of this last chapter of <i>P.R.E</i>. published by Wertheimer in <i>Bottê Midrashoth</i>, iii. pp. 29–34.</i> do we know that the (bridal) banquet (lasts) seven days? Because it is said, "Fulfil the week of this one…. And Jacob did so, and fulfilled<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> her week" (<i>ibid.</i> xxix. 27, 28). Whence do we know that a leper (keeps) seven (days of purification)? From Miriam, as it is said, "And Miriam was shut up<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> without the camp seven days" (Num. 12:15).
Rabbi said: They<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> The Israelites.</i> slandered God again and said, We were dwelling in the land of Egypt in ease and contentment, but the Holy One, blessed be He, and Moses have brought us forth from Egypt to die in the wilderness, as it is said, "And the people spake against God, and against Moses, Wherefore have ye brought us up<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> out of Egypt to die in the wilderness?" (<i>ibid.</i> xxi. 5). What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do unto them? He sent against them fiery serpents which bit and killed them, as it is said, "And the Lord sent among the people fiery serpents,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> and they bit the people; and much people of Israel died" (<i>ibid.</i> 6). Moses beheld the misfortune of Israel, and he arose and prayed on their behalf. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: Moses! Make thee a serpent of copper like that serpent<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See <i>supra</i>, p. 428, and cf. Tanchuma (ed. Buber), Num. p. 63 f.</i> || which spoke slander betwixt Adam and his helpmate, and place it on a high place. Let every man who has been bitten direct his heart to his Father<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> See T.B. Rosh Ha-Shanah, 29a, and Wisdom, xvi. 7.</i> who is in heaven, and let him gaze at that serpent, and he will be healed. Moses made a serpent of copper and set it up in a high place, and every man who had been bitten turned his heart to his Father who is in heaven, and gazed at that serpent, forthwith he became restored to health, as it is said, "And it came to pass, that if a serpent had bitten<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotation ends here in the MS.</i> any man, when he looked at the serpent of copper, he lived" (<i>ibid.</i> 9); and it also says, "If the serpent bite without enchantment, then is there no advantage in the master of the tongue" (Eccles. 10:11).<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The expression, “the master of the tongue,” seems to point to the slanderer, whose condemnation forms the theme of our chapter. See Bacher, P. i. 402 and 485, for Midrashic interpretations of this verse.</i>
Rabbi Meir said: If a doctor visit one whom a serpent has bitten, and cure him, verily will goodness be shown to this one.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> The doctor.</i>
Rabbi José said: If a man hire a workman who is zealous, and (when) he discharges him should he give him his wages in full; what favour does he give him?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The labourer who has fully earned his wages. Cf. Matt. xx. 1–16.</i> But if he hire a workman who is lazy, (when) he discharges him should he give him his wages in full, verily he is giving him a real favour.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> For the lazy workman has not earned his wages, and therefore is receiving more than his due.</i> Likewise spake Solomon before the Holy One, blessed be He<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Wertheimer’s text omits the following two sentences.</i>: Sovereign of all the worlds! Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob were zealous workmen. Thou gavest to them wages in full, of their own (earnings) Thou didst give them. But we are lazy workmen, and when Thou wilt give us our wages in full, and wilt heal us; verily, every one will praise Thee and bless (Thee).<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> In acknowledging that all we receive is due to the boundless love and grace of our Heavenly Father. See T.B. Baba Mezi’a, 86b.<br>Immediately following the <i>P.R.E</i>. in the MS. comes the well-known Aboth de R. Nathan, the text of which corresponds to the Recension “A” in Dr. Schechter’s edition. In a future work, I hope to translate the chapters claimed to belong to <i>P.R.E</i>., and published by Horowitz, and later by Friedmann in his edition of the Tanna de bê Elijahu.<br>I have a very humble favour to ask at the hands of my readers. Will they kindly let me know whether they can suggest any variations in my translation and offer any parallels from Jewish and Christian and Mohammedan, as well as from classical literature, in illustration of the various points arising out of this Midrash? I am painfully aware that this work is in a very crude condition, and that there are many errors, but in spite of all its blemishes I sincerely hope that something of value may be found in this volume, which has cost the author very many hours of toil snatched away from leisure and holiday.</i>
It is finished. Praise be to Go
